text: INTRODUCTION
title: Elementary Forms

text: SUBJECT OF OUR STUDY: RELIGIOUS SOCIOLOGY AND THE THEORY OF KNOWLEDGE
title: Elementary Forms

text: In this book we propose to study the most primitive and simple religion
title: Elementary Forms

text: which is actually known, to make an analysis of it, and to attempt an
title: Elementary Forms

text: explanation of it. A religious system may be said to be the most
title: Elementary Forms

text: primitive which we can observe when it fulfils the two following
title: Elementary Forms

text: conditions: in the first place, when it is found in a society whose
title: Elementary Forms

text: organization is surpassed by no others in simplicity;[1] and secondly,
title: Elementary Forms

text: when it is possible to explain it without making use of any element
title: Elementary Forms

text: borrowed from a previous religion.
title: Elementary Forms

text: We shall set ourselves to describe the organization of this system with
title: Elementary Forms

text: all the exactness and fidelity that an ethnographer or an historian
title: Elementary Forms

text: could give it. But our task will not be limited to that: sociology
title: Elementary Forms

text: raises other problems than history or ethnography. It does not seek to
title: Elementary Forms

text: know the passed forms of civilization with the sole end of knowing them
title: Elementary Forms

text: and reconstructing them. But rather, like every positive science, it has
title: Elementary Forms

text: as its object the explanation of some actual reality which is near to
title: Elementary Forms

text: us, and which consequently is capable of affecting our ideas and our
title: Elementary Forms

text: acts: this reality is man, and more precisely, the man of to-day, for
title: Elementary Forms

text: there is nothing which we are more interested in knowing. Then we are
title: Elementary Forms

text: not going to study a very archaic religion simply for the pleasure of
title: Elementary Forms

text: telling its peculiarities and its singularities. If we have taken it as
title: Elementary Forms

text: the subject of our research, it is because it has seemed to us better
title: Elementary Forms

text: adapted than any other to lead to an understanding of the religious
title: Elementary Forms

text: nature of man, that is to say, to show us an essential and permanent
title: Elementary Forms

text: aspect of humanity.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But this proposition is not accepted before the raising of strong
title: Elementary Forms

text: objections. It seems very strange that one must turn back, and be
title: Elementary Forms

text: transported to the very beginnings of history, in order to arrive at an
title: Elementary Forms

text: understanding of humanity as it is at present. This manner of procedure
title: Elementary Forms

text: seems particularly paradoxical in the question which concerns us. In
title: Elementary Forms

text: fact, the various religions generally pass as being quite unequal in
title: Elementary Forms

text: value and dignity; it is said that they do not all contain the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: quota of truth. Then it seems as though one could not compare the
title: Elementary Forms

text: highest forms of religious thought with the lowest, without reducing the
title: Elementary Forms

text: first to the level of the second. If we admit that the crude cults of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the Australian tribes can help us to understand Christianity, for
title: Elementary Forms

text: example, is that not supposing that this latter religion proceeds from
title: Elementary Forms

text: the same mentality as the former, that it is made up of the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: superstitions and rests upon the same errors? This is how the
title: Elementary Forms

text: theoretical importance which has sometimes been attributed to primitive
title: Elementary Forms

text: religions has come to pass as a sign of a systematic hostility to all
title: Elementary Forms

text: religion, which, by prejudging the results of the study, vitiates them
title: Elementary Forms

text: in advance.
title: Elementary Forms

text: There is no occasion for asking here whether or not there are scholars
title: Elementary Forms

text: who have merited this reproach, and who have made religious history and
title: Elementary Forms

text: ethnology a weapon against religion. In any case, a sociologist cannot
title: Elementary Forms

text: hold such a point of view. In fact, it is an essential postulate of
title: Elementary Forms

text: sociology that a human institution cannot rest upon an error and a lie,
title: Elementary Forms

text: without which it could not exist. If it were not founded in the nature
title: Elementary Forms

text: of things, it would have encountered in the facts a resistance over
title: Elementary Forms

text: which it could never have triumphed. So when we commence the study of
title: Elementary Forms

text: primitive religions, it is with the assurance that they hold to reality
title: Elementary Forms

text: and express it; this principle will be seen to re-enter again and again
title: Elementary Forms

text: in the course of the analyses and discussions which follow, and the
title: Elementary Forms

text: reproach which we make against the schools from which we have separated
title: Elementary Forms

text: ourselves is that they have ignored it. When only the letter of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: formulae is considered, these religious beliefs and practices undoubtedly
title: Elementary Forms

text: seem disconcerting at times, and one is tempted to attribute them to
title: Elementary Forms

text: some sort of a deep-rooted error. But one must know how to go underneath
title: Elementary Forms

text: the symbol to the reality which it represents and which gives it its
title: Elementary Forms

text: meaning. The most barbarous and the most fantastic rites and the
title: Elementary Forms

text: strangest myths translate some human need, some aspect of life, either
title: Elementary Forms

text: individual or social. The reasons with which the faithful justify them
title: Elementary Forms

text: may be, and generally are, erroneous; but the true reasons do not cease
title: Elementary Forms

text: to exist, and it is the duty of science to discover them.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In reality, then, there are no religions which are false. All are true
title: Elementary Forms

text: in their own fashion; all answer, though in different ways, to the given
title: Elementary Forms

text: conditions of human existence. It is undeniably possible to arrange them
title: Elementary Forms

text: in a hierarchy. Some can be called superior to others, in the sense that
title: Elementary Forms

text: they call into play higher mental functions, that they are richer in
title: Elementary Forms

text: ideas and sentiments, that they contain more concepts with fewer
title: Elementary Forms

text: sensations and images, and that their arrangement is wiser. But
title: Elementary Forms

text: howsoever real this greater complexity and this higher ideality may be,
title: Elementary Forms

text: they are not sufficient to place the corresponding religions in
title: Elementary Forms

text: different classes. All are religions equally, just as all living beings
title: Elementary Forms

text: are equally alive, from the most humble plastids up to man. So when we
title: Elementary Forms

text: turn to primitive religions it is not with the idea of depreciating
title: Elementary Forms

text: religion in general, for these religions are no less respectable than
title: Elementary Forms

text: the others. They respond to the same needs, they play the same role,
title: Elementary Forms

text: they depend upon the same causes; they can also well serve to show the
title: Elementary Forms

text: nature of the religious life, and consequently to resolve the problem
title: Elementary Forms

text: which we wish to study.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But why give them a sort of prerogative? Why choose them in preference
title: Elementary Forms

text: to all others as the subject of our study?--It is merely for reasons of
title: Elementary Forms

text: method.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In the first place, we cannot arrive at an understanding of the most
title: Elementary Forms

text: recent religions except by following the manner in which they have been
title: Elementary Forms

text: progressively composed in history. In fact, historical analysis is the
title: Elementary Forms

text: only means of explanation which it is possible to apply to them. It
title: Elementary Forms

text: alone enables us to resolve an institution into its constituent
title: Elementary Forms

text: elements, for it shows them to us as they are born in time, one after
title: Elementary Forms

text: another. On the other hand, by placing every one of them in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: condition where it was born, it puts into our hands the only means we
title: Elementary Forms

text: have of determining the causes which gave rise to it. Every time that we
title: Elementary Forms

text: undertake to explain something human, taken at a given moment in
title: Elementary Forms

text: history--be it a religious belief, a moral precept, a legal principle,
title: Elementary Forms

text: an aesthetic style or an economic system--it is necessary to commence by
title: Elementary Forms

text: going back to its most primitive and simple form, to try to account for
title: Elementary Forms

text: the characteristics by which it was marked at that time, and then to
title: Elementary Forms

text: show how it developed and became complicated little by little, and how
title: Elementary Forms

text: it became that which it is at the moment in question. One readily
title: Elementary Forms

text: understands the importance which the determination of the point of
title: Elementary Forms

text: departure has for this series of progressive explanations, for all the
title: Elementary Forms

text: others are attached to it. It was one of Descartes's principles that
title: Elementary Forms

text: the first ring has a predominating place in the chain of scientific
title: Elementary Forms

text: truths. But there is no question of placing at the foundation of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: science of religions an idea elaborated after the cartesian manner, that
title: Elementary Forms

text: is to say, a logical concept, a pure possibility, constructed simply by
title: Elementary Forms

text: force of thought. What we must find is a concrete reality, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: historical and ethnological observation alone can reveal that to us. But
title: Elementary Forms

text: even if this cardinal conception is obtained by a different process than
title: Elementary Forms

text: that of Descartes, it remains true that it is destined to have a
title: Elementary Forms

text: considerable influence on the whole series of propositions which the
title: Elementary Forms

text: science establishes. Biological evolution has been conceived quite
title: Elementary Forms

text: differently ever since it has been known that monocellular beings do
title: Elementary Forms

text: exist. In the same way, the arrangement of religious facts is explained
title: Elementary Forms

text: quite differently, according as we put naturism, animism or some other
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious form at the beginning of the evolution. Even the most
title: Elementary Forms

text: specialized scholars, if they are unwilling to confine themselves to a
title: Elementary Forms

text: task of pure erudition, and if they desire to interpret the facts which
title: Elementary Forms

text: they analyse, are obliged to choose one of these hypotheses, and make it
title: Elementary Forms

text: their starting-point. Whether they desire it or not, the questions which
title: Elementary Forms

text: they raise necessarily take the following form: how has naturism or
title: Elementary Forms

text: animism been led to take this particular form, here or there, or to
title: Elementary Forms

text: enrich itself or impoverish itself in such and such a fashion? Since it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is impossible to avoid taking sides on this initial problem, and since
title: Elementary Forms

text: the solution given is destined to affect the whole science, it must be
title: Elementary Forms

text: attacked at the outset: that is what we propose to do.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Besides this, outside of these indirect reactions, the study of
title: Elementary Forms

text: primitive religions has of itself an immediate interest which is of
title: Elementary Forms

text: primary importance.
title: Elementary Forms

text: If it is useful to know what a certain particular religion consists in,
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is still more important to know what religion in general is. This is
title: Elementary Forms

text: the problem which has aroused the interest of philosophers in all times;
title: Elementary Forms

text: and not without reason, for it is of interest to all humanity.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Unfortunately, the method which they generally employ is purely
title: Elementary Forms

text: dialectic: they confine themselves to analysing the idea which they make
title: Elementary Forms

text: for themselves of religion, except as they illustrate the results of
title: Elementary Forms

text: this mental analysis by examples borrowed from the religions which best
title: Elementary Forms

text: realize their ideal. But even if this method ought to be abandoned, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: problem remains intact, and the great service of philosophy is to have
title: Elementary Forms

text: prevented its being suppressed by the disdain of scholars. Now it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: possible to attack it in a different way. Since all religions can be
title: Elementary Forms

text: compared to each other, and since all are species of the same class,
title: Elementary Forms

text: there are necessarily many elements which are common to all. We do not
title: Elementary Forms

text: mean to speak simply of the outward and visible characteristics which
title: Elementary Forms

text: they all have equally, and which make it possible to give them a
title: Elementary Forms

text: provisional definition from the very outset of our researches; the
title: Elementary Forms

text: discovery of these apparent signs is relatively easy, for the
title: Elementary Forms

text: observation which it demands does not go beneath the surface of things.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But these external resemblances suppose others which are profound. At
title: Elementary Forms

text: the foundation of all systems of beliefs and of all cults there ought
title: Elementary Forms

text: necessarily to be a certain number of fundamental representations or
title: Elementary Forms

text: conceptions and of ritual attitudes which, in spite of the diversity of
title: Elementary Forms

text: forms which they have taken, have the same objective significance and
title: Elementary Forms

text: fulfil the same functions everywhere. These are the permanent elements
title: Elementary Forms

text: which constitute that which is permanent and human in religion; they
title: Elementary Forms

text: form all the objective contents of the idea which is expressed when one
title: Elementary Forms

text: speaks of _religion_ in general. How is it possible to pick them out?
title: Elementary Forms

text: Surely it is not by observing the complex religions which appear in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: course of history. Every one of these is made up of such a variety of
title: Elementary Forms

text: elements that it is very difficult to distinguish what is secondary from
title: Elementary Forms

text: what is principal, the essential from the accessory. Suppose that the
title: Elementary Forms

text: religion considered is like that of Egypt, India or the classical
title: Elementary Forms

text: antiquity. It is a confused mass of many cults, varying according to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: locality, the temples, the generations, the dynasties, the invasions,
title: Elementary Forms

text: etc. Popular superstitions are there confused with the purest dogmas.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Neither the thought nor the activity of the religion is evenly
title: Elementary Forms

text: distributed among the believers; according to the men, the environment
title: Elementary Forms

text: and the circumstances, the beliefs as well as the rites are thought of
title: Elementary Forms

text: in different ways. Here they are priests, there they are monks,
title: Elementary Forms

text: elsewhere they are laymen; there are mystics and rationalists,
title: Elementary Forms

text: theologians and prophets, etc. In these conditions it is difficult to
title: Elementary Forms

text: see what is common to all. In one or another of these systems it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: quite possible to find the means of making a profitable study of some
title: Elementary Forms

text: particular fact which is specially developed there, such as sacrifice or
title: Elementary Forms

text: prophecy, monasticism or the mysteries; but how is it possible to find
title: Elementary Forms

text: the common foundation of the religious life underneath the luxuriant
title: Elementary Forms

text: vegetation which covers it? How is it possible to find, underneath the
title: Elementary Forms

text: disputes of theology, the variations of ritual, the multiplicity of
title: Elementary Forms

text: groups and the diversity of individuals, the fundamental states
title: Elementary Forms

text: characteristic of religious mentality in general?
title: Elementary Forms

text: Things are quite different in the lower societies. The slighter
title: Elementary Forms

text: development of individuality, the small extension of the group, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: homogeneity of external circumstances, all contribute to reducing the
title: Elementary Forms

text: differences and variations to a minimum. The group has an intellectual
title: Elementary Forms

text: and moral conformity of which we find but rare examples in the more
title: Elementary Forms

text: advanced societies. Everything is common to all. Movements are
title: Elementary Forms

text: stereotyped; everybody performs the same ones in the same circumstances,
title: Elementary Forms

text: and this conformity of conduct only translates the conformity of
title: Elementary Forms

text: thought. Every mind being drawn into the same eddy, the individual type
title: Elementary Forms

text: nearly confounds itself with that of the race. And while all is uniform,
title: Elementary Forms

text: all is simple as well. Nothing is deformed like these myths, all
title: Elementary Forms

text: composed of one and the same theme which is endlessly repeated, or like
title: Elementary Forms

text: these rites made up of a small number of gestures repeated again and
title: Elementary Forms

text: again. Neither the popular imagination nor that of the priests has had
title: Elementary Forms

text: either the time or the means of refining and transforming the original
title: Elementary Forms

text: substance of the religious ideas and practices; these are shown in all
title: Elementary Forms

text: their nudity, and offer themselves to an examination, it requiring only
title: Elementary Forms

text: the slightest effort to lay them open. That which is accessory or
title: Elementary Forms

text: secondary, the development of luxury, has not yet come to hide the
title: Elementary Forms

text: principal elements.[2] All is reduced to that which is indispensable, to
title: Elementary Forms

text: that without which there could be no religion. But that which is
title: Elementary Forms

text: indispensable is also that which is essential, that is to say, that
title: Elementary Forms

text: which we must know before all else.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Primitive civilizations offer privileged cases, then, because they are
title: Elementary Forms

text: simple cases. That is why, in all fields of human activity, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: observations of ethnologists have frequently been veritable revelations,
title: Elementary Forms

text: which have renewed the study of human institutions. For example, before
title: Elementary Forms

text: the middle of the nineteenth century, everybody was convinced that the
title: Elementary Forms

text: father was the essential element of the family; no one had dreamed that
title: Elementary Forms

text: there could be a family organization of which the paternal authority was
title: Elementary Forms

text: not the keystone. But the discovery of Bachofen came and upset this old
title: Elementary Forms

text: conception. Up to very recent times it was regarded as evident that the
title: Elementary Forms

text: moral and legal relations of kindred were only another aspect of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: psychological relations which result from a common descent; Bachofen and
title: Elementary Forms

text: his successors, MacLennan, Morgan and many others still laboured under
title: Elementary Forms

text: this misunderstanding. But since we have become acquainted with the
title: Elementary Forms

text: nature of the primitive clan, we know that, on the contrary,
title: Elementary Forms

text: relationships cannot be explained by consanguinity. To return to
title: Elementary Forms

text: religions, the study of only the most familiar ones had led men to
title: Elementary Forms

text: believe for a long time that the idea of god was characteristic of
title: Elementary Forms

text: everything that is religious. Now the religion which we are going to
title: Elementary Forms

text: study presently is, in a large part, foreign to all idea of divinity;
title: Elementary Forms

text: the forces to which the rites are there addressed are very different
title: Elementary Forms

text: from those which occupy the leading place in our modern religions, yet
title: Elementary Forms

text: they aid us in understanding these latter forces. So nothing is more
title: Elementary Forms

text: unjust than the disdain with which too many historians still regard the
title: Elementary Forms

text: work of ethnographers. Indeed, it is certain that ethnology has
title: Elementary Forms

text: frequently brought about the most fruitful revolutions in the different
title: Elementary Forms

text: branches of sociology. It is for this same reason that the discovery of
title: Elementary Forms

text: unicellular beings, of which we just spoke, has transformed the current
title: Elementary Forms

text: idea of life. Since in these very simple beings, life is reduced to its
title: Elementary Forms

text: essential traits, these are less easily misunderstood.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But primitive religions do not merely aid us in disengaging the
title: Elementary Forms

text: constituent elements of religion; they also have the great advantage
title: Elementary Forms

text: that they facilitate the explanation of it. Since the facts there are
title: Elementary Forms

text: simpler, the relations between them are more apparent. The reasons with
title: Elementary Forms

text: which men account for their acts have not yet been elaborated and
title: Elementary Forms

text: denatured by studied reflection; they are nearer and more closely
title: Elementary Forms

text: related to the motives which have really determined these acts. In order
title: Elementary Forms

text: to understand an hallucination perfectly, and give it its most
title: Elementary Forms

text: appropriate treatment, a physician must know its original point of
title: Elementary Forms

text: departure. Now this event is proportionately easier to find if he can
title: Elementary Forms

text: observe it near its beginnings. The longer the disease is allowed to
title: Elementary Forms

text: develop, the more it evades observation; that is because all sorts of
title: Elementary Forms

text: interpretations have intervened as it advanced, which tend to force the
title: Elementary Forms

text: original state into the background, and across which it is frequently
title: Elementary Forms

text: difficult to find the initial one. Between a systematized hallucination
title: Elementary Forms

text: and the first impressions which gave it birth, the distance is often
title: Elementary Forms

text: considerable. It is the same thing with religious thought. In proportion
title: Elementary Forms

text: as it progresses in history, the causes which called it into existence,
title: Elementary Forms

text: though remaining active, are no longer perceived, except across a vast
title: Elementary Forms

text: scheme of interpretations which quite transform them. Popular
title: Elementary Forms

text: mythologies and subtile theologies have done their work: they have
title: Elementary Forms

text: superimposed upon the primitive sentiments others which are quite
title: Elementary Forms

text: different, and which, though holding to the first, of which they are an
title: Elementary Forms

text: elaborated form, only allow their true nature to appear very
title: Elementary Forms

text: imperfectly. The psychological gap between the cause and the effect,
title: Elementary Forms

text: between the apparent cause and the effective cause, has become more
title: Elementary Forms

text: considerable and more difficult for the mind to leap. The remainder of
title: Elementary Forms

text: this book will be an illustration and a verification of this remark on
title: Elementary Forms

text: method. It will be seen how, in the primitive religions, the religious
title: Elementary Forms

text: fact still visibly carries the mark of its origins: it would have been
title: Elementary Forms

text: well-nigh impossible to infer them merely from the study of the more
title: Elementary Forms

text: developed religions.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The study which we are undertaking is therefore a way of taking up
title: Elementary Forms

text: again, _but under new conditions_, the old problem of the origin of
title: Elementary Forms

text: religion. To be sure, if by origin we are to understand the very first
title: Elementary Forms

text: beginning, the question has nothing scientific about it, and should be
title: Elementary Forms

text: resolutely discarded. There was no given moment when religion began to
title: Elementary Forms

text: exist, and there is consequently no need of finding a means of
title: Elementary Forms

text: transporting ourselves thither in thought. Like every human institution,
title: Elementary Forms

text: religion did not commence anywhere. Therefore, all speculations of this
title: Elementary Forms

text: sort are justly discredited; they can only consist in subjective and
title: Elementary Forms

text: arbitrary constructions which are subject to no sort of control. But the
title: Elementary Forms

text: problem which we raise is quite another one. What we want to do is to
title: Elementary Forms

text: find a means of discerning the ever-present causes upon which the most
title: Elementary Forms

text: essential forms of religious thought and practice depend. Now for the
title: Elementary Forms

text: reasons which were just set forth, these causes are proportionately more
title: Elementary Forms

text: easily observable as the societies where they are observed are less
title: Elementary Forms

text: complicated. That is why we try to get as near as possible to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: origins.[3] It is not that we ascribe particular virtues to the lower
title: Elementary Forms

text: religions. On the contrary, they are rudimentary and gross; we cannot
title: Elementary Forms

text: make of them a sort of model which later religions only have to
title: Elementary Forms

text: reproduce. But even their grossness makes them instructive, for they
title: Elementary Forms

text: thus become convenient for experiments, as in them, the facts and their
title: Elementary Forms

text: relations are easily seen. In order to discover the laws of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: phenomena which he studies, the physicist tries to simplify these latter
title: Elementary Forms

text: and rid them of their secondary characteristics. For that which concerns
title: Elementary Forms

text: institutions, nature spontaneously makes the same sort of
title: Elementary Forms

text: simplifications at the beginning of history. We merely wish to put these
title: Elementary Forms

text: to profit. Undoubtedly we can only touch very elementary facts by this
title: Elementary Forms

text: method. When we shall have accounted for them as far as possible, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: novelties of every sort which have been produced in the course of
title: Elementary Forms

text: evolution will not yet be explained. But while we do not dream of
title: Elementary Forms

text: denying the importance of the problems thus raised, we think that they
title: Elementary Forms

text: will profit by being treated in their turn, and that it is important to
title: Elementary Forms

text: take them up only after those of which we are going to undertake the
title: Elementary Forms

text: study at present.
title: Elementary Forms

text: II
title: Elementary Forms

text: But our study is not of interest merely for the science of religion. In
title: Elementary Forms

text: fact, every religion has one side by which it overlaps the circle of
title: Elementary Forms

text: properly religious ideas, and there, the study of religious phenomena
title: Elementary Forms

text: gives a means of renewing the problems which, up to the present, have
title: Elementary Forms

text: only been discussed among philosophers.
title: Elementary Forms

text: For a long time it has been known that the first systems of
title: Elementary Forms

text: representations with which men have pictured to themselves the world and
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves were of religious origin. There is no religion that is not a
title: Elementary Forms

text: cosmology at the same time that it is a speculation upon divine things.
title: Elementary Forms

text: If philosophy and the sciences were born of religion, it is because
title: Elementary Forms

text: religion began by taking the place of the sciences and philosophy. But
title: Elementary Forms

text: it has been less frequently noticed that religion has not confined
title: Elementary Forms

text: itself to enriching the human intellect, formed beforehand, with a
title: Elementary Forms

text: certain number of ideas; it has contributed to forming the intellect
title: Elementary Forms

text: itself. Men owe to it not only a good part of the substance of their
title: Elementary Forms

text: knowledge, but also the form in which this knowledge has been
title: Elementary Forms

text: elaborated.
title: Elementary Forms

text: At the roots of all our judgments there are a certain number of
title: Elementary Forms

text: essential ideas which dominate all our intellectual life; they are what
title: Elementary Forms

text: philosophers since Aristotle have called the categories of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: understanding: ideas of time, space,[4] class, number, cause, substance,
title: Elementary Forms

text: personality, etc. They correspond to the most universal properties of
title: Elementary Forms

text: things. They are like the solid frame which encloses all thought; this
title: Elementary Forms

text: does not seem to be able to liberate itself from them without destroying
title: Elementary Forms

text: itself, for it seems that we cannot think of objects that are not in
title: Elementary Forms

text: time and space, which have no number, etc. Other ideas are contingent
title: Elementary Forms

text: and unsteady; we can conceive of their being unknown to a man, a society
title: Elementary Forms

text: or an epoch; but these others appear to be nearly inseparable from the
title: Elementary Forms

text: normal working of the intellect. They are like the framework of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: intelligence. Now when primitive religious beliefs are systematically
title: Elementary Forms

text: analysed, the principal categories are naturally found. They are born in
title: Elementary Forms

text: religion and of religion; they are a product of religious thought. This
title: Elementary Forms

text: is a statement that we are going to have occasion to make many times in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the course of this work.
title: Elementary Forms

text: This remark has some interest of itself already; but here is what gives
title: Elementary Forms

text: it its real importance.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The general conclusion of the book which the reader has before him is
title: Elementary Forms

text: that religion is something eminently social. Religious representations
title: Elementary Forms

text: are collective representations which express collective realities; the
title: Elementary Forms

text: rites are a manner of acting which take rise in the midst of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: assembled groups and which are destined to excite, maintain or recreate
title: Elementary Forms

text: certain mental states in these groups. So if the categories are of
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious origin, they ought to participate in this nature common to all
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious facts; they too should be social affairs and the product of
title: Elementary Forms

text: collective thought. At least--for in the actual condition of our
title: Elementary Forms

text: knowledge of these matters, one should be careful to avoid all radical
title: Elementary Forms

text: and exclusive statements--it is allowable to suppose that they are rich
title: Elementary Forms

text: in social elements.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Even at present, these can be imperfectly seen in some of them. For
title: Elementary Forms

text: example, try to represent what the notion of time would be without the
title: Elementary Forms

text: processes by which we divide it, measure it or express it with objective
title: Elementary Forms

text: signs, a time which is not a succession of years, months, weeks, days
title: Elementary Forms

text: and hours! This is something nearly unthinkable. We cannot conceive of
title: Elementary Forms

text: time, except on condition of distinguishing its different moments. Now
title: Elementary Forms

text: what is the origin of this differentiation? Undoubtedly, the states of
title: Elementary Forms

text: consciousness which we have already experienced can be reproduced in us
title: Elementary Forms

text: in the same order in which they passed in the first place; thus portions
title: Elementary Forms

text: of our past become present again, though being clearly distinguished
title: Elementary Forms

text: from the present. But howsoever important this distinction may be for
title: Elementary Forms

text: our private experience, it is far from being enough to constitute the
title: Elementary Forms

text: notion or category of time. This does not consist merely in a
title: Elementary Forms

text: commemoration, either partial or integral, of our past life. It is an
title: Elementary Forms

text: abstract and impersonal frame which surrounds, not only our individual
title: Elementary Forms

text: existence, but that of all humanity. It is like an endless chart, where
title: Elementary Forms

text: all duration is spread out before the mind, and upon which all possible
title: Elementary Forms

text: events can be located in relation to fixed and determined guide lines.
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is not _my time_ that is thus arranged; it is time in general, such
title: Elementary Forms

text: as it is objectively thought of by everybody in a single civilization.
title: Elementary Forms

text: That alone is enough to give us a hint that such an arrangement ought to
title: Elementary Forms

text: be collective. And in reality, observation proves that these
title: Elementary Forms

text: indispensable guide lines, in relation to which all things are
title: Elementary Forms

text: temporally located, are taken from social life. The divisions into days,
title: Elementary Forms

text: weeks, months, years, etc., correspond to the periodical recurrence of
title: Elementary Forms

text: rites, feasts, and public ceremonies.[5] A calendar expresses the
title: Elementary Forms

text: rhythm of the collective activities, while at the same time its function
title: Elementary Forms

text: is to assure their regularity.[6]
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is the same thing with space. As Hamelin has shown,[7] space is not
title: Elementary Forms

text: the vague and indetermined medium which Kant imagined; if purely and
title: Elementary Forms

text: absolutely homogeneous, it would be of no use, and could not be grasped
title: Elementary Forms

text: by the mind. Spatial representation consists essentially in a primary
title: Elementary Forms

text: co-ordination of the data of sensuous experience. But this co-ordination
title: Elementary Forms

text: would be impossible if the parts of space were qualitatively equivalent
title: Elementary Forms

text: and if they were really interchangeable. To dispose things spatially
title: Elementary Forms

text: there must be a possibility of placing them differently, of putting some
title: Elementary Forms

text: at the right, others at the left, these above, those below, at the north

title: Elementary Forms

text: localizing them at determined dates. That is to say that space could not
title: Elementary Forms

text: be what it is if it were not, like time, divided and differentiated. But
title: Elementary Forms

text: whence come these divisions which are so essential? By themselves, there
title: Elementary Forms

text: are neither right nor left, up nor down, north nor south, etc. All these
title: Elementary Forms

text: distinctions evidently come from the fact that different sympathetic
title: Elementary Forms

text: values have been attributed to various regions. Since all the men of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: single civilization represent space in the same way, it is clearly
title: Elementary Forms

text: necessary that these sympathetic values, and the distinctions which
title: Elementary Forms

text: depend upon them, should be equally universal, and that almost
title: Elementary Forms

text: necessarily implies that they be of social origin.[8]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Besides that, there are cases where this social character is made
title: Elementary Forms

text: manifest. There are societies in Australia and North America where space
title: Elementary Forms

text: is conceived in the form of an immense circle, because the camp has a
title: Elementary Forms

text: circular form;[9] and this spatial circle is divided up exactly like the
title: Elementary Forms

text: tribal circle, and is in its image. There are as many regions
title: Elementary Forms

text: distinguished as there are clans in the tribe, and it is the place
title: Elementary Forms

text: occupied by the clans inside the encampment which has determined the
title: Elementary Forms

text: orientation of these regions. Each region is defined by the totem of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: clan to which it is assigned. Among the Zuni, for example, the pueblo
title: Elementary Forms

text: contains seven quarters; each of these is a group of clans which has had
title: Elementary Forms

text: a unity: in all probability it was originally a single clan which was
title: Elementary Forms

text: later subdivided. Now their space also contains seven quarters, and each
title: Elementary Forms

text: of these seven quarters of the world is in intimate connection with a
title: Elementary Forms

text: quarter of the pueblo, that is to say with a group of clans.[10] "Thus,"
title: Elementary Forms

text: says Cushing, "one division is thought to be in relation with the north,
title: Elementary Forms

text: another represents the west, another the south," etc.[11] Each quarter
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the pueblo has its characteristic colour, which symbolizes it; each
title: Elementary Forms

text: region has its colour, which is exactly the same as that of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: corresponding quarter. In the course of history the number of
title: Elementary Forms

text: fundamental clans has varied; the number of the fundamental regions of
title: Elementary Forms

text: space has varied with them. Thus the social organization has been the
title: Elementary Forms

text: model for the spatial organization and a reproduction of it. It is thus
title: Elementary Forms

text: even up to the distinction between right and left which, far from being
title: Elementary Forms

text: inherent in the nature of man in general, is very probably the product
title: Elementary Forms

text: of representations which are religious and therefore collective.[12]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Analogous proofs will be found presently in regard to the ideas of
title: Elementary Forms

text: class, force, personality and efficacy. It is even possible to ask if
title: Elementary Forms

text: the idea of contradiction does not also depend upon social conditions.
title: Elementary Forms

text: What makes one tend to believe this is that the empire which the idea
title: Elementary Forms

text: has exercised over human thought has varied with times and societies.
title: Elementary Forms

text: To-day the principle of identity dominates scientific thought; but there
title: Elementary Forms

text: are vast systems of representations which have played a considerable
title: Elementary Forms

text: role in the history of ideas where it has frequently been set aside:
title: Elementary Forms

text: these are the mythologies, from the grossest up to the most
title: Elementary Forms

text: reasonable.[13] There, we are continually coming upon beings which have
title: Elementary Forms

text: the most contradictory attributes simultaneously, who are at the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: time one and many, material and spiritual, who can divide themselves up
title: Elementary Forms

text: indefinitely without losing anything of their constitution; in mythology
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is an axiom that the part is worth the whole. These variations
title: Elementary Forms

text: through which the rules which seem to govern our present logic have
title: Elementary Forms

text: passed prove that, far from being engraven through all eternity upon the
title: Elementary Forms

text: mental constitution of men, they depend, at least in part, upon factors
title: Elementary Forms

text: that are historical and consequently social. We do not know exactly what
title: Elementary Forms

text: they are, but we may presume that they exist.[14]
title: Elementary Forms

text: This hypothesis once admitted, the problem of knowledge is posed in new
title: Elementary Forms

text: terms.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Up to the present there have been only two doctrines in the field. For
title: Elementary Forms

text: some, the categories cannot be derived from experience: they are
title: Elementary Forms

text: logically prior to it and condition it. They are represented as so many
title: Elementary Forms

text: simple and irreducible data, imminent in the human mind by virtue of its
title: Elementary Forms

text: inborn constitution. For this reason they are said to be _a priori_.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Others, however, hold that they are constructed and made up of pieces
title: Elementary Forms

text: and bits, and that the individual is the artisan of this
title: Elementary Forms

text: construction.[15]
title: Elementary Forms

text: But each solution raises grave difficulties.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Is the empirical thesis the one adopted? Then it is necessary to deprive
title: Elementary Forms

text: the categories of all their characteristic properties. As a matter of
title: Elementary Forms

text: fact they are distinguished from all other knowledge by their
title: Elementary Forms

text: universality and necessity. They are the most general concepts which
title: Elementary Forms

text: exist, because they are applicable to all that is real, and since they
title: Elementary Forms

text: are not attached to any particular object they are independent of every
title: Elementary Forms

text: particular subject; they constitute the common field where all minds
title: Elementary Forms

text: meet. Further, they must meet there, for reason, which is nothing more
title: Elementary Forms

text: than all the fundamental categories taken together, is invested with an
title: Elementary Forms

text: authority which we could not set aside if we would. When we attempt to
title: Elementary Forms

text: revolt against it, and to free ourselves from some of these essential
title: Elementary Forms

text: ideas, we meet with great resistances. They do not merely depend upon
title: Elementary Forms

text: us, but they impose themselves upon us. Now empirical data present
title: Elementary Forms

text: characteristics which are diametrically opposed to these. A sensation or
title: Elementary Forms

text: an image always relies upon a determined object, or upon a collection of
title: Elementary Forms

text: objects of the same sort, and expresses the momentary condition of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: particular consciousness; it is essentially individual and subjective.
title: Elementary Forms

text: We therefore have considerable liberty in dealing with the
title: Elementary Forms

text: representations of such an origin. It is true that when our sensations
title: Elementary Forms

text: are actual, they impose themselves upon us _in fact_. But _by right_ we
title: Elementary Forms

text: are free to conceive them otherwise than they really are, or to
title: Elementary Forms

text: represent them to ourselves as occurring in a different order from that
title: Elementary Forms

text: where they are really produced. In regard to them nothing is forced upon
title: Elementary Forms

text: us except as considerations of another sort intervene. Thus we find that
title: Elementary Forms

text: we have here two sorts of knowledge, which are like the two opposite
title: Elementary Forms

text: poles of the intelligence. Under these conditions forcing reason back
title: Elementary Forms

text: upon experience causes it to disappear, for it is equivalent to reducing
title: Elementary Forms

text: the universality and necessity which characterize it to pure appearance,
title: Elementary Forms

text: to an illusion which may be useful practically, but which corresponds to
title: Elementary Forms

text: nothing in reality; consequently it is denying all objective reality to
title: Elementary Forms

text: the logical life, whose regulation and organization is the function of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the categories. Classical empiricism results in irrationalism; perhaps
title: Elementary Forms

text: it would even be fitting to designate it by this latter name.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In spite of the sense ordinarily attached to the name, the apriorists
title: Elementary Forms

text: have more respect for the facts. Since they do not admit it as a truth
title: Elementary Forms

text: established by evidence that the categories are made up of the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: elements as our sensual representations, they are not obliged to
title: Elementary Forms

text: impoverish them systematically, to draw from them all their real
title: Elementary Forms

text: content, and to reduce them to nothing more than verbal artifices. On
title: Elementary Forms

text: the contrary, they leave them all their specific characteristics. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: apriorists are the rationalists; they believe that the world has a
title: Elementary Forms

text: logical aspect which the reason expresses excellently. But for all that,
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is necessary for them to give the mind a certain power of
title: Elementary Forms

text: transcending experience and of adding to that which is given to it
title: Elementary Forms

text: directly; and of this singular power they give neither explanation nor
title: Elementary Forms

text: justification. For it is no explanation to say that it is inherent in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the nature of the human intellect. It is necessary to show whence we
title: Elementary Forms

text: hold this surprising prerogative and how it comes that we can see
title: Elementary Forms

text: certain relations in things which the examination of these things cannot
title: Elementary Forms

text: reveal to us. Saying that only on this condition is experience itself
title: Elementary Forms

text: possible changes the problem perhaps, but does not answer it. For the
title: Elementary Forms

text: real question is to know how it comes that experience is not sufficient
title: Elementary Forms

text: unto itself, but presupposes certain conditions which are exterior and
title: Elementary Forms

text: prior to it, and how it happens that these conditions are realized at
title: Elementary Forms

text: the moment and in the manner that is desirable. To answer these
title: Elementary Forms

text: questions it has sometimes been assumed that above the reason of
title: Elementary Forms

text: individuals there is a superior and perfect reason from which the others
title: Elementary Forms

text: emanate and from which they get this marvellous power of theirs, by a
title: Elementary Forms

text: sort of mystic participation: this is the divine reason. But this
title: Elementary Forms

text: hypothesis has at least the one grave disadvantage of being deprived of
title: Elementary Forms

text: all experimental control; thus it does not satisfy the conditions
title: Elementary Forms

text: demanded of a scientific hypothesis. More than that, the categories of
title: Elementary Forms

text: human thought are never fixed in any one definite form; they are made,
title: Elementary Forms

text: unmade and remade incessantly; they change with places and times. On the
title: Elementary Forms

text: other hand, the divine reason is immutable. How can this immutability
title: Elementary Forms

text: give rise to this incessant variability?
title: Elementary Forms

text: Such are the two conceptions that have been pitted against each other
title: Elementary Forms

text: for centuries; and if this debate seems to be eternal, it is because the
title: Elementary Forms

text: arguments given are really about equivalent. If reason is only a form of
title: Elementary Forms

text: individual experience, it no longer exists. On the other hand, if the
title: Elementary Forms

text: powers which it has are recognized but not accounted for, it seems to be
title: Elementary Forms

text: set outside the confines of nature and science. In the face of these two
title: Elementary Forms

text: opposed objections the mind remains uncertain. But if the social origin
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the categories is admitted, a new attitude becomes possible, which we
title: Elementary Forms

text: believe will enable us to escape both of the opposed difficulties.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The fundamental proposition of the apriorist theory is that knowledge is
title: Elementary Forms

text: made up of two sorts of elements, which cannot be reduced into one
title: Elementary Forms

text: another, and which are like two distinct layers superimposed one upon
title: Elementary Forms

text: the other.[16] Our hypothesis keeps this principle intact. In fact, that
title: Elementary Forms

text: knowledge which is called empirical, the only knowledge of which the
title: Elementary Forms

text: theorists of empiricism have made use in constructing the reason, is
title: Elementary Forms

text: that which is brought into our minds by the direct action of objects. It
title: Elementary Forms

text: is composed of individual states which are completely explained[17] by
title: Elementary Forms

text: the psychical nature of the individual. If, on the other hand, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: categories are, as we believe they are, essentially collective
title: Elementary Forms

text: representations, before all else, they should show the mental states of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the group; they should depend upon the way in which this is founded and
title: Elementary Forms

text: organized, upon its morphology, upon its religious, moral and economic
title: Elementary Forms

text: institutions, etc. So between these two sorts of representations there
title: Elementary Forms

text: is all the difference which exists between the individual and the
title: Elementary Forms

text: social, and one can no more derive the second from the first than he can
title: Elementary Forms

text: deduce society from the individual, the whole from the part, the complex
title: Elementary Forms

text: from the simple.[18] Society is a reality _sui generis_; it has its own
title: Elementary Forms

text: peculiar characteristics, which are not found elsewhere and which are
title: Elementary Forms

text: not met with again in the same form in all the rest of the universe. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: representations which express it have a wholly different contents from
title: Elementary Forms

text: purely individual ones and we may rest assured in advance that the first
title: Elementary Forms

text: add something to the second.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Even the manner in which the two are formed results in differentiating
title: Elementary Forms

text: them. Collective representations are the result of an immense
title: Elementary Forms

text: co-operation, which stretches out not only into space but into time as
title: Elementary Forms

text: well; to make them, a multitude of minds have associated, united and
title: Elementary Forms

text: combined their ideas and sentiments; for them, long generations have
title: Elementary Forms

text: accumulated their experience and their knowledge. A special intellectual
title: Elementary Forms

text: activity is therefore concentrated in them which is infinitely richer
title: Elementary Forms

text: and complexer than that of the individual. From that one can understand
title: Elementary Forms

text: how the reason has been able to go beyond the limits of empirical
title: Elementary Forms

text: knowledge. It does not owe this to any vague mysterious virtue but
title: Elementary Forms

text: simply to the fact that according to the well-known formula, man is
title: Elementary Forms

text: double. There are two beings in him: an individual being which has its
title: Elementary Forms

text: foundation in the organism and the circle of whose activities is
title: Elementary Forms

text: therefore strictly limited, and a social being which represents the
title: Elementary Forms

text: highest reality in the intellectual and moral order that we can know by
title: Elementary Forms

text: observation--I mean society. This duality of our nature has as its
title: Elementary Forms

text: consequence in the practical order, the irreducibility of a moral ideal
title: Elementary Forms

text: to a utilitarian motive, and in the order of thought, the irreducibility
title: Elementary Forms

text: of reason to individual experience. In so far as he belongs to society,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the individual transcends himself, both when he thinks and when he
title: Elementary Forms

text: acts.
title: Elementary Forms

text: This same social character leads to an understanding of the origin of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the necessity of the categories. It is said that an idea is necessary
title: Elementary Forms

text: when it imposes itself upon the mind by some sort of virtue of its own,
title: Elementary Forms

text: without being accompanied by any proof. It contains within it something
title: Elementary Forms

text: which constrains the intelligence and which leads to its acceptance
title: Elementary Forms

text: without preliminary examination. The apriorist postulates this singular
title: Elementary Forms

text: quality, but does not account for it; for saying that the categories are
title: Elementary Forms

text: necessary because they are indispensable to the functioning of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: intellect is simply repeating that they are necessary. But if they
title: Elementary Forms

text: really have the origin which we attribute to them, their ascendancy no
title: Elementary Forms

text: longer has anything surprising in it. They represent the most general
title: Elementary Forms

text: relations which exist between things; surpassing all our other ideas in
title: Elementary Forms

text: extension, they dominate all the details of our intellectual life. If
title: Elementary Forms

text: men did not agree upon these essential ideas at every moment, if they
title: Elementary Forms

text: did not have the same conception of time, space, cause, number, etc.,
title: Elementary Forms

text: all contact between their minds would be impossible, and with that, all
title: Elementary Forms

text: life together. Thus society could not abandon the categories to the free
title: Elementary Forms

text: choice of the individual without abandoning itself. If it is to live
title: Elementary Forms

text: there is not merely need of a satisfactory moral conformity, but also
title: Elementary Forms

text: there is a minimum of logical conformity beyond which it cannot safely
title: Elementary Forms

text: go. For this reason it uses all its authority upon its members to
title: Elementary Forms

text: forestall such dissidences. Does a mind ostensibly free itself from
title: Elementary Forms

text: these forms of thought? It is no longer considered a human mind in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: full sense of the word, and is treated accordingly. That is why we feel
title: Elementary Forms

text: that we are no longer completely free and that something resists, both
title: Elementary Forms

text: within and outside ourselves, when we attempt to rid ourselves of these
title: Elementary Forms

text: fundamental notions, even in our own conscience. Outside of us there is
title: Elementary Forms

text: public opinion which judges us; but more than that, since society is
title: Elementary Forms

text: also represented inside of us, it sets itself against these
title: Elementary Forms

text: revolutionary fancies, even inside of ourselves; we have the feeling
title: Elementary Forms

text: that we cannot abandon them if our whole thought is not to cease being
title: Elementary Forms

text: really human. This seems to be the origin of the exceptional authority
title: Elementary Forms

text: which is inherent in the reason and which makes us accept its
title: Elementary Forms

text: suggestions with confidence. It is the very authority of society,[19]
title: Elementary Forms

text: transferring itself to a certain manner of thought which is the
title: Elementary Forms

text: indispensable condition of all common action. The necessity with which
title: Elementary Forms

text: the categories are imposed upon us is not the effect of simple habits
title: Elementary Forms

text: whose yoke we could easily throw off with a little effort; nor is it a
title: Elementary Forms

text: physical or metaphysical necessity, since the categories change in
title: Elementary Forms

text: different places and times; it is a special sort of moral necessity
title: Elementary Forms

text: which is to the intellectual life what moral obligation is to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: will.[20]
title: Elementary Forms

text: But if the categories originally only translate social states, does it
title: Elementary Forms

text: not follow that they can be applied to the rest of nature only as
title: Elementary Forms

text: metaphors? If they were made merely to express social conditions, it
title: Elementary Forms

text: seems as though they could not be extended to other realms except in
title: Elementary Forms

text: this sense. Thus in so far as they aid us in thinking of the physical or
title: Elementary Forms

text: biological world, they have only the value of artificial symbols, useful
title: Elementary Forms

text: practically perhaps, but having no connection with reality. Thus we come
title: Elementary Forms

text: back, by a different road, to nominalism and empiricism.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But when we interpret a sociological theory of knowledge in this way, we
title: Elementary Forms

text: forget that even if society is a specific reality it is not an empire
title: Elementary Forms

text: within an empire; it is a part of nature, and indeed its highest
title: Elementary Forms

text: representation. The social realm is a natural realm which differs from
title: Elementary Forms

text: the others only by a greater complexity. Now it is impossible that
title: Elementary Forms

text: nature should differ radically from itself in the one case and the other
title: Elementary Forms

text: in regard to that which is most essential. The fundamental relations
title: Elementary Forms

text: that exist between things--just that which it is the function of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: categories to express--cannot be essentially dissimilar in the different
title: Elementary Forms

text: realms. If, for reasons which we shall discuss later,[21] they are more
title: Elementary Forms

text: clearly disengaged in the social world, it is nevertheless impossible
title: Elementary Forms

text: that they should not be found elsewhere, though in less pronounced
title: Elementary Forms

text: forms. Society makes them more manifest but it does not have a monopoly
title: Elementary Forms

text: upon them. That is why ideas which have been elaborated on the model of
title: Elementary Forms

text: social things can aid us in thinking of another department of nature. It
title: Elementary Forms

text: is at least true that if these ideas play the role of symbols when they
title: Elementary Forms

text: are thus turned aside from their original signification, they are
title: Elementary Forms

text: well-founded symbols. If a sort of artificiality enters into them from
title: Elementary Forms

text: the mere fact that they are constructed concepts, it is an
title: Elementary Forms

text: artificiality which follows nature very closely and which is constantly
title: Elementary Forms

text: approaching it still more closely.[22] From the fact that the ideas of
title: Elementary Forms

text: time, space, class, cause or personality are constructed out of social
title: Elementary Forms

text: elements, it is not necessary to conclude that they are devoid of all
title: Elementary Forms

text: objective value. On the contrary, their social origin rather leads to
title: Elementary Forms

text: the belief that they are not without foundation in the nature of
title: Elementary Forms

text: things.[23]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Thus renovated, the theory of knowledge seems destined to unite the
title: Elementary Forms

text: opposing advantages of the two rival theories, without incurring their
title: Elementary Forms

text: inconveniences. It keeps all the essential principles of the apriorists;
title: Elementary Forms

text: but at the same time it is inspired by that positive spirit which the
title: Elementary Forms

text: empiricists have striven to satisfy. It leaves the reason its specific
title: Elementary Forms

text: power, but it accounts for it and does so without leaving the world of
title: Elementary Forms

text: observable phenomena. It affirms the duality of our intellectual life,
title: Elementary Forms

text: but it explains it, and with natural causes. The categories are no
title: Elementary Forms

text: longer considered as primary and unanalysable facts, yet they keep a
title: Elementary Forms

text: complexity which falsifies any analysis as ready as that with which the
title: Elementary Forms

text: empiricists content themselves. They no longer appear as very simple
title: Elementary Forms

text: notions which the first comer can very easily arrange from his own
title: Elementary Forms

text: personal observations and which the popular imagination has unluckily
title: Elementary Forms

text: complicated, but rather they appear as priceless instruments of thought
title: Elementary Forms

text: which the human groups have laboriously forged through the centuries and
title: Elementary Forms

text: where they have accumulated the best of their intellectual capital.[24]
title: Elementary Forms

text: A complete section of the history of humanity is resumed therein. This
title: Elementary Forms

text: is equivalent to saying that to succeed in understanding them and
title: Elementary Forms

text: judging them, it is necessary to resort to other means than those which
title: Elementary Forms

text: have been in use up to the present. To know what these conceptions which
title: Elementary Forms

text: we have not made ourselves are really made of, it does not suffice to
title: Elementary Forms

text: interrogate our own consciousnesses; we must look outside of ourselves,
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is history that we must observe, there is a whole science which must
title: Elementary Forms

text: be formed, a complex science which can advance but slowly and by
title: Elementary Forms

text: collective labour, and to which the present work brings some fragmentary
title: Elementary Forms

text: contributions in the nature of an attempt. Without making these
title: Elementary Forms

text: questions the direct object of our study, we shall profit by all the
title: Elementary Forms

text: occasions which present themselves to us of catching at their very birth
title: Elementary Forms

text: some at least of these ideas which, while being of religious origin,
title: Elementary Forms

text: still remain at the foundation of the human intelligence.

text: CHAPTER I
title: Elementary Forms

text: DEFINITION OF RELIGIOUS PHENOMENA AND OF RELIGION[25]
title: Elementary Forms

text: If we are going to look for the most primitive and simple religion which
title: Elementary Forms

text: we can observe, it is necessary to begin by defining what is meant by a
title: Elementary Forms

text: religion; for without this, we would run the risk of giving the name to
title: Elementary Forms

text: a system of ideas and practices which has nothing at all religious about
title: Elementary Forms

text: it, or else of leaving to one side many religious facts, without
title: Elementary Forms

text: perceiving their true nature. That this is not an imaginary danger, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: that nothing is thus sacrificed to a vain formalism of method, is well
title: Elementary Forms

text: shown by the fact that owing to his not having taken this precaution, a
title: Elementary Forms

text: certain scholar to whom the science of comparative religions owes a
title: Elementary Forms

text: great deal, Professor Frazer, has not been able to recognize the
title: Elementary Forms

text: profoundly religious character of the beliefs and rites which will be
title: Elementary Forms

text: studied below, where, according to our view, the initial germ of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious life of humanity is to be found. So this is a prejudicial
title: Elementary Forms

text: question, which must be treated before all others. It is not that we
title: Elementary Forms

text: dream of arriving at once at the profound characteristics which really
title: Elementary Forms

text: explain religion: these can be determined only at the end of our study.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But that which is necessary and possible, is to indicate a certain
title: Elementary Forms

text: number of external and easily recognizable signs, which will enable us
title: Elementary Forms

text: to recognize religious phenomena wherever they are met with, and which
title: Elementary Forms

text: will deter us from confounding them with others. We shall proceed to
title: Elementary Forms

text: this preliminary operation at once.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But to attain the desired results, it is necessary to begin by freeing
title: Elementary Forms

text: the mind of every preconceived idea. Men have been obliged to make for
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves a notion of what religion is, long before the science of
title: Elementary Forms

text: religions started its methodical comparisons. The necessities of
title: Elementary Forms

text: existence force all of us, believers and non-believers, to represent in
title: Elementary Forms

text: some way these things in the midst of which we live, upon which we must
title: Elementary Forms

text: pass judgment constantly, and which we must take into account in all our
title: Elementary Forms

text: conduct. However, since these preconceived ideas are formed without any
title: Elementary Forms

text: method, according to the circumstances and chances of life, they have no
title: Elementary Forms

text: right to any credit whatsoever, and must be rigorously set aside in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: examination which is to follow. It is not from our prejudices, passions
title: Elementary Forms

text: or habits that we should demand the elements of the definition which we
title: Elementary Forms

text: must have; it is from the reality itself which we are going to define.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Let us set ourselves before this reality. Leaving aside all conceptions
title: Elementary Forms

text: of religion in general, let us consider the various religions in their
title: Elementary Forms

text: concrete reality, and attempt to disengage that which they have in
title: Elementary Forms

text: common; for religion cannot be defined except by the characteristics
title: Elementary Forms

text: which are found wherever religion itself is found. In this comparison,
title: Elementary Forms

text: then, we shall make use of all the religious systems which we can know,
title: Elementary Forms

text: those of the present and those of the past, the most primitive and
title: Elementary Forms

text: simple as well as the most recent and refined; for we have neither the
title: Elementary Forms

text: right nor the logical means of excluding some and retaining others. For
title: Elementary Forms

text: those who regard religion as only a natural manifestation of human
title: Elementary Forms

text: activity, all religions, without any exception whatsoever, are
title: Elementary Forms

text: instructive; for all, after their manner, express man, and thus can aid
title: Elementary Forms

text: us in better understanding this aspect of our nature. Also, we have seen
title: Elementary Forms

text: how far it is from being the best way of studying religion to consider
title: Elementary Forms

text: by preference the forms which it presents among the most civilized
title: Elementary Forms

text: peoples.[26]
title: Elementary Forms

text: But to aid the mind in freeing itself from these usual conceptions
title: Elementary Forms

text: which, owing to their prestige, might prevent it from seeing things as
title: Elementary Forms

text: they really are, it is fitting to examine some of the most current of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the definitions in which these prejudices are commonly expressed, before
title: Elementary Forms

text: taking up the question on our own account.

text: I
title: Elementary Forms

text: One idea which generally passes as characteristic of all that is
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious, is that of the supernatural. By this is understood all sorts
title: Elementary Forms

text: of things which surpass the limits of our knowledge; the supernatural
title: Elementary Forms

text: is the world of the mysterious, of the unknowable, of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: un-understandable. Thus religion would be a sort of speculation upon all
title: Elementary Forms

text: that which evades science or distinct thought in general. "Religions
title: Elementary Forms

text: diametrically opposed in their overt dogmas," said Spencer, "are
title: Elementary Forms

text: perfectly at one in the tacit conviction that the existence of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: world, with all it contains and all which surrounds it, is a mystery
title: Elementary Forms

text: calling for an explanation"; he thus makes them consist essentially in
title: Elementary Forms

text: "the belief in the omnipresence of something which is inscrutable."[27]
title: Elementary Forms

text: In the same manner, Max Mueller sees in religion "a struggle to conceive
title: Elementary Forms

text: the inconceivable, to utter the unutterable, a longing after the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Infinite."[28]
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is certain that the sentiment of mystery has not been without a
title: Elementary Forms

text: considerable importance in certain religions, notably in Christianity.
title: Elementary Forms

text: It must also be said that the importance of this sentiment has varied
title: Elementary Forms

text: remarkably at different moments in the history of Christianity. There
title: Elementary Forms

text: are periods when this notion passes to an inferior place, and is even
title: Elementary Forms

text: effaced. For example, for the Christians of the seventeenth century,
title: Elementary Forms

text: dogma had nothing disturbing for the reason; faith reconciled itself
title: Elementary Forms

text: easily with science and philosophy, and the thinkers, such as Pascal,
title: Elementary Forms

text: who really felt that there is something profoundly obscure in things,
title: Elementary Forms

text: were so little in harmony with their age that they remained
title: Elementary Forms

text: misunderstood by their contemporaries.[29] It would appear somewhat
title: Elementary Forms

text: hasty, therefore, to make an idea subject to parallel eclipses, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: essential element of even the Christian religion.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In all events, it is certain that this idea does not appear until late
title: Elementary Forms

text: in the history of religions; it is completely foreign, not only to those
title: Elementary Forms

text: peoples who are called primitive, but also to all others who have not
title: Elementary Forms

text: attained a considerable degree of intellectual culture. When we see them
title: Elementary Forms

text: attribute extraordinary virtues to insignificant objects, and people the
title: Elementary Forms

text: universe with singular principles, made up of the most diverse elements
title: Elementary Forms

text: and endowed with a sort of ubiquity which is hardly representable, we
title: Elementary Forms

text: are undoubtedly prone to find an air of mystery in these conceptions. It
title: Elementary Forms

text: seems to us that these men would have been willing to resign themselves
title: Elementary Forms

text: to these ideas, so disturbing for our modern reason, only because of
title: Elementary Forms

text: their inability to find others which were more rational. But, as a
title: Elementary Forms

text: matter of fact, these explanations which surprise us so much, appear to
title: Elementary Forms

text: the primitive man as the simplest in the world. He does not regard them
title: Elementary Forms

text: as a sort of _ultima ratio_ to which the intellect resigns itself only
title: Elementary Forms

text: in despair of others, but rather as the most obvious manner of
title: Elementary Forms

text: representing and understanding what he sees about him. For him there is
title: Elementary Forms

text: nothing strange in the fact that by a mere word or gesture one is able
title: Elementary Forms

text: to command the elements, retard or precipitate the motion of the stars,
title: Elementary Forms

text: bring rain or cause it to cease, etc. The rites which he employs to
title: Elementary Forms

text: assure the fertility of the soil or the fecundity of the animal species
title: Elementary Forms

text: on which he is nourished do not appear more irrational to his eyes than
title: Elementary Forms

text: the technical processes of which our agriculturists make use, for the
title: Elementary Forms

text: same object, do to ours. The powers which he puts into play by these
title: Elementary Forms

text: diverse means do not seem to him to have anything especially mysterious
title: Elementary Forms

text: about them. Undoubtedly these forces are different from those which the
title: Elementary Forms

text: modern scientist thinks of, and whose use he teaches us; they have a
title: Elementary Forms

text: different way of acting, and do not allow themselves to be directed in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the same manner; but for those who believe in them, they are no more
title: Elementary Forms

text: unintelligible than are gravitation and electricity for the physicist of
title: Elementary Forms

text: to-day. Moreover, we shall see, in the course of this work, that the
title: Elementary Forms

text: idea of physical forces is very probably derived from that of religious
title: Elementary Forms

text: forces; then there cannot exist between the two the abyss which
title: Elementary Forms

text: separates the rational from the irrational. Even the fact that religious
title: Elementary Forms

text: forces are frequently conceived under the form of spiritual beings or
title: Elementary Forms

text: conscious wills, is no proof of their irrationality. The reason has no
title: Elementary Forms

text: repugnance _a priori_ to admitting that the so-called inanimate bodies
title: Elementary Forms

text: should be directed by intelligences, just as the human body is, though
title: Elementary Forms

text: contemporary science accommodates itself with difficulty to this
title: Elementary Forms

text: hypothesis. When Leibniz proposed to conceive the external world as an
title: Elementary Forms

text: immense society of minds, between which there were, and could be, only
title: Elementary Forms

text: spiritual relations, he thought he was working as a rationalist, and saw
title: Elementary Forms

text: nothing in this universal animism which could be offensive to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: intellect.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Moreover, the idea of the supernatural, as we understand it, dates only
title: Elementary Forms

text: from to-day; in fact, it presupposes the contrary idea, of which it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: the negation; but this idea is not at all primitive. In order to say
title: Elementary Forms

text: that certain things are supernatural, it is necessary to have the
title: Elementary Forms

text: sentiment that a _natural order of things_ exists, that is to say, that
title: Elementary Forms

text: the phenomena of the universe are bound together by necessary relations,
title: Elementary Forms

text: called laws. When this principle has once been admitted, all that is
title: Elementary Forms
