text: contrary to these laws must necessarily appear to be outside of nature,
title: Elementary Forms

text: and consequently, of reason; for what is natural in this sense of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: word, is also rational, these necessary relations only expressing the
title: Elementary Forms

text: manner in which things are logically related. But this idea of universal
title: Elementary Forms

text: determinism is of recent origin; even the greatest thinkers of classical
title: Elementary Forms

text: antiquity never succeeded in becoming fully conscious of it. It is a
title: Elementary Forms

text: conquest of the positive sciences; it is the postulate upon which they
title: Elementary Forms

text: repose and which they have proved by their progress. Now as long as this
title: Elementary Forms

text: was lacking or insufficiently established, the most marvellous events
title: Elementary Forms

text: contained nothing which did not appear perfectly conceivable. So long as
title: Elementary Forms

text: men did not know the immutability and the inflexibility of the order of
title: Elementary Forms

text: things, and so long as they saw there the work of contingent wills, they
title: Elementary Forms

text: found it natural that either these wills or others could modify them
title: Elementary Forms

text: arbitrarily. That is why the miraculous interventions which the ancients
title: Elementary Forms

text: attributed to their gods were not to their eyes miracles in the modern
title: Elementary Forms

text: acceptation of the term. For them, they were beautiful, rare or terrible
title: Elementary Forms

text: spectacles, or causes of surprise and marvel ([Greek: thaumata],
title: Elementary Forms

text: _mirabilia_, _miracula_); but they never saw in them glimpses of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: mysterious world into which the reason cannot penetrate.
title: Elementary Forms

text: We can understand this mentality the better since it has not yet
title: Elementary Forms

text: completely disappeared from our midst. If the principle of determinism
title: Elementary Forms

text: is solidly established to-day in the physical and natural sciences, it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is only a century ago that it was first introduced into the social
title: Elementary Forms

text: sciences, and its authority there is still contested. There are only a
title: Elementary Forms

text: small number of minds which are strongly penetrated with this idea that
title: Elementary Forms

text: societies are subject to natural laws and form a kingdom of nature. It
title: Elementary Forms

text: follows that veritable miracles are believed to be possible there. It is
title: Elementary Forms

text: admitted, for example, that a legislator can create an institution out
title: Elementary Forms

text: of nothing by a mere injunction of its will, or transform one social
title: Elementary Forms

text: system into another, just as the believers in so many religions have
title: Elementary Forms

text: held that the divine will created the world out of nothing, or can
title: Elementary Forms

text: arbitrarily transmute one thing into another. As far as social facts are
title: Elementary Forms

text: concerned, we still have the mentality of primitives. However, if so
title: Elementary Forms

text: many of our contemporaries still retain this antiquated conception for
title: Elementary Forms

text: sociological affairs, it is not because the life of societies appears
title: Elementary Forms

text: obscure and mysterious to them; on the contrary, if they are so easily
title: Elementary Forms

text: contented with these explanations, and if they are so obstinate in their
title: Elementary Forms

text: illusions which experience constantly belies, it is because social
title: Elementary Forms

text: events seem to them the clearest thing in the world; it is because they
title: Elementary Forms

text: have not yet realized their real obscurity; it is because they have not
title: Elementary Forms

text: yet recognized the necessity of resorting to the laborious methods of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the natural sciences to gradually scatter the darkness. The same state
title: Elementary Forms

text: of mind is found at the root of many religious beliefs which surprise us
title: Elementary Forms

text: by their pseudo-simplicity. It is science and not religion which has
title: Elementary Forms

text: taught men that things are complex and difficult to understand.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But the human mind, says Jevons,[30] has no need of a properly
title: Elementary Forms

text: scientific culture to notice that determined sequences, or a constant
title: Elementary Forms

text: order of succession, exist between facts, or to observe, on the other
title: Elementary Forms

text: hand, that this order is frequently upset. It sometimes happens that the
title: Elementary Forms

text: sun is suddenly eclipsed, that rain fails at the time when it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: expected, that the moon is slow to reappear after its periodical
title: Elementary Forms

text: disappearance, etc. Since these events are outside the ordinary course
title: Elementary Forms

text: of affairs, they are attributed to extraordinary exceptional causes,
title: Elementary Forms

text: that is to say, in fine, to extra-natural causes. It is under this form
title: Elementary Forms

text: that the idea of the supernatural is born at the very outset of history,
title: Elementary Forms

text: and from this moment, according to this author, religious thought finds
title: Elementary Forms

text: itself provided with its proper subject.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But in the first place, the supernatural cannot be reduced to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: unforeseen. The new is a part of nature just as well as its contrary. If
title: Elementary Forms

text: we state that in general, phenomena succeed one another in a determined
title: Elementary Forms

text: order, we observe equally well that this order is only approximative,
title: Elementary Forms

text: that it is not always precisely the same, and that it has all kinds of
title: Elementary Forms

text: exceptions. If we have ever so little experience, we are accustomed to
title: Elementary Forms

text: seeing our expectations fail, and these deceptions return too often to
title: Elementary Forms

text: appear extraordinary to us. A certain contingency is taught by
title: Elementary Forms

text: experience just as well as a certain uniformity; then we have no reason
title: Elementary Forms

text: for assigning the one to causes and forces entirely different from those
title: Elementary Forms

text: upon which the other depends. In order to arrive at the idea of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: supernatural, it is not enough, therefore, to be witnesses to unexpected
title: Elementary Forms

text: events; it is also necessary that these be conceived as impossible, that
title: Elementary Forms

text: is to say, irreconcilable with an order which, rightly or wrongly,
title: Elementary Forms

text: appears to us to be implied in the nature of things. Now this idea of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: necessary order has been constructed little by little by the positive
title: Elementary Forms

text: sciences, and consequently the contrary notion could not have existed
title: Elementary Forms

text: before them.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Also, in whatever manner men have represented the novelties and
title: Elementary Forms

text: contingencies revealed by experience, there is nothing in these
title: Elementary Forms

text: representations which could serve to characterize religion. For
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious conceptions have as their object, before everything else, to
title: Elementary Forms

text: express and explain, not that which is exceptional and abnormal in
title: Elementary Forms

text: things, but, on the contrary, that which is constant and regular. Very
title: Elementary Forms

text: frequently, the gods serve less to account for the monstrosities,
title: Elementary Forms

text: fantasies and anomalies than for the regular march of the universe, for
title: Elementary Forms

text: the movement of the stars, the rhythm of the seasons, the annual growth
title: Elementary Forms

text: of vegetation, the perpetuation of species, etc. It is far from being
title: Elementary Forms

text: true, then, that the notion of the religions coincides with that of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: extraordinary or the unforeseen. Jevons replies that this conception of
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious forces is not primitive. Men commenced by imagining them to
title: Elementary Forms

text: account for disorders and accidents, and it was only afterwards that
title: Elementary Forms

text: they began to utilize them in explaining the uniformities of
title: Elementary Forms

text: nature.[31] But it is not clear what could have led men to attribute
title: Elementary Forms

text: such manifestly contradictory functions to them. More than that, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: hypothesis according to which sacred beings were at first restricted to
title: Elementary Forms

text: the negative function of disturbers is quite arbitrary. In fact, we
title: Elementary Forms

text: shall see that, even with the most simple religions we know, their
title: Elementary Forms

text: essential task is to maintain, in a positive manner, the normal course
title: Elementary Forms

text: of life.[32]
title: Elementary Forms

text: So the idea of mystery is not of primitive origin. It was not given to
title: Elementary Forms

text: man; it is man who has forged it, with his own hands, along with the
title: Elementary Forms

text: contrary idea. This is why it has a place only in a very small number of
title: Elementary Forms

text: advanced religions. It is impossible to make it the characteristic mark
title: Elementary Forms

text: of religious phenomena without excluding from the definition the
title: Elementary Forms

text: majority of the facts to be defined.
title: Elementary Forms

text: II
title: Elementary Forms

text: Another idea by which the attempt to define religion is often made, is
title: Elementary Forms

text: that of divinity. "Religion," says M. Reville,[33] "is the determination
title: Elementary Forms

text: of human life by the sentiment of a bond uniting the human mind to that
title: Elementary Forms

text: mysterious mind whose domination of the world and itself it recognizes,
title: Elementary Forms

text: and to whom it delights in feeling itself united." It is certain that if
title: Elementary Forms

text: the word divinity is taken in a precise and narrow sense, this
title: Elementary Forms

text: definition leaves aside a multitude of obviously religious facts. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: souls of the dead and the spirits of all ranks and classes with which
title: Elementary Forms

text: the religious imagination of so many different peoples has populated
title: Elementary Forms

text: nature, are always the object of rites and sometimes even of a regular
title: Elementary Forms

text: cult; yet they are not gods in the proper sense of the term. But in
title: Elementary Forms

text: order that the definition may embrace them, it is enough to substitute
title: Elementary Forms

text: for the term "gods" the more comprehensive one of "spiritual beings."
title: Elementary Forms

text: This is what Tylor does. "The first requisite in a systematic study of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the religions of the lower races," he says, "is to lay down a
title: Elementary Forms

text: rudimentary definition of religion. By requiring in this definition the
title: Elementary Forms

text: belief in a supreme deity ..., no doubt many tribes may be excluded from
title: Elementary Forms

text: the category of religious. But such narrow definition has the fault of
title: Elementary Forms

text: identifying religion rather with particular developments.... It seems
title: Elementary Forms

text: best ... simply to claim as a minimum definition of Religion, the belief
title: Elementary Forms

text: in Spiritual Beings."[34] By spiritual beings must be understood
title: Elementary Forms

text: conscious subjects gifted with powers superior to those possessed by
title: Elementary Forms

text: common men; this qualification is found in the souls of the dead,
title: Elementary Forms

text: geniuses or demons as well as in divinities properly so-called. It is
title: Elementary Forms

text: important, therefore, to give our attention at once to the particular
title: Elementary Forms

text: conception of religion which is implied in this definition. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: relations which we can have with beings of this sort are determined by
title: Elementary Forms

text: the nature attributed to them. They are conscious beings; then we can
title: Elementary Forms

text: act upon them only in the same way that we act upon consciousnesses in
title: Elementary Forms

text: general, that is to say, by psychological processes, attempting to
title: Elementary Forms

text: convince them or move them, either with the aid of words (invocations,
title: Elementary Forms

text: prayers), or by offerings and sacrifices. And since the object of
title: Elementary Forms

text: religion is to regulate our relations with these special beings, there
title: Elementary Forms

text: can be no religion except where there are prayers, sacrifices,
title: Elementary Forms

text: propitiatory rites, etc. Thus we have a very simple criterium which
title: Elementary Forms

text: permits us to distinguish that which is religious from that which is
title: Elementary Forms

text: not. It is to this criterium that Frazer,[35] and with him numerous
title: Elementary Forms

text: ethnographers,[36] systematically makes reference.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But howsoever evident this definition may appear, thanks to the mental
title: Elementary Forms

text: habits which we owe to our religious education, there are many facts to
title: Elementary Forms

text: which it is not applicable, but which appertain to the field of religion
title: Elementary Forms

text: nevertheless.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In the first place, there are great religions from which the idea of
title: Elementary Forms

text: gods and spirits is absent, or at least, where it plays only a secondary
title: Elementary Forms

text: and minor role. This is the case with Buddhism. Buddhism, says Burnouf,
title: Elementary Forms

text: "sets itself in opposition to Brahmanism as a moral system without god
title: Elementary Forms

text: and an atheism without Nature."[37] "As it recognizes not a god upon
title: Elementary Forms

text: whom man depends," says Barth, "its doctrine is absolutely
title: Elementary Forms

text: atheistic,"[38] while Oldenberg, in his turn, calls it "a faith without
title: Elementary Forms

text: a god."[39] In fact, all that is essential to Buddhism is found in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: four propositions which the faithful call the four noble truths.[40] The
title: Elementary Forms

text: first states the existence of suffering as the accompaniment to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: perpetual change of things; the second shows desire to be the cause of
title: Elementary Forms

text: suffering; the third makes the suppression of desire the only means of
title: Elementary Forms

text: suppressing sorrow; the fourth enumerates the three stages through which
title: Elementary Forms

text: one must pass to attain this suppression: they are uprightness,
title: Elementary Forms

text: meditation, and finally wisdom, the full possession of the doctrine.
title: Elementary Forms

text: These three stages once traversed, one arrives at the end of the road,
title: Elementary Forms

text: at the deliverance, at salvation by the Nirvana.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Now in none of these principles is there question of a divinity. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: Buddhist is not interested in knowing whence came the world in which he
title: Elementary Forms

text: lives and suffers; he takes it as a given fact,[41] and his whole
title: Elementary Forms

text: concern is to escape it. On the other hand, in this work of salvation,
title: Elementary Forms

text: he can count only upon himself; "he has no god to thank, as he had
title: Elementary Forms

text: previously no god to invoke during his struggle."[42] Instead of
title: Elementary Forms

text: praying, in the ordinary sense of the term, instead of turning towards a
title: Elementary Forms

text: superior being and imploring his assistance, he relies upon himself and
title: Elementary Forms

text: meditates. This is not saying "that he absolutely denies the existence
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the beings called Indra, Agni and Varuna;[43] but he believes that he
title: Elementary Forms

text: owes them nothing and that he has nothing to do with them," for their
title: Elementary Forms

text: power can only extend over the goods of this world, which are without
title: Elementary Forms

text: value for him. Then he is an atheist, in the sense that he does not
title: Elementary Forms

text: concern himself with the question whether gods exist or not. Besides,
title: Elementary Forms

text: even if they should exist, and with whatever powers they might be armed,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the saint or the emancipated man regards himself superior to them; for
title: Elementary Forms

text: that which causes the dignity of beings is not the extent of the action
title: Elementary Forms

text: they exercise over things, but merely the degree of their advancement
title: Elementary Forms

text: upon the road of salvation.[44]
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is true that Buddha, at least in some divisions of the Buddhist
title: Elementary Forms

text: Church, has sometimes been considered as a sort of god. He has his
title: Elementary Forms

text: temples; he is the object of a cult, which, by the way, is a very simple
title: Elementary Forms

text: one, for it is reduced essentially to the offering of flowers and the
title: Elementary Forms

text: adoration of consecrated relics or images. It is scarcely more than a
title: Elementary Forms

text: commemorative cult. But more than that, this divinization of Buddha,
title: Elementary Forms

text: granting that the term is exact, is peculiar to the form known as
title: Elementary Forms

text: Northern Buddhism. "The Buddhist of the South," says Kern, "and the less
title: Elementary Forms

text: advanced of the Northern Buddhists can be said, according to data known
title: Elementary Forms

text: to-day, to speak of their founder as if he were a man."[45] Of course,
title: Elementary Forms

text: they attribute extraordinary powers to Buddha, which are superior to
title: Elementary Forms

text: those possessed by ordinary mortals; but it was a very ancient belief in
title: Elementary Forms

text: India, and one that is also very general in a host of different
title: Elementary Forms

text: religions, that a great saint is endowed with exceptional virtues;[46]
title: Elementary Forms

text: yet a saint is not a god, any more than a priest or magician is, in
title: Elementary Forms

text: spite of the superhuman faculties frequently attributed to them. On the
title: Elementary Forms

text: other hand, according to the most authorized scholars, all this theism
title: Elementary Forms

text: and the complicated mythology which generally accompanies it, are only
title: Elementary Forms

text: derived and deviated forms of Buddhism. At first, Buddha was only
title: Elementary Forms

text: regarded as "the wisest of men."[47] Burnouf says "the conception of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: Buddha who is something more than a man arrived at the highest stage of
title: Elementary Forms

text: holiness, is outside the circle of ideas which form the foundation of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the simple Sutras";[48] and the same author adds elsewhere that "his
title: Elementary Forms

text: humanity is a fact so incontestably recognized by all that the
title: Elementary Forms

text: myth-makers, to whom miracles cost so little, have never even had the
title: Elementary Forms

text: idea of making a god out of him since his death."[49] So we may well ask
title: Elementary Forms

text: if he has ever really divested himself completely of all human
title: Elementary Forms

text: character, and if we have a right to make him into a god completely;[50]
title: Elementary Forms

text: in any case, it would have to be a god of a very particular character
title: Elementary Forms

text: and one whose role in no way resembles that of other divine
title: Elementary Forms

text: personalities. For a god is before all else a living being, with whom
title: Elementary Forms

text: man should reckon, and upon whom he may count; but Buddha is dead, he
title: Elementary Forms

text: has entered into the Nirvana, and he can no longer influence the march
title: Elementary Forms

text: of human events.[51]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Finally, whatever one may think of the divinity of Buddha, it remains a
title: Elementary Forms

text: fact that this is a conception wholly outside the essential part of
title: Elementary Forms

text: Buddhism. Buddhism consists primarily in the idea of salvation, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: salvation supposes only that one know the good doctrine and practise it.
title: Elementary Forms

text: To be sure, this could never have been known if Buddha had not come to
title: Elementary Forms

text: reveal it; but when this revelation had once been made, the work of
title: Elementary Forms

text: Buddha was accomplished. From that moment he ceased to be a factor
title: Elementary Forms

text: necessary to the religious life. The practice of the four holy truths
title: Elementary Forms

text: would be possible, even if the memory of him who revealed them were
title: Elementary Forms

text: completely obliterated.[52] It is quite another matter with
title: Elementary Forms

text: Christianity, which is inconceivable without the ever-present idea of
title: Elementary Forms

text: Christ and his ever-practised cult; for it is by the ever-living Christ,
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacrificed each day, that the community of believers continues to
title: Elementary Forms

text: communicate with the supreme source of the spiritual life.[53]
title: Elementary Forms

text: All that precedes can be applied equally well to another great religion
title: Elementary Forms

text: of India, Jainism. The two doctrines have nearly the same conception of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the world and of life. "Like the Buddhists," says Barth, "the Jainas are
title: Elementary Forms

text: atheists. They admit of no creator; the world is eternal; they
title: Elementary Forms

text: explicitly deny the possibility of a perfect being from the beginning.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The Jina became perfect; he was not always so."
title: Elementary Forms

text: Just as the Buddhists in the north, the Jainists, or at least certain of
title: Elementary Forms

text: them, have come back to a sort of deism; in the inscriptions of Dekhan
title: Elementary Forms

text: there is mention of a _Jinapati_, a sort of supreme Jina, who is called
title: Elementary Forms

text: the primary creator; but such language, says the same author, is "in
title: Elementary Forms

text: contradiction to the most explicit declarations extracted from their
title: Elementary Forms

text: most authorized writings."[54]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Moreover, if this indifference for the divine is developed to such a
title: Elementary Forms

text: point in Buddhism and Jainism, it is because its germ existed already in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the Brahmanism from which the two were derived. In certain of its forms
title: Elementary Forms

text: at least, Brahmic speculation ended in "a frankly materialistic and
title: Elementary Forms

text: atheistic interpretation of the universe."[55] In time, the numerous
title: Elementary Forms

text: divinities which the people of India had originally learned to adore,
title: Elementary Forms

text: came to merge themselves into a sort of principal deity, impersonal and
title: Elementary Forms

text: abstract, the essence of all that exists. This supreme reality, which no
title: Elementary Forms

text: longer has anything of a divine personality about it, is contained
title: Elementary Forms

text: within man himself, or rather, man is but one with it, for nothing
title: Elementary Forms

text: exists apart from it. To find it, and unite himself to it, one does not
title: Elementary Forms

text: have to search some external support outside himself; it is enough to
title: Elementary Forms

text: concentrate upon himself and meditate. "If in Buddhism," says Oldenberg,
title: Elementary Forms

text: "the proud attempt be made to conceive a deliverance in which man
title: Elementary Forms

text: himself delivers himself, to create a faith without a god, it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: Brahmanical speculation which has prepared the way for this thought. It
title: Elementary Forms

text: thrusts back the idea of a god step by step; the forms of the old gods
title: Elementary Forms

text: have faded away, and besides the Brahma, which is enthroned in its
title: Elementary Forms

text: everlasting quietude, highly exalted above the destinies of the human
title: Elementary Forms

text: world, there is left remaining, as the sole really active person in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: great work of deliverance, man himself."[56] Here, then, we find a
title: Elementary Forms

text: considerable portion of religious evolution which has consisted in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: progressive recoil of the idea of a spiritual being from that of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: deity. Here are great religions where invocations, propitiations,
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacrifices and prayers properly so-called are far from holding a
title: Elementary Forms

text: preponderating place, and which consequently do not present that
title: Elementary Forms

text: distinctive sign by which some claim to recognize those manifestations
title: Elementary Forms

text: which are properly called religious.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But even within deistic religions there are many rites which are
title: Elementary Forms

text: completely independent of all idea of gods or spiritual beings. In the
title: Elementary Forms

text: first place, there are a multitude of interdictions. For example, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Bible orders that a woman live isolated during a determined period each
title: Elementary Forms

text: month;[57] a similar isolation is obligatory during the lying-in at
title: Elementary Forms

text: child-birth;[58] it is forbidden to hitch an ass and a horse together,
title: Elementary Forms

text: or to wear a garment in which the hemp is mixed with flax;[59] but it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: impossible to see the part which belief in Jahveh can have played in
title: Elementary Forms

text: these interdictions, for he is wholly absent from all the relations thus
title: Elementary Forms

text: forbidden, and could not be interested in them. As much can be said for
title: Elementary Forms

text: the majority of the dietetic regulations. These prohibitions are not
title: Elementary Forms

text: peculiar to the Hebrews, but they are found under diverse forms, but
title: Elementary Forms

text: with substantially the same character, in innumerable religions.
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is true that these rites are purely negative, but they do not cease
title: Elementary Forms

text: being religious for that. Also there are others which demand active and
title: Elementary Forms

text: positive services of the faithful, but which are nevertheless of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: same nature. They work by themselves, and their efficacy depends upon no
title: Elementary Forms

text: divine power; they mechanically produce the effects which are the reason
title: Elementary Forms

text: for their existence. They do not consist either in prayers or offerings
title: Elementary Forms

text: addressed to a being upon whose goodwill the expected result depends;
title: Elementary Forms

text: this result is obtained by the automatic operation of the ritual. Such
title: Elementary Forms

text: is notably the case with the sacrifice of the Vedic religion. "The
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacrifice exercises a direct influence upon the celestial phenomena,"
title: Elementary Forms

text: says Bergaigne;[60] it is all-powerful of itself, and without any divine
title: Elementary Forms

text: influence. It is this, for example, which broke open the doors of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: cavern where the dawn was imprisoned and which made the light of day
title: Elementary Forms

text: burst forth.[61] In the same way there are special hymns which, by
title: Elementary Forms

text: their direct action, made the waters of heaven fall upon the earth, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: _even in spite of the gods_.[62] The practice of certain austerities has
title: Elementary Forms

text: the same power. More than that, "the sacrifice is so fully the origin of
title: Elementary Forms

text: things _par excellence_, that they have attributed to it not only the
title: Elementary Forms

text: origin of man, but even that of the gods.... Such a conception may well
title: Elementary Forms

text: appear strange. It is explained, however, as being one of the ultimate
title: Elementary Forms

text: consequences of the idea of the omnipotence of sacrifice."[63] Thus, in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the entire first part of his work, M. Bergaigne speaks only of
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacrifices, where divinities play no role whatsoever.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Nor is this fact peculiar to the Vedic religion, but is, on the
title: Elementary Forms

text: contrary, quite general. In every cult there are practices which act by
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves, by a virtue which is their own, without the intervention of
title: Elementary Forms

text: any god between the individual who practises the rite and the end sought
title: Elementary Forms

text: after. When, in the so-called Feast of the Tabernacles, the Jew set the
title: Elementary Forms

text: air in motion by shaking willow branches in a certain rhythm, it was to
title: Elementary Forms

text: cause the wind to rise and the rain to fall; and it was believed that
title: Elementary Forms

text: the desired phenomenon would result automatically from the rite,
title: Elementary Forms

text: provided it were correctly performed.[64] This is the explanation of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: fundamental importance laid by nearly all cults upon the material
title: Elementary Forms

text: portion of the ceremonies. This religious formalism--very probably the
title: Elementary Forms

text: first form of legal formalism--comes from the fact that since the
title: Elementary Forms

text: formula to be pronounced and the movements to be made contain within
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves the source of their efficacy, they would lose it if they did
title: Elementary Forms

text: not conform absolutely to the type consecrated by success.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Thus there are rites without gods, and even rites from which gods are
title: Elementary Forms

text: derived. All religious powers do not emanate from divine personalities,
title: Elementary Forms

text: and there are relations of cult which have other objects than uniting
title: Elementary Forms

text: man to a deity. Religion is more than the idea of gods or spirits, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: consequently cannot be defined exclusively in relation to these latter.
title: Elementary Forms

text: III
title: Elementary Forms

text: These definitions set aside, let us set ourselves before the problem.
title: Elementary Forms

text: First of all, let us remark that in all these formulae it is the nature
title: Elementary Forms

text: of religion as a whole that they seek to express. They proceed as if it
title: Elementary Forms

text: were a sort of indivisible entity, while, as a matter of fact, it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: made up of parts; it is a more or less complex system of myths, dogmas,
title: Elementary Forms

text: rites and ceremonies. Now a whole cannot be defined except in relation
title: Elementary Forms

text: to its parts. It will be more methodical, then, to try to characterize
title: Elementary Forms

text: the various elementary phenomena of which all religions are made up,
title: Elementary Forms

text: before we attack the system produced by their union. This method is
title: Elementary Forms

text: imposed still more forcibly by the fact that there are religious
title: Elementary Forms

text: phenomena which belong to no determined religion. Such are those
title: Elementary Forms

text: phenomena which constitute the matter of folk-lore. In general, they are
title: Elementary Forms

text: the debris of passed religions, inorganized survivals; but there are
title: Elementary Forms

text: some which have been formed spontaneously under the influence of local
title: Elementary Forms

text: causes. In our European countries Christianity has forced itself to
title: Elementary Forms

text: absorb and assimilate them; it has given them a Christian colouring.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Nevertheless, there are many which have persisted up until a recent
title: Elementary Forms

text: date, or which still exist with a relative autonomy: celebrations of May
title: Elementary Forms

text: Day, the summer solstice or the carnival, beliefs relative to genii,
title: Elementary Forms

text: local demons, etc., are cases in point. If the religious character of
title: Elementary Forms

text: these facts is now diminishing, their religious importance is
title: Elementary Forms

text: nevertheless so great that they have enabled Mannhardt and his school to
title: Elementary Forms

text: revive the science of religions. A definition which did not take account
title: Elementary Forms

text: of them would not cover all that is religious.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Religious phenomena are naturally arranged in two fundamental
title: Elementary Forms

text: categories: beliefs and rites. The first are states of opinion, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: consist in representations; the second are determined modes of action.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Between these two classes of facts there is all the difference which
title: Elementary Forms

text: separates thought from action.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The rites can be defined and distinguished from other human practices,
title: Elementary Forms

text: moral practices, for example, only by the special nature of their
title: Elementary Forms

text: object. A moral rule prescribes certain manners of acting to us, just as
title: Elementary Forms

text: a rite does, but which are addressed to a different class of objects. So
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is the object of the rite which must be characterized, if we are to
title: Elementary Forms

text: characterize the rite itself. Now it is in the beliefs that the special
title: Elementary Forms

text: nature of this object is expressed. It is possible to define the rite
title: Elementary Forms

text: only after we have defined the belief.
title: Elementary Forms

text: All known religious beliefs, whether simple or complex, present one
title: Elementary Forms

text: common characteristic: they presuppose a classification of all the
title: Elementary Forms

text: things, real and ideal, of which men think, into two classes or opposed
title: Elementary Forms

text: groups, generally designated by two distinct terms which are translated
title: Elementary Forms

text: well enough by the words _profane_ and _sacred_ (_profane_, _sacre_).
title: Elementary Forms

text: This division of the world into two domains, the one containing all that
title: Elementary Forms

text: is sacred, the other all that is profane, is the distinctive trait of
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious thought; the beliefs, myths, dogmas and legends are either
title: Elementary Forms

text: representations or systems of representations which express the nature
title: Elementary Forms

text: of sacred things, the virtues and powers which are attributed to them,
title: Elementary Forms

text: or their relations with each other and with profane things. But by
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacred things one must not understand simply those personal beings which
title: Elementary Forms

text: are called gods or spirits; a rock, a tree, a spring, a pebble, a piece
title: Elementary Forms

text: of wood, a house, in a word, anything can be sacred. A rite can have
title: Elementary Forms

text: this character; in fact, the rite does not exist which does not have it
title: Elementary Forms

text: to a certain degree. There are words, expressions and formulae which can
title: Elementary Forms

text: be pronounced only by the mouths of consecrated persons; there are
title: Elementary Forms

text: gestures and movements which everybody cannot perform. If the Vedic
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacrifice has had such an efficacy that, according to mythology, it was
title: Elementary Forms

text: the creator of the gods, and not merely a means of winning their favour,
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is because it possessed a virtue comparable to that of the most
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacred beings. The circle of sacred objects cannot be determined, then,
title: Elementary Forms

text: once for all. Its extent varies infinitely, according to the different
title: Elementary Forms

text: religions. That is how Buddhism is a religion: in default of gods, it
title: Elementary Forms

text: admits the existence of sacred things, namely, the four noble truths and
title: Elementary Forms

text: the practices derived from them.[65]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Up to the present we have confined ourselves to enumerating a certain
title: Elementary Forms

text: number of sacred things as examples: we must now show by what general
title: Elementary Forms

text: characteristics they are to be distinguished from profane things.
title: Elementary Forms

text: One might be tempted, first of all, to define them by the place they are
title: Elementary Forms

text: generally assigned in the hierarchy of things. They are naturally
title: Elementary Forms

text: considered superior in dignity and power to profane things, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: particularly to man, when he is only a man and has nothing sacred about
title: Elementary Forms

text: him. One thinks of himself as occupying an inferior and dependent
title: Elementary Forms

text: position in relation to them; and surely this conception is not without
title: Elementary Forms

text: some truth. Only there is nothing in it which is really characteristic
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the sacred. It is not enough that one thing be subordinated to
title: Elementary Forms

text: another for the second to be sacred in regard to the first. Slaves are
title: Elementary Forms

text: inferior to their masters, subjects to their king, soldiers to their
title: Elementary Forms

text: leaders, the miser to his gold, the man ambitious for power to the hands
title: Elementary Forms

text: which keep it from him; but if it is sometimes said of a man that he
title: Elementary Forms

text: makes a religion of those beings or things whose eminent value and
title: Elementary Forms

text: superiority to himself he thus recognizes, it is clear that in any case
title: Elementary Forms

text: the word is taken in a metaphorical sense, and that there is nothing in
title: Elementary Forms

text: these relations which is really religious.[66]
title: Elementary Forms

text: On the other hand, it must not be lost to view that there are sacred
title: Elementary Forms

text: things of every degree, and that there are some in relation to which a
title: Elementary Forms

text: man feels himself relatively at his ease. An amulet has a sacred
title: Elementary Forms

text: character, yet the respect which it inspires is nothing exceptional.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Even before his gods, a man is not always in such a marked state of
title: Elementary Forms

text: inferiority; for it very frequently happens that he exercises a
title: Elementary Forms

text: veritable physical constraint upon them to obtain what he desires. He
title: Elementary Forms

text: beats the fetich with which he is not contented, but only to reconcile
title: Elementary Forms

text: himself with it again, if in the end it shows itself more docile to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: wishes of its adorer.[67] To have rain, he throws stones into the spring
title: Elementary Forms

text: or sacred lake where the god of rain is thought to reside; he believes
title: Elementary Forms

text: that by this means he forces him to come out and show himself.[68]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Moreover, if it is true that man depends upon his gods, this dependence
title: Elementary Forms

text: is reciprocal. The gods also have need of man; without offerings and
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacrifices they would die. We shall even have occasion to show that this
title: Elementary Forms

text: dependence of the gods upon their worshippers is maintained even in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: most idealistic religions.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But if a purely hierarchic distinction is a criterium at once too
title: Elementary Forms

text: general and too imprecise, there is nothing left with which to
title: Elementary Forms

text: characterize the sacred in its relation to the profane except their
title: Elementary Forms

text: heterogeneity. However, this heterogeneity is sufficient to characterize
title: Elementary Forms

text: this classification of things and to distinguish it from all others,
title: Elementary Forms

text: because it is very particular: _it is absolute_. In all the history of
title: Elementary Forms

text: human thought there exists no other example of two categories of things
title: Elementary Forms

text: so profoundly differentiated or so radically opposed to one another. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: traditional opposition of good and bad is nothing beside this; for the
title: Elementary Forms

text: good and the bad are only two opposed species of the same class, namely
title: Elementary Forms

text: morals, just as sickness and health are two different aspects of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: same order of facts, life, while the sacred and the profane have always
title: Elementary Forms

text: and everywhere been conceived by the human mind as two distinct classes,
title: Elementary Forms

text: as two worlds between which there is nothing in common. The forces
title: Elementary Forms

text: which play in one are not simply those which are met with in the other,
title: Elementary Forms

text: but a little stronger; they are of a different sort. In different
title: Elementary Forms

text: religions, this opposition has been conceived in different ways. Here,
title: Elementary Forms

text: to separate these two sorts of things, it has seemed sufficient to
title: Elementary Forms

text: localize them in different parts of the physical universe; there, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: first have been put into an ideal and transcendental world, while the
title: Elementary Forms

text: material world is left in full possession of the others. But howsoever
title: Elementary Forms

text: much the forms of the contrast may vary,[69] the fact of the contrast is
title: Elementary Forms

text: universal.
title: Elementary Forms

text: This is not equivalent to saying that a being can never pass from one of
title: Elementary Forms

text: these worlds into the other: but the manner in which this passage is
title: Elementary Forms

text: effected, when it does take place, puts into relief the essential
title: Elementary Forms

text: duality of the two kingdoms. In fact, it implies a veritable
title: Elementary Forms

text: metamorphosis. This is notably demonstrated by the initiation rites,
title: Elementary Forms

text: such as they are practised by a multitude of peoples. This initiation is
title: Elementary Forms

text: a long series of ceremonies with the object of introducing the young man
title: Elementary Forms

text: into the religious life: for the first time, he leaves the purely
title: Elementary Forms

text: profane world where he passed his first infancy, and enters into the
title: Elementary Forms

text: world of sacred things. Now this change of state is thought of, not as a
title: Elementary Forms

text: simple and regular development of pre-existent germs, but as a
title: Elementary Forms

text: transformation _totius substantiae_--of the whole being. It is said that
title: Elementary Forms

text: at this moment the young man dies, that the person that he was ceases to
title: Elementary Forms

text: exist, and that another is instantly substituted for it. He is re-born
title: Elementary Forms

text: under a new form. Appropriate ceremonies are felt to bring about this
title: Elementary Forms

text: death and re-birth, which are not understood in a merely symbolic sense,
title: Elementary Forms

text: but are taken literally.[70] Does this not prove that between the
title: Elementary Forms

text: profane being which he was and the religious being which he becomes,
title: Elementary Forms

text: there is a break of continuity?
title: Elementary Forms

text: This heterogeneity is even so complete that it frequently degenerates
title: Elementary Forms

text: into a veritable antagonism. The two worlds are not only conceived of as
title: Elementary Forms

text: separate, but as even hostile and jealous rivals of each other. Since
title: Elementary Forms

text: men cannot fully belong to one except on condition of leaving the other
title: Elementary Forms

text: completely, they are exhorted to withdraw themselves completely from the
title: Elementary Forms

text: profane world, in order to lead an exclusively religious life. Hence
title: Elementary Forms

text: comes the monasticism which is artificially organized outside of and
title: Elementary Forms

text: apart from the natural environment in which the ordinary man leads the
title: Elementary Forms

text: life of this world, in a different one, closed to the first, and nearly
title: Elementary Forms

text: its contrary. Hence comes the mystic asceticism whose object is to root
title: Elementary Forms

text: out from man all the attachment for the profane world that remains in
title: Elementary Forms

text: him. From that come all the forms of religious suicide, the logical
title: Elementary Forms

text: working-out of this asceticism; for the only manner of fully escaping
title: Elementary Forms

text: the profane life is, after all, to forsake all life.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The opposition of these two classes manifests itself outwardly with a
title: Elementary Forms

text: visible sign by which we can easily recognize this very special
title: Elementary Forms

text: classification, wherever it exists. Since the idea of the sacred is
title: Elementary Forms

text: always and everywhere separated from the idea of the profane in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: thought of men, and since we picture a sort of logical chasm between the
title: Elementary Forms

text: two, the mind irresistibly refuses to allow the two corresponding things
title: Elementary Forms

text: to be confounded, or even to be merely put in contact with each other;
title: Elementary Forms

text: for such a promiscuity, or even too direct a contiguity, would
title: Elementary Forms

text: contradict too violently the dissociation of these ideas in the mind.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The sacred thing is _par excellence_ that which the profane should not
title: Elementary Forms

text: touch, and cannot touch with impunity. To be sure, this interdiction
title: Elementary Forms

text: cannot go so far as to make all communication between the two worlds
title: Elementary Forms

text: impossible; for if the profane could in no way enter into relations with
title: Elementary Forms

text: the sacred, this latter could be good for nothing. But, in addition to
title: Elementary Forms

text: the fact that this establishment of relations is always a delicate
title: Elementary Forms

text: operation in itself, demanding great precautions and a more or less
title: Elementary Forms

text: complicated initiation,[71] it is quite impossible, unless the profane
title: Elementary Forms

text: is to lose its specific characteristics and become sacred after a
title: Elementary Forms

text: fashion and to a certain degree itself. The two classes cannot even
title: Elementary Forms

text: approach each other and keep their own nature at the same time.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Thus we arrive at the first criterium of religious beliefs. Undoubtedly
title: Elementary Forms

text: there are secondary species within these two fundamental classes which,
title: Elementary Forms

text: in their turn, are more or less incompatible with each other.[72] But
title: Elementary Forms

text: the real characteristic of religious phenomena is that they always
title: Elementary Forms

text: suppose a bipartite division of the whole universe, known and knowable,
title: Elementary Forms

text: into two classes which embrace all that exists, but which radically
title: Elementary Forms

text: exclude each other. Sacred things are those which the interdictions
title: Elementary Forms

text: protect and isolate; profane things, those to which these interdictions
title: Elementary Forms

text: are applied and which must remain at a distance from the first.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Religious beliefs are the representations which express the nature of
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacred things and the relations which they sustain, either with each
title: Elementary Forms

text: other or with profane things. Finally, rites are the rules of conduct
title: Elementary Forms

text: which prescribe how a man should comport himself in the presence of
title: Elementary Forms

text: these sacred objects.
title: Elementary Forms

text: When a certain number of sacred things sustain relations of
title: Elementary Forms

text: co-ordination or subordination with each other in such a way as to form
title: Elementary Forms

text: a system having a certain unity, but which is not comprised within any
title: Elementary Forms

text: other system of the same sort, the totality of these beliefs and their
title: Elementary Forms

text: corresponding rites constitutes a religion. From this definition it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: seen that a religion is not necessarily contained within one sole and
title: Elementary Forms

text: single idea, and does not proceed from one unique principle which,
title: Elementary Forms

text: though varying according to the circumstances under which it is applied,
title: Elementary Forms

text: is nevertheless at bottom always the same: it is rather a whole made up
title: Elementary Forms

text: of distinct and relatively individualized parts. Each homogeneous group
title: Elementary Forms

text: of sacred things, or even each sacred thing of some importance,
title: Elementary Forms

text: constitutes a centre of organization about which gravitate a group of
title: Elementary Forms

text: beliefs and rites, or a particular cult; there is no religion, howsoever
title: Elementary Forms

text: unified it may be, which does not recognize a plurality of sacred
title: Elementary Forms

text: things. Even Christianity, at least in its Catholic form, admits, in
title: Elementary Forms

text: addition to the divine personality which, incidentally, is triple as
title: Elementary Forms

text: well as one, the Virgin, angels, saints, souls of the dead, etc. Thus a
title: Elementary Forms

text: religion cannot be reduced to one single cult generally, but father
title: Elementary Forms

text: consists in a system of cults, each endowed with a certain autonomy.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Also, this autonomy is variable. Sometimes they are arranged in a
title: Elementary Forms

text: hierarchy, and subordinated to some predominating cult, into which they
title: Elementary Forms

text: are finally absorbed; but sometimes, also, they are merely rearranged
title: Elementary Forms

text: and united. The religion which we are going to study will furnish us
title: Elementary Forms

text: with an example of just this latter sort of organization.
title: Elementary Forms

text: At the same time we find the explanation of how there can be groups of
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious phenomena which do not belong to any special religion; it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: because they have not been, or are no longer, a part of any religious
title: Elementary Forms

text: system. If, for some special reason, one of the cults of which we just
title: Elementary Forms

text: spoke happens to be maintained while the group of which it was a part
title: Elementary Forms

text: disappears, it survives only in a disintegrated condition. That is what
title: Elementary Forms

text: has happened to many agrarian cults which have survived themselves as
title: Elementary Forms

text: folk-lore. In certain cases, it is not even a cult, but a simple
title: Elementary Forms

text: ceremony or particular rite which persists in this way.[73]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Although this definition is only preliminary, it permits us to see in
title: Elementary Forms

text: what terms the problem which necessarily dominates the science of
title: Elementary Forms

text: religions should be stated. When we believed that sacred beings could be
title: Elementary Forms

text: distinguished from others merely by the greater intensity of the powers
title: Elementary Forms

text: attributed to them, the question of how men came to imagine them was
title: Elementary Forms

text: sufficiently simple: it was enough to demand which forces had, because
title: Elementary Forms

text: of their exceptional energy, been able to strike the human imagination
title: Elementary Forms

text: forcefully enough to inspire religious sentiments. But if, as we have
title: Elementary Forms

text: sought to establish, sacred things differ in nature from profane things,
title: Elementary Forms

text: if they have a wholly different essence, then the problem is more
title: Elementary Forms

text: complex. For we must first of all ask what has been able to lead men to
title: Elementary Forms

text: see in the world two heterogeneous and incompatible worlds, though
title: Elementary Forms

text: nothing sensible experience seems able to suggest the idea of so radical
title: Elementary Forms

text: a duality to them.
title: Elementary Forms

text: IV
title: Elementary Forms

text: However, this definition is not yet complete, for it is equally
title: Elementary Forms

text: applicable to two sorts of facts which, while being related to each
title: Elementary Forms

text: other, must be distinguished nevertheless: these are magic and religion.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Magic, too, is made up of beliefs and rites. Like religion, it has its
title: Elementary Forms

text: myths and its dogmas; only they are more elementary, undoubtedly
title: Elementary Forms

text: because, seeking technical and utilitarian ends, it does not waste its
title: Elementary Forms

text: time in pure speculation. It has its ceremonies, sacrifices,
title: Elementary Forms

text: lustrations, prayers, chants and dances as well. The beings which the
title: Elementary Forms

text: magician invokes and the forces which he throws in play are not merely
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the same nature as the forces and beings to which religion addresses
title: Elementary Forms

text: itself; very frequently, they are identically the same. Thus, even with
title: Elementary Forms

text: the most inferior societies, the souls of the dead are essentially
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacred things, and the object of religious rites. But at the same time,
title: Elementary Forms

text: they play a considerable role in magic. In Australia[74] as well as in
title: Elementary Forms

text: Melanesia,[75] in Greece as well as among the Christian peoples,[76] the
title: Elementary Forms

text: souls of the dead, their bones and their hair, are among the
title: Elementary Forms

text: intermediaries used the most frequently by the magician. Demons are also
title: Elementary Forms

text: a common instrument for magic action. Now these demons are also beings
title: Elementary Forms

text: surrounded with interdictions; they too are separated and live in a
title: Elementary Forms

text: world apart, so that it is frequently difficult to distinguish them
title: Elementary Forms

text: from the gods properly so-called.[77] Moreover, in Christianity itself,
title: Elementary Forms

text: is not the devil a fallen god, or even leaving aside all question of his
title: Elementary Forms

text: origin, does he not have a religious character from the mere fact that
title: Elementary Forms

text: the hell of which he has charge is something indispensable to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Christian religion? There are even some regular and official deities who
title: Elementary Forms

text: are invoked by the magician. Sometimes these are the gods of a foreign
title: Elementary Forms

text: people; for example, Greek magicians called upon Egyptian, Assyrian or
title: Elementary Forms

text: Jewish gods. Sometimes, they are even national gods: Hecate and Diana
title: Elementary Forms

text: were the object of a magic cult; the Virgin, Christ and the saints have
title: Elementary Forms

text: been utilized in the same way by Christian magicians.[78]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Then will it be necessary to say that magic is hardly distinguishable
title: Elementary Forms

text: from religion; that magic is full of religion just as religion is full
title: Elementary Forms

text: of magic, and consequently that it is impossible to separate them and to
title: Elementary Forms

text: define the one without the other? It is difficult to sustain this
title: Elementary Forms

text: thesis, because of the marked repugnance of religion for magic, and in
title: Elementary Forms

text: return, the hostility of the second towards the first. Magic takes a
title: Elementary Forms

text: sort of professional pleasure in profaning holy things;[79] in its
title: Elementary Forms

text: rites, it performs the contrary of the religious ceremony.[80] On its
title: Elementary Forms

text: side, religion, when it has not condemned and prohibited magic rites,
title: Elementary Forms

text: has always looked upon them with disfavour. As Hubert and Mauss have
title: Elementary Forms

text: remarked, there is something thoroughly anti-religious in the doings of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the magician.[81] Whatever relations there may be between these two
title: Elementary Forms

text: sorts of institutions, it is difficult to imagine their not being
title: Elementary Forms

text: opposed somewhere; and it is still more necessary for us to find where
title: Elementary Forms

text: they are differentiated, as we plan to limit our researches to religion,
title: Elementary Forms

text: and to stop at the point where magic commences.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Here is how a line of demarcation can be traced between these two
title: Elementary Forms

text: domains.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The really religious beliefs are always common to a determined group,
title: Elementary Forms

text: which makes profession of adhering to them and of practising the rites
title: Elementary Forms

text: connected with them. They are not merely received individually by all
title: Elementary Forms

text: the members of this group; they are something belonging to the group,
title: Elementary Forms

text: and they make its unity. The individuals which compose it feel
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves united to each other by the simple fact that they have a
title: Elementary Forms

text: common faith. A society whose members are united by the fact that they
title: Elementary Forms

text: think in the same way in regard to the sacred world and its relations
title: Elementary Forms

text: with the profane world, and by the fact that they translate these common
title: Elementary Forms

text: ideas into common practices, is what is called a Church. In all history,
title: Elementary Forms

text: we do not find a single religion without a Church. Sometimes the Church
title: Elementary Forms

text: is strictly national, sometimes it passes the frontiers; sometimes it
title: Elementary Forms

text: embraces an entire people (Rome, Athens, the Hebrews), sometimes it
title: Elementary Forms

text: embraces only a part of them (the Christian societies since the advent
title: Elementary Forms

text: of Protestantism); sometimes it is directed by a corps of priests,
title: Elementary Forms

text: sometimes it is almost completely devoid of any official directing
title: Elementary Forms

text: body.[82] But wherever we observe the religious life, we find that it
title: Elementary Forms

text: has a definite group as its foundation. Even the so-called private
title: Elementary Forms

text: cults, such as the domestic cult or the cult of a corporation, satisfy
title: Elementary Forms

text: this condition; for they are always celebrated by a group, the family or
title: Elementary Forms

text: the corporation. Moreover, even these particular religions are
title: Elementary Forms

text: ordinarily only special forms of a more general religion which embraces
title: Elementary Forms

text: all;[83] these restricted Churches are in reality only chapels of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: vaster Church which, by reason of this very extent, merits this name
title: Elementary Forms

text: still more.[84]
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is quite another matter with magic. To be sure, the belief in magic
title: Elementary Forms

text: is always more or less general; it is very frequently diffused in large
title: Elementary Forms

text: masses of the population, and there are even peoples where it has as
title: Elementary Forms

text: many adherents as the real religion. But it does not result in binding
title: Elementary Forms

text: together those who adhere to it, nor in uniting them into a group
title: Elementary Forms

text: leading a common life. _There is no Church of magic._ Between the
title: Elementary Forms

text: magician and the individuals who consult him, as between these
title: Elementary Forms

text: individuals themselves, there are no lasting bonds which make them
title: Elementary Forms

text: members of the same moral community, comparable to that formed by the
title: Elementary Forms

text: believers in the same god or the observers of the same cult. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: magician has a clientele and not a Church, and it is very possible that
title: Elementary Forms

text: his clients have no other relations between each other, or even do not
title: Elementary Forms

text: know each other; even the relations which they have with him are
title: Elementary Forms

text: generally accidental and transient; they are just like those of a sick
title: Elementary Forms

text: man with his physician. The official and public character with which he
title: Elementary Forms

text: is sometimes invested changes nothing in this situation; the fact that
title: Elementary Forms

text: he works openly does not unite him more regularly or more durably to
title: Elementary Forms

text: those who have recourse to his services.
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is true that in certain cases, magicians form societies among
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves: it happens that they assemble more or less periodically to
title: Elementary Forms

text: celebrate certain rites in common; it is well known what a place these
title: Elementary Forms

text: assemblies of witches hold in European folk-lore. But it is to be
title: Elementary Forms

text: remarked that these associations are in no way indispensable to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: working of the magic; they are even rare and rather exceptional. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: magician has no need of uniting himself to his fellows to practise his
title: Elementary Forms

text: art. More frequently, he is a recluse; in general, far from seeking
title: Elementary Forms

text: society, he flees it. "Even in regard to his colleagues, he always keeps
title: Elementary Forms

text: his personal independence."[85] Religion, on the other hand, is
title: Elementary Forms

text: inseparable from the idea of a Church. From this point of view, there is
title: Elementary Forms

text: an essential difference between magic and religion. But what is
title: Elementary Forms

text: especially important is that when these societies of magic are formed,
title: Elementary Forms

text: they do not include all the adherents to magic, but only the magicians;
title: Elementary Forms

text: the laymen, if they may be so called, that is to say, those for whose
title: Elementary Forms

text: profit the rites are celebrated, in fine, those who represent the
title: Elementary Forms

text: worshippers in the regular cults, are excluded. Now the magician is for
title: Elementary Forms

text: magic what the priest is for religion, but a college of priests is not a
title: Elementary Forms

text: Church, any more than a religious congregation which should devote
title: Elementary Forms

text: itself to some particular saint in the shadow of a cloister, would be a
title: Elementary Forms

text: particular cult. A Church is not a fraternity of priests; it is a moral
title: Elementary Forms

text: community formed by all the believers in a single faith, laymen as well
title: Elementary Forms

text: as priests. But magic lacks any such community.[86]
title: Elementary Forms

text: But if the idea of a Church is made to enter into the definition of
title: Elementary Forms

text: religion, does that not exclude the private religions which the
title: Elementary Forms

text: individual establishes for himself and celebrates by himself? There is
title: Elementary Forms

text: scarcely a society where these are not found. Every Ojibway, as we shall
title: Elementary Forms

text: see below, has his own personal _manitou_, which he chooses himself and
title: Elementary Forms

text: to which he renders special religious services; the Melanesian of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Banks Islands has his _tamaniu_;[87] the Roman, his _genius_;[88] the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Christian, his patron saint and guardian angel, etc. By definition all
title: Elementary Forms

text: these cults seem to be independent of all idea of the group. Not only
title: Elementary Forms

text: are these individual religions very frequent in history, but nowadays
title: Elementary Forms

text: many are asking if they are not destined to be the pre-eminent form of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the religious life, and if the day will not come when there will be no
title: Elementary Forms

text: other cult than that which each man will freely perform within
title: Elementary Forms

text: himself.[89]
title: Elementary Forms

text: But if we leave these speculations in regard to the future aside for the
title: Elementary Forms

text: moment, and confine ourselves to religions such as they are at present
title: Elementary Forms

text: or have been in the past, it becomes clearly evident that these
title: Elementary Forms

text: individual cults are not distinct and autonomous religious systems, but
title: Elementary Forms

text: merely aspects of the common religion of the whole Church, of which the
title: Elementary Forms

text: individuals are members. The patron saint of the Christian is chosen
title: Elementary Forms

text: from the official list of saints recognized by the Catholic Church;
title: Elementary Forms

text: there are even canonical rules prescribing how each Catholic should
title: Elementary Forms

text: perform this private cult. In the same way, the idea that each man
title: Elementary Forms

text: necessarily has a protecting genius is found, under different forms, at
title: Elementary Forms

text: the basis of a great number of American religions, as well as of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Roman religion (to cite only these two examples); for, as will be seen
title: Elementary Forms

text: later, it is very closely connected with the idea of the soul, and this
title: Elementary Forms

text: idea of the soul is not one of those which can be left entirely to
title: Elementary Forms

text: individual choice. In a word, it is the Church of which he is a member
title: Elementary Forms

text: which teaches the individual what these personal gods are, what their
title: Elementary Forms

text: function is, how he should enter into relations with them and how he
title: Elementary Forms

text: should honour them. When a methodical analysis is made of the doctrines
title: Elementary Forms

text: of any Church whatsoever, sooner or later we come upon those concerning
title: Elementary Forms

text: private cults. So these are not two religions of different types, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: turned in opposite directions; both are made up of the same ideas and
title: Elementary Forms

text: the same principles, here applied to circumstances which are of interest
title: Elementary Forms

text: to the group as a whole, there to the life of the individual. This
title: Elementary Forms

text: solidarity is even so close that among certain peoples,[90] the
title: Elementary Forms

text: ceremonies by which the faithful first enter into communication with
title: Elementary Forms

text: their protecting geniuses are mixed with rites whose public character is
title: Elementary Forms

text: incontestable, namely the rites of initiation.[91]
title: Elementary Forms

text: There still remain those contemporary aspirations towards a religion
title: Elementary Forms

text: which would consist entirely in internal and subjective states, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: which would be constructed freely by each of us. But howsoever real
title: Elementary Forms

text: these aspirations may be, they cannot affect our definition, for this is
title: Elementary Forms

text: to be applied only to facts already realized, and not to uncertain
title: Elementary Forms

text: possibilities. One can define religions such as they are, or such as
title: Elementary Forms

text: they have been, but not such as they more or less vaguely tend to
title: Elementary Forms

text: become. It is possible that this religious individualism is destined to
title: Elementary Forms

text: be realized in facts; but before we can say just how far this may be the
title: Elementary Forms

text: case, we must first know what religion is, of what elements it is made
title: Elementary Forms

text: up, from what causes it results, and what function it fulfils--all
title: Elementary Forms

text: questions whose solution cannot be foreseen before the threshold of our
title: Elementary Forms

text: study has been passed. It is only at the close of this study that we can
title: Elementary Forms

text: attempt to anticipate the future.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Thus we arrive at the following definition: _A religion is a unified
title: Elementary Forms

text: system of beliefs and practices relative to sacred things, that is to
title: Elementary Forms

text: say, things set apart and forbidden--beliefs and practices which unite
title: Elementary Forms

text: into one single moral community called a Church, all those who adhere to
title: Elementary Forms

text: them._ The second element which thus finds a place in our definition is
title: Elementary Forms

text: no less essential than the first; for by showing that the idea of
title: Elementary Forms

text: religion is inseparable from that of the Church, it makes it clear that
title: Elementary Forms

text: religion should be an eminently collective thing.[92]
title: Elementary Forms

text: CHAPTER II
title: Elementary Forms

text: LEADING CONCEPTIONS OF THE ELEMENTARY RELIGION
title: Elementary Forms

text: I.--_Animism_
title: Elementary Forms

text: Armed with this definition, we are now able to set out in search of this
title: Elementary Forms

text: elementary religion which we propose to study.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Even the crudest religions with which history and ethnology make us
title: Elementary Forms

text: acquainted are already of a complexity which corresponds badly with the
title: Elementary Forms

text: idea sometimes held of primitive mentality. One finds there not only a
title: Elementary Forms

text: confused system of beliefs and rites, but also such a plurality of
title: Elementary Forms

text: different principles, and such a richness of essential notions, that it
title: Elementary Forms

text: seems impossible to see in them anything but the late product of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: rather long evolution. Hence it has been concluded that to discover the
title: Elementary Forms

text: truly original form of the religious life, it is necessary to descend by
title: Elementary Forms

text: analysis beyond these observable religions, to resolve them into their
title: Elementary Forms

text: common and fundamental elements, and then to seek among these latter
title: Elementary Forms

text: some one from which the others were derived.
title: Elementary Forms

text: To the problem thus stated, two contrary solutions have been given.
title: Elementary Forms

text: There is no religious system, ancient or recent, where one does not
title: Elementary Forms

text: meet, under different forms, two religions, as it were, side by side,
title: Elementary Forms

text: which, though being united closely and mutually penetrating each other,
title: Elementary Forms

text: do not cease, nevertheless, to be distinct. The one addresses itself to
title: Elementary Forms

text: the phenomena of nature, either the great cosmic forces, such as winds,
title: Elementary Forms

text: rivers, stars or the sky, etc., or else the objects of various sorts
title: Elementary Forms

text: which cover the surface of the earth, such as plants, animals, rocks,
title: Elementary Forms

text: etc.; for this reason it has been given the name of _naturism_. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: other has spiritual beings as its object, spirits, souls, geniuses,
title: Elementary Forms

text: demons, divinities properly so-called, animated and conscious agents
title: Elementary Forms

text: like man, but distinguished from him, nevertheless, by the nature of
title: Elementary Forms

text: their powers and especially by the peculiar characteristic that they do
title: Elementary Forms

text: not affect the senses in the same way: ordinarily they are not visible
title: Elementary Forms

text: to human eyes. This religion of spirits is called _animism_. Now, to
title: Elementary Forms

text: explain the universal co-existence of these two sorts of cults, two
title: Elementary Forms

text: contradictory theories have been proposed. For some, animism is the
title: Elementary Forms

text: primitive religion, of which naturism is only a secondary and derived
title: Elementary Forms

text: form. For the others, on the contrary, it is the nature cult which was
title: Elementary Forms

text: the point of departure for religious evolution; the cult of spirits is
title: Elementary Forms

text: only a peculiar case of that.
title: Elementary Forms

text: These two theories are, up to the present, the only ones by which the
title: Elementary Forms

text: attempt has been made to explain rationally[93] the origins of religious
title: Elementary Forms

text: thought. Thus the capital problem raised by the history of religions is
title: Elementary Forms

text: generally reduced to asking which of these two solutions should be
title: Elementary Forms

text: chosen, or whether it is not better to combine them, and in that case,
title: Elementary Forms

text: what place must be given to each of the two elements.[94] Even those
title: Elementary Forms

text: scholars who do not admit either of these hypotheses in their systematic
title: Elementary Forms

text: form, do not refuse to retain certain propositions upon which they
title: Elementary Forms

text: rest.[95] Thus we have a certain number of theories already made, which
title: Elementary Forms

text: must be submitted to criticism before we take up the study of the facts
title: Elementary Forms

text: for ourselves. It will be better understood how indispensable it is to
title: Elementary Forms

text: attempt a new one, when we have seen the insufficiency of these
title: Elementary Forms

text: traditional conceptions.
title: Elementary Forms

text: I
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is Tylor who formed the animist theory in its essential outlines.[96]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Spencer, who took it up after him, did not reproduce it without
title: Elementary Forms

text: introducing certain modifications.[97] But in general the questions are
title: Elementary Forms

text: posed by each in the same terms, and the solutions accepted are, with a
title: Elementary Forms

text: single exception, identically the same. Therefore we can unite these two
title: Elementary Forms

text: doctrines in the exposition which follows, if we mark, at the proper
title: Elementary Forms

text: moment, the place where the two diverge from one another.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In order to find the elementary form of the religious life in these
title: Elementary Forms

text: animistic beliefs and practices, three _desiderata_ must be satisfied:
title: Elementary Forms

text: first, since according to this hypothesis, the idea of the soul is the
title: Elementary Forms

text: cardinal idea of religion, it must be shown how this is formed without
title: Elementary Forms

text: taking any of its elements from an anterior religion; secondly, it must
title: Elementary Forms

text: be made clear how souls become the object of a cult and are transformed
title: Elementary Forms

text: into spirits; and thirdly and finally, since the cult of these spirits
title: Elementary Forms

text: is not all of any religion, it remains to be explained how the cult of
title: Elementary Forms

text: nature is derived from it.
title: Elementary Forms

text: According to this theory, the idea of the soul was first suggested to
title: Elementary Forms

text: men by the badly understood spectacle of the double life they ordinarily
title: Elementary Forms

text: lead, on the one hand, when awake, on the other, when asleep. In fact,
title: Elementary Forms

text: for the savage,[98] the mental representations which he has while awake
title: Elementary Forms
