text: and those of his dreams are said to be of the same value: he objectifies
title: Elementary Forms

text: the second like the first, that is to say, that he sees in them the
title: Elementary Forms

text: images of external objects whose appearance they more or less accurately
title: Elementary Forms

text: reproduce. So when he dreams that he has visited a distant country, he
title: Elementary Forms

text: believes that he really was there. But he could not have gone there,
title: Elementary Forms

text: unless two beings exist within him: the one, his body, which has
title: Elementary Forms

text: remained lying on the ground and which he finds in the same position on
title: Elementary Forms

text: awakening; the other, during this time, has travelled through space.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Similarly, if he seems to talk with one of his companions who he knows
title: Elementary Forms

text: was really at a distance, he concludes that the other also is composed
title: Elementary Forms

text: of two beings: one which sleeps at a distance, and another which has
title: Elementary Forms

text: come to manifest himself by means of the dream. From these repeated
title: Elementary Forms

text: experiences, he little by little arrives at the idea that each of us has
title: Elementary Forms

text: a double, another self, which in determined conditions has the power of
title: Elementary Forms

text: leaving the organism where it resides and of going roaming at a
title: Elementary Forms

text: distance.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Of course, this double reproduces all the essential traits of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: perceptible being which serves it as external covering; but at the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: time it is distinguished from this by many characteristics. It is more
title: Elementary Forms

text: active, since it can cover vast distances in an instant. It is more
title: Elementary Forms

text: malleable and plastic; for, to leave the body, it must pass out by its
title: Elementary Forms

text: apertures, especially the mouth and nose. It is represented as made of
title: Elementary Forms

text: matter, undoubtedly, but of a matter much more subtile and etherial than
title: Elementary Forms

text: any which we know empirically. This double is the soul. In fact, it
title: Elementary Forms

text: cannot be doubted that in numerous societies the soul has been conceived
title: Elementary Forms

text: in the image of the body; it is believed that it reproduces even the
title: Elementary Forms

text: accidental deformities such as those resulting from wounds or
title: Elementary Forms

text: mutilations. Certain Australians, after having killed their enemy, cut
title: Elementary Forms

text: off his right thumb, so that his soul, deprived of its thumb also,
title: Elementary Forms

text: cannot throw a javelin and revenge itself. But while it resembles the
title: Elementary Forms

text: body, it has, at the same time, something half spiritual about it. They
title: Elementary Forms

text: say that "it is the finer or more aeriform part of the body," that "it
title: Elementary Forms

text: has no flesh nor bone nor sinew"; that when one wishes to take hold of
title: Elementary Forms

text: it, he feels nothing; that it is "like a purified body."[99]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Also, other facts of experience which affect the mind in the same way
title: Elementary Forms

text: naturally group themselves around this fundamental fact taught by the
title: Elementary Forms

text: dream: fainting, apoplexy, catalepsy, ecstasy, in a word, all cases of
title: Elementary Forms

text: temporary insensibility. In fact, they all are explained very well by
title: Elementary Forms

text: the hypothesis that the principle of life and feeling is able to leave
title: Elementary Forms

text: the body momentarily. Also, it is natural that this principle should be
title: Elementary Forms

text: confounded with the double, since the absence of the double during sleep
title: Elementary Forms

text: daily has the effect of suspending thought and life. Thus diverse
title: Elementary Forms

text: observations seem to agree mutually and to confirm the idea of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: constitutional duality of man.[100]
title: Elementary Forms

text: But the soul is not a spirit. It is attached to a body which it can
title: Elementary Forms

text: leave only by exception; in so far as it is nothing more than that, it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is not the object of any cult. The spirit, on the other hand, though
title: Elementary Forms

text: generally having some special thing as its residence, can go away at
title: Elementary Forms

text: will, and a man can enter into relations with it only by observing
title: Elementary Forms

text: ritual precautions. The soul can become a spirit, then, only by
title: Elementary Forms

text: transforming itself: the simple application of these preceding ideas to
title: Elementary Forms

text: the fact of death produced this metamorphosis quite naturally. For a
title: Elementary Forms

text: rudimentary intelligence, in fact, death is not distinguished from a
title: Elementary Forms

text: long fainting swoon or a prolonged sleep; it has all their aspects. Thus
title: Elementary Forms

text: it seems that it too consists in a separation of the soul and the body,
title: Elementary Forms

text: analogous to that produced every night; but as in such cases, the body
title: Elementary Forms

text: is not reanimated, the idea is formed of a separation without an
title: Elementary Forms

text: assignable limit of time. When the body is once destroyed--and funeral
title: Elementary Forms

text: rites have the object of hastening this destruction--the separation is
title: Elementary Forms

text: taken as final. Hence come spirits detached from any organism and left
title: Elementary Forms

text: free in space. As their number augments with time, a population of
title: Elementary Forms

text: souls forms around the living population. These souls of men have the
title: Elementary Forms

text: needs and passions of men; they seek to concern themselves with the life
title: Elementary Forms

text: of their companions of yesterday, either to aid them or to injure them,
title: Elementary Forms

text: according to the sentiments which they have kept towards them. According
title: Elementary Forms

text: to the circumstances, their nature makes them either very precious
title: Elementary Forms

text: auxiliaries or very redoubtable adversaries. Owing to their extreme
title: Elementary Forms

text: fluidity, they can even enter into the body, and cause all sorts of
title: Elementary Forms

text: disorders there, or else increase its vitality. Thus comes the habit of
title: Elementary Forms

text: attributing to them all those events of life which vary slightly from
title: Elementary Forms

text: the ordinary: there are very few of these for which they cannot account.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Thus they constitute a sort of ever-ready supply of causes which never
title: Elementary Forms

text: leaves one at a loss when in search of explanations. Does a man appear
title: Elementary Forms

text: inspired, does he speak with energy, is it as though he were lifted
title: Elementary Forms

text: outside himself and above the ordinary level of men? It is because a
title: Elementary Forms

text: good spirit is in him and animates him. Is he overtaken by an attack or
title: Elementary Forms

text: seized by madness? It is because an evil spirit has entered into him and
title: Elementary Forms

text: brought him all this trouble. There are no maladies which cannot be
title: Elementary Forms

text: assigned to some influence of this sort. Thus the power of souls is
title: Elementary Forms

text: increased by all that men attribute to them, and in the end men find
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves the prisoners of this imaginary world of which they are,
title: Elementary Forms

text: however, the authors and the models. They fall into dependence upon
title: Elementary Forms

text: these spiritual forces which they have created with their own hands and
title: Elementary Forms

text: in their own image. For if souls are the givers of health and sickness,
title: Elementary Forms

text: of goods and evils to this extent, it is wise to conciliate their favour
title: Elementary Forms

text: or appease them when they are irritated; hence come the offerings,
title: Elementary Forms

text: prayers, sacrifices, in a word, all the apparatus of religious
title: Elementary Forms

text: observances.[101]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Here is the soul transformed. From a simple vital principle animating
title: Elementary Forms

text: the body of a man, it has become a spirit, a good or evil genius, or
title: Elementary Forms

text: even a deity, according to the importance of the effects with which it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is charged. But since it is death which brought about this apotheosis,
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is to the dead, to the souls of ancestors, that the first cult known
title: Elementary Forms

text: to humanity was addressed. Thus the first rites were funeral rites; the
title: Elementary Forms

text: first sacrifices were food offerings destined to satisfy the needs of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the departed; the first altars were tombs.[102]
title: Elementary Forms

text: But since these spirits were of human origin, they interested themselves
title: Elementary Forms

text: only in the life of men and were thought to act only upon human events.
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is still to be explained how other spirits were imagined to account
title: Elementary Forms

text: for the other phenomena of the universe and how the cult of nature was
title: Elementary Forms

text: subsequently formed beside that of the ancestors.
title: Elementary Forms

text: For Tylor, this extension of animism was due to the particular mentality
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the primitive who, like an infant, cannot distinguish the animate and
title: Elementary Forms

text: the inanimate. Since the first beings of which the child commences to
title: Elementary Forms

text: have an idea are men, that is, himself and those around him, it is upon
title: Elementary Forms

text: this model of human nature that he tends to think of everything. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: toys with which he plays, or the objects of every sort which affect his
title: Elementary Forms

text: senses, he regards as living beings like himself. Now the primitive
title: Elementary Forms

text: thinks like a child. Consequently, he also is inclined to endow all
title: Elementary Forms

text: things, even inanimate ones, with a nature analogous to his own. Then
title: Elementary Forms

text: if, for the reasons exposed above, he once arrives at the idea that man
title: Elementary Forms

text: is a body animated by a spirit, he must necessarily attribute a duality
title: Elementary Forms

text: of this sort and souls like his own even to inert bodies themselves. Yet
title: Elementary Forms

text: the sphere of action of the two could not be the same. The souls of men
title: Elementary Forms

text: have a direct influence only upon the world of men: they have a marked
title: Elementary Forms

text: preference for the human organism, even when death has given them their
title: Elementary Forms

text: liberty. On the other hand, the souls of things reside especially in
title: Elementary Forms

text: these things, and are regarded as the productive causes of all that
title: Elementary Forms

text: passes there. The first account for health and sickness, skilfulness or
title: Elementary Forms

text: unskilfulness, etc.; by the second are explained especially the
title: Elementary Forms

text: phenomena of the physical world, the movement of water-courses or the
title: Elementary Forms

text: stars, the germination of plants, the reproduction of animals, etc. Thus
title: Elementary Forms

text: the first philosophy of man, which is at the basis of the ancestor-cult,
title: Elementary Forms

text: is completed by a philosophy of the world.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In regard to these cosmic spirits, man finds himself in a state of
title: Elementary Forms

text: dependence still more evident than that in regard to the wandering
title: Elementary Forms

text: doubles of his ancestors. For he could have only ideal and imaginary
title: Elementary Forms

text: relations with the latter, but he depends upon things in reality; to
title: Elementary Forms

text: live, he has need of their concurrence; he then believes that he has an
title: Elementary Forms

text: equal need of the spirits which appear to animate these things and to
title: Elementary Forms

text: determine their diverse manifestations. He implores their assistance, he
title: Elementary Forms

text: solicits them with offerings and prayers, and the religion of man is
title: Elementary Forms

text: thus completed in a religion of nature.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Herbert Spencer objects against this explanation that the hypothesis
title: Elementary Forms

text: upon which it rests is contradicted by the facts. It is held, he says,
title: Elementary Forms

text: that there is a time when men do not realize the differences which
title: Elementary Forms

text: separate the animate from the inanimate. Now, as one advances in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: animal scale, he sees the ability to make this distinction develop. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: superior animals do not confound an object which moves of itself and
title: Elementary Forms

text: whose movements are adapted to certain ends, with those which are
title: Elementary Forms

text: mechanically moved from without. "Amusing herself with a mouse she has
title: Elementary Forms

text: caught, the cat, if it remains long stationary, touches it with her paw
title: Elementary Forms

text: to make it run. Obviously the thought is that a living thing disturbed
title: Elementary Forms

text: will try to escape."[103] Even the primitive men could not have an
title: Elementary Forms

text: intelligence inferior to that of the animals which preceded them in
title: Elementary Forms

text: evolution; then it cannot be for lack of discernment that they passed
title: Elementary Forms

text: from the cult of ancestors to the cult of things.
title: Elementary Forms

text: According to Spencer, who upon this point, but upon this point only,
title: Elementary Forms

text: differs from Tylor, this passage was certainly due to a confusion, but
title: Elementary Forms

text: to one of a different sort. It was, in a large part at least, the result
title: Elementary Forms

text: of numerous errors due to language. In many inferior societies it is a
title: Elementary Forms

text: very common custom to give to each individual, either at his birth or
title: Elementary Forms

text: later, the name of some animal, plant, star or natural object. But as a
title: Elementary Forms

text: consequence of the extreme imprecision of his language, it is very
title: Elementary Forms

text: difficult for a primitive to distinguish a metaphor from the reality. He
title: Elementary Forms

text: soon lost sight of the fact that these names were only figures, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: taking them literally, he ended by believing that an ancestor named
title: Elementary Forms

text: "Tiger" or "Lion" was really a tiger or a lion. Then the cult of which
title: Elementary Forms

text: the ancestor was the object up to that time, was changed over to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: animal with which he was thereafter confounded; and as the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: substitution went on for the plants, the stars and all the natural
title: Elementary Forms

text: phenomena, the religion of nature took the place of the old religion of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the dead. Besides this fundamental confusion, Spencer signalizes others
title: Elementary Forms

text: which aided the action of the first from time to time. For example, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: animals which frequent the surroundings of the tombs or houses of men
title: Elementary Forms

text: have been taken for their reincarnated souls, and adored under this
title: Elementary Forms

text: title;[104] or again, the mountain which tradition made the cradle of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the race was finally taken for the ancestor of the race; it was thought
title: Elementary Forms

text: that men were descended from it because their ancestors appeared coming
title: Elementary Forms

text: from it, and it was consequently treated as an ancestor itself.[105] But
title: Elementary Forms

text: according to the statement of Spencer, these accessory causes had only a
title: Elementary Forms

text: secondary influence; that which principally determined the institution
title: Elementary Forms

text: of naturism was "the literal interpretation of metaphorical names."[106]
title: Elementary Forms

text: We had to mention this theory to have our exposition of animism
title: Elementary Forms

text: complete; but it is too inadequate for the facts, and too universally
title: Elementary Forms

text: abandoned to-day to demand that we stop any longer for it. In order to
title: Elementary Forms

text: explain a fact as general as the religion of nature by an illusion, it
title: Elementary Forms

text: would be necessary that the illusion invoked should have causes of an
title: Elementary Forms

text: equal generality. Now even if misunderstandings, such as those of which
title: Elementary Forms

text: Spencer gives some rare illustrations, could explain the transformation
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the cult of ancestors into that of nature, it is not clear why this
title: Elementary Forms

text: should be produced with a sort of universality. No psychical mechanism
title: Elementary Forms

text: necessitated it. It is true that because of its ambiguity, the word
title: Elementary Forms

text: might lead to an equivocation; but on the other hand, all the personal
title: Elementary Forms

text: souvenirs left by the ancestor in the memories of men should oppose this
title: Elementary Forms

text: confusion. Why should the tradition which represented the ancestor such
title: Elementary Forms

text: as he really was, that is to say, as a man who led the life of a man,
title: Elementary Forms

text: everywhere give way before the prestige of a word? Likewise, one should
title: Elementary Forms

text: have a little difficulty in admitting that men were born of a mountain
title: Elementary Forms

text: or a star, of an animal or a plant; the idea of a similar exception to
title: Elementary Forms

text: the ordinary conceptions of generation could not fail to raise active
title: Elementary Forms

text: resistance. Thus, it is far from true that the error found a road all
title: Elementary Forms

text: prepared before it, but rather, all sorts of reasons should have kept it
title: Elementary Forms

text: from being accepted. It is difficult to understand how, in spite of all
title: Elementary Forms

text: these obstacles, it could have triumphed so generally.
title: Elementary Forms

text: II
title: Elementary Forms

text: The theory of Tylor, whose authority is always great, still remains. His
title: Elementary Forms

text: hypotheses on the dream and the origin of the ideas of the soul and of
title: Elementary Forms

text: spirits are still classic; it is necessary, therefore, to test their
title: Elementary Forms

text: value.
title: Elementary Forms

text: First of all, it should be recognized that the theorists of animism have
title: Elementary Forms

text: rendered an important service to the science of religions, and even to
title: Elementary Forms

text: the general history of ideas, by submitting the idea of the soul to
title: Elementary Forms

text: historical analysis. Instead of following so many philosophers and
title: Elementary Forms

text: making it a simple and immediate object of consciousness, they have much
title: Elementary Forms

text: more correctly viewed it as a complex whole, a product of history and
title: Elementary Forms

text: mythology. It cannot be doubted that it is something essentially
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious in its nature, origin and functions. It is from religion that
title: Elementary Forms

text: the philosophers received it; it is impossible to understand the form in
title: Elementary Forms

text: which it is represented by the thinkers of antiquity, if one does not
title: Elementary Forms

text: take into account the mythical elements which served in its formation.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But if Tylor has had the merit of raising this problem, the solution he
title: Elementary Forms

text: gives raises grave difficulties.
title: Elementary Forms

text: First of all, there are reservations to be made in regard to the very
title: Elementary Forms

text: principle which is at the basis of this theory. It is taken for granted
title: Elementary Forms

text: that the soul is entirely distinct from the body, that it is its double,
title: Elementary Forms

text: and that within it or outside of it, it normally lives its own
title: Elementary Forms

text: autonomous life. Now we shall see[107] that this conception is not that
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the primitive, or at least, that it only expresses one aspect of his
title: Elementary Forms

text: idea of the soul. For him, the soul, though being under certain
title: Elementary Forms

text: conditions independent of the organism which it animates, confounds
title: Elementary Forms

text: itself with this latter to such an extent that it cannot be radically
title: Elementary Forms

text: separated from it: there are organs which are not only its appointed
title: Elementary Forms

text: seat, but also its outward form and material manifestation. The notion
title: Elementary Forms

text: is therefore more complex than the doctrine supposes, and it is doubtful
title: Elementary Forms

text: consequently whether the experiences mentioned are sufficient to account
title: Elementary Forms

text: for it; for even if they did enable us to understand how men have come
title: Elementary Forms

text: to believe themselves double, they cannot explain how this duality does
title: Elementary Forms

text: not exclude, but rather, implies a deeper unity and an intimate
title: Elementary Forms

text: interpenetration of the two beings thus differentiated.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But let us admit that the idea of the soul can be reduced to the idea of
title: Elementary Forms

text: a double, and then see how this latter came to be formed. It could not
title: Elementary Forms

text: have been suggested to men except by the experience of dreams. That they
title: Elementary Forms

text: might understand how they could see places more or less distant during
title: Elementary Forms

text: sleep, while their bodies remained lying on the ground, it would seem
title: Elementary Forms

text: that they were led to conceive of themselves as two beings: on the one
title: Elementary Forms

text: hand, the body, and on the other, a second self, able to leave the
title: Elementary Forms

text: organism in which it lives and to roam about in space. But if this
title: Elementary Forms

text: hypothesis of a double is to be able to impose itself upon men with a
title: Elementary Forms

text: sort of necessity, it should be the only one possible, or at least, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: most economical one. Now as a matter of fact, there are more simple ones
title: Elementary Forms

text: which, it would seem, might have occurred to the mind just as naturally.
title: Elementary Forms

text: For example, why should the sleeper not imagine that while asleep he is
title: Elementary Forms

text: able to see things at a distance? To imagine such a power would demand
title: Elementary Forms

text: less expense to the imagination than the construction of this complex
title: Elementary Forms

text: notion of a double, made of some etherial, semi-invisible substance, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: of which direct experience offers no example. But even supposing that
title: Elementary Forms

text: certain dreams rather naturally suggest the animistic explanation, there
title: Elementary Forms

text: are certainly many others which are absolutely incompatible with it.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Often our dreams are concerned with passed events; we see again the
title: Elementary Forms

text: things which we saw or did yesterday or the day before or even during
title: Elementary Forms

text: our youth, etc.; dreams of this sort are frequent and hold a rather
title: Elementary Forms

text: considerable place in our nocturnal life. But the idea of a double
title: Elementary Forms

text: cannot account for them. Even if the double can go from one point to
title: Elementary Forms

text: another in space, it is not clear how it could possibly go back and
title: Elementary Forms

text: forth in time. Howsoever rudimentary his intelligence may be, how could
title: Elementary Forms

text: a man on awakening believe that he had really been assisting at or
title: Elementary Forms

text: taking part in events which he knows passed long before? How could he
title: Elementary Forms

text: imagine that during his sleep he lived a life which he knows has long
title: Elementary Forms

text: since gone by? It would be much more natural that he should regard these
title: Elementary Forms

text: renewed images as merely what they really are, that is, as souvenirs
title: Elementary Forms

text: like those which he has during the day, but ones of a special intensity.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Moreover, in the scenes of which we are the actors and witnesses while
title: Elementary Forms

text: we sleep, it constantly happens that one of our contemporaries has a
title: Elementary Forms

text: role as well as ourselves: we think we see and hear him in the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: place where we see ourselves. According to the animists, the primitive
title: Elementary Forms

text: would explain this by imagining that his double was visited by or met
title: Elementary Forms

text: with those of certain of his companions. But it would be enough that on
title: Elementary Forms

text: awakening he question them, to find that their experiences do not
title: Elementary Forms

text: coincide with his. During this same time, they too have had dreams, but
title: Elementary Forms

text: wholly different ones. They have not seen themselves participating in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the same scene; they believe that they have visited wholly different
title: Elementary Forms

text: places. Since such contradictions should be the rule in these cases, why
title: Elementary Forms

text: should they not lead men to believe that there had probably been an
title: Elementary Forms

text: error, that they had merely imagined it, that they had been duped by
title: Elementary Forms

text: illusions? This blind credulity which is attributed to the primitive is
title: Elementary Forms

text: really too simple. It is not true that he must objectify all his
title: Elementary Forms

text: sensations. He cannot live long without perceiving that even when awake
title: Elementary Forms

text: his senses sometimes deceive him. Then why should he believe them more
title: Elementary Forms

text: infallible at night than during the day? Thus we find that there are
title: Elementary Forms

text: many reasons opposing the theory that he takes his dreams for the
title: Elementary Forms

text: reality and interprets them by means of a double of himself.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But more than that, even if every dream were well explained by the
title: Elementary Forms

text: hypothesis of a double, and could not be explained otherwise, it would
title: Elementary Forms

text: remain a question why men have attempted to explain them. Dreams
title: Elementary Forms

text: undoubtedly constitute the matter of a possible problem. But we pass by
title: Elementary Forms

text: problems every day which we do not raise, and of which we have no
title: Elementary Forms

text: suspicion until some circumstance makes us feel the necessity of raising
title: Elementary Forms

text: them. Even when the taste for pure speculation is aroused, reflection is
title: Elementary Forms

text: far from raising all the problems to which it could eventually apply
title: Elementary Forms

text: itself; only those attract it which present a particular interest.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Especially, when it is a question of facts which always take place in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the same manner, habit easily numbs curiosity, and we do not even dream
title: Elementary Forms

text: of questioning them. To shake off this torpor, it is necessary that
title: Elementary Forms

text: practical exigencies, or at least a very pressing theoretical interest,
title: Elementary Forms

text: stimulate our attention and turn it in this direction. That is why, at
title: Elementary Forms

text: every moment of history, there have been so many things that we have not
title: Elementary Forms

text: tried to understand, without even being conscious of our renunciation.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Up until very recent times, it was believed that the sun was only a few
title: Elementary Forms

text: feet in diameter. There is something incomprehensible in the statement
title: Elementary Forms

text: that a luminous disc of such slight dimensions could illuminate the
title: Elementary Forms

text: world: yet for centuries men never thought of resolving this
title: Elementary Forms

text: contradiction. The fact of heredity has been known for a long time, but
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is very recently that the attempt has been made to formulate its
title: Elementary Forms

text: theory. Certain beliefs were even admitted which rendered it wholly
title: Elementary Forms

text: unintelligible: thus in many Australian societies of which we shall have
title: Elementary Forms

text: occasion to speak, the child is not physiologically the offspring of its
title: Elementary Forms

text: parents.[108] This intellectual laziness is necessarily at its maximum
title: Elementary Forms

text: among the primitive peoples. These weak beings, who have so much trouble
title: Elementary Forms

text: in maintaining life against all the forces which assail it, have no
title: Elementary Forms

text: means for supporting any luxury in the way of speculation. They do not
title: Elementary Forms

text: reflect except when they are driven to it. Now it is difficult to see
title: Elementary Forms

text: what could have led them to make dreams the theme of their meditations.
title: Elementary Forms

text: What does the dream amount to in our lives? How little is the place it
title: Elementary Forms

text: holds, especially because of the very vague impressions it leaves in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: memory, and of the rapidity with which it is effaced from remembrance,
title: Elementary Forms

text: and consequently, how surprising it is that a man of so rudimentary an
title: Elementary Forms

text: intelligence should have expended such efforts to find its explanation!
title: Elementary Forms

text: Of the two existences which he successively leads, that of the day and
title: Elementary Forms

text: that of the night, it is the first which should interest him the most.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Is it not strange that the second should have so captivated his
title: Elementary Forms

text: attention that he made it the basis of a whole system of complicated
title: Elementary Forms

text: ideas destined to have so profound an influence upon his thought and
title: Elementary Forms

text: conduct?
title: Elementary Forms

text: Thus all tends to show that, in spite of the credit it still enjoys, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: animistic theory of the soul must be revised. It is true that to-day the
title: Elementary Forms

text: primitive attributes his dreams, or at least certain of them, to
title: Elementary Forms

text: displacements of his double. But that does not say that the dream
title: Elementary Forms

text: actually furnished the materials out of which the idea of the double or
title: Elementary Forms

text: the soul was first constructed; it might have been applied afterwards to
title: Elementary Forms

text: the phenomena of dreams, ecstasy and possession, without having been
title: Elementary Forms

text: derived from them. It is very frequent that, after it has been formed,
title: Elementary Forms

text: an idea is employed to co-ordinate or illuminate--with a light
title: Elementary Forms

text: frequently more apparent than real--certain facts with which it had no
title: Elementary Forms

text: relation at first, and which would never have suggested it themselves.
title: Elementary Forms

text: God and the immortality of the soul are frequently proven to-day by
title: Elementary Forms

text: showing that these beliefs are implied in the fundamental principles of
title: Elementary Forms

text: morality; as a matter of fact, they have quite another origin. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: history of religious thought could furnish numerous examples of these
title: Elementary Forms

text: retrospective justifications, which can teach us nothing of the way in
title: Elementary Forms

text: which the ideas were formed, nor of the elements out of which they are
title: Elementary Forms

text: composed.
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is also probable that the primitive distinguishes between his dreams,
title: Elementary Forms

text: and does not interpret them all in the same way. In our European
title: Elementary Forms

text: societies the still numerous persons for whom sleep is a sort of
title: Elementary Forms

text: magico-religious state in which the mind, being partially relieved of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the body, has a sharpness of vision which it does not enjoy during
title: Elementary Forms

text: waking moments, do not go to the point of considering all their dreams
title: Elementary Forms

text: as so many mystic intuitions: on the contrary, along with everybody
title: Elementary Forms

text: else, they see in the majority of their dreams only profane conditions,
title: Elementary Forms

text: vain plays of images, or simple hallucinations. It might be supposed
title: Elementary Forms

text: that the primitive should make analogous distinctions. Codrington says
title: Elementary Forms

text: distinctly that the Melanesians do not attribute all their dreams
title: Elementary Forms

text: indiscriminately to the wanderings of their souls, but merely those
title: Elementary Forms

text: which strike their imagination forcibly:[109] undoubtedly by that should
title: Elementary Forms

text: be understood those in which the sleeper imagines himself in relations
title: Elementary Forms

text: with religious beings, good or evil geniuses, souls of the dead, etc.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Similarly, the Dieri in Australia sharply distinguish ordinary dreams
title: Elementary Forms

text: from those nocturnal visions in which some deceased friend or relative
title: Elementary Forms

text: shows himself to them. In the first, they see a simple fantasy of their
title: Elementary Forms

text: imagination; they attribute the second to the action of an evil
title: Elementary Forms

text: spirit.[110] All the facts which Howitt mentions as examples to show how
title: Elementary Forms

text: the Australian attributes to the soul the power of leaving the body,
title: Elementary Forms

text: have an equally mystic character. The sleeper believes himself
title: Elementary Forms

text: transported into the land of the dead or else he converses with a dead
title: Elementary Forms

text: companion.[111] These dreams are frequent among the primitives.[112] It
title: Elementary Forms

text: is probably upon these facts that the theory is based. To account for
title: Elementary Forms

text: them, it is admitted that the souls of the dead come back to the living
title: Elementary Forms

text: during their sleep. This theory was the more readily accepted because no
title: Elementary Forms

text: fact of experience could invalidate it. But these dreams were possible
title: Elementary Forms

text: only where the ideas of spirits, souls and a land of the dead were
title: Elementary Forms

text: already existent, that is to say, where religious evolution was
title: Elementary Forms

text: relatively advanced. Thus, far from having been able to furnish to
title: Elementary Forms

text: religion the fundamental notion upon which it rests, they suppose a
title: Elementary Forms

text: previous religious system, upon which they depended.[113]
title: Elementary Forms

text: III
title: Elementary Forms

text: We now arrive at that which constitutes the very heart of the doctrine.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Wherever this idea of a double may come from, it is not sufficient,
title: Elementary Forms

text: according to the avowal of the animists themselves, to explain the
title: Elementary Forms

text: formation of the cult of the ancestors which they would make the initial
title: Elementary Forms

text: type of all religions. If this double is to become the object of a cult,
title: Elementary Forms

text: it must cease to be a simple reproduction of the individual, and must
title: Elementary Forms

text: acquire the characteristics necessary to put it in the rank of sacred
title: Elementary Forms

text: beings. It is death, they say, which performs this transformation. But
title: Elementary Forms

text: whence comes the virtue which they attribute to this? Even were the
title: Elementary Forms

text: analogy of sleep and death sufficient to make one believe that the soul
title: Elementary Forms

text: survives the body (and there are reservations to be made on this point),
title: Elementary Forms

text: why does this soul, by the mere fact that it is now detached from the
title: Elementary Forms

text: organism, so completely change its nature? If it was only a profane
title: Elementary Forms

text: thing, a wandering vital principle, during life, how does it become a
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacred thing all at once, and the object of religious sentiments? Death
title: Elementary Forms

text: adds nothing essential to it, except a greater liberty of movement.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Being no longer attached to a special residence, from now on, it can do
title: Elementary Forms

text: at any time what it formerly did only by night; but the action of which
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is capable is always of the same sort. Then why have the living
title: Elementary Forms

text: considered this uprooted and vagabond double of their former companion
title: Elementary Forms

text: as anything more than an equal? It was a fellow-creature, whose approach
title: Elementary Forms

text: might be inconvenient; it was not a divinity.[114]
title: Elementary Forms

text: It seems as though death ought to have the effect of weakening vital
title: Elementary Forms

text: energies, instead of strengthening them. It is, in fact, a very common
title: Elementary Forms

text: belief in the inferior societies that the soul participates actively in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the life of the body. If the body is wounded, it is wounded itself and
title: Elementary Forms

text: in a corresponding place. Then it should grow old along with the body.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In fact, there are peoples who do not render funeral honours to men
title: Elementary Forms

text: arrived at senility; they are treated as if their souls also had become
title: Elementary Forms

text: senile.[115] It even happens that they regularly put to death, before
title: Elementary Forms

text: they arrive at old age, certain privileged persons, such as kings or
title: Elementary Forms

text: priests, who are supposed to be the possessors of powerful spirits whose
title: Elementary Forms

text: protection the community wishes to keep. They thus seek to keep the
title: Elementary Forms

text: spirit from being affected by the physical decadence of its momentary
title: Elementary Forms

text: keepers; with this end in view, they take it from the organism where it
title: Elementary Forms

text: resides before age can have weakened it, and they transport it, while it
title: Elementary Forms

text: has as yet lost nothing of its vigour, into a younger body where it will
title: Elementary Forms

text: be able to keep its vitality intact.[116] So when death results from
title: Elementary Forms

text: sickness or old age, it seems as though the soul could retain only a
title: Elementary Forms

text: diminished power; and if it is only its double, it is difficult to see
title: Elementary Forms

text: how it could survive at all, after the body is once definitely
title: Elementary Forms

text: dissolved. From this point of view, the idea of survival is intelligible
title: Elementary Forms

text: only with great difficulty. There is a logical and psychological gap
title: Elementary Forms

text: between the idea of a double at liberty and that of a spirit to which a
title: Elementary Forms

text: cult is addressed.
title: Elementary Forms

text: This interval appears still more considerable when we realize what an
title: Elementary Forms

text: abyss separates the sacred world from the profane; it becomes evident
title: Elementary Forms

text: that a simple change of degree could not be enough to make something
title: Elementary Forms

text: pass from one category into the other. Sacred beings are not
title: Elementary Forms

text: distinguished from profane ones merely by the strange or disconcerting
title: Elementary Forms

text: forms which they take or by the greater powers which they enjoy; between
title: Elementary Forms

text: the two there is no common measure. Now there is nothing in the notion
title: Elementary Forms

text: of a double which could account for so radical a heterogeneity. It is
title: Elementary Forms

text: said that when once freed from the body, the spirit can work all sorts
title: Elementary Forms

text: of good or evil for the living, according to the way in which it regards
title: Elementary Forms

text: them. But it is not enough that a being should disturb his neighbourhood
title: Elementary Forms

text: to seem to be of a wholly different nature from those whose tranquillity
title: Elementary Forms

text: it menaces. To be sure, in the sentiment which the believer feels for
title: Elementary Forms

text: the things he adores, there always enters in some element of reserve and
title: Elementary Forms

text: fear; but this is a fear _sui generis_, derived from respect more than
title: Elementary Forms

text: from fright, and where the dominating emotion is that which _la majeste_
title: Elementary Forms

text: inspires in men. The idea of majesty is essentially religious. Then we
title: Elementary Forms

text: have explained nothing of religion until we have found whence this idea
title: Elementary Forms

text: comes, to what it corresponds and what can have aroused it in the mind.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Simple souls of men cannot become invested with this character by the
title: Elementary Forms

text: simple fact of being no longer incarnate.
title: Elementary Forms

text: This is clearly shown by an example from Melanesia. The Melanesians
title: Elementary Forms

text: believe that men have souls which leave the body at death; it then
title: Elementary Forms

text: changes its name and becomes what they call a _tindalo_, a _natmat_,
title: Elementary Forms

text: etc. Also, they have a cult of the souls of the dead: they pray to them,
title: Elementary Forms

text: invoke them and make offerings and sacrifices to them. But every
title: Elementary Forms

text: _tindalo_ is not the object of these ritual practices; only those have
title: Elementary Forms

text: this honour which come from men to whom public opinion attributed,
title: Elementary Forms

text: during life, the very special virtue which the Melanesians call the
title: Elementary Forms

text: _mana_. Later on, we shall have occasion to fix precisely the meaning
title: Elementary Forms

text: which this word expresses; for the time being, it will suffice to say
title: Elementary Forms

text: that it is the distinctive character of every sacred being. As
title: Elementary Forms

text: Codrington says, "it is what works to effect anything which is beyond
title: Elementary Forms

text: the ordinary power of men, outside the common processes of nature."[117]
title: Elementary Forms

text: A priest, a sorcerer or a ritual formula have mana as well as a sacred
title: Elementary Forms

text: stone or spirit. Thus the only tindalo to which religious services are
title: Elementary Forms

text: rendered are those which were already sacred of themselves, when their
title: Elementary Forms

text: proprietor was still alive. In regard to the other souls, which come
title: Elementary Forms

text: from ordinary men, from the crowd of the profane, the same author says
title: Elementary Forms

text: that they are "nobodies alike before and after death."[118] By itself,
title: Elementary Forms

text: death has no deifying virtue. Since it brings about in a more or less
title: Elementary Forms

text: complete and final fashion the separation of the soul from profane
title: Elementary Forms

text: things, it can well reinforce the sacred character of the soul, if this
title: Elementary Forms

text: already exists, but it cannot create it.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Moreover, if, as the hypothesis of the animists supposes, the first
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacred beings were really the souls of the dead and the first cult that
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the ancestors, it should be found that the lower the societies
title: Elementary Forms

text: examined are, the more the place given to this cult in the religious
title: Elementary Forms

text: life. But it is rather the contrary which is true. The ancestral cult is
title: Elementary Forms

text: not greatly developed, or even presented under a characteristic form,
title: Elementary Forms

text: except in advanced societies like those of China, Egypt or the Greek and
title: Elementary Forms

text: Latin cities; on the other hand, it is completely lacking in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Australian societies which, as we shall see, represent the lowest and
title: Elementary Forms

text: simplest form of social organization which we know. It is true that
title: Elementary Forms

text: funeral rites and rites of mourning are found there; but these practices
title: Elementary Forms

text: do not constitute a cult, though this name has sometimes wrongfully been
title: Elementary Forms

text: given them. In reality, a cult is not a simple group of ritual
title: Elementary Forms

text: precautions which a man is held to take in certain circumstances; it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: a system of diverse rites, festivals and ceremonies which _all have this
title: Elementary Forms

text: characteristic, that they reappear periodically_. They fulfil the need
title: Elementary Forms

text: which the believer feels of strengthening and reaffirming, at regular
title: Elementary Forms

text: intervals of time, the bond which unites him to the sacred beings upon
title: Elementary Forms

text: which he depends. That is why one speaks of marriage rites but not of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: marriage cult, of rites of birth but not of a cult of the new-born
title: Elementary Forms

text: child; it is because the events on the occasion of which these rites
title: Elementary Forms

text: take place imply no periodicity. In the same way, there is no cult of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the ancestors except when sacrifices are made on the tombs from time to
title: Elementary Forms

text: time, when libations are poured there on certain more or less specific
title: Elementary Forms

text: dates, or when festivals are regularly celebrated in honour of the dead.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But the Australian has no relations of this sort with his dead. It is
title: Elementary Forms

text: true that he must bury their remains according to a ritual, mourn for
title: Elementary Forms

text: them during a prescribed length of time and in a prescribed manner, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: revenge them if there is occasion to.[119] But when he has once
title: Elementary Forms

text: accomplished these pious tasks, when the bones are once dry and the
title: Elementary Forms

text: period of mourning is once accomplished, then all is said and done, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: the survivors have no more duties towards their relatives who exist no
title: Elementary Forms

text: longer. It is true that there is a way in which the dead continue to
title: Elementary Forms

text: hold a place in the lives of their kindred, even after the mourning is
title: Elementary Forms

text: finished. It is sometimes the case that their hair or certain of their
title: Elementary Forms

text: bones are kept, because of special virtues which are attached to
title: Elementary Forms

text: them.[120] But by that time they have ceased to exist as persons, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: have fallen to the rank of anonymous and impersonal charms. In this
title: Elementary Forms

text: condition they are the object of no cult; they serve only for magical
title: Elementary Forms

text: purposes.
title: Elementary Forms

text: However, there are certain Australian tribes which periodically
title: Elementary Forms

text: celebrate rites in honour of fabulous ancestors whom tradition places at
title: Elementary Forms

text: the beginning of time. These ceremonies generally consist in a sort of
title: Elementary Forms

text: dramatic representation in which are rehearsed the deeds which the myths
title: Elementary Forms

text: ascribe to these legendary heroes.[121] But the personages thus
title: Elementary Forms

text: represented are not men who, after living the life of men, have been
title: Elementary Forms

text: transformed into a sort of god by the fact of their death. They are
title: Elementary Forms

text: considered to have exercised superhuman powers while alive. To them is
title: Elementary Forms

text: attributed all that is grand in the history of the tribe, or even of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: whole world. It is they who in a large measure made the earth such as it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is, and men such as they are. The haloes with which they are still
title: Elementary Forms

text: decorated do not come to them merely from the fact that they are
title: Elementary Forms

text: ancestors, that is to say, in fine, that they are dead, but rather from
title: Elementary Forms

text: the fact that a divine character is and always has been attributed to
title: Elementary Forms

text: them; to use the Melanesian expression, it is because they are
title: Elementary Forms

text: constitutionally endowed with mana. Consequently, there is nothing in
title: Elementary Forms

text: these rites which shows that death has the slightest power of
title: Elementary Forms

text: deification. It cannot even be correctly said of certain rites that they
title: Elementary Forms

text: form an ancestor-cult, since they are not addressed to ancestors as
title: Elementary Forms

text: such. In order to have a real cult of the dead, it is necessary that
title: Elementary Forms

text: after death real ancestors, the relations whom men really lose every
title: Elementary Forms

text: day, become the object of the cult; let us repeat it once more, there
title: Elementary Forms

text: are no traces of any such cult in Australia.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Thus the cult which, according to this hypothesis, ought to be the
title: Elementary Forms

text: predominating one in inferior societies, is really nonexistent there. In
title: Elementary Forms

text: reality, the Australian is not concerned with his dead, except at the
title: Elementary Forms

text: moment of their decease and during the time which immediately follows.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Yet these same peoples, as we shall see, have a very complex cult for
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacred beings of a wholly different nature, which is made up of numerous
title: Elementary Forms

text: ceremonies and frequently occupying weeks or even entire months. It
title: Elementary Forms

text: cannot be admitted that the few rites which the Australian performs when
title: Elementary Forms

text: he happens to lose one of his relatives were the origin of these
title: Elementary Forms

text: permanent cults which return regularly every year and which take up a
title: Elementary Forms

text: considerable part of his existence. The contrast between the two is so
title: Elementary Forms

text: great that we may even ask whether the first were not rather derived
title: Elementary Forms

text: from the second, and if the souls of men, far from having been the model
title: Elementary Forms

text: upon which the gods were originally imagined, have not rather been
title: Elementary Forms

text: conceived from the very first as emanations from the divinity.
title: Elementary Forms

text: IV
title: Elementary Forms

text: From the moment that the cult of the dead is shown not to be primitive,
title: Elementary Forms

text: animism lacks a basis. It would then seem useless to discuss the third
title: Elementary Forms

text: thesis of the system, which concerns the transformation of the cult of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the dead into the cult of nature. But since the postulate upon which it
title: Elementary Forms

text: rests is also found in certain historians of religion who do not admit
title: Elementary Forms

text: the animism properly so-called, such as Brinton,[122] Lang,[123]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Reville,[124] and even Robertson Smith himself,[125] it is necessary to
title: Elementary Forms

text: make an examination of it.
title: Elementary Forms

text: This extension of the cult of the dead to all nature is said to come
title: Elementary Forms

text: from the fact that we instinctively tend to represent all things in our
title: Elementary Forms

text: own image, that is to say, as living and thinking beings. We have seen
title: Elementary Forms

text: that Spencer has already contested the reality of this so-called
title: Elementary Forms

text: instinct. Since animals clearly distinguish living bodies from dead
title: Elementary Forms

text: ones, it seemed to him impossible that man, the heir of the animals,
title: Elementary Forms

text: should not have had this same faculty of discernment from the very
title: Elementary Forms

text: first. But howsoever certain the facts cited by Spencer may be, they
title: Elementary Forms

text: have not the demonstrative value which he attributes to them. His
title: Elementary Forms

text: reasoning supposes that all the faculties, instincts and aptitudes of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the animal have passed integrally into man; now many errors have their
title: Elementary Forms

text: origin in this principle which is wrongfully taken as a proven truth.
title: Elementary Forms

text: For example, since sexual jealousy is generally very strong among the
title: Elementary Forms

text: higher animals, it has been concluded that it ought to be found among
title: Elementary Forms

text: men with the same intensity from the very beginnings of history.[126]
title: Elementary Forms

text: But it is well known to-day that men can practise a sexual communism
title: Elementary Forms

text: which would be impossible if this jealousy were not capable of
title: Elementary Forms

text: attenuating itself and even of disappearing when necessary.[127] The
title: Elementary Forms

text: fact is that man is not merely an animal with certain additional
title: Elementary Forms

text: qualities: he is something else. Human nature is the result of a sort of
title: Elementary Forms

text: recasting of the animal nature, and in the course of the various complex
title: Elementary Forms

text: operations which have brought about this recasting, there have been
title: Elementary Forms

text: losses as well as gains. How many instincts have we not lost? The reason
title: Elementary Forms

text: for this is that men are not only in relations with the physical
title: Elementary Forms

text: environment, but also with a social environment infinitely more
title: Elementary Forms

text: extended, more stable and more active than the one whose influence
title: Elementary Forms

text: animals undergo. To live, they must adapt themselves to this. Now in
title: Elementary Forms

text: order to maintain itself, society frequently finds it necessary that we
title: Elementary Forms

text: should see things from a certain angle and feel them in a certain way;
title: Elementary Forms

text: consequently it modifies the ideas which we would ordinarily make of
title: Elementary Forms

text: them for ourselves and the sentiments to which we would be inclined if
title: Elementary Forms

text: we listened only to our animal nature; it alters them, even going so far
title: Elementary Forms

text: as to put the contrary sentiments in their place. Does it not even go so
title: Elementary Forms

text: far as to make us regard our own individual lives as something of little
title: Elementary Forms

text: value, while for the animal this is the greatest of things?[128] Then it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is a vain enterprise to seek to infer the mental constitution of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: primitive man from that of the higher animals.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But if the objection of Spencer does not have the decisive value which
title: Elementary Forms

text: its author gives it, it is equally true that the animist theory can draw
title: Elementary Forms

text: no authority from the confusions which children seem to make. When we
title: Elementary Forms

text: hear a child angrily apostrophize an object which he has hit against, we
title: Elementary Forms

text: conclude that he thinks of it as a conscious being like himself; but
title: Elementary Forms

text: that is interpreting his words and acts very badly. In reality, he is
title: Elementary Forms

text: quite a stranger to the very complicated reasoning attributed to him. If
title: Elementary Forms

text: he lays the blame on the table which has hurt him, it is not because he
title: Elementary Forms

text: supposes it animated and intelligent, but because it has hurt him. His
title: Elementary Forms

text: anger, once aroused by the pain, must overflow; so it looks for
title: Elementary Forms

text: something upon which to discharge itself, and naturally turns toward the
title: Elementary Forms

text: thing which has provoked it, even though this has no effect. The action
title: Elementary Forms

text: of an adult in similar circumstances is often as slightly reasonable.
title: Elementary Forms

text: When we are violently irritated, we feel the need of inveighing, of
title: Elementary Forms

text: destroying, though we attribute no conscious ill-will to the objects
title: Elementary Forms

text: upon which we vent our anger. There is even so little confusion that
title: Elementary Forms

text: when the emotion of a child is calmed, he can very well distinguish a
title: Elementary Forms

text: chair from a person: he does not act in at all the same way towards the
title: Elementary Forms

text: two. It is a similar reason which explains his tendency to treat his
title: Elementary Forms

text: playthings as if they were living beings. It is his extremely intense
title: Elementary Forms

text: need of playing which thus finds a means of expressing itself, just as
title: Elementary Forms

text: in the other case the violent sentiments caused by pain created an
title: Elementary Forms

text: object out of nothing. In order that he may consciously play with his
title: Elementary Forms

text: jumping-jack, he imagines it a living person. This illusion is the
title: Elementary Forms

text: easier for him because imagination is his sovereign mistress; he thinks
title: Elementary Forms

text: almost entirely with images, and we know how pliant images are, bending
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves with docility before every exigency of the will. But he is so
title: Elementary Forms

text: little deceived by his own fiction that he would be the first to be
title: Elementary Forms

text: surprised if it suddenly became a reality, and his toy bit him![129]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Let us therefore leave these doubtful analogies to one side. To find out
title: Elementary Forms

text: if men were primitively inclined to the confusions imputed to them, we
title: Elementary Forms

text: should not study animals or children of to-day, but the primitive
title: Elementary Forms

text: beliefs themselves. If the spirits and gods of nature were really formed
title: Elementary Forms

text: in the image of the human soul, they should bear traces of their origin
title: Elementary Forms

text: and bring to mind the essential traits of their model. The most
title: Elementary Forms

text: important characteristic of the soul is that it is conceived as the
title: Elementary Forms

text: internal principle which animates the organism: it is that which moves
title: Elementary Forms

text: it and makes it live, to such an extent that when it withdraws itself,
title: Elementary Forms

text: life ceases or is suspended. It has its natural residence in the body,
title: Elementary Forms

text: at least while this exists. But it is not thus with the spirits assigned
title: Elementary Forms

text: to the different things in nature. The god of the sun is not necessarily
title: Elementary Forms

text: in the sun, nor is the spirit of a certain rock in the rock which is its
title: Elementary Forms

text: principal place of habitation. A spirit undoubtedly has close relations
title: Elementary Forms

text: with the body to which it is attached, but one employs a very inexact
title: Elementary Forms

text: expression when he says that it is its soul. As Codrington says,[130]
title: Elementary Forms

text: "there does not appear to be anywhere in Melanesia a belief in a spirit
title: Elementary Forms

text: which animates any natural object, a tree, waterfall, storm or rock, so
title: Elementary Forms

text: as to be to it what the soul is believed to be to the body of man.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Europeans, it is true, speak of the spirits of the sea or of the storm
title: Elementary Forms

text: or of the forest; but the native idea which they represent is that
title: Elementary Forms

text: ghosts haunt the sea and the forest, having power to raise storms and
title: Elementary Forms

text: strike a traveller with disease." While the soul is essentially within
title: Elementary Forms

text: the body, the spirit passes the major portion of its time outside the
title: Elementary Forms

text: object which serves as its base. This is one difference which does not
title: Elementary Forms

text: seem to show that the second idea was derived from the first.
title: Elementary Forms

text: From another point of view, it must be added that if men were really
title: Elementary Forms

text: forced to project their own image into things, then the first sacred
title: Elementary Forms

text: beings ought to have been conceived in their likeness. Now
title: Elementary Forms

text: anthropomorphism, far from being primitive, is rather the mark of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: relatively advanced civilization. In the beginning, sacred beings are
title: Elementary Forms

text: conceived in the form of an animal or vegetable, from which the human
title: Elementary Forms

text: form is only slowly disengaged. It will be seen below that in Australia,
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is animals and plants which are the first sacred beings. Even among
title: Elementary Forms

text: the Indians of North America, the great cosmic divinities, which
title: Elementary Forms

text: commence to be the object of a cult there, are very frequently
title: Elementary Forms

text: represented in animal forms.[131] "The difference between the animal,
title: Elementary Forms

text: man and the divine being," says Reville, not without surprise, "is not
title: Elementary Forms

text: felt in this state of mind, and generally it might be said that _it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: the animal form which is the fundamental one_."[132] To find a god made
title: Elementary Forms

text: up entirely of human elements, it is necessary to advance nearly to
title: Elementary Forms

text: Christianity. Here, God is a man, not only in the physical aspect in
title: Elementary Forms

text: which he is temporarily made manifest, but also in the ideas and
title: Elementary Forms

text: sentiments which he expresses. But even in Greece and Rome, though the
title: Elementary Forms

text: gods were generally represented with human traits, many mythical
title: Elementary Forms

text: personages still had traces of an animal origin: thus there is Dionysus,
title: Elementary Forms

text: who is often met with in the form of a bull, or at least with the horns
title: Elementary Forms

text: of a bull; there is Demeter, who is often represented with a horse's
title: Elementary Forms

text: mane, there are Pan and Silenus, there are the Fauns, etc.[133] It is
title: Elementary Forms

text: not at all true that man has had such an inclination to impose his own
title: Elementary Forms

text: form upon things. More than that, he even commenced by conceiving of
title: Elementary Forms

text: himself as participating closely in the animal nature. In fact, it is a
title: Elementary Forms

text: belief almost universal in Australia, and very widespread among the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Indians of North America, that the ancestors of men were beasts or
title: Elementary Forms

text: plants, or at least that the first men had, either in whole or in part,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the distinctive characters of certain animal or vegetable species. Thus,
title: Elementary Forms

text: far from seeing beings like themselves everywhere, men commenced by
title: Elementary Forms

text: believing themselves to be in the image of some beings from which they
title: Elementary Forms

text: differed radically.
title: Elementary Forms

text: V
title: Elementary Forms

text: Finally, the animistic theory implies a consequence which is perhaps its
title: Elementary Forms

text: best refutation.
title: Elementary Forms

text: If it were true, it would be necessary to admit that religious beliefs
title: Elementary Forms

text: are so many hallucinatory representations, without any objective
title: Elementary Forms

text: foundation whatsoever. It is supposed that they are all derived from the
title: Elementary Forms

text: idea of the soul because one sees only a magnified soul in the spirits
title: Elementary Forms

text: and gods. But according to Tylor and his disciples, the idea of the soul
title: Elementary Forms

text: is itself constructed entirely out of the vague and inconsistent images
title: Elementary Forms

text: which occupy our attention during sleep: for the soul is the double, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: the double is merely a man as he appears to himself while he sleeps.
title: Elementary Forms

text: From this point of view, then, sacred beings are only the imaginary
title: Elementary Forms

text: conceptions which men have produced during a sort of delirium which
title: Elementary Forms

text: regularly overtakes them every day, though it is quite impossible to see
title: Elementary Forms

text: to what useful ends these conceptions serve, nor what they answer to in
title: Elementary Forms

text: reality. If a man prays, if he makes sacrifices and offerings, if he
title: Elementary Forms

text: submits to the multiple privations which the ritual prescribes, it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: because a sort of constitutional eccentricity has made him take his
title: Elementary Forms

text: dreams for perceptions, death for a prolonged sleep, and dead bodies for
title: Elementary Forms

text: living and thinking beings. Thus not only is it true, as many have held,
title: Elementary Forms

text: that the forms under which religious powers have been represented to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: mind do not express them exactly, and that the symbols with the aid of
title: Elementary Forms

text: which they have been thought of partially hide their real nature, but
title: Elementary Forms

text: more than that, behind these images and figures there exists nothing but
title: Elementary Forms

text: the nightmares of primitive minds. In fine, religion is nothing but a
title: Elementary Forms

text: dream, systematized and lived, but without any foundation in
title: Elementary Forms

text: reality.[134] Thence it comes about that the theorists of animism, when
title: Elementary Forms

text: looking for the origins of religious thought, content themselves with a
title: Elementary Forms

text: small outlay of energy. When they think that they have explained how men
title: Elementary Forms

text: have been induced to imagine beings of a strange, vaporous form, such as
title: Elementary Forms

text: those they see in their dreams, they think the problem is resolved.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In reality, it is not even approached. It is inadmissible that systems
title: Elementary Forms

text: of ideas like religions, which have held so considerable a place in
title: Elementary Forms

text: history, and to which, in all times, men have come to receive the energy
title: Elementary Forms

text: which they must have to live, should be made up of a tissue of
title: Elementary Forms

text: illusions. To-day we are beginning to realize that law, morals and even
title: Elementary Forms

text: scientific thought itself were born of religion, were for a long time
title: Elementary Forms

text: confounded with it, and have remained penetrated with its spirit. How
title: Elementary Forms

text: could a vain fantasy have been able to fashion the human consciousness
title: Elementary Forms

text: so strongly and so durably? Surely it ought to be a principle of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: science of religions that religion expresses nothing which does not
title: Elementary Forms

text: exist in nature; for there are sciences only of natural phenomena. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: only question is to learn from what part of nature these realities come
title: Elementary Forms

text: and what has been able to make men represent them under this singular
title: Elementary Forms

text: form which is peculiar to religious thought. But if this question is to
title: Elementary Forms

text: be raised, it is necessary to commence by admitting that they are real
title: Elementary Forms

text: things which are thus represented. When the philosophers of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: eighteenth century made religion a vast error imagined by the priests,
title: Elementary Forms

text: they could at least explain its persistence by the interest which the
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacerdotal class had in deceiving the people. But if the people
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves have been the artisans of these systems of erroneous ideas at
title: Elementary Forms

text: the same time that they were its dupes, how has this extraordinary
title: Elementary Forms

text: dupery been able to perpetuate itself all through the course of history?
title: Elementary Forms

text: One might even demand if under these conditions the words of science of
title: Elementary Forms

text: religions can be employed without impropriety. A science is a discipline
title: Elementary Forms

text: which, in whatever manner it is conceived, is always applied to some
title: Elementary Forms

text: real data. Physics and chemistry are sciences because physico-chemical
title: Elementary Forms

text: phenomena are real, and of a reality which does not depend upon the
title: Elementary Forms

text: truths which these sciences show. There is a psychological science
title: Elementary Forms

text: because there are really consciousnesses which do not hold their right
title: Elementary Forms

text: of existence from the psychologist. But on the contrary, religion could
title: Elementary Forms

text: not survive the animistic theory and the day when its truth was
title: Elementary Forms

text: recognized by men, for they could not fail to renounce the errors whose
title: Elementary Forms

text: nature and origin would thus be revealed to them. What sort of a science
title: Elementary Forms

text: is it whose principal discovery is that the subject of which it treats
title: Elementary Forms

text: does not exist?
title: Elementary Forms

text: CHAPTER III
title: Elementary Forms

text: LEADING CONCEPTIONS OF THE ELEMENTARY RELIGION--_continued_
title: Elementary Forms

text: II.--_Naturism_
title: Elementary Forms

text: The spirit of the naturistic school is quite different. In the first
title: Elementary Forms

text: place, it is recruited in a different environment. The animists are, for
title: Elementary Forms

text: the most part, ethnologists or anthropologists. The religions which they
title: Elementary Forms

text: have studied are the crudest which humanity has ever known. Hence comes
title: Elementary Forms

text: the extraordinary importance which they attribute to the souls of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: dead, to spirits and to demons, and, in fact, to all spiritual beings of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the second order: it is because these religions know hardly any of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: higher order.[135] On the contrary, the theories which we are now going
title: Elementary Forms

text: to describe are the work of scholars who have concerned themselves
title: Elementary Forms

text: especially with the great civilizations of Europe and Asia.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Ever since the work of the Grimm brothers, who pointed out the interest
title: Elementary Forms

text: that there is in comparing the different mythologies of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Indo-European peoples, scholars have been struck by the remarkable
title: Elementary Forms

text: similarities which these present. Mythical personages were identified
title: Elementary Forms

text: who, though having different names, symbolized the same ideas and
title: Elementary Forms

text: fulfilled the same functions; even the names were frequently related,
title: Elementary Forms

text: and it has been thought possible to establish the fact that they are not
title: Elementary Forms

text: unconnected with one another. Such resemblances seemed to be explicable
title: Elementary Forms

text: only by a common origin. Thus they were led to suppose that these
title: Elementary Forms

text: conceptions, so varied in appearance, really came from one common
title: Elementary Forms

text: source, of which they were only diversified forms, and which it was not
title: Elementary Forms

text: impossible to discover. By the comparative method, they believed one
title: Elementary Forms

text: should be able to go back, beyond these great religions, to a much more
title: Elementary Forms

text: ancient system of ideas, and to the really primitive religion, from
title: Elementary Forms

text: which the others were derived.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The discovery of the Vedas aided greatly in stimulating these ambitions.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In the Vedas, scholars had a written text, whose antiquity was
title: Elementary Forms

text: undoubtedly exaggerated at the moment of its discovery, but which is
title: Elementary Forms

text: surely one of the most ancient which we have at our disposition in an
title: Elementary Forms

text: Indo-European language. Here they were enabled to study, by the ordinary
title: Elementary Forms

text: methods of philology, a literature as old as or older than Homer, and a
title: Elementary Forms

text: religion which was believed more primitive than that of the ancient
title: Elementary Forms

text: Germans. A document of such value was evidently destined to throw a new
title: Elementary Forms

text: light upon the religious beginnings of humanity, and the science of
title: Elementary Forms

text: religions could not fail to be revolutionized by it.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The conception which was thus born was so fully demanded by the state of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the science and by the general march of ideas, that it appeared almost
title: Elementary Forms

text: simultaneously in two different lands. In 1856, Max Mueller exposed its
title: Elementary Forms

text: principles in his _Oxford Essays_.[136] Three years later appeared the
title: Elementary Forms

text: work of Adalbert Kuhn on _The Origin of Fire and the Drink of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Gods_,[137] which was clearly inspired by the same spirit. When once set
title: Elementary Forms

text: forth, the idea spread very rapidly in scientific circles. To the name
title: Elementary Forms

text: of Kuhn is closely associated that of his brother-in-law Schwartz, whose
title: Elementary Forms

text: work on _The Origin of Mythology_,[138] followed closely upon the
title: Elementary Forms

text: preceding one. Steinthal and the whole German school of
title: Elementary Forms

text: _Voelkerpsychologie_ attached themselves to the same movement. The theory
title: Elementary Forms

text: was introduced into France in 1863 by M. Michel Breal.[139] It met so
title: Elementary Forms

text: little resistance that, according to an expression of Gruppe,[140] "a
title: Elementary Forms

text: time came when, aside from certain classical philologists, to whom Vedic
title: Elementary Forms

text: studies were unknown, all the mythologists had adopted the principles of
title: Elementary Forms

text: Max Mueller or Kuhn as their point of departure."[141] It is therefore
title: Elementary Forms

text: important to see what they really are, and what they are worth.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Since no one has presented them in a more systematic form than Max
title: Elementary Forms

text: Mueller, it is upon his work that we shall base the description which
title: Elementary Forms

text: follows.[142]
title: Elementary Forms

text: I
title: Elementary Forms

text: We have seen that the postulate at the basis of animism is that
title: Elementary Forms

text: religion, at least in its origin, expresses no physical reality. But Max
title: Elementary Forms

text: Mueller commences with the contrary principle. For him, it is an axiom
title: Elementary Forms

text: that religion reposes upon an experience, from which it draws all its
title: Elementary Forms

text: authority. "Religion," he says, "if it is to hold its place as a
title: Elementary Forms

text: legitimate element of our consciousness, must, like all other knowledge,
