title: Elementary Forms

text: begin with sensuous experience."[143] Taking up the old empirical adage,
title: Elementary Forms

text: "_Nihil est in intellectu quod non ante fuerit in sensu_," he applies it
title: Elementary Forms

text: to religion and declares that there can be nothing in beliefs which was
title: Elementary Forms

text: not first perceived. So here is a doctrine which seems to escape the
title: Elementary Forms

text: grave objection which we raised against animism. From this point of
title: Elementary Forms

text: view, it seems that religion ought to appear, not as a sort of vague and
title: Elementary Forms

text: confused dreaming, but as a system of ideas and practices well founded
title: Elementary Forms

text: in reality.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But which are these sensations which give birth to religious thought?
title: Elementary Forms

text: That is the question which the study of the Vedas is supposed to aid in
title: Elementary Forms

text: resolving.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The names of the gods are generally either common words, still employed,
title: Elementary Forms

text: or else words formerly common, whose original sense it is possible to
title: Elementary Forms

text: discover. Now both designate the principal phenomena of nature. Thus
title: Elementary Forms

text: _Agni_, the name of one of the principal divinities of India, originally
title: Elementary Forms

text: signified only the material fact of fire, such as it is ordinarily
title: Elementary Forms

text: perceived by the senses and without any mythological addition. Even in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the Vedas, it is still employed with this meaning; in any case, it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: well shown that this signification was primitive by the fact that it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: conserved in other Indo-European languages: the Latin _ignis_, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Lithuanian _ugnis_, the old Slav _ogny_ are evidently closely related to
title: Elementary Forms

text: Agni. Similarly, the relationship of the Sanskrit _Dyaus_, the Greek
title: Elementary Forms

text: _Zeus_, the Latin _Jovis_ and the _Zio_ of High German is to-day
title: Elementary Forms

text: uncontested. This proves that these different words designate one single
title: Elementary Forms

text: and the same divinity, whom the different Indo-European peoples
title: Elementary Forms

text: recognized as such before their separation. Now Dyaus signifies the
title: Elementary Forms

text: bright sky. These and other similar facts tend to show that among these
title: Elementary Forms

text: peoples the forms and forces of nature were the first objects to which
title: Elementary Forms

text: the religious sentiment attached itself: they were the first things to
title: Elementary Forms

text: be deified. Going one step farther in his generalization, Max Mueller
title: Elementary Forms

text: thought that he was prepared to conclude that the religious evolution of
title: Elementary Forms

text: humanity in general had the same point of departure.
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is almost entirely by considerations of a psychological sort that he
title: Elementary Forms

text: justifies these inferences. The varied spectacles which nature offers
title: Elementary Forms

text: man seemed to him to fulfil all the conditions necessary for arousing
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious ideas in the mind directly. In fact, he says, "at first sight,
title: Elementary Forms

text: nothing seemed less natural than nature. Nature was the greatest
title: Elementary Forms

text: surprise, a terror, a marvel, a standing miracle, and it was only on
title: Elementary Forms

text: account of their permanence, constancy, and regular recurrence that
title: Elementary Forms

text: certain features of that standing miracle were called natural, in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: sense of foreseen, common, intelligible.... It was that vast domain of
title: Elementary Forms

text: surprise, of terror, of marvel, of miracle, the unknown, as
title: Elementary Forms

text: distinguished from the known, or, as I like to express it, the infinite,
title: Elementary Forms

text: as distinct from the finite, which supplied from the earliest times the
title: Elementary Forms

text: impulse to religious thought and language."[144] In order to illustrate
title: Elementary Forms

text: his idea, he applies it to a natural force which holds a rather large
title: Elementary Forms

text: place in the Vedic religion, fire. He says, "if you can for a moment
title: Elementary Forms

text: transfer yourselves to that early stage of life to which we must refer
title: Elementary Forms

text: not only the origin, but likewise the early phases of Physical Religion,
title: Elementary Forms

text: you can easily understand what an impression the first appearance of
title: Elementary Forms

text: fire must have made on the human mind. Fire was not given as something
title: Elementary Forms

text: permanent or eternal, like the sky, or the earth, or the water. In
title: Elementary Forms

text: whatever way it first appeared, whether through lightning or through the
title: Elementary Forms

text: friction of the branches of trees, or through the sparks of flints, it
title: Elementary Forms

text: came and went, it had to be guarded, it brought destruction, but at the
title: Elementary Forms

text: same time, it made life possible in winter, it served as a protection
title: Elementary Forms

text: during the night, it became a weapon of defence and offence, and last,
title: Elementary Forms

text: not least, it changed man from a devourer of raw flesh into an eater of
title: Elementary Forms

text: cooked meat. At a later time it became the means of working metal, of
title: Elementary Forms

text: making tools and weapons, it became an indispensable factor in all
title: Elementary Forms

text: mechanical and artistic progress, and has remained so ever since. What
title: Elementary Forms

text: should we be without fire even now?"[145] The same author says in
title: Elementary Forms

text: another work that a man could not enter into relations with nature
title: Elementary Forms

text: without taking account of its immensity, of its infiniteness. It
title: Elementary Forms

text: surpasses him in every way. Beyond the distances which he perceives,
title: Elementary Forms

text: there are others which extend without limits; each moment of time is
title: Elementary Forms

text: preceded and followed by a time to which no limit can be assigned; the
title: Elementary Forms

text: flowing river manifests an infinite force, since nothing can exhaust
title: Elementary Forms

text: it.[146] There is no aspect of nature which is not fitted to awaken
title: Elementary Forms

text: within us this overwhelming sensation of an infinity which surrounds us
title: Elementary Forms

text: and dominates us.[147] It is from this sensation that religions are
title: Elementary Forms

text: derived.[148]
title: Elementary Forms

text: However, they are there only in germ.[149] Religion really commences
title: Elementary Forms

text: only at the moment when these natural forces are no longer represented
title: Elementary Forms

text: in the mind in an abstract form. They must be transformed into personal
title: Elementary Forms

text: agents, living and thinking beings, spiritual powers or gods; for it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: to beings of this sort that the cult is generally addressed. We have
title: Elementary Forms

text: seen that animism itself has been obliged to raise this question, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: also how it has answered it: man seems to have a sort of native
title: Elementary Forms

text: incapacity for distinguishing the animate from the inanimate and an
title: Elementary Forms

text: irresistible tendency to conceive the second under the form of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: first. Max Mueller rejects any such solution.[150] According to him it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: language which has brought about this metamorphosis, by the action which
title: Elementary Forms

text: it exercises upon thought.
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is easily explained how men, being perplexed by the marvellous forces
title: Elementary Forms

text: upon which they feel that they depend, have been led to reflect upon
title: Elementary Forms

text: them, and how they have asked themselves what these forces are and have
title: Elementary Forms

text: made an effort to substitute for the obscure sensation which they
title: Elementary Forms

text: primitively had of them, a clearer idea and a better defined concept.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But as our author very justly says,[151] this idea and concept are
title: Elementary Forms

text: impossible without the word. Language is not merely the external
title: Elementary Forms

text: covering of a thought; it also is its internal framework. It does not
title: Elementary Forms

text: confine itself to expressing this thought after it has once been formed;
title: Elementary Forms

text: it also aids in making it. However, its nature is of a different sort,
title: Elementary Forms

text: so its laws are not those of thought. Then since it contributes to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: elaboration of this latter, it cannot fail to do it violence to some
title: Elementary Forms

text: extent, and to deform it. It is a deformation of this sort which is said
title: Elementary Forms

text: to have created the special characteristic of religious thought.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Thinking consists in arranging our ideas, and consequently in
title: Elementary Forms

text: classifying them. To think of fire, for example, is to put it into a
title: Elementary Forms

text: certain category of things, in such a way as to be able to say that it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is this or that, or this and not that. But classifying is also naming,
title: Elementary Forms

text: for a general idea has no existence and reality except in and by the
title: Elementary Forms

text: word which expresses it and which alone makes its individuality. Thus
title: Elementary Forms

text: the language of a people always has an influence upon the manner in
title: Elementary Forms

text: which new things, recently learned, are classified in the mind and are
title: Elementary Forms

text: subsequently thought of; these new things are thus forced to adapt
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves to pre-existing forms. For this reason, the language which
title: Elementary Forms

text: men spoke when they undertook to construct an elaborated representation
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the universe marked the system of ideas which was then born with an
title: Elementary Forms

text: indelible trace.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Nor are we without some knowledge of this language, at least in so far
title: Elementary Forms

text: as the Indo-European peoples are concerned. Howsoever distant it may be
title: Elementary Forms

text: from us, souvenirs of it remain in our actual languages which permit us
title: Elementary Forms

text: to imagine what it was: these are the roots. These stems, from which are
title: Elementary Forms

text: derived all the words which we employ and which are found at the basis
title: Elementary Forms

text: of all the Indo-European languages, are regarded by Max Mueller as so
title: Elementary Forms

text: many echoes of the language which the corresponding peoples spoke before
title: Elementary Forms

text: their separation, that is to say, at the very moment when this religion
title: Elementary Forms

text: of nature, which is to be explained, was being formed. Now these roots
title: Elementary Forms

text: present two remarkable characteristics, which, it is true, have as yet
title: Elementary Forms

text: been observed only in this particular group of languages, but which our
title: Elementary Forms

text: author believes to be present equally in the other linguistic
title: Elementary Forms

text: families.[152]
title: Elementary Forms

text: In the first place, the roots are general; that is to say that they do
title: Elementary Forms

text: not express particular things and individuals, but types, and even types
title: Elementary Forms

text: of an extreme generality. They represent the most general themes of
title: Elementary Forms

text: thought; one finds there, as though fixed and crystallized, those
title: Elementary Forms

text: fundamental categories of the intellect which at every moment in history
title: Elementary Forms

text: dominate the entire mental life, the arrangement of which philosophers
title: Elementary Forms

text: have many times attempted to reconstruct.[153]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Secondly, the types to which they correspond are types of action, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: not of objects. They translate the most general manners of acting which
title: Elementary Forms

text: are to be observed among living beings and especially among men; they
title: Elementary Forms

text: are such actions as striking, pushing, rubbing, lying down, getting up,
title: Elementary Forms

text: pressing, mounting, descending, walking, etc. In other words, men
title: Elementary Forms

text: generalized and named their principal ways of acting before generalizing
title: Elementary Forms

text: and naming the phenomena of nature.[154]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Owing to their extreme generality, these words could easily be extended
title: Elementary Forms

text: to all sorts of objects which they did not originally include; it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: even this extreme suppleness which has permitted them to give birth to
title: Elementary Forms

text: the numerous words which are derived from them. Then when men, turning
title: Elementary Forms

text: towards things, undertook to name them, that they might be able to think
title: Elementary Forms

text: about them, they applied these words to them, though they were in no way
title: Elementary Forms

text: designed for them. But, owing to their origin, these were able to
title: Elementary Forms

text: designate the forces of nature only by means of their manifestations
title: Elementary Forms

text: which seemed the nearest to human actions: a thunderbolt was called
title: Elementary Forms

text: _something_ that tears up the soil or that spreads fire; the wind,
title: Elementary Forms

text: _something_ that sighs or whistles; the sun, _something_ that throws
title: Elementary Forms

text: golden arrows across space; a river, _something_ that flows, etc. But
title: Elementary Forms

text: since natural phenomena were thus compared to human acts, this
title: Elementary Forms

text: _something_ to which they were attached was necessarily conceived under
title: Elementary Forms

text: the form of personal agents, more or less like men. It was only a
title: Elementary Forms

text: metaphor, but it was taken literally; the error was inevitable, for
title: Elementary Forms

text: science, which alone could dispel the illusion, did not yet exist. In a
title: Elementary Forms

text: word, since language was made of human elements, translating human
title: Elementary Forms

text: states, it could not be applied to nature without transforming it.[155]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Even to-day, remarks M. Breal, it forces us in a certain measure to
title: Elementary Forms

text: represent things from this angle. "We do not express an idea, even one
title: Elementary Forms

text: designating a simple quality, without giving it a gender, that is to
title: Elementary Forms

text: say, a sex; we cannot speak of an object, even though it be considered
title: Elementary Forms

text: in a most general fashion, without determining it by an article; every
title: Elementary Forms

text: subject of a sentence is presented as an active being, every idea as an
title: Elementary Forms

text: action, and every action, be it transitory or permanent, is limited in
title: Elementary Forms

text: its duration by the tense in which we put the verb."[156] Our scientific
title: Elementary Forms

text: training enables us to rectify the errors which language might thus
title: Elementary Forms

text: suggest to us; but the influence of the word ought to be all-powerful
title: Elementary Forms

text: when it has no check. Language thus superimposes upon the material
title: Elementary Forms

text: world, such as it is revealed to our senses, a new world, composed
title: Elementary Forms

text: wholly of spiritual beings which it has created out of nothing and which
title: Elementary Forms

text: have been considered as the causes determining physical phenomena ever
title: Elementary Forms

text: since.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But its action does not stop there. When words were once forged to
title: Elementary Forms

text: represent these personalities which the popular imagination had placed
title: Elementary Forms

text: behind things, a reaction affected these words themselves: they raised
title: Elementary Forms

text: all sorts of questions, and it was to resolve these problems that myths
title: Elementary Forms

text: were invented. It happened that one object received a plurality of
title: Elementary Forms

text: names, corresponding to the plurality of aspects under which it was
title: Elementary Forms

text: presented in experience; thus there are more than twenty words in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Vedas for the sky. Since these words were different, it was believed
title: Elementary Forms

text: that they corresponded to so many distinct personalities. But at the
title: Elementary Forms

text: same time, it was strongly felt that these same personalities had an air
title: Elementary Forms

text: of relationship. To account for that, it was imagined that they formed a
title: Elementary Forms

text: single family; genealogies, a civil condition and a history were
title: Elementary Forms

text: invented for them. In other cases, different things were designated by
title: Elementary Forms

text: the same term: to explain these homonyms, it was believed that the
title: Elementary Forms

text: corresponding things were transformations of each other, and new
title: Elementary Forms

text: fictions were invented to make these metamorphoses intelligible. Or
title: Elementary Forms

text: again, a word which had ceased to be understood, was the origin of
title: Elementary Forms

text: fables designed to give it a meaning. The creative work of language
title: Elementary Forms

text: continued then, making constructions ever more and more complex, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: then mythology came to endow each god with a biography, ever more and
title: Elementary Forms

text: more extended and complete, the result of all of which was that the
title: Elementary Forms

text: divine personalities, at first confounded with things, finally
title: Elementary Forms

text: distinguished and determined themselves.
title: Elementary Forms

text: This is how the notion of the divine is said to have been constructed.
title: Elementary Forms

text: As for the religion of ancestors, it was only a reflection of this
title: Elementary Forms

text: other.[157] The idea of the soul is said to have been first formed for
title: Elementary Forms

text: reasons somewhat analogous to those given by Tylor, except that
title: Elementary Forms

text: according to Max Mueller, they were designed to account for death, rather
title: Elementary Forms

text: than for dreams.[158] Then, under the influence of diverse, partially
title: Elementary Forms

text: accidental, circumstances,[159] the souls of men, being once disengaged
title: Elementary Forms

text: from the body, were drawn little by little within the circle of divine
title: Elementary Forms

text: beings, and were thus finally deified themselves. But this new cult was
title: Elementary Forms

text: the product of only a secondary formation. This is proven by the fact
title: Elementary Forms

text: that deified men have generally been imperfect gods or demi-gods, whom
title: Elementary Forms

text: the people have always been able to distinguish from the genuine
title: Elementary Forms

text: deities.[160]

text: II
title: Elementary Forms

text: This doctrine rests, in part, upon a certain number of linguistic
title: Elementary Forms

text: postulates which have been and still are very much questioned. Some have
title: Elementary Forms

text: contested the reality of many of the similarities which Max Mueller
title: Elementary Forms

text: claimed to have found between the names of the gods in the various
title: Elementary Forms

text: European languages. The interpretation which he gave them has been
title: Elementary Forms

text: especially doubted: it has been asked if these names, far from being the
title: Elementary Forms

text: mark of a very primitive religion, are not the slow product, either of
title: Elementary Forms

text: direct borrowings or of natural intercourse with others.[161] Also, it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is no longer admitted that the roots once existed in an isolated state
title: Elementary Forms

text: as autonomous realities, nor that they allow us to reconstruct, even
title: Elementary Forms

text: hypothetically, the original language of the Indo-Europeans.[162]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Finally, recent researches would tend to show that the Vedic divinities
title: Elementary Forms

text: did not all have the exclusively naturistic character attributed to them
title: Elementary Forms

text: by Max Mueller and his school.[163] But we shall leave aside those
title: Elementary Forms

text: questions, the discussion of which requires a special competence as a
title: Elementary Forms

text: philologist, and address ourselves directly to the general principles of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the system. It will be important here not to confound the naturistic
title: Elementary Forms

text: theory with these controverted postulates; for this is held by numbers
title: Elementary Forms

text: of scholars who do not make language play the predominating role
title: Elementary Forms

text: attributed to it by Max Mueller.
title: Elementary Forms

text: That men have an interest in knowing the world which surrounds them, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: consequently that their reflection should have been applied to it at an
title: Elementary Forms

text: early date, is something that everyone will readily admit. Co-operation
title: Elementary Forms

text: with the things with which they were in immediate connection was so
title: Elementary Forms

text: necessary for them that they could not fail to seek a knowledge of their
title: Elementary Forms

text: nature. But if, as naturism pretends, it is of these reflections that
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious thought was born, it is impossible to explain how it was able
title: Elementary Forms

text: to survive the first attempts made, and the persistence with which it
title: Elementary Forms

text: has maintained itself becomes unintelligible. If we have need of knowing
title: Elementary Forms

text: the nature of things, it is in order to act upon them in an appropriate
title: Elementary Forms

text: manner. But the conception of the universe given us by religion,
title: Elementary Forms

text: especially in its early forms, is too greatly mutilated to lead to
title: Elementary Forms

text: temporarily useful practices. Things become nothing less than living and
title: Elementary Forms

text: thinking beings, minds or personalities like those which the religious
title: Elementary Forms

text: imagination has made into the agents of cosmic phenomena. It is not by
title: Elementary Forms

text: conceiving of them under this form or by treating them according to this
title: Elementary Forms

text: conception that men could make them work for their ends. It is not by
title: Elementary Forms

text: addressing prayers to them, by celebrating them in feasts and
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacrifices, or by imposing upon themselves fasts and privations, that
title: Elementary Forms

text: men can deter them from working harm or oblige them to serve their own
title: Elementary Forms

text: designs. Such processes could succeed only very exceptionally and, so to
title: Elementary Forms

text: speak, miraculously. If, then, religion's reason for existence was to
title: Elementary Forms

text: give us a conception of the world which would guide us in our relations
title: Elementary Forms

text: with it, it was in no condition to fulfil its function, and people would
title: Elementary Forms

text: not have been slow to perceive it: failures, being infinitely more
title: Elementary Forms

text: frequent than successes, would have quickly shown them that they were
title: Elementary Forms

text: following a false route, and religion, shaken at each instant by these
title: Elementary Forms

text: repeated contradictions, would not have been able to survive.
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is undeniably true that errors have been able to perpetuate
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves in history; but, except under a union of very exceptional
title: Elementary Forms

text: circumstances, they can never perpetuate themselves thus unless they
title: Elementary Forms

text: were _true practically_, that is to say, unless, without giving us a
title: Elementary Forms

text: theoretically exact idea of the things with which they deal, they
title: Elementary Forms

text: express well enough the manner in which they affect us, either for good
title: Elementary Forms

text: or for bad. Under these circumstances, the actions which they determine
title: Elementary Forms

text: have every chance of being, at least in a general way, the very ones
title: Elementary Forms

text: which are proper, so it is easily explained how they have been able to
title: Elementary Forms

text: survive the proofs of experience.[164] But an error and especially a
title: Elementary Forms

text: system of errors which leads to, and can lead to nothing but mistaken
title: Elementary Forms

text: and useless practices, has no chance of living. Now what is there in
title: Elementary Forms

text: common between the rites with which the believer tries to act upon
title: Elementary Forms

text: nature and the processes by which science has taught us to make use of
title: Elementary Forms

text: it, and which we now know are the only efficacious ones? If that is what
title: Elementary Forms

text: men demanded of religion, it is impossible to see how it could have
title: Elementary Forms

text: maintained itself, unless clever tricks had prevented their seeing that
title: Elementary Forms

text: it did not give them what they expected from it. It would be necessary
title: Elementary Forms

text: to return again to the over simple explanations of the eighteenth
title: Elementary Forms

text: century.[165]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Thus it is only in appearance that naturism escapes the objection which
title: Elementary Forms

text: we recently raised against animism. It also makes religion a system of
title: Elementary Forms

text: hallucinations, since it reduces it to an immense metaphor with no
title: Elementary Forms

text: objective value. It is true that it gives religion a point of departure
title: Elementary Forms

text: in reality, to wit, in the sensations which the phenomena of nature
title: Elementary Forms

text: provoke in us; but by the bewitching action of language, this sensation
title: Elementary Forms

text: is soon transformed into extravagant conceptions. Religious thought does
title: Elementary Forms

text: not come in contact with reality, except to cover it at once with a
title: Elementary Forms

text: thick veil which conceals its real forms: this veil is the tissue of
title: Elementary Forms

text: fabulous beliefs which mythology brought forth. Thus the believer, like
title: Elementary Forms

text: the delirious man, lives in a world peopled with beings and things which
title: Elementary Forms

text: have only a verbal existence. Max Mueller himself recognized this, for he
title: Elementary Forms

text: regarded myths as the product of a disease of the intellect. At first,
title: Elementary Forms

text: he attributed them to a disease of language, but since language and the
title: Elementary Forms

text: intellect are inseparable for him, what is true of the one is true of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the other. "When trying to explain the inmost nature of mythology," he
title: Elementary Forms

text: says, "I called it a disease of Language rather than of Thought....
title: Elementary Forms

text: After I had fully explained in my _Science of Thought_ that language and
title: Elementary Forms

text: thought are inseparable, and that a disease of language is therefore the
title: Elementary Forms

text: same thing as a disease of thought, no doubt ought to have remained as
title: Elementary Forms

text: to what I meant. To represent the supreme God as committing every kind
title: Elementary Forms

text: of crime, as being deceived by men, as being angry with his wife and
title: Elementary Forms

text: violent with his children, is surely a proof of a disease, of an unusual
title: Elementary Forms

text: condition of thought, or, to speak more clearly, of real madness."[166]
title: Elementary Forms

text: And this argument is not valid merely against Max Mueller and his theory,
title: Elementary Forms

text: but against the very principle of naturism, in whatever way it may be
title: Elementary Forms

text: applied. Whatever we may do, if religion has as its principal object the
title: Elementary Forms

text: expression of the forces of nature, it is impossible to see in it
title: Elementary Forms

text: anything more than a system of lying fictions, whose survival is
title: Elementary Forms

text: incomprehensible.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Max Mueller thought he escaped this objection, whose gravity he felt, by
title: Elementary Forms

text: distinguishing radically between mythology and religion, and by putting
title: Elementary Forms

text: the first outside the second. He claims the right of reserving the name
title: Elementary Forms

text: of religion for only those beliefs which conform to the prescriptions of
title: Elementary Forms

text: a sane moral system and a rational theology. The myths were parasitic
title: Elementary Forms

text: growths which, under the influence of language, attached themselves upon
title: Elementary Forms

text: these fundamental conceptions, and denatured them. Thus the belief in
title: Elementary Forms

text: Zeus was religious in so far as the Greeks considered him the supreme
title: Elementary Forms

text: God, father of humanity, protector of laws, avenger of crimes, etc.; but
title: Elementary Forms

text: all that which concerned the biography of Zeus, his marriages and his
title: Elementary Forms

text: adventures, was only mythology.[167]
title: Elementary Forms

text: But this distinction is arbitrary. It is true that mythology has an
title: Elementary Forms

text: aesthetic interest as well as one for the history of religions; but it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: one of the essential elements of the religious life, nevertheless. If
title: Elementary Forms

text: the myth were withdrawn from religion, it would be necessary to withdraw
title: Elementary Forms

text: the rite also; for the rites are generally addressed to definite
title: Elementary Forms

text: personalities who have a name, a character, determined attributes and a
title: Elementary Forms

text: history, and they vary according to the manner in which these
title: Elementary Forms

text: personalities are conceived. The cult rendered to a divinity depends
title: Elementary Forms

text: upon the character attributed to him; and it is the myth which
title: Elementary Forms

text: determines this character. Very frequently, the rite is nothing more
title: Elementary Forms

text: than the myth put in action; the Christian communion is inseparable from
title: Elementary Forms

text: the myth of the Last Supper, from which it derives all its meaning. Then
title: Elementary Forms

text: if all mythology is the result of a sort of verbal delirium, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: question which we raised remains intact: the existence, and especially
title: Elementary Forms

text: the persistence of the cult become inexplicable. It is hard to
title: Elementary Forms

text: understand how men have continued to do certain things for centuries
title: Elementary Forms

text: without any object. Moreover, it is not merely the peculiar traits of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the divine personalities which are determined by mythology; the very
title: Elementary Forms

text: idea that there are gods or spiritual beings set above the various
title: Elementary Forms

text: departments of nature, in no matter what manner they may be represented,
title: Elementary Forms

text: is essentially mythical.[168] Now if all that which appertains to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: notion of gods conceived as cosmic agents is blotted out of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: religions of the past, what remains? The idea of a divinity in itself,
title: Elementary Forms

text: of a transcendental power upon which man depends and upon which he
title: Elementary Forms

text: supports himself? But that is only an abstract and philosophic
title: Elementary Forms

text: conception which has been fully realized in no historical religion; it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is without interest for the science of religions.[169] We must therefore
title: Elementary Forms

text: avoid distinguishing between religious beliefs, keeping some because
title: Elementary Forms

text: they seem to us to be true and sane and rejecting others because they
title: Elementary Forms

text: shock and disconcert us. All myths, even those which we find the most
title: Elementary Forms

text: unreasonable, have been believed.[170] Men have believed in them no less
title: Elementary Forms

text: firmly than in their own sensations; they have based their conduct upon
title: Elementary Forms

text: them. In spite of appearances, it is therefore impossible that they
title: Elementary Forms

text: should be without objective foundation.
title: Elementary Forms

text: However, it will be said that in whatever manner religions may be
title: Elementary Forms

text: explained, it is certain that they are mistaken in regard to the real
title: Elementary Forms

text: nature of things: science has proved it. The modes of action which they
title: Elementary Forms

text: counsel or prescribe to men can therefore rarely have useful effects: it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is not by lustrations that the sick are cured nor by sacrifices and
title: Elementary Forms

text: chants that the crops are made to grow. Thus the objection which we have
title: Elementary Forms

text: made to naturism would seem to be applicable to all possible systems of
title: Elementary Forms

text: explanation.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Nevertheless, there is one which escapes it. Let us suppose that
title: Elementary Forms

text: religion responds to quite another need than that of adapting ourselves
title: Elementary Forms

text: to sensible objects: then it will not risk being weakened by the fact
title: Elementary Forms

text: that it does not satisfy, or only badly satisfies, this need. If
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious faith was not born to put man in harmony with the material
title: Elementary Forms

text: world, the injuries which it has been able to do him in his struggle
title: Elementary Forms

text: with the world do not touch it at its source, because it is fed from
title: Elementary Forms

text: another.
title: Elementary Forms

text: If it is not for these reasons that a man comes to believe, he should
title: Elementary Forms

text: continue to believe even when these reasons are contradicted by the
title: Elementary Forms

text: facts. It is even conceivable that faith should be strong enough, not
title: Elementary Forms

text: only to support these contradictions, but also even to deny them and to
title: Elementary Forms

text: keep the believer from seeing their importance; this is what succeeds in
title: Elementary Forms

text: rendering them inoffensive for religion. When the religious sentiment is
title: Elementary Forms

text: active, it will not admit that religion can be in the wrong, and it
title: Elementary Forms

text: readily suggests explanations which make it appear innocent; if the rite
title: Elementary Forms

text: does not produce the desired results, this failure is imputed either to
title: Elementary Forms

text: some fault of execution, or to the intervention of another, contrary
title: Elementary Forms

text: deity. But for that, it is necessary that these religious ideas have
title: Elementary Forms

text: their source in another sentiment than that betrayed by these deceptions
title: Elementary Forms

text: of experience, or else whence could come their force of resistance?
title: Elementary Forms

text: III
title: Elementary Forms

text: But more than that, even if men had really had reasons for remaining
title: Elementary Forms

text: obstinate, in spite of all their mistakes, in expressing cosmic
title: Elementary Forms

text: phenomena in religious terms, it is also necessary that these be of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: nature to suggest such an interpretation. Now when could they have
title: Elementary Forms

text: gotten such a property? Here again we find ourselves in the presence of
title: Elementary Forms

text: one of those postulates which pass as evident only because they have not
title: Elementary Forms

text: been criticized. It is stated as an axiom that in the natural play of
title: Elementary Forms

text: physical forces there is all that is needed to arouse within us the idea
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the sacred; but when we closely examine the proofs of this
title: Elementary Forms

text: proposition, which, by the way, are sufficiently brief, we find that
title: Elementary Forms

text: they reduce to a prejudice.
title: Elementary Forms

text: They talk about the marvel which men should feel as they discover the
title: Elementary Forms

text: world. But really, that which characterizes the life of nature is a
title: Elementary Forms

text: regularity which approaches monotony. Every morning the sun mounts in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the horizon, every evening it sets; every month the moon goes through
title: Elementary Forms

text: the same cycle; the river flows in an uninterrupted manner in its bed;
title: Elementary Forms

text: the same seasons periodically bring back the same sensations. To be
title: Elementary Forms

text: sure, here and there an unexpected event sometimes happens: the sun is
title: Elementary Forms

text: eclipsed, the moon is hidden behind clouds, the river overflows. But
title: Elementary Forms

text: these momentary variations could only give birth to equally momentary
title: Elementary Forms

text: impressions, the remembrance of which is gone after a little while; they
title: Elementary Forms

text: could not serve as a basis for these stable and permanent systems of
title: Elementary Forms

text: ideas and practices which constitute religions. Normally, the course of
title: Elementary Forms

text: nature is uniform, and uniformity could never produce strong emotions.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Representing the savage as filled with admiration before these marvels
title: Elementary Forms

text: transports much more recent sentiments to the beginnings of history. He
title: Elementary Forms

text: is much too accustomed to it to be greatly surprised by it. It requires
title: Elementary Forms

text: culture and reflection to shake off this yoke of habit and to discover
title: Elementary Forms

text: how marvellous this regularity itself is. Besides, as we have already
title: Elementary Forms

text: remarked,[171] admiring an object is not enough to make it appear sacred
title: Elementary Forms

text: to us, that is to say, to mark it with those characteristics which make
title: Elementary Forms

text: all direct contact with it appear a sacrilege and a profanation. We
title: Elementary Forms

text: misunderstand what the religious sentiment really is, if we confound it
title: Elementary Forms

text: with every impression of admiration and surprise.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But, they say, even if it is not admiration, there is a certain
title: Elementary Forms

text: impression which men cannot help feeling in the presence of nature. He
title: Elementary Forms

text: cannot come in contact with it, without realizing that it is greater
title: Elementary Forms

text: than he. It overwhelms him by its immensity. This sensation of an
title: Elementary Forms

text: infinite space which surrounds him, of an infinite time which has
title: Elementary Forms

text: preceded and will follow the present moment, and of forces infinitely
title: Elementary Forms

text: superior to those of which he is master, cannot fail, as it seems, to
title: Elementary Forms

text: awaken within him the idea that outside of him there exists an infinite
title: Elementary Forms

text: power upon which he depends. And this idea enters as an essential
title: Elementary Forms

text: element into our conception of the divine.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But let us bear in mind what the question is. We are trying to find out
title: Elementary Forms

text: how men came to think that there are in reality two categories of
title: Elementary Forms

text: things, radically heterogeneous and incomparable to each other. Now how
title: Elementary Forms

text: could the spectacle of nature give rise to the idea of this duality?
title: Elementary Forms

text: Nature is always and everywhere of the same sort. It matters little that
title: Elementary Forms

text: it extends to infinity: beyond the extreme limit to which my eyes can
title: Elementary Forms

text: reach, it is not different from what it is here. The space which I
title: Elementary Forms

text: imagine beyond the horizon is still space, identical with that which I
title: Elementary Forms

text: see. The time which flows without end is made up of moments identical
title: Elementary Forms

text: with those which I have passed through. Extension, like duration,
title: Elementary Forms

text: repeats itself indefinitely; if the portions which I touch have of
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves no sacred character, where did the others get theirs? The
title: Elementary Forms

text: fact that I do not see them directly, is not enough to transform
title: Elementary Forms

text: them.[172] A world of profane things may well be unlimited; but it
title: Elementary Forms

text: remains a profane world. Do they say that the physical forces with which
title: Elementary Forms

text: we come in contact exceed our own? Sacred forces are not to be
title: Elementary Forms

text: distinguished from profane ones simply by their greater intensity, they
title: Elementary Forms

text: are different; they have special qualities which the others do not have.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Quite on the contrary, all the forces manifested in the universe are of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the same nature, those that are within us just as those that are outside
title: Elementary Forms

text: of us. And especially, there is no reason which could have allowed
title: Elementary Forms

text: giving a sort of pre-eminent dignity to some in relation to others. Then
title: Elementary Forms

text: if religion really was born because of the need of assigning causes to
title: Elementary Forms

text: physical phenomena, the forces thus imagined would have been no more
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacred than those conceived by the scientist to-day to account for the
title: Elementary Forms

text: same facts.[173] This is as much as to say that there would have been
title: Elementary Forms

text: no sacred beings and therefore no religion.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But even supposing that this sensation of being "overwhelmed" were
title: Elementary Forms

text: really able to suggest religious ideas, it could not have produced this
title: Elementary Forms

text: effect upon the primitive, for he does not have it. He is in no way
title: Elementary Forms

text: conscious that cosmic forces are so superior to his own. Since science
title: Elementary Forms

text: has not yet taught him modesty, he attributes to himself an empire over
title: Elementary Forms

text: things which he really does not have, but the illusion of which is
title: Elementary Forms

text: enough to prevent his feeling dominated by them. As we have already
title: Elementary Forms

text: pointed out, he thinks that he can command the elements, release the
title: Elementary Forms

text: winds, compel the rain to fall, or stop the sun, by a gesture, etc.[174]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Religion itself contributes to giving him this security, for he believes
title: Elementary Forms

text: that it arms him with extended powers over nature. His rites are, in
title: Elementary Forms

text: part, means destined to aid him in imposing his will upon the world.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Thus, far from being due to the sentiment which men should have of their
title: Elementary Forms

text: littleness before the universe, religions are rather inspired by the
title: Elementary Forms

text: contrary sentiment. Even the most elevated and idealistic have the
title: Elementary Forms

text: effect of reassuring men in their struggle with things: they teach that
title: Elementary Forms

text: faith is, of itself, able "to move mountains," that is to say, to
title: Elementary Forms

text: dominate the forces of nature. How could they give rise to this
title: Elementary Forms

text: confidence if they had had their origin in a sensation of feebleness and
title: Elementary Forms

text: impotency?
title: Elementary Forms

text: Finally, if the objects of nature really became sacred because of their
title: Elementary Forms

text: imposing forms or the forces which they manifest, then the sun, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: moon, the sky, the mountains, the sea, the winds, in a word, the great
title: Elementary Forms

text: cosmic powers, should have been the first to be raised to this dignity;
title: Elementary Forms

text: for there are no others more fitted to appeal to the senses and the
title: Elementary Forms

text: imagination. But as a matter of fact, they were divinized but slowly.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The first beings to which the cult is addressed--the proof will be found
title: Elementary Forms

text: in the chapters which follow--are humble vegetables and animals, in
title: Elementary Forms

text: relation to which men could at least claim an equality: they are ducks,
title: Elementary Forms

text: rabbits, kangaroos, lizards, worms, frogs, etc. Their objective
title: Elementary Forms

text: qualities surely were not the origin of the religious sentiments which
title: Elementary Forms

text: they inspired.
title: Elementary Forms

text: CHAPTER IV
title: Elementary Forms

text: TOTEMISM AS AN ELEMENTARY RELIGION
title: Elementary Forms

text: _History of the Question.--Method of Treating it_
title: Elementary Forms

text: Howsoever opposed their conclusions may seem to be, the two systems
title: Elementary Forms

text: which we have just studied agree upon one essential point: they state
title: Elementary Forms

text: the problem in identical terms. Both undertake to construct the idea of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the divine out of the sensations aroused in us by certain natural
title: Elementary Forms

text: phenomena, either physical or biological. For the animists it is dreams,
title: Elementary Forms

text: for the naturists, certain cosmic phenomena, which served as the point
title: Elementary Forms

text: of departure for religious evolution. But for both, it is in the nature,
title: Elementary Forms

text: either of man or of the universe, that we must look for the germ of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: grand opposition which separates the profane from the sacred.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But such an enterprise is impossible: it supposes a veritable creation
title: Elementary Forms

text: _ex nihilo_. A fact of common experience cannot give us the idea of
title: Elementary Forms

text: something whose characteristic is to be outside the world of common
title: Elementary Forms

text: experience. A man, as he appears to himself in his dreams, is only a
title: Elementary Forms

text: man. Natural forces, as our senses perceive them, are only natural
title: Elementary Forms

text: forces, howsoever great their intensity may be. Hence comes the common
title: Elementary Forms

text: criticism which we address to both doctrines. In order to explain how
title: Elementary Forms

text: these pretended data of religious thought have been able to take a
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacred character which has no objective foundation, it would be
title: Elementary Forms

text: necessary to admit that a whole world of delusive representations has
title: Elementary Forms

text: superimposed itself upon the other, denatured it to the point of making
title: Elementary Forms

text: it unrecognizable, and substituted a pure hallucination for reality.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Here, it is the illusions of the dream which brought about this
title: Elementary Forms

text: transfiguration; there, it is the brilliant and vain company of images
title: Elementary Forms

text: evoked by the word. But in one case as in the other, it is necessary to
title: Elementary Forms

text: regard religion as the product of a delirious imagination.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Thus one positive conclusion is arrived at as the result of this
title: Elementary Forms

text: critical examination. Since neither man nor nature have of themselves a
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacred character, they must get it from another source. Aside from the
title: Elementary Forms

text: human individual and the physical world, there should be some other
title: Elementary Forms

text: reality, in relation to which this variety of delirium which all
title: Elementary Forms

text: religion is in a sense, has a significance and an objective value. In
title: Elementary Forms

text: other words, beyond those which we have called animistic and naturistic,
title: Elementary Forms

text: there should be another sort of cult, more fundamental and more
title: Elementary Forms

text: primitive, of which the first are only derived forms or particular
title: Elementary Forms

text: aspects.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In fact, this cult does exist: it is the one to which ethnologists have
title: Elementary Forms

text: given the name of totemism.
title: Elementary Forms

text: I
title: Elementary Forms

text: It was only at the end of the eighteenth century that the word totem
title: Elementary Forms

text: appeared in ethnographical literature. It is found for the first time in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the book of an Indian interpreter, J. Long, which was published in
title: Elementary Forms

text: London in 1791.[175] For nearly a half a century, totemism was known
title: Elementary Forms

text: only as something exclusively American.[176] It was only in 1841 that
title: Elementary Forms

text: Grey, in a passage which has remained celebrated,[177] pointed out the
title: Elementary Forms

text: existence of wholly similar practices in Australia. From that time on,
title: Elementary Forms

text: scholars began to realize that they were in the presence of a system of
title: Elementary Forms

text: a certain generality.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But they saw there only an essentially archaic institution, an
title: Elementary Forms

text: ethnographical curiosity, having no great interest for the historian.
title: Elementary Forms

text: MacLennan was the first who undertook to attach totemism to the general
title: Elementary Forms

text: history of humanity. In a series of articles in the _Fortnightly
title: Elementary Forms

text: Review_,[178] he set himself to show that totemism was not only a
title: Elementary Forms

text: religion, but one from which were derived a multitude of beliefs and
title: Elementary Forms

text: practices which are found in much more advanced religious systems. He
title: Elementary Forms

text: even went so far as to make it the source of all the animal-worshipping
title: Elementary Forms

text: and plant-worshipping cults which are found among ancient peoples.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Certainly this extension of totemism was abusive. The cults of animals
title: Elementary Forms

text: and plants depend upon numerous causes which cannot be reduced to one,
title: Elementary Forms

text: without the error of too great simplicity. But this error, by its very
title: Elementary Forms

text: exaggerations, had at least the advantage, that it put into evidence the
title: Elementary Forms

text: historical importance of totemism.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Students of American totemism had already known for a long time that
title: Elementary Forms

text: this form of religion was most intimately united to a determined social
title: Elementary Forms

text: organization, that its basis is the division of the social group into
title: Elementary Forms

text: clans.[179] In 1877, in his _Ancient Society_,[180] Lewis H. Morgan
title: Elementary Forms

text: undertook to make a study of it, to determine its distinctive
title: Elementary Forms

text: characteristics, and at the same time to point out its generality among
title: Elementary Forms

text: the Indian tribes of North and Central America. At nearly the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: moment, and even following the direct suggestion of Morgan, Fison and
title: Elementary Forms

text: Howitt[181] established the existence of the same social system in
title: Elementary Forms

text: Australia, as well as its relations with totemism.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Under the influence of these directing ideas, observations could be made
title: Elementary Forms

text: with better method. The researches which the American Bureau of
title: Elementary Forms

text: Ethnology undertook, played an important part in the advance of these
title: Elementary Forms

text: studies.[182] By 1887, the documents were sufficiently numerous and
title: Elementary Forms

text: significant to make Frazer consider it time to unite them and present
title: Elementary Forms

text: them to us in a systematic form. Such is the object of his little book
title: Elementary Forms

text: _Totemism_,[183] where the system is studied both as a religion and as a
title: Elementary Forms

text: legal institution. But this study was purely descriptive; no effort was
title: Elementary Forms

text: made to explain totemism[184] or to understand its fundamental notions.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Robertson Smith is the first who undertook this work of elaboration. He
title: Elementary Forms

text: realized more clearly than any of his predecessors how rich this crude
title: Elementary Forms

text: and confused religion is in germs for the future. It is true that
title: Elementary Forms

text: MacLennan had already connected it with the great religions of
title: Elementary Forms

text: antiquity; but that was merely because he thought he had found here and
title: Elementary Forms

text: there the cult of animals or plants. Now if we reduce totemism to a sort
title: Elementary Forms

text: of animal or plant worship, we have seen only its most superficial
title: Elementary Forms

text: aspect: we have even misunderstood its real nature. Going beyond the
title: Elementary Forms

text: mere letter of the totemic beliefs, Smith set himself to find the
title: Elementary Forms

text: fundamental principles upon which they depend. In his book upon _Kinship
title: Elementary Forms

text: and Marriage in Early Arabia_,[185] he had already pointed out that
title: Elementary Forms

text: totemism supposes a likeness in nature, either natural or acquired, of
title: Elementary Forms

text: men and animals (or plants). In his _The Religion of the Semites_,[186]
title: Elementary Forms

text: he makes this same idea the first origin of the entire sacrificial
title: Elementary Forms

text: system: it is to totemism that humanity owes the principle of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: communion meal. It is true that the theory of Smith can now be shown
title: Elementary Forms

text: one-sided; it is no longer adequate for the facts actually known; but
title: Elementary Forms

text: for all that, it contains an ingenious theory and has exercised a most
title: Elementary Forms

text: fertile influence upon the science of religions. The _Golden Bough_[187]
title: Elementary Forms

text: of Frazer is inspired by these same ideas, for totemism, which MacLennan
title: Elementary Forms

text: had attached to the religions of classical antiquity, and Smith to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: religions of the Semitic peoples, is here connected to the European
title: Elementary Forms

text: folk-lore. The schools of MacLennan and Morgan are thus united to that
title: Elementary Forms

text: of Mannhardt.[188]
title: Elementary Forms

text: During this time, the American tradition continued to develop with an
title: Elementary Forms

text: independence which it has kept up until very recent times. Three groups
title: Elementary Forms

text: of societies were the special object of the researches which were
title: Elementary Forms

text: concerned with totemism. These are, first, certain tribes of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: North-west, the Tlinkit, the Haida, the Kwakiutl, the Salish and the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Tsimshian; then, the great nation of the Sioux; and finally, the Pueblo
title: Elementary Forms

text: Indians in the south-western part of the United States. The first were
title: Elementary Forms

text: studied principally by Dall, Krause, Boas, Swanton, Hill Tout; the
title: Elementary Forms

text: second by Dorsey; the last by Mindeleff, Mrs. Stevenson and
title: Elementary Forms

text: Cushing.[189] But however rich the harvest of facts thus gathered in all
title: Elementary Forms

text: parts of the country may have been, the documents at our disposal were
title: Elementary Forms

text: still fragmentary. Though the American religions contain numerous traces
title: Elementary Forms

text: of totemism, they have passed the stage of real totemism. On the other
title: Elementary Forms

text: hand, observations in Australia had brought little more than scattered
title: Elementary Forms

text: beliefs and isolated rites, initiation rituals and interdictions
title: Elementary Forms

text: relative to totemism. It was with facts taken from all these sources
title: Elementary Forms

text: that Frazer attempted to draw a picture of totemism in its entirety.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Whatever may be the incontestable merit of the reconstruction undertaken
title: Elementary Forms

text: in such circumstances, it could not help being incomplete and
title: Elementary Forms

text: hypothetical. A totemic religion in complete action had not yet been
title: Elementary Forms

text: observed.
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is only in very recent years that this serious deficiency has been
title: Elementary Forms

text: repaired. Two observers of remarkable ability, Baldwin Spencer and F. J.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Gillen, discovered[190] in the interior of the Australian continent a
title: Elementary Forms

text: considerable number of tribes whose basis and unity was founded in
title: Elementary Forms

text: totemic beliefs. The results of their observations have been published
title: Elementary Forms

text: in two works, which have given a new life to the study of totemism. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: first of these, _The Native Tribes of Central Australia_,[191] deals
title: Elementary Forms

text: with the more central of these tribes, the Arunta, the Luritcha, and a
title: Elementary Forms

text: little farther to the south, on the shores of Lake Eyre, the Urabunna.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The second, which is entitled _The Northern Tribes of Central
title: Elementary Forms

text: Australia_,[192] deals with the societies north of the Urabunna,
title: Elementary Forms

text: occupying the territory between MacDonnell's Range and Carpenter Gulf.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Among the principal of these we may mention the Unmatjera, the Kaitish,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the Warramunga, the Worgaia, the Tjingilli, the Binbinga, the Walpari,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the Gnanji and finally, on the very shores of the gulf, the Mara and the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Anula.[193]
title: Elementary Forms

text: More recently, a German missionary, Carl Strehlow, who has also passed
title: Elementary Forms

text: long years in these same Central Australian societies,[194] has
title: Elementary Forms

text: commenced to publish his own observations on two of these tribes, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Aranda and the Loritja (the Arunta and Luritcha of Spencer and
title: Elementary Forms

text: Gillen).[195] Having well mastered the language spoken by these
title: Elementary Forms

text: peoples,[196] Strehlow has been able to bring us a large number of
title: Elementary Forms

text: totemic myths and religious songs, which are given us, for the most
title: Elementary Forms

text: part, in the original text. In spite of some differences of detail which
title: Elementary Forms

text: are easily explained and whose importance has been greatly
title: Elementary Forms

text: exaggerated,[197] we shall see that the observations of Strehlow, though
title: Elementary Forms

text: completing, making more precise and sometimes even rectifying those of
title: Elementary Forms

text: Spencer and Gillen, confirm them in all that is essential.
title: Elementary Forms

text: These discoveries have given rise to an abundant literature to which we
title: Elementary Forms

text: shall have occasion to return. The works of Spencer and Gillen
title: Elementary Forms

text: especially have exercised a considerable influence, not only because
title: Elementary Forms

text: they were the oldest, but also because the facts were there presented in
title: Elementary Forms

text: a systematic form, which was of a nature to give a direction to later
title: Elementary Forms

text: studies,[198] and to stimulate speculation. Their results were commented
title: Elementary Forms

text: upon, discussed and interpreted in all possible manners. At this same
title: Elementary Forms

text: time, Howitt, whose fragmentary studies were scattered in a number of
title: Elementary Forms

text: different publications,[199] undertook to do for the southern tribes
title: Elementary Forms

text: what Spencer and Gillen had done for those of the centre. In his _Native
title: Elementary Forms

text: Tribes of South-East Australia_,[200] he gives us a view of the social
title: Elementary Forms

text: organization of the peoples who occupy Southern Australia, New South
title: Elementary Forms

text: Wales, and a good part of Queensland. The progress thus realized
title: Elementary Forms

text: suggested to Frazer the idea of completing his Totemism by a sort of
title: Elementary Forms

text: compendium[201] where would be brought together all the important
title: Elementary Forms

text: documents which are concerned either with the totemic religion or the
title: Elementary Forms

text: family and matrimonial organization which, rightly or wrongly, is
title: Elementary Forms

text: believed to be connected with this religion. The purpose of this book is
title: Elementary Forms

text: not to give us a general and systematic view of totemism, but rather to
title: Elementary Forms

text: put the materials necessary for a construction of this sort at the
title: Elementary Forms

text: disposition of scholars.[202] The facts are here arranged in a strictly
title: Elementary Forms

text: ethnographical and geographical order: each continent, and within the
title: Elementary Forms

text: continent, each tribe or ethnic group is studied separately. Though so
title: Elementary Forms

text: extended a study, where so many diverse peoples are successively passed
title: Elementary Forms

text: in review, could hardly be equally thorough in all its parts, still it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is a useful hand-book to consult, and one which can aid greatly in
title: Elementary Forms

text: facilitating researches.
title: Elementary Forms

text: II
title: Elementary Forms

text: From this historical resume it is clear that Australia is the most
title: Elementary Forms

text: favourable field for the study of totemism, and therefore we shall make
title: Elementary Forms

text: it the principal area of our observations.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In his _Totemism_, Frazer sought especially to collect all the traces of
title: Elementary Forms

text: totemism which could be found in history or ethnography. He was thus led
title: Elementary Forms

text: to include in his study societies the nature and degree of whose culture
title: Elementary Forms

text: differs most widely: ancient Egypt,[203] Arabia and Greece,[204] and the
title: Elementary Forms

text: southern Slavs[205] are found there, side by side with the tribes of
title: Elementary Forms

text: Australia and America. This manner of procedure is not at all surprising
title: Elementary Forms

text: for a disciple of the anthropological school. For this school does not
title: Elementary Forms

text: seek to locate religions in the social environments of which they are a
title: Elementary Forms

text: part,[206] and to differentiate them according to the different
title: Elementary Forms

text: environments to which they are thus connected. But rather, as is
title: Elementary Forms

text: indicated by the name which it has taken to itself, its purpose is to go
title: Elementary Forms

text: beyond the national and historical differences to the universal and
title: Elementary Forms

text: really human bases of the religious life. It is supposed that man has a
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious nature of himself, in virtue of his own constitution, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: independently of all social conditions, and they propose to study
title: Elementary Forms

text: this.[207] For researches of this sort, all peoples can be called upon
title: Elementary Forms

text: equally well. It is true that they prefer the more primitive peoples,
title: Elementary Forms

text: because this fundamental nature is more apt to be unaltered here; but
title: Elementary Forms

text: since it is found equally well among the most civilized peoples, it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: but natural that they too should be called as witnesses. Consequently,
title: Elementary Forms

text: all those who pass as being not too far removed from the origins, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: who are confusedly lumped together under the rather imprecise rubric of
title: Elementary Forms

text: _savages_, are put on the same plane and consulted indifferently. Since
title: Elementary Forms

text: from this point of view, facts have an interest only in proportion to
title: Elementary Forms

text: their generality, they consider themselves obliged to collect as large a
title: Elementary Forms

text: number as possible of them; the circle of comparisons could not become
title: Elementary Forms

text: too large.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Our method will not be such a one, for several reasons.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In the first place, for the sociologist as for the historian, social
title: Elementary Forms

text: facts vary with the social system of which they form a part; they cannot
title: Elementary Forms

text: be understood when detached from it. This is why two facts which come
title: Elementary Forms

text: from two different societies cannot be profitably compared merely
title: Elementary Forms

text: because they seem to resemble each other; it is necessary that these
title: Elementary Forms

text: societies themselves resemble each other, that is to say, that they be
title: Elementary Forms

text: only varieties of the same species. The comparative method would be
title: Elementary Forms

text: impossible, if social types did not exist, and it cannot be usefully
title: Elementary Forms

text: applied except within a single type. What errors have not been committed
title: Elementary Forms

text: for having neglected this precept! It is thus that facts have been
title: Elementary Forms

text: unduly connected with each other which, in spite of exterior
title: Elementary Forms

text: resemblances, really have neither the same sense nor the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: importance: the primitive democracy and that of to-day, the collectivism
title: Elementary Forms

text: of inferior societies and actual socialistic tendencies, the monogamy
title: Elementary Forms

text: which is frequent in Australian tribes and that sanctioned by our laws,
title: Elementary Forms

text: etc. Even in the work of Frazer such confusions are found. It frequently
title: Elementary Forms

text: happens that he assimilates simple rites of wild-animal-worship to
title: Elementary Forms

text: practices that are really totemic, though the distance, sometimes very
title: Elementary Forms

text: great, which separates the two social systems would exclude all idea of
title: Elementary Forms

text: assimilation. Then if we do not wish to fall into these same errors,
title: Elementary Forms

text: instead of scattering our researches over all the societies possible, we
title: Elementary Forms

text: must concentrate them upon one clearly determined type.
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is even necessary that this concentration be as close as possible.
title: Elementary Forms

text: One cannot usefully compare facts with which he is not perfectly well
title: Elementary Forms

text: acquainted. But when he undertakes to include all sorts of societies and
title: Elementary Forms

text: civilizations, one cannot know any of them with the necessary
title: Elementary Forms

text: thoroughness; when he assembles facts from every country in order to
title: Elementary Forms

text: compare them, he is obliged to take them hastily, without having either
title: Elementary Forms

text: the means or the time to carefully criticize them. Tumultuous and
title: Elementary Forms

text: summary comparisons result, which discredit the comparative method with
title: Elementary Forms

text: many intelligent persons. It can give serious results only when it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: applied to so limited a number of societies that each of them can be
title: Elementary Forms

text: studied with sufficient precision. The essential thing is to choose
title: Elementary Forms

text: those where investigations have the greatest chance to be fruitful.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Also, the value of the facts is much more important than their number.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In our eyes, the question whether totemism has been more or less
title: Elementary Forms

text: universal or not, is quite secondary.[208] If it interests us, it does
title: Elementary Forms

text: so before all because in studying it we hope to discover relations of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: nature to make us understand better what religion is. Now to establish
title: Elementary Forms

text: these relations it is neither necessary nor always useful to heap up
title: Elementary Forms

text: numerous experiences upon each other; it is much more important to have
title: Elementary Forms

text: a few that are well studied and really significant. One single fact may
title: Elementary Forms

text: make a law appear, where a multitude of imprecise and vague observations
title: Elementary Forms

text: would only produce confusion. In every science, the scholar would be
title: Elementary Forms

text: overwhelmed by the facts which present themselves to him, if he did not
title: Elementary Forms

text: make a choice among them. It is necessary that he distinguish those
title: Elementary Forms

text: which promise to be the most instructive, that he concentrate his
title: Elementary Forms

text: attention upon these, and that he temporarily leave the others to one
title: Elementary Forms

text: side.
title: Elementary Forms

text: That is why, with one reservation which will be indicated below, we
title: Elementary Forms

text: propose to limit our research to Australian societies. They fulfil all
title: Elementary Forms

text: the conditions which were just enumerated. They are perfectly
title: Elementary Forms

text: homogeneous, for though it is possible to distinguish varieties among
title: Elementary Forms

text: them, they all belong to one common type. This homogeneity is even so
title: Elementary Forms

text: great that the forms of social organization are not only the same, but
title: Elementary Forms

text: that they are even designated by identical or equivalent names in a
title: Elementary Forms

text: multitude of tribes, sometimes very distant from each other.[209] Also,
title: Elementary Forms

text: Australian totemism is the variety for which our documents are the most
title: Elementary Forms

text: complete. Finally, that which we propose to study in this work is the
title: Elementary Forms

text: most primitive and simple religion which it is possible to find. It is
title: Elementary Forms

text: therefore natural that to discover it, we address ourselves to
title: Elementary Forms

text: societies as slightly evolved as possible, for it is evidently there
title: Elementary Forms

text: that we have the greatest chance of finding it and studying it well. Now
title: Elementary Forms

text: there are no societies which present this characteristic to a higher
title: Elementary Forms

text: degree than the Australian ones. Not only is their civilization most
title: Elementary Forms

text: rudimentary--the house and even the hut are still unknown--but also
title: Elementary Forms

text: their organization is the most primitive and simple which is actually
title: Elementary Forms

text: known; it is that which we have elsewhere called _organization on a
title: Elementary Forms

text: basis of clans_.[210] In the next chapter, we shall have occasion to
title: Elementary Forms

text: restate its essential traits.
title: Elementary Forms

text: However, though making Australia the principal field of our research, we
title: Elementary Forms

text: think it best not to leave completely aside the societies where totemism
title: Elementary Forms

text: was first discovered, that is to say, the Indian tribes of North
title: Elementary Forms

text: America.
title: Elementary Forms

text: This extension of the field of comparison has nothing about it which is
title: Elementary Forms

text: not legitimate. Undoubtedly these people are more advanced than those of
title: Elementary Forms

text: Australia. Their civilization has become much more advanced: men there
title: Elementary Forms

text: live in houses or under tents, and there are even fortified villages.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The size of the society is much greater, and centralization, which is
title: Elementary Forms

text: completely lacking in Australia, is beginning to appear there; we find
title: Elementary Forms

text: vast confederations, such as that of the Iroquois, under one central
title: Elementary Forms

text: authority. Sometimes a complicated system of differentiated classes
title: Elementary Forms

text: arranged in a hierarchy is found. However, the essential lines of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: social structure remain the same as those in Australia; it is always the
title: Elementary Forms

text: organization on a basis of clans. Thus we are not in the presence of two
title: Elementary Forms

text: different types, but of two varieties of a single type, which are still
title: Elementary Forms

text: very close to each other. They represent two successive moments of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: single evolution, so their homogeneousness is still great enough to
title: Elementary Forms

text: permit comparisons.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Also, these comparisons may have their utility. Just because their
title: Elementary Forms

text: civilization is more advanced than that of the Australians, certain
title: Elementary Forms

text: phases of the social organization which is common to both can be studied
title: Elementary Forms

text: more easily among the first than among the second. As long as men are
title: Elementary Forms

text: still making their first steps in the art of expressing their thought,
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is not easy for the observer to perceive that which moves them; for
title: Elementary Forms

text: there is nothing to translate clearly that which passes in these obscure
title: Elementary Forms

text: minds which have only a confused and ephemeral knowledge of themselves.
title: Elementary Forms

text: For example, religious symbols then consist only in formless
title: Elementary Forms

text: combinations of lines and colours, whose sense it is not easy to divine,
title: Elementary Forms

text: as we shall see. There are many gestures and movements by which interior
title: Elementary Forms

text: states express themselves; but being essentially ephemeral, they
title: Elementary Forms

text: readily elude observation. That is why totemism was discovered earlier
title: Elementary Forms

text: in America than in Australia; it was much more visible there, though it
title: Elementary Forms

text: held relatively less place in the totality of the religious life. Also,
title: Elementary Forms

text: wherever beliefs and institutions do not take a somewhat definite
title: Elementary Forms

text: material form, they are more liable to change under the influence of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: slightest circumstances, or to become wholly effaced from the memory.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Thus the Australian clans frequently have something floating and Protean
title: Elementary Forms

text: about them, while the corresponding organization in America has a
title: Elementary Forms

text: greater stability and more clearly defined contours. Thus, though
title: Elementary Forms

text: American totemism is further removed from its origins than that of
title: Elementary Forms

text: Australia, still there are important characteristics of which it has
title: Elementary Forms

text: better kept the memory.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In the second place, in order to understand an institution, it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: frequently well to follow it into the advanced stages of its
title: Elementary Forms

text: evolution;[211] for sometimes it is only when it is fully developed that
title: Elementary Forms

text: its real signification appears with the greatest clearness. In this way
title: Elementary Forms
