text: also, American totemism, since it has a long history behind it, could
title: Elementary Forms

text: serve to clarify certain aspects of Australian totemism.[212] At the
title: Elementary Forms

text: same time, it will put us in a better condition to see how totemism is
title: Elementary Forms

text: bound up with the forms which follow, and to mark its place in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: general historical development of religion.
title: Elementary Forms

text: So in the discussions which follow, we shall not forbid ourselves the
title: Elementary Forms

text: use of certain facts borrowed from the Indian societies of North
title: Elementary Forms

text: America. But we are not going to study American totemism here;[213] such
title: Elementary Forms

text: a study must be made directly and by itself, and cannot be mixed with
title: Elementary Forms

text: the one which we are undertaking; it raises other problems and implies a
title: Elementary Forms

text: wholly different set of special investigations. We shall have recourse
title: Elementary Forms

text: to American facts merely in a supplementary way, and only when they seem
title: Elementary Forms

text: to be able to make us understand Australian facts to advantage. It is
title: Elementary Forms

text: these latter which constitute the real and immediate object of our
title: Elementary Forms

text: researches.[214]
title: Elementary Forms

text: BOOK II
title: Elementary Forms

text: THE ELEMENTARY BELIEFS
title: Elementary Forms

text: CHAPTER I
title: Elementary Forms

text: TOTEMIC BELIEFS
title: Elementary Forms

text: _The Totem as Name and as Emblem_
title: Elementary Forms

text: Owing to its nature, our study will include two parts. Since every
title: Elementary Forms

text: religion is made up of intellectual conceptions and ritual practices, we
title: Elementary Forms

text: must deal successively with the beliefs and rites which compose the
title: Elementary Forms

text: totemic religion. These two elements of the religious life are too
title: Elementary Forms

text: closely connected with each other to allow of any radical separation. In
title: Elementary Forms

text: principle, the cult is derived from the beliefs, yet it reacts upon
title: Elementary Forms

text: them; the myth is frequently modelled after the rite in order to account
title: Elementary Forms

text: for it, especially when its sense is no longer apparent. On the other
title: Elementary Forms

text: hand, there are beliefs which are clearly manifested only through the
title: Elementary Forms

text: rites which express them. So these two parts of our analysis cannot fail
title: Elementary Forms

text: to overlap. However, these two orders of facts are so different that it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is indispensable to study them separately. And since it is impossible to
title: Elementary Forms

text: understand anything about a religion while unacquainted with the ideas
title: Elementary Forms

text: upon which it rests, we must seek to become acquainted with these latter
title: Elementary Forms

text: first of all.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But it is not our intention to retrace all the speculations into which
title: Elementary Forms

text: the religious thought, even of the Australians alone, has run. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: things we wish to reach are the elementary notions at the basis of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: religion, but there is no need of following them through all the
title: Elementary Forms

text: development, sometimes very confused, which the mythological imagination
title: Elementary Forms

text: of these peoples has given them. We shall make use of myths when they
title: Elementary Forms

text: enable us to understand these fundamental ideas better, but we shall not
title: Elementary Forms

text: make mythology itself the subject of our studies. In so far as this is a
title: Elementary Forms

text: work of art, it does not fall within the jurisdiction of the simple
title: Elementary Forms

text: science of religions. Also, the intellectual evolution from which it
title: Elementary Forms

text: results is of too great a complexity to be studied indirectly and from a
title: Elementary Forms

text: foreign point of view. It constitutes a very difficult problem which
title: Elementary Forms

text: must be treated by itself, for itself and with a method peculiar to
title: Elementary Forms

text: itself.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Among the beliefs upon which totemism rests, the most important are
title: Elementary Forms

text: naturally those concerning the totem; it is with these that we must
title: Elementary Forms

text: begin.
title: Elementary Forms

text: I
title: Elementary Forms

text: At the basis of nearly all the Australian tribes we find a group which
title: Elementary Forms

text: holds a preponderating place in the collective life: this is the clan.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Two essential traits characterize it.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In the first place, the individuals who compose it consider themselves
title: Elementary Forms

text: united by a bond of kinship, but one which is of a very special nature.
title: Elementary Forms

text: This relationship does not come from the fact that they have definite
title: Elementary Forms

text: blood connections with one another; they are relatives from the mere
title: Elementary Forms

text: fact that they have the same name. They are not fathers and mothers,
title: Elementary Forms

text: sons or daughters, uncles or nephews of one another in the sense which
title: Elementary Forms

text: we now give these words; yet they think of themselves as forming a
title: Elementary Forms

text: single family, which is large or small according to the dimensions of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the clan, merely because they are collectively designated by the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: word. When we say that they regard themselves as a single family, we do
title: Elementary Forms

text: so because they recognize duties towards each other which are identical
title: Elementary Forms

text: with those which have always been incumbent upon kindred: such duties as
title: Elementary Forms

text: aid, vengeance, mourning, the obligation not to marry among themselves,
title: Elementary Forms

text: etc.
title: Elementary Forms

text: By this first characteristic, the clan does not differ from the Roman
title: Elementary Forms

text: _gens_ or the Greek [Greek: genos]; for this relationship also came
title: Elementary Forms

text: merely from the fact that all the members of the _gens_ had the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: name,[215] the _nomen gentilicium_. And in one sense, the _gens_ is a
title: Elementary Forms

text: clan; but it is a variety which should not be confounded with the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Australian clan.[216] This latter is distinguished by the fact that its
title: Elementary Forms

text: name is also the name of a determined species of material things with
title: Elementary Forms

text: which it believes that it has very particular relations, the nature of
title: Elementary Forms

text: which we shall presently describe; they are especially relations of
title: Elementary Forms

text: kinship. The species of things which serves to designate the clan
title: Elementary Forms

text: collectively is called its _totem_. The totem of the clan is also that
title: Elementary Forms

text: of each of its members.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Each clan has its totem, which belongs to it alone; two different clans
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the same tribe cannot have the same. In fact, one is a member of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: clan merely because he has a certain name. All who bear this name are
title: Elementary Forms

text: members of it for that very reason; in whatever manner they may be
title: Elementary Forms

text: spread over the tribal territory, they all have the same relations of
title: Elementary Forms

text: kinship with one another.[217] Consequently, two groups having the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: totem can only be two sections of the same clan. Undoubtedly, it
title: Elementary Forms

text: frequently happens that all of a clan does not reside in the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: locality, but has representatives in several different places. However,
title: Elementary Forms

text: this lack of a geographical basis does not cause its unity to be the
title: Elementary Forms

text: less keenly felt.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In regard to the word totem, we may say that it is the one employed by
title: Elementary Forms

text: the Ojibway, an Algonquin tribe, to designate the sort of thing whose
title: Elementary Forms

text: name the clan bears.[218] Although this expression is not at all
title: Elementary Forms

text: Australian,[219] and is found only in one single society in America,
title: Elementary Forms

text: ethnographers have definitely adopted it, and use it to denote, in a
title: Elementary Forms

text: general way, the system which we are describing. Schoolcraft was the
title: Elementary Forms

text: first to extend the meaning of the word thus and to speak of a "totemic
title: Elementary Forms

text: system."[220] This extension, of which there are examples enough in
title: Elementary Forms

text: ethnography, is not without inconveniences. It is not normal for an
title: Elementary Forms

text: institution of this importance to bear a chance name, taken from a
title: Elementary Forms

text: strictly local dialect, and bringing to mind none of the distinctive
title: Elementary Forms

text: characteristics of the thing it designates. But to-day this way of
title: Elementary Forms

text: employing the word is so universally accepted that it would be an excess
title: Elementary Forms

text: of purism to rise against this usage.[221]
title: Elementary Forms

text: In a very large proportion of the cases, the objects which serve as
title: Elementary Forms

text: totems belong either to the animal or the vegetable kingdom, but
title: Elementary Forms

text: especially to the former. Inanimate things are much more rarely
title: Elementary Forms

text: employed. Out of more than 500 totemic names collected by Howitt among
title: Elementary Forms

text: the tribes of south-eastern Australia, there are scarcely forty which
title: Elementary Forms

text: are not the names of plants or animals; these are the clouds, rain,
title: Elementary Forms

text: hail, frost, the moon, the sun, the wind, the autumn, the summer, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: winter, certain stars, thunder, fire, smoke, water or the sea. It is
title: Elementary Forms

text: noticeable how small a place is given to celestial bodies and, more
title: Elementary Forms

text: generally, to the great cosmic phenomena, which were destined to so
title: Elementary Forms

text: great a fortune in later religious development. Among all the clans of
title: Elementary Forms

text: which Howitt speaks, there were only two which had the moon as
title: Elementary Forms

text: totem,[222] two the sun,[223] three a star,[224] three the thunder,[225]
title: Elementary Forms

text: two the lightning.[226] The rain is a single exception; it, on the
title: Elementary Forms

text: contrary, is very frequent.[227]
title: Elementary Forms

text: These are the totems which can be spoken of as normal. But totemism has
title: Elementary Forms

text: its abnormalities as well. It sometimes happens that the totem is not a
title: Elementary Forms

text: whole object, but the part of an object. This fact appears rather rarely
title: Elementary Forms

text: in Australia;[228] Howitt cites only one example.[229] However, it may
title: Elementary Forms

text: well be that this is found with a certain frequency in the tribes where
title: Elementary Forms

text: the totemic groups are excessively subdivided; it might be said that the
title: Elementary Forms

text: totems had to break themselves up in order to be able to furnish names
title: Elementary Forms

text: to these numerous divisions. This is what seems to have taken place
title: Elementary Forms

text: among the Arunta and the Loritja. Strehlow has collected 442 totems in
title: Elementary Forms

text: these two societies, of which many are not an animal species, but some
title: Elementary Forms

text: particular organ of the animal of the species, such as the tail or
title: Elementary Forms

text: stomach of an opossum, the fat of the kangaroo, etc.[230]
title: Elementary Forms

text: We have seen that normally the totem is not an individual, but a species
title: Elementary Forms

text: or a variety: it is not such and such a kangaroo or crow, but the
title: Elementary Forms

text: kangaroo or crow in general. Sometimes, however, it is a particular
title: Elementary Forms

text: object. First of all, this is necessarily the case when the thing
title: Elementary Forms

text: serving as totem is unique in its class, as the sun, the moon, such or
title: Elementary Forms

text: such a constellation, etc. It also happens that clans take their names
title: Elementary Forms

text: from certain geographical irregularities or depressions of the land,
title: Elementary Forms

text: from a certain ant-hill, etc. It is true that we have only a small
title: Elementary Forms

text: number of examples of this in Australia; but Strehlow does mention
title: Elementary Forms

text: some.[231] But the very causes which have given rise to these abnormal
title: Elementary Forms

text: totems show that they are of a relatively recent origin. In fact, what
title: Elementary Forms

text: has made certain geographical features of the land become totems is that
title: Elementary Forms

text: a mythical ancestor is supposed to have stopped there or to have
title: Elementary Forms

text: performed some act of his legendary life there.[232] But at the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: time, these ancestors are represented in the myths as themselves
title: Elementary Forms

text: belonging to clans which had perfectly regular totems, that is to say,
title: Elementary Forms

text: ones taken from the animal or vegetable kingdoms. Therefore, the totemic
title: Elementary Forms

text: names thus commemorating the acts and performances of these heroes
title: Elementary Forms

text: cannot be primitive; they belong to a form of totemism that is already
title: Elementary Forms

text: derived and deviated. It is even permissible to ask if the
title: Elementary Forms

text: meteorological totems have not a similar origin; for the sun, the moon
title: Elementary Forms

text: and the stars are frequently identified with the ancestors of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: mythological epoch.[233]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Sometimes, but no less exceptionally, it is an ancestor or a group of
title: Elementary Forms

text: ancestors which serves as totem directly. In this case, the clan takes
title: Elementary Forms

text: its name, not from a thing or a species of real things, but from a
title: Elementary Forms

text: purely mythical being. Spencer and Gillen had already mentioned two or
title: Elementary Forms

text: three totems of this sort. Among the Warramunga and among the Tjingilli
title: Elementary Forms

text: there are clans which bear the name of an ancestor named Thaballa who
title: Elementary Forms

text: seems to be gaiety incarnate.[234] Another Warramunga clan bears the
title: Elementary Forms

text: name of a huge fabulous serpent named Wollunqua, from which the clan
title: Elementary Forms

text: considers itself descended.[235] We owe other similar facts to
title: Elementary Forms

text: Strehlow.[236] In any case, it is easy enough to see what probably took
title: Elementary Forms

text: place. Under the influence of diverse causes and by the very development
title: Elementary Forms

text: of mythological thought, the collective and impersonal totem became
title: Elementary Forms

text: effaced before certain mythical personages who advanced to the first
title: Elementary Forms

text: rank and became totems themselves.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Howsoever interesting these different irregularities may be, they
title: Elementary Forms

text: contain nothing which forces us to modify our definition of a totem.
title: Elementary Forms

text: They are not, as has sometimes been believed,[237] different varieties
title: Elementary Forms

text: of totems which are more or less irreducible into each other or into the
title: Elementary Forms

text: normal totem, such as we have defined it. They are merely secondary and
title: Elementary Forms

text: sometimes even aberrant forms of a single notion which is much more
title: Elementary Forms

text: general, and there is every ground for believing it the more primitive.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The manner in which the name is acquired is more important for the
title: Elementary Forms

text: organization and recruiting of the clan than for religion; it belongs to
title: Elementary Forms

text: the sociology of the family rather than to religious sociology.[238] So
title: Elementary Forms

text: we shall confine ourselves to indicating summarily the most essential
title: Elementary Forms

text: principles which regulate the matter.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In the different tribes, three different systems are in use.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In a great number, or it might even be said, in the greater number of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the societies, the child takes the totem of its mother, by right of
title: Elementary Forms

text: birth: this is what happens among the Dieri and the Urabunna of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: centre of Southern Australia; the Wotjobaluk and the Gournditch-Mara of
title: Elementary Forms

text: Victoria; the Kamilaroi, the Wiradjuri, the Wonghibon and the Euahlayi
title: Elementary Forms

text: of New South Wales; and the Wakelbura, the Pitta-Pitta and the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Kurnandaburi of Queensland, to mention only the most important names. In
title: Elementary Forms

text: this case, owing to a law of exogamy, the mother is necessarily of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: different totem from her husband, and on the other hand, as she lives in
title: Elementary Forms

text: his community, the members of a single totem are necessarily dispersed
title: Elementary Forms

text: in different localities according to the chances of their marriages. As
title: Elementary Forms

text: a result, the totemic group lacks a territorial base.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Elsewhere the totem is transmitted in the paternal line. In this case,
title: Elementary Forms

text: if the child remains with his father, the local group is largely made up
title: Elementary Forms

text: of people belonging to a single totem; only the married women there
title: Elementary Forms

text: represent foreign totems. In other words, each locality has its
title: Elementary Forms

text: particular totem. Up until recent times, this scheme of organization was
title: Elementary Forms

text: found in Australia only among the tribes where totemism was in
title: Elementary Forms

text: decadence, such as the Narrinyeri, where the totem has almost no
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious character at all any more.[239] It was therefore possible to
title: Elementary Forms

text: believe that there was a close connection between the totemic system and
title: Elementary Forms

text: descent in the uterine line. But Spencer and Gillen have observed, in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the northern part of central Australia, a whole group of tribes where
title: Elementary Forms

text: the totemic religion is still practised but where the transmission of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the totem is in the paternal line: these are the Warramunga, the Quanji,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the Umbia, the Binbinga, the Mara and the Anula.[240]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Finally, a third combination is the one observed among the Arunta and
title: Elementary Forms

text: Loritja. Here the totem of the child is not necessarily either that of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the mother or that of the father; it is that of a mythical ancestor who
title: Elementary Forms

text: came, by processes which the observers recount in different ways,[241]
title: Elementary Forms

text: and mysteriously fecundated the mother at the moment of conception. A
title: Elementary Forms

text: special process makes it possible to learn which ancestor it was and to
title: Elementary Forms

text: which totemic group he belonged.[242] But since it was only chance which
title: Elementary Forms

text: determined that this ancestor happened to be near the mother, rather
title: Elementary Forms

text: than another, the totem of the child is thus found to depend finally
title: Elementary Forms

text: upon fortuitous circumstances.[243]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Outside of and above the totems of clans there are totems of phratries
title: Elementary Forms

text: which, though not differing from the former in nature, must none the
title: Elementary Forms

text: less be distinguished from them.
title: Elementary Forms

text: A phratry is a group of clans which are united to each other by
title: Elementary Forms

text: particular bonds of fraternity. Ordinarily the Australian tribe is
title: Elementary Forms

text: divided into two phratries between which the different clans are
title: Elementary Forms

text: distributed. Of course there are some tribes where this organization has
title: Elementary Forms

text: disappeared, but everything leads us to believe that it was once
title: Elementary Forms

text: general. In any case, there are no tribes in Australia where the number
title: Elementary Forms

text: of phratries is greater than two.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Now in nearly all the cases where the phratries have a name whose
title: Elementary Forms

text: meaning has been established, this name is that of an animal; it would
title: Elementary Forms

text: therefore seem that it is a totem. This has been well demonstrated in a
title: Elementary Forms

text: recent work by A. Lang.[244] Thus, among the Gournditch (Victoria), the
title: Elementary Forms

text: phratries are called Krokitch and Kaputch; the former of the words
title: Elementary Forms

text: designates the white cockatoo and the latter the black cockatoo.[245]
title: Elementary Forms

text: The same expressions are found again among the Buandik and the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Wotjobaluk.[246] Among the Wurunjerri, the names employed are Bunjil and
title: Elementary Forms

text: Waang, which designate the eagle-hawk and the crow.[247] The words
title: Elementary Forms

text: Mukwara and Kilpara are used for the same purpose in a large number of
title: Elementary Forms

text: tribes of New South Wales;[248] they designate the same birds.[249] It
title: Elementary Forms

text: is also the eagle-hawk and the crow which have given their names to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: two phratries of the Ngarigo and the Wolgal.[250] Among the Kuinmurbura,
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is the white cockatoo and the crow.[251] Many other examples might be
title: Elementary Forms

text: cited. Thus we are led to regard the phratry as an ancient clan which
title: Elementary Forms

text: has been dismembered; the actual clans are the product of this
title: Elementary Forms

text: dismemberment, and the solidarity which unites them is a souvenir of
title: Elementary Forms

text: their primitive unity.[252] It is true that in certain tribes, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: phratries no longer have special names, as it seems; in others where
title: Elementary Forms

text: these names exist, their meaning is no longer known, even to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: members. But there is nothing surprising in this. The phratries are
title: Elementary Forms

text: certainly a primitive institution, for they are everywhere in a state of
title: Elementary Forms

text: regression; their descendants the clans have passed to the first rank.
title: Elementary Forms

text: So it is but natural that the names which they bore should have been
title: Elementary Forms

text: effaced from memory little by little, when they were no longer
title: Elementary Forms

text: understood; for they must belong to a very archaic language no longer in
title: Elementary Forms

text: use. This is proved by the fact that in many cases where we know the
title: Elementary Forms

text: animal whose name the phratry bears, the word designating this animal in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the current language is very different from the one employed here.[253]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Between the totem of the phratry and the totems of the clans there
title: Elementary Forms

text: exists a sort of relation of subordination. In fact, in principle each
title: Elementary Forms

text: clan belongs to one and only one phratry; it is very exceptional that it
title: Elementary Forms

text: has representatives in the other phratry. This is not met with at all
title: Elementary Forms

text: except among certain central tribes, notably the Arunta;[254] also even
title: Elementary Forms

text: where, owing to disturbing influences, overlappings of this sort have
title: Elementary Forms

text: taken place, the great part of the clan is included entirely within one
title: Elementary Forms

text: or the other of the two groups of the tribe; only a small minority is to
title: Elementary Forms

text: be found in the other one.[255] As a rule then, the two phratries do not
title: Elementary Forms

text: overlap each other; consequently, the list of totems which an individual
title: Elementary Forms

text: may have is predetermined by the phratry to which he belongs. In other
title: Elementary Forms

text: words, the phratry is like a species of which the clans are varieties.
title: Elementary Forms

text: We shall presently see that this comparison is not purely metaphorical.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In addition to the phratries and clans, another secondary group is
title: Elementary Forms

text: frequently met with in Australian societies, which is not without a
title: Elementary Forms

text: certain individuality: these are the matrimonial classes.
title: Elementary Forms

text: By this name they designate certain subdivisions of the phratry, whose
title: Elementary Forms

text: number varies with the tribe: there are sometimes two and sometimes four
title: Elementary Forms

text: per phratry.[256] Their recruiting and operation are regulated by the
title: Elementary Forms

text: two following principles. In the first place, each generation in a
title: Elementary Forms

text: phratry belongs to different clans from the immediately preceding one.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Thus, when there are only two classes per phratry, they necessarily
title: Elementary Forms

text: alternate with each other every generation. The children make up the
title: Elementary Forms

text: class of which their parents are not members; but grandchildren are of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the same class as their grandparents. Thus, among the Kamilaroi, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Kupathin phratry has two classes, Ippai and Kumbo; the Dilby phratry,
title: Elementary Forms

text: two others which are called Murri and Kubbi. As descent is in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: uterine line, the child is in the phratry of its mother; if she is a
title: Elementary Forms

text: Kupathin, the child will be one also. But if she is of the Ippai class,
title: Elementary Forms

text: he will be a Kumbo; if the child is a girl, her children will again be
title: Elementary Forms

text: in the Ippai class.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Likewise, the children of the women of the Murri class will be in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Kubbi class, and the children of the Kubbi women will be Murri again.
title: Elementary Forms

text: When there are four classes per phratry, instead of two, the system is
title: Elementary Forms

text: naturally more complex, but the principle is the same. The four classes
title: Elementary Forms

text: form two couples of two classes each, and these two classes alternate
title: Elementary Forms

text: with each other every generation in the manner just indicated. Secondly,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the members of one class can in principle[257] marry into only one of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the classes of the other phratry. The Ippai must marry into the Kubbi
title: Elementary Forms

text: class and the Murri into the Kumbo class. It is because this
title: Elementary Forms

text: organization profoundly affects matrimonial relations that we give the
title: Elementary Forms

text: group the name of matrimonial class.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Now it may be asked whether these classes do not sometimes have totems
title: Elementary Forms

text: like the phratries and clans.
title: Elementary Forms

text: This question is raised by the fact that in certain tribes of
title: Elementary Forms

text: Queensland, each matrimonial class has dietetic restrictions that are
title: Elementary Forms

text: peculiar to it. The individuals who compose it must abstain from eating
title: Elementary Forms

text: the flesh of certain animals which the others may consume freely.[258]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Are these animals not totems?
title: Elementary Forms

text: But dietetic restrictions are not the characteristic marks of totemism.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The totem is a name first of all, and then, as we shall see, an emblem.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Now in the societies of which we just spoke, there are no matrimonial
title: Elementary Forms

text: classes which bear the name of an animal or plant, or which have an
title: Elementary Forms

text: emblem.[259] Of course it is possible that these restrictions are
title: Elementary Forms

text: indirectly derived from totemism. It might be supposed that the animals
title: Elementary Forms

text: which these interdictions protect were once the totems of clans which
title: Elementary Forms

text: have since disappeared, while the matrimonial classes remained. It is
title: Elementary Forms

text: certain that they have a force of endurance which the clans do not have.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Then these interdictions, deprived of their original field, may have
title: Elementary Forms

text: spread themselves out over the entire class, since there were no other
title: Elementary Forms

text: groups to which they could be attached. But it is clear that if this
title: Elementary Forms

text: regulation was born of totemism, it represents only an enfeebled and
title: Elementary Forms

text: denatured form of it.[260]
title: Elementary Forms

text: All that has been said of the totem in Australian societies is equally
title: Elementary Forms

text: applicable to the Indian tribes of North America. The only difference is
title: Elementary Forms

text: that among these latter, the totemic organization has a strictness of
title: Elementary Forms

text: outline and a stability which are not found in Australia. The Australian
title: Elementary Forms

text: clans are not only very numerous, but in a single tribe their number is
title: Elementary Forms

text: almost unlimited. Observers cite some of them as examples, but without
title: Elementary Forms

text: ever succeeding in giving us a complete list. This is because the list
title: Elementary Forms

text: is never definitely terminated. The same process of dismemberment which
title: Elementary Forms

text: broke up the original phratries and give birth to clans properly
title: Elementary Forms

text: so-called still continues within these latter; as a result of this
title: Elementary Forms

text: progressive crumbling, a clan frequently has only a very small effective
title: Elementary Forms

text: force.[261] In America, on the contrary, the totemic system has better
title: Elementary Forms

text: defined forms. Although the tribes there are considerably larger on the
title: Elementary Forms

text: average, the clans are less numerous. A single tribe rarely has more
title: Elementary Forms

text: than a dozen of them,[262] and frequently less; each of them is
title: Elementary Forms

text: therefore a much more important group. But above all, their number is
title: Elementary Forms

text: fixed; they know their exact number, and they it tell to us.[263]
title: Elementary Forms

text: This difference is due to the superiority of their social economy. From
title: Elementary Forms

text: the moment when these tribes were observed for the first time, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: social groups were strongly attached to the soil, and consequently
title: Elementary Forms

text: better able to resist the decentralizing forces which assailed them. At
title: Elementary Forms

text: the same time, the society had too keen a sentiment of its unity to
title: Elementary Forms

text: remain unconscious of itself and of the parts out of which it was
title: Elementary Forms

text: composed. The example of America thus enables us to explain even better
title: Elementary Forms

text: the organization at the base of the clans. We would take a mistaken
title: Elementary Forms

text: view, if we judged this only on the present conditions in Australia. In
title: Elementary Forms

text: fact, it is in a state of change and dissolution there, which is not at
title: Elementary Forms

text: all normal; it is much rather the product of a degeneration which we
title: Elementary Forms

text: see, due both to the natural decay of time and the disorganizing effect
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the whites. To be sure, it is hardly probable that the Australian
title: Elementary Forms

text: clans ever had the dimensions and solid structure of the American ones.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But there must have been a time when the distance between them was less
title: Elementary Forms

text: considerable than it is to-day, for the American societies would never
title: Elementary Forms

text: have succeeded in making so solid a structure if the clans had always
title: Elementary Forms

text: been of so fluid and inconsistent a nature.
title: Elementary Forms

text: This greater stability has even enabled the archaic system of phratries
title: Elementary Forms

text: to maintain itself in America with a clearness and a relief no longer to
title: Elementary Forms

text: be found in Australia. We have just seen that in the latter continent
title: Elementary Forms

text: the phratry is everywhere in a state of decadence; very frequently it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: nothing more than an anonymous group; when it has a name, this is either
title: Elementary Forms

text: no longer understood, or in any case, it cannot mean a great deal to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: native, since it is borrowed from a foreign language, or from one no
title: Elementary Forms

text: longer spoken. Thus we have been able to infer the existence of totems
title: Elementary Forms

text: for phratries only from a few survivals, which, for the most part, are
title: Elementary Forms

text: so slightly marked that they have escaped the attention of many
title: Elementary Forms

text: observers. In certain parts of America, on the contrary, this
title: Elementary Forms

text: institution has retained its primitive importance. The tribes of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: North-west coast, the Tlinkit and the Haida especially, have now
title: Elementary Forms

text: attained a relatively advanced civilization; yet they are divided into
title: Elementary Forms

text: two phratries which are subdivided into a certain number of clans: the
title: Elementary Forms

text: phratries of the Crow and the Wolf among the Tlinkit,[264] of the Eagle
title: Elementary Forms

text: and the Crow among the Haida.[265] And this division is not merely
title: Elementary Forms

text: nominal; it corresponds to an ever-existing state of tribal customs and
title: Elementary Forms

text: is deeply marked with the tribal life. The moral distance separating the
title: Elementary Forms

text: clans is very slight in comparison with that separating the
title: Elementary Forms

text: phratries.[266] The name of each is not a word whose sense is forgotten
title: Elementary Forms

text: or only vaguely known; it is a totem in the full sense of the term; they
title: Elementary Forms

text: have all its essential attributes, such as will be described below.[267]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Consequently, upon this point also, American tribes must not be
title: Elementary Forms

text: neglected, for we can study the totems of phratries directly there,
title: Elementary Forms

text: while Australia offers only obscure vestiges of them.
title: Elementary Forms

text: II
title: Elementary Forms

text: But the totem is not merely a name; it is an emblem, a veritable
title: Elementary Forms

text: coat-of-arms whose analogies with the arms of heraldry have often been
title: Elementary Forms

text: remarked. In speaking of the Australians, Grey says, "each family adopt
title: Elementary Forms

text: an animal or vegetable as their crest and sign,"[268] and what Grey
title: Elementary Forms

text: calls a family is incontestably a clan. Also Fison and Howitt say, "the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Australian divisions show that the totem is, in the first place, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: badge of a group."[269] Schoolcraft says the same thing about the totems
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the Indians of North America. "The totem is in fact a design which
title: Elementary Forms

text: corresponds to the heraldic emblems of civilized nations, and each
title: Elementary Forms

text: person is authorized to bear it as a proof of the identity of the family
title: Elementary Forms

text: to which it belongs. This is proved by the real etymology of the word,
title: Elementary Forms

text: which is derived from _dodaim_, which means village or the residence of
title: Elementary Forms

text: a family group."[270] Thus when the Indians entered into relations with
title: Elementary Forms

text: the Europeans and contracts were formed between them, it was with its
title: Elementary Forms

text: totem that each clan sealed the treaties thus concluded.[271]
title: Elementary Forms

text: The nobles of the feudal period carved, engraved and designed in every
title: Elementary Forms

text: way their coats-of-arms upon the walls of their castles, their arms, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: every sort of object that belonged to them; the blacks of Australia and
title: Elementary Forms

text: the Indians of North America do the same thing with their totems. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: Indians who accompanied Samuel Hearne painted their totems on their
title: Elementary Forms

text: shields before going into battle.[272] According to Charlevoix, in time
title: Elementary Forms

text: of war, certain tribes of Indians had veritable ensigns, made of bits of
title: Elementary Forms

text: bark fastened to the end of a pole, upon which the totems were
title: Elementary Forms

text: represented.[273] Among the Tlinkit, when a conflict breaks out between
title: Elementary Forms

text: two clans, the champions of the two hostile groups wear helmets over
title: Elementary Forms

text: their heads, upon which are painted their respective totems.[274] Among
title: Elementary Forms

text: the Iroquois, they put the skin of the animal which serves as totem upon
title: Elementary Forms

text: each wigwam, as a mark of the clan.[275] According to another observer,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the animal was stuffed and set up before the door.[276] Among the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Wyandot, each clan has its own ornaments and its distinctive
title: Elementary Forms

text: paintings.[277] Among the Omaha, and among the Sioux generally, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: totem is painted on the tent.[278]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Wherever the society has become sedentary, where the tent is replaced by
title: Elementary Forms

text: the house, and where the plastic arts are more fully developed, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: totem is engraved upon the woodwork and upon the walls. This is what
title: Elementary Forms

text: happens, for example, among the Haida, the Tsimshian, the Salish and the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Tlinkit. "A very particular ornament of the house, among the Tlinkit,"
title: Elementary Forms

text: says Krause, "is the totemic coat-of-arms." Animal forms, sometimes
title: Elementary Forms

text: combined with human forms, are engraved upon the posts at the sides of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the door of entry, which are as high as 15 yards; they are generally
title: Elementary Forms

text: painted with very bright colours.[279] However, these totemic
title: Elementary Forms

text: decorations are not very numerous in the Tlinkit village; they are found
title: Elementary Forms

text: almost solely before the houses of the chiefs and rich men. They are
title: Elementary Forms

text: much more frequent in the neighbouring tribe of the Haida; here there
title: Elementary Forms

text: are always several for each house.[280] With its many sculptured posts
title: Elementary Forms

text: arising on every hand, sometimes to a great height, a Haida village
title: Elementary Forms

text: gives the impression of a sacred city, all bristling with belfries or
title: Elementary Forms

text: little minarets.[281] Among the Salish, the totem is frequently
title: Elementary Forms

text: represented upon the interior walls of the house.[282] Elsewhere, it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: found upon the canoes, the utensils of every sort and the funeral
title: Elementary Forms

text: piles.[283]
title: Elementary Forms

text: The preceding examples are taken exclusively from the Indians of North
title: Elementary Forms

text: America. This is because sculpture, engravings and permanent figurations
title: Elementary Forms

text: are not possible except where the technique of the plastic arts has
title: Elementary Forms

text: reached a degree of perfection to which the Australian tribes have not
title: Elementary Forms

text: yet attained. Consequently the totemic representations of the sort which
title: Elementary Forms

text: we just mentioned are rarer and less apparent in Australia than in
title: Elementary Forms

text: America. However, cases of them are cited. Among the Warramunga, at the
title: Elementary Forms

text: end of the burial ceremonies, the bones of the dead man are interred,
title: Elementary Forms

text: after they have been dried and reduced to powder; beside the place where
title: Elementary Forms

text: they are deposited, a figure representing the totem is traced upon the
title: Elementary Forms

text: ground.[284] Among the Mara and the Anula, the body is placed in a piece
title: Elementary Forms

text: of hollow wood decorated with designs characteristic of the totem.[285]
title: Elementary Forms

text: In New South Wales, Oxley found engravings upon the trees near the tomb
title: Elementary Forms

text: where a native was buried[286] to which Brough Smyth attributes a
title: Elementary Forms

text: totemic character. The natives of the Upper Darling carve totemic images
title: Elementary Forms

text: upon their shields.[287] According to Collins, nearly all the utensils
title: Elementary Forms

text: are covered with ornaments which probably have the same significance;
title: Elementary Forms

text: figures of the same sort are found upon the rocks.[288] These totemic
title: Elementary Forms

text: designs may even be more frequent than it seems, for, owing to reasons
title: Elementary Forms

text: which will be discussed below, it is not always easy to see what their
title: Elementary Forms

text: real meaning is.
title: Elementary Forms

text: These different facts give us an idea of the considerable place held by
title: Elementary Forms

text: the totem in the social life of the primitives. However, up to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: present, it has appeared to us as something relatively outside of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: man, for it is only upon external things that we have seen it
title: Elementary Forms

text: represented. But totemic images are not placed only upon the walls of
title: Elementary Forms

text: their houses, the sides of their canoes, their arms, their utensils and
title: Elementary Forms

text: their tombs; they are also found on the bodies of the men. They do not
title: Elementary Forms

text: put their coat-of-arms merely upon the things which they possess, but
title: Elementary Forms

text: they put it upon their persons; they imprint it upon their flesh, it
title: Elementary Forms

text: becomes a part of them, and this world of representations is even by
title: Elementary Forms

text: far the more important one.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In fact, it is a very general rule that the members of each clan seek to
title: Elementary Forms

text: give themselves the external aspect of their totem. At certain religious
title: Elementary Forms

text: festivals among the Tlinkit, the person who is to direct the ceremonies
title: Elementary Forms

text: wears a garment which represents, either wholly or in part, the body of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the animal whose name he bears.[289] These same usages are also found in
title: Elementary Forms

text: all the North-West of America.[290] They are found again among the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Minnitaree, when they go into combat,[291] and among the Indians of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Pueblos.[292] Elsewhere, when the totem is a bird, men wear the feathers
title: Elementary Forms

text: of this bird on their heads.[293] Among the Iowa, each clan has a
title: Elementary Forms

text: special fashion of cutting the hair. In the Eagle clan, two large tufts
title: Elementary Forms

text: are arranged on the front of the head, while there is another one
title: Elementary Forms

text: behind; in the Buffalo clan, they are arranged in the form of
title: Elementary Forms

text: horns.[294] Among the Omaha, analogous arrangements are found: each clan
title: Elementary Forms

text: has its own head-dress. In the Turtle clan, for example, the hair is all
title: Elementary Forms

text: shaved off, except six bunches, two on each side of the head, one in
title: Elementary Forms

text: front, and one behind, in such a way as to imitate the legs, the head
title: Elementary Forms

text: and the tail of the animal.[295]
title: Elementary Forms

text: But it is more frequently upon the body itself that the totemic mark is
title: Elementary Forms

text: stamped: for this is a way of representation within the capacity of even
title: Elementary Forms

text: the least advanced societies. It has sometimes been asked whether the
title: Elementary Forms

text: common rite of knocking out a young man's two upper teeth at the age of
title: Elementary Forms

text: puberty does not have the object of reproducing the form of the totem.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The fact is not established, but it is worth mentioning that the natives
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves sometimes explain the custom thus. For example, among the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Arunta, the extraction of teeth is practised only in the clans of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: rain and of water; now according to tradition, the object of this
title: Elementary Forms

text: operation is to make their faces look like certain black clouds with
title: Elementary Forms

text: light borders which are believed to announce the speedy arrival of rain,
title: Elementary Forms

text: and which are therefore considered things of the same family.[296] This
title: Elementary Forms

text: is a proof that the native himself is conscious that the object of these
title: Elementary Forms

text: deformations is to give him, at least conventionally, the aspect of his
title: Elementary Forms

text: totem. Among these same Arunta, in the course of the rites of
title: Elementary Forms

text: sub-incision, certain gashes are cut upon the sisters and the future
title: Elementary Forms

text: wife of the novice; scars result from these, whose form is also
title: Elementary Forms

text: represented upon a certain sacred object of which we shall speak
title: Elementary Forms

text: presently and which is called the _churinga_; as we shall see, the lines
title: Elementary Forms

text: thus drawn upon the _churinga_ are emblematic of the totem.[297] Among
title: Elementary Forms

text: the Kaitish, the euro is believed to be closely connected with the
title: Elementary Forms

text: rain;[298] the men of the rain clan wear little ear-rings made of euro
title: Elementary Forms

text: teeth.[299] Among the Yerkla, during the initiation the young man is
title: Elementary Forms

text: given a certain number of slashes which leave scars; the number and form
title: Elementary Forms

text: of these varies with the totems.[300] An informer of Fison mentions the
title: Elementary Forms

text: same fact in the tribes observed by him.[301] According to Howitt, a
title: Elementary Forms

text: relationship of the same sort exists among the Dieri between certain
title: Elementary Forms

text: arrangements of scars and the water totem.[302] Among the Indians of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: North-West, it is a very general custom for them to tattoo themselves
title: Elementary Forms

text: with the totem.[303]
title: Elementary Forms

text: But even if the tattooings which are made by mutilations or scars do not
title: Elementary Forms

text: always have a totemic significance,[304] it is different with simple
title: Elementary Forms

text: designs drawn upon the body: they are generally representations of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: totem. It is true that the native does not carry them every day. When he
title: Elementary Forms

text: is occupied with purely economic occupations, or when the small family
title: Elementary Forms

text: groups scatter to hunt or fish, he does not bother with all this
title: Elementary Forms

text: paraphernalia, which is quite complicated. But when the clans unite to
title: Elementary Forms

text: live a common life and to assist at the religious ceremonies together,
title: Elementary Forms

text: then he must adorn himself. As we shall see, each of the ceremonies
title: Elementary Forms

text: concerns a particular totem, and in theory the rites which are connected
title: Elementary Forms

text: with a totem can be performed only by the men of that totem. Now those
title: Elementary Forms

text: who perform,[305] who take the part of officiants, and sometimes even
title: Elementary Forms

text: those who assist as spectators, always have designs representing the
title: Elementary Forms

text: totem on their bodies.[306] One of the principal rites of initiation, by
title: Elementary Forms

text: which a young man enters into the religious life of the tribe, consists
title: Elementary Forms

text: in painting the totemic symbol on his body.[307] It is true that among
title: Elementary Forms

text: the Arunta the design thus traced does not always and necessarily
title: Elementary Forms

text: represent the totem of the initiated;[308] but these are exceptions,
title: Elementary Forms

text: due, undoubtedly, to the disturbed state of the totemic organization of
title: Elementary Forms

text: this tribe.[309] Also, even among the Arunta, at the most solemn moment
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the initiation, which is its crown and consecration, when the
title: Elementary Forms

text: neophyte is allowed to enter the sanctuary where all the sacred objects
title: Elementary Forms

text: belonging to the clan are preserved, an emblematic painting is placed
title: Elementary Forms

text: upon him; this time, it is the totem of the young man which is thus
title: Elementary Forms

text: represented.[310] The bonds which unite the individual to his totem are
title: Elementary Forms

text: even so strong that in the tribes on the North-west coast of North
title: Elementary Forms

text: America, the emblem of the clan is painted not only upon the living but
title: Elementary Forms

text: also upon the dead: before a corpse is interred, they put the totemic
title: Elementary Forms

text: mark upon it.[311]
title: Elementary Forms

text: III
title: Elementary Forms

text: These totemic decorations enable us to see that the totem is not merely
title: Elementary Forms

text: a name and an emblem. It is in the course of the religious ceremonies
title: Elementary Forms

text: that they are employed; they are a part of the liturgy; so while the
title: Elementary Forms

text: totem is a collective label, it also has a religious character. In fact,
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is in connection with it, that things are classified as sacred or
title: Elementary Forms

text: profane. It is the very type of sacred thing.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The tribes of Central Australia, especially the Arunta, the Loritja, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Kaitish, the Unmatjera, and the Ilpirra,[312] make constant use of
title: Elementary Forms

text: certain instruments in their rites which are called the _churinga_ by
title: Elementary Forms

text: the Arunta, according to Spencer and Gillen, or the _tjurunga_,
title: Elementary Forms

text: according to Strehlow.[313] They are pieces of wood or bits of polished
title: Elementary Forms

text: stone, of a great variety of forms, but generally oval or oblong.[314]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Each totemic group has a more or less important collection of these.
title: Elementary Forms

text: _Upon each of these is engraved a design representing the totem of this
title: Elementary Forms

text: same group._[315] A certain number of the churinga have a hole at one
title: Elementary Forms

text: end, through which goes a thread made of human hair or that of an
title: Elementary Forms

text: opossum. Those which are made of wood and are pierced in this way serve
title: Elementary Forms

text: for exactly the same purposes as those instruments of the cult to which
title: Elementary Forms

text: English ethnographers have given the name of "bull-roarers." By means of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the thread by which they are suspended, they are whirled rapidly in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: air in such a way as to produce a sort of humming identical with that
title: Elementary Forms

text: made by the toys of this name still used by our children; this deafening
title: Elementary Forms

text: noise has a ritual significance and accompanies all ceremonies of any
title: Elementary Forms

text: importance. These sorts of churinga are real bull-roarers. But there are
title: Elementary Forms

text: others which are not made of wood and are not pierced; consequently they
title: Elementary Forms

text: cannot be employed in this way. Nevertheless, they inspire the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious sentiments.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In fact, every churinga, for whatever purpose it may be employed, is
title: Elementary Forms

text: counted among the eminently sacred things; there are none which surpass
title: Elementary Forms

text: it in religious dignity. This is indicated even by the word which is
title: Elementary Forms

text: used to designate them. It is not only a substantive but also an
title: Elementary Forms

text: adjective meaning sacred. Also, among the several names which each
title: Elementary Forms

text: Arunta has, there is one so sacred that it must not be revealed to a
title: Elementary Forms

text: stranger; it is pronounced but rarely, and then in a low voice and a
title: Elementary Forms

text: sort of mysterious murmur. Now this name is called the _aritna churinga_
title: Elementary Forms

text: (aritna means name).[316] In general, the word churinga is used to
title: Elementary Forms

text: designate all ritual acts; for example, _ilia churinga_ signifies the
title: Elementary Forms

text: cult of the emu.[317] Churinga, when used substantively, therefore
title: Elementary Forms

text: designates the thing whose essential characteristic is sacredness.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Profane persons, that is to say, women and young men not yet initiated
title: Elementary Forms

text: into the religious life, may not touch or even see the churinga; they
title: Elementary Forms

text: are only allowed to look at it from a distance, and even this is only on
title: Elementary Forms

text: rare occasions.[318]
title: Elementary Forms

text: The churinga are piously kept in a special place, which the Arunta call
title: Elementary Forms

text: the _ertnatulunga_.[319] This is a cave or a sort of cavern hidden in a
title: Elementary Forms

text: deserted place. The entrance is carefully closed by means of stones so
title: Elementary Forms

text: cleverly placed that a stranger going past it could not suspect that the
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious treasury of the clan was so near to him. The sacred character
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the churinga is so great that it communicates itself to the locality
title: Elementary Forms

text: where they are stored: the women and the uninitiated cannot approach it.
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is only after their initiation is completely finished that the young
title: Elementary Forms

text: men have access to it: there are some who are not esteemed worthy of
title: Elementary Forms

text: this favour except after years of trial.[320] The religious nature
title: Elementary Forms

text: radiates to a distance and communicates itself to all the surroundings:
title: Elementary Forms

text: everything near by participates in this same nature and is therefore
title: Elementary Forms

text: withdrawn from profane touch. Is one man pursued by another? If he
title: Elementary Forms

text: succeeds in reaching the ertnatulunga, he is saved; he cannot be seized
title: Elementary Forms

text: there.[321] Even a wounded animal which takes refuge there must be
title: Elementary Forms

text: respected.[322] Quarrels are forbidden there. It is a place of peace, as
title: Elementary Forms

text: is said in the Germanic societies; it is a sanctuary of the totemic
title: Elementary Forms

text: group, it is a veritable place of asylum.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But the virtues of the churinga are not manifested merely by the way in
title: Elementary Forms

text: which it keeps the profane at a distance. If it is thus isolated, it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: because it is something of a high religious value whose loss would
title: Elementary Forms

text: injure the group and the individuals severely. It has all sorts of
title: Elementary Forms

text: marvellous properties: by contact it heals wounds, especially those
title: Elementary Forms

text: resulting from circumcision;[323] it has the same power over
title: Elementary Forms

text: sickness;[324] it is useful for making the beard grow;[325] it confers
title: Elementary Forms

text: important powers over the totemic species, whose normal reproduction it
title: Elementary Forms

text: ensures;[326] it gives men force, courage and perseverance, while, on
title: Elementary Forms

text: the other hand, it depresses and weakens their enemies. This latter
title: Elementary Forms

text: belief is so firmly rooted that when two combatants stand pitted against
title: Elementary Forms

text: one another, if one sees that the other has brought churinga against
title: Elementary Forms

text: him, he loses confidence and his defeat is certain.[327] Thus there is
title: Elementary Forms

text: no ritual instrument which has a more important place in the religious
title: Elementary Forms

text: ceremonies.[328] By means of various sorts of anointings, their powers
title: Elementary Forms

text: are communicated either to the officiants or to the assistants; to bring
title: Elementary Forms

text: this about, they are rubbed over the members and stomach of the faithful
title: Elementary Forms

text: after being covered with grease;[329] or sometimes they are covered with
title: Elementary Forms

text: a down which flies away and scatters itself in every direction when they
title: Elementary Forms

text: are whirled; this a way of disseminating the virtues which are in
title: Elementary Forms

text: them.[330]
title: Elementary Forms

text: But they are not useful merely to individuals; the fate of the clan as a
title: Elementary Forms

text: whole is bound up with theirs. Their loss is a disaster; it is the
title: Elementary Forms

text: greatest misfortune which can happen to the group.[331] Sometimes they
title: Elementary Forms

text: leave the ertnatulunga, for example when they are loaned to other
title: Elementary Forms

text: groups.[332] Then follows a veritable public mourning. For two weeks,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the people of the totem weep and lament, covering their bodies with
title: Elementary Forms

text: white clay just as they do when they have lost a relative.[333] And the
title: Elementary Forms

text: churinga are not left at the free disposition of everybody; the
title: Elementary Forms

text: ertnatulunga where they are kept is placed under the control of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: chief of the group. It is true that each individual has special rights
title: Elementary Forms

text: to some of them;[334] yet, though he is their proprietor in a sense, he
title: Elementary Forms

text: cannot make use of them except with the consent and under the direction
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the chief. It is a collective treasury; it is the sacred ark of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: clan.[335] The devotion of which they are the object shows the high
title: Elementary Forms

text: price that is attached to them. The respect with which they are handled
title: Elementary Forms

text: is shown by the solemnity of the movements.[336] They are taken care of,
title: Elementary Forms

text: they are greased, rubbed, polished, and when they are moved from one
title: Elementary Forms

text: locality to another, it is in the midst of ceremonies which bear witness
title: Elementary Forms

text: to the fact that this displacement is regarded as an act of the highest
title: Elementary Forms

text: importance.[337]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Now in themselves, the churinga are objects of wood and stone like all
title: Elementary Forms

text: others; they are distinguished from profane things of the same sort by
title: Elementary Forms

text: only one particularity: this is that the totemic mark is drawn or
title: Elementary Forms

text: engraved upon them. So it is this mark and this alone which gives them
title: Elementary Forms

text: their sacred character. It is true that according to Spencer and Gillen,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the churinga serve as the residence of an ancestor's soul and that it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: the presence of this soul which confers these properties.[338] While
title: Elementary Forms

text: declaring this interpretation inexact, Strehlow, in his turn, proposes
title: Elementary Forms

text: another which does not differ materially from the other: he claims that
title: Elementary Forms

text: the churinga are considered the image of the ancestor's body, or the
title: Elementary Forms

text: body itself.[339] So, in any case, it would be sentiments inspired by
title: Elementary Forms

text: the ancestor which fix themselves upon the material object, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: convert it into a sort of fetish. But in the first place, both
title: Elementary Forms

text: conceptions,--which, by the way, scarcely differ except in the letter of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the myth,--have obviously been made up afterwards, to account for the
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacred character of the churinga. In the constitution of these pieces of
title: Elementary Forms

text: wood and bits of stone, and in their external appearance, there is
title: Elementary Forms

text: nothing which predestines them to be considered the seat of an ancestral
title: Elementary Forms

text: soul, or the image of his body. So if men have imagined this myth, it
title: Elementary Forms

text: was in order to explain the religious respect which these things
title: Elementary Forms

text: inspired in them, and the respect was not determined by the myth. This
title: Elementary Forms

text: explanation, like so many mythological explanations, resolves the
title: Elementary Forms

text: question only by repeating it in slightly different terms; for saying
title: Elementary Forms

text: that the churinga is sacred and saying that it has such and such a
title: Elementary Forms

text: relation with a sacred being, is merely to proclaim the same fact in two
title: Elementary Forms

text: different ways; it is not accounting for them. Moreover, according to
title: Elementary Forms

text: the avowal of Spencer and Gillen, there are some churinga among the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Arunta which are made by the old men of the group, to the knowledge of
title: Elementary Forms

text: and before the eyes of all;[340] these obviously do not come from the
title: Elementary Forms

text: great ancestors. However, except for certain differences of degree, they
title: Elementary Forms

text: have the same power as the others and are preserved in the same manner.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Finally, there are whole tribes where the churinga is never associated
title: Elementary Forms

text: with a spirit.[341] Its religious nature comes to it, then, from some
title: Elementary Forms

text: other source, and whence could it come, if not from the totemic stamp
title: Elementary Forms

text: which it bears? It is to this image, therefore, that the demonstrations
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the rite are really addressed; it is this which sanctifies the object
title: Elementary Forms

text: upon which it is carved.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Among the Arunta and the neighbouring tribes, there are two other
title: Elementary Forms

text: liturgical instruments closely connected with the totem and the
title: Elementary Forms

text: churinga itself, which ordinarily enters into their composition: they
title: Elementary Forms

text: are the _nurtunja_ and the _waninga_.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The nurtunja,[342] which is found among the northern Arunta and their
title: Elementary Forms

text: immediate neighbours,[343] is made up principally of a vertical support
title: Elementary Forms

text: which is either a single lance, or several lances united into a bundle,
title: Elementary Forms

text: or of a simple pole.[344] Bunches of grass are fastened all around it by
title: Elementary Forms

text: means of belts or little cords made of hair. Above this, down is placed,
title: Elementary Forms

text: arranged either in circles or in parallel lines which run from the top
title: Elementary Forms

text: to the bottom of the support. The top is decorated with the plumes of an
title: Elementary Forms

text: eagle-hawk. This is only the most general and typical form; in
title: Elementary Forms

text: particular cases, it has all sorts of variations.[345]
title: Elementary Forms

text: The waninga, which is found only among the southern Arunta, the Urabunna
title: Elementary Forms

text: and the Loritja, has no one unique model either. Reduced to its most
title: Elementary Forms

text: essential elements, it too consists in a vertical support, formed by a
title: Elementary Forms

text: long stick or by a lance several yards high, with sometimes one and
title: Elementary Forms

text: sometimes two cross-pieces.[346] In the former case, it has the
title: Elementary Forms

text: appearance of a cross. Cords made either of human hair or opossum or
title: Elementary Forms

text: bandicoot fur diagonally cross the space included between the arms of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the cross and the extremities of the central axis; as they are quite
title: Elementary Forms

text: close to each other, they form a network in the form of a lozenge. When
title: Elementary Forms

text: there are two cross-bars, these cords go from one to the other and from
title: Elementary Forms

text: these to the top and bottom of the support. They are sometimes covered
title: Elementary Forms

text: with a layer of down, thick enough to conceal the foundation. Thus the
title: Elementary Forms

text: waninga has the appearance of a veritable flag.[347]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Now the nurtunja and the waninga, which figure in a multitude of
title: Elementary Forms

text: important rites, are the object of a religious respect quite like that
title: Elementary Forms

text: inspired by the churinga. The process of their manufacture and erection
title: Elementary Forms

text: is conducted with the greatest solemnity. Fixed in the earth, or carried
title: Elementary Forms

text: by an officiant, they mark the central point of the ceremony: it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: about them that the dances take place and the rites are performed. In
title: Elementary Forms

text: the course of the initiation, the novice is led to the foot of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: nurtunja erected for the occasion. Someone says to him, "There is the
title: Elementary Forms

text: nurtunja of your father; many young men have already been made by it."
title: Elementary Forms

text: After that, the initiate must kiss the nurtunja.[348] By this kiss, he
title: Elementary Forms

text: enters into relations with the religious principle which resides there;
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is a veritable communion which should give the young man the force
title: Elementary Forms

text: required to support the terrible operation of sub-incision.[349] The
title: Elementary Forms

text: nurtunja also plays a considerable role in the mythology of these
title: Elementary Forms

text: societies. The myths relate that in the fabulous times of the great
title: Elementary Forms

text: ancestors, the territory of the tribe was overrun in every direction by
title: Elementary Forms

text: companies composed exclusively of individuals of the same totem.[350]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Each of these troops had a nurtunja with it. When it stopped to camp,
title: Elementary Forms

text: before scattering to hunt, the members fixed their nurtunja in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: ground, from the top of which their churinga was suspended.[351] That is
title: Elementary Forms

text: equivalent to saying that they confided the most precious things they
title: Elementary Forms

text: had to it. It was at the same time a sort of standard which served as a
title: Elementary Forms

text: rallying-centre for the group. One cannot fail to be struck by the
title: Elementary Forms

text: analogies between the nurtunja and the sacred post of the Omaha.[352]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Now its sacred character can come from only one cause: that is that it
title: Elementary Forms

text: represents the totem materially. The vertical lines or rings of down
title: Elementary Forms

text: which cover it, and even the cords of different colours which fasten the
title: Elementary Forms

text: arms of the waninga to the central axis, are not arranged arbitrarily,
title: Elementary Forms

text: according to the taste of the makers; they must conform to a type
title: Elementary Forms

text: strictly determined by tradition which, in the minds of the natives,
title: Elementary Forms

text: represents the totem.[353] Here we cannot ask, as we did in the case of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the churinga, whether the veneration accorded to this instrument of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: cult is not merely the reflex of that inspired by the ancestors; for it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is a rule that each nurtunja and each waninga last only during the
title: Elementary Forms

text: ceremony where they are used. They are made all over again every time
title: Elementary Forms

text: that it is necessary, and when the rite is once accomplished, they are
title: Elementary Forms

text: stripped of their ornaments and the elements out of which they are made
title: Elementary Forms

text: are scattered.[354] They are nothing more than images--and temporary
title: Elementary Forms

text: images at that--of the totem, and consequently it is on this ground,
title: Elementary Forms

text: and on this ground alone, that they play a religious role.
title: Elementary Forms

text: So the churinga, the nurtunja and the waninga owe their religious nature
title: Elementary Forms

text: solely to the fact that they bear the totemic emblem. It is the emblem
title: Elementary Forms

text: that is sacred. It keeps this character, no matter where it may be
title: Elementary Forms

text: represented. Sometimes it is painted upon rocks; these paintings are
title: Elementary Forms

text: called _churinga ilkinia_, sacred drawings.[355] The decorations with
title: Elementary Forms

text: which the officiants and assistants at the religious ceremonies adorn
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves have the same name: women and children may not see them.[356]
title: Elementary Forms

text: In the course of certain rites, the totem is drawn upon the ground. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: way in which this is done bears witness to the sentiments inspired by
title: Elementary Forms

text: this design, and the high value attributed to it; it is traced upon a
title: Elementary Forms

text: place that has been previously sprinkled, and saturated with human
title: Elementary Forms

text: blood,[357] and we shall presently see that the blood is in itself a
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacred liquid, serving for pious uses only. When the design has been
title: Elementary Forms

text: made, the faithful remain seated on the ground before it, in an attitude
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the purest devotion.[358] If we give the word a sense corresponding
title: Elementary Forms

text: to the mentality of the primitive, we may say that they adore it. This
title: Elementary Forms

text: enables us to understand how the totemic blazon has remained something
title: Elementary Forms

text: very precious for the Indians of North America: it is always surrounded
title: Elementary Forms

text: with a sort of religious halo.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But if we are seeking to understand how it comes that these totemic
title: Elementary Forms

text: representations are so sacred, it is not without interest to see what
title: Elementary Forms

text: they consist in.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Among the Indians of North America, they are painted, engraved or carved
title: Elementary Forms

text: images which attempt to reproduce as faithfully as possible the external
title: Elementary Forms

text: aspect of the totemic animal. The means employed are those which we use
title: Elementary Forms

text: to-day in similar circumstances, except that they are generally cruder.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But it is not the same in Australia, and it is in the Australian
title: Elementary Forms

text: societies that we must seek the origin of these representations.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Although the Australian may show himself sufficiently capable of
title: Elementary Forms

text: imitating the forms of things in a rudimentary way,[359] sacred
title: Elementary Forms

text: representations generally seem to show no ambitions in this line: they
title: Elementary Forms

text: consist essentially in geometrical designs drawn upon the churinga, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: nurtunga, rocks, the ground, or the human body. They are either straight
title: Elementary Forms

text: or curved lines, painted in different ways,[360] and the whole having
title: Elementary Forms

text: only a conventional meaning. The connection between the figure and the
title: Elementary Forms

text: thing represented is so remote and indirect that it cannot be seen,
title: Elementary Forms

text: except when it is pointed out. Only the members of the clan can say what
title: Elementary Forms

text: meaning is attached to such and such combinations of lines.[361] Men and
title: Elementary Forms

text: women are generally represented by semicircles, and animals by whole
title: Elementary Forms

text: circles or spirals,[362] the tracks of men or animals by lines of
title: Elementary Forms

text: points, etc. The meaning of the figures thus obtained is so arbitrary
title: Elementary Forms

text: that a single design may have two different meanings for the men of two
title: Elementary Forms

text: different totems, representing one animal here, and another animal or
title: Elementary Forms

text: plant there. This is perhaps still more apparent with the nurtunja and
title: Elementary Forms

text: waninga. Each of them represents a different totem. But the few and
title: Elementary Forms

text: simple elements which enter into their composition do not allow a great
title: Elementary Forms

text: variety of combinations. The result is that two nurtunja may have
title: Elementary Forms

text: exactly the same appearance, and yet express two things as different as
title: Elementary Forms

text: a gum tree and an emu.[363] When a nurtunja is made, it is given a
title: Elementary Forms

text: meaning which it keeps during the whole ceremony, but which, in the last
title: Elementary Forms

text: resort, is fixed by convention.
title: Elementary Forms

text: These facts prove that if the Australian is so strongly inclined to
title: Elementary Forms

text: represent his totem, it is in order not to have a portrait of it before
title: Elementary Forms

text: his eyes which would constantly renew the sensation of it; it is merely
title: Elementary Forms

text: because he feels the need of representing the idea which he forms of it
title: Elementary Forms

text: by means of material and external signs, no matter what these signs may
title: Elementary Forms

text: be. We are not yet ready to attempt to understand what has thus caused
title: Elementary Forms

text: the primitive to write his idea of his totem upon his person and upon
title: Elementary Forms

text: different objects, but it is important to state at once the nature of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the need which has given rise to these numerous representations.[364]
title: Elementary Forms

text: CHAPTER II
title: Elementary Forms

text: TOTEMIC BELIEFS--_continued_
title: Elementary Forms

text: _The Totemic Animal and Man_
title: Elementary Forms

text: But totemic images are not the only sacred things. There are real things
title: Elementary Forms

text: which are also the object of rites, because of the relations which they
title: Elementary Forms

text: have with the totem: before all others, are the beings of the totemic
title: Elementary Forms

text: species and the members of the clan.
title: Elementary Forms

text: I
title: Elementary Forms

text: First of all, since the designs which represent the totem arouse
title: Elementary Forms
