text: religious sentiments, it is natural that the things whose aspect these
title: Elementary Forms

text: designs reproduce should have this same property, at least to a certain
title: Elementary Forms

text: degree.
title: Elementary Forms

text: For the most part, these are animals or plants. The profane function of
title: Elementary Forms

text: vegetables and even of animals is ordinarily to serve as food; then the
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacred character of the totemic animal or plant is shown by the fact
title: Elementary Forms

text: that it is forbidden to eat them. It is true that since they are sacred
title: Elementary Forms

text: things, they can enter into the composition of certain mystical repasts,
title: Elementary Forms

text: and we shall see, in fact, that they sometimes serve as veritable
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacraments; yet normally they cannot be used for everyday consumption.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Whoever oversteps this rule, exposes himself to grave dangers. It is not
title: Elementary Forms

text: that the group always intervenes to punish this infraction artificially;
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is believed that the sacrilege produces death automatically. A
title: Elementary Forms

text: redoubtable principle is held to reside in the totemic plant or animal,
title: Elementary Forms

text: which cannot enter into the profane organism without disorganizing it or
title: Elementary Forms

text: destroying it.[365] In certain tribes at least, only the old men are
title: Elementary Forms

text: free from this prohibition;[366] we shall see the reason for this later.
title: Elementary Forms

text: However, if this prohibition is formal in a large number of
title: Elementary Forms

text: tribes[367]--with certain exceptions which will be mentioned later--it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is incontestable that it tends to weaken as the old totemic organization
title: Elementary Forms

text: is disturbed. But the restrictions which remain even then prove that
title: Elementary Forms

text: these attenuations are not admitted without difficulty. For example,
title: Elementary Forms

text: when it is permitted to eat the plant or animal that serves as totem, it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is not possible to do so freely; only a little bit may be taken at a
title: Elementary Forms

text: time. To go beyond this amount is a ritual fault that has grave
title: Elementary Forms

text: consequences.[368] Elsewhere, the prohibition remains intact for the
title: Elementary Forms

text: parts that are regarded as the most precious, that is to say, as the
title: Elementary Forms

text: most sacred; for example, the eggs or the fat.[369] In still other
title: Elementary Forms

text: parts, consumption is not allowed except when the animal in question has
title: Elementary Forms

text: not yet reached full maturity.[370] In this case, they undoubtedly think
title: Elementary Forms

text: that its sacred character is not yet complete. So the barrier which
title: Elementary Forms

text: isolates and protects the totemic being yields but slowly and with
title: Elementary Forms

text: active resistance, which bears witness to what it must have been at
title: Elementary Forms

text: first.
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is true that according to Spencer and Gillen these restrictions are
title: Elementary Forms

text: not the remnants of what was once a rigorous prohibition now losing
title: Elementary Forms

text: hold, but the beginnings of an interdiction which is only commencing to
title: Elementary Forms

text: establish itself. These writers hold[371] that at first there was a
title: Elementary Forms

text: complete liberty of consumption and that the limitations which were
title: Elementary Forms

text: presently brought are relatively recent. They think they find the proof
title: Elementary Forms

text: of their theory in the two following facts. In the first place, as we
title: Elementary Forms

text: just said, there are solemn occasions when the members of the clan or
title: Elementary Forms

text: their chief not only may, but must eat the totemic animal or plant.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Moreover, the myths relate that the great ancestors, the founders of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: clans, ate their totems regularly: now, it is said, these stories cannot
title: Elementary Forms

text: be understood except as an echo of a time when the present prohibitions
title: Elementary Forms

text: did not exist.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But the fact that in the course of certain solemn ceremonies a
title: Elementary Forms

text: consumption of the totem, and a moderate one at that, is ritually
title: Elementary Forms

text: required in no way implies that it was once an ordinary article of food.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Quite on the contrary, the food that one eats at a mystical repast is
title: Elementary Forms

text: essentially sacred, and consequently forbidden to the profane. As for
title: Elementary Forms

text: the myths, a somewhat summary critical method is employed, if they are
title: Elementary Forms

text: so readily given the value of historical documents. In general, their
title: Elementary Forms

text: object is to interpret existing rites rather than to commemorate past
title: Elementary Forms

text: events; they are an explanation of the present much more than a history.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In this case, the traditions according to which the ancestors of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: fabulous epoch ate their totem are in perfect accord with the beliefs
title: Elementary Forms

text: and rites which are always in force. The old men and those who have
title: Elementary Forms

text: attained a high religious dignity are freed from the restrictions under
title: Elementary Forms

text: which ordinary men are placed:[372] they can eat the sacred thing
title: Elementary Forms

text: because they are sacred themselves; this rule is in no way peculiar to
title: Elementary Forms

text: totemism, but it is found in all the most diverse religions. Now the
title: Elementary Forms

text: ancestral heroes were nearly gods. It is therefore still more natural
title: Elementary Forms

text: that they should eat the sacred food;[373] but that is no reason why the
title: Elementary Forms

text: same privilege should be awarded to the simple profane.[374]
title: Elementary Forms

text: However, it is neither certain nor even probable that the prohibition
title: Elementary Forms

text: was ever absolute. It seems to have always been suspended in case of
title: Elementary Forms

text: necessity, as, for example, when a man is famished and has nothing else
title: Elementary Forms

text: with which to nourish himself.[375] A stronger reason for this is found
title: Elementary Forms

text: when the totem is a form of nourishment which a man cannot do without.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Thus there are a great many tribes where water is a totem; a strict
title: Elementary Forms

text: prohibition is manifestly impossible in this case. However, even here,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the privilege granted is submitted to certain restrictions which greatly
title: Elementary Forms

text: limit its use and which show clearly that it goes against a recognized
title: Elementary Forms

text: principle. Among the Kaitish and the Warramunga, a man of this totem is
title: Elementary Forms

text: not allowed to drink water freely; he may not take it up himself; he may
title: Elementary Forms

text: receive it only from the hands of a third party who must belong to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: phratry of which he is not a member.[376] The complexity of this
title: Elementary Forms

text: procedure and the embarrassment which results from it are still another
title: Elementary Forms

text: proof that access to the sacred thing is not free. This same rule is
title: Elementary Forms

text: applied in certain central tribes every time that the totem is eaten,
title: Elementary Forms

text: whether from necessity or any other cause. It should also be added that
title: Elementary Forms

text: when this formality is not possible, that is, when a man is alone or
title: Elementary Forms

text: with members of his own phratry only, he may, on necessity, do without
title: Elementary Forms

text: an intermediary. It is clear that the prohibition is susceptible of
title: Elementary Forms

text: various moderations.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Nevertheless, it rests upon ideas so strongly ingrained in the mind that
title: Elementary Forms

text: it frequently survives its original cause for being. We have seen that
title: Elementary Forms

text: in all probability, the different clans of a phratry are only
title: Elementary Forms

text: subdivisions of one original clan which has been dismembered. So there
title: Elementary Forms

text: was a time when all the clans, being welded together, had the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: totem; consequently, wherever the souvenir of this common origin is not
title: Elementary Forms

text: completely effaced, each clan continues to feel itself united to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: others and to consider that their totems are not completely foreign to
title: Elementary Forms

text: it. For this reason an individual may not eat freely of the totems held
title: Elementary Forms

text: by the different clans of the phratry of which he is a member; he may
title: Elementary Forms

text: touch them only if the forbidden plant or animal is given him by a
title: Elementary Forms

text: member of the other phratry.[377]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Another survival of the same sort is the one concerning the maternal
title: Elementary Forms

text: totem. There are strong reasons for believing that at first, the totem
title: Elementary Forms

text: was transmitted in the uterine line. Therefore, wherever descent in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: paternal line has been introduced, this probably took place only after a
title: Elementary Forms

text: long period, during which the opposite principle was applied and the
title: Elementary Forms

text: child had the totem of his mother along with all the restrictions
title: Elementary Forms

text: attached to it. Now in certain tribes where the child inherits the
title: Elementary Forms

text: paternal totem to-day, some of the interdictions which originally
title: Elementary Forms

text: protected the totem of his mother still survive: he cannot eat it
title: Elementary Forms

text: freely.[378] In the present state of affairs, however, there is no
title: Elementary Forms

text: longer anything corresponding to this prohibition.
title: Elementary Forms

text: To this prohibition of eating is frequently added that of killing the
title: Elementary Forms

text: totem, or picking it, when it is a plant.[379] However, here also there
title: Elementary Forms

text: are exceptions and tolerations. These are especially in the case of
title: Elementary Forms

text: necessity, when the totem is a dangerous animal,[380] for example, or
title: Elementary Forms

text: when the man has nothing to eat. There are even tribes where men are
title: Elementary Forms

text: forbidden to hunt the animals whose names they bear, on their own
title: Elementary Forms

text: accounts, but where they may kill them for others.[381] But the way in
title: Elementary Forms

text: which this act is generally accomplished clearly indicates that it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: something illicit. One excuses himself as though for a fault, and bears
title: Elementary Forms

text: witness to the chagrin which he suffers and the repugnance which he
title: Elementary Forms

text: feels,[382] while precautions are taken that the animal may suffer as
title: Elementary Forms

text: little as possible.[383]
title: Elementary Forms

text: In addition to these fundamental interdictions, certain cases of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: prohibition of contact between a man and his totem are cited. Thus among
title: Elementary Forms

text: the Omaha, in the clan of the Elk, no one may touch any part of the body
title: Elementary Forms

text: of a male elk; in the sub-clan of the Buffalo, no one is allowed to
title: Elementary Forms

text: touch the head of this animal.[384] Among the Bechuana, no man dares to
title: Elementary Forms

text: clothe himself in the skin of his totem.[385] But these cases are rare;
title: Elementary Forms

text: and it is natural that they should be exceptional, for normally a man
title: Elementary Forms

text: must wear the image of his totem or something which brings it to mind.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The tattooings and the totemic costumes would not be possible if all
title: Elementary Forms

text: contact were forbidden. It has also been remarked that this prohibition
title: Elementary Forms

text: has not been found in Australia, but only in those societies where
title: Elementary Forms

text: totemism has advanced far from its original form; it is therefore
title: Elementary Forms

text: probably of late origin and due perhaps to the influence of ideas that
title: Elementary Forms

text: are really not totemic at all.[386]
title: Elementary Forms

text: If we now compare these various interdictions with those whose object is
title: Elementary Forms

text: the totemic emblem, contrarily to all that could be foreseen, it appears
title: Elementary Forms

text: that these latter are more numerous, stricter, and more severely
title: Elementary Forms

text: enforced than the former. The figures of all sorts which represent the
title: Elementary Forms

text: totem are surrounded with a respect sensibly superior to that inspired
title: Elementary Forms

text: by the very being whose form these figures reproduce. The churinga, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: nurtunja and the waninga can never be handled by the women or the
title: Elementary Forms

text: uninitiated, who are even allowed to catch glimpses of it only very
title: Elementary Forms

text: exceptionally, and from a respectful distance. On the other hand, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: plant or animal whose name the clan bears may be seen and touched by
title: Elementary Forms

text: everybody. The churinga are preserved in a sort of temple, upon whose
title: Elementary Forms

text: threshold all noises from the profane life must cease; it is the domain
title: Elementary Forms

text: of sacred things. On the contrary, the totemic animals and plants live
title: Elementary Forms

text: in the profane world and are mixed up with the common everyday life.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Since the number and importance of the interdictions which isolate a
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacred thing, and keep it apart, correspond to the degree of sacredness
title: Elementary Forms

text: with which it is invested, we arrive at the remarkable conclusion that
title: Elementary Forms

text: _the images of totemic beings are more sacred than the beings
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves_. Also, in the ceremonies of the cult, it is the churinga and
title: Elementary Forms

text: the nurtunja which have the most important place; the animal appears
title: Elementary Forms

text: there only very exceptionally. In a certain rite, of which we shall have
title: Elementary Forms

text: occasion to speak,[387] it serves as the substance for a religious
title: Elementary Forms

text: repast, but it plays no active role. The Arunta dance around the
title: Elementary Forms

text: nurtunja, and assemble before the image of their totem to adore it, but
title: Elementary Forms

text: a similar demonstration is never made before the totemic being itself.
title: Elementary Forms

text: If this latter were the primarily sacred object, it would be with it,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the sacred animal or plant, that the young initiate would communicate
title: Elementary Forms

text: when he is introduced into the religious life; but we have seen that on
title: Elementary Forms

text: the contrary, the most solemn moment of the initiation is the one when
title: Elementary Forms

text: the novice enters into the sanctuary of the churinga. It is with them
title: Elementary Forms

text: and the nurtunja that he communicates. The representations of the totem
title: Elementary Forms

text: are therefore more actively powerful than the totem itself.
title: Elementary Forms

text: II
title: Elementary Forms

text: We must now determine the place of man in the scheme of religious
title: Elementary Forms

text: things.
title: Elementary Forms

text: By the force of a whole group of acquired habits and of language itself,
title: Elementary Forms

text: we are inclined to consider the common man, the simple believer, as an
title: Elementary Forms

text: essentially profane being. It may well happen that this conception is
title: Elementary Forms

text: not literally true for any religion;[388] in any case, it is not
title: Elementary Forms

text: applicable to totemism. Every member of the clan is invested with a
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacred character which is not materially inferior to that which we just
title: Elementary Forms

text: observed in the animal. This personal sacredness is due to the fact that
title: Elementary Forms

text: the man believes that while he is a man in the usual sense of the word,
title: Elementary Forms

text: he is also an animal or plant of the totemic species.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In fact, he bears its name; this identity of name is therefore supposed
title: Elementary Forms

text: to imply an identity of nature. The first is not merely considered as an
title: Elementary Forms

text: outward sign of the second; it supposes it logically. This is because
title: Elementary Forms

text: the name, for a primitive, is not merely a word or a combination of
title: Elementary Forms

text: sounds; it is a part of the being, and even something essential to it. A
title: Elementary Forms

text: member of the Kangaroo clan calls himself a kangaroo; he is therefore,
title: Elementary Forms

text: in one sense, an animal of this species. "The totem of any man," say
title: Elementary Forms

text: Spencer and Gillen, "is regarded as the same thing as himself; a native
title: Elementary Forms

text: once said to us when we were discussing the matter with him, 'That one,'
title: Elementary Forms

text: pointing to his photograph which we had taken, 'is the same thing as me:
title: Elementary Forms

text: so is a kangaroo' (his totem)."[389] So each individual has a double
title: Elementary Forms

text: nature: two beings coexist within him, a man and an animal.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In order to give a semblance of intelligibility to this duality, so
title: Elementary Forms

text: strange for us, the primitive has invented myths which, it is true,
title: Elementary Forms

text: explain nothing and only shift the difficulty, but which, by shifting
title: Elementary Forms

text: it, seem at least to lessen the logical scandal. With slight variations
title: Elementary Forms

text: of detail, all are constructed on the same plan: their object is to
title: Elementary Forms

text: establish genealogical connections between the man and the totemic
title: Elementary Forms

text: animal, making the one a relative of the other. By this common origin,
title: Elementary Forms

text: which, by the way, is represented in various manners, they believe that
title: Elementary Forms

text: they account for their common nature. The Narrinyeri, for example, have
title: Elementary Forms

text: imagined that certain of the first men had the power of transforming
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves into beasts.[390] Other Australian societies place at the
title: Elementary Forms

text: beginning of humanity either strange animals from which the men were
title: Elementary Forms

text: descended in some unknown way,[391] or mixed beings, half-way between
title: Elementary Forms

text: the two kingdoms,[392] or else unformed creatures, hardly representable,
title: Elementary Forms

text: deprived of all determined organs, and even of all definite members, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: the different parts of whose bodies were hardly outlined.[393] Mythical
title: Elementary Forms

text: powers, sometimes conceived under the form of animals, then intervened
title: Elementary Forms

text: and made men out of these ambiguous and innumerable beings which Spencer
title: Elementary Forms

text: and Gillen say represent "stages in the transformation of animals and
title: Elementary Forms

text: plants into human beings."[394] These transformations are represented to
title: Elementary Forms

text: us under the form of violent and, as it were, surgical operations. It is
title: Elementary Forms

text: under the blows of an axe or, if the operator is a bird, blows of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: beak, that the human individual was carved out of this shapeless mass,
title: Elementary Forms

text: his members separated from each other, his mouth opened and his nostrils
title: Elementary Forms

text: pierced.[395] Analogous legends are found in America, except that owing
title: Elementary Forms

text: to the more highly developed mentality of these peoples, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: representations which they employ do not contain confusions so
title: Elementary Forms

text: troublesome for the mind. Sometimes it is a legendary personage who, by
title: Elementary Forms

text: an act of his power, metamorphosed the animal who gives its name to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: clan into a man.[396] Sometimes the myth attempts to explain how, by a
title: Elementary Forms

text: series of nearly natural events and a sort of spontaneous evolution, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: animal transformed himself little by little, and finally took a human
title: Elementary Forms

text: form.[397]
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is true that there are societies (the Haida, Tlinkit, Tsimshian)
title: Elementary Forms

text: where it is no longer admitted that man was born of an animal or plant;
title: Elementary Forms

text: but the idea of an affinity between the animals of the totemic species
title: Elementary Forms

text: and the members of the clan has survived there nevertheless, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: expresses itself in myths which, though differing from the preceding,
title: Elementary Forms

text: still retain all that is essential in them. Here is one of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: fundamental themes. The ancestor who gives his name to the clan is here
title: Elementary Forms

text: represented as a human being, but who, in the course of various
title: Elementary Forms

text: wanderings, has been led to live for a while among the fabulous animals
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the very species which gave the clan its name. As the result of this
title: Elementary Forms

text: intimate and prolonged connection, he became so like his new companions
title: Elementary Forms

text: that when he returned to men, they no longer recognized him. He was
title: Elementary Forms

text: therefore given the name of the animal which he resembled. It is from
title: Elementary Forms

text: his stay in this mythical land that he brought back the totemic emblem,
title: Elementary Forms

text: together with the powers and virtues believed to be attached to it.[398]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Thus in this case, as in the others, men are believed to participate in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the nature of the animal, though this participation may be conceived in
title: Elementary Forms

text: slightly different forms.[399]
title: Elementary Forms

text: So man also has something sacred about him. Though diffused into the
title: Elementary Forms

text: whole organism, this characteristic is especially apparent in certain
title: Elementary Forms

text: privileged places. There are organs and tissues that are specially
title: Elementary Forms

text: marked out: these are particularly the blood and the hair.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In the first place, human blood is so holy a thing that in the tribes of
title: Elementary Forms

text: Central Australia, it frequently serves to consecrate the most respected
title: Elementary Forms

text: instruments of the cult. For example, in certain cases, the nurtunja is
title: Elementary Forms

text: regularly anointed from top to bottom with the blood of a man.[400] It
title: Elementary Forms

text: is upon ground all saturated with blood that the men of the Emu, among
title: Elementary Forms

text: the Arunta, trace their sacred images.[401] We shall presently see that
title: Elementary Forms

text: streams of blood are poured upon the rocks which represent the totemic
title: Elementary Forms

text: animals and plants.[402] There is no religious ceremony where blood does
title: Elementary Forms

text: not have some part to play.[403] During the initiation, the adults open
title: Elementary Forms

text: their veins and sprinkle the novice with their blood; and this blood is
title: Elementary Forms

text: so sacred a thing that women may not be present while it is flowing; the
title: Elementary Forms

text: sight of it is forbidden them, just as the sight of a churinga is.[404]
title: Elementary Forms

text: The blood lost by a young initiate during the very violent operations he
title: Elementary Forms

text: must undergo has very particular virtues: it is used in various
title: Elementary Forms

text: ceremonies.[405] That which flows during the sub-incision is piously
title: Elementary Forms

text: kept by the Arunta and buried in a place upon which they put a piece of
title: Elementary Forms

text: wood warning passers-by of the sacredness of the spot; no woman should
title: Elementary Forms

text: approach it.[406] The religious nature of blood also explains the equal
title: Elementary Forms

text: importance, religiously, of the red ochre, which is very frequently
title: Elementary Forms

text: employed in ceremonies; they rub the churinga with it and use it in
title: Elementary Forms

text: ritual decorations.[407] This is due to the fact that because of its
title: Elementary Forms

text: colour, it is regarded as something kindred to blood. Many deposits of
title: Elementary Forms

text: red ochre which are found in the Arunta territory are even supposed to
title: Elementary Forms

text: be the coagulated blood which certain heroines of the mythical period
title: Elementary Forms

text: shed on to the soil.[408]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Hair has similar properties. The natives of the centre wear belts made
title: Elementary Forms

text: of human hair, whose religious functions we have already pointed out:
title: Elementary Forms

text: they are also used to wrap up certain instruments of the cult.[409]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Does one man loan another one of his churinga? As a sign of
title: Elementary Forms

text: acknowledgment, the second makes a present of hair to the first; these
title: Elementary Forms

text: two sorts of things are therefore thought to be of the same order and of
title: Elementary Forms

text: equivalent value.[410] So the operation of cutting the hair is a ritual
title: Elementary Forms

text: act, accompanied by definite ceremonies: the individual operated upon
title: Elementary Forms

text: must squat on the ground, with his face turned in the direction of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: place where the fabulous ancestors from which the clan of his mother is
title: Elementary Forms

text: believed to be descended, are thought to have camped.[411] For the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: reason, as soon as a man is dead, they cut his hair off and put it away
title: Elementary Forms

text: in some distant place, for neither women nor the non-initiated have the
title: Elementary Forms

text: right of seeing it: it is here, far from profane eyes, that the belts
title: Elementary Forms

text: are made.[412]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Other organic tissues might be mentioned which have similar properties,
title: Elementary Forms

text: in varying degrees: such are the whiskers, the foreskin, the fat of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: liver, etc.[413] But it is useless to multiply examples. Those already
title: Elementary Forms

text: given are enough to prove that there is something in man which holds
title: Elementary Forms

text: profane things at a distance and which possesses a religious power; in
title: Elementary Forms

text: other words, the human organism conceals within its depths a sacred
title: Elementary Forms

text: principle, which visibly comes to the surface in certain determined
title: Elementary Forms

text: cases. This principle does not differ materially from that which causes
title: Elementary Forms

text: the religious character of the totem. In fact, we have just seen that
title: Elementary Forms

text: the different substances in which it incarnates itself especially enter
title: Elementary Forms

text: into the ritual composition of the objects of the cult (nurtunja,
title: Elementary Forms

text: totemic designs), or else are used in the anointings whose object is to
title: Elementary Forms

text: renew the virtues either of the churinga or of the sacred rocks; they
title: Elementary Forms

text: are things of the same species.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Sometimes the religious dignity which is inherent in each member of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: clan on this account is not equal for all. Men possess it to a higher
title: Elementary Forms

text: degree than women; in relation to them, women are like profane
title: Elementary Forms

text: beings.[414] Thus, every time that there is an assembly, either of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: totemic group or of the tribe, the men have a separate camp, distinct
title: Elementary Forms

text: from that of the women, and into which these latter may not enter: they
title: Elementary Forms

text: are separated off.[415] But there are also differences in the way in
title: Elementary Forms

text: which men are marked with a religious character. The young men not yet
title: Elementary Forms

text: initiated are wholly deprived of it, since they are not admitted to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: ceremonies. It is among the old men that it reaches its greatest
title: Elementary Forms

text: intensity. They are so very sacred that certain things forbidden to
title: Elementary Forms

text: ordinary people are permissible for them: they may eat the totemic
title: Elementary Forms

text: animal more freely and, as we have seen, there are even some tribes
title: Elementary Forms

text: where they are freed from all dietetic restrictions.
title: Elementary Forms

text: So we must be careful not to consider totemism a sort of animal worship.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The attitude of a man towards the animals or plants whose name he bears
title: Elementary Forms

text: is not at all that of a believer towards his god, for he belongs to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacred world himself. Their relations are rather those of two beings who
title: Elementary Forms

text: are on the same level and of equal value. The most that can be said is
title: Elementary Forms

text: that in certain cases, at least, the animal seems to occupy a slightly
title: Elementary Forms

text: more elevated place in the hierarchy of sacred things. It is because of
title: Elementary Forms

text: this that it is sometimes called the father or the grandfather of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: men of the clan, which seems to show that they feel themselves in a
title: Elementary Forms

text: state of moral dependence in regard to it.[416] But in other, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: perhaps even more frequent cases, it happens that the expressions used
title: Elementary Forms

text: denote rather a sentiment of equality. The totemic animal is called the
title: Elementary Forms

text: friend or the elder brother of its human fellows.[417] Finally, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: bonds which exist between them and it are much more like those which
title: Elementary Forms

text: unite the members of a single family; the animals and the men are made
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the same flesh, as the Buandik say.[418] On account of this kinship,
title: Elementary Forms

text: men regard the animals of the totemic species as kindly associates upon
title: Elementary Forms

text: whose aid they think they can rely. They call them to their aid[419] and
title: Elementary Forms

text: they come, to direct their blows in the hunt and to give warning of
title: Elementary Forms

text: whatever dangers there may be.[420] In return for this, men treat them
title: Elementary Forms

text: with regard and are never cruel to them;[421] but these attentions in no
title: Elementary Forms

text: way resemble a cult.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Men sometimes even appear to have a mysterious sort of property-right
title: Elementary Forms

text: over their totems. The prohibition against killing and eating them is
title: Elementary Forms

text: applied only to members of the clan, of course; it could not be extended
title: Elementary Forms

text: to other persons without making life practically impossible. If, in a
title: Elementary Forms

text: tribe like the Arunta, where there is such a host of different totems,
title: Elementary Forms

text: it were forbidden to eat, not only the animal or plant whose name one
title: Elementary Forms

text: bears, but also all the animals and all the plants which serve as totems
title: Elementary Forms

text: to other clans, the sources of food would be reduced to nothing. Yet
title: Elementary Forms

text: there are tribes where the consumption of the totemic plant or animal is
title: Elementary Forms

text: not allowed without restrictions, even to foreigners. Among the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Wakelbura, it must not take place in the presence of men of this
title: Elementary Forms

text: totem.[422] In other places, their permission must be given. For
title: Elementary Forms

text: example, among the Kaitish and the Unmatjera, whenever a man of the Emu
title: Elementary Forms

text: totem happens to be in a place occupied by a grass-seed clan, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: gathers some of these seed, before eating them he must go to the chief
title: Elementary Forms

text: and say to him, "I have gathered these seeds in your country." To this
title: Elementary Forms

text: the chief replies, "All right; you may eat them." But if the Emu man ate
title: Elementary Forms

text: them before demanding permission, it is believed that he would fall sick
title: Elementary Forms

text: and run the risk of dying.[423] There are even cases where the chief of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the group must take a little of the food and eat it himself: it is a
title: Elementary Forms

text: sort of payment which must be made.[424] For the same reason, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: churinga gives the hunter a certain power over the corresponding animal:
title: Elementary Forms

text: by rubbing his body with a Euro churinga, for example, a man acquires a
title: Elementary Forms

text: greater chance of catching euros.[425] This is the proof that the fact
title: Elementary Forms

text: of participating in the nature of a totemic being confers a sort of
title: Elementary Forms

text: eminent right over this latter. Finally, there is one tribe in northern
title: Elementary Forms

text: Queensland, the Karingbool, where the men of the totem are the only ones
title: Elementary Forms

text: who have a right to kill the animal or, if the totem is a tree, to peel
title: Elementary Forms

text: off its bark. Their aid is indispensable to all others who want to use
title: Elementary Forms

text: the flesh of this animal or the wood of this tree for their own personal
title: Elementary Forms

text: ends.[426] So they appear as proprietors, though it is quite evidently
title: Elementary Forms

text: over a special sort of property, of which we find it hard to form an
title: Elementary Forms

text: idea.
title: Elementary Forms

text: CHAPTER III
title: Elementary Forms

text: TOTEMIC BELIEFS--_continued_
title: Elementary Forms

text: _The Cosmological System of Totemism and the Idea of Class_
title: Elementary Forms

text: We are beginning to see that totemism is a much more complex religion
title: Elementary Forms

text: than it first appeared to be. We have already distinguished three
title: Elementary Forms

text: classes of things which it recognizes as sacred, in varying degrees: the
title: Elementary Forms

text: totemic emblem, the animal or plant whose appearance this emblem
title: Elementary Forms

text: reproduces, and the members of the clan. However, this list is not yet
title: Elementary Forms

text: complete. In fact, a religion is not merely a collection of fragmentary
title: Elementary Forms

text: beliefs in regard to special objects like those we have just been
title: Elementary Forms

text: discussing. To a greater or less extent, all known religions have been
title: Elementary Forms

text: systems of ideas which tend to embrace the universality of things, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: to give us a complete representation of the world. If totemism is to be
title: Elementary Forms

text: considered as a religion comparable to the others, it too should offer
title: Elementary Forms

text: us a conception of the universe. As a matter of fact, it does satisfy
title: Elementary Forms

text: this condition.
title: Elementary Forms

text: I
title: Elementary Forms

text: The fact that this aspect of totemism has generally been neglected is
title: Elementary Forms

text: due to the too narrow notion of the clan which has been prevalent.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Ordinarily it is regarded as a mere group of human beings. Being a
title: Elementary Forms

text: simple subdivision of the tribe, it seems that like this, it is made up
title: Elementary Forms

text: of nothing but men. But in reasoning thus, we substitute our European
title: Elementary Forms

text: ideas for those which the primitive has of man and of society. For the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Australian, things themselves, everything which is in the universe, are
title: Elementary Forms

text: a part of the tribe; they are constituent elements of it and, so to
title: Elementary Forms

text: speak, regular members of it; just like men, they have a determined
title: Elementary Forms

text: place in the general scheme of organization of the society. "The South
title: Elementary Forms

text: Australian savage," says Fison, "looks upon the universe as the Great
title: Elementary Forms

text: Tribe, to one of whose divisions he himself belongs; and all things,
title: Elementary Forms

text: animate and inanimate, which belong to his class are parts of the body
title: Elementary Forms

text: corporate whereof he himself is a part."[427] As a consequence of this
title: Elementary Forms

text: principle, whenever the tribe is divided into two phratries, all known
title: Elementary Forms

text: things are distributed between them. "All nature," says Palmer, in
title: Elementary Forms

text: speaking of the Bellinger River tribe, "is also divided into class
title: Elementary Forms

text: [phratry] names.... The sun and moon and stars are said ... to belong
title: Elementary Forms

text: to classes [phratries] just as the blacks themselves."[428] The Port
title: Elementary Forms

text: Mackay tribe in Queensland has two phratries with the names Yungaroo and
title: Elementary Forms

text: Wootaroo, as do the neighbouring tribes. Now as Bridgmann says, "all
title: Elementary Forms

text: things, animate and inanimate, are divided by these tribes into two
title: Elementary Forms

text: classes, named Yungaroo and Wootaroo."[429] Nor does the classification
title: Elementary Forms

text: stop here. The men of each phratry are distributed among a certain
title: Elementary Forms

text: number of clans; likewise, the things attributed to each phratry are in
title: Elementary Forms

text: their turn distributed among the clans of which the phratry is composed.
title: Elementary Forms

text: A certain tree, for example, will be assigned to the Kangaroo clan, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: to it alone; then, just like the human members of the clan, it will have
title: Elementary Forms

text: the Kangaroo as totem; another will belong to the Snake clan; clouds
title: Elementary Forms

text: will be placed under one totem, the sun under another, etc. All known
title: Elementary Forms

text: things will thus be arranged in a sort of tableau or systematic
title: Elementary Forms

text: classification embracing the whole of nature.
title: Elementary Forms

text: We have given a certain number of these classifications elsewhere;[430]
title: Elementary Forms

text: at present we shall confine ourselves to repeating a few of these as
title: Elementary Forms

text: examples. One of the best known of these is the one found in the Mount
title: Elementary Forms

text: Gambier tribe. This tribe includes two phratries, named respectively the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Kumite and the Kroki; each of these, in its turn, is subdivided into
title: Elementary Forms

text: five clans. Now "everything in nature belongs to one or another of these
title: Elementary Forms

text: ten clans";[431] Fison and Howitt say that they are all "included"
title: Elementary Forms

text: within it. In fact, they are classified under these ten totems just like
title: Elementary Forms

text: species in their respective classes. This is well shown by the following
title: Elementary Forms

text: table based on information gathered by Curr and by Fison and
title: Elementary Forms

text: Howitt.[432]
title: Elementary Forms

text: PHRATRIES.          CLANS.               THINGS CLASSED IN EACH CLAN.
title: Elementary Forms

text: { Fish-hawk                   { Smoke, honeysuckle, certain
title: Elementary Forms

text: {                             {   trees, etc.
title: Elementary Forms

text: { Pelican                     { Blackwood-trees, dogs, fire,
title: Elementary Forms

text: {                             {   frost, etc.
title: Elementary Forms

text: KUMITE   { Crow                        { Rain, thunder, lightning,
title: Elementary Forms

text: {                             {   clouds, hail, winter, etc.
title: Elementary Forms

text: { Black cockatoo              { The stars, the moon, etc.
title: Elementary Forms

text: { A non-poisonous snake       { Fish, seal, eel, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: {   stringybark-tree, etc.
title: Elementary Forms

text: { Tea-tree                    { Duck, crayfish, owls, etc.
title: Elementary Forms

text: { An edible root              { Bustard, quail, a small
title: Elementary Forms

text: KROKI    {                             {   kangaroo, etc.
title: Elementary Forms

text: { A white crestless cockatoo  { Kangaroo, the summer, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: {                             {   sun, wind, the autumn, etc.
title: Elementary Forms

text: { Details are lacking for the fourth and fifth Kroki clans.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The list of things attached to each clan is quite incomplete; Curr
title: Elementary Forms

text: himself warns us that he has limited himself to enumerating some of
title: Elementary Forms

text: them. But through the work of Mathews and of Howitt[433] we have more
title: Elementary Forms

text: extended information to-day on the classification adopted by the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Wotjobaluk tribe, which enables us to understand better how a system of
title: Elementary Forms

text: this kind is able to include the whole universe, as known to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: natives. The Wotjobaluk also are divided into two phratries called
title: Elementary Forms

text: Gurogity and Gumaty (Krokitch and Gamutch according to Howitt[434]); not
title: Elementary Forms

text: to prolong this enumeration, we shall content ourselves with indicating,
title: Elementary Forms

text: after Mathews, the things classed in some of the clans of the Gurogity
title: Elementary Forms

text: phratry.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In the clan of the Yam are classified the plain-turkey, the native cat,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the _mopoke_, the _dyim-dyim_ owl, the _mallee_ hen, the rosella parrot,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the peewee.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In the Mussel[435] clan are the grey emu, the porcupine, the curlew, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: white cockatoo, the wood-duck, the _mallee_ lizard, the stinking turtle,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the flying squirrel, the ring-tail opossum, the bronze-wing pigeon, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: _wijuggla_.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In the Sun clan are the bandicoot, the moon, the kangaroo-rat, the black
title: Elementary Forms

text: and white magpies, the opossum, the _ng[)u]rt_ hawk, the gum-tree grub,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the wattle-tree grub, the planet Venus.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In the clan of the Warm Wind[436] are the grey-headed eagle-hawk, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: carpet snake, the smoker parrot, the shell parrot, the _murrakan_ hawk,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the _dikkomur_ snake, the ring-neck parrot, the _mirudai_ snake, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: shingle-back lizard.
title: Elementary Forms

text: If we remember that there are many other clans (Howitt names twelve and
title: Elementary Forms

text: Mathews fourteen and adds that his list is incomplete[437]), we will
title: Elementary Forms

text: understand how all the things in which the native takes an interest find
title: Elementary Forms

text: a natural place in these classifications.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Similar arrangements have been observed in the most diverse parts of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the Australian continent; in South Australia, in Victoria, and in New
title: Elementary Forms

text: South Wales (among the Euahlayi[438]); very clear traces of it are found
title: Elementary Forms

text: in the central tribes.[439] In Queensland, where the clans seem to have
title: Elementary Forms

text: disappeared and where the matrimonial classes are the only subdivisions
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the phratry, things are divided up among these classes. Thus, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Wakelbura are divided into two phratries, Mallera and Wutaru; the
title: Elementary Forms

text: classes of the first are called Kurgilla and Banbe, those of the second,
title: Elementary Forms

text: Wungo and Obu. Now to the Banbe belong the opossum, the kangaroo, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: dog, honey of little bees, etc.; to the Wungo are attributed the emu,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the bandicoot, the black duck, the black snake, the brown snake; to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Obu, the carpet snake, the honey of stinging bees, etc.; to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Kurgilla, the porcupine, the turkey of the plains, water, rain, fire,
title: Elementary Forms

text: thunder, etc.[440]
title: Elementary Forms

text: This same organization is found among the Indians of North America. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: Zuni have a system of classification which, in its essential lines, is
title: Elementary Forms

text: in all points comparable to the one we have just described. That of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Omaha rests on the same principles as that of the Wotjobaluk.[441] An
title: Elementary Forms

text: echo of these same ideas survives even into the more advanced societies.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Among the Haida, all the gods and mythical beings who are placed in
title: Elementary Forms

text: charge of the different phenomena of nature are classified in one or the
title: Elementary Forms

text: other of the two phratries which make up the tribe just like men; some
title: Elementary Forms

text: are Eagles, the others, Crows.[442] Now the gods of things are only
title: Elementary Forms

text: another aspect of the things which they govern.[443] This mythological
title: Elementary Forms

text: classification is therefore merely another form of the preceding one. So
title: Elementary Forms

text: we may rest assured that this way of conceiving the world is independent
title: Elementary Forms

text: of all ethnic or geographic particularities; and at the same time it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: clearly seen to be closely united to the whole system of totemic
title: Elementary Forms

text: beliefs.
title: Elementary Forms

text: II
title: Elementary Forms

text: In the paper to which we have already made allusion several times, we
title: Elementary Forms

text: have shown what light these facts throw upon the way in which the idea
title: Elementary Forms

text: of kind or class was formed in humanity. In fact, these systematic
title: Elementary Forms

text: classifications are the first we meet with in history, and we have just
title: Elementary Forms

text: seen that they are modelled upon the social organization, or rather that
title: Elementary Forms

text: they have taken the forms of society as their framework. It is the
title: Elementary Forms

text: phratries which have served as classes, and the clans as species. It is
title: Elementary Forms

text: because men were organized that they have been able to organize things,
title: Elementary Forms

text: for in classifying these latter, they limited themselves to giving them
title: Elementary Forms

text: places in the groups they formed themselves. And if these different
title: Elementary Forms

text: classes of things are not merely put next to each other, but are
title: Elementary Forms

text: arranged according to a unified plan, it is because the social groups
title: Elementary Forms

text: with which they commingle themselves are unified and, through their
title: Elementary Forms

text: union, form an organic whole, the tribe. The unity of these first
title: Elementary Forms

text: logical systems merely reproduces the unity of the society. Thus we have
title: Elementary Forms

text: an occasion for verifying the proposition which we laid down at the
title: Elementary Forms

text: commencement of this work, and for assuring ourselves that the
title: Elementary Forms

text: fundamental notions of the intellect, the essential categories of
title: Elementary Forms

text: thought, may be the product of social factors. The above-mentioned facts
title: Elementary Forms

text: show clearly that this is the case with the very notion of category
title: Elementary Forms

text: itself.
title: Elementary Forms

text: However, it is not our intention to deny that the individual intellect
title: Elementary Forms

text: has of itself the power of perceiving resemblances between the different
title: Elementary Forms

text: objects of which it is conscious. Quite on the contrary, it is clear
title: Elementary Forms

text: that even the most primitive and simple classifications presuppose this
title: Elementary Forms

text: faculty. The Australian does not place things in the same clan or in
title: Elementary Forms

text: different clans at random. For him as for us, similar images attract one
title: Elementary Forms

text: another, while opposed ones repel one another, and it is on the basis of
title: Elementary Forms

text: these feelings of affinity or of repulsion that he classifies the
title: Elementary Forms

text: corresponding things in one place or another.
title: Elementary Forms

text: There are also cases where we are able to perceive the reasons which
title: Elementary Forms

text: inspired this. The two phratries were very probably the original and
title: Elementary Forms

text: fundamental bases for these classifications, which were consequently
title: Elementary Forms

text: bifurcate at first. Now, when a classification is reduced to two
title: Elementary Forms

text: classes, these are almost necessarily conceived as antitheses; they are
title: Elementary Forms

text: used primarily as a means of clearly separating things between which
title: Elementary Forms

text: there is a very marked contrast. Some are set at the right, the others
title: Elementary Forms

text: at the left. As a matter of fact this is the character of the Australian
title: Elementary Forms

text: classifications. If the white cockatoo is in one phratry, the black one
title: Elementary Forms

text: is in the other; if the sun is on one side, the moon and the stars of
title: Elementary Forms

text: night are on the opposite side.[444] Very frequently the beings which
title: Elementary Forms

text: serve as the totems of the two phratries have contrary colours.[445]
title: Elementary Forms

text: These oppositions are even met with outside of Australia. Where one of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the phratries is disposed to peace, the other is disposed to war;[446]
title: Elementary Forms

text: if one has water as its totem, the other has earth.[447] This is
title: Elementary Forms

text: undoubtedly the explanation of why the two phratries have frequently
title: Elementary Forms

text: been thought of as naturally antagonistic to one another. They say that
title: Elementary Forms

text: there is a sort of rivalry or even a constitutional hostility between
title: Elementary Forms

text: them.[448] This opposition of things has extended itself to persons; the
title: Elementary Forms

text: logical contrast has begotten a sort of social conflict.[449]
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is also to be observed that within each phratry, those things have
title: Elementary Forms

text: been placed in a single clan which seem to have the greatest affinity
title: Elementary Forms

text: with that serving as totem. For example, the moon has been placed with
title: Elementary Forms

text: the black cockatoo, but the sun, together with the atmosphere and the
title: Elementary Forms

text: wind, with the white cockatoo. Or again, to a totemic animal has been
title: Elementary Forms

text: united all that serves him as food,[450] as well as the animals with
title: Elementary Forms

text: which he has the closest connection.[451] Of course, we cannot always
title: Elementary Forms

text: understand the obscure psychology which has caused many of these
title: Elementary Forms

text: connections and distinctions, but the preceding examples are enough to
title: Elementary Forms

text: show that a certain intuition of the resemblances and differences
title: Elementary Forms

text: presented by things has played an important part in the genesis of
title: Elementary Forms

text: these classifications.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But the feeling of resemblances is one thing and the idea of class is
title: Elementary Forms

text: another. The class is the external framework of which objects perceived
title: Elementary Forms

text: to be similar form, in part, the contents. Now the contents cannot
title: Elementary Forms

text: furnish the frame into which they fit. They are made up of _vague and
title: Elementary Forms

text: fluctuating_ images, due to the super-imposition and partial fusion of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: _determined number of individual images_, which are found to have common
title: Elementary Forms

text: elements; the framework, on the contrary, is a _definite form_, with
title: Elementary Forms

text: fixed outlines, but which may be applied to an _undetermined number of
title: Elementary Forms

text: things_, perceived or not, actual or possible. In fact, every class has
title: Elementary Forms

text: possibilities of extension which go far beyond the circle of objects
title: Elementary Forms

text: which we know, either from direct experience or from resemblance. This
title: Elementary Forms

text: is why every school of thinkers has refused, and not with good reason,
title: Elementary Forms

text: to identify the idea of class with that of a generic image. The generic
title: Elementary Forms

text: image is only the indistinctly-bounded residual representation left in
title: Elementary Forms

text: us by similar representations, when they are present in consciousness
title: Elementary Forms

text: simultaneously; the class is a logical symbol by means of which we think
title: Elementary Forms

text: distinctly of these similarities and of other analogous ones. Moreover,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the best proof of the distance separating these two notions is that an
title: Elementary Forms

text: animal is able to form generic images though ignorant of the art of
title: Elementary Forms

text: thinking in classes and species.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The idea of class is an instrument of thought which has obviously been
title: Elementary Forms

text: constructed by men. But in constructing it, we have at least had need of
title: Elementary Forms

text: a model; for how could this idea ever have been born, if there had been
title: Elementary Forms

text: nothing either in us or around us which was capable of suggesting it to
title: Elementary Forms

text: us? To reply that it was given to us _a priori_ is not to reply at all;
title: Elementary Forms

text: this lazy man's solution is, as has been said, the death of analysis.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But it is hard to see where we could have found this indispensable model
title: Elementary Forms

text: except in the spectacle of the collective life. In fact, a class is not
title: Elementary Forms

text: an ideal, but a clearly defined group of things between which internal
title: Elementary Forms

text: relationships exist, similar to those of kindred. Now the only groups of
title: Elementary Forms

text: this sort known from experience are those formed by men in associating
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves. Material things may be able to form collections of units, or
title: Elementary Forms

text: heaps, or mechanical assemblages with no internal unity, but not groups
title: Elementary Forms

text: in the sense we have given the word. A heap of sand or a pile of rock is
title: Elementary Forms

text: in no way comparable to that variety of definite and organized society
title: Elementary Forms

text: which forms a class. In all probability, we would never have thought of
title: Elementary Forms

text: uniting the beings of the universe into homogeneous groups, called
title: Elementary Forms

text: classes, if we had not had the example of human societies before our
title: Elementary Forms

text: eyes, if we had not even commenced by making things themselves members
title: Elementary Forms

text: of men's society, and also if human groups and logical groups had not
title: Elementary Forms

text: been confused at first.[452]
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is also to be borne in mind that a classification is a system whose
title: Elementary Forms

text: parts are arranged according to a hierarchy. There are dominating
title: Elementary Forms

text: members and others which are subordinate to the first; species and their
title: Elementary Forms

text: distinctive properties depend upon classes and the attributes which
title: Elementary Forms

text: characterize them; again, the different species of a single class are
title: Elementary Forms

text: conceived as all placed on the same level in regard to each other. Does
title: Elementary Forms

text: someone prefer to regard them from the point of view of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: understanding? Then he represents things to himself in an inverse order:
title: Elementary Forms

text: he puts at the top the species that are the most particularized and the
title: Elementary Forms

text: richest in reality, while the types that are most general and the
title: Elementary Forms

text: poorest in qualities are at the bottom. Nevertheless, all are
title: Elementary Forms

text: represented in a hierarchic form. And we must be careful not to believe
title: Elementary Forms

text: that the expression has only a metaphorical sense here: there are really
title: Elementary Forms

text: relations of subordination and co-ordination, the establishment of which
title: Elementary Forms

text: is the object of all classification, and men would never have thought of
title: Elementary Forms

text: arranging their knowledge in this way if they had not known beforehand
title: Elementary Forms

text: what a hierarchy was. But neither the spectacle of physical nature nor
title: Elementary Forms

text: the mechanism of mental associations could furnish them with this
title: Elementary Forms

text: knowledge. The hierarchy is exclusively a social affair. It is only in
title: Elementary Forms

text: society that there are superiors, inferiors and equals. Consequently,
title: Elementary Forms

text: even if the facts were not enough to prove it, the mere analysis of
title: Elementary Forms

text: these ideas would reveal their origin. We have taken them from society,
title: Elementary Forms

text: and projected them into our conceptions of the world. It is society that
title: Elementary Forms

text: has furnished the outlines which logical thought has filled in.
title: Elementary Forms

text: III
title: Elementary Forms

text: But these primitive classifications have a no less direct interest for
title: Elementary Forms

text: the origins of religious thought.
title: Elementary Forms

text: They imply that all the things thus classed in a single clan or a single
title: Elementary Forms

text: phratry are closely related both to each other and to the thing serving
title: Elementary Forms

text: as the totem of this clan or phratry. When an Australian of the Port
title: Elementary Forms

text: Mackay tribe says that the sun, snakes, etc., are of the Yungaroo
title: Elementary Forms

text: phratry, he does not mean merely to apply a common, but none the less a
title: Elementary Forms

text: purely conventional, nomenclature to these different things; the word
title: Elementary Forms

text: has an objective signification for him. He believes that "alligators
title: Elementary Forms

text: really _are_ Yungaroo and that kangaroos are Wootaroo. The sun _is_
title: Elementary Forms

text: Yungaroo, the moon Wootaroo, and so on for the constellations, trees,
title: Elementary Forms

text: plants, etc."[453] An internal bond attaches them to the group in which
title: Elementary Forms

text: they are placed; they are regular members of it. It is said that they
title: Elementary Forms

text: belong to the group,[454] just exactly as the individual men make a part
title: Elementary Forms

text: of it; consequently, the same sort of a relation unites them to these
title: Elementary Forms

text: latter. Men regard the things in their clan as their relatives or
title: Elementary Forms

text: associates; they call them their friends and think that they are made
title: Elementary Forms

text: out of the same flesh as themselves.[455] Therefore, between the two
title: Elementary Forms

text: there are elective affinities and quite special relations of agreement.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Things and people have a common name, and in a certain way they
title: Elementary Forms

text: naturally understand each other and harmonize with one another. For
title: Elementary Forms

text: example, when a Wakelbura of the Mallera phratry is buried, the scaffold
title: Elementary Forms

text: upon which the body is exposed "must be made of the wood of some tree
title: Elementary Forms

text: belonging to the Mallera phratry."[456] The same is true for the
title: Elementary Forms

text: branches that cover the corpse. If the deceased is of the Banbe class, a
title: Elementary Forms

text: Banbe tree must be used. In this same tribe, a magician can use in his
title: Elementary Forms

text: art only those things which belong to his own phratry;[457] since the
title: Elementary Forms

text: others are strangers to him, he does not know how to make them obey him.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Thus a bond of mystic sympathy unites each individual to those beings,
title: Elementary Forms

text: whether living or not, which are associated with him; the result of this
title: Elementary Forms

text: is a belief in the possibility of deducing what he will do or what he
title: Elementary Forms

text: has done from what they are doing. Among these same Wakelbura, when a
title: Elementary Forms

text: man dreams that he has killed an animal belonging to a certain social
title: Elementary Forms

text: division, he expects to meet a man of this same division the next
title: Elementary Forms

text: day.[458] Inversely, the things attributed to a clan or phratry cannot
title: Elementary Forms

text: be used against the members of this clan or phratry. Among the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Wotjobaluk, each phratry has its own special trees. Now in hunting an
title: Elementary Forms

text: animal of the Gurogity phratry, only arms whose wood is taken from trees
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the other phratry may be used, and _vice versa_; otherwise the hunter
title: Elementary Forms

text: is sure to miss his aim.[459] The native is convinced that the arrow
title: Elementary Forms

text: would turn of itself and refuse, so to speak, to hit a kindred and
title: Elementary Forms

text: friendly animal.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Thus the men of the clan and the things which are classified in it form
title: Elementary Forms

text: by their union a solid system, all of whose parts are united and vibrate
title: Elementary Forms

text: sympathetically. This organization, which at first may have appeared to
title: Elementary Forms

text: us as purely logical, is at the same time moral. A single principle
title: Elementary Forms

text: animates it and makes its unity: this is the totem. Just as a man who
title: Elementary Forms

text: belongs to the Crow clan has within him something of this animal, so the
title: Elementary Forms

text: rain, since it is of the same clan and belongs to the same totem, is
title: Elementary Forms

text: also necessarily considered as being "the same thing as a crow"; for the
title: Elementary Forms

text: same reason, the moon is a black cockatoo, the sun a white cockatoo,
title: Elementary Forms

text: every black-nut tree a pelican, etc. All the beings arranged in a single
title: Elementary Forms

text: clan, whether men, animals, plants or inanimate objects, are merely
title: Elementary Forms

text: forms of the totemic being. This is the meaning of the formula which we
title: Elementary Forms

text: have just cited and this is what makes the two really of the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: species: all are really of the same flesh in the sense that all partake
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the nature of the totemic animal. Also, the qualifiers given them are
title: Elementary Forms

text: those given to the totem.[460] The Wotjobaluk give the name _Mir_ both
title: Elementary Forms

text: to the totem and to the things classed with it.[461] It is true that
title: Elementary Forms

text: among the Arunta, where visible traces of classification still exist, as
title: Elementary Forms

text: we shall see, different words designate the totem and the other beings
title: Elementary Forms

text: placed with it; however, the name given to these latter bears witness to
title: Elementary Forms

text: the close relations which unite them to the totemic animal. It is said
title: Elementary Forms

text: that they are its _intimates_, its _associates_, its _friends_; it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: believed that they are inseparable from it.[462] So there is a feeling
title: Elementary Forms

text: that these are very closely related things.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But we also know that the totemic animal is a sacred being. All the
title: Elementary Forms

text: things that are classified in the clan of which it is the emblem have
title: Elementary Forms

text: this same character, because in one sense, they are animals of the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: species, just as the man is. They, too, are sacred, and the
title: Elementary Forms

text: classifications which locate them in relation to the other things of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: universe, by that very act give them a place in the religious world. For
title: Elementary Forms

text: this reason, the animals or plants among these may not be eaten freely
title: Elementary Forms

text: by the human members of the clan. Thus in the Mount Gambier tribe, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: men whose totem is a certain non-poisonous snake must not merely refrain
title: Elementary Forms

text: from eating the flesh of this snake; that of seals, eels, etc., is also
title: Elementary Forms

text: forbidden to them.[463] If, driven by necessity, they do eat some of it,
title: Elementary Forms

text: they must at least attenuate the sacrilege by expiatory rites, just as
title: Elementary Forms

text: if they had eaten the totem itself.[464] Among the Euahlayi, where it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is permitted to use the totem, but not to abuse it, the same rule is
title: Elementary Forms

text: applied to the other members of the clan.[465] Among the Arunta, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: interdictions protecting the totemic animal extend over the associated
title: Elementary Forms

text: animals;[466] and in any case, particular attention must be given to
title: Elementary Forms

text: these latter.[467] The sentiments inspired by the two are
title: Elementary Forms

text: identical.[468]
title: Elementary Forms

text: But the fact that the things thus attached to the totem are not of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: different nature from it, and consequently have a religious character,
title: Elementary Forms

text: is best proved by the fact that on certain occasions they fulfil the
title: Elementary Forms

text: same functions. They are accessory or secondary totems, or, according to
title: Elementary Forms

text: an expression now consecrated by usage, they are sub-totems.[469] It is
title: Elementary Forms

text: constantly happening in the clans that under the influence of various
title: Elementary Forms

text: sympathies, particular affinities are forming, smaller groups and more
title: Elementary Forms

text: limited associations arise, which tend to lead a relatively autonomous
title: Elementary Forms

text: life and to form a new subdivision like a sub-clan within the larger
title: Elementary Forms

text: one. In order to distinguish and individualize itself, this sub-clan
title: Elementary Forms

text: needs a special totem or, consequently, a sub-totem.[470] Now the totems
title: Elementary Forms

text: of these secondary groups are chosen from among the things classified
title: Elementary Forms

text: under the principal totem. So they are always almost totems and the
title: Elementary Forms

text: slightest circumstance is enough to make them actually so. There is a
title: Elementary Forms

text: latent totemic nature in them, which shows itself as soon as conditions
title: Elementary Forms

text: permit it or demand it. It thus happens that a single individual has
title: Elementary Forms

text: two totems, a principal totem common to the whole clan and a sub-totem
title: Elementary Forms

text: which is special to the sub-clan of which he is a member. This is
title: Elementary Forms

text: something analogous to the _nomen_ and _cognomen_ of the Romans.[471]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Sometimes we see a sub-clan emancipate itself completely and become an
title: Elementary Forms

text: autonomous group and an independent clan; then, the sub-totem, on its
title: Elementary Forms

text: side, becomes a regular totem. One tribe where this process of
title: Elementary Forms

text: segmentation has been pushed to the limit, so to speak, is the Arunta.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The information contained in the first book of Spencer and Gillen showed
title: Elementary Forms

text: that there were some sixty totems among the Arunta;[472] but the recent
title: Elementary Forms

text: researches of Strehlow have shown the number to be much larger. He
title: Elementary Forms

text: counted no less than 442.[473] Spencer and Gillen did not exaggerate at
title: Elementary Forms

text: all when they said, "In fact, there is scarcely an object, animate or
title: Elementary Forms

text: inanimate, to be found in the country occupied by the natives which does
title: Elementary Forms

text: not give its name to some totemic group."[474] Now this multitude of
title: Elementary Forms

text: totems, whose number is prodigious when compared to the population, is
title: Elementary Forms

text: due to the fact that under special circumstances, the original clans
title: Elementary Forms

text: have divided and sub-divided infinitely; consequently nearly all the
title: Elementary Forms

text: sub-totems have passed to the stage of totems.
title: Elementary Forms

text: This has been definitely proved by the observations of Strehlow. Spencer
title: Elementary Forms

text: and Gillen cited only certain isolated cases of associated totems.[475]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Strehlow has shown that this is in reality an absolutely general
title: Elementary Forms

text: organization. He has been able to draw up a table where nearly all the
title: Elementary Forms

text: totems of the Arunta are classified according to this principle: all are
title: Elementary Forms

text: attached, either as associates or as auxiliaries, to some sixty
title: Elementary Forms

text: principal totems.[476] The first are believed to be in the service of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the second.[477] This state of dependence is very probably the echo of
title: Elementary Forms

text: a time when the "allies" of to-day were only sub-totems, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: consequently when the tribe contained only a small number of clans
title: Elementary Forms

text: subdivided into sub-clans. Numerous survivals confirm this hypothesis.
title: Elementary Forms

text: It frequently happens that two groups thus associated have the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: totemic emblem: now this unity of emblem is explicable only if the two
title: Elementary Forms

text: groups were at first only one.[478] The relation of the two clans is
title: Elementary Forms

text: also shown by the part and the interest that each one takes in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: rites of the other. The two cults are still only imperfectly separated;
title: Elementary Forms

text: this is very probably because they were at first completely
title: Elementary Forms

text: intermingled.[479] Tradition explains the bonds which unite them by
title: Elementary Forms

text: imagining that formerly the two clans occupied neighbouring places.[480]
title: Elementary Forms

text: In other cases, the myth says expressly that one of them was derived
title: Elementary Forms

text: from the other. It is related that at first the associated animal
title: Elementary Forms

text: belonged to the species still serving as principal totem; it
title: Elementary Forms

text: differentiated itself at a later period. Thus the chantunga birds, which
title: Elementary Forms

text: are associated with the witchetly grub to-day, were witchetly grubs in
title: Elementary Forms

text: fabulous times, who later transformed themselves into birds. Two species
title: Elementary Forms

text: which are now attached to the honey-ant were formerly honey-ants,
title: Elementary Forms

text: etc.[481] This transformation of a sub-totem into a totem goes on by
title: Elementary Forms

text: imperceptible degrees, so that in certain cases the situation is
title: Elementary Forms

text: undecided, and it is hard to say whether one is dealing with a principal
title: Elementary Forms

text: totem or a secondary one.[482] As Howitt says in regard to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Wotjobaluk, there are sub-totems which are totems in formation.[483]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Thus the different things classified in a clan constitute, as it were,
title: Elementary Forms

text: so many nuclei around which new totemic cults are able to form. This is
title: Elementary Forms

text: the best proof of the religious sentiments which they inspire. If they
title: Elementary Forms

text: did not have a sacred character, they could not be promoted so easily to
title: Elementary Forms

text: the same dignity as the things which are sacred before all others, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: regular totems.
title: Elementary Forms

text: So the field of religious things extends well beyond the limits within
title: Elementary Forms

text: which it seemed to be confined at first. It embraces not only the
title: Elementary Forms

text: totemic animals and the human members of the clan; but since no known
title: Elementary Forms

text: thing exists that is not classified in a clan and under a totem, there
title: Elementary Forms

text: is likewise nothing which does not receive to some degree something of
title: Elementary Forms

text: a religious character. When, in the religions which later come into
title: Elementary Forms

text: being, the gods properly so-called appear, each of them will be set over
title: Elementary Forms

text: a special category of natural phenomena, this one over the sea, that one
title: Elementary Forms

text: over the air, another over the harvest or over fruits, etc., and each of
title: Elementary Forms

text: these provinces of nature will be believed to draw what life there is in
title: Elementary Forms

text: it from the god upon whom it depends. This division of nature among the
title: Elementary Forms

text: different divinities constitutes the conception which these religions
title: Elementary Forms

text: give us of the universe. Now so long as humanity has not passed the
title: Elementary Forms

text: phase of totemism, the different totems of the tribe fulfil exactly the
title: Elementary Forms

text: same functions that will later fall upon the divine personalities. In
title: Elementary Forms

text: the Mount Gambier tribe, which we have taken as our principal example,
title: Elementary Forms

text: there are ten clans; consequently the entire world is divided into ten
title: Elementary Forms

text: classes, or rather into ten families, each of which has a special totem
title: Elementary Forms

text: as its basis. It is from this basis that the things classed in the clan
title: Elementary Forms

text: get all their reality, for they are thought of as variant forms of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: totemic being; to return to our example, the rain, thunder, lightning,
title: Elementary Forms

text: clouds, hail and winter are regarded as different sorts of crows. When
title: Elementary Forms

text: brought together, these ten families of things make up a complete and
title: Elementary Forms

text: systematic representation of the world; and this representation is
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious, for religious notions furnish its basis. Far from being
title: Elementary Forms

text: limited to one or two categories of beings, the domain of totemic
title: Elementary Forms
