text: religion extends to the final limits of the known universe. Just like
title: Elementary Forms

text: the Greek religion, it puts the divine everywhere; the celebrated
title: Elementary Forms

text: formula [Greek: panta plere theon] (everything is full of the gods),
title: Elementary Forms

text: might equally well serve it as motto.
title: Elementary Forms

text: However, if totemism is to be represented thus, the notion of it which
title: Elementary Forms

text: has long been held must be modified on one essential point. Until the
title: Elementary Forms

text: discoveries of recent years, it was made to consist entirely in the cult
title: Elementary Forms

text: of one particular totem, and it was defined as the religion of the clan.
title: Elementary Forms

text: From this point of view, each tribe seemed to have as many totemic
title: Elementary Forms

text: religions, each independent of the others, as it had different clans.
title: Elementary Forms

text: This conception was also in harmony with the idea currently held of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: clan; in fact, this was regarded as an autonomous society,[484] more or
title: Elementary Forms

text: less closed to other similar societies, or having only external and
title: Elementary Forms

text: superficial relations with these latter. But the reality is more
title: Elementary Forms

text: complex. Undoubtedly, the cult of each totem has its home in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: corresponding clan; it is there, and only there, that it is celebrated;
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is members of the clan who have charge of it; it is through them
title: Elementary Forms

text: that it is transmitted from one generation to another, along with the
title: Elementary Forms

text: beliefs which are its basis. But it is also true that the different
title: Elementary Forms

text: totemic cults thus practised within a single tribe do not have a
title: Elementary Forms

text: parallel development, though remaining ignorant of each other, as if
title: Elementary Forms

text: each of them constituted a complete and self-sufficing religion. On the
title: Elementary Forms

text: contrary, they mutually imply each other; they are only the parts of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: single whole, the elements of a single religion. The men of one clan
title: Elementary Forms

text: never regard the beliefs of neighbouring clans with that indifference,
title: Elementary Forms

text: scepticism or hostility which one religion ordinarily inspires for
title: Elementary Forms

text: another which is foreign to it; they partake of these beliefs
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves. The Crow people are also convinced that the Snake people
title: Elementary Forms

text: have a mythical serpent as ancestor, and that they owe special virtues
title: Elementary Forms

text: and marvellous powers to this origin. And have we not seen that at least
title: Elementary Forms

text: in certain conditions, a man may eat a totem that is not his own only
title: Elementary Forms

text: after he has observed certain ritual formalities? Especially, he must
title: Elementary Forms

text: demand the permission of the men of this totem, if any are present. So
title: Elementary Forms

text: for him also, this food is not entirely profane; he also admits that
title: Elementary Forms

text: there are intimate affinities between the members of a clan of which he
title: Elementary Forms

text: is not a member and the animal whose name they bear. Also, this
title: Elementary Forms

text: community of belief is sometimes shown in the cult. If in theory the
title: Elementary Forms

text: rites concerning a totem can be performed only by the men of this totem,
title: Elementary Forms

text: nevertheless representatives of different clans frequently assist at
title: Elementary Forms

text: them. It sometimes happens that their part is not simply that of
title: Elementary Forms

text: spectators; it is true that they do not officiate, but they decorate the
title: Elementary Forms

text: officiants and prepare the service. They themselves have an interest in
title: Elementary Forms

text: its being celebrated; therefore, in certain tribes, it is they who
title: Elementary Forms

text: invite the qualified clan to proceed with the ceremonies.[485] There is
title: Elementary Forms

text: even a whole cycle of rites which must take place in the presence of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: assembled tribe: these are the totemic ceremonies of initiation.[486]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Finally, the totemic organization, such as we have just described it,
title: Elementary Forms

text: must obviously be the result of some sort of an indistinct understanding
title: Elementary Forms

text: between all the members of the tribe. It is impossible that each clan
title: Elementary Forms

text: should have made its beliefs in an absolutely independent manner; it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: absolutely necessary that the cults of the different totems should be in
title: Elementary Forms

text: some way adjusted to each other, since they complete one another
title: Elementary Forms

text: exactly. In fact, we have seen that normally a single totem is not
title: Elementary Forms

text: repeated twice in the same tribe, and that the whole universe is divided
title: Elementary Forms

text: up among the totems thus constituted in such a way that the same object
title: Elementary Forms

text: is not found in two different clans. So methodical a division could
title: Elementary Forms

text: never have been made without an agreement, tacit or planned, in which
title: Elementary Forms

text: the whole tribe participated. So the group of beliefs which thus arise
title: Elementary Forms

text: are partially (but only partially) a tribal affair.[487]
title: Elementary Forms

text: To sum up, then, in order to form an adequate idea of totemism, we must
title: Elementary Forms

text: not confine ourselves within the limits of the clan, but must consider
title: Elementary Forms

text: the tribe as a whole. It is true that the particular cult of each clan
title: Elementary Forms

text: enjoys a very great autonomy; we can now see that it is within the clan
title: Elementary Forms

text: that the active ferment of the religious life takes place. But it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: also true that these cults fit into each other and the totemic religion
title: Elementary Forms

text: is a complex system formed by their union, just as Greek polytheism was
title: Elementary Forms

text: made by the union of all the particular cults addressed to the different
title: Elementary Forms

text: divinities. We have just shown that, thus understood, totemism also has
title: Elementary Forms

text: it cosmology.
title: Elementary Forms

text: CHAPTER IV
title: Elementary Forms

text: TOTEMIC BELIEFS--_end_
title: Elementary Forms

text: _The Individual Totem and the Sexual Totem_
title: Elementary Forms

text: Up to the present, we have studied totemism only as a public
title: Elementary Forms

text: institution: the only totems of which we have spoken are common to a
title: Elementary Forms

text: clan, a phratry or, in a sense, to a tribe;[488] an individual has a
title: Elementary Forms

text: part in them only as a member of a group. But we know that there is no
title: Elementary Forms

text: religion which does not have an individual aspect. This general
title: Elementary Forms

text: observation is applicable to totemism. In addition to the impersonal and
title: Elementary Forms

text: collective totems which hold the first place, there are others which are
title: Elementary Forms

text: peculiar to each individual, which express his personality, and whose
title: Elementary Forms

text: cult he celebrates in private.
title: Elementary Forms

text: I
title: Elementary Forms

text: In certain Australian tribes, and in the majority of the Indian tribes
title: Elementary Forms

text: of North America,[489] each individual personally sustains relations
title: Elementary Forms

text: with some determined object, which are comparable to those which each
title: Elementary Forms

text: clan sustains with its totem. This is sometimes an inanimate being or an
title: Elementary Forms

text: artificial object; but it is generally an animal. In certain cases, a
title: Elementary Forms

text: special part of the organism, such as the head, the feet or the liver,
title: Elementary Forms

text: fulfils this office.[490]
title: Elementary Forms

text: The name of the thing also serves as the name of the individual. It is
title: Elementary Forms

text: his personal name, his forename, which is added to that of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: collective totem, as the _praenomen_ of the Romans was to the _nomen
title: Elementary Forms

text: gentilicium_. It is true that this fact is not reported except in a
title: Elementary Forms

text: certain number of societies,[491] but it is probably general. In fact,
title: Elementary Forms

text: we shall presently show that there is an identity of nature between the
title: Elementary Forms

text: individual and the thing; now an identity of nature implies one of name.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Being given in the course of especially important religious ceremonies,
title: Elementary Forms

text: this forename has a sacred character. It is not pronounced in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: ordinary circumstances of profane life. It even happens that the word
title: Elementary Forms

text: designating this object in the ordinary language must be modified to a
title: Elementary Forms

text: greater or less extent if it is to serve in this particular case.[492]
title: Elementary Forms

text: This is because the terms of the usual language are excluded from the
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious life.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In certain American tribes, at least, this name is reinforced by an
title: Elementary Forms

text: emblem belonging to each individual and representing, under various
title: Elementary Forms

text: forms, the thing designated by the name. For example, each Mandan wears
title: Elementary Forms

text: the skin of the animal of which he is the namesake.[493] If it is a
title: Elementary Forms

text: bird, he decorates himself with its feathers.[494] The Hurons and
title: Elementary Forms

text: Algonquins tattoo their bodies with its image.[495] It is represented on
title: Elementary Forms

text: their arms.[496] Among the north-western tribes, the individual emblem,
title: Elementary Forms

text: just like the collective emblem of the clan, is carved or engraved on
title: Elementary Forms

text: the utensils, houses,[497] etc.; it serves as a mark of ownership.[498]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Frequently the two coats-of-arms are combined together, which partially
title: Elementary Forms

text: explains the great diversity of aspects presented by the totemic
title: Elementary Forms

text: escutcheons among these peoples.[499]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Between the individual and his animal namesake there exist the very
title: Elementary Forms

text: closest bonds. The man participates in the nature of the animal; he has
title: Elementary Forms

text: its good qualities as well as its faults. For example, a man having the
title: Elementary Forms

text: eagle as his coat-of-arms is believed to possess the gift of seeing into
title: Elementary Forms

text: the future; if he is named after a bear, they say that he is apt to be
title: Elementary Forms

text: wounded in combat, for the bear is heavy and slow and easily
title: Elementary Forms

text: caught;[500] if the animal is despised, the man is the object of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: same sentiment.[501] The relationship of the two is even so close that
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is believed that in certain circumstances, especially in case of
title: Elementary Forms

text: danger, the man can take the form of the animal.[502] Inversely, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: animal is regarded as a double of the man, as his _alter ego_.[503] The
title: Elementary Forms

text: association of the two is so close that their destinies are frequently
title: Elementary Forms

text: thought to be bound up together: nothing can happen to one without the
title: Elementary Forms

text: other's feeling a reaction.[504] If the animal dies, the life of the man
title: Elementary Forms

text: is menaced. Thus it comes to be a very general rule that one should not
title: Elementary Forms

text: kill the animal, nor eat its flesh. This interdiction, which, when
title: Elementary Forms

text: concerning the totem of the clan, allows of all sorts of attenuations
title: Elementary Forms

text: and modifications, is now much more formal and absolute.[505]
title: Elementary Forms

text: On its side, the animal protects the man and serves him as a sort of
title: Elementary Forms

text: patron. It informs him of possible dangers and of the way of escaping
title: Elementary Forms

text: them;[506] they say that it is his friend.[507] Since it frequently
title: Elementary Forms

text: happens to possess marvellous powers, it communicates them to its human
title: Elementary Forms

text: associate, who believes in them, even under the proof of bullets,
title: Elementary Forms

text: arrows, and blows of every sort.[508] This confidence of an individual
title: Elementary Forms

text: in the efficacy of his protector is so great that he braves the greatest
title: Elementary Forms

text: dangers and accomplishes the most disconcerting feats with an intrepid
title: Elementary Forms

text: serenity: faith gives him the necessary courage and strength.[509]
title: Elementary Forms

text: However, the relations of a man with his patron are not purely and
title: Elementary Forms

text: simply those of dependence. He, on his side, is able to act upon the
title: Elementary Forms

text: animal. He gives it orders; he has influence over it. A Kurnai having
title: Elementary Forms

text: the shark as ally and friend believes that he can disperse the sharks
title: Elementary Forms

text: who menace a boat, by means of a charm.[510] In other cases, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: relations thus contracted are believed to confer upon the man a special
title: Elementary Forms

text: aptitude for hunting the animal with success.[511]
title: Elementary Forms

text: The very nature of these relations seems clearly to imply that the being
title: Elementary Forms

text: to which each individual is thus associated is only an individual
title: Elementary Forms

text: itself, and not a species. A man does not have a species as his _alter
title: Elementary Forms

text: ego_. In fact, there are cases where it is certainly a certain
title: Elementary Forms

text: determined tree, rock or stone that fulfils this function.[512] It must
title: Elementary Forms

text: be thus every time that it is an animal, and that the existences of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: animal and the man are believed to be connected. A man could not be
title: Elementary Forms

text: united so closely to a whole species, for there is not a day nor, so to
title: Elementary Forms

text: speak, an instant when the species does not lose some one of its
title: Elementary Forms

text: members. Yet the primitive has a certain incapacity for thinking of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: individual apart from the species; the bonds uniting him to the one
title: Elementary Forms

text: readily extend to the other; he confounds the two in the same sentiment.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Thus the entire species becomes sacred for him.[513]
title: Elementary Forms

text: This protector is naturally given different names in different
title: Elementary Forms

text: societies: _nagual_ among the Indians of Mexico,[514] _manitou_ among
title: Elementary Forms

text: the Algonquins and _okki_ among the Hurons,[515] _snam_ among certain
title: Elementary Forms

text: Salish,[516] _sulia_ among others,[517] _budjan_ among the Yuin,[518]
title: Elementary Forms

text: _yunbeai_ among the Euahlayi,[519] etc. Owing to the importance of these
title: Elementary Forms

text: beliefs and practices among the Indians of North America, some have
title: Elementary Forms

text: proposed creating a word _nagualism_ or _manitouism_ to designate
title: Elementary Forms

text: them.[520] But in giving them a special and distinctive name, we run the
title: Elementary Forms

text: risk of misunderstanding their relations with the rest of totemism. In
title: Elementary Forms

text: fact, the same principle is applied in the one case to the clan and in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the other to the individual. In both cases we find the same belief that
title: Elementary Forms

text: there are vital connections between the things and the men, and that
title: Elementary Forms

text: the former are endowed with special powers, of which their human allies
title: Elementary Forms

text: may also enjoy the advantage. We also find the same custom of giving the
title: Elementary Forms

text: man the name of the thing with which he is associated and of adding an
title: Elementary Forms

text: emblem to this name. The totem is the patron of the clan, just as the
title: Elementary Forms

text: patron of the individual is his personal totem. So it is important that
title: Elementary Forms

text: our terminology should make the relationship of the two systems
title: Elementary Forms

text: apparent; that is why we, with Frazer, shall give the name _individual
title: Elementary Forms

text: totemism_ to the cult rendered by each individual to his patron. A
title: Elementary Forms

text: further justification of this expression is found in the fact that in
title: Elementary Forms

text: certain cases the primitive himself uses the same word to designate the
title: Elementary Forms

text: totem of the clan and the animal protector of the individual.[521] If
title: Elementary Forms

text: Tylor and Powell have rejected this term and demanded different ones for
title: Elementary Forms

text: these two sorts of religious institutions, it is because the collective
title: Elementary Forms

text: totem is, in their opinion, only a name or label, having no religious
title: Elementary Forms

text: character.[522] But we, on the contrary, know that it is a sacred thing,
title: Elementary Forms

text: and even more so than the protecting animal. Moreover, the continuation
title: Elementary Forms

text: of our study will show how these two varieties of totemism are
title: Elementary Forms

text: inseparable from each other.[523]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Yet, howsoever close the kinship between these two institutions may be,
title: Elementary Forms

text: there are important differences between them. While the clan believes
title: Elementary Forms

text: that it is the offspring of the animal or plant serving it as totem, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: individual does not believe that he has any relationship of descent with
title: Elementary Forms

text: his personal totem. It is a friend, an associate, a protector; but it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: not a relative. He takes advantage of the virtues it is believed to
title: Elementary Forms

text: possess; but he is not of the same blood. In the second place, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: members of a clan allow neighbouring clans to eat of the animal whose
title: Elementary Forms

text: name they bear collectively, under the simple condition that the
title: Elementary Forms

text: necessary formalities shall be observed. But, on the contrary, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: individual respects the species to which his personal totem belongs and
title: Elementary Forms

text: also protects it against strangers, at least in those parts where the
title: Elementary Forms

text: destiny of the man is held to be bound up with that of the animal.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But the chief difference between these two sorts of totems is in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: manner in which they are acquired.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The collective totem is a part of the civil status of each individual:
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is generally hereditary; in any case, it is birth which designates
title: Elementary Forms

text: it, and the wish of men counts for nothing. Sometimes the child has the
title: Elementary Forms

text: totem of his mother (Kamilaroi, Dieri, Urabunna, etc.); sometimes that
title: Elementary Forms

text: of his father (Narrinyeri, Warramunga, etc.); sometimes the one
title: Elementary Forms

text: predominating in the locality where his mother conceived (Arunta,
title: Elementary Forms

text: Loritja). But, on the contrary, the individual totem is acquired by a
title: Elementary Forms

text: deliberate act:[524] a whole series of ritual operations are necessary
title: Elementary Forms

text: to determine it. The method generally employed by the Indians of North
title: Elementary Forms

text: America is as follows. About the time of puberty, as the time for
title: Elementary Forms

text: initiation approaches, the young man withdraws into a distant place, for
title: Elementary Forms

text: example, into a forest. There, during a period varying from a few days
title: Elementary Forms

text: to several years, he submits himself to all sorts of exhausting and
title: Elementary Forms

text: unnatural exercises. He fasts, mortifies himself and inflicts various
title: Elementary Forms

text: mutilations upon himself. Now he wanders about, uttering violent cries
title: Elementary Forms

text: and veritable howls; now he lies extended, motionless and lamenting,
title: Elementary Forms

text: upon the ground. Sometimes he dances, prays and invokes his ordinary
title: Elementary Forms

text: divinities. At last, he thus gets himself into an extreme state of
title: Elementary Forms

text: super-excitation, verging on delirium. When he has reached this
title: Elementary Forms

text: paroxysm, his representations readily take on the character of
title: Elementary Forms

text: hallucinations. "When," says Heckewelder, "a boy is on the eve of being
title: Elementary Forms

text: initiated, he is submitted to an alternating regime of fasts and medical
title: Elementary Forms

text: treatment; he abstains from all food and takes the most powerful and
title: Elementary Forms

text: repugnant drugs: at times, he drinks intoxicating concoctions until his
title: Elementary Forms

text: mind really wanders. Then he has, or thinks he has, visions and
title: Elementary Forms

text: extraordinary dreams to which he was of course predisposed by all this
title: Elementary Forms

text: training. He imagines himself flying through the air, advancing under
title: Elementary Forms

text: the ground, jumping from one mountain-top to another across the valleys,
title: Elementary Forms

text: and fighting and conquering giants and monsters."[525] If in these
title: Elementary Forms

text: circumstances he sees, or, as amounts to the same thing, he thinks he
title: Elementary Forms

text: sees, while dreaming or while awake, an animal appearing to him in an
title: Elementary Forms

text: attitude seeming to show friendly intentions, then he imagines that he
title: Elementary Forms

text: has discovered the patron he awaited.[526]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Yet this procedure is rarely employed in Australia.[527] On this
title: Elementary Forms

text: continent, the personal totem seems to be imposed by a third party,
title: Elementary Forms

text: either at birth[528] or at the moment of initiation.[529] Generally it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is a relative who takes this part, or else a personage invested with
title: Elementary Forms

text: special powers, such as an old man or a magician. Sometimes divination
title: Elementary Forms

text: is used for this purpose. For example, on Charlotte Bay, Cape Bedford or
title: Elementary Forms

text: the Proserpine River, the grandmother or some other old woman takes a
title: Elementary Forms

text: little piece of umbilical cord to which the placenta is still attached
title: Elementary Forms

text: and whirls it about quite violently. Meanwhile the other old women
title: Elementary Forms

text: propose different names. That one is adopted which happens to be
title: Elementary Forms

text: pronounced just at the moment when the cord breaks.[530] Among the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Yarrai-kanna of Cape York, after a tooth has been knocked out of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: young initiate, they give him a little water to rinse his mouth and ask
title: Elementary Forms

text: him to spit in a bucket full of water. The old men carefully examine the
title: Elementary Forms

text: clot formed by the blood and saliva thus spit out, and the natural
title: Elementary Forms

text: object whose shape it resembles becomes the personal totem of the young
title: Elementary Forms

text: man.[531] In other cases, the totem is transmitted from one individual
title: Elementary Forms

text: to another, for example from father to son, or uncle to nephew.[532]
title: Elementary Forms

text: This method is also used in America. In a case reported by Hill Tout,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the operator was a shaman,[533] who wished to transmit his totem to his
title: Elementary Forms

text: nephew. "The uncle took the symbol of his _snam_ (his personal totem),
title: Elementary Forms

text: which in this case was a dried bird's skin, and bade his nephew breathe
title: Elementary Forms

text: upon it. He then blew upon it also himself, uttered some mystic words
title: Elementary Forms

text: and the dried skin seemed to Paul (the nephew) to become a living bird,
title: Elementary Forms

text: which flew about them a moment or two and then finally disappeared.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Paul was then instructed by his uncle to procure that day a bird's skin
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the same kind as his uncle's and wear it on his person. This he did,
title: Elementary Forms

text: and that night he had a dream, in which the _snam_ appeared to him in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the shape of a human being, disclosed to him its mystic name by which it
title: Elementary Forms

text: might be summoned, and promised him protection."[534]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Not only is the individual totem acquired and not given, but ordinarily
title: Elementary Forms

text: the acquisition of one is not obligatory. In the first place, there are
title: Elementary Forms

text: a multitude of tribes in Australia where the custom seems to be
title: Elementary Forms

text: absolutely unknown.[535] Also, even where it does exist, it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: frequently optional. Thus among the Euahlayi, while all the magicians
title: Elementary Forms

text: have individual totems from which they get their powers, there are a
title: Elementary Forms

text: great number of laymen who have none at all. It is a favour given by the
title: Elementary Forms

text: magician, but which he reserves for his friends, his favourites and
title: Elementary Forms

text: those who aspire to becoming his colleagues.[536] Likewise, among
title: Elementary Forms

text: certain Salish, persons desiring to excel especially either in fighting
title: Elementary Forms

text: or in hunting, or aspirants to the position of shaman, are the only ones
title: Elementary Forms

text: who provide themselves with protectors of this sort.[537] So among
title: Elementary Forms

text: certain peoples, at least, the individual totem seems to be considered
title: Elementary Forms

text: an advantage and convenient thing rather than a necessity. It is a good
title: Elementary Forms

text: thing to have, but a man can do without one. Inversely, a man need not
title: Elementary Forms

text: limit himself to a single totem; if he wishes to be more fully
title: Elementary Forms

text: protected, nothing hinders his seeking and acquiring several,[538] and
title: Elementary Forms

text: if the one he has fulfils its part badly, he can change it.[539]
title: Elementary Forms

text: But while it is more optional and free, individual totemism contains
title: Elementary Forms

text: within it a force of resistance never attained by the totemism of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: clan. One of the chief informers of Hill Tout was a baptized Salish;
title: Elementary Forms

text: however, though he had sincerely abandoned the faith of his fathers, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: though he had become a model catechist, still his faith in the efficacy
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the personal totems remained unshaken.[540] Similarly, though no
title: Elementary Forms

text: visible traces of collective totemism remain in civilized countries, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: idea that there is a connection between each individual and some
title: Elementary Forms

text: animal, plant or other object, is at the bottom of many customs still
title: Elementary Forms

text: observable in many European countries.[541]
title: Elementary Forms

text: II
title: Elementary Forms

text: Between collective totemism and individual totemism there is an
title: Elementary Forms

text: intermediate form partaking of the characteristics of each: this is
title: Elementary Forms

text: sexual totemism. It is found only in Australia and in a small number of
title: Elementary Forms

text: tribes. It is mentioned especially in Victoria and New South Wales.[542]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Mathews, it is true, claims to have observed it in all the parts of
title: Elementary Forms

text: Australia that he has visited, but he gives no precise facts to support
title: Elementary Forms

text: this affirmation.[543]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Among these different peoples, all the men of the tribe on the one hand,
title: Elementary Forms

text: and all the women on the other, to whatever special clan they may
title: Elementary Forms

text: belong, form, as it were, two distinct and even antagonistic societies.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Now each of these two sexual corporations believes that it is united by
title: Elementary Forms

text: mystical bonds to a determined animal. Among the Kurnai, all the men
title: Elementary Forms

text: think they are brothers, as it were, of the emu-wren (Yeer[)u]ng), all
title: Elementary Forms

text: the women, that they are as sisters of the linnet (Djeetg[)u]n); all the
title: Elementary Forms

text: men are Yeer[)u]ng and all the women are Djeetg[)u]n. Among the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Wotjobaluk and the Wurunjerri, it is the bat and the _nightjar_ (a
title: Elementary Forms

text: species of screech-owl) respectively who take this role. In other
title: Elementary Forms

text: tribes, the woodpecker is substituted for the _nightjar_. Each sex
title: Elementary Forms

text: regards the animal to which it is thus related as a sort of protector
title: Elementary Forms

text: which must be treated with the greatest regard; it is also forbidden to
title: Elementary Forms

text: kill and eat it.[544]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Thus this protecting animal plays the same part in relation to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: sexual society that the totem of the clan plays to this latter group. So
title: Elementary Forms

text: the expression sexual totemism, which we borrow from Frazer,[545] is
title: Elementary Forms

text: justified. This new sort of totem resembles that of the clan
title: Elementary Forms

text: particularly in that it, too, is collective; it belongs to all the
title: Elementary Forms

text: people of one sex indiscriminately. It also resembles this form in that
title: Elementary Forms

text: it implies a relationship of descent and consanguinity between the
title: Elementary Forms

text: animal patron and the corresponding sex: among the Kurnai, all the men
title: Elementary Forms

text: are believed to be descended from Yeer[)u]ng and all the women from
title: Elementary Forms

text: Djeetg[)u]n.[546] The first observer to point out this curious
title: Elementary Forms

text: institution described it, in 1834, in the following terms: "Tilmun, a
title: Elementary Forms

text: little bird the size of a thrush (it is a sort of woodpecker), is
title: Elementary Forms

text: supposed by the women to be the first maker of women. These birds are
title: Elementary Forms

text: held in veneration by the women only."[547] So it was a great ancestor.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But in other ways, this same totem resembles the individual totem. In
title: Elementary Forms

text: fact, it is believed that each member of a sexual group is personally
title: Elementary Forms

text: united to a determined individual of the corresponding animal species.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The two lives are so closely associated that the death of the animal
title: Elementary Forms

text: brings about that of the man. "The life of a bat," say the Wotjobaluk,
title: Elementary Forms

text: "is the life of a man."[548] That is why each sex not only respects its
title: Elementary Forms

text: own totem, but forces the members of the other to do so as well. Every
title: Elementary Forms

text: violation of this interdiction gives rise to actual bloody battles
title: Elementary Forms

text: between the men and the women.[549]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Finally, the really original feature of these totems is that they are,
title: Elementary Forms

text: in a sense, a sort of tribal totems. In fact, they result from men's
title: Elementary Forms

text: representing the tribe as descended as a whole from one couple of
title: Elementary Forms

text: mythical beings. Such a belief seems to demonstrate clearly that the
title: Elementary Forms

text: tribal sentiment has acquired sufficient force to resist, at least to a
title: Elementary Forms

text: considerable extent, the particularism of the clans. In regard to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: distinct origins assigned to men and to women, it must be said that its
title: Elementary Forms

text: cause is to be sought in the separate conditions in which the men and
title: Elementary Forms

text: the women live.[550]
title: Elementary Forms

text: It would be interesting to know how the sexual totems are related to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: totems of the clans, according to the theory of the Australians, what
title: Elementary Forms

text: relations there were between the two ancestors thus placed at the
title: Elementary Forms

text: commencement of the tribe, and from which one each special clan is
title: Elementary Forms

text: believed to be descended. But the ethnographical data at our present
title: Elementary Forms

text: disposal do not allow us to resolve these questions. Moreover, however
title: Elementary Forms

text: natural and even necessary it may appear to us, it is very possible that
title: Elementary Forms

text: the natives never raised it. They do not feel the need of co-ordinating
title: Elementary Forms

text: and systematizing their beliefs as strongly as we do.[551]
title: Elementary Forms

text: CHAPTER V
title: Elementary Forms

text: ORIGINS OF THESE BELIEFS
title: Elementary Forms

text: _Critical Examination of Preceding Theories_
title: Elementary Forms

text: The beliefs which we have just summarized are manifestly of a religious
title: Elementary Forms

text: nature, since they imply a division of things into sacred and profane.
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is certain that there is no thought of spiritual beings, and in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: course of our exposition we have not even had occasion to pronounce the
title: Elementary Forms

text: words, spirits, genii or divine personalities. But if certain writers,
title: Elementary Forms

text: of whom we shall have something more to say presently, have, for this
title: Elementary Forms

text: reason, refused to regard totemism as a religion, it is because they
title: Elementary Forms

text: have an inexact notion of what religious phenomena are.
title: Elementary Forms

text: On the other hand, we are assured that this religion is the most
title: Elementary Forms

text: primitive one that is now observable and even, in all probability, that
title: Elementary Forms

text: has ever existed. In fact, it is inseparable from a social organization
title: Elementary Forms

text: on a clan basis. Not only is it impossible, as we have already pointed
title: Elementary Forms

text: out, to define it except in connection with the clan, but it even seems
title: Elementary Forms

text: as though the clan could not exist, in the form it has taken in a great
title: Elementary Forms

text: number of Australian societies, without the totem. For the members of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: single clan are not united to each other either by a common habitat or
title: Elementary Forms

text: by common blood, as they are not necessarily consanguineous and are
title: Elementary Forms

text: frequently scattered over different parts of the tribal territory. Their
title: Elementary Forms

text: unity comes solely from their having the same name and the same emblem,
title: Elementary Forms

text: their believing that they have the same relations with the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: categories of things, their practising the same rites, or, in a word,
title: Elementary Forms

text: from their participating in the same totemic cult. Thus totemism and the
title: Elementary Forms

text: clan mutually imply each other, in so far, at least, as the latter is
title: Elementary Forms

text: not confounded with the local group. Now the social organization on a
title: Elementary Forms

text: clan basis is the simplest which we know. In fact, it exists in all its
title: Elementary Forms

text: essential elements from the moment when the society includes two primary
title: Elementary Forms

text: clans; consequently, we may say that there are none more rudimentary, as
title: Elementary Forms

text: long as societies reduced to a single clan have not been discovered, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: we believe that up to the present no traces of such have been found. A
title: Elementary Forms

text: religion so closely connected to a social system surpassing all others
title: Elementary Forms

text: in simplicity may well be regarded as the most elementary religion we
title: Elementary Forms

text: can possibly know. If we succeed in discovering the origins of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: beliefs which we have just analysed, we shall very probably discover at
title: Elementary Forms

text: the same time the causes leading to the rise of the religious sentiment
title: Elementary Forms

text: in humanity.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But before treating this question for ourselves, we must examine the
title: Elementary Forms

text: most authorized solutions of it which have already been proposed.
title: Elementary Forms

text: I
title: Elementary Forms

text: In the first place, we find a group of scholars who believe that they
title: Elementary Forms

text: can account for totemism by deriving it from some previous religion.
title: Elementary Forms

text: For Tylor[552] and Wilken,[553] totemism is a special form of the cult
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the ancestors; it was the widespread doctrine of the transmigration
title: Elementary Forms

text: of souls that served as a bridge between these two religious systems. A
title: Elementary Forms

text: large number of peoples believe that after death, the soul does not
title: Elementary Forms

text: remain disincarnate for ever, but presently animates another living
title: Elementary Forms

text: body; on the other hand, "the lower psychology, drawing no definite line
title: Elementary Forms

text: of demarcation between the souls of men and of beasts, can at least
title: Elementary Forms

text: admit without difficulty the transmigration of human souls into the
title: Elementary Forms

text: bodies of the lower animals."[554] Tylor cites a certain number of
title: Elementary Forms

text: cases.[555] Under these circumstances, the religious respect inspired by
title: Elementary Forms

text: the ancestor is quite naturally attached to the animal or plant with
title: Elementary Forms

text: which he is presently confounded. The animal thus serving as a
title: Elementary Forms

text: receptacle for a venerated being becomes a holy thing, the object of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: cult, that is, a totem, for all the descendants of the ancestor, who
title: Elementary Forms

text: form the clan descended from him.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Facts pointed out by Wilken among the societies of the Malay Archipelago
title: Elementary Forms

text: would tend to prove that it really was in this manner that the totemic
title: Elementary Forms

text: beliefs originated. In Java and Sumatra, crocodiles are especially
title: Elementary Forms

text: honoured; they are regarded as benevolent protectors who must not be
title: Elementary Forms

text: killed; offerings are made to them. Now the cult thus rendered to them
title: Elementary Forms

text: is due to their being supposed to incarnate the souls of ancestors. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: Malays of the Philippines consider the crocodile their grandfather; the
title: Elementary Forms

text: tiger is treated in the same way for the same reasons. Similar beliefs
title: Elementary Forms

text: have been observed among the Bantous.[556] In Melanesia it sometimes
title: Elementary Forms

text: happens that an influential man, at the moment of death, announces his
title: Elementary Forms

text: desire to reincarnate himself in a certain animal or plant; it is easily
title: Elementary Forms

text: understood how the object thus chosen as his posthumous residence
title: Elementary Forms

text: becomes sacred for his whole family.[557] So, far from being a primitive
title: Elementary Forms

text: fact, totemism would seem to be the product of a more complex religion
title: Elementary Forms

text: which preceded it.[558]
title: Elementary Forms

text: But the societies from which these facts were taken had already arrived
title: Elementary Forms

text: at a rather advanced stage of culture; in any case, they had passed the
title: Elementary Forms

text: stage of pure totemism. They have families and not totemic clans.[559]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Even the majority of the animals to which religious honours are thus
title: Elementary Forms

text: rendered are venerated, not by special groups of families, but by the
title: Elementary Forms

text: tribes as a whole. So if these beliefs and practices do have some
title: Elementary Forms

text: connection with ancient totemic cults, they now represent only altered
title: Elementary Forms

text: forms of them[560] and are consequently not very well fitted for showing
title: Elementary Forms

text: us their origins. It is not by studying an institution at the moment
title: Elementary Forms

text: when it is in full decadence that we can learn how it was formed. If we
title: Elementary Forms

text: want to know how totemism originated, it is neither in Java nor Sumatra
title: Elementary Forms

text: nor Melanesia that we must study it, but in Australia. Here we find
title: Elementary Forms

text: neither a cult of the dead[561] nor the doctrine of transmigration. Of
title: Elementary Forms

text: course they believe that the mythical heroes, the founders of the clan,
title: Elementary Forms

text: reincarnate themselves periodically; _but this is in human bodies only_;
title: Elementary Forms

text: each birth, as we shall see, is the product of one of these
title: Elementary Forms

text: reincarnations. So if the animals of the totemic species are the object
title: Elementary Forms

text: of rites, it is not because the ancestral souls are believed to reside
title: Elementary Forms

text: in them. It is true that the first ancestors are frequently represented
title: Elementary Forms

text: under the form of an animal, and this very common representation is an
title: Elementary Forms

text: important fact for which we must account; but it was not the belief in
title: Elementary Forms

text: metempsychosis which gave it birth, for this belief is unknown among
title: Elementary Forms

text: Australian societies.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Moreover, far from being able to explain totemism, this belief takes for
title: Elementary Forms

text: granted one of the fundamental principles upon which this rests; that is
title: Elementary Forms

text: to say, it begs the question to be explained. It, just as much as
title: Elementary Forms

text: totemism, implies that man is considered a close relative of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: animal; for if these two kingdoms were clearly distinguished in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: mind, men would never believe that a human soul could pass so easily
title: Elementary Forms

text: from one into the other. It is even necessary that the body of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: animal be considered its true home, for it is believed to go there as
title: Elementary Forms

text: soon as it regains its liberty. Now while the doctrine of transmigration
title: Elementary Forms

text: postulates this singular affinity, it offers no explanation of it. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: only explanation offered by Tylor is that men sometimes resemble in
title: Elementary Forms

text: certain traits the anatomy and physiology of the animal. "The half-human
title: Elementary Forms

text: features and actions and characters of animals are watched with
title: Elementary Forms

text: wondering sympathy by the savage, as by the child. The beast is the very
title: Elementary Forms

text: incarnation of familiar qualities of man: and such names as lion, bear,
title: Elementary Forms

text: fox, owl, parrot, viper, worm, when we apply them as epithets to men,
title: Elementary Forms

text: condense into a word some leading features of a human life."[562] But
title: Elementary Forms

text: even if these resemblances are met with, they are uncertain and
title: Elementary Forms

text: exceptional; before all else, men resemble their relatives and
title: Elementary Forms

text: companions, and not plants and animals. Such rare and questionable
title: Elementary Forms

text: analogies could not overcome such unanimous proofs, nor could they lead
title: Elementary Forms

text: a man to think of himself and his forefathers in forms contradicted by
title: Elementary Forms

text: daily experience. So this question remains untouched, and as long as it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is not answered, we cannot say that totemism is explained.[563]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Finally, this whole theory rests upon a fundamental misunderstanding.
title: Elementary Forms

text: For Tylor as for Wundt, totemism is only a particular case of the cult
title: Elementary Forms

text: of animals.[564] But we, on the contrary, know that it is something
title: Elementary Forms

text: very different from a sort of animal-worship.[565] The animal is never
title: Elementary Forms

text: adored; the man is nearly its equal and sometimes even treats it as his
title: Elementary Forms

text: possession, so far is he from being subordinate to it like a believer
title: Elementary Forms

text: before his god. If the animals of the totemic species are really
title: Elementary Forms

text: believed to incarnate the ancestors, the members of foreign clans would
title: Elementary Forms

text: not be allowed to eat their flesh freely. In reality, it is not to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: animal as such that the cult is addressed, but to the emblem and the
title: Elementary Forms

text: image of the totem. Now between this religion of the emblem and the
title: Elementary Forms

text: ancestor-cult, there is no connection whatsoever.
title: Elementary Forms

text: While Tylor derives totemism from the ancestor-cult, Jevons derives it
title: Elementary Forms

text: from the nature-cult,[566] and here is how he does so.
title: Elementary Forms

text: When, under the impulse of the surprise occasioned by the irregularities
title: Elementary Forms

text: observed in the course of phenomena, men had once peopled the world with
title: Elementary Forms

text: supernatural beings,[567] they felt the need of making agreements with
title: Elementary Forms

text: these redoubtable forces with which they had surrounded themselves. They
title: Elementary Forms

text: understood that the best way to escape being overwhelmed by them was to
title: Elementary Forms

text: ally themselves to some of them, and thus make sure of their aid. But at
title: Elementary Forms

text: this period of history men knew no other form of alliance and
title: Elementary Forms

text: association than the one resulting from kinship. All the members of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: single clan aid each other mutually because they are kindred or, as
title: Elementary Forms

text: amounts to the same thing, because they think they are; on the other
title: Elementary Forms

text: hand, different clans treat each other as enemies because they are of
title: Elementary Forms

text: different blood. So the only way of assuring themselves of the support
title: Elementary Forms

text: of these supernatural beings was to adopt them as kindred and to be
title: Elementary Forms

text: adopted by them in the same quality: the well-known processes of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: blood-covenant permitted them to attain this result quite easily. But
title: Elementary Forms

text: since at this period, the individual did not yet have a real
title: Elementary Forms

text: personality, and was regarded only as a part of his group, or clan, it
title: Elementary Forms

text: was the clan as a whole, and not the individual, which collectively
title: Elementary Forms

text: contracted this relationship. For the same reason, it was contracted,
title: Elementary Forms

text: not with a particular object, but with the natural group or species of
title: Elementary Forms

text: which this object was a part; for men think of the world as they think
title: Elementary Forms

text: of themselves, and just as they could not conceive themselves apart from
title: Elementary Forms

text: their clans, so they were unable to conceive of anything else as
title: Elementary Forms

text: distinct from the species to which it belonged. Now a species of things
title: Elementary Forms

text: united to a clan by a bond of kinship is, says Jevons, a totem.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In fact, it is certain that totemism implies the close association of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: clan to a determined category of objects. But that this association was
title: Elementary Forms

text: contracted with a deliberate design and in the full consciousness of an
title: Elementary Forms

text: end sought after, as Jevons would have us believe, is a statement having
title: Elementary Forms

text: but little harmony with what history teaches. Religions are too complex,
title: Elementary Forms

text: and answer to needs that are too many and too obscure, to have their
title: Elementary Forms

text: origin in a premeditated act of the will. And while it sins through
title: Elementary Forms

text: over-simplicity, this hypothesis is also highly improbable. It says that
title: Elementary Forms

text: men sought to assure themselves of the aid of the supernatural beings
title: Elementary Forms

text: upon which things depend. Then they should preferably have addressed
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves to the most powerful of these, and to those whose protection
title: Elementary Forms

text: promised to be the most beneficial.[568] But quite on the contrary, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: beings with whom they have formed this mystic kinship are often among
title: Elementary Forms

text: the most humble which exist. Also, if it were only a question of making
title: Elementary Forms

text: allies and defenders, they would have tried to make as many as possible;
title: Elementary Forms

text: for one cannot be defended too well. Yet as a matter of fact, each clan
title: Elementary Forms

text: systematically contents itself with a single totem, that is to say, with
title: Elementary Forms

text: one single protector, leaving the other clans to enjoy their own in
title: Elementary Forms

text: perfect liberty. Each group confines itself within its own religious
title: Elementary Forms

text: domain, never seeking to trespass upon that of its neighbours. This
title: Elementary Forms

text: reserve and moderation are inexplicable according to the hypothesis
title: Elementary Forms

text: under consideration.
title: Elementary Forms

text: II
title: Elementary Forms

text: Moreover, all these theories are wrong in omitting one question which
title: Elementary Forms

text: dominates the whole subject. We have seen that there are two sorts of
title: Elementary Forms

text: totemism: that of the individual and that of the clan. There is too
title: Elementary Forms

text: evident a kinship between the two for them not to have some connection
title: Elementary Forms

text: with each other. So we may well ask if one is not derived from the
title: Elementary Forms

text: other, and, in the case of an affirmative answer, which is the more
title: Elementary Forms

text: primitive; according to the solution accepted, the problem of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: origins of totemism will be posed in different terms. This question
title: Elementary Forms

text: becomes all the more necessary because of its general interest.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Individual totemism is an individual aspect of the totemic cult. Then if
title: Elementary Forms

text: it was the primitive fact, we must say that religion is born in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: consciousness of the individual, that before all else, it answers to
title: Elementary Forms

text: individual aspirations, and that its collective form is merely
title: Elementary Forms

text: secondary.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The desire for an undue simplicity, with which ethnologists and
title: Elementary Forms

text: sociologists are too frequently inspired, has naturally led many
title: Elementary Forms

text: scholars to explain, here as elsewhere, the complex by the simple, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: totem of the group by that of the individual. Such, in fact, is the
title: Elementary Forms

text: theory sustained by Frazer in his _Golden Bough_,[569] by Hill
title: Elementary Forms

text: Tout,[570] by Miss Fletcher,[571] by Boas[572] and by Swanton.[573] It
title: Elementary Forms

text: has the additional advantage of being in harmony with the conception of
title: Elementary Forms

text: religion which is currently held; this is quite generally regarded as
title: Elementary Forms

text: something intimate and personal. From this point of view, the totem of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the clan can only be an individual totem which has become generalized.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Some eminent man, having found from experience the value of a totem he
title: Elementary Forms

text: chose for himself by his own free will, transmitted it to his
title: Elementary Forms

text: descendants; these latter, multiplying as time went on, finally formed
title: Elementary Forms

text: the extended family known as a clan, and thus the totem became
title: Elementary Forms

text: collective.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Hill Tout believes that he has found a proof supporting this theory in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the way totemism has spread among certain societies of North-western
title: Elementary Forms

text: America, especially among the Salish and certain Indians on the Thompson
title: Elementary Forms

text: River. Individual totemism and the clan totemism are both found among
title: Elementary Forms

text: these peoples; but they either do not co-exist in the same tribe, or
title: Elementary Forms

text: else, when they do co-exist, they are not equally developed. They vary
title: Elementary Forms

text: in an inverse proportion to each other; where the clan totem tends to
title: Elementary Forms

text: become the general rule, the individual totem tends to disappear, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: _vice versa_. Is that not as much as to say that the first is a more
title: Elementary Forms

text: recent form of the second, which excludes it by replacing it?[574]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Mythology seems to confirm this interpretation. In these same societies,
title: Elementary Forms

text: in fact, the ancestor of the clan is not a totemic animal; the founder
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the group is generally represented in the form of a human being who,
title: Elementary Forms

text: at a certain time, had entered into familiar relations with a fabulous
title: Elementary Forms

text: animal from whom he received his totemic emblem. This emblem, together
title: Elementary Forms

text: with the special powers which are attached to it, was then passed on to
title: Elementary Forms

text: the descendants of this mythical hero by right of heritage. So these
title: Elementary Forms

text: people themselves seem to consider the collective totem as an individual
title: Elementary Forms

text: one, perpetuated in the same family.[575] Moreover, it still happens
title: Elementary Forms

text: to-day that a father transmits his own totem to his children. So if we
title: Elementary Forms

text: imagine that the collective totem had, in a general way, this same
title: Elementary Forms

text: origin, we are assuming that the same thing took place in the past which
title: Elementary Forms

text: is still observable to-day.[576]
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is still to be explained whence the individual totem comes. The reply
title: Elementary Forms

text: given to this question varies with different authors.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Hill Tout considers it a particular case of fetishism. Feeling himself
title: Elementary Forms

text: surrounded on all sides by dreaded spirits, the individual experienced
title: Elementary Forms

text: that sentiment which we have just seen Jevons attribute to the clan: in
title: Elementary Forms

text: order that he might continue to exist, he sought some powerful protector
title: Elementary Forms

text: in this mysterious world. Thus the use of a personal totem became
title: Elementary Forms

text: established.[577] For Frazer, this same institution was rather a
title: Elementary Forms

text: subterfuge or trick of war, invented by men that they might escape from
title: Elementary Forms

text: certain dangers. It is known that according to a belief which is very
title: Elementary Forms

text: widespread in a large number of inferior societies, the human soul is
title: Elementary Forms

text: able, without great inconvenience, to quit the body it inhabits for a
title: Elementary Forms

text: while; howsoever far away it may be, it continues to animate this body
title: Elementary Forms

text: by a sort of detached control. Then, in certain critical moments, when
title: Elementary Forms

text: life is supposed to be particularly menaced, it may be desirable to
title: Elementary Forms

text: withdraw the soul from the body and lead it to some place or into some
title: Elementary Forms

text: object where it will be in greater security. In fact, there are a
title: Elementary Forms

text: certain number of practices whose object is to withdraw the soul in
title: Elementary Forms

text: order to protect it from some danger, either real or imaginary. For
title: Elementary Forms

text: example, at the moment when men are going to enter a newly-built house,
title: Elementary Forms

text: a magician removes their souls and puts them in a sack, to be saved and
title: Elementary Forms

text: returned to their proprietors after the door-sill has been crossed. This
title: Elementary Forms

text: is because the moment when one enters a new house is exceptionally
title: Elementary Forms

text: critical; one may have disturbed, and consequently offended, the spirits
title: Elementary Forms

text: who reside in the ground and especially under the sill, and if
title: Elementary Forms

text: precautions are not taken, these could make a man pay dearly for his
title: Elementary Forms

text: audacity. But when this danger is once passed, and one has been able to
title: Elementary Forms

text: anticipate their anger and even to make sure of their favour through the
title: Elementary Forms

text: accomplishment of certain rites, the souls may safely retake their
title: Elementary Forms

text: accustomed place.[578] It is this same belief which gave birth to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: personal totem. To protect themselves from sorcery, men thought it wise
title: Elementary Forms

text: to hide their souls in the anonymous crowd of some species of animal or
title: Elementary Forms

text: vegetable. But after these relations had once been established, each
title: Elementary Forms

text: individual found himself closely united to the animal or plant where his
title: Elementary Forms

text: own vital principle was believed to reside. Two beings so closely united
title: Elementary Forms

text: were finally thought to be practically indistinguishable: men believed
title: Elementary Forms

text: that each participated in the nature of the other. When this belief had
title: Elementary Forms

text: once been accepted, it facilitated and hastened the transformation of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the personal totem into an hereditary, and consequently a collective,
title: Elementary Forms

text: totem; for it seemed quite evident that this kinship of nature should be
title: Elementary Forms

text: transmitted hereditarily from father to child.
title: Elementary Forms

text: We shall not stop to discuss these two explanations of the individual
title: Elementary Forms

text: totem at length: they are ingenious fabrications of the mind, but they
title: Elementary Forms

text: completely lack all positive proof. If we are going to reduce totemism
title: Elementary Forms

text: to fetishism, we must first establish that the latter is prior to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: former; now, not merely is no fact brought forward to support this
title: Elementary Forms

text: hypothesis, but it is even contradicted by everything that we know. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: ill-determined group of rites going under the name of fetishism seem to
title: Elementary Forms

text: appear only among peoples who have already attained to a certain degree
title: Elementary Forms

text: of civilization; but it is a species of cult unknown in Australia. It is
title: Elementary Forms

text: true that some have described the churinga as a fetish;[579] but even
title: Elementary Forms

text: supposing that this qualification were justified, it would not prove the
title: Elementary Forms

text: priority which is postulated. Quite on the contrary, the churinga
title: Elementary Forms

text: presupposes totemism, since it is essentially an instrument of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: totemic cult and owes the virtues attributed to it to totemic beliefs
title: Elementary Forms

text: alone.
title: Elementary Forms

text: As for the theory of Frazer, it presupposes a thoroughgoing idiocy on
title: Elementary Forms

text: the part of the primitive which known facts do not allow us to attribute
title: Elementary Forms

text: to him. He does have a logic, however strange this may at times appear;
title: Elementary Forms

text: now unless he were completely deprived of it, he could never be guilty
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the reasoning imputed to him. Nothing could be more natural than that
title: Elementary Forms

text: he should believe it possible to assure the survival of his soul by
title: Elementary Forms

text: hiding it in a secret and inaccessible place, as so many heroes of myths
title: Elementary Forms

text: and legends are said to have done. But why should he think it safer in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the body of an animal than in his own? Of course, if it were thus lost
title: Elementary Forms

text: in space, it might have a chance to escape the spells of a magician more
title: Elementary Forms

text: readily, but at the same time it would be prepared for the blows of
title: Elementary Forms

text: hunters. It is a strange way of sheltering it to place it in a material
title: Elementary Forms

text: form exposing it to risks at every instant.[580] But above all, it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: inconceivable that a whole people should allow themselves to be carried
title: Elementary Forms

text: into such an aberration.[581] Finally, in a very large number of cases,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the function of the individual totem is very different from that
title: Elementary Forms

text: assigned it by Frazer; before all else, it is a means of conferring
title: Elementary Forms

text: extraordinary powers upon magicians, hunters or warriors.[582] As to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: kinship of the man and the thing, with all the inconveniences it
title: Elementary Forms

text: implies, it is accepted as a consequence of the rite; but it is not
title: Elementary Forms

text: desired in its and for itself.
title: Elementary Forms

text: There is still less occasion for delaying over this controversy since it
title: Elementary Forms

text: concerns no real problem. What we must know before everything else is
title: Elementary Forms

text: whether or not the individual totem is really a primitive fact, from
title: Elementary Forms

text: which the collective totem was derived; for, according to the reply
title: Elementary Forms

text: given to this question, we must seek the home of the religious life in
title: Elementary Forms

text: one or the other of two opposite directions.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Against the hypothesis of Hill Tout, Miss Fletcher, Boas and Frazer
title: Elementary Forms

text: there is such an array of decisive facts that one is surprised that it
title: Elementary Forms

text: has been so readily and so generally accepted.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In the first place, we know that a man frequently has the greatest
title: Elementary Forms

text: interest not only in respecting, but also in making his companions
title: Elementary Forms

text: respect the species serving him as personal totem; his own life is
title: Elementary Forms

text: connected with it. Then if collective totemism were only a generalized
title: Elementary Forms

text: form of individual totemism, it too should repose upon this same
title: Elementary Forms

text: principle. Not only should the men of a clan abstain from killing and
title: Elementary Forms

text: eating their totem-animal themselves, but they should also do all in
title: Elementary Forms

text: their power to force this same abstention upon others. But as a matter
title: Elementary Forms

text: of fact, far from imposing such a renunciation upon the whole tribe,
title: Elementary Forms

text: each clan, by rites which we shall describe below, takes care that the
title: Elementary Forms

text: plant or animal whose name it bears shall increase and prosper, so as
title: Elementary Forms

text: to assure an abundant supply of food for the other clans. So we must at
title: Elementary Forms

text: least admit that in becoming collective, individual totemism was
title: Elementary Forms

text: transformed profoundly, and we must therefore account for this
title: Elementary Forms

text: transformation.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In the second place, how is it possible to explain, from this point of
title: Elementary Forms

text: view, the fact that except where totemism is in full decay, two clans of
title: Elementary Forms

text: a single tribe always have different totems? It seems that nothing
title: Elementary Forms

text: prevents two or several members of a single tribe, even when there is no
title: Elementary Forms

text: kinship between them, from choosing their personal totem in the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: animal species and passing it on to their descendants. Does it not
title: Elementary Forms

text: happen to-day that two distinct families have the same name? The
title: Elementary Forms

text: carefully regulated way in which the totems and sub-totems are divided
title: Elementary Forms

text: up, first between the two phratries and then among the various clans of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the phratry, obviously presupposes a social agreement and a collective
title: Elementary Forms

text: organization. This is as much as to say that totemism is something more
title: Elementary Forms

text: than an individual practice spontaneously generalized.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Moreover, collective totemism cannot be deduced from individual totemism
title: Elementary Forms

text: except by a misunderstanding of the differences separating the two. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: one is acquired by the child at birth; it is a part of his civil status.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The other is acquired during the course of his life; it presupposes the
title: Elementary Forms

text: accomplishment of a determined rite and a change of condition. Some seek
title: Elementary Forms

text: to diminish this distance by inserting between the two, as a sort of
title: Elementary Forms

text: middle term, the right of each possessor of a totem to transmit it to
title: Elementary Forms

text: whomsoever he pleases. But wherever these transfers do take place, they
title: Elementary Forms

text: are rare and relatively exceptional acts; they cannot be performed
title: Elementary Forms

text: except by magicians or other personages invested with special
title: Elementary Forms

text: powers;[583] in any case, they are possible only through ritual
title: Elementary Forms

text: ceremonies which bring about the change. So it is necessary to explain
title: Elementary Forms

text: how this prerogative of a few became the right of all; how that which at
title: Elementary Forms

text: first implied a profound change in the religious and moral constitution
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the individual, was able to become an element of this constitution;
title: Elementary Forms

text: and finally, how a transmission which at first was the consequence of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: rite was later believed to operate automatically from the nature of
title: Elementary Forms

text: things and without the intervention of any human will.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In support of his interpretation, Hill Tout claims that certain myths
title: Elementary Forms

text: give the totem of the clan an individual origin: they tell how the
title: Elementary Forms

text: totemic emblem was acquired by some special individual, who then
title: Elementary Forms

text: transmitted it to his descendants. But in the first place, it is to be
title: Elementary Forms

text: remarked that these myths are all taken from the Indian tribes of North
title: Elementary Forms

text: America, which are societies arrived at a rather high degree of culture.
title: Elementary Forms

text: How could a mythology so far removed from the origins of things aid in
title: Elementary Forms

text: reconstituting the primitive form of an institution with any degree of
title: Elementary Forms

text: certainty? There are many chances for intermediate causes to have
title: Elementary Forms

text: gravely disfigured the recollection which these people have been able to
title: Elementary Forms

text: retain. Moreover, it is very easy to answer these myths with others,
title: Elementary Forms

text: which seem much more primitive and whose signification is quite
title: Elementary Forms

text: different. The totem is there represented as the very being from whom
title: Elementary Forms

text: the clan is descended. So it must be that it constitutes the substance
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the clan; men have it within them from their birth; it is a part of
title: Elementary Forms

text: their very flesh and blood, so far are they from having received it from
title: Elementary Forms

text: without.[584] More than that, the very myths upon which Hill Tout relies
title: Elementary Forms

text: contain an echo of this ancient conception. The founder who gave his
title: Elementary Forms

text: name to the clan certainly had a human form; but he was a man who, after
title: Elementary Forms

text: living among animals of a certain species, finally came to resemble
title: Elementary Forms

text: them. This is undoubtedly because a time came when the mind was too
title: Elementary Forms

text: cultivated to admit any longer, as it had formerly done, that men might
title: Elementary Forms

text: have been born of animals; so the animal ancestor, now become
title: Elementary Forms

text: inconceivable, is replaced by a human being; but the idea persists that
title: Elementary Forms

text: this man had acquired certain characteristics of the animal either by
title: Elementary Forms

text: imitation or by some other process. Thus even this late mythology bears
title: Elementary Forms

text: the mark of a more remote epoch when the totem of the clan was never
title: Elementary Forms

text: regarded as a sort of individual creation.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But this hypothesis does not merely raise grave logical difficulties; it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is contradicted directly by the following facts.
title: Elementary Forms

text: If individual totemism were the initial fact, it should be more
title: Elementary Forms

text: developed and apparent, the more primitive the societies are, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: inversely, it should lose ground and disappear before the other among
title: Elementary Forms

text: the more advanced peoples. Now it is the contrary which is true. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: Australian tribes are far behind those of North America; yet Australia
title: Elementary Forms

text: is the classic land of collective totemism. _In the great majority of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the tribes, it alone is found, while we do not know a single one where
title: Elementary Forms

text: individual totemism alone is practised._[585] This latter is found in a
title: Elementary Forms

text: characteristic form only in an infinitesimal number of tribes.[586] Even
title: Elementary Forms

text: where it is met with it is generally in a rudimentary form. It is made
title: Elementary Forms

text: up of individual and optional practices having no generality. Only
title: Elementary Forms

text: magicians are acquainted with the art of creating mysterious
title: Elementary Forms

text: relationships with species of animals to which they are not related by
title: Elementary Forms

text: nature. Ordinary people do not enjoy this privilege.[587] In America, on
title: Elementary Forms

text: the contrary, the collective totem is in full decadence; in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: societies of the North-west especially, its religious character is
title: Elementary Forms

text: almost gone. Inversely, the individual totem plays a considerable role
title: Elementary Forms

text: among these same peoples. A very great efficacy is attributed to it; it
title: Elementary Forms

text: has become a real public institution. This is because it is the sign of
title: Elementary Forms

text: a higher civilization. This is undoubtedly the explanation of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: inversion of these two forms of totemism, which Hill Tout believes he
title: Elementary Forms

text: has observed among the Salish. If in those parts where collective
title: Elementary Forms

text: totemism is the most fully developed the other form is almost lacking,
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is not because the second has disappeared before the first, but
title: Elementary Forms

text: rather, because the conditions necessary for its existence have not yet
title: Elementary Forms

text: been fully realized.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But a fact which is still more conclusive is that individual totemism,
title: Elementary Forms

text: far from having given birth to the totemism of the clan, presupposes
title: Elementary Forms

text: this latter. It is within the frame of collective totemism that it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: born and lives: it is an integral part of it. In fact, in those very
title: Elementary Forms

text: societies where it is preponderating, the novices do not have the right
title: Elementary Forms

text: of taking any animal as their individual totem; to each clan a certain
title: Elementary Forms

text: definite number of species are assigned, outside of which it may not
title: Elementary Forms

text: choose. In return, those belonging to it thus are its exclusive
title: Elementary Forms

text: property; members of other clans may not usurp them.[588] They are
title: Elementary Forms

text: thought to have relations of close dependence upon the one serving as
title: Elementary Forms

text: totem to the clan as a whole. There are even cases where it is quite
title: Elementary Forms

text: possible to observe these relations: the individual aspect represents a
title: Elementary Forms

text: part or a particular aspect of the collective totem.[589] Among the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Wotjobaluk, each member of the clan considers the personal totems of
title: Elementary Forms

text: his companions as being his own after a fashion;[590] so they are
title: Elementary Forms

text: probably sub-totems. Now the sub-totem supposes the totem, as the
title: Elementary Forms

text: species supposes the class. Thus the first form of individual religion
title: Elementary Forms

text: met with in history appears, not as the active principle of all public
title: Elementary Forms

text: religion, but, on the contrary, as a simple aspect of this latter. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: cult which the individual organizes for himself in his own inner
title: Elementary Forms

text: conscience, far from being the germ of the collective cult, is only this
title: Elementary Forms

text: latter adapted to the personal needs of the individual.
title: Elementary Forms

text: III
title: Elementary Forms

text: In a more recent study,[591] which the works of Spencer and Gillen
title: Elementary Forms

text: suggested to him, Frazer has attempted to substitute a new explanation
title: Elementary Forms

text: of totemism for the one he first proposed, and which we have just been
title: Elementary Forms

text: discussing. It rests on the postulate that the totemism of the Arunta is
title: Elementary Forms

text: the most primitive which we know; Frazer even goes so far as to say that
title: Elementary Forms

text: it scarcely differs from the really and absolutely original type.[592]
title: Elementary Forms

text: The singular thing about it is that the totems are attached neither to
title: Elementary Forms

text: persons nor to determined groups of persons, but to localities. In fact,
title: Elementary Forms

text: each totem has its centre at some definite spot. It is there that the
title: Elementary Forms
