text: souls of the first ancestors, who founded the totemic group at the
title: Elementary Forms

text: beginning of time, are believed to have their preferred residence. It is
title: Elementary Forms

text: there that the sanctuary is located where the churinga are kept; there
title: Elementary Forms

text: the cult is celebrated. It is also this geographical distribution of
title: Elementary Forms

text: totems which determines the manner in which the clans are recruited. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: child has neither the totem of his father nor that of his mother, but
title: Elementary Forms

text: the one whose centre is at the spot where the mother believes that she
title: Elementary Forms

text: felt the first symptoms of approaching maternity. For it is said that
title: Elementary Forms

text: the Arunta is ignorant of the exact relation existing between generation
title: Elementary Forms

text: and the sexual act;[593] he thinks that every conception is due to a
title: Elementary Forms

text: sort of mystic fecundation. According to him, it is due to the entrance
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the soul of an ancestor into the body of a woman and its becoming the
title: Elementary Forms

text: principle of a new life there. So at the moment when a woman feels the
title: Elementary Forms

text: first tremblings of the child, she imagines that one of the souls whose
title: Elementary Forms

text: principal residence is at the place where she happens to be, has just
title: Elementary Forms

text: entered into her. As the child who is presently born is merely the
title: Elementary Forms

text: reincarnation of this ancestor, he necessarily has the same totem; thus
title: Elementary Forms

text: his totem is determined by the locality where he is believed to have
title: Elementary Forms

text: been mysteriously conceived.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Now, it is this local totemism which represents the original form of
title: Elementary Forms

text: totemism; at most, it is separated from this by a very short step. This
title: Elementary Forms

text: is how Frazer explains its genesis.
title: Elementary Forms

text: At the exact moment when the woman realizes that she is pregnant, she
title: Elementary Forms

text: must think that the spirit by which she feels herself possessed has come
title: Elementary Forms

text: to her from the objects about her, and especially from one of those
title: Elementary Forms

text: which attract her attention at the moment. So if she is engaged in
title: Elementary Forms

text: plucking a plant, or watching an animal, she believes that the soul of
title: Elementary Forms

text: this plant or animal has passed into her. Among the things to which she
title: Elementary Forms

text: will be particularly inclined to attribute her condition are, in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: first place, the things she has just eaten. If she has recently eaten
title: Elementary Forms

text: emu or yam, she will not doubt that an emu or yam has been born in her
title: Elementary Forms

text: and is developing. Under these conditions, it is evident how the child,
title: Elementary Forms

text: in his turn, will be considered a sort of yam or emu, how he regards
title: Elementary Forms

text: himself as a relative of the plant or animal of the same species, how he
title: Elementary Forms

text: has sympathy and regard for them, how he refuses to eat them, etc.[594]
title: Elementary Forms

text: From this moment, totemism exists in its essential traits: it is the
title: Elementary Forms

text: native's theory of conception that gave rise to it, so Frazer calls this
title: Elementary Forms

text: primitive totemism _conceptional_.
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is from this original type that all the other forms of totemism are
title: Elementary Forms

text: derived. "When several women had, one after the other, felt the first
title: Elementary Forms

text: premonitions of maternity at the same spot and under the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: circumstances, the place would come to be regarded as haunted by spirits
title: Elementary Forms

text: of a peculiar sort; and so the whole country might in time be dotted
title: Elementary Forms

text: over with totem centres and distributed into totem districts."[595] This
title: Elementary Forms

text: is how the local totemism of the Arunta originated. In order that the
title: Elementary Forms

text: totems may subsequently be detached from their territorial base, it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: sufficient to think that the ancestral souls, instead of remaining
title: Elementary Forms

text: immutably fixed to a determined spot, are able to move freely over the
title: Elementary Forms

text: surface of the territory and that in their voyages they follow the men
title: Elementary Forms

text: and women of the same totem as themselves. In this way, a woman may be
title: Elementary Forms

text: impregnated by her own totem or that of her husband, though residing in
title: Elementary Forms

text: a different totemic district. According to whether it is believed that
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is the ancestor of the husband or of the wife who thus follow the
title: Elementary Forms

text: family about, seeking occasions to reincarnate themselves, the totem of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the child will be that of his father or mother. In fact, it is in just
title: Elementary Forms

text: this way that the Guanji and Umbaia on the one hand, and the Urabunna on
title: Elementary Forms

text: the other, explain their systems of filiation.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But this theory, like that of Tylor, rests upon a begging of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: question. If he is to imagine that human souls are the souls of animals
title: Elementary Forms

text: or plants, one must believe beforehand that men take either from the
title: Elementary Forms

text: animal or vegetable world whatever is most essential in them. Now this
title: Elementary Forms

text: belief is one of those at the foundation of totemism. To state it as
title: Elementary Forms

text: something evident is therefore to take for granted that which is to be
title: Elementary Forms

text: explained.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Moreover, from this point of view, the religious character of the totem
title: Elementary Forms

text: is entirely inexplicable, for the vague belief in an obscure kinship
title: Elementary Forms

text: between the man and the animal is not enough to found a cult. This
title: Elementary Forms

text: confusion of distinct kingdoms could never result in dividing the world
title: Elementary Forms

text: into sacred and profane. It is true that, being consistent with himself,
title: Elementary Forms

text: Frazer refuses to admit that totemism is a religion, under the pretext
title: Elementary Forms

text: that he finds in it neither spiritual beings, nor prayers, nor
title: Elementary Forms

text: invocations, nor offerings, etc. According to him, it is only a system
title: Elementary Forms

text: of magic, by which he means a sort of crude and erroneous science, a
title: Elementary Forms

text: first effort to discover the laws of things.[596] But we know how
title: Elementary Forms

text: inexact this conception, both of magic and of religion, is. We have a
title: Elementary Forms

text: religion as soon as the sacred is distinguished from the profane, and we
title: Elementary Forms

text: have seen that totemism is a vast system of sacred things. If we are to
title: Elementary Forms

text: explain it, we must therefore show how it happened that these things
title: Elementary Forms

text: were stamped with this character.[597] But he does not even raise this
title: Elementary Forms

text: problem.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But this system is completely overthrown by the fact that the postulate
title: Elementary Forms

text: upon which it rests can no longer be sustained. The whole argument of
title: Elementary Forms

text: Frazer supposes that the local totemism of the Arunta is the most
title: Elementary Forms

text: primitive we know, and especially that it is clearly prior to
title: Elementary Forms

text: hereditary totemism, either in the paternal or the maternal line. Now as
title: Elementary Forms

text: soon as the facts contained in the first volume of Spencer and Gillen
title: Elementary Forms

text: were at our disposal, we were able to conjecture that there had been a
title: Elementary Forms

text: time in the history of the Arunta people when the totems, instead of
title: Elementary Forms

text: being attached to localities, were transmitted hereditarily from mother
title: Elementary Forms

text: to child.[598] This conjecture is definitely proved by the new facts
title: Elementary Forms

text: discovered by Strehlow,[599] which only confirm the previous
title: Elementary Forms

text: observations of Schulze.[600] In fact, both of these authors tell us
title: Elementary Forms

text: that even now, in addition to his local totem, each Arunta has another
title: Elementary Forms

text: which is completely independent of all geographical conditions, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: which belongs to him as a birthright: it is his mother's. This second
title: Elementary Forms

text: totem, just like the first, is considered a powerful friend and
title: Elementary Forms

text: protector by the natives, which looks after their food, warns them of
title: Elementary Forms

text: possible dangers, etc. They have the right of taking part in its cult.
title: Elementary Forms

text: When they are buried, the corpse is laid so that the face is turned
title: Elementary Forms

text: towards the region of the maternal totemic centre. So after a fashion
title: Elementary Forms

text: this centre is also that of the deceased. In fact it is given the name
title: Elementary Forms

text: _tmara altjira_, which is translated: camp of the totem which is
title: Elementary Forms

text: associated with me. So it is certain that among the Arunta, hereditary
title: Elementary Forms

text: totemism in the uterine line is not later than local totemism, but, on
title: Elementary Forms

text: the contrary, must have preceded it. For to-day, the maternal totem has
title: Elementary Forms

text: only an accessory and supplementary role; it is a second totem, which
title: Elementary Forms

text: explains how it was able to escape observation as attentive and careful
title: Elementary Forms

text: as that of Spencer and Gillen. But in order that it should be able to
title: Elementary Forms

text: retain this secondary place, being employed along with the local totem,
title: Elementary Forms

text: there must have been a time when it held the primary place in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious life. It is, in part, a fallen totem, but one recalling an
title: Elementary Forms

text: epoch when the totemic organization of the Arunta was very different
title: Elementary Forms

text: from what it is to-day. So the whole superstructure of Frazer's system
title: Elementary Forms

text: is undermined at its foundation.[601]
title: Elementary Forms

text: IV
title: Elementary Forms

text: Although Andrew Lang has actively contested this theory of Frazer's, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: one he proposes himself in his later works,[602] resembles it on more
title: Elementary Forms

text: than one point. Like Frazer, he makes totemism consist in the belief in
title: Elementary Forms

text: a sort of consubstantiality of the man and the animal. But he explains
title: Elementary Forms

text: it differently.
title: Elementary Forms

text: He derives it entirely from the fact that the totem is a name. As soon
title: Elementary Forms

text: as human groups were founded,[603] each one felt the need of
title: Elementary Forms

text: distinguishing between the neighbouring groups with which it came into
title: Elementary Forms

text: contact and, with this end in view, it gave them different names. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: names were preferably chosen from the surrounding flora and fauna
title: Elementary Forms

text: because animals and plants can easily be designated by movements or
title: Elementary Forms

text: represented by drawings.[604] The more or less precise resemblances
title: Elementary Forms

text: which men may have with such and such objects determined the way in
title: Elementary Forms

text: which these collective denominations were distributed among the
title: Elementary Forms

text: groups.[605]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Now, it is a well-known fact that "to the early mind names, and the
title: Elementary Forms

text: things known by names, are in a mystic and transcendental connection of
title: Elementary Forms

text: _rapport_."[606] For example, the name of an individual is not
title: Elementary Forms

text: considered as a simple word or conventional sign, but as an essential
title: Elementary Forms

text: part of the individual himself. So if it were the name of an animal, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: man would have to believe that he himself had the most characteristic
title: Elementary Forms

text: attributes of this same animal. This theory would become better and
title: Elementary Forms

text: better accredited as the historic origins of these denominations became
title: Elementary Forms

text: more remote and were effaced from the memory. Myths arose to make this
title: Elementary Forms

text: strange ambiguity of human nature more easily representable in the mind.
title: Elementary Forms

text: To explain this, they imagined that the animal was the ancestor of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: men, or else that the two were descended from a common ancestor. Thus
title: Elementary Forms

text: came the conception of bonds of kinship uniting each clan to the animal
title: Elementary Forms

text: species whose name it bore. With the origins of this fabulous kinship
title: Elementary Forms

text: once explained, it seems to our author that totemism no longer contains
title: Elementary Forms

text: a mystery.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But whence comes the religious character of the totemic beliefs and
title: Elementary Forms

text: practices? For the fact that a man considers himself an animal of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: certain species does not explain why he attributes marvellous powers to
title: Elementary Forms

text: this species, and especially why he renders a cult to the images
title: Elementary Forms

text: symbolizing it.--To this question Lang gives the same response as
title: Elementary Forms

text: Frazer: he denies that totemism is a religion. "I find in Australia," he
title: Elementary Forms

text: says, "no example of religious practices such as praying to, nourishing
title: Elementary Forms

text: or burying the totem."[607] It was only at a later epoch, when it was
title: Elementary Forms

text: already established, that totemism was drawn into and surrounded by a
title: Elementary Forms

text: system of conceptions properly called religious. According to a remark
title: Elementary Forms

text: of Howitt,[608] when the natives undertake the explanation of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: totemic institutions, they do not attribute them to the totems
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves nor to a man, but to some supernatural being such as Bunjil
title: Elementary Forms

text: or Baiame. "Accepting this evidence," says Lang, "one source of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: 'religious' character of totemism is at once revealed. The totemist
title: Elementary Forms

text: obeys the decree of Bunjil, or Baiame, as the Cretans obeyed the divine
title: Elementary Forms

text: decrees given by Zeus to Minos." Now according to Lang the idea of these
title: Elementary Forms

text: great divinities arose outside of the totemic system; so this is not a
title: Elementary Forms

text: religion in itself; it has merely been given a religious colouring by
title: Elementary Forms

text: contact with a genuine religion.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But these very myths contradict Lang's conception of totemism. If the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Australians had regarded totemism as something human and profane, it
title: Elementary Forms

text: would never have occurred to them to make a divine institution out of
title: Elementary Forms

text: it. If, on the other hand, they have felt the need of connecting it with
title: Elementary Forms

text: a divinity, it is because they have seen a sacred character in it. So
title: Elementary Forms

text: these mythological interpretations prove the religious nature of
title: Elementary Forms

text: totemism, but do not explain it.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Moreover, Lang himself recognizes that this solution is not sufficient.
title: Elementary Forms

text: He realizes that totemic things are treated with a religious
title: Elementary Forms

text: respect;[609] that especially the blood of an animal, as well as that of
title: Elementary Forms

text: a man, is the object of numerous interdictions, or, as he says, taboos
title: Elementary Forms

text: which this comparatively late mythology cannot explain.[610] Then where
title: Elementary Forms

text: do they come from? Here are the words with which Lang answers this
title: Elementary Forms

text: question: "As soon as the animal-named groups evolved the universally
title: Elementary Forms

text: diffused beliefs about the _wakan_ or _mana_, or mystically sacred
title: Elementary Forms

text: quality of the blood as the life, they would also develop the various
title: Elementary Forms

text: taboos."[611] The words _wakan_ and _mana_, as we shall see in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: following chapter, involve the very idea of _sacredness_ itself; the one
title: Elementary Forms

text: is taken from the language of the Sioux, the other from that of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Melanesian peoples. To explain the sacred character of totemic things by
title: Elementary Forms

text: postulating this characteristic, is to answer the question by the
title: Elementary Forms

text: question. What we must find out is whence this idea of _wakan_ comes and
title: Elementary Forms

text: how it comes to be applied to the totem and all that is derived from it.
title: Elementary Forms

text: As long as these two questions remain unanswered, nothing is explained.
title: Elementary Forms

text: V
title: Elementary Forms

text: We have now passed in review all the principal explanations which have
title: Elementary Forms

text: been given for totemic beliefs,[612] leaving to each of them its own
title: Elementary Forms

text: individuality. But now that this examination is finished, we may state
title: Elementary Forms

text: one criticism which addresses itself to all these systems alike.
title: Elementary Forms

text: If we stick to the letter of the formulae, it seems that these may be
title: Elementary Forms

text: arranged in two groups. Some (Frazer, Lang) deny the religious character
title: Elementary Forms

text: of totemism; in reality, that amounts to denying the facts. Others
title: Elementary Forms

text: recognize this, but think that they can explain it by deriving it from
title: Elementary Forms

text: an anterior religion out of which totemism developed. But as a matter of
title: Elementary Forms

text: fact, this distinction is only apparent: the first group is contained
title: Elementary Forms

text: within the second. Neither Frazer nor Lang have been able to maintain
title: Elementary Forms

text: their principle systematically and explain totemism as if it were not a
title: Elementary Forms

text: religion. By the very force of facts, they have been compelled to slip
title: Elementary Forms

text: ideas of a religious nature into their explanations. We have just seen
title: Elementary Forms

text: how Lang calls in the idea of sacredness, which is the cardinal idea of
title: Elementary Forms

text: all religion. Frazer, on his side, in each of the theories which he has
title: Elementary Forms

text: successively proposed, appeals openly to the idea of souls or spirits;
title: Elementary Forms

text: for according to him, totemism came from the fact that men thought they
title: Elementary Forms

text: could deposit their souls in safety in some external object, or else
title: Elementary Forms

text: that they attributed conception to a sort of spiritual fecundation of
title: Elementary Forms

text: which a spirit was the agent. Now a soul, and still more, a spirit, are
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacred things and the object of rites; so the ideas expressing them are
title: Elementary Forms

text: essentially religious and it is therefore in vain that Frazer makes
title: Elementary Forms

text: totemism a mere system of magic, for he succeeds in explaining it only
title: Elementary Forms

text: in the terms of another religion.
title: Elementary Forms

text: We have already pointed out the insufficiencies of animism and naturism;
title: Elementary Forms

text: so one may not have recourse to them, as Tylor and Jevons do, without
title: Elementary Forms

text: exposing himself to these same objections. Yet neither Frazer nor Lang
title: Elementary Forms

text: seems to dream of the possibility of another hypothesis.[613] On the
title: Elementary Forms

text: other hand, we know that totemism is tightly bound up with the most
title: Elementary Forms

text: primitive social system which we know, and in all probability, of which
title: Elementary Forms

text: we can conceive. To suppose that it has developed out of another
title: Elementary Forms

text: religion, differing from it only in degree, is to leave the data of
title: Elementary Forms

text: observation and enter into the domain of arbitrary and unverifiable
title: Elementary Forms

text: conjectures. If we wish to remain in harmony with the results we have
title: Elementary Forms

text: already obtained, it is necessary that while affirming the religious
title: Elementary Forms

text: nature of totemism, we abstain from deriving it from another different
title: Elementary Forms

text: religion. There can be no hope of assigning it non-religious ideas as
title: Elementary Forms

text: its cause. But among the representations entering into the conditions
title: Elementary Forms

text: from which it results, there may be some which directly suggest a
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious nature of themselves. These are the ones we must look for.
title: Elementary Forms

text: CHAPTER VI
title: Elementary Forms

text: ORIGINS OF THESE BELIEFS--_continued_
title: Elementary Forms

text: _The Notion of the Totemic Principle, or Mana, and the Idea of Force_
title: Elementary Forms

text: Since individual totemism is later than the totemism of the clan, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: even seems to be derived from it, it is to this latter form that we must
title: Elementary Forms

text: turn first of all. But as the analysis which we have just made of it has
title: Elementary Forms

text: resolved it into a multiplicity of beliefs which may appear quite
title: Elementary Forms

text: heterogeneous, before going farther, we must seek to learn what makes
title: Elementary Forms

text: its unity.
title: Elementary Forms

text: I
title: Elementary Forms

text: We have seen that totemism places the figured representations of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: totem in the first rank of the things it considers sacred; next come the
title: Elementary Forms

text: animals or vegetables whose name the clan bears, and finally the members
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the clan. Since all these things are sacred in the same way, though
title: Elementary Forms

text: to different degrees, their religious character can be due to none of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the special attributes distinguishing them from each other. If a certain
title: Elementary Forms

text: species of animal or vegetable is the object of a reverential fear, this
title: Elementary Forms

text: is not because of its special properties, for the human members of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: clan enjoy this same privilege, though to a slightly inferior degree,
title: Elementary Forms

text: while the mere image of this same plant or animal inspires an even more
title: Elementary Forms

text: pronounced respect. The similar sentiments inspired by these different
title: Elementary Forms

text: sorts of things in the mind of the believer, which give them their
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacred character, can evidently come only from some common principle
title: Elementary Forms

text: partaken of alike by the totemic emblems, the men of the clan and the
title: Elementary Forms

text: individuals of the species serving as totem. In reality, it is to this
title: Elementary Forms

text: common principle that the cult is addressed. In other words totemism is
title: Elementary Forms

text: the religion, not of such and such animals or men or images, but of an
title: Elementary Forms

text: anonymous and impersonal force, found in each of these beings but not to
title: Elementary Forms

text: be confounded with any of them. No one possesses it entirely and all
title: Elementary Forms

text: participate in it. It is so completely independent of the particular
title: Elementary Forms

text: subjects in whom it incarnates itself, that it precedes them and
title: Elementary Forms

text: survives them. Individuals die, generations pass and are replaced by
title: Elementary Forms

text: others; but this force always remains actual, living and the same. It
title: Elementary Forms

text: animates the generations of to-day as it animated those of yesterday and
title: Elementary Forms

text: as it will animate those of to-morrow. Taking the words in a large
title: Elementary Forms

text: sense, we may say that it is the god adored by each totemic cult. Yet it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is an impersonal god, without name or history, immanent in the world and
title: Elementary Forms

text: diffused in an innumerable multitude of things.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But even now we have only an imperfect idea of the real ubiquity of this
title: Elementary Forms

text: quasi-divine entity. It is not merely found in the whole totemic
title: Elementary Forms

text: species, the whole clan and all the objects symbolizing the totem: the
title: Elementary Forms

text: circle of its action extends beyond that. In fact, we have seen that in
title: Elementary Forms

text: addition to the eminently holy things, all those attributed to the clan
title: Elementary Forms

text: as dependencies of the principal totem have this same character to a
title: Elementary Forms

text: certain degree. They also have something religious about them, for some
title: Elementary Forms

text: are protected by interdictions, while others have determined functions
title: Elementary Forms

text: in the ceremonies of the cult. Their religiousness does not differ in
title: Elementary Forms

text: kind from that of the totem under which they are classified; it must
title: Elementary Forms

text: therefore be derived from the same source. So it is because the totemic
title: Elementary Forms

text: god--to use again the metaphorical expression which we have just
title: Elementary Forms

text: employed--is in them, just as it is in the species serving as totem and
title: Elementary Forms

text: in the men of the clan. We may see how much it differs from the beings
title: Elementary Forms

text: in which it resides from the fact that it is the soul of so many
title: Elementary Forms

text: different beings.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But the Australian does not represent this impersonal force in an
title: Elementary Forms

text: abstract form. Under the influence of causes which we must seek, he has
title: Elementary Forms

text: been led to conceive it under the form of an animal or vegetable
title: Elementary Forms

text: species, or, in a word, of a visible object This is what the totem
title: Elementary Forms

text: really consists in: it is only the material form under which the
title: Elementary Forms

text: imagination represents this immaterial substance, this energy diffused
title: Elementary Forms

text: through all sorts of heterogeneous things, which alone is the real
title: Elementary Forms

text: object of the cult. We are now in a better condition for understanding
title: Elementary Forms

text: what the native means when he says that the men of the Crow phratry, for
title: Elementary Forms

text: example, are crows. He does not exactly mean to say that they are crows
title: Elementary Forms

text: in the vulgar and empiric sense of the term, but that the same principle
title: Elementary Forms

text: is found in all of them, which is their most essential characteristic,
title: Elementary Forms

text: which they have in common with the animals of the same name and which is
title: Elementary Forms

text: thought of under the external form of a crow. Thus the universe, as
title: Elementary Forms

text: totemism conceives it, is filled and animated by a certain number of
title: Elementary Forms

text: forces which the imagination represents in forms taken, with only a few
title: Elementary Forms

text: exceptions, from the animal or vegetable kingdoms: there are as many of
title: Elementary Forms

text: them as there are clans in the tribe, and each of them is also found in
title: Elementary Forms

text: certain categories of things, of which it is the essence and vital
title: Elementary Forms

text: principle.
title: Elementary Forms

text: When we say that these principles are forces, we do not take the word in
title: Elementary Forms

text: a metaphorical sense; they act just like veritable forces. In one sense,
title: Elementary Forms

text: they are even material forces which mechanically engender physical
title: Elementary Forms

text: effects. Does an individual come in contact with them without having
title: Elementary Forms

text: taken proper precautions? He receives a shock which might be compared to
title: Elementary Forms

text: the effect of an electric discharge. Sometimes they seem to conceive of
title: Elementary Forms

text: these as a sort of fluid escaping by points.[614] If they are introduced
title: Elementary Forms

text: into an organism not made to receive them, they produce sickness and
title: Elementary Forms

text: death by a wholly automatic action.[615] Outside of men, they play the
title: Elementary Forms

text: role of vital principle; it is by acting on them, we shall see,[616]
title: Elementary Forms

text: that the reproduction of the species is assured. It is upon them that
title: Elementary Forms

text: the universal life reposes.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But in addition to this physical aspect, they also have a moral
title: Elementary Forms

text: character. When someone asks a native why he observes his rites, he
title: Elementary Forms

text: replies that his ancestors always have observed them, and he ought to
title: Elementary Forms

text: follow their example.[617] So if he acts in a certain way towards the
title: Elementary Forms

text: totemic beings, it is not only because the forces resident in them are
title: Elementary Forms

text: physically redoubtable, but because he feels himself morally obliged to
title: Elementary Forms

text: act thus; he has the feeling that he is obeying an imperative, that he
title: Elementary Forms

text: is fulfilling a duty. For these sacred beings, he has not merely fear,
title: Elementary Forms

text: but also respect. Moreover, the totem is the source of the moral life of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the clan. All the beings partaking of the same totemic principle
title: Elementary Forms

text: consider that owing to this very fact, they are morally bound to one
title: Elementary Forms

text: another; they have definite duties of assistance, vendetta, etc.,
title: Elementary Forms

text: towards each other; and it is these duties which constitute kinship. So
title: Elementary Forms

text: while the totemic principle is a totemic force, it is also a moral
title: Elementary Forms

text: power; so we shall see how it easily transforms itself into a divinity
title: Elementary Forms

text: properly so-called.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Moreover, there is nothing here which is special to totemism. Even in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the most advanced religions, there is scarcely a god who has not kept
title: Elementary Forms

text: something of this ambiguity and whose functions are not at once cosmic
title: Elementary Forms

text: and moral. At the same time that it is a spiritual discipline, every
title: Elementary Forms

text: religion is also a means enabling men to face the world with greater
title: Elementary Forms

text: confidence. Even for the Christian, is not God the Father the guardian
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the physical order as well as the legislator and the judge of human
title: Elementary Forms

text: conduct?
title: Elementary Forms

text: II
title: Elementary Forms

text: Perhaps someone will ask whether, in interpreting totemism thus, we do
title: Elementary Forms

text: not endow the native with ideas surpassing the limits of his intellect.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Of course we are not prepared to affirm that he represents these forces
title: Elementary Forms

text: with the relative clarity which we have been able to give to them in our
title: Elementary Forms

text: analysis. We are able to show quite clearly that this notion is implied
title: Elementary Forms

text: by the whole system of beliefs which it dominates; but we are unable to
title: Elementary Forms

text: say how far it is conscious and how far, on the contrary, it is only
title: Elementary Forms

text: implicit and confusedly felt. There is no way of determining just what
title: Elementary Forms

text: degree of clarity an idea like this may have in obscure minds. But it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: well shown, in any case, that this in no way surpasses the capacities of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the primitive mind, and on the contrary, the results at which we have
title: Elementary Forms

text: just arrived are confirmed by the fact that either in the societies
title: Elementary Forms

text: closely related to these Australian tribes, or even in these tribes
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves, we find, in an explicit form, conceptions which differ from
title: Elementary Forms

text: the preceding only by shades and degrees.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The native religions of Samoa have certainly passed the totemic phase.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Real gods are found there, who have their own names, and, to a certain
title: Elementary Forms

text: degree, their own personal physiognomy. Yet the traces of totemism are
title: Elementary Forms

text: hardly contestable. In fact, each god is attached to a group, either
title: Elementary Forms

text: local or domestic, just as the totem is to its clan.[618] Then, each of
title: Elementary Forms

text: these gods is thought of as immanent in a special species of animal. But
title: Elementary Forms

text: this does not mean that he resides in one subject in particular: he is
title: Elementary Forms

text: immanent in all at once; he is diffused in the species as a whole. When
title: Elementary Forms

text: an animal dies, the men of the group who venerate it weep for it and
title: Elementary Forms

text: render pious duties to it, because a god inhabits it; but the god is not
title: Elementary Forms

text: dead. He is eternal, like the species. He is not even confused with the
title: Elementary Forms

text: present generation; he has already been the soul of the preceding one,
title: Elementary Forms

text: as he will be the soul of the one which is to follow.[619] So he has all
title: Elementary Forms

text: the characteristics of the totemic principle. He is the totemic
title: Elementary Forms

text: principle, re-clothed in a slightly personal form by the imagination.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But still, we must not exaggerate a personality which is hardly
title: Elementary Forms

text: reconcilable with this diffusion and ubiquity. If its contours were
title: Elementary Forms

text: clearly defined, it could never spread out thus and enter into such a
title: Elementary Forms

text: multitude of things.
title: Elementary Forms

text: However, it is incontestable that in this case the idea of an impersonal
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious force is beginning to change; but there are other cases where
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is affirmed in all its abstract purity and even reaches a higher
title: Elementary Forms

text: degree of generality than in Australia. If the different totemic
title: Elementary Forms

text: principles to which the various clans of a single tribe address
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves are distinct from each other, they are, none the less,
title: Elementary Forms

text: comparable to each other at bottom; for all play the same role in their
title: Elementary Forms

text: respective spheres. There are societies which have had the feeling of
title: Elementary Forms

text: this unity with nature and have consequently advanced to the idea of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: unique religious force of which all other sacred principles are only
title: Elementary Forms

text: expressions and which makes the unity of the universe. As these
title: Elementary Forms

text: societies are still thoroughly impregnated with totemism, and as they
title: Elementary Forms

text: remain entangled in a social organization identical with that of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Australians, we may say that totemism contained this idea in
title: Elementary Forms

text: potentiality.
title: Elementary Forms

text: This can be observed in a large number of American tribes, especially
title: Elementary Forms

text: those belonging to the great Sioux family: the Omaha, Ponka, Kansas,
title: Elementary Forms

text: Osage, Assiniboin, Dakota, Iowa, Winnebago, Mandan, Hidatsa, etc. Many
title: Elementary Forms

text: of these are still organized in clans, as the Omaha[620] and the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Iowa;[621] others were so not long since, and, says Dorsey, it is still
title: Elementary Forms

text: possible to find among them "all the foundations of the totemic system,
title: Elementary Forms

text: just as in the other societies of the Sioux."[622] Now among these
title: Elementary Forms

text: peoples, above all the particular deities to whom men render a cult,
title: Elementary Forms

text: there is a pre-eminent power to which all the others have the relation
title: Elementary Forms

text: of derived forms, and which is called _wakan_.[623] Owing to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: preponderating place thus assigned to this principle in the Siouan
title: Elementary Forms

text: pantheon, it is sometimes regarded as a sort of sovereign god, or a
title: Elementary Forms

text: Jupiter or Jahveh, and travellers have frequently translated wakan by
title: Elementary Forms

text: "great spirit." This is misrepresenting its real nature gravely. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: wakan is in no way a personal being; the natives do not represent it in
title: Elementary Forms

text: a determined form. According to an observer cited by Dorsey, "they say
title: Elementary Forms

text: that they have never seen the wakanda, so they cannot pretend to
title: Elementary Forms

text: personify it."[624] It is not even possible to define it by determined
title: Elementary Forms

text: attributes and characteristics. "No word," says Riggs, "can explain the
title: Elementary Forms

text: meaning of this term among the Dakota. It embraces all mystery, all
title: Elementary Forms

text: secret power, all divinity."[625] All the beings which the Dakota
title: Elementary Forms

text: reveres, "the earth, the four winds, the sun, the moon and the stars,
title: Elementary Forms

text: are manifestations of this mysterious life and power" which enters into
title: Elementary Forms

text: all. Sometimes it is represented in the form of a wind, as a breath
title: Elementary Forms

text: having its seat in the four cardinal points and moving everything:[626]
title: Elementary Forms

text: sometimes it is a voice heard in the crashing of the thunder;[627] the
title: Elementary Forms

text: sun, moon and stars are wakan.[628] But no enumeration could exhaust
title: Elementary Forms

text: this infinitely complex idea. It is not a definite and definable power,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the power of doing this or that; it is Power in an absolute sense, with
title: Elementary Forms

text: no epithet or determination of any sort. The various divine powers are
title: Elementary Forms

text: only particular manifestations and personifications of it; each of them
title: Elementary Forms

text: is this power seen under one of its numerous aspects.[629] It is this
title: Elementary Forms

text: which made one observer say, "He is a protean god; he is supposed to
title: Elementary Forms

text: appear to different persons in different forms."[630] Nor are the gods
title: Elementary Forms

text: the only beings animated by it: it is the principle of all that lives or
title: Elementary Forms

text: acts or moves. "All life is wakan. So also is everything which exhibits
title: Elementary Forms

text: power, whether in action, as the winds and drifting clouds, or in
title: Elementary Forms

text: passive endurance, as the boulder by the wayside."[631]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Among the Iroquois, whose social organization has an even more
title: Elementary Forms

text: pronouncedly totemic character, this, same idea is found again; the word
title: Elementary Forms

text: _orenda_ which expresses it is the exact equivalent of the wakan of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Sioux. "The savage man," says Hewitt, "conceived the diverse bodies
title: Elementary Forms

text: collectively constituting his environment to possess inherently mystic
title: Elementary Forms

text: potence ... (whether they be) the rocks, the waters, the tides, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: plants and the trees, the animals and man, the wind and the storms, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: clouds and the thunders and the lightnings,"[632] etc. "This potence is
title: Elementary Forms

text: held to be the property of all things ... and by the inchoate mentation
title: Elementary Forms

text: of man is regarded as the efficient cause of all phenomena, all the
title: Elementary Forms

text: activities of his environment."[633] A sorcerer or shaman has orenda,
title: Elementary Forms

text: but as much would be said of a man succeeding in his enterprises. At
title: Elementary Forms

text: bottom, there is nothing in the world which does not have its quota of
title: Elementary Forms

text: orenda; but the quantities vary. There are some beings, either men or
title: Elementary Forms

text: things, which are favoured; there are others which are relatively
title: Elementary Forms

text: disinherited, and the universal life consists in the struggles of these
title: Elementary Forms

text: orenda of unequal intensity. The more intense conquer the weaker. Is one
title: Elementary Forms

text: man more successful than his companions in the hunt or at war? It is
title: Elementary Forms

text: because he has more orenda. If an animal escapes from a hunter who is
title: Elementary Forms

text: pursuing it, it is because the orenda of the former was the more
title: Elementary Forms

text: powerful.
title: Elementary Forms

text: This same idea is found among the Shoshone under the name of _pokunt_,
title: Elementary Forms

text: among the Algonquin under the name of _manitou_,[634] of _nauala_ among
title: Elementary Forms

text: the Kwakiutl,[635] of _yek_ among the Tlinkit[636] and of _sgana_ among
title: Elementary Forms

text: the Haida.[637] But it is not peculiar to the Indians of North America;
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is in Melanesia that it was studied for the first time. It is true
title: Elementary Forms

text: that in certain of the islands of Melanesia, social organization is no
title: Elementary Forms

text: longer on a totemic basis; but in all, totemism is still visible,[638]
title: Elementary Forms

text: in spite of what Codrington has said about it. Now among these peoples,
title: Elementary Forms

text: we find, under the name of _mana_, an idea which is the exact equivalent
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the wakan of the Sioux and the orenda of the Iroquois. The definition
title: Elementary Forms

text: given by Codrington is as follows: "There is a belief in a force
title: Elementary Forms

text: altogether distinct from physical power, which acts in all ways for good
title: Elementary Forms

text: and evil; and which it is of the greatest advantage to possess or
title: Elementary Forms

text: control. This is Mana. I think I know what our people mean by it. ... It
title: Elementary Forms

text: is a power or influence, not physical and in a way supernatural; but it
title: Elementary Forms

text: shows itself in physical force, or in any kind of power or excellence
title: Elementary Forms

text: which a man possesses. This mana is not fixed in anything, and can be
title: Elementary Forms

text: conveyed in almost anything. ... All Melanesian religion consists, in
title: Elementary Forms

text: fact, in getting this mana for one's self, or getting it used for one's
title: Elementary Forms

text: benefit."[639] Is this not the same notion of an anonymous and diffused
title: Elementary Forms

text: force, the germs of which we recently found in the totemism of
title: Elementary Forms

text: Australia? Here is the same impersonality; for, as Codrington says, we
title: Elementary Forms

text: must be careful not to regard it as a sort of supreme being; any such
title: Elementary Forms

text: idea is "absolutely foreign" to Melanesian thought. Here is the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: ubiquity; the mana is located nowhere definitely and it is everywhere.
title: Elementary Forms

text: All forms of life and all the effects of the action, either of men or
title: Elementary Forms

text: of living beings or of simple minerals, are attributed to its
title: Elementary Forms

text: influence.[640]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Therefore there is no undue temerity in attributing to the Australians
title: Elementary Forms

text: an idea such as the one we have discovered in our analysis of totemic
title: Elementary Forms

text: beliefs, for we find it again, but abstracted and generalized to a
title: Elementary Forms

text: higher degree, at the basis of other religions whose roots go back into
title: Elementary Forms

text: a system like the Australian one and which visibly bear the mark of
title: Elementary Forms

text: this. The two conceptions are obviously related; they differ only in
title: Elementary Forms

text: degree, while the mana is diffused into the whole universe, what we call
title: Elementary Forms

text: the god or, to speak more precisely, the totemic principle, is localized
title: Elementary Forms

text: in the more limited circle of the beings and things of certain species.
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is mana, but a little more specialized; yet as a matter of fact, this
title: Elementary Forms

text: specialization is quite relative.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Moreover, there is one case where this connection is made especially
title: Elementary Forms

text: apparent. Among the Omaha, there are totems of all sorts, both
title: Elementary Forms

text: individual and collective;[641] but both are only particular forms of
title: Elementary Forms

text: wakan. "The foundation of the Indian's faith in the efficacy of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: totem," says Miss Fletcher, "rested upon his belief concerning nature
title: Elementary Forms

text: and life. This conception was complex and involved two prominent ideas:
title: Elementary Forms

text: First, that all things, animate and inanimate, were permeated by a
title: Elementary Forms

text: common life; and second, that this life could not be broken, but was
title: Elementary Forms

text: continuous."[642] Now this common principle of life is the wakan. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: totem is the means by which an individual is put into relations with
title: Elementary Forms

text: this source of energy; if the totem has any powers, it is because it
title: Elementary Forms

text: incarnates the wakan. If a man who has violated the interdictions
title: Elementary Forms

text: protecting his totem is struck by sickness or death, it is because this
title: Elementary Forms

text: mysterious force against which he has thus set himself, that is, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: wakan, reacts against him with a force proportionate to the shock
title: Elementary Forms

text: received.[643] Also, just as the totem is wakan, so the wakan, in its
title: Elementary Forms

text: turn, sometimes shows its totemic origin by the way in which it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: conceived. In fact, Say says that among the Dakota the "wahconda" is
title: Elementary Forms

text: manifested sometimes in the form of a grey bear, sometimes of a bison, a
title: Elementary Forms

text: beaver or some other animal.[644] Undoubtedly, this formula cannot be
title: Elementary Forms

text: accepted without reserve. The wakan repels all personification and
title: Elementary Forms

text: consequently it is hardly probable that it has ever been thought of in
title: Elementary Forms

text: its abstract generality with the aid of such definite symbols. But Say's
title: Elementary Forms

text: remark is probably applicable to the particular forms which it takes in
title: Elementary Forms

text: specializing itself in the concrete reality of life. Now if there is a
title: Elementary Forms

text: possibility that there was a time when these specializations of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: wakan bore witness to such an affinity for an animal form, that would be
title: Elementary Forms

text: one more proof of the close bonds uniting this conception to the totemic
title: Elementary Forms

text: beliefs.[645]
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is possible to explain why this idea has been unable to reach the
title: Elementary Forms

text: same degree of abstraction in Australia as in the more advanced
title: Elementary Forms

text: societies. This is not merely due to the insufficient aptitude of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Australian for abstracting and generalizing: before all, it is the
title: Elementary Forms

text: nature of the social environment which has imposed this particularism.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In fact, as long as totemism remains at the basis of the cultural
title: Elementary Forms

text: organization, the clan keeps an autonomy in the religious society which,
title: Elementary Forms

text: though not absolute, is always very marked. Of course we can say that in
title: Elementary Forms

text: one sense each totemic group is only a chapel of the tribal Church; but
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is a chapel enjoying a large independence. The cult celebrated there,
title: Elementary Forms

text: though not a self-sufficing whole, has only external relations with the
title: Elementary Forms

text: others; they interchange without intermingling; the totem of the clan is
title: Elementary Forms

text: fully sacred only for this clan. Consequently the groups of things
title: Elementary Forms

text: attributed to each clan, which are a part of it in the same way the men
title: Elementary Forms

text: are, have the same individuality and autonomy. Each of them is
title: Elementary Forms

text: represented as irreducible into similar groups, as separated from them
title: Elementary Forms

text: by a break of continuity, and as constituting a distinct realm. Under
title: Elementary Forms

text: these circumstances, it would occur to no one that these heterogeneous
title: Elementary Forms

text: worlds were different manifestations of one and the same fundamental
title: Elementary Forms

text: force; on the contrary, one might suppose that each of them corresponded
title: Elementary Forms

text: to an organically different mana whose action could not extend beyond
title: Elementary Forms

text: the clan and the circle of things attributed to it. The idea of a single
title: Elementary Forms

text: and universal mana could be born only at the moment when the tribal
title: Elementary Forms

text: religion developed above that of the clans and absorbed them more or
title: Elementary Forms

text: less completely. It is along with the feeling of the tribal unity that
title: Elementary Forms

text: the feeling of the substantial unity of the world awakens. As we shall
title: Elementary Forms

text: presently show,[646] it is true that the Australian societies are
title: Elementary Forms

text: already acquainted with a cult that is common to the tribe as a whole.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But if this cult represents the highest form of the Australian
title: Elementary Forms

text: religions, it has not succeeded in touching and modifying the principles
title: Elementary Forms

text: upon which they repose: totemism is essentially a federative religion
title: Elementary Forms

text: which cannot go beyond a certain degree of centralization without
title: Elementary Forms

text: ceasing to be itself.
title: Elementary Forms

text: One characteristic fact clearly shows the fundamental reason which has
title: Elementary Forms

text: kept the idea of the mana so specialized in Australia. The real
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious forces, those thought of in the form of totems, are not the
title: Elementary Forms

text: only ones with which the Australian feels himself obliged to reckon.
title: Elementary Forms

text: There are also some over which magicians have particular control. While
title: Elementary Forms

text: the former are theoretically considered healthful and beneficent, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: second have it as their especial function to cause sickness and death.
title: Elementary Forms

text: And at the same time that they differ so greatly in the nature of their
title: Elementary Forms

text: effects, they are contrasted also by the relations which they sustain
title: Elementary Forms

text: with the social organization. A totem is always a matter of the clan;
title: Elementary Forms

text: but on the contrary, magic is a tribal and even an intertribal
title: Elementary Forms

text: institution. Magic forces do not belong to any special portion of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: tribe in particular. All that is needed to make use of them is the
title: Elementary Forms

text: possession of efficient recipes. Likewise, everybody is liable to feel
title: Elementary Forms

text: their effects and consequently should try to protect himself against
title: Elementary Forms

text: them. These are vague forces, specially attached to no determined social
title: Elementary Forms

text: division, and even able to spread their action beyond the tribe. Now it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is a remarkable fact that among the Arunta and Loritja, they are
title: Elementary Forms

text: conceived as simple aspects and particular forms of a unique force,
title: Elementary Forms

text: called in Arunta _Arungquiltha_ or _Arunkulta_.[647] "This is a term,"
title: Elementary Forms

text: say Spencer and Gillen, "of somewhat vague import, but always associated
title: Elementary Forms

text: at bottom with the possession of _supernatural evil power_.... The name
title: Elementary Forms

text: is applied indiscriminately to the evil influence or to the object in
title: Elementary Forms

text: which it is, for the time being, or permanently, resident."[648] "By
title: Elementary Forms

text: arunkulta," says Strehlow, "the native signifies a force which suddenly
title: Elementary Forms

text: stops life and brings death to all who come in contact with it."[649]
title: Elementary Forms

text: This name is given to the bones and pieces of wood from which
title: Elementary Forms

text: evil-working charms are derived, and also to poisonous animals and
title: Elementary Forms

text: vegetables. So it may accurately be called a harmful mana. Grey mentions
title: Elementary Forms

text: an absolutely identical notion among the tribes he observed.[650] Thus
title: Elementary Forms

text: among these different peoples, while the properly religious forces do
title: Elementary Forms

text: not succeed in avoiding a certain heterogeneity, magic forces are
title: Elementary Forms

text: thought of as being all of the same nature; the mind represents them in
title: Elementary Forms

text: their generic unity. This is because they rise above the social
title: Elementary Forms

text: organization and its divisions and subdivisions, and move in a
title: Elementary Forms

text: homogeneous and continuous space where they meet with nothing to
title: Elementary Forms

text: differentiate them. The others, on the contrary, being localized in
title: Elementary Forms

text: definite and distinct social forms, are diversified and particularized
title: Elementary Forms

text: in the image of the environment in which they are situated.
title: Elementary Forms

text: From this we can see how thoroughly the idea of an impersonal religious
title: Elementary Forms

text: force enters into the meaning and spirit of Australian totemism, for it
title: Elementary Forms

text: disengages itself with clarity as soon as no contrary cause opposes it.
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is true that the arungquiltha is purely a magic force. But between
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious forces and magic forces there is no difference of kind:[651]
title: Elementary Forms

text: sometimes they are even designated by the same name: in Melanesia, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: magicians and charms have mana just like the agents and rites of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: regular cult;[652] the word oranda is employed in the same way by the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Iroquois.[653] So we can legitimately infer the nature of the one from
title: Elementary Forms

text: that of the other.[654]
title: Elementary Forms

text: III
title: Elementary Forms

text: The results to which the above analysis has led us do not concern the
title: Elementary Forms

text: history of totemism only, but also the genesis of religious thought in
title: Elementary Forms

text: general.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Under the pretext that in early times men were dominated by their senses
title: Elementary Forms

text: and the representations of their senses, it has frequently been held
title: Elementary Forms

text: that they commenced by representing the divine in the concrete form of
title: Elementary Forms

text: definite and personal beings. The facts do not confirm this presumption.
title: Elementary Forms

text: We have just described a systematically united scheme of religious
title: Elementary Forms

text: beliefs which we have good reason to regard as very primitive, yet we
title: Elementary Forms

text: have met with no personalities of this sort. The real totemic cult is
title: Elementary Forms

text: addressed neither to certain determined animals nor to certain
title: Elementary Forms

text: vegetables nor even to an animal or vegetable species, but to a vague
title: Elementary Forms

text: power spread through these things.[655] Even in the most advanced
title: Elementary Forms

text: religions which have developed out of totemism, such as those which we
title: Elementary Forms

text: find among the North American Indians, this idea, instead of being
title: Elementary Forms

text: effaced, becomes more conscious of itself; it is declared with a clarity
title: Elementary Forms

text: it did not have before, while at the same time, it attains a higher
title: Elementary Forms

text: generality. It is this which dominates the entire religious system.
title: Elementary Forms

text: This is the original matter out of which have been constructed those
title: Elementary Forms

text: beings of every sort which the religions of all times have consecrated
title: Elementary Forms

text: and adored. The spirits, demons, genii and gods of every sort are only
title: Elementary Forms

text: the concrete forms taken by this energy, or "potentiality," as Hewitt
title: Elementary Forms

text: calls it,[656] in individualizing itself, in fixing itself upon a
title: Elementary Forms

text: certain determined object or point in space, or in centring around an
title: Elementary Forms

text: ideal and legendary being, though one conceived as real by the popular
title: Elementary Forms

text: imagination. A Dakota questioned by Miss Fletcher expressed this
title: Elementary Forms

text: essential consubstantiability of all sacred things in language that is
title: Elementary Forms

text: full of relief. "Every thing as it moves, now and then, here and there,
title: Elementary Forms

text: makes stops. The bird as it flies stops in one place to make its nest,
title: Elementary Forms

text: and in another to rest in its flight. A man when he goes forth stops
title: Elementary Forms

text: when he wills. So the god has stopped. The sun, which is so bright and
title: Elementary Forms

text: beautiful, is one place where he has stopped. The trees, the animals,
title: Elementary Forms

text: are where he has stopped, and the Indian thinks of these places and
title: Elementary Forms

text: sends his prayers to reach the place where the god has stopped and to
title: Elementary Forms

text: win help and a blessing."[657] In other words, the wakan (for this is
title: Elementary Forms

text: what he was talking about) comes and goes through the world, and sacred
title: Elementary Forms

text: things are the points upon which it alights. Here we are, for once, just
title: Elementary Forms

text: as far from naturism as from animism. If the sun, the moon and the stars
title: Elementary Forms

text: have been adored, they have not owed this honour to their intrinsic
title: Elementary Forms

text: nature or their distinctive properties, but to the fact that they are
title: Elementary Forms

text: thought to participate in this force which alone is able to give things
title: Elementary Forms

text: a sacred character, and which is also found in a multitude of other
title: Elementary Forms

text: beings, even the smallest. If the souls of the dead have been the object
title: Elementary Forms

text: of rites, it is not because they are believed to be made out of some
title: Elementary Forms

text: fluid and impalpable substance, nor is it because they resemble the
title: Elementary Forms

text: shadow cast by a body or its reflection on a surface of water.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Lightness and fluidity are not enough to confer sanctity; they have been
title: Elementary Forms

text: invested with this dignity only in so far as they contained within them
title: Elementary Forms

text: something of this same force, the source of all religiosity.
title: Elementary Forms

text: We are now in a better condition to understand why it has been
title: Elementary Forms

text: impossible to define religion by the idea of mythical personalities,
title: Elementary Forms

text: gods or spirits; it is because this way of representing religious things
title: Elementary Forms

text: is in no way inherent in their nature. What we find at the origin and
title: Elementary Forms

text: basis of religious thought are not determined and distinct objects and
title: Elementary Forms

text: beings possessing a sacred character of themselves; they are indefinite
title: Elementary Forms

text: powers, anonymous forces, more or less numerous in different societies,
title: Elementary Forms

text: and sometimes even reduced to a unity, and whose impersonality is
title: Elementary Forms

text: strictly comparable to that of the physical forces whose manifestations
title: Elementary Forms

text: the sciences of nature study. As for particular sacred things, they are
title: Elementary Forms

text: only individualized forms of this essential principle. So it is not
title: Elementary Forms

text: surprising that even in the religions where there are avowed divinities,
title: Elementary Forms

text: there are rites having an efficient virtue in themselves, independently
title: Elementary Forms

text: of all divine intervention. It is because this force may be attached to
title: Elementary Forms

text: words that are pronounced or movements that are made just as well as to
title: Elementary Forms

text: corporal substances; the voice or the movements may serve as its
title: Elementary Forms

text: vehicle, and it may produce its effects through their intermediacy,
title: Elementary Forms

text: without the aid of any god or spirit. Even should it happen to
title: Elementary Forms

text: concentrate itself especially in a rite, this will become a creator of
title: Elementary Forms

text: divinities from that very fact.[658] This is why there is scarcely a
title: Elementary Forms

text: divine personality who does not retain some impersonality. Those who
title: Elementary Forms

text: represent it most clearly in a concrete and visible form, think of it,
title: Elementary Forms

text: at the same time, as an abstract power which cannot be defined except by
title: Elementary Forms

text: its own efficacy, or as a force spread out in space and which is
title: Elementary Forms

text: contained, at least in part, in each of its effects. It is the power of
title: Elementary Forms

text: producing rain or wind, crops or the light of day; Zeus is in each of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the raindrops which falls, just as Ceres is in each of the sheaves of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the harvest.[659] As a general rule, in fact, this efficacy is so
title: Elementary Forms

text: imperfectly determined that the believer is able to form only a very
title: Elementary Forms

text: vague notion of it. Moreover, it is this indecision which has made
title: Elementary Forms

text: possible these syncretisms and duplications in the course of which gods
title: Elementary Forms

text: are broken up, dismembered and confused in every way. Perhaps there is
title: Elementary Forms

text: not a single religion in which the original mana, whether unique or
title: Elementary Forms

text: multiform, has been resolved entirely into a clearly defined number of
title: Elementary Forms

text: beings who are distinct and separate from each other; each of them
title: Elementary Forms

text: always retains a touch of impersonality, as it were, which enables it to
title: Elementary Forms

text: enter into new combinations, not as the result of a simple survival but
title: Elementary Forms

text: because it is the nature of religious forces to be unable to
title: Elementary Forms

text: individualize themselves completely.
title: Elementary Forms

text: This conception, to which we have been led by the study of totemism
title: Elementary Forms

text: alone, has the additional recommendation that many scholars have
title: Elementary Forms

text: recently adopted it quite independently of one another, as a conclusion
title: Elementary Forms

text: from very different sorts of studies. There is a tendency towards a
title: Elementary Forms

text: spontaneous agreement on this point which should be remarked, for it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: a presumption of objectivity.
title: Elementary Forms

text: As early as 1899, we pointed out the impossibility of making the idea of
title: Elementary Forms

text: a mythical personality enter into the definition of religious
title: Elementary Forms

text: phenomena.[660] In 1900, Marrett showed the existence of a religious
title: Elementary Forms

text: phase which he called _preanimistic_, in which the rites are addressed
title: Elementary Forms

text: to impersonal forces like the Melanesian mana and the wakan of the Omaha
title: Elementary Forms

text: and Dakota.[661] However, Marrett did not go so far as to maintain that
title: Elementary Forms

text: always and in every case the idea of a spirit is logically and
title: Elementary Forms

text: chronologically posterior to that of mana and is derived from it; he
title: Elementary Forms

text: even seemed disposed to admit that it has sometimes appeared
title: Elementary Forms

text: independently and consequently, that religious thought flows from a
title: Elementary Forms

text: double source.[662] On the other hand, he conceived the mana as an
title: Elementary Forms

text: inherent property of things, as an element of their appearance; for,
title: Elementary Forms

text: according to him, this is simply the character which we attribute to
title: Elementary Forms

text: everything out of the ordinary, and which inspires a sentiment of fear
title: Elementary Forms

text: or admiration.[663] This practically amounts to a return to the naturist
title: Elementary Forms

text: theory.[664]
title: Elementary Forms

text: A little later, MM. Hubert and Mauss, while attempting to formulate a
title: Elementary Forms

text: general theory of magic, established the fact that magic as a whole
title: Elementary Forms

text: reposes on the notion of mana.[665] The close kinship of the magic rite
title: Elementary Forms

text: and the religious rite being known, it was even possible to foresee that
title: Elementary Forms

text: the same theory should be applied to religion. This was sustained by
title: Elementary Forms

text: Preuss in a series of articles in the _Globus_[666] that same year.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Relying chiefly upon facts taken from American civilizations, Preuss set
title: Elementary Forms

text: out to prove that the ideas of the soul and spirit were not developed
title: Elementary Forms

text: until after those of power and impersonal force, that the former are
title: Elementary Forms

text: only a transformation of the latter, and that up to a relatively late
title: Elementary Forms

text: date they retain the marks of their original impersonality. In fact, he
title: Elementary Forms

text: shows that even in the advanced religions, they are represented in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: form of vague emanations disengaging themselves automatically from the
title: Elementary Forms

text: things in which they reside, and even tending to escape by all the ways
title: Elementary Forms

text: that are open to them: the mouth, the nose and all the other openings of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the body, the breath, the look, the word, etc. At the same time, Preuss
title: Elementary Forms

text: pointed out their Protean forms and their extreme plasticity which
title: Elementary Forms

text: permits them to give themselves successively and almost concurrently to
title: Elementary Forms

text: the most varied uses.[667] It is true that if we stick to the letter of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the terminology employed by this author, we may believe that for him the
title: Elementary Forms

text: forces have a magic, not a religious nature: he calls them charms
title: Elementary Forms

text: (_Zauber, Zauberkraefte_). But it is evident that in expressing himself
title: Elementary Forms

text: thus, he does not intend to put them outside of religion; for it is in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the essentially religious rites that he shows their action, for example,
title: Elementary Forms

text: in the great Mexican ceremonies.[668] If he uses these expressions, it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is undoubtedly because he knows no others which mark better the
title: Elementary Forms

text: impersonality of these forces and the sort of mechanism with which they
title: Elementary Forms

text: operate.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Thus this same idea tends to come to light on every side.[669] The
title: Elementary Forms

text: impression becomes more and more prevalent that even the most elementary
title: Elementary Forms

text: mythological constructions are secondary products[670] which cover over
title: Elementary Forms

text: a system of beliefs, at once simpler and more obscure, vaguer and more
title: Elementary Forms

text: essential, which form the solid foundations upon which the religious
title: Elementary Forms

text: systems are built. It is this primitive foundation which our analysis of
title: Elementary Forms

text: totemism has enabled us to reach. The various writers whose studies we
title: Elementary Forms

text: have just mentioned arrived at this conclusion only through facts taken
title: Elementary Forms

text: from very diverse religions, some of which even correspond to a
title: Elementary Forms

text: civilization that is already far advanced: such is the case, for
title: Elementary Forms

text: example, with the Mexican religions, of which Preuss makes great use. So
title: Elementary Forms

text: it might be asked if this theory is equally applicable to the most
title: Elementary Forms

text: simple religions. But since it is impossible to go lower than totemism,
title: Elementary Forms

text: we are not exposed to this risk of error, and at the same time, we have
title: Elementary Forms

text: an opportunity of finding the initial notion from which the ideas of
title: Elementary Forms

text: wakan and mana are derived: this is the notion of the totemic
title: Elementary Forms

text: principle.[671]
title: Elementary Forms

text: IV
title: Elementary Forms

text: But this notion is not only of primary importance because of the role it
title: Elementary Forms

text: has played in the development of religious ideas; it also has a lay
title: Elementary Forms

text: aspect in which it is of interest for the history of scientific thought.
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is the first form of the idea of force.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In fact, the wakan plays the same role in the world, as the Sioux
title: Elementary Forms

text: conceives it, as the one played by the forces with which science
title: Elementary Forms

text: explains the diverse phenomena of nature. This, however, does not mean
title: Elementary Forms

text: that it is thought of as an exclusively physical energy; on the
title: Elementary Forms

text: contrary, in the next chapter we shall see that the elements going to
title: Elementary Forms

text: make up this idea are taken from the most diverse realms. But this very
title: Elementary Forms

text: compositeness of its nature enables it to be utilized as a universal
title: Elementary Forms

text: principle of explanation. It is from it that all life comes;[672] "all
title: Elementary Forms

text: life is wakan"; and by this word life, we must understand everything
title: Elementary Forms

text: that acts and reacts, that moves and is moved, in both the mineral and
title: Elementary Forms

text: biological kingdoms. The wakan is the cause of all the movements which
title: Elementary Forms

text: take place in the universe. We have even seen that the orenda of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Iroquois is "the efficient cause of all the phenomena and all the
title: Elementary Forms

text: activities which are manifested around men." It is a power "inherent in
title: Elementary Forms

text: all bodies and all things."[673] It is the orenda which makes the wind
title: Elementary Forms

text: blow, the sun lighten and heat the earth, or animals reproduce and which
title: Elementary Forms

text: makes men strong, clever and intelligent. When the Iroquois says that
title: Elementary Forms

text: the life of all nature is the product of the conflicts aroused between
title: Elementary Forms

text: the unequally intense orenda of the different beings, he only expresses,
title: Elementary Forms

text: in his own language, this modern idea that the world is a system of
title: Elementary Forms

text: forces limiting and containing each other and making an equilibrium.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The Melanesian attributes this same general efficacy to his mana. It is
title: Elementary Forms

text: owing to his mana that a man succeeds in hunting or fighting, that
title: Elementary Forms

text: gardens give a good return or that flocks prosper. If an arrow strikes
title: Elementary Forms

text: its mark, it is because it is charged with mana; it is the same cause
title: Elementary Forms

text: which makes a net catch fish well, or a canoe ride well on the sea,[674]
title: Elementary Forms

text: etc. It is true that if certain phrases of Codrington are taken
title: Elementary Forms

text: literally, mana should be the cause to which is attributed "everything
title: Elementary Forms

text: which is beyond the ordinary power of men, outside the common processes
title: Elementary Forms

text: of nature."[675] But from the very examples which he cites, it is quite
title: Elementary Forms

text: evident that the sphere of the mana is really much more extended. In
title: Elementary Forms

text: reality, it serves to explain usual and everyday phenomena; there is
title: Elementary Forms

text: nothing superhuman or supernatural in the fact that a ship sails or a
title: Elementary Forms

text: hunter catches game, etc. However, among these events of daily life,
title: Elementary Forms

text: there are some so insignificant and familiar that they pass unperceived:
title: Elementary Forms

text: they are not noticed and consequently no need is felt of explaining
title: Elementary Forms

text: them. The concept of mana is applied only to those that are important
title: Elementary Forms

text: enough to cause reflection, and to awaken a minimum of interest and
title: Elementary Forms

text: curiosity; but they are not marvellous for all that. And what is true of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the mana as well as the orenda and wakan, may be said equally well of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the totemic principle. It is through this that the life of the men of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the clan and the animals or plants of the totemic species, as well as
title: Elementary Forms

text: all the things which are classified under the totem and partake of its
title: Elementary Forms

text: nature, is manifested.
title: Elementary Forms

text: So the idea of force is of religious origin. It is from religion that it
title: Elementary Forms

text: has been borrowed, first by philosophy, then by the sciences. This has
title: Elementary Forms

text: already been foreseen by Comte and this is why he made metaphysics the
title: Elementary Forms

text: heir of "theology." But he concluded from this that the idea of force is
title: Elementary Forms

text: destined to disappear from science; for, owing to its mystic origins, he
title: Elementary Forms

text: refused it all objective value. But we are going to show that, on the
title: Elementary Forms

text: contrary, religious forces are real, howsoever imperfect the symbols may
title: Elementary Forms

text: be, by the aid of which they are thought of. From this it will follow
title: Elementary Forms

text: that the same is true of the concept of force in general.
title: Elementary Forms

text: CHAPTER VII
title: Elementary Forms
