text: ORIGINS OF THESE BELIEFS--_end_
title: Elementary Forms

text: _Origin of the Idea of the Totemic Principle or Mana_
title: Elementary Forms

text: The proposition established in the preceding chapter determines the
title: Elementary Forms

text: terms in which the problem of the origins of totemism should be posed.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Since totemism is everywhere dominated by the idea of a quasi-divine
title: Elementary Forms

text: principle, imminent in certain categories of men and things and thought
title: Elementary Forms

text: of under the form of an animal or vegetable, the explanation of this
title: Elementary Forms

text: religion is essentially the explanation of this belief; to arrive at
title: Elementary Forms

text: this, we must seek to learn how men have been led to construct this idea
title: Elementary Forms

text: and out of what materials they have constructed it.
title: Elementary Forms

text: I
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is obviously not out of the sensations which the things serving as
title: Elementary Forms

text: totems are able to arouse in the mind; we have shown that these things
title: Elementary Forms

text: are frequently insignificant. The lizard, the caterpillar, the rat, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: ant, the frog, the turkey, the bream-fish, the plum-tree, the cockatoo,
title: Elementary Forms

text: etc., to cite only those names which appear frequently in the lists of
title: Elementary Forms

text: Australian totems, are not of a nature to produce upon men these great
title: Elementary Forms

text: and strong impressions which in a way resemble religious emotions and
title: Elementary Forms

text: which impress a sacred character upon the objects they create. It is
title: Elementary Forms

text: true that this is not the case with the stars and the great atmospheric
title: Elementary Forms

text: phenomena, which have, on the contrary, all that is necessary to strike
title: Elementary Forms

text: the imagination forcibly; but as a matter of fact, these serve only very
title: Elementary Forms

text: exceptionally as totems. It is even probable that they were very slow in
title: Elementary Forms

text: taking this office.[676] So it is not the intrinsic nature of the thing
title: Elementary Forms

text: whose name the clan bears that marked it out to become the object of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: cult. Also, if the sentiments which it inspired were really the
title: Elementary Forms

text: determining cause of the totemic rites and beliefs, it would be the
title: Elementary Forms

text: pre-eminently sacred thing; the animals or plants employed as totems
title: Elementary Forms

text: would play an eminent part in the religious life. But we know that the
title: Elementary Forms

text: centre of the cult is actually elsewhere. It is the figurative
title: Elementary Forms

text: representations of this plant or animal and the totemic emblems and
title: Elementary Forms

text: symbols of every sort, which have the greatest sanctity; so it is in
title: Elementary Forms

text: them that is found the source of that religious nature, of which the
title: Elementary Forms

text: real objects represented by these emblems receive only a reflection.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Thus the totem is before all a symbol, a material expression of
title: Elementary Forms

text: something else.[677] But of what?
title: Elementary Forms

text: From the analysis to which we have been giving our attention, it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: evident that it expresses and symbolizes two different sorts of things.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In the first place, it is the outward and visible form of what we have
title: Elementary Forms

text: called the totemic principle or god. But it is also the symbol of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: determined society called the clan. It is its flag; it is the sign by
title: Elementary Forms

text: which each clan distinguishes itself from the others, the visible mark
title: Elementary Forms

text: of its personality, a mark borne by everything which is a part of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: clan under any title whatsoever, men, beasts or things. So if it is at
title: Elementary Forms

text: once the symbol of the god and of the society, is that not because the
title: Elementary Forms

text: god and the society are only one? How could the emblem of the group have
title: Elementary Forms

text: been able to become the figure of this quasi-divinity, if the group and
title: Elementary Forms

text: the divinity were two distinct realities? The god of the clan, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: totemic principle, can therefore be nothing else than the clan itself,
title: Elementary Forms

text: personified and represented to the imagination under the visible form of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the animal or vegetable which serves as totem.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But how has this apotheosis been possible, and how did it happen to take
title: Elementary Forms

text: place in this fashion?
title: Elementary Forms

text: II
title: Elementary Forms

text: In a general way, it is unquestionable that a society has all that is
title: Elementary Forms

text: necessary to arouse the sensation of the divine in minds, merely by the
title: Elementary Forms

text: power that it has over them; for to its members it is what a god is to
title: Elementary Forms

text: his worshippers. In fact, a god is, first of all, a being whom men think
title: Elementary Forms

text: of as superior to themselves, and upon whom they feel that they depend.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Whether it be a conscious personality, such as Zeus or Jahveh, or merely
title: Elementary Forms

text: abstract forces such as those in play in totemism, the worshipper, in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the one case as in the other, believes himself held to certain manners
title: Elementary Forms

text: of acting which are imposed upon him by the nature of the sacred
title: Elementary Forms

text: principle with which he feels that he is in communion. Now society also
title: Elementary Forms

text: gives us the sensation of a perpetual dependence. Since it has a nature
title: Elementary Forms

text: which is peculiar to itself and different from our individual nature, it
title: Elementary Forms

text: pursues ends which are likewise special to it; but, as it cannot attain
title: Elementary Forms

text: them except through our intermediacy, it imperiously demands our aid. It
title: Elementary Forms

text: requires that, forgetful of our own interests, we make ourselves its
title: Elementary Forms

text: servitors, and it submits us to every sort of inconvenience, privation
title: Elementary Forms

text: and sacrifice, without which social life would be impossible. It is
title: Elementary Forms

text: because of this that at every instant we are obliged to submit ourselves
title: Elementary Forms

text: to rules of conduct and of thought which we have neither made nor
title: Elementary Forms

text: desired, and which are sometimes even contrary to our most fundamental
title: Elementary Forms

text: inclinations and instincts.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Even if society were unable to obtain these concessions and sacrifices
title: Elementary Forms

text: from us except by a material constraint, it might awaken in us only the
title: Elementary Forms

text: idea of a physical force to which we must give way of necessity, instead
title: Elementary Forms

text: of that of a moral power such as religions adore. But as a matter of
title: Elementary Forms

text: fact, the empire which it holds over consciences is due much less to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: physical supremacy of which it has the privilege than to the moral
title: Elementary Forms

text: authority with which it is invested. If we yield to its orders, it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: not merely because it is strong enough to triumph over our resistance;
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is primarily because it is the object of a venerable respect.
title: Elementary Forms

text: We say that an object, whether individual or collective, inspires
title: Elementary Forms

text: respect when the representation expressing it in the mind is gifted with
title: Elementary Forms

text: such a force that it automatically causes or inhibits actions, _without
title: Elementary Forms

text: regard for any consideration relative to their useful or injurious
title: Elementary Forms

text: effects_. When we obey somebody because of the moral authority which we
title: Elementary Forms

text: recognize in him, we follow out his opinions, not because they seem
title: Elementary Forms

text: wise, but because a certain sort of physical energy is imminent in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: idea that we form of this person, which conquers our will and inclines
title: Elementary Forms

text: it in the indicated direction. Respect is the emotion which we
title: Elementary Forms

text: experience when we feel this interior and wholly spiritual pressure
title: Elementary Forms

text: operating upon us. Then we are not determined by the advantages or
title: Elementary Forms

text: inconveniences of the attitude which is prescribed or recommended to us;
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is by the way in which we represent to ourselves the person
title: Elementary Forms

text: recommending or prescribing it. This is why commands generally take a
title: Elementary Forms

text: short, peremptory form leaving no place for hesitation; it is because,
title: Elementary Forms

text: in so far as it is a command and goes by its own force, it excludes all
title: Elementary Forms

text: idea of deliberation or calculation; it gets its efficacy from the
title: Elementary Forms

text: intensity of the mental state in which it is placed. It is this
title: Elementary Forms

text: intensity which creates what is called a moral ascendancy.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Now the ways of action to which society is strongly enough attached to
title: Elementary Forms

text: impose them upon its members, are, by that very fact, marked with a
title: Elementary Forms

text: distinctive sign provocative of respect. Since they are elaborated in
title: Elementary Forms

text: common, the vigour with which they have been thought of by each
title: Elementary Forms

text: particular mind is retained in all the other minds, and reciprocally.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The representations which express them within each of us have an
title: Elementary Forms

text: intensity which no purely private states of consciousness could ever
title: Elementary Forms

text: attain; for they have the strength of the innumerable individual
title: Elementary Forms

text: representations which have served to form each of them. It is society
title: Elementary Forms

text: who speaks through the mouths of those who affirm them in our presence;
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is society whom we hear in hearing them; and the voice of all has an
title: Elementary Forms

text: accent which that of one alone could never have.[678] The very violence
title: Elementary Forms

text: with which society reacts, by way of blame or material suppression,
title: Elementary Forms

text: against every attempted dissidence, contributes to strengthening its
title: Elementary Forms

text: empire by manifesting the common conviction through this burst of
title: Elementary Forms

text: ardour.[679] In a word, when something is the object of such a state of
title: Elementary Forms

text: opinion, the representation which each individual has of it gains a
title: Elementary Forms

text: power of action from its origins and the conditions in which it was
title: Elementary Forms

text: born, which even those feel who do not submit themselves to it. It tends
title: Elementary Forms

text: to repel the representations which contradict it, and it keeps them at a
title: Elementary Forms

text: distance; on the other hand, it commands those acts which will realize
title: Elementary Forms

text: it, and it does so, not by a material coercion or by the perspective of
title: Elementary Forms

text: something of this sort, but by the simple radiation of the mental energy
title: Elementary Forms

text: which it contains. It has an efficacy coming solely from its psychical
title: Elementary Forms

text: properties, and it is by just this sign that moral authority is
title: Elementary Forms

text: recognized. So opinion, primarily a social thing, is a source of
title: Elementary Forms

text: authority, and it might even be asked whether all authority is not the
title: Elementary Forms

text: daughter of opinion.[680] It may be objected that science is often the
title: Elementary Forms

text: antagonist of opinion, whose errors it combats and rectifies. But it
title: Elementary Forms

text: cannot succeed in this task if it does not have sufficient authority,
title: Elementary Forms

text: and it can obtain this authority only from opinion itself. If a people
title: Elementary Forms

text: did not have faith in science, all the scientific demonstrations in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: world would be without any influence whatsoever over their minds. Even
title: Elementary Forms

text: to-day, if science happened to resist a very strong current of public
title: Elementary Forms

text: opinion, it would risk losing its credit there.[681]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Since it is in spiritual ways that social pressure exercises itself, it
title: Elementary Forms

text: could not fail to give men the idea that outside themselves there exist
title: Elementary Forms

text: one or several powers, both moral and, at the same time, efficacious,
title: Elementary Forms

text: upon which they depend. They must think of these powers, at least in
title: Elementary Forms

text: part, as outside themselves, for these address them in a tone of command
title: Elementary Forms

text: and sometimes even order them to do violence to their most natural
title: Elementary Forms

text: inclinations. It is undoubtedly true that if they were able to see that
title: Elementary Forms

text: these influences which they feel emanate from society, then the
title: Elementary Forms

text: mythological system of interpretations would never be born. But social
title: Elementary Forms

text: action follows ways that are too circuitous and obscure, and employs
title: Elementary Forms

text: psychical mechanisms that are too complex to allow the ordinary observer
title: Elementary Forms

text: to see whence it comes. As long as scientific analysis does not come to
title: Elementary Forms

text: teach it to them, men know well that they are acted upon, but they do
title: Elementary Forms

text: not know by whom. So they must invent by themselves the idea of these
title: Elementary Forms

text: powers with which they feel themselves in connection, and from that, we
title: Elementary Forms

text: are able to catch a glimpse of the way by which they were led to
title: Elementary Forms

text: represent them under forms that are really foreign to their nature and
title: Elementary Forms

text: to transfigure them by thought.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But a god is not merely an authority upon whom we depend; it is a force
title: Elementary Forms

text: upon which our strength relies. The man who has obeyed his god and who,
title: Elementary Forms

text: for this reason, believes the god is with him, approaches the world with
title: Elementary Forms

text: confidence and with the feeling of an increased energy. Likewise, social
title: Elementary Forms

text: action does not confine itself to demanding sacrifices, privations and
title: Elementary Forms

text: efforts from us. For the collective force is not entirely outside of us;
title: Elementary Forms

text: it does not act upon us wholly from without; but rather, since society
title: Elementary Forms

text: cannot exist except in and through individual consciousnesses,[682] this
title: Elementary Forms

text: force must also penetrate us and organize itself within us; it thus
title: Elementary Forms

text: becomes an integral part of our being and by that very fact this is
title: Elementary Forms

text: elevated and magnified.
title: Elementary Forms

text: There are occasions when this strengthening and vivifying action of
title: Elementary Forms

text: society is especially apparent. In the midst of an assembly animated by
title: Elementary Forms

text: a common passion, we become susceptible of acts and sentiments of which
title: Elementary Forms

text: we are incapable when reduced to our own forces; and when the assembly
title: Elementary Forms

text: is dissolved and when, finding ourselves alone again, we fall back to
title: Elementary Forms

text: our ordinary level, we are then able to measure the height to which we
title: Elementary Forms

text: have been raised above ourselves. History abounds in examples of this
title: Elementary Forms

text: sort. It is enough to think of the night of the Fourth of August, 1789,
title: Elementary Forms

text: when an assembly was suddenly led to an act of sacrifice and abnegation
title: Elementary Forms

text: which each of its members had refused the day before, and at which they
title: Elementary Forms

text: were all surprised the day after.[683] This is why all parties,
title: Elementary Forms

text: political, economic or confessional, are careful to have periodical
title: Elementary Forms

text: reunions where their members may revivify their common faith by
title: Elementary Forms

text: manifesting it in common. To strengthen those sentiments which, if left
title: Elementary Forms

text: to themselves, would soon weaken, it is sufficient to bring those who
title: Elementary Forms

text: hold them together and to put them into closer and more active relations
title: Elementary Forms

text: with one another. This is the explanation of the particular attitude of
title: Elementary Forms

text: a man speaking to a crowd, at least if he has succeeded in entering into
title: Elementary Forms

text: communion with it. His language has a grandiloquence that would be
title: Elementary Forms

text: ridiculous in ordinary circumstances; his gestures show a certain
title: Elementary Forms

text: domination; his very thought is impatient of all rules, and easily falls
title: Elementary Forms

text: into all sorts of excesses. It is because he feels within him an
title: Elementary Forms

text: abnormal over-supply of force which overflows and tries to burst out
title: Elementary Forms

text: from him; sometimes he even has the feeling that he is dominated by a
title: Elementary Forms

text: moral force which is greater than he and of which he is only the
title: Elementary Forms

text: interpreter. It is by this trait that we are able to recognize what has
title: Elementary Forms

text: often been called the demon of oratorical inspiration. Now this
title: Elementary Forms

text: exceptional increase of force is something very real; it comes to him
title: Elementary Forms

text: from the very group which he addresses. The sentiments provoked by his
title: Elementary Forms

text: words come back to him, but enlarged and amplified, and to this degree
title: Elementary Forms

text: they strengthen his own sentiment. The passionate energies he arouses
title: Elementary Forms

text: re-echo within him and quicken his vital tone. It is no longer a simple
title: Elementary Forms

text: individual who speaks; it is a group incarnate and personified.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Beside these passing and intermittent states, there are other more
title: Elementary Forms

text: durable ones, where this strengthening influence of society makes itself
title: Elementary Forms

text: felt with greater consequences and frequently even with greater
title: Elementary Forms

text: brilliancy. There are periods in history when, under the influence of
title: Elementary Forms

text: some great collective shock, social interactions have become much more
title: Elementary Forms

text: frequent and active. Men look for each other and assemble together more
title: Elementary Forms

text: than ever. That general effervescence results which is characteristic of
title: Elementary Forms

text: revolutionary or creative epochs. Now this greater activity results in
title: Elementary Forms

text: a general stimulation of individual forces. Men see more and differently
title: Elementary Forms

text: now than in normal times. Changes are not merely of shades and degrees;
title: Elementary Forms

text: men become different. The passions moving them are of such an intensity
title: Elementary Forms

text: that they cannot be satisfied except by violent and unrestrained
title: Elementary Forms

text: actions, actions of superhuman heroism or of bloody barbarism. This is
title: Elementary Forms

text: what explains the Crusades,[684] for example, or many of the scenes,
title: Elementary Forms

text: either sublime or savage, of the French Revolution.[685] Under the
title: Elementary Forms

text: influence of the general exaltation, we see the most mediocre and
title: Elementary Forms

text: inoffensive bourgeois become either a hero or a butcher.[686] And so
title: Elementary Forms

text: clearly are all these mental processes the ones that are also at the
title: Elementary Forms

text: root of religion that the individuals themselves have often pictured the
title: Elementary Forms

text: pressure before which they thus gave way in a distinctly religious form.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The Crusaders believed that they felt God present in the midst of them,
title: Elementary Forms

text: enjoining them to go to the conquest of the Holy Land; Joan of Arc
title: Elementary Forms

text: believed that she obeyed celestial voices.[687]
title: Elementary Forms

text: But it is not only in exceptional circumstances that this stimulating
title: Elementary Forms

text: action of society makes itself felt; there is not, so to speak, a moment
title: Elementary Forms

text: in our lives when some current of energy does not come to us from
title: Elementary Forms

text: without. The man who has done his duty finds, in the manifestations of
title: Elementary Forms

text: every sort expressing the sympathy, esteem or affection which his
title: Elementary Forms

text: fellows have for him, a feeling of comfort, of which he does not
title: Elementary Forms

text: ordinarily take account, but which sustains him, none the less. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: sentiments which society has for him raise the sentiments which he has
title: Elementary Forms

text: for himself. Because he is in moral harmony with his comrades, he has
title: Elementary Forms

text: more confidence, courage and boldness in action, just like the believer
title: Elementary Forms

text: who thinks that he feels the regard of his god turned graciously towards
title: Elementary Forms

text: him. It thus produces, as it were, a perpetual sustenance for our moral
title: Elementary Forms

text: nature. Since this varies with a multitude of external circumstances, as
title: Elementary Forms

text: our relations with the groups about us are more or less active and as
title: Elementary Forms

text: these groups themselves vary, we cannot fail to feel that this moral
title: Elementary Forms

text: support depends upon an external cause; but we do not perceive where
title: Elementary Forms

text: this cause is nor what it is. So we ordinarily think of it under the
title: Elementary Forms

text: form of a moral power which, though immanent in us, represents within us
title: Elementary Forms

text: something not ourselves: this is the moral conscience, of which, by the
title: Elementary Forms

text: way, men have never made even a slightly distinct representation except
title: Elementary Forms

text: by the aid of religious symbols.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In addition to these free forces which are constantly coming to renew
title: Elementary Forms

text: our own, there are others which are fixed in the methods and traditions
title: Elementary Forms

text: which we employ. We speak a language that we did not make; we use
title: Elementary Forms

text: instruments that we did not invent; we invoke rights that we did not
title: Elementary Forms

text: found; a treasury of knowledge is transmitted to each generation that it
title: Elementary Forms

text: did not gather itself, etc. It is to society that we owe these varied
title: Elementary Forms

text: benefits of civilization, and if we do not ordinarily see the source
title: Elementary Forms

text: from which we get them, we at least know that they are not our own work.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Now it is these things that give man his own place among things; a man
title: Elementary Forms

text: is a man only because he is civilized. So he could not escape the
title: Elementary Forms

text: feeling that outside of him there are active causes from which he gets
title: Elementary Forms

text: the characteristic attributes of his nature and which, as benevolent
title: Elementary Forms

text: powers, assist him, protect him and assure him of a privileged fate. And
title: Elementary Forms

text: of course he must attribute to these powers a dignity corresponding to
title: Elementary Forms

text: the great value of the good things he attributes to them.[688]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Thus the environment in which we live seems to us to be peopled with
title: Elementary Forms

text: forces that are at once imperious and helpful, august and gracious, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: with which we have relations. Since they exercise over us a pressure of
title: Elementary Forms

text: which we are conscious, we are forced to localize them outside
title: Elementary Forms

text: ourselves, just as we do for the objective causes of our sensations. But
title: Elementary Forms

text: the sentiments which they inspire in us differ in nature from those
title: Elementary Forms

text: which we have for simple visible objects. As long as these latter are
title: Elementary Forms

text: reduced to their empirical characteristics as shown in ordinary
title: Elementary Forms

text: experience, and as long as the religious imagination has not
title: Elementary Forms

text: metamorphosed them, we entertain for them no feeling which resembles
title: Elementary Forms

text: respect, and they contain within them nothing that is able to raise us
title: Elementary Forms

text: outside ourselves. Therefore, the representations which express them
title: Elementary Forms

text: appear to us to be very different from those aroused in us by collective
title: Elementary Forms

text: influences. The two form two distinct and separate mental states in our
title: Elementary Forms

text: consciousness, just as do the two forms of life to which they
title: Elementary Forms

text: correspond. Consequently, we get the impression that we are in relations
title: Elementary Forms

text: with two distinct sorts of reality and that a sharply drawn line of
title: Elementary Forms

text: demarcation separates them from each other: on the one hand is the world
title: Elementary Forms

text: of profane things, on the other, that of sacred things.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Also, in the present day just as much as in the past, we see society
title: Elementary Forms

text: constantly creating sacred things out of ordinary ones. If it happens
title: Elementary Forms

text: to fall in love with a man and if it thinks it has found in him the
title: Elementary Forms

text: principal aspirations that move it, as well as the means of satisfying
title: Elementary Forms

text: them, this man will be raised above the others and, as it were, deified.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Opinion will invest him with a majesty exactly analogous to that
title: Elementary Forms

text: protecting the gods. This is what has happened to so many sovereigns in
title: Elementary Forms

text: whom their age had faith: if they were not made gods, they were at least
title: Elementary Forms

text: regarded as direct representatives of the deity. And the fact that it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: society alone which is the author of these varieties of apotheosis, is
title: Elementary Forms

text: evident since it frequently chances to consecrate men thus who have no
title: Elementary Forms

text: right to it from their own merit. The simple deference inspired by men
title: Elementary Forms

text: invested with high social functions is not different in nature from
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious respect. It is expressed by the same movements: a man keeps at
title: Elementary Forms

text: a distance from a high personage; he approaches him only with
title: Elementary Forms

text: precautions; in conversing with him, he uses other gestures and language
title: Elementary Forms

text: than those used with ordinary mortals. The sentiment felt on these
title: Elementary Forms

text: occasions is so closely related to the religious sentiment that many
title: Elementary Forms

text: peoples have confounded the two. In order to explain the consideration
title: Elementary Forms

text: accorded to princes, nobles and political chiefs, a sacred character has
title: Elementary Forms

text: been attributed to them. In Melanesia and Polynesia, for example, it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: said that an influential man has _mana_, and that his influence is due
title: Elementary Forms

text: to this _mana_.[689] However, it is evident that his situation is due
title: Elementary Forms

text: solely to the importance attributed to him by public opinion. Thus the
title: Elementary Forms

text: moral power conferred by opinion and that with which sacred beings are
title: Elementary Forms

text: invested are at bottom of a single origin and made up of the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: elements. That is why a single word is able to designate the two.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In addition to men, society also consecrates things, especially ideas.
title: Elementary Forms

text: If a belief is unanimously shared by a people, then, for the reason
title: Elementary Forms

text: which we pointed out above, it is forbidden to touch it, that is to say,
title: Elementary Forms

text: to deny it or to contest it. Now the prohibition of criticism is an
title: Elementary Forms

text: interdiction like the others and proves the presence of something
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacred. Even to-day, howsoever great may be the liberty which we accord
title: Elementary Forms

text: to others, a man who should totally deny progress or ridicule the human
title: Elementary Forms

text: ideal to which modern societies are attached, would produce the effect
title: Elementary Forms

text: of a sacrilege. There is at least one principle which those the most
title: Elementary Forms

text: devoted to the free examination of everything tend to place above
title: Elementary Forms

text: discussion and to regard as untouchable, that is to say, as sacred: this
title: Elementary Forms

text: is the very principle of free examination.
title: Elementary Forms

text: This aptitude of society for setting itself up as a god or for creating
title: Elementary Forms

text: gods was never more apparent than during the first years of the French
title: Elementary Forms

text: Revolution. At this time, in fact, under the influence of the general
title: Elementary Forms

text: enthusiasm, things purely laical by nature were transformed by public
title: Elementary Forms

text: opinion into sacred things: these were the Fatherland, Liberty,
title: Elementary Forms

text: Reason.[690] A religion tended to become established which had its
title: Elementary Forms

text: dogmas,[691] symbols,[692] altars[693] and feasts.[694] It was to these
title: Elementary Forms

text: spontaneous aspirations that the cult of Reason and the Supreme Being
title: Elementary Forms

text: attempted to give a sort of official satisfaction. It is true that this
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious renovation had only an ephemeral duration. But that was
title: Elementary Forms

text: because the patriotic enthusiasm which at first transported the masses
title: Elementary Forms

text: soon relaxed.[695] The cause being gone, the effect could not remain.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But this experiment, though short-lived, keeps all its sociological
title: Elementary Forms

text: interest. It remains true that in one determined case we have seen
title: Elementary Forms

text: society and its essential ideas become, directly and with no
title: Elementary Forms

text: transfiguration of any sort, the object of a veritable cult.
title: Elementary Forms

text: All these facts allow us to catch glimpses of how the clan was able to
title: Elementary Forms

text: awaken within its members the idea that outside of them there exist
title: Elementary Forms

text: forces which dominate them and at the same time sustain them, that is to
title: Elementary Forms

text: say in fine, religious forces: it is because there is no society with
title: Elementary Forms

text: which the primitive is more directly and closely connected. The bonds
title: Elementary Forms

text: uniting him to the tribe are much more lax and more feebly felt.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Although this is not at all strange or foreign to him, it is with the
title: Elementary Forms

text: people of his own clan that he has the greatest number of things in
title: Elementary Forms

text: common; it is the action of this group that he feels the most directly;
title: Elementary Forms

text: so it is this also which, in preference to all others, should express
title: Elementary Forms

text: itself in religious symbols.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But this first explanation has been too general, for it is applicable to
title: Elementary Forms

text: every sort of society indifferently, and consequently to every sort of
title: Elementary Forms

text: religion. Let us attempt to determine exactly what form this collective
title: Elementary Forms

text: action takes in the clan and how it arouses the sensation of sacredness
title: Elementary Forms

text: there. For there is no place where it is more easily observable or more
title: Elementary Forms

text: apparent in its results.
title: Elementary Forms

text: III
title: Elementary Forms

text: The life of the Australian societies passes alternately through two
title: Elementary Forms

text: distinct phases.[696] Sometimes the population is broken up into little
title: Elementary Forms

text: groups who wander about independently of one another, in their various
title: Elementary Forms

text: occupations; each family lives by itself, hunting and fishing, and in a
title: Elementary Forms

text: word, trying to procure its indispensable food by all the means in its
title: Elementary Forms

text: power. Sometimes, on the contrary, the population concentrates and
title: Elementary Forms

text: gathers at determined points for a length of time varying from several
title: Elementary Forms

text: days to several months. This concentration takes place when a clan or a
title: Elementary Forms

text: part of the tribe[697] is summoned to the gathering, and on this
title: Elementary Forms

text: occasion they celebrate a religious ceremony, or else hold what is
title: Elementary Forms

text: called a corrobbori[698] in the usual ethnological language.
title: Elementary Forms

text: These two phases are contrasted with each other in the sharpest way. In
title: Elementary Forms

text: the first, economic activity is the preponderating one, and it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: generally of a very mediocre intensity. Gathering the grains or herbs
title: Elementary Forms

text: that are necessary for food, or hunting and fishing are not occupations
title: Elementary Forms

text: to awaken very lively passions.[699] The dispersed condition in which
title: Elementary Forms

text: the society finds itself results in making its life uniform, languishing
title: Elementary Forms

text: and dull.[700] But when a corrobbori takes place, everything changes.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Since the emotional and passional faculties of the primitive are only
title: Elementary Forms

text: imperfectly placed under the control of his reason and will, he easily
title: Elementary Forms

text: loses control of himself. Any event of some importance puts him quite
title: Elementary Forms

text: outside himself. Does he receive good news? There are at once transports
title: Elementary Forms

text: of enthusiasm. In the contrary conditions, he is to be seen running here
title: Elementary Forms

text: and there like a madman, giving himself up to all sorts of immoderate
title: Elementary Forms

text: movements, crying, shrieking, rolling in the dust, throwing it in every
title: Elementary Forms

text: direction, biting himself, brandishing his arms in a furious manner,
title: Elementary Forms

text: etc.[701] The very fact of the concentration acts as an exceptionally
title: Elementary Forms

text: powerful stimulant. When they are once come together, a sort of
title: Elementary Forms

text: electricity is formed by their collecting which quickly transports them
title: Elementary Forms

text: to an extraordinary degree of exaltation. Every sentiment expressed
title: Elementary Forms

text: finds a place without resistance in all the minds, which are very open
title: Elementary Forms

text: to outside impressions; each re-echoes the others, and is re-echoed by
title: Elementary Forms

text: the others. The initial impulse thus proceeds, growing as it goes, as an
title: Elementary Forms

text: avalanche grows in its advance. And as such active passions so free from
title: Elementary Forms

text: all control could not fail to burst out, on every side one sees nothing
title: Elementary Forms

text: but violent gestures, cries, veritable howls, and deafening noises of
title: Elementary Forms

text: every sort, which aid in intensifying still more the state of mind which
title: Elementary Forms

text: they manifest. And since a collective sentiment cannot express itself
title: Elementary Forms

text: collectively except on the condition of observing a certain order
title: Elementary Forms

text: permitting co-operation and movements in unison, these gestures and
title: Elementary Forms

text: cries naturally tend to become rhythmic and regular; hence come songs
title: Elementary Forms

text: and dances. But in taking a more regular form, they lose nothing of
title: Elementary Forms

text: their natural violence; a regulated tumult remains tumult. The human
title: Elementary Forms

text: voice is not sufficient for the task; it is reinforced by means of
title: Elementary Forms

text: artificial processes: boomerangs are beaten against each other;
title: Elementary Forms

text: bull-roarers are whirled. It is probable that these instruments, the use
title: Elementary Forms

text: of which is so general in the Australian religious ceremonies, are used
title: Elementary Forms

text: primarily to express in a more adequate fashion the agitation felt. But
title: Elementary Forms

text: while they express it, they also strengthen it. This effervescence often
title: Elementary Forms

text: reaches such a point that it causes unheard-of actions. The passions
title: Elementary Forms

text: released are of such an impetuosity that they can be restrained by
title: Elementary Forms

text: nothing. They are so far removed from their ordinary conditions of life,
title: Elementary Forms

text: and they are so thoroughly conscious of it, that they feel that they
title: Elementary Forms

text: must set themselves outside of and above their ordinary morals. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: sexes unite contrarily to the rules governing sexual relations. Men
title: Elementary Forms

text: exchange wives with each other. Sometimes even incestuous unions, which
title: Elementary Forms

text: in normal times are thought abominable and are severely punished, are
title: Elementary Forms

text: now contracted openly and with impunity.[702] If we add to all this that
title: Elementary Forms

text: the ceremonies generally take place at night in a darkness pierced here
title: Elementary Forms

text: and there by the light of fires, we can easily imagine what effect such
title: Elementary Forms

text: scenes ought to produce on the minds of those who participate. They
title: Elementary Forms

text: produce such a violent super-excitation of the whole physical and mental
title: Elementary Forms

text: life that it cannot be supported very long: the actor taking the
title: Elementary Forms

text: principal part finally falls exhausted on the ground.[703]
title: Elementary Forms

text: To illustrate and make specific this necessarily schematic picture, let
title: Elementary Forms

text: us describe certain scenes taken from Spencer and Gillen.
title: Elementary Forms

text: One of the most important religious ceremonies among the Warramunga is
title: Elementary Forms

text: the one concerning the snake Wollunqua. It consists in a series of
title: Elementary Forms

text: ceremonies lasting through several days. On the fourth day comes the
title: Elementary Forms

text: following scene.
title: Elementary Forms

text: According to the ceremonial used among the Warramunga, representatives
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the two phratries take part, one as officiants, the other as
title: Elementary Forms

text: preparers and assistants. Only the members of the Uluuru phratry are
title: Elementary Forms

text: qualified to celebrate the rite, but the members of the Kingilli phratry
title: Elementary Forms

text: must decorate the actors, make ready the place and the instruments, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: play the part of an audience. In this capacity, they were charged with
title: Elementary Forms

text: making a sort of mound in advance out of wet sand, upon which a design
title: Elementary Forms

text: is marked with red down which represents the snake Wollunqua. The real
title: Elementary Forms

text: ceremony only commenced after nightfall. Towards ten or eleven o'clock,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the Uluuru and Kingilli men arrived on the ground, sat down on the mound
title: Elementary Forms

text: and commenced to sing. Everyone was evidently very excited. A little
title: Elementary Forms

text: later in the evening, the Uluuru brought up their wives and gave them
title: Elementary Forms

text: over to the Kingilli,[704] who had intercourse with them. Then the
title: Elementary Forms

text: recently initiated young men were brought in and the whole ceremony was
title: Elementary Forms

text: explained to them in detail, and until three o'clock in the morning
title: Elementary Forms

text: singing went on without a pause. Then followed a scene of the wildest
title: Elementary Forms

text: excitement. While fires were lighted on all sides, making the whiteness
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the gum-trees stand out sharply against the surrounding darkness, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Uluuru knelt down one behind another beside the mound, then rising from
title: Elementary Forms

text: the ground they went around it, with a movement in unison, their two
title: Elementary Forms

text: hands resting upon their thighs, then a little farther on they knelt
title: Elementary Forms

text: down again, and so on. At the same time they swayed their bodies, now to
title: Elementary Forms

text: the right and now to the left, while uttering at each movement a
title: Elementary Forms

text: piercing cry, a veritable yell, "_Yrrsh! Yrrsh! Yrrsh!_" In the meantime
title: Elementary Forms

text: the Kingilli, in a state of great excitement, clanged their boomerangs
title: Elementary Forms

text: and their chief was even more agitated than his companions. When the
title: Elementary Forms

text: procession of the Uluuru had twice gone around the mound, quitting the
title: Elementary Forms

text: kneeling position, they sat down and commenced to sing again; at moments
title: Elementary Forms

text: the singing died away, then suddenly took up again. When day commenced
title: Elementary Forms

text: to dawn, all leaped to their feet; the fires that had gone out were
title: Elementary Forms

text: relighted and the Uluuru, urged on by the Kingilli, attacked the mound
title: Elementary Forms

text: furiously with boomerangs, lances and clubs; in a few minutes it was
title: Elementary Forms

text: torn to pieces. The fires died away and profound silence reigned
title: Elementary Forms

text: again.[705]
title: Elementary Forms

text: A still more violent scene at which these same observers assisted was in
title: Elementary Forms

text: connection with the fire ceremonies among the Warramunga.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Commencing at nightfall, all sorts of processions, dances and songs had
title: Elementary Forms

text: taken place by torchlight; the general effervescence was constantly
title: Elementary Forms

text: increasing. At a given moment, twelve assistants each took a great
title: Elementary Forms

text: lighted torch in their hands, and one of them holding his like a
title: Elementary Forms

text: bayonet, charged into a group of natives. Blows were warded off with
title: Elementary Forms

text: clubs and spears. A general melee followed. The men leaped and pranced
title: Elementary Forms

text: about, uttering savage yells all the time; the burning torches
title: Elementary Forms

text: continually came crashing down on the heads and bodies of the men,
title: Elementary Forms

text: scattering lighted sparks in every direction. "The smoke, the blazing
title: Elementary Forms

text: torches, the showers of sparks falling in all directions and the masses
title: Elementary Forms

text: of dancing, yelling men," say Spencer and Gillen, "formed altogether a
title: Elementary Forms

text: genuinely wild and savage scene of which it is impossible to convey any
title: Elementary Forms

text: adequate idea in words."[706]
title: Elementary Forms

text: One can readily conceive how, when arrived at this state of exaltation,
title: Elementary Forms

text: a man does not recognize himself any longer. Feeling himself dominated
title: Elementary Forms

text: and carried away by some sort of an external power which makes him think
title: Elementary Forms

text: and act differently than in normal times, he naturally has the
title: Elementary Forms

text: impression of being himself no longer. It seems to him that he has
title: Elementary Forms

text: become a new being: the decorations he puts on and the masks that cover
title: Elementary Forms

text: his face figure materially in this interior transformation, and to a
title: Elementary Forms

text: still greater extent, they aid in determining its nature. And as at the
title: Elementary Forms

text: same time all his companions feel themselves transformed in the same way
title: Elementary Forms

text: and express this sentiment by their cries, their gestures and their
title: Elementary Forms

text: general attitude, everything is just as though he really were
title: Elementary Forms

text: transported into a special world, entirely different from the one where
title: Elementary Forms

text: he ordinarily lives, and into an environment filled with exceptionally
title: Elementary Forms

text: intense forces that take hold of him and metamorphose him. How could
title: Elementary Forms

text: such experiences as these, especially when they are repeated every day.
title: Elementary Forms

text: for weeks, fail to leave in him the conviction that there really exist
title: Elementary Forms

text: two heterogeneous and mutually incomparable worlds? One is that where
title: Elementary Forms

text: his daily life drags wearily along; but he cannot penetrate into the
title: Elementary Forms

text: other without at once entering into relations with extraordinary powers
title: Elementary Forms

text: that excite him to the point of frenzy. The first is the profane world,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the second, that of sacred things.
title: Elementary Forms

text: So it is in the midst of these effervescent social environments and out
title: Elementary Forms

text: of this effervescence itself that the religious idea seems to be born.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The theory that this is really its origin is confirmed by the fact that
title: Elementary Forms

text: in Australia the really religious activity is almost entirely confined
title: Elementary Forms

text: to the moments when these assemblies are held. To be sure, there is no
title: Elementary Forms

text: people among whom the great solemnities of the cult are not more or less
title: Elementary Forms

text: periodic; but in the more advanced societies, there is not, so to speak,
title: Elementary Forms

text: a day when some prayer or offering is not addressed to the gods and some
title: Elementary Forms

text: ritual act is not performed. But in Australia, on the contrary, apart
title: Elementary Forms

text: from the celebrations of the clan and tribe, the time is nearly all
title: Elementary Forms

text: filled with lay and profane occupations. Of course there are
title: Elementary Forms

text: prohibitions that should be and are preserved even during these periods
title: Elementary Forms

text: of temporal activity; it is never permissible to kill or eat freely of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the totemic animal, at least in those parts where the interdiction has
title: Elementary Forms

text: retained its original vigour; but almost no positive rites are then
title: Elementary Forms

text: celebrated, and there are no ceremonies of any importance. These take
title: Elementary Forms

text: place only in the midst of assembled groups. The religious life of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Australian passes through successive phases of complete lull and of
title: Elementary Forms

text: super-excitation, and social life oscillates in the same rhythm. This
title: Elementary Forms

text: puts clearly into evidence the bond uniting them to one another, but
title: Elementary Forms

text: among the peoples called civilized, the relative continuity of the two
title: Elementary Forms

text: blurs their relations. It might even be asked whether the violence of
title: Elementary Forms

text: this contrast was not necessary to disengage the feeling of sacredness
title: Elementary Forms

text: in its first form. By concentrating itself almost entirely in certain
title: Elementary Forms

text: determined moments, the collective life has been able to attain its
title: Elementary Forms

text: greatest intensity and efficacy, and consequently to give men a more
title: Elementary Forms

text: active sentiment of the double existence they lead and of the double
title: Elementary Forms

text: nature in which they participate.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But this explanation is still incomplete. We have shown how the clan, by
title: Elementary Forms

text: the manner in which it acts upon its members, awakens within them the
title: Elementary Forms

text: idea of external forces which dominate them and exalt them; but we must
title: Elementary Forms

text: still demand how it happens that these forces are thought of under the
title: Elementary Forms

text: form of totems, that is to say, in the shape of an animal or plant.
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is because this animal or plant has given its name to the clan and
title: Elementary Forms

text: serves it as emblem. In fact, it is a well-known law that the sentiments
title: Elementary Forms

text: aroused in us by something spontaneously attach themselves to the symbol
title: Elementary Forms

text: which represents them. For us, black is a sign of mourning; it also
title: Elementary Forms

text: suggests sad impressions and ideas. This transference of sentiments
title: Elementary Forms

text: comes simply from the fact that the idea of a thing and the idea of its
title: Elementary Forms

text: symbol are closely united in our minds; the result is that the emotions
title: Elementary Forms

text: provoked by the one extend contagiously to the other. But this
title: Elementary Forms

text: contagion, which takes place in every case to a certain degree, is much
title: Elementary Forms

text: more complete and more marked when the symbol is something simple,
title: Elementary Forms

text: definite and easily representable, while the thing itself, owing to its
title: Elementary Forms

text: dimensions, the number of its parts and the complexity of their
title: Elementary Forms

text: arrangement, is difficult to hold in the mind. For we are unable to
title: Elementary Forms

text: consider an abstract entity, which we can represent only laboriously and
title: Elementary Forms

text: confusedly, the source of the strong sentiments which we feel. We cannot
title: Elementary Forms

text: explain them to ourselves except by connecting them to some concrete
title: Elementary Forms

text: object of whose reality we are vividly aware. Then if the thing itself
title: Elementary Forms

text: does not fulfil this condition, it cannot serve as the accepted basis of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the sentiments felt, even though it may be what really aroused them.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Then some sign takes its place; it is to this that we connect the
title: Elementary Forms

text: emotions it excites. It is this which is loved, feared, respected; it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: to this that we are grateful; it is for this that we sacrifice
title: Elementary Forms

text: ourselves. The soldier who dies for his flag, dies for his country; but
title: Elementary Forms

text: as a matter of fact, in his own consciousness, it is the flag that has
title: Elementary Forms

text: the first place. It sometimes happens that this even directly determines
title: Elementary Forms

text: action. Whether one isolated standard remains in the hands of the enemy
title: Elementary Forms

text: or not does not determine the fate of the country, yet the soldier
title: Elementary Forms

text: allows himself to be killed to regain it. He loses sight of the fact
title: Elementary Forms

text: that the flag is only a sign, and that it has no value in itself, but
title: Elementary Forms

text: only brings to mind the reality that it represents; it is treated as if
title: Elementary Forms

text: it were this reality itself.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Now the totem is the flag of the clan. It is therefore natural that the
title: Elementary Forms

text: impressions aroused by the clan in individual minds--impressions of
title: Elementary Forms

text: dependence and of increased vitality--should fix themselves to the idea
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the totem rather than that of the clan: for the clan is too complex a
title: Elementary Forms

text: reality to be represented clearly in all its complex unity by such
title: Elementary Forms

text: rudimentary intelligences. More than that, the primitive does not even
title: Elementary Forms

text: see that these impressions come to him from the group. He does not know
title: Elementary Forms

text: that the coming together of a number of men associated in the same life
title: Elementary Forms

text: results in disengaging new energies, which transform each of them. All
title: Elementary Forms

text: that he knows is that he is raised above himself and that he sees a
title: Elementary Forms

text: different life from the one he ordinarily leads. However, he must
title: Elementary Forms

text: connect these sensations to some external object as their cause. Now
title: Elementary Forms

text: what does he see about him? On every side those things which appeal to
title: Elementary Forms

text: his senses and strike his imagination are the numerous images of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: totem. They are the waninga and the nurtunja, which are symbols of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacred being. They are churinga and bull-roarers, upon which are
title: Elementary Forms

text: generally carved combinations of lines having the same significance.
title: Elementary Forms

text: They are the decorations covering the different parts of his body,
title: Elementary Forms

text: which are totemic marks. How could this image, repeated everywhere and
title: Elementary Forms

text: in all sorts of forms, fail to stand out with exceptional relief in his
title: Elementary Forms

text: mind? Placed thus in the centre of the scene, it becomes representative.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The sentiments experienced fix themselves upon it, for it is the only
title: Elementary Forms

text: concrete object upon which they can fix themselves. It continues to
title: Elementary Forms

text: bring them to mind and to evoke them even after the assembly has
title: Elementary Forms

text: dissolved, for it survives the assembly, being carved upon the
title: Elementary Forms

text: instruments of the cult, upon the sides of rocks, upon bucklers, etc. By
title: Elementary Forms

text: it, the emotions experienced are perpetually sustained and revived.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Everything happens just as if they inspired them directly. It is still
title: Elementary Forms

text: more natural to attribute them to it for, since they are common to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: group, they can be associated only with something that is equally common
title: Elementary Forms

text: to all. Now the totemic emblem is the only thing satisfying this
title: Elementary Forms

text: condition. By definition, it is common to all. During the ceremony, it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is the centre of all regards. While generations change, it remains the
title: Elementary Forms

text: same; it is the permanent element of the social life. So it is from it
title: Elementary Forms

text: that those mysterious forces seem to emanate with which men feel that
title: Elementary Forms

text: they are related, and thus they have been led to represent these forces
title: Elementary Forms

text: under the form of the animate or inanimate being whose name the clan
title: Elementary Forms

text: bears.
title: Elementary Forms

text: When this point is once established, we are in a position to understand
title: Elementary Forms

text: all that is essential in the totemic beliefs.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Since religious force is nothing other than the collective and anonymous
title: Elementary Forms

text: force of the clan, and since this can be represented in the mind only in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the form of the totem, the totemic emblem is like the visible body of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the god. Therefore, it is from it that those kindly or dreadful actions
title: Elementary Forms

text: seem to emanate, which the cult seeks to provoke or prevent;
title: Elementary Forms

text: consequently, it is to it that the cult is addressed. This is the
title: Elementary Forms

text: explanation of why it holds the first place in the series of sacred
title: Elementary Forms

text: things.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But the clan, like every other sort of society, can live only in and
title: Elementary Forms

text: through the individual consciousnesses that compose it. So if religious
title: Elementary Forms

text: force, in so far as it is conceived as incorporated in the totemic
title: Elementary Forms

text: emblem, appears to be outside of the individuals and to be endowed with
title: Elementary Forms

text: a sort of transcendence over them, it, like the clan of which it is the
title: Elementary Forms

text: symbol, can be realized only in and through them; in this sense, it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: imminent in them and they necessarily represent it as such. They feel it
title: Elementary Forms

text: present and active within them, for, it is this which raises them to a
title: Elementary Forms

text: superior life. This is why men have believed that they contain within
title: Elementary Forms

text: them a principle comparable to the one residing in the totem, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: consequently, why they have attributed a sacred character to themselves,
title: Elementary Forms

text: but one less marked than that of the emblem. It is because the emblem
title: Elementary Forms

text: is the pre-eminent source of the religious life; the man participates in
title: Elementary Forms

text: it only indirectly, as he is well aware; he takes into account the fact
title: Elementary Forms

text: that the force that transports him into the world of sacred things is
title: Elementary Forms

text: not inherent in him, but comes to him from the outside.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But for still another reason, the animals or vegetables of the totemic
title: Elementary Forms

text: species should have the same character, and even to a higher degree. If
title: Elementary Forms

text: the totemic principle is nothing else than the clan, it is the clan
title: Elementary Forms

text: thought of under the material form of the totemic emblem; now this form
title: Elementary Forms

text: is also that of the concrete beings whose name the clan bears. Owing to
title: Elementary Forms

text: this resemblance, they could not fail to evoke sentiments analogous to
title: Elementary Forms

text: those aroused by the emblem itself. Since the latter is the object of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious respect, they too should inspire respect of the same sort and
title: Elementary Forms

text: appear to be sacred. Having external forms so nearly identical, it would
title: Elementary Forms

text: be impossible for the native not to attribute to them forces of the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: nature. It is therefore forbidden to kill or eat the totemic animal,
title: Elementary Forms

text: since its flesh is believed to have the positive virtues resulting from
title: Elementary Forms

text: the rites; it is because it resembles the emblem of the clan, that is to
title: Elementary Forms

text: say, it is in its own image. And since the animal naturally resembles
title: Elementary Forms

text: the emblem more than the man does, it is placed on a superior rank in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the hierarchy of sacred things. Between these two beings there is
title: Elementary Forms

text: undoubtedly a close relationship, for they both partake of the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: essence: both incarnate something of the totemic principle. However,
title: Elementary Forms

text: since the principle itself is conceived under an animal form, the animal
title: Elementary Forms

text: seems to incarnate it more fully than the man. Therefore, if men
title: Elementary Forms

text: consider it and treat it as a brother, it is at least as an elder
title: Elementary Forms

text: brother.[707]
title: Elementary Forms

text: But even if the totemic principle has its preferred seat in a determined
title: Elementary Forms

text: species of animal or vegetable, it cannot remain localized there. A
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacred character is to a high degree contagious;[708] it therefore
title: Elementary Forms

text: spreads out from the totemic being to everything that is closely or
title: Elementary Forms

text: remotely connected with it. The religious sentiments inspired by the
title: Elementary Forms

text: animal are communicated to the substances upon which it is nourished and
title: Elementary Forms

text: which serve to make or remake its flesh and blood, to the things that
title: Elementary Forms

text: resemble it, and to the different beings with which it has constant
title: Elementary Forms

text: relations. Thus, little by little, sub-totems are attached to the totems
title: Elementary Forms

text: and from the cosmological systems expressed by the primitive
title: Elementary Forms

text: classifications. At last, the whole world is divided up among the
title: Elementary Forms

text: totemic principles of each tribe.
title: Elementary Forms

text: We are now able to explain the origin of the ambiguity of religious
title: Elementary Forms

text: forces as they appear in history, and how they are physical as well as
title: Elementary Forms

text: human, moral as well as material. They are moral powers because they are
title: Elementary Forms

text: made up entirely of the impressions this moral being, the group, arouses
title: Elementary Forms

text: in those other moral beings, its individual members; they do not
title: Elementary Forms

text: translate the manner in which physical things affect our senses, but the
title: Elementary Forms

text: way in which the collective consciousness acts upon individual
title: Elementary Forms

text: consciousnesses. Their authority is only one form of the moral
title: Elementary Forms

text: ascendancy of society over its members. But, on the other hand, since
title: Elementary Forms

text: they are conceived of under material forms, they could not fail to be
title: Elementary Forms

text: regarded as closely related to material things.[709] Therefore they
title: Elementary Forms

text: dominate the two worlds. Their residence is in men, but at the same time
title: Elementary Forms

text: they are the vital principles of things. They animate minds and
title: Elementary Forms

text: discipline them, but it is also they who make plants grow and animals
title: Elementary Forms

text: reproduce. It is this double nature which has enabled religion to be
title: Elementary Forms

text: like the womb from which come all the leading germs of human
title: Elementary Forms

text: civilization. Since it has been made to embrace all of reality, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: physical world as well as the moral one, the forces that move bodies as
title: Elementary Forms

text: well as those that move minds have been conceived in a religious form.
title: Elementary Forms

text: That is how the most diverse methods and practices, both those that make
title: Elementary Forms

text: possible the continuation of the moral life (law, morals, beaux-arts)
title: Elementary Forms

text: and those serving the material life (the natural, technical and
title: Elementary Forms

text: practical sciences), are either directly or indirectly derived from
title: Elementary Forms

text: religion.[710]
title: Elementary Forms

text: IV
title: Elementary Forms

text: The first religious conceptions have often been attributed to feelings
title: Elementary Forms

text: of weakness and dependence, of fear and anguish which seized men when
title: Elementary Forms

text: they came into contact with the world. Being the victims of nightmares
title: Elementary Forms

text: of which they were themselves the creators, they believed themselves
title: Elementary Forms

text: surrounded by hostile and redoubtable powers which their rites sought to
title: Elementary Forms

text: appease. We have now shown that the first religions were of a wholly
title: Elementary Forms

text: different origin. The famous formula _Primus in orbe deos fecit timor_
title: Elementary Forms

text: is in no way justified by the facts. The primitive does not regard his
title: Elementary Forms

text: gods as foreigners, enemies or thoroughly and necessarily malevolent
title: Elementary Forms

text: beings whose favours he must acquire at any price; quite on the
title: Elementary Forms

text: contrary, they are rather friends, kindred or natural protectors for
title: Elementary Forms

text: him. Are these not the names he gives to the beings of the totemic
title: Elementary Forms

text: species? The power to which the cult is addressed is not represented as
title: Elementary Forms

text: soaring high above him and overwhelming him by its superiority; on the
title: Elementary Forms

text: contrary, it is very near to him and confers upon him very useful powers
title: Elementary Forms

text: which he could never acquire by himself. Perhaps the deity has never
title: Elementary Forms

text: been nearer to men than at this period of history, when it is present in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the things filling their immediate environment and is, in part, imminent
title: Elementary Forms

text: in himself. In fine, the sentiments at the root of totemism are those of
title: Elementary Forms

text: happy confidence rather than of terror and compression. If we set aside
title: Elementary Forms

text: the funeral rites--the sober side of every religion--we find the totemic
title: Elementary Forms

text: cult celebrated in the midst of songs, dances and dramatic
title: Elementary Forms

text: representations. As we shall see, cruel expiations are relatively rare;
title: Elementary Forms

text: even the painful and obligatory mutilations of the initiations are not
title: Elementary Forms

text: of this character. The terrible and jealous gods appear but slowly in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the religious evolution. This is because primitive societies are not
title: Elementary Forms

text: those huge Leviathans which overwhelm a man by the enormity of their
title: Elementary Forms

text: power and place him under a severe discipline;[711] he gives himself up
title: Elementary Forms

text: to them spontaneously and without resistance. As the social soul is then
title: Elementary Forms

text: made up of only a small number of ideas and sentiments, it easily
title: Elementary Forms

text: becomes wholly incarnate in each individual consciousness. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: individual carries it all inside of him; it is a part of him and
title: Elementary Forms

text: consequently, when he gives himself up to the impulses inspired by it,
title: Elementary Forms

text: he does not feel that he is giving way before compulsion, but that he is
title: Elementary Forms

text: going where his nature calls him.[712]
title: Elementary Forms

text: This way of understanding the origins of religious thought escapes the
title: Elementary Forms

text: objections raised against the most accredited classical theories.
title: Elementary Forms

text: We have seen how the naturists and animists pretend to construct the
title: Elementary Forms

text: idea of sacred beings out of the sensations evoked in us by different
title: Elementary Forms

text: phenomena of the physical or biological order, and we have shown how
title: Elementary Forms

text: this enterprise is impossible and even self-contradictory. Nothing is
title: Elementary Forms

text: worth nothing. The impressions produced in us by the physical world can,
title: Elementary Forms

text: by definition, contain nothing that surpasses this world. Out of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: visible, only the visible can be made; out of that which is heard, we
title: Elementary Forms

text: cannot make something not heard. Then to explain how the idea of
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacredness has been able to take form under these conditions, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: majority of the theorists have been obliged to admit that men have
title: Elementary Forms

text: superimposed upon reality, such as it is given by observation, an unreal
title: Elementary Forms

text: world, constructed entirely out of the fantastic images which agitate
title: Elementary Forms

text: his mind during a dream, or else out of the frequently monstrous
title: Elementary Forms

text: aberrations produced by the mythological imagination under the
title: Elementary Forms

text: bewitching but deceiving influence of language. But it remained
title: Elementary Forms

text: incomprehensible that humanity should have remained obstinate in these
title: Elementary Forms

text: errors through the ages, for experience should have very quickly proven
title: Elementary Forms

text: them false.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But from our point of view, these difficulties disappear. Religion
title: Elementary Forms

text: ceases to be an inexplicable hallucination and takes a foothold in
title: Elementary Forms

text: reality. In fact, we can say that the believer is not deceived when he
title: Elementary Forms

text: believes in the existence of a moral power upon which he depends and
title: Elementary Forms

text: from which he receives all that is best in himself: this power exists,
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is society. When the Australian is carried outside himself and feels
title: Elementary Forms

text: a new life flowing within him whose intensity surprises him, he is not
title: Elementary Forms

text: the dupe of an illusion; this exaltation is real and is really the
title: Elementary Forms

text: effect of forces outside of and superior to the individual. It is true
title: Elementary Forms

text: that he is wrong in thinking that this increase of vitality is the work
title: Elementary Forms

text: of a power in the form of some animal or plant. But this error is merely
title: Elementary Forms

text: in regard to the letter of the symbol by which this being is represented
title: Elementary Forms

text: to the mind and the external appearance which the imagination has given
title: Elementary Forms

text: it, and not in regard to the fact of its existence. Behind these figures
title: Elementary Forms

text: and metaphors, be they gross or refined, there is a concrete and living
title: Elementary Forms

text: reality. Thus religion acquires a meaning and a reasonableness that the
title: Elementary Forms

text: most intransigent rationalist cannot misunderstand. Its primary object
title: Elementary Forms

text: is not to give men a representation of the physical world; for if that
title: Elementary Forms

text: were its essential task, we could not understand how it has been able to
title: Elementary Forms

text: survive, for, on this side, it is scarcely more than a fabric of errors.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Before all, it is a system of ideas with which the individuals represent
title: Elementary Forms

text: to themselves the society of which they are members, and the obscure but
title: Elementary Forms

text: intimate relations which they have with it. This is its primary
title: Elementary Forms

text: function; and though metaphorical and symbolic, this representation is
title: Elementary Forms

text: not unfaithful. Quite on the contrary, it translates everything
title: Elementary Forms

text: essential in the relations which are to be explained: for it is an
title: Elementary Forms

text: eternal truth that outside of us there exists something greater than us,
title: Elementary Forms

text: with which we enter into communion.
title: Elementary Forms

text: That is why we can rest assured in advance that the practices of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: cult, whatever they may be, are something more than movements without
title: Elementary Forms

text: importance and gestures without efficacy. By the mere fact that their
title: Elementary Forms

text: apparent function is to strengthen the bonds attaching the believer to
title: Elementary Forms

text: his god, they at the same time really strengthen the bonds attaching the
title: Elementary Forms

text: individual to the society of which he is a member, since the god is only
title: Elementary Forms

text: a figurative expression of the society. We are even able to understand
title: Elementary Forms

text: how the fundamental truth thus contained in religion has been able to
title: Elementary Forms

text: compensate for the secondary errors which it almost necessarily implies,
title: Elementary Forms

text: and how believers have consequently been restrained from tearing
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves off from it, in spite of the misunderstandings which must
title: Elementary Forms

text: result from these errors. It is undeniably true that the recipes which
title: Elementary Forms

text: it recommends that men use to act upon things are generally found to be
title: Elementary Forms

text: ineffective. But these checks can have no profound influence, for they
title: Elementary Forms

text: do not touch religion in its fundamentals.[713]
title: Elementary Forms

text: However, it may be objected that even according to this hypothesis,
title: Elementary Forms

text: religion remains the object of a certain delirium. What other name can
title: Elementary Forms

text: we give to that state when, after a collective effervescence, men
title: Elementary Forms

text: believe themselves transported into an entirely different world from the
title: Elementary Forms

text: one they have before their eyes?
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is certainly true that religious life cannot attain a certain degree
title: Elementary Forms

text: of intensity without implying a psychical exaltation not far removed
title: Elementary Forms

text: from delirium. That is why the prophets, the founders of religions, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: great saints, in a word, the men whose religious consciousness is
title: Elementary Forms

text: exceptionally sensitive, very frequently give signs of an excessive
title: Elementary Forms

text: nervousness that is even pathological: these physiological defects
title: Elementary Forms

text: predestined them to great religious roles. The ritual use of
title: Elementary Forms

text: intoxicating liquors is to be explained in the same way.[714] Of course
title: Elementary Forms

text: this does not mean that an ardent religious faith is necessarily the
title: Elementary Forms

text: fruit of the drunkenness and mental derangement which accompany it; but
title: Elementary Forms

text: as experience soon informed people of the similarities between the
title: Elementary Forms

text: mentality of a delirious person and that of a seer, they sought to open
title: Elementary Forms

text: a way to the second by artificially exciting the first. But if, for this
title: Elementary Forms

text: reason, it may be said that religion is not without a certain delirium,
title: Elementary Forms

text: it must be added that this delirium, if it has the causes which we have
title: Elementary Forms

text: attributed to it, _is well-founded_. The images out of which it is made
title: Elementary Forms

text: are not pure illusions like those the naturists and animists put at the
title: Elementary Forms

text: basis of religion; they correspond to something in reality. Of course it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is only natural that the moral forces they express should be unable to
title: Elementary Forms

text: affect the human mind powerfully without pulling it outside itself and
title: Elementary Forms

text: without plunging it into a state that may be called _ecstatic_, provided
title: Elementary Forms

text: that the word be taken in its etymological sense ([Greek: ekstasis]);
title: Elementary Forms

text: but it does not follow that they are imaginary. Quite on the contrary,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the mental agitation they cause bears witness to their reality. It is
title: Elementary Forms

text: merely one more proof that a very intense social life always does a sort
title: Elementary Forms

text: of violence to the organism, as well as to the individual consciousness,
title: Elementary Forms

text: which interferes with its normal functioning. Therefore it can last only
title: Elementary Forms

text: a limited length of time.[715]
