title: Elementary Forms

text: Moreover, if we give the name delirious to every state in which the mind
title: Elementary Forms

text: adds to the immediate data given by the senses and projects its own
title: Elementary Forms

text: sentiments and feelings into things, then nearly every collective
title: Elementary Forms

text: representation is in a sense delirious; religious beliefs are only one
title: Elementary Forms

text: particular case of a very general law. Our whole social environment
title: Elementary Forms

text: seems to us to be filled with forces which really exist only in our own
title: Elementary Forms

text: minds. We know what the flag is for the soldier; in itself, it is only a
title: Elementary Forms

text: piece of cloth. Human blood is only an organic liquid, but even to-day
title: Elementary Forms

text: we cannot see it flowing without feeling a violent emotion which its
title: Elementary Forms

text: physico-chemical properties cannot explain. From the physical point of
title: Elementary Forms

text: view, a man is nothing more than a system of cells, or from the mental
title: Elementary Forms

text: point of view, than a system of representations; in either case, he
title: Elementary Forms

text: differs only in degree from animals. Yet society conceives him, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: obliges us to conceive him, as invested with a character _sui generis_
title: Elementary Forms

text: that isolates him, holds at a distance all rash encroachments and, in a
title: Elementary Forms

text: word, imposes respect. This dignity which puts him into a class by
title: Elementary Forms

text: himself appears to us as one of his distinctive attributes, although we
title: Elementary Forms

text: can find nothing in the empirical nature of man which justifies it. A
title: Elementary Forms

text: cancelled postage stamp may be worth a fortune; but surely this value is
title: Elementary Forms

text: in no way implied in its natural properties. In a sense, our
title: Elementary Forms

text: representation of the external world is undoubtedly a mere fabric of
title: Elementary Forms

text: hallucinations, for the odours, tastes and colours that we put into
title: Elementary Forms

text: bodies are not really there, or at least, they are not such as we
title: Elementary Forms

text: perceive them. However, our olfactory, gustatory and visual sensations
title: Elementary Forms

text: continue to correspond to certain objective states of the things
title: Elementary Forms

text: represented; they express in their way the properties, either of
title: Elementary Forms

text: material particles or of ether waves, which certainly have their origin
title: Elementary Forms

text: in the bodies which we perceive as fragrant, sapid or coloured. But
title: Elementary Forms

text: collective representations very frequently attribute to the things to
title: Elementary Forms

text: which they are attached qualities which do not exist under any form or
title: Elementary Forms

text: to any degree. Out of the commonest object, they can make a most
title: Elementary Forms

text: powerful sacred being.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Yet the powers which are thus conferred, though purely ideal, act as
title: Elementary Forms

text: though they were real; they determine the conduct of men with the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: degree of necessity as physical forces. The Arunta who has been rubbed
title: Elementary Forms

text: with his churinga feels himself stronger; he is stronger. If he has
title: Elementary Forms

text: eaten the flesh of an animal which, though perfectly healthy, is
title: Elementary Forms

text: forbidden to him, he will feel himself sick, and may die of it. Surely
title: Elementary Forms

text: the soldier who falls while defending his flag does not believe that he
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacrifices himself for a bit of cloth. This is all because social
title: Elementary Forms

text: thought, owing to the imperative authority that is in it, has an
title: Elementary Forms

text: efficacy that individual thought could never have; by the power which it
title: Elementary Forms

text: has over our minds, it can make us see things in whatever light it
title: Elementary Forms

text: pleases; it adds to reality or deducts from it according to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: circumstances. Thus there is one division of nature where the formula of
title: Elementary Forms

text: idealism is applicable almost to the letter: this is the social kingdom.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Here more than anywhere else, the idea is the reality. Even in this
title: Elementary Forms

text: case, of course, idealism is not true without modification. We can never
title: Elementary Forms

text: escape the duality of our nature and free ourselves completely from
title: Elementary Forms

text: physical necessities: in order to express our own ideas to ourselves, it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is necessary, as has been shown above, that we fix them upon material
title: Elementary Forms

text: things which symbolize them. But here the part of matter is reduced to a
title: Elementary Forms

text: minimum. The object serving as support for the idea is not much in
title: Elementary Forms

text: comparison with the ideal superstructure, beneath which it disappears,
title: Elementary Forms

text: and also, it counts for nothing in the superstructure. This is what that
title: Elementary Forms

text: pseudo-delirium consists in, which we find at the bottom of so many
title: Elementary Forms

text: collective representations: it is only a form of this essential
title: Elementary Forms

text: idealism.[716] So it is not properly called a delirium, for the ideas
title: Elementary Forms

text: thus objectified are well founded, not in the nature of the material
title: Elementary Forms

text: things upon which they settle themselves, but in the nature of society.
title: Elementary Forms

text: We are now able to understand how the totemic principle, and in
title: Elementary Forms

text: general, every religious force, comes to be outside of the object in
title: Elementary Forms

text: which it resides.[717] It is because the idea of it is in no way made up
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the impressions directly produced by this thing upon our senses or
title: Elementary Forms

text: minds. Religious force is only the sentiment inspired by the group in
title: Elementary Forms

text: its members, but projected outside of the consciousnesses that
title: Elementary Forms

text: experience them, and objectified. To be objectified, they are fixed upon
title: Elementary Forms

text: some object which thus becomes sacred; but any object might fulfil this
title: Elementary Forms

text: function. In principle, there are none whose nature predestines them to
title: Elementary Forms

text: it to the exclusion of all others; but also there are none that are
title: Elementary Forms

text: necessarily impossible.[718] Everything depends upon the circumstances
title: Elementary Forms

text: which lead the sentiment creating religious ideas to establish itself
title: Elementary Forms

text: here or there, upon this point or upon that one. Therefore, the sacred
title: Elementary Forms

text: character assumed by an object is not implied in the intrinsic
title: Elementary Forms

text: properties of this latter: _it is added to them_. The world of religious
title: Elementary Forms

text: things is not one particular aspect of empirical nature; _it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: superimposed upon it_.
title: Elementary Forms

text: This conception of the religious, finally, allows us to explain an
title: Elementary Forms

text: important principle found at the bottom of a multitude of myths and
title: Elementary Forms

text: rites, and which may be stated thus: when a sacred thing is subdivided,
title: Elementary Forms

text: each of its parts remains equal to the thing itself. In other words, as
title: Elementary Forms

text: far as religious thought is concerned, the part is equal to the whole;
title: Elementary Forms

text: it has the same powers, the same efficacy. The debris of a relic has the
title: Elementary Forms

text: same virtue as a relic in good condition. The smallest drop of blood
title: Elementary Forms

text: contains the same active principle as the whole thing. The soul, as we
title: Elementary Forms

text: shall see, may be broken up into nearly as many pieces as there are
title: Elementary Forms

text: organs or tissues in the organism; each of these partial souls is worth
title: Elementary Forms

text: a whole soul. This conception would be inexplicable if the sacredness of
title: Elementary Forms

text: something were due to the constituent properties of the thing itself;
title: Elementary Forms

text: for in that case, it should vary with this thing, increasing and
title: Elementary Forms

text: decreasing with it. But if the virtues it is believed to possess are not
title: Elementary Forms

text: intrinsic in it, and if they come from certain sentiments which it
title: Elementary Forms

text: brings to mind and symbolizes, though these originate outside of it,
title: Elementary Forms

text: then, since it has no need of determined dimensions to play this role of
title: Elementary Forms

text: reminder, it will have the same value whether it is entire or not. Since
title: Elementary Forms

text: the part makes us think of the whole, it evokes the same sentiments as
title: Elementary Forms

text: the whole. A mere fragment of the flag represents the fatherland just as
title: Elementary Forms

text: well as the flag itself: so it is sacred in the same way and to the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: degree.[719]
title: Elementary Forms

text: V
title: Elementary Forms

text: But if this theory of totemism has enabled us to explain the most
title: Elementary Forms

text: characteristic beliefs of this religion, it rests upon a fact not yet
title: Elementary Forms

text: explained. When the idea of the totem, the emblem of the clan, is given,
title: Elementary Forms

text: all the rest follows; but we must still investigate how this idea has
title: Elementary Forms

text: been formed. This is a double question and may be subdivided as follows:
title: Elementary Forms

text: What has led the clan to choose an emblem? and why have these emblems
title: Elementary Forms

text: been borrowed from the animal and vegetable worlds, and particularly
title: Elementary Forms

text: from the former?
title: Elementary Forms

text: That an emblem is useful as a rallying-centre for any sort of a group it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is superfluous to point out. By expressing the social unity in a
title: Elementary Forms

text: material form, it makes this more obvious to all, and for that very
title: Elementary Forms

text: reason the use of emblematic symbols must have spread quickly when once
title: Elementary Forms

text: thought of. But more than that, this idea should spontaneously arise out
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the conditions of common life; for the emblem is not merely a
title: Elementary Forms

text: convenient process for clarifying the sentiment society has of itself:
title: Elementary Forms

text: it also serves to create this sentiment; it is one of its constituent
title: Elementary Forms

text: elements.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In fact, if left to themselves, individual consciousnesses are closed to
title: Elementary Forms

text: each other; they can communicate only by means of signs which express
title: Elementary Forms

text: their internal states. If the communication established between them is
title: Elementary Forms

text: to become a real communion, that is to say, a fusion of all particular
title: Elementary Forms

text: sentiments into one common sentiment, the signs expressing them must
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves be fused into one single and unique resultant. It is the
title: Elementary Forms

text: appearance of this that informs individuals that they are in harmony and
title: Elementary Forms

text: makes them conscious of their moral unity. It is by uttering the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: cry, pronouncing the same word, or performing the same gesture in regard
title: Elementary Forms

text: to some object that they become and feel themselves to be in unison. It
title: Elementary Forms

text: is true that individual representations also cause reactions in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: organism that are not without importance; however, they can be thought
title: Elementary Forms

text: of apart from these physical reactions which accompany them or follow
title: Elementary Forms

text: them, but which do not constitute them. But it is quite another matter
title: Elementary Forms

text: with collective representations. They presuppose that minds act and
title: Elementary Forms

text: react upon one another; they are the product of these actions and
title: Elementary Forms

text: reactions which are themselves possible only through material
title: Elementary Forms

text: intermediaries. These latter do not confine themselves to revealing the
title: Elementary Forms

text: mental state with which they are associated; they aid in creating it.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Individual minds cannot come in contact and communicate with each other
title: Elementary Forms

text: except by coming out of themselves; but they cannot do this except by
title: Elementary Forms

text: movements. So it is the homogeneity of these movements that gives the
title: Elementary Forms

text: group consciousness of itself and consequently makes it exist. When
title: Elementary Forms

text: this homogeneity is once established and these movements have once taken
title: Elementary Forms

text: a stereotyped form, they serve to symbolize the corresponding
title: Elementary Forms

text: representations. But they symbolize them only because they have aided in
title: Elementary Forms

text: forming them.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Moreover, without symbols, social sentiments could have only a
title: Elementary Forms

text: precarious existence. Though very strong as long as men are together and
title: Elementary Forms

text: influence each other reciprocally, they exist only in the form of
title: Elementary Forms

text: recollections after the assembly has ended, and when left to themselves,
title: Elementary Forms

text: these become feebler and feebler; for since the group is now no longer
title: Elementary Forms

text: present and active, individual temperaments easily regain the upper
title: Elementary Forms

text: hand. The violent passions which may have been released in the heart of
title: Elementary Forms

text: a crowd fall away and are extinguished when this is dissolved, and men
title: Elementary Forms

text: ask themselves with astonishment how they could ever have been so
title: Elementary Forms

text: carried away from their normal character. But if the movements by which
title: Elementary Forms

text: these sentiments are expressed are connected with something that
title: Elementary Forms

text: endures, the sentiments themselves become more durable. These other
title: Elementary Forms

text: things are constantly bringing them to mind and arousing them; it is as
title: Elementary Forms

text: though the cause which excited them in the first place continued to act.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Thus these systems of emblems, which are necessary if society is to
title: Elementary Forms

text: become conscious of itself, are no less indispensable for assuring the
title: Elementary Forms

text: continuation of this consciousness.
title: Elementary Forms

text: So we must refrain from regarding these symbols as simple artifices, as
title: Elementary Forms

text: sorts of labels attached to representations already made, in order to
title: Elementary Forms

text: make them more manageable: they are an integral part of them. Even the
title: Elementary Forms

text: fact that collective sentiments are thus attached to things completely
title: Elementary Forms

text: foreign to them is not purely conventional: it illustrates under a
title: Elementary Forms

text: conventional form a real characteristic of social facts, that is, their
title: Elementary Forms

text: transcendence over individual minds. In fact, it is known that social
title: Elementary Forms

text: phenomena are born, not in individuals, but in the group. Whatever part
title: Elementary Forms

text: we may take in their origin, each of us receives them from without.[720]
title: Elementary Forms

text: So when we represent them to ourselves as emanating from a material
title: Elementary Forms

text: object, we do not completely misunderstand their nature. Of course they
title: Elementary Forms

text: do not come from the specific thing to which we connect them, but
title: Elementary Forms

text: nevertheless, it is true that their origin is outside of us. If the
title: Elementary Forms

text: moral force sustaining the believer does not come from the idol he
title: Elementary Forms

text: adores or the emblem he venerates, still it is from outside of him, as
title: Elementary Forms

text: he is well aware. The objectivity of its symbol only translates its
title: Elementary Forms

text: externalness.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Thus social life, in all its aspects and in every period of its history,
title: Elementary Forms

text: is made possible only by a vast symbolism. The material emblems and
title: Elementary Forms

text: figurative representations with which we are more especially concerned
title: Elementary Forms

text: in our present study, are one form of this; but there are many others.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Collective sentiments can just as well become incarnate in persons or
title: Elementary Forms

text: formulae: some formulae are flags, while there are persons, either real or
title: Elementary Forms

text: mythical, who are symbols. But there is one sort of emblem which should
title: Elementary Forms

text: make an early appearance without reflection or calculation: this is
title: Elementary Forms

text: tattooing. Indeed, well-known facts demonstrate that it is produced
title: Elementary Forms

text: almost automatically in certain conditions. When men of an inferior
title: Elementary Forms

text: culture are associated in a common life, they are frequently led, by an
title: Elementary Forms

text: instinctive tendency, as it were, to paint or cut upon the body, images
title: Elementary Forms

text: that bear witness to their common existence. According to a text of
title: Elementary Forms

text: Procopius, the early Christians printed on their skin the name of Christ
title: Elementary Forms

text: or the sign of the cross;[721] for a long time, the groups of pilgrims
title: Elementary Forms

text: going to Palestine were also tattooed on the arm or wrist with designs
title: Elementary Forms

text: representing the cross or the monogram of Christ.[722] This same usage
title: Elementary Forms

text: is also reported among the pilgrims going to certain holy places in
title: Elementary Forms

text: Italy.[723] A curious case of spontaneous tattooing is given by
title: Elementary Forms

text: Lombroso: twenty young men in an Italian college, when on the point of
title: Elementary Forms

text: separating, decorated themselves with tattoos recording, in various
title: Elementary Forms

text: ways, the years they had spent together.[724] The same fact has
title: Elementary Forms

text: frequently been observed among the soldiers in the same barracks, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: sailors in the same boat, or the prisoners in the same jail.[725] It
title: Elementary Forms

text: will be understood that especially where methods are still rudimentary,
title: Elementary Forms

text: tattooing should be the most direct and expressive means by which the
title: Elementary Forms

text: communion of minds can be affirmed. The best way of proving to one's
title: Elementary Forms

text: self and to others that one is a member of a certain group is to place a
title: Elementary Forms

text: distinctive mark on the body. The proof that this is the reason for the
title: Elementary Forms

text: existence of the totemic image is the fact, which we have already
title: Elementary Forms

text: mentioned, that it does not seek to reproduce the aspect of the thing it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is supposed to represent. It is made up of lines and points to which a
title: Elementary Forms

text: wholly conventional significance is attributed.[726] Its object is not
title: Elementary Forms

text: to represent or bring to mind a determined object, but to bear witness
title: Elementary Forms

text: to the fact that a certain number of individuals participate in the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: moral life.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Moreover, the clan is a society which is less able than any other to do
title: Elementary Forms

text: without an emblem or symbol, for there is almost no other so lacking in
title: Elementary Forms

text: consistency. The clan cannot be defined by its chief, for if central
title: Elementary Forms

text: authority is not lacking, it is at least uncertain and unstable.[727]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Nor can it be defined by the territory it occupies, for the population,
title: Elementary Forms

text: being nomad,[728] is not closely attached to any special locality. Also,
title: Elementary Forms

text: owing to the exogamic law, husband and wife must be of different totems;
title: Elementary Forms

text: so wherever the totem is transmitted in the maternal line--and this
title: Elementary Forms

text: system of filiation is still the most general one[729]--the children are
title: Elementary Forms

text: of a different clan from their father, though living near to him.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Therefore we find representatives of a number of different clans in each
title: Elementary Forms

text: family, and still more in each locality. The unity of the group is
title: Elementary Forms

text: visible, therefore, only in the collective name borne by all the
title: Elementary Forms

text: members, and in the equally collective emblem reproducing the object
title: Elementary Forms

text: designated by this name. A clan is essentially a reunion of individuals
title: Elementary Forms

text: who bear the same name and rally around the same sign. Take away the
title: Elementary Forms

text: name and the sign which materializes it, and the clan is no longer
title: Elementary Forms

text: representable. Since the group is possible only on this condition, both
title: Elementary Forms

text: the institution of the emblem and the part it takes in the life of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: group are thus explained.
title: Elementary Forms

text: It remains to ask why these names and emblems were taken almost
title: Elementary Forms

text: exclusively from the animal and vegetable kingdoms, but especially from
title: Elementary Forms

text: the former.
title: Elementary Forms

text: It seems probable to us that the emblem has played a more important part
title: Elementary Forms

text: than the name. In any case, the written sign still holds a more central
title: Elementary Forms

text: place in the life of the clan to-day than does the spoken sign. Now the
title: Elementary Forms

text: basis of an emblematic image can be found only in something susceptible
title: Elementary Forms

text: of being represented by a design. On the other hand, these things had to
title: Elementary Forms

text: be those with which the men of the clan were the most immediately and
title: Elementary Forms

text: habitually coming in contact. Animals fulfilled this condition to a
title: Elementary Forms

text: pre-eminent degree. For these nations of hunters and fishers, the animal
title: Elementary Forms

text: constituted an essential element of the economic environment. In this
title: Elementary Forms

text: connection plants had only a secondary place for they can hold only a
title: Elementary Forms

text: secondary place as food as long as they are not cultivated. Moreover,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the animal is more closely associated with the life of men than the
title: Elementary Forms

text: plant is, if only because of the natural kinship uniting these two to
title: Elementary Forms

text: each other. On the other hand, the sun, moon and stars are too far away,
title: Elementary Forms

text: they give the effect of belonging to another world.[730] Also, as long
title: Elementary Forms

text: as the constellations were not distinguished and classified, the starry
title: Elementary Forms

text: vault did not offer a sufficient diversity of clearly differentiated
title: Elementary Forms

text: things to be able to mark all the clans and sub-clans of a tribe; but,
title: Elementary Forms

text: on the contrary, the variety of the flora, and especially of the fauna,
title: Elementary Forms

text: was almost inexhaustible. Therefore celestial bodies, in spite of their
title: Elementary Forms

text: brilliancy and the sharp impression they make upon the senses, were
title: Elementary Forms

text: unfitted for the role of totems, while animals and plants seemed
title: Elementary Forms

text: predestined to it.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Ah observation of Strehlow even allows us to state precisely the way in
title: Elementary Forms

text: which these emblems were probably chosen. He says that he has noticed
title: Elementary Forms

text: that the totemic centres are generally situated near a mountain, spring
title: Elementary Forms

text: or gorge where the animals serving as totems to the group gather in
title: Elementary Forms

text: abundance, and he cites a certain number of examples of this fact.[731]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Now these totemic centres are surely the consecrated places where the
title: Elementary Forms

text: meetings of the clan are held. So it seems as though each group had
title: Elementary Forms

text: taken as its insignia the animal or plant that was the commonest in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: vicinity of the place where it had the habit of meeting.[732]
title: Elementary Forms

text: VI
title: Elementary Forms

text: This conception of totemism will give us the explanation of a very
title: Elementary Forms

text: curious trait of human mentality which, even though more marked formerly
title: Elementary Forms

text: than to-day, has not yet disappeared and which, in any case, has been of
title: Elementary Forms

text: considerable importance in the history of human thought. It will furnish
title: Elementary Forms

text: still another occasion for showing how logical evolution is closely
title: Elementary Forms

text: connected with religious evolution and how it, like this latter, depends
title: Elementary Forms

text: upon social conditions.[733]
title: Elementary Forms

text: If there is one truth which appears to be absolutely certain to-day, it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is that beings differing not only in their outward appearance but also
title: Elementary Forms

text: in their most essential properties, such as minerals, plants, animals
title: Elementary Forms

text: and men, cannot be considered equivalent and interchangeable. Long
title: Elementary Forms

text: usage, which scientific culture has still more firmly embedded in our
title: Elementary Forms

text: minds, has taught us to establish barriers between the kingdoms, whose
title: Elementary Forms

text: existence transformism itself does not deny; for though this admits that
title: Elementary Forms

text: life may have arisen from non-living matter and men from animals, still,
title: Elementary Forms

text: it does not fail to recognize the fact that living beings, once formed,
title: Elementary Forms

text: are different from minerals, and men different from animals. Within each
title: Elementary Forms

text: kingdom the same barriers separate the different classes: we cannot
title: Elementary Forms

text: conceive of one mineral having the same distinctive characteristics as
title: Elementary Forms

text: another, or of one animal species having those of another species. But
title: Elementary Forms

text: these distinctions, which seem so natural to us, are in no way
title: Elementary Forms

text: primitive. In the beginning, all the kingdoms are confounded with each
title: Elementary Forms

text: other. Rocks have a sex; they have the power of begetting; the sun, moon
title: Elementary Forms

text: and stars are men or women who feel and express human sentiments, while
title: Elementary Forms

text: men, on the contrary, are thought of as animals or plants. This state of
title: Elementary Forms

text: confusion is found at the basis of all mythologies. Hence comes the
title: Elementary Forms

text: ambiguous character of the beings portrayed in the mythologies; they can
title: Elementary Forms

text: be classified in no definite group, for they participate at the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: time in the most opposed groups. It is also readily admitted that they
title: Elementary Forms

text: can go from one into another; and for a long time men believed that they
title: Elementary Forms

text: were able to explain the origin of things by these transmutations.
title: Elementary Forms

text: That the anthropomorphic instinct, with which the animists have endowed
title: Elementary Forms

text: primitive men, cannot explain their mental condition is shown by the
title: Elementary Forms

text: nature of the confusions of which they are guilty. In fact, these do not
title: Elementary Forms

text: come from the fact that men have immoderately extended the human kingdom
title: Elementary Forms

text: to the point of making all the others enter into it, but from the fact
title: Elementary Forms

text: that they confound the most disparate kingdoms. They have not conceived
title: Elementary Forms

text: the world in their own image any more than they have conceived
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves in the world's image: they have done both at the same time.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Into the idea they have formed of things, they have undoubtedly made
title: Elementary Forms

text: human elements enter; but into the idea they have formed of themselves,
title: Elementary Forms

text: they have made enter elements coming from things.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Yet there is nothing in experience which could suggest these connections
title: Elementary Forms

text: and confusions. As far as the observation of the senses is able to go,
title: Elementary Forms

text: everything is different and disconnected. Nowhere do we really see
title: Elementary Forms

text: beings mixing their natures and metamorphosing themselves into each
title: Elementary Forms

text: other. It is therefore necessary that some exceptionally powerful cause
title: Elementary Forms

text: should have intervened to transfigure reality in such a way as to make
title: Elementary Forms

text: it appear under an aspect that is not really its own.
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is religion that was the agent of this transfiguration; it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious beliefs that have substituted for the world, as it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: perceived by the senses, another different one. This is well shown by
title: Elementary Forms

text: the case of totemism. The fundamental thing in this religion is that the
title: Elementary Forms

text: men of the clan and the different beings whose form the totemic emblems
title: Elementary Forms

text: reproduce pass as being made of the same essence. Now when this belief
title: Elementary Forms

text: was once admitted, the bridge between the different kingdoms was already
title: Elementary Forms

text: built. The man was represented as a sort of animal or plant; the plants
title: Elementary Forms

text: and animals were thought of as the relatives of men, or rather, all
title: Elementary Forms

text: these beings, so different for the senses, were thought of as
title: Elementary Forms

text: participating in a single nature. So this remarkable aptitude for
title: Elementary Forms

text: confusing things that seem to be obviously distinct comes from the fact
title: Elementary Forms

text: that the first forces with which the human intellect has peopled the
title: Elementary Forms

text: world were elaborated by religion. Since these were made up of elements
title: Elementary Forms

text: taken from the different kingdoms, men conceived a principle common to
title: Elementary Forms

text: the most heterogeneous things, which thus became endowed with a sole and
title: Elementary Forms

text: single essence.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But we also know that these religious conceptions are the result of
title: Elementary Forms

text: determined social causes. Since the clan cannot exist without a name and
title: Elementary Forms

text: an emblem, and since this emblem is always before the eyes of men, it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: upon this, and the objects whose image it is, that the sentiments which
title: Elementary Forms

text: society arouses in its members are fixed. Men were thus compelled to
title: Elementary Forms

text: represent the collective force, whose action they felt, in the form of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the thing serving as flag to the group. Therefore, in the idea of this
title: Elementary Forms

text: force were mixed up the most different kingdoms; in one sense, it was
title: Elementary Forms

text: essentially human, since it was made up of human ideas and sentiments;
title: Elementary Forms

text: but at the same time, it could not fail to appear as closely related to
title: Elementary Forms

text: the animate or inanimate beings who gave it its outward form. Moreover,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the cause whose action we observe here is not peculiar to totemism;
title: Elementary Forms

text: there is no society where it is not active. In a general way, a
title: Elementary Forms

text: collective sentiment can become conscious of itself only by being fixed
title: Elementary Forms

text: upon some material object;[734] but by this very fact, it participates
title: Elementary Forms

text: in the nature of this object, and reciprocally, the object participates
title: Elementary Forms

text: in its nature. So it was social necessity which brought about the fusion
title: Elementary Forms

text: of notions appearing distinct at first, and social life has facilitated
title: Elementary Forms

text: this fusion by the great mental effervescences it determines.[735] This
title: Elementary Forms

text: is one more proof that logical understanding is a function of society,
title: Elementary Forms

text: for it takes the forms and attitudes that this latter presses upon it.
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is true that this logic is disconcerting for us. Yet we must be
title: Elementary Forms

text: careful not to depreciate it: howsoever crude it may appear to us, it
title: Elementary Forms

text: has been an aid of the greatest importance in the intellectual evolution
title: Elementary Forms

text: of humanity. In fact, it is through it that the first explanation of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: world has been made possible. Of course the mental habits it implies
title: Elementary Forms

text: prevented men from seeing reality as their senses show it to them; but
title: Elementary Forms

text: as they show it, it has the grave inconvenience of allowing of no
title: Elementary Forms

text: explanation. For to explain is to attach things to each other and to
title: Elementary Forms

text: establish relations between them which make them appear to us as
title: Elementary Forms

text: functions of each other and as vibrating sympathetically according to an
title: Elementary Forms

text: internal law founded in their nature. But sensations, which see nothing
title: Elementary Forms

text: except from the outside, could never make them disclose these relations
title: Elementary Forms

text: and internal bonds; the intellect alone can create the notion of them.
title: Elementary Forms

text: When I learn that A regularly precedes B, my knowledge is increased by a
title: Elementary Forms

text: new fact; but my intelligence is not at all satisfied with a statement
title: Elementary Forms

text: which does not show its reason. I commence to _understand_ only if it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: possible for me to conceive B in a way that makes it appear to me as
title: Elementary Forms

text: something that is not foreign to A, and as united to A by some relation
title: Elementary Forms

text: of kinship. The great service that religions have rendered to thought is
title: Elementary Forms

text: that they have constructed a first representation of what these
title: Elementary Forms

text: relations of kinship between things may be. In the circumstances under
title: Elementary Forms

text: which it was attempted, the enterprise could obviously attain only
title: Elementary Forms

text: precarious results. But then, does it ever attain any that are definite,
title: Elementary Forms

text: and is it not always necessary to reconsider them? And also, it is less
title: Elementary Forms

text: important to succeed than to try. The essential thing was not to leave
title: Elementary Forms

text: the mind enslaved to visible appearances, but to teach it to dominate
title: Elementary Forms

text: them and to connect what the senses separated; for from the moment when
title: Elementary Forms

text: men have an idea that there are internal connections between things,
title: Elementary Forms

text: science and philosophy become possible. Religion opened up the way for
title: Elementary Forms

text: them. But if it has been able to play this part, it is only because it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is a social affair. In order to make a law for the impressions of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: senses and to substitute a new way of representing reality for them,
title: Elementary Forms

text: thought of a new sort had to be founded: this is collective thought. If
title: Elementary Forms

text: this alone has had this efficacy, it is because of the fact that to
title: Elementary Forms

text: create a world of ideals through which the world of experienced
title: Elementary Forms

text: realities would appear transfigured, a super-excitation of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: intellectual forces was necessary, which is possible only in and through
title: Elementary Forms

text: society.
title: Elementary Forms

text: So it is far from true that this mentality has no connection with ours.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Our logic was born of this logic. The explanations of contemporary
title: Elementary Forms

text: science are surer of being objective because they are more methodical
title: Elementary Forms

text: and because they rest on more carefully controlled observations, but
title: Elementary Forms

text: they do not differ in nature from those which satisfy primitive thought.
title: Elementary Forms

text: To-day, as formerly, to explain is to show how one thing participates in
title: Elementary Forms

text: one or several others. It has been said that the participations of this
title: Elementary Forms

text: sort implied by the mythologies violate the principle of contradiction
title: Elementary Forms

text: and that they are by that opposed to those implied by scientific
title: Elementary Forms

text: explanations.[736] Is not the statement that a man is a kangaroo or the
title: Elementary Forms

text: sun a bird, equal to identifying the two with each other? But our manner
title: Elementary Forms

text: of thought is not different when we say of heat that it is a movement,
title: Elementary Forms

text: or of light that it is a vibration of the ether, etc. Every time that we
title: Elementary Forms

text: unite heterogeneous terms by an internal bond, we forcibly identify
title: Elementary Forms

text: contraries. Of course the terms we unite are not those which the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Australian brings together; we choose them according to different
title: Elementary Forms

text: criteria and for different reasons; but the processes by which the mind
title: Elementary Forms

text: puts them in connection do not differ essentially.
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is true that if primitive thought had that sort of general and
title: Elementary Forms

text: systematic indifference to contradictions which has been attributed to
title: Elementary Forms

text: it,[737] it would be in open contradiction on this point with modern
title: Elementary Forms

text: thought, which is always careful to remain consistent with itself. But
title: Elementary Forms

text: we do not believe that it is possible to characterize the mentality of
title: Elementary Forms

text: inferior societies by a single and exclusive inclination for
title: Elementary Forms

text: indistinction. If the primitive confounds things which we distinguish,
title: Elementary Forms

text: he also distinguishes things which we connect together, and he even
title: Elementary Forms

text: conceives these distinctions in the form of sharp and clear-cut
title: Elementary Forms

text: oppositions. Between two things which are classified in two different
title: Elementary Forms

text: phratries, there is not only separation, but even antagonism.[738] For
title: Elementary Forms

text: this reason, the same Australian who confounds the sun and the white
title: Elementary Forms

text: cockatoo, opposes this latter to the black cockatoo as to its contrary.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The two seem to him to belong to two separate classes between which
title: Elementary Forms

text: there is nothing in common. A still more marked opposition is that
title: Elementary Forms

text: existing between sacred things and profane things. They repel and
title: Elementary Forms

text: contradict each other with so much force that the mind refuses to think
title: Elementary Forms

text: of them at the same time. They mutually expel each other from the
title: Elementary Forms

text: consciousness.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Thus between the logic of religious thought and that of scientific
title: Elementary Forms

text: thought there is no abyss. The two are made up of the same elements,
title: Elementary Forms

text: though inequally and differently developed. The special characteristic
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the former seems to be its natural taste for immoderate confusions as
title: Elementary Forms

text: well as sharp contrasts. It is voluntarily excessive in each direction.
title: Elementary Forms

text: When it connects, it confounds; when it distinguishes, it opposes. It
title: Elementary Forms

text: knows no shades and measures, it seeks extremes; it consequently employs
title: Elementary Forms

text: logical mechanisms with a certain awkwardness, but it ignores none of
title: Elementary Forms

text: them.
title: Elementary Forms

text: CHAPTER VIII
title: Elementary Forms

text: THE IDEA OF THE SOUL
title: Elementary Forms

text: In the preceding chapters we have been studying the fundamental
title: Elementary Forms

text: principles of the totemic religion. We have seen that no idea of soul or
title: Elementary Forms

text: spirit or mythical personality is to be found among these. Yet, even if
title: Elementary Forms

text: the idea of spiritual beings is not at the foundation of totemism or,
title: Elementary Forms

text: consequently, of religious thought in general, still, there is no
title: Elementary Forms

text: religion where this notion is not met with. So it is important to see
title: Elementary Forms

text: how it is formed. To make sure that it is the product of a secondary
title: Elementary Forms

text: formation, we must discover the way in which it is derived from the more
title: Elementary Forms

text: essential conceptions which we have just described and explained.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Among the various spiritual beings, there is one which should receive
title: Elementary Forms

text: our attention first of all because it is the prototype after which the
title: Elementary Forms

text: others have been constructed: this is the soul.
title: Elementary Forms

text: I
title: Elementary Forms

text: Just as there is no known society without a religion, so there exist
title: Elementary Forms

text: none, howsoever crudely organized they may be, where we do not find a
title: Elementary Forms

text: whole system of collective representations concerning the soul, its
title: Elementary Forms

text: origin and its destiny. So far as we are able to judge from the data of
title: Elementary Forms

text: ethnology, the idea of the soul seems to have been contemporaneous with
title: Elementary Forms

text: humanity itself, and it seems to have had all of its essential
title: Elementary Forms

text: characteristics so well formulated at the very outset that the work of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the more advanced religions and philosophy has been practically confined
title: Elementary Forms

text: to refining it, while adding nothing that is really fundamental. In
title: Elementary Forms

text: fact, all the Australian societies admit that every human body shelters
title: Elementary Forms

text: an interior being, the principle of the life which animates it: this is
title: Elementary Forms

text: the soul. It sometimes happens, it is true, that women form an exception
title: Elementary Forms

text: to this general rule: there are tribes where they are believed to have
title: Elementary Forms

text: no souls.[739] If Dawson is to be believed, it is the same with young
title: Elementary Forms

text: children in the tribes that he has observed.[740] But these are
title: Elementary Forms

text: exceptional and probably late cases;[741] the last one even seems to be
title: Elementary Forms

text: suspect and may well be due to an erroneous interpretation of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: facts.[742]
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is not easy to determine the idea which the Australian makes of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: soul, because it is so obscure and floating; but we should not be
title: Elementary Forms

text: surprised at this. If someone asked our own contemporaries, or even
title: Elementary Forms

text: those of them who believe most firmly in the existence of the soul, how
title: Elementary Forms

text: they represented it, the replies that he would receive would not have
title: Elementary Forms

text: much more coherence and precision. This is because we are dealing with a
title: Elementary Forms

text: very complex notion, into which a multitude of badly analysed
title: Elementary Forms

text: impressions enter, whose elaboration has been carried on for centuries,
title: Elementary Forms

text: though men have had no clear consciousness of it. Yet from this come the
title: Elementary Forms

text: most essential, though frequently contradictory, characteristics by
title: Elementary Forms

text: which it is defined.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In some cases they tell us that it has the external appearance of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: body.[743] But sometimes it is also represented as having the size of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: grain of sand; its dimensions are so reduced that it can pass through
title: Elementary Forms

text: the smallest crevices or the finest tissues.[744] We shall also see that
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is represented in the appearance of animals. This shows that its form
title: Elementary Forms

text: is essentially inconsistent and undetermined;[745] it varies from one
title: Elementary Forms

text: moment to another with the demands of circumstances or according to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: exigencies of the myth and the rite. The substance out of which it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: made is no less indefinable. It is not without matter, for it has a
title: Elementary Forms

text: form, howsoever vague this may be. And in fact, even during this life,
title: Elementary Forms

text: it has physical needs: it eats, and inversely, it may be eaten.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Sometimes it leaves the body, and in the course of its travels it
title: Elementary Forms

text: occasionally nourishes itself on foreign souls.[746] After it has once
title: Elementary Forms

text: been completely freed from the organism, it is thought to lead a life
title: Elementary Forms

text: absolutely analogous to the one it led in this world; it eats, drinks,
title: Elementary Forms

text: hunts, etc.[747] When it flutters among the branches of trees, it causes
title: Elementary Forms

text: rustlings and crackings which even profane ears hear.[748] But at the
title: Elementary Forms

text: same time, it is believed to be invisible to the vulgar.[749] It is true
title: Elementary Forms

text: that magicians or old men have the faculty of seeing souls; but it is in
title: Elementary Forms

text: virtue of special powers which they owe either to age or to a special
title: Elementary Forms

text: training that they perceive things which escape our senses. According to
title: Elementary Forms

text: Dawson, ordinary individuals enjoy the same privilege at only one moment
title: Elementary Forms

text: of their existence: when they are on the eve of a premature death.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Therefore this quasi-miraculous vision is considered a sinister omen.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Now, invisibility is generally considered one of the signs of
title: Elementary Forms

text: spirituality. So the soul is conceived as being immaterial to a certain
title: Elementary Forms

text: degree, for it does not affect the senses in the way bodies do: it has
title: Elementary Forms

text: no bones, as the tribes of the Tully River say.[750] In order to
title: Elementary Forms

text: conciliate all these opposed characteristics, they represent it as made
title: Elementary Forms

text: of some infinitely rare and subtle matter, like something ethereal,[751]
title: Elementary Forms

text: and comparable to a shadow or breath.[752]
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is distinct and independent of the body, for during this life it can
title: Elementary Forms

text: leave it at any moment. It does leave it during sleep, fainting spells,
title: Elementary Forms

text: etc.[753] It may even remain absent for some time without entailing
title: Elementary Forms

text: death; however, during these absences life is weakened and even stops if
title: Elementary Forms

text: the soul does not return home.[754] But it is especially at death that
title: Elementary Forms

text: this distinction and independence manifest themselves with the greatest
title: Elementary Forms

text: clarity. While the body no longer exists and no visible traces of it
title: Elementary Forms

text: remain, the soul continues to live: it leads an autonomous existence in
title: Elementary Forms

text: another world.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But howsoever real this duality may be, it is in no way absolute. It
title: Elementary Forms

text: would show a grave misunderstanding to represent the body as a sort of
title: Elementary Forms

text: habitat in which the soul resides, but with which it has only external
title: Elementary Forms

text: relations. Quite on the contrary, it is united to it by the closest
title: Elementary Forms

text: bonds; it is separable from it only imperfectly and with difficulty. We
title: Elementary Forms

text: have already seen that it has, or at least is able to have, its external
title: Elementary Forms

text: aspect. Consequently, everything that hurts the one hurts the other;
title: Elementary Forms

text: every wound of the body spreads to the soul.[755] It is so intimately
title: Elementary Forms

text: associated with the life of the organism that it grows with it and
title: Elementary Forms

text: decays with it. This is why a man who has attained a certain age enjoys
title: Elementary Forms

text: privileges refused to young men; it is because the religious principle
title: Elementary Forms

text: within him has acquired greater force and efficacy as he has advanced in
title: Elementary Forms

text: life. But when senility sets in, and the old man is no longer able to
title: Elementary Forms

text: take a useful part in the great religious ceremonies in which the vital
title: Elementary Forms

text: interests of the tribe are concerned, this respect is no longer accorded
title: Elementary Forms

text: to him. It is thought that weakness of the body is communicated to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: soul. Having the same powers no longer, he no longer has a right to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: same prestige.[756]
title: Elementary Forms

text: There is not only a close union of soul and body, but there is also a
title: Elementary Forms

text: partial confusion of the two. Just as there is something of the body in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the soul, since it sometimes reproduces its form, so there is something
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the soul in the body. Certain regions and certain products of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: organism are believed to have a special affinity with it: such is the
title: Elementary Forms

text: case with the heart, the breath, the placenta,[757] the blood,[758] the
title: Elementary Forms

text: shadow,[759] the liver, the fat of the liver, the kidneys,[760] etc.
title: Elementary Forms

text: These various material substrata are not mere habitations of the soul;
title: Elementary Forms

text: they are the soul itself seen from without. When blood flows, the soul
title: Elementary Forms

text: escapes with it. The soul is not in the breath; it is the breath. It and
title: Elementary Forms

text: the part of the body where it resides are only one. Hence comes the
title: Elementary Forms

text: conception according to which a man has a number of souls. Being
title: Elementary Forms

text: dispersed in various parts of the organism, the soul is differentiated
title: Elementary Forms

text: and broken up into fragments. Each organ has individualized, as it were,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the portion of the soul which it contains, and which has thus become a
title: Elementary Forms

text: distinct entity. The soul of the heart could not be that of the breath
title: Elementary Forms

text: or the shadow or the placenta. While they are all related, still they
title: Elementary Forms

text: are to be distinguished, and even have different names.[761]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Moreover, even if the soul is localized especially in certain parts of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the organism, it is not absent from the others. In varying degrees, it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is diffused through the whole body, as is well shown by the funeral
title: Elementary Forms

text: rites. After the last breath has been expired and the soul is believed
title: Elementary Forms

text: to be gone, it seems as though it should profit by the liberty thus
title: Elementary Forms

text: regained, to move about at will and to return as quickly as possible to
title: Elementary Forms

text: its real home, which is elsewhere. Nevertheless, it remains near to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: corpse; the bond uniting them has been loosened, but not broken. A whole
title: Elementary Forms

text: series of special rites are necessary to induce it to depart definitely.
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is invited to go by gestures and significant movements.[762] The way
title: Elementary Forms

text: is laid open for it, and outlets are arranged so that it can go more
title: Elementary Forms

text: easily.[763] This is because it has not left the body entirely; it was
title: Elementary Forms

text: too closely united to it to break away all at once. Hence comes the very
title: Elementary Forms

text: frequent rite of funeral anthropophagy; the flesh of the dead is eaten
title: Elementary Forms

text: because it is thought to contain a sacred principle, which is really
title: Elementary Forms

text: nothing more than the soul.[764] In order to drive it out definitely,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the flesh is melted, either by submitting it to the heat of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: sun,[765] or to that of an artificial fire.[766] The soul departs with
title: Elementary Forms

text: the liquids which result. But even the dry bones still retain some part
title: Elementary Forms

text: of it. Therefore they can be used as sacred objects or instruments of
title: Elementary Forms

text: magic;[767] or if someone wishes to give complete liberty to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: principle which they contain, he breaks these.[768]
title: Elementary Forms

text: But a moment does arrive when the final separation is accomplished; the
title: Elementary Forms

text: liberated soul takes flight. But by nature it is so intimately
title: Elementary Forms

text: associated with the body that this removal cannot take place without a
title: Elementary Forms

text: profound change in its condition. So it takes a new name also.[769]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Although keeping all the distinctive traits of the individual whom it
title: Elementary Forms

text: animated, his humours and his good and bad qualities,[770] still it has
title: Elementary Forms

text: become a new being. From that moment a new existence commences for it.
title: Elementary Forms

text: It goes to the land of souls. This land is conceived differently by
title: Elementary Forms

text: different tribes; sometimes different conceptions are found existing
title: Elementary Forms

text: side by side in the same society. For some, it is situated under the
title: Elementary Forms

text: earth, where each totemic group has its part. This is at the spot where
title: Elementary Forms

text: the first ancestors, the founders of the clan, entered the ground at a
title: Elementary Forms

text: certain time, and where they live since their death. In the subterranean
title: Elementary Forms

text: world there is a geographical disposition of the dead corresponding to
title: Elementary Forms

text: that of the living. There, the sun always shines and rivers flow which
title: Elementary Forms

text: never run dry. Such is the conception which Spencer and Gillen attribute
title: Elementary Forms

text: to the central tribes, Arunta,[771] Warramunga,[772] etc. It is found
title: Elementary Forms

text: again among the Wotjobaluk.[773] In other places, all the dead, no
title: Elementary Forms

text: matter what their totems may have been, are believed to live together in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the same place, which is more or less vaguely localized as beyond the
title: Elementary Forms

text: sea, in an island,[774] or on the shores of a lake.[775] Sometimes,
title: Elementary Forms

text: finally, it is into the sky, beyond the clouds, that the souls are
title: Elementary Forms

text: thought to go. "There," says Dawson, "there is a delectable land,
title: Elementary Forms

text: abounding in kangaroos and game of every sort, where men lead a happy
title: Elementary Forms

text: life. Souls meet again there and recognize one another."[776] It is
title: Elementary Forms

text: probable that certain of the features of this picture have been taken
title: Elementary Forms

text: from the paradise of the Christian missionaries;[777] but the idea that
title: Elementary Forms

text: souls, or at least some souls, enter the skies after death appears to be
title: Elementary Forms

text: quite indigenous; for it is found again in other parts of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: continent.[778]
title: Elementary Forms

text: In general, all the souls meet the same fate and lead the same life.
title: Elementary Forms

text: However, a different treatment is sometimes accorded them based on the
title: Elementary Forms

text: way they have conducted themselves upon earth, and we can see the first
title: Elementary Forms

text: outlines of these two distinct and even opposed compartments into which
title: Elementary Forms

text: the world to come will later be divided. The souls of those who have
title: Elementary Forms

text: excelled, during life, as hunters, warriors, dancers, etc., are not
title: Elementary Forms

text: confounded with the common horde of the others; a special place is
title: Elementary Forms

text: granted to them.[779] Sometimes, this is the sky.[780] Strehlow even
title: Elementary Forms

text: says that according to one myth, the souls of the wicked are devoured by
title: Elementary Forms

text: dreadful spirits, and destroyed.[781] Nevertheless, these conceptions
title: Elementary Forms

text: always remain very vague in Australia;[782] they begin to have a clarity
title: Elementary Forms

text: and determination only in the more advanced societies, such as those of
title: Elementary Forms

text: America.[783]
title: Elementary Forms

text: II
title: Elementary Forms

text: Such are the beliefs relative to the soul and its destiny, in their most
title: Elementary Forms

text: primitive form, and reduced to their most essential traits. We must now
title: Elementary Forms

text: attempt to explain them. What is it that has been able to lead men into
title: Elementary Forms

text: thinking that there are two beings in them, one of which possesses these
title: Elementary Forms

text: very special characteristics which we have just enumerated? To find the
title: Elementary Forms

text: reply to this question, let us begin by seeking the origin attributed to
title: Elementary Forms

text: this spiritual principle by the primitive himself: if it is well
title: Elementary Forms

text: analysed, his own conception will put us on the way towards the
title: Elementary Forms

text: solution.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Following out the method which we have set before ourselves, we shall
title: Elementary Forms

text: study these ideas in a determined group of societies where they have
title: Elementary Forms

text: been observed with an especial precision; these are the tribes of
title: Elementary Forms

text: Central Australia. Though not narrow, the area of our observations will
title: Elementary Forms

text: be limited. But there is good reason for believing that these same ideas
title: Elementary Forms

text: are quite generally held, in various forms, even outside of Australia.
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is also to be noted that the idea of the soul, as it is found among
title: Elementary Forms

text: these central tribes, does not differ specifically from the one found in
title: Elementary Forms

text: other tribes; it has the same essential characteristics everywhere. As
title: Elementary Forms

text: one effect always has the same cause, we may well think that this idea,
title: Elementary Forms

text: which is everywhere the same, does not result from one cause here and
title: Elementary Forms

text: another there. So the origin which we shall be led to attribute to it as
title: Elementary Forms

text: a result of our study of these particular tribes with which we are going
title: Elementary Forms

text: to deal, ought to be equally true for the others. These tribes will give
title: Elementary Forms

text: us a chance to make an experiment, as it were, whose results, like those
title: Elementary Forms

text: of every well-made experiment, are susceptible of generalization. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: homogeneity of the Australian civilization would of itself be enough to
title: Elementary Forms

text: justify this generalization; but we shall be careful to verify it
title: Elementary Forms

text: afterwards with facts taken from other peoples, both in Australia and
title: Elementary Forms

text: America.
title: Elementary Forms

text: As the conceptions which are going to furnish us with the basis of our
title: Elementary Forms

text: demonstration have been reported in different terms by Spencer and
title: Elementary Forms

text: Gillen on the one hand and Strehlow on the other, we must give these two
title: Elementary Forms

text: versions one after the other. We shall see that when they are well
title: Elementary Forms

text: understood, they differ in form more than in matter, and that they both
title: Elementary Forms

text: have the same sociological significance.
title: Elementary Forms

text: According to Spencer and Gillen, the souls which, in each generation,
title: Elementary Forms

text: come to animate the bodies of newly-born children, are not special and
title: Elementary Forms

text: original creations; all these tribes hold that there is a definite stock
title: Elementary Forms

text: of souls, whose number cannot be augmented at all,[784] and which
title: Elementary Forms

text: reincarnate themselves periodically. When an individual dies, his soul
title: Elementary Forms

text: quits the body in which it dwelt, and after the mourning is
title: Elementary Forms

text: accomplished, it goes to the land of the souls; but after a certain
title: Elementary Forms

text: length of time, it returns to incarnate itself again, and these
title: Elementary Forms

text: reincarnations are the cause of conception and birth. At the beginning
title: Elementary Forms

text: of things, it was these fundamental souls which animated the first
title: Elementary Forms

text: ancestors, the founders of the clan. At an epoch, beyond which the
title: Elementary Forms

text: imagination does not go and which is considered the very beginning of
title: Elementary Forms

text: time, there were certain beings who were not derived from any others.
title: Elementary Forms

text: For this reason, the Arunta call them the _Altjirangamitjina_,[785] the
title: Elementary Forms

text: uncreated ones, those who exist from all eternity, and, according to
title: Elementary Forms

text: Spencer and Gillen, they give the name _Alcheringa_[786] to the period
title: Elementary Forms

text: when these fabulous beings are thought to have lived. Being organized in
title: Elementary Forms

text: totemic clans just as the men of to-day are, they passed their time in
title: Elementary Forms

text: travels, in the course of which they accomplished all sorts of
title: Elementary Forms

text: prodigious actions, the memory of which is preserved in the myths. But a
title: Elementary Forms

text: moment arrived when this terrestrial life came to a close; singly or in
title: Elementary Forms

text: groups, they entered into the earth. But their souls live for ever; they
title: Elementary Forms

text: are immortal. They even continue to frequent the places where the
title: Elementary Forms

text: existence of their former hosts came to an end. Moreover, owing to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: memories attached to them, these places have a sacred character; it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: here that the oknanikilla are located, the sorts of sanctuaries where
title: Elementary Forms

text: the churinga of the clan is kept, and the centres of the different
title: Elementary Forms

text: totemic cults. When one of the souls which wander about these
title: Elementary Forms

text: sanctuaries enters into the body of a woman, the result is a conception
title: Elementary Forms

text: and later a birth.[787] So each individual is considered as a new
title: Elementary Forms

text: appearance of a determined ancestor: it is this ancestor himself, come
title: Elementary Forms

text: back in a new body and with new features. Now, what were these
title: Elementary Forms

text: ancestors?
title: Elementary Forms

text: In the first place, they were endowed with powers infinitely superior to
title: Elementary Forms

text: those possessed by men to-day, even the most respected old men and the
title: Elementary Forms

text: most celebrated magicians. They are attributed virtues which we may
title: Elementary Forms

text: speak of as miraculous: "They could travel on, or above, or beneath the
title: Elementary Forms

text: ground; by opening a vein in the arm, each of them could flood whole
title: Elementary Forms

text: tracts of country or cause level plains to arise; in rocky ranges they
title: Elementary Forms

text: could make pools of water spring into existence, or could make deep
title: Elementary Forms

text: gorges and gaps through which to traverse the ranges, and where they
title: Elementary Forms

text: planted their sacred poles (nurtunja), there rocks or trees arose to
title: Elementary Forms

text: mark the spot."[788] It is they who gave the earth the form it has at
title: Elementary Forms

text: present. They created all sorts of beings, both men and animals. They
title: Elementary Forms

text: are nearly gods. So their souls also have a divine character. And since
title: Elementary Forms

text: the souls of men are these ancestral souls reincarnated in the human
title: Elementary Forms

text: body, these are sacred beings too.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In the second place, these ancestors were not men in the proper sense of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the word, but animals or vegetables, or perhaps mixed beings in which
title: Elementary Forms

text: the animal or vegetable element predominated: "In the Alcheringa," say
title: Elementary Forms

text: Spencer and Gillen, "lived ancestors who, in the native mind, are so
title: Elementary Forms

text: intimately associated with the animals or plants the name of which they
title: Elementary Forms

text: bear that an Alcheringa man of, say, the kangaroo totem may sometimes be
title: Elementary Forms

text: spoken of either as a man-kangaroo or a kangaroo-man. The identity of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the human individual is often sunk in that of the animal or plant from
title: Elementary Forms

text: which he is supposed to have originated."[789] Their immortal souls
title: Elementary Forms

text: necessarily have the same nature; in them, also, the human element is
title: Elementary Forms

text: wedded to the animal element, with a certain tendency for the latter to
title: Elementary Forms

text: predominate over the former. So they are made of the same substance as
title: Elementary Forms

text: the totemic principle, for we know that the special characteristic of
title: Elementary Forms

text: this is to present this double nature, and to synthesize and confound
title: Elementary Forms

text: the two realms in itself.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Since no other souls than these exist, we reach the conclusion that, in
title: Elementary Forms

text: a general way, the soul is nothing other than the totemic principle
title: Elementary Forms

text: incarnate in each individual. And there is nothing to surprise us in
title: Elementary Forms

text: this derivation. We already know that this principle is immanent in each
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the members of the clan. But in penetrating into these individuals,
title: Elementary Forms

text: it must inevitably individualize itself. Because the consciousnesses, of
title: Elementary Forms

text: which it becomes thus an integral part, differ from each other, it
title: Elementary Forms

text: differentiates itself according to their image; since each has its own
title: Elementary Forms

text: physiognomy, it takes a distinct physiognomy in each. Of course it
title: Elementary Forms

text: remains something outside of and foreign to the man, but the portion of
title: Elementary Forms

text: it which each is believed to possess cannot fail to contract close
title: Elementary Forms

text: affinities with the particular subject in which it resides; it becomes
title: Elementary Forms

text: his to a certain extent. Thus it has two contradictory characteristics,
title: Elementary Forms

text: but whose coexistence is one of the distinctive features of the notion
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the soul. To-day, as formerly, the soul is what is best and most
title: Elementary Forms

text: profound in ourselves, and the pre-eminent part of our being; yet it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: also a passing guest which comes from the outside, which leads in us an
title: Elementary Forms

text: existence distinct from that of the body, and which should one day
title: Elementary Forms

text: regain its entire independence. In a word, just as society exists only
title: Elementary Forms

text: in and through individuals, the totemic principle exists only in and
title: Elementary Forms

text: through the individual consciousnesses whose association forms the clan.
title: Elementary Forms

text: If they did not feel it in them it would not exist; it is they who put
title: Elementary Forms

text: it into things. So it must of necessity be divided and distributed among
title: Elementary Forms

text: them. Each of these fragments is a soul.
title: Elementary Forms

text: A myth which is found in a rather large number of the societies of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: centre, and which, moreover, is only a particular form of the preceding
title: Elementary Forms

text: ones, shows even better that this is really the matter out of which the
title: Elementary Forms

text: idea of the soul is made. In these tribes, tradition puts the origin of
title: Elementary Forms

text: each clan, not in a number of ancestors, but in only two,[790] or even
title: Elementary Forms

text: in one.[791] This unique being, as long as he remained single, contained
title: Elementary Forms

text: the totemic principle within him integrally, for at this moment there
title: Elementary Forms

text: was nothing to which this principle could be communicated. Now,
title: Elementary Forms

text: according to this same tradition, all the human souls which exist, both
title: Elementary Forms

text: those which now animate the bodies of men and those which are at present
title: Elementary Forms

text: unemployed, being held in reserve for the future, have issued from this
title: Elementary Forms

text: unique personage; they are made of his substance. While travelling over
title: Elementary Forms

text: the surface of the ground, or moving about, or shaking himself, he made
title: Elementary Forms

text: them leave his body and planted them in the various places he is
title: Elementary Forms

text: believed to have passed over. Is this not merely a symbolic way of
title: Elementary Forms

text: saying that they are parts of the totemic divinity?
title: Elementary Forms

text: But this conclusion presupposes that the tribes of which we have just
title: Elementary Forms

text: been speaking admit the doctrine of reincarnation. Now according to
title: Elementary Forms

text: Strehlow, this doctrine is unknown to the Arunta, the society which
title: Elementary Forms

text: Spencer and Gillen have studied the longest and the best. If, in this
title: Elementary Forms

text: particular case, these two observers have misunderstood things to such
title: Elementary Forms

text: an extent, their whole testimony would become suspect. So it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: important to determine the actual extent of this divergence.
title: Elementary Forms

text: According to Strehlow, after the soul has once been definitely freed
title: Elementary Forms

text: from the body by the rites of mourning, it never reincarnates itself
title: Elementary Forms

text: again. It goes off to the isles of the dead, where it passes its days in
title: Elementary Forms

text: sleeping and its nights in dancing, until it returns again to earth.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Then it comes back into the midst of the living and plays the role of
title: Elementary Forms

text: protecting genius to the young sons, or if such are lacking, to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: grandsons whom the dead man left behind him; it enters their body and
title: Elementary Forms

text: aids their growth. It remains thus in the midst of its former family for
title: Elementary Forms

text: a year or two, after which it goes back to the land of the souls. But
title: Elementary Forms

text: after a certain length of time it goes away once more to make another
title: Elementary Forms

text: sojourn upon earth, which is to be the last. A time will come when it
title: Elementary Forms

text: must take up again, and with no hope of return this time, the route to
title: Elementary Forms

text: the isles of the dead; then, after various incidents, the details of
title: Elementary Forms

text: which it is useless to relate, a storm will overtake it, in the course
title: Elementary Forms

text: of which it will be struck by a flash of lightning. Thus its career is
title: Elementary Forms

text: definitely terminated.[792]
title: Elementary Forms

text: So it cannot reincarnate itself; nor can conceptions and births be due
title: Elementary Forms

text: to the reincarnation of souls which periodically commence new existences
title: Elementary Forms

text: in new bodies. It is true that Strehlow, as Spencer and Gillen, declares
title: Elementary Forms

text: that for the Arunta commerce of the sexes is in no way the determining
title: Elementary Forms

text: condition of generation,[793] which is considered the result of mystic
title: Elementary Forms

text: operations, but different from the ones which the other observers told
title: Elementary Forms

text: us about. It takes place in one or the other of the two following ways:
title: Elementary Forms

text: Wherever an ancestor of the Alcheringa[794] times is believed to have
title: Elementary Forms

text: entered into the ground, there is either a stone or a tree representing
title: Elementary Forms

text: his body. The tree or rock which has this mystic relation with the
title: Elementary Forms

text: departed hero is called _nanja_ according to Spencer and Gillen,[795]
title: Elementary Forms

text: or _ngarra_ according to Strehlow.[796] Sometimes it is a water-hole
title: Elementary Forms

text: which is believed to have been formed in this way. Now, on each of these
title: Elementary Forms

text: trees or rocks and in each of these water-holes, there live embryo
title: Elementary Forms

text: children, called _ratapa_,[797] which belong to exactly the same totem
title: Elementary Forms

text: as the corresponding ancestor. For example, on a gum-tree representing
title: Elementary Forms

text: an ancestor of the kangaroo totem there are ratapa, all of which have
title: Elementary Forms

text: the kangaroo as their totem. If a woman happens to pass it, and she is
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the matrimonial class to which the mothers of these ratapa should
title: Elementary Forms

text: belong,[798] one of them may enter her through the hip. The woman learns
title: Elementary Forms

text: of this act by the characteristic pains which are the first symptoms of
title: Elementary Forms

text: pregnancy. The child thus conceived will of course belong to the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: totem as the ancestor upon whose mystical body he resided before
title: Elementary Forms

text: becoming incarnate.[799]
title: Elementary Forms

text: In other cases, the process employed is slightly different: the ancestor
title: Elementary Forms

text: himself acts in person. At a given moment he leaves his subterranean
