title: Elementary Forms

text: retreat and throws on to the passing woman a little churinga of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: special form, called _namatuna_.[800] The churinga enters the body of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the woman and takes a human form there, while the ancestor disappears
title: Elementary Forms

text: again into the earth.[801]
title: Elementary Forms

text: These two ways of conception are believed to be equally frequent. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: features of the child will reveal the manner in which he was conceived;
title: Elementary Forms

text: according to whether his face is broad or long, they say that he is the
title: Elementary Forms

text: incarnation of a ratapa or a namatuna. Beside these two means of
title: Elementary Forms

text: fecundation, Strehlow places a third, which, however, is much more rare.
title: Elementary Forms

text: After his namatuna has penetrated into the body of the woman, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: ancestor himself enters her and voluntarily submits to a new birth. So
title: Elementary Forms

text: in this case, the conception is due to a real reincarnation of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: ancestor. But this is very exceptional, and when a man who has been
title: Elementary Forms

text: conceived thus dies, the ancestral soul which animated him goes away,
title: Elementary Forms

text: just like ordinary souls, to the isles of the dead where, after the
title: Elementary Forms

text: usual delays, it is definitely annihilated. So it cannot undergo any
title: Elementary Forms

text: further reincarnations.[802]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Such is the version of Strehlow.[803] In the opinion of this author it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is radically opposed to that of Spencer and Gillen. But in reality it
title: Elementary Forms

text: differs only in the letter of the formulae and symbols, while in both
title: Elementary Forms

text: cases we find the same mythical theme in slightly different forms.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In the first place, all the observers agree that every conception is the
title: Elementary Forms

text: result of an incarnation. Only according to Strehlow, that which is
title: Elementary Forms

text: incarnated is not a soul but a ratapa or a namatuna. But what is a
title: Elementary Forms

text: ratapa? Strehlow says that it is a complete embryo, made up of a soul
title: Elementary Forms

text: and a body. But the soul is always represented in material forms; it
title: Elementary Forms

text: sleeps, dances, hunts, eats, etc. So it, too, has a corporal element.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Inversely, the ratapa is invisible to ordinary men; no one sees it as it
title: Elementary Forms

text: enters the body of the woman;[804] this is equivalent to saying that it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is made of a matter quite similar to that of the soul. So it hardly
title: Elementary Forms

text: seems possible to differentiate the two clearly in this regard. In
title: Elementary Forms

text: reality, these are mythical beings which are obviously conceived after
title: Elementary Forms

text: the same model. Schulze calls them the souls of children.[805] Moreover,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the ratapa, just like the soul, sustains the closest relations with the
title: Elementary Forms

text: ancestor of which the sacred tree or rock is the materialized form. It
title: Elementary Forms

text: is of the same totem as this ancestor, of the same phratry and of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: same matrimonial class.[806] Its place in the social organization of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: tribe is the very one that its ancestor is believed to have held before
title: Elementary Forms

text: it. It bears the same name,[807] which is a proof that these two
title: Elementary Forms

text: personalities are at least very closely related to one another.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But there is more than this; this relationship even goes as far as a
title: Elementary Forms

text: complete identification. In fact, it is on the mystic body of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: ancestor that the ratapa is formed; it comes from this; it is like a
title: Elementary Forms

text: detached portion of it. So it really is a part of the ancestor which
title: Elementary Forms

text: penetrates into the womb of the mother and which becomes the child. Thus
title: Elementary Forms

text: we get back to the conception of Spencer and Gillen: birth is due to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: reincarnation of an ancestral personage. Of course it is not the entire
title: Elementary Forms

text: person that is reincarnated, it is only an emanation from him. But this
title: Elementary Forms

text: difference has only a secondary interest, for when a sacred being
title: Elementary Forms

text: divides and duplicates itself, all of its essential characteristics are
title: Elementary Forms

text: to be found again in each of the fragments into which it is broken up.
title: Elementary Forms

text: So really the Alcheringa ancestor is entire in each part of himself
title: Elementary Forms

text: which becomes a ratapa.[808]
title: Elementary Forms

text: The second mode of conception distinguished by Strehlow has the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: significance. In fact, the churinga, and more especially the particular
title: Elementary Forms

text: churinga that is called the namatuna, is considered a transformation of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the ancestor; according to Strehlow,[809] it is his body, just as the
title: Elementary Forms

text: nanja tree is. In other words, the personality of the ancestor, his
title: Elementary Forms

text: churinga and his nanja tree, are sacred things, inspiring the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: sentiments and to which the same religious value is attributed. So they
title: Elementary Forms

text: transmute themselves into one another: in the spot where an ancestor
title: Elementary Forms

text: lost his churinga, a sacred tree or rock has come out of the soil, just
title: Elementary Forms

text: the same as in those places where he entered the ground himself.[810] So
title: Elementary Forms

text: there is a mythological equivalence of a person of the Alcheringa and
title: Elementary Forms

text: his churinga; consequently, when the former throws a namatuna into the
title: Elementary Forms

text: body of a woman, it is as if he entered into it himself. In fact, we
title: Elementary Forms

text: have seen that sometimes he does enter in person after the namatuna;
title: Elementary Forms

text: according to other stories he precedes it; it might be said that he
title: Elementary Forms

text: opens up the way for it.[811] The fact that these two themes exist side
title: Elementary Forms

text: by side in the same myth completes the proof that one is only a doublet
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the other.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Moreover, in whatever way the conception may have taken place, there can
title: Elementary Forms

text: be no doubt that each individual is united to some determined ancestor
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the Alcheringa by especially close bonds. In the first place, each
title: Elementary Forms

text: man has his appointed ancestor; two persons cannot have the same one
title: Elementary Forms

text: simultaneously. In other words, a being of the Alcheringa never has more
title: Elementary Forms

text: than one representative among the living.[812] More than that, the one
title: Elementary Forms

text: is only an aspect of the other. In fact, as we already know, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: churinga left by the ancestor expresses his personality; if we adopt the
title: Elementary Forms

text: interpretation of Strehlow, which, perhaps, is the more satisfactory, we
title: Elementary Forms

text: shall say that it is his body. But this same churinga is related in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: same way to the individual who is believed to have been conceived under
title: Elementary Forms

text: the influence of this ancestor, and who is the fruit of his mystic
title: Elementary Forms

text: works. When the young initiate is introduced into the sanctuary of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: clan, he is shown the churinga of his ancestor, and someone says to him,
title: Elementary Forms

text: "You are this body; you are the same thing as this."[813] So, in
title: Elementary Forms

text: Strehlow's own expression, the churinga is "the body common to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: individual and his ancestor."[814] Now if they are to have the same body
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is necessary that on one side at least their two personalities be
title: Elementary Forms

text: confounded. Strehlow recognizes this explicitly, moreover, when he says,
title: Elementary Forms

text: "By the tjurunga (churinga) the individual is united to his personal
title: Elementary Forms

text: ancestor."[815]
title: Elementary Forms

text: So for Strehlow as well as for Spencer and Gillen, there is a mystic,
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious principle in each new-born child, which emanates from an
title: Elementary Forms

text: ancestor of the Alcheringa. It is this principle which forms the essence
title: Elementary Forms

text: of each individual, therefore it is his soul, or in any case the soul is
title: Elementary Forms

text: made of the same matter and the same substance. Now it is only upon this
title: Elementary Forms

text: one fundamental fact that we have relied in determining the nature and
title: Elementary Forms

text: origin of the idea of the soul. The different metaphors by means of
title: Elementary Forms

text: which it may have been expressed have only a secondary interest for
title: Elementary Forms

text: Far from contradicting the data upon which our theory rests, the recent
title: Elementary Forms

text: observations of Strehlow bring new proofs confirming it. Our reasoning
title: Elementary Forms

text: consisted in inferring the totemic nature of the human soul from the
title: Elementary Forms

text: totemic nature of the ancestral soul, of which the former is an
title: Elementary Forms

text: emanation and a sort of replica. Now, some of the new facts which we owe
title: Elementary Forms

text: to Strehlow show this character of both even more categorically than
title: Elementary Forms

text: those we had at our disposal before do. In the first place, Strehlow,
title: Elementary Forms

text: like Spencer and Gillen, insists on "the intimate relations uniting each
title: Elementary Forms

text: ancestor to an animal, to a plant, or to some other natural object."
title: Elementary Forms

text: Some of these Altjirangamitjina (these are Spencer and Gillen's men of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the Alcheringa) "should," he says, "be manifested directly as animals;
title: Elementary Forms

text: others take the animal form in a way."[817] Even now they are constantly
title: Elementary Forms

text: transforming themselves into animals.[818] In any case, whatever
title: Elementary Forms

text: external aspect they may have, "the special and distinctive qualities of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the animal clearly appear in each of them." For example, the ancestors
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the Kangaroo clan eat grass just like real kangaroos, and flee before
title: Elementary Forms

text: the hunter; those of the Emu clan run and feed like emus,[819] etc. More
title: Elementary Forms

text: than that, those ancestors who had a vegetable as totem become this
title: Elementary Forms

text: vegetable itself on death.[820] Moreover, this close kinship of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: ancestor and the totemic being is so keenly felt by the natives that it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is shown even in their terminology. Among the Arunta, the child calls
title: Elementary Forms

text: the totem of his mother, which serves him as a secondary totem,[821]
title: Elementary Forms

text: _altjira_. As filiation was at first in the uterine line, there was once
title: Elementary Forms

text: a time when each individual had no other totem than that of his mother;
title: Elementary Forms

text: so it is very probable that the term _altjira_ then designated the real
title: Elementary Forms

text: totem. Now this clearly enters into the composition of the word which
title: Elementary Forms

text: means great ancestor, _altjirangamitjina_.[822]
title: Elementary Forms

text: The idea of the totem and that of the ancestor are even so closely
title: Elementary Forms

text: kindred that they sometimes seem to be confounded. Thus, after speaking
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the totem of the mother, or _altjira_, Strehlow goes on to say, "This
title: Elementary Forms

text: altjira appears to the natives in dreams and gives them warnings, just
title: Elementary Forms

text: as it takes information concerning them to their sleeping friends."[823]
title: Elementary Forms

text: This _altjira_, which speaks and which is attached to each individual
title: Elementary Forms

text: personally, is evidently an ancestor; yet it is also an incarnation of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the totem. A certain text in Roth, which speaks of invocations addressed
title: Elementary Forms

text: to the totem, should certainly be interpreted in this sense.[824] So it
title: Elementary Forms

text: appears that the totem is sometimes represented in the mind in the form
title: Elementary Forms

text: of a group of ideal beings or mythical personages who are more or less
title: Elementary Forms

text: indistinct from the ancestors. In a word, the ancestors are the
title: Elementary Forms

text: fragments of the totem.[825]
title: Elementary Forms

text: But if the ancestor is so readily confused with the totemic being, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: individual soul, which is so near the ancestral soul, cannot do
title: Elementary Forms

text: otherwise. Moreover, this is what actually results from the close union
title: Elementary Forms

text: of each man with his churinga. In fact, we know that the churinga
title: Elementary Forms

text: represents the personality of the individual who is believed to have
title: Elementary Forms

text: been born of it;[826] but it also expresses the totemic animal. When the
title: Elementary Forms

text: civilizing hero, Mangarkunjerkunja, presented each member of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Kangaroo clan with his personal totem, he spoke as follows: "Here is the
title: Elementary Forms

text: body of a kangaroo."[827] Thus the churinga is at once the body of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: ancestor, of the individual himself and of the totemic animal; so,
title: Elementary Forms

text: according to a strong and very just expression of Strehlow, these three
title: Elementary Forms

text: beings form a "solid unity."[828] They are almost equivalent and
title: Elementary Forms

text: interchangeable terms. This is as much as to say that they are thought
title: Elementary Forms

text: of as different aspects of one and the same reality, which is also
title: Elementary Forms

text: defined by the distinctive attributes of the totem. Their common essence
title: Elementary Forms

text: is the totemic principle. The language itself expresses this identity.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The word ratapa, and the _aratapi_ of the Loritja language, designate
title: Elementary Forms

text: the mythical embryo which is detached from the ancestor and which
title: Elementary Forms

text: becomes the child; now these same words also designate the totem of this
title: Elementary Forms

text: same child, such as is determined by the spot where the mother believes
title: Elementary Forms

text: that she conceived.[829]
title: Elementary Forms

text: III
title: Elementary Forms

text: Up to the present we have studied the doctrine of reincarnation only in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the tribes of Central Australia; therefore the bases upon which our
title: Elementary Forms

text: inference rests may be deemed too narrow. But in the first place, for
title: Elementary Forms

text: the reasons which we have pointed out, the experiment holds good outside
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the societies which we have observed directly. Also, there are
title: Elementary Forms

text: abundant facts proving that the same or analogous conceptions are found
title: Elementary Forms

text: in the most diverse parts of Australia or, at least, have left very
title: Elementary Forms

text: evident traces there. They are found even in America.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Howitt mentions them among the Dieri of South Australia.[830] The word
title: Elementary Forms

text: _Mura-mura_, which Gason translates with Good Spirit and which he thinks
title: Elementary Forms

text: expresses a belief in a god creator,[831] is really a collective word
title: Elementary Forms

text: designating the group of ancestors placed by the myth at the beginning
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the tribe. They continue to exist to-day as formerly. "They are
title: Elementary Forms

text: believed to live in trees, which are sacred for this reason." Certain
title: Elementary Forms

text: irregularities of the ground, rocks and springs are identified with
title: Elementary Forms

text: these Mura-mura,[832] which consequently resemble the Altjirangamitjina
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the Arunta in a singular way. The Kurnai of Gippsland, though
title: Elementary Forms

text: retaining only vestiges of totemism, also believe in the existence of
title: Elementary Forms

text: ancestors called _Muk-Kurnai_, and which they think of as beings
title: Elementary Forms

text: intermediate between men and animals.[833] Among the Nimbaldi, Taplin
title: Elementary Forms

text: has observed a theory of conception similar to that which Strehlow
title: Elementary Forms

text: attributes to the Arunta.[834] We find this belief in reincarnation held
title: Elementary Forms

text: integrally by the Wotjobaluk in Victoria. "The spirits of the dead,"
title: Elementary Forms

text: says Mathews, "assemble in the _miyur_[835] of their respective clans;
title: Elementary Forms

text: they leave these to be born again in human form when a favourable
title: Elementary Forms

text: occasion presents itself."[836] Mathews even affirms that "the belief in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the reincarnation or transmigration of souls is strongly enrooted in all
title: Elementary Forms

text: the Australian tribes."[837]
title: Elementary Forms

text: If we pass to the northern regions we find the pure doctrine of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Arunta among the Niol-Niol in the north-west; every birth is attributed
title: Elementary Forms

text: to the incarnation of a pre-existing soul, which introduces itself into
title: Elementary Forms

text: the body of a woman.[838] In northern Queensland myths, differing from
title: Elementary Forms

text: the preceding only in form, express exactly the same ideas. Among the
title: Elementary Forms

text: tribes on the Pennefather River it is believed that every man has two
title: Elementary Forms

text: souls: the one, called _ngai_, resides in the heart; the other, called
title: Elementary Forms

text: _choi_, remains in the placenta. Soon after birth the placenta is buried
title: Elementary Forms

text: in a consecrated place. A particular genius, named Anje-a, who has
title: Elementary Forms

text: charge of the phenomena of procreation, comes to get this _choi_ and
title: Elementary Forms

text: keeps it until the child, being grown up, is married. When the time
title: Elementary Forms

text: comes to give him a son, Anje-a takes a bit of the choi of this man,
title: Elementary Forms

text: places it in the embryo he is making, and inserts it into the womb of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the mother. So it is out of the soul of the father that that of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: child is made. It is true that the child does not receive the paternal
title: Elementary Forms

text: soul integrally at first, for the _ngai_ remains in the heart of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: father as long as he lives. But when he dies the _ngai_, being
title: Elementary Forms

text: liberated, also incarnates itself in the bodies of the children; if
title: Elementary Forms

text: there are several children it is divided equally among them. Thus there
title: Elementary Forms

text: is a perfect spiritual continuity between the generations; it is the
title: Elementary Forms

text: same soul which is transmitted from a father to his children and from
title: Elementary Forms

text: these to their children, and this unique soul, always remaining itself
title: Elementary Forms

text: in spite of its successive divisions and subdivisions, is the one which
title: Elementary Forms

text: animated the first ancestor at the beginning of all things.[839] Between
title: Elementary Forms

text: this theory and the one held by the central tribes there is only one
title: Elementary Forms

text: difference of any importance; this is that the reincarnation is not the
title: Elementary Forms

text: work of the ancestors themselves but that of a special genius who takes
title: Elementary Forms

text: charge of this function professionally. But it seems probable that this
title: Elementary Forms

text: genius is the product of a syncretism which has fused the numerous
title: Elementary Forms

text: figures of the first ancestors into one single being. This hypothesis is
title: Elementary Forms

text: at least made probable by the fact that the words Anje-a and Anjir are
title: Elementary Forms

text: evidently very closely related; now the second designates the first man,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the original ancestor from whom all men are descended.[840]
title: Elementary Forms

text: These same ideas are found again among the Indian tribes of America.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Krauss says that among the Tlinkit, the souls of the departed are
title: Elementary Forms

text: believed to come back to earth and introduce themselves into the bodies
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the pregnant women of their families. "So when a woman dreams, during
title: Elementary Forms

text: pregnancy, of some deceased relative, she believes that the soul of this
title: Elementary Forms

text: latter has penetrated into her. If the young child has some
title: Elementary Forms

text: characteristic mark which the dead man had before, they believe that it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is the dead man himself come back to earth, and his name is given to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: child."[841] This belief is also general among the Haida. It is the
title: Elementary Forms

text: shaman who reveals which relative it was who reincarnated himself in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: child and what name should consequently be given to him.[842] Among the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Kwakiutl it is believed that the latest member of a family who died
title: Elementary Forms

text: comes back to life in the person of the first child to be born in that
title: Elementary Forms

text: family.[843] It is the same with the Hurons, the Iroquois, the Tinneh,
title: Elementary Forms

text: and many other tribes of the United States.[844]
title: Elementary Forms

text: The universality of these conceptions extends, of course, to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: conclusion which we have deduced from them, that is, to the explanation
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the idea of the soul which we have proposed. Its general
title: Elementary Forms

text: acceptability is also proved by the following facts.
title: Elementary Forms

text: We know[845] that each individual contains within him something of that
title: Elementary Forms

text: anonymous force which is diffused in the sacred species; he is a member
title: Elementary Forms

text: of this species himself. But as an empirical and visible being, he is
title: Elementary Forms

text: not, for, in spite of the symbolic designs and marks with which he
title: Elementary Forms

text: decorates his body, there is nothing in him to suggest the form of an
title: Elementary Forms

text: animal or plant. So it must be that there is another being in him, in
title: Elementary Forms

text: whom he recognizes himself, but whom he represents in the form of an
title: Elementary Forms

text: animal or vegetable species. Now is it not evident that this double can
title: Elementary Forms

text: only be the soul, since the soul is, of itself, already a double of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: subject whom it animates? The justification of this identification is
title: Elementary Forms

text: completed by the fact that the organs where the fragment of the totemic
title: Elementary Forms

text: principle contained in each individual incarnates itself the most
title: Elementary Forms

text: eminently are also those where the soul resides. This is the case with
title: Elementary Forms

text: the blood. The blood contains something of the nature of the totem, as
title: Elementary Forms

text: is proved by the part it takes in the totemic ceremonies.[846] But at
title: Elementary Forms

text: the same time, the blood is one of the seats of the soul; or rather, it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is the soul itself, seen from without. When blood flows, life runs out
title: Elementary Forms

text: and, in the same process, the soul escapes. So the soul is confused with
title: Elementary Forms

text: the sacred principle which is imminent in the blood.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Regarding matters from another point of view, if our explanation is
title: Elementary Forms

text: well-founded, the totemic principle, in penetrating into the individual
title: Elementary Forms

text: as we suppose, should retain a certain amount of autonomy there, since
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is quite distinct from the subject in whom it is incarnated. Now this
title: Elementary Forms

text: is just what Howitt claims to have observed among the Yuin: "That in
title: Elementary Forms

text: this tribe the totem is thought to be in some way part of a man is
title: Elementary Forms

text: clearly seen by the case of Umbara, before mentioned, who told me that,
title: Elementary Forms

text: many years ago, someone of the Lace-lizard totem sent it while he was
title: Elementary Forms

text: asleep, and that it went down his throat and almost ate his totem, which
title: Elementary Forms

text: was in his breast, so that he nearly died."[847] So it is quite true
title: Elementary Forms

text: that the totem is broken up in individualizing itself and that each of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the bits thus detached plays the part of a spirit or soul residing in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the body.[848]
title: Elementary Forms

text: But there are other more clearly demonstrative facts. If the soul is
title: Elementary Forms

text: only the totemic principle individualized, it should have, in certain
title: Elementary Forms

text: cases at least, rather close relations with the animal or vegetable
title: Elementary Forms

text: species whose form is reproduced by the totem. And, in fact, "the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Geawe-Gal (a tribe of New South Wales) had a superstition that everyone
title: Elementary Forms

text: had within himself an affinity to the spirit of some bird, beast or
title: Elementary Forms

text: reptile. Not that he sprung from the creature in any way, but that the
title: Elementary Forms

text: spirit which was in him was akin to that of the creature."[849]
title: Elementary Forms

text: There are even cases where the soul is believed to emanate directly from
title: Elementary Forms

text: the animal or vegetable serving as totem. Among the Arunta, according to
title: Elementary Forms

text: Strehlow, when a woman has eaten a great deal of fruit, it is believed
title: Elementary Forms

text: that she will give birth to a child who will have this fruit as totem.
title: Elementary Forms

text: If, at the moment when she felt the first tremblings of the child, she
title: Elementary Forms

text: was looking at a kangaroo, it is believed that the ratapa of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: kangaroo has entered her body and fertilized her.[850] H. Basedow
title: Elementary Forms

text: reported the same fact from the Wogait.[851] We know, also, that the
title: Elementary Forms

text: ratapa and the soul are almost indistinguishable things. Now, such an
title: Elementary Forms

text: origin could never have been attributed to the soul if men did not think
title: Elementary Forms

text: that it was made out of the same substances as the plants and animals of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the totemic species.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Thus the soul is frequently represented in an animal form. It is known
title: Elementary Forms

text: that in inferior societies, death is never considered a natural event,
title: Elementary Forms

text: due to the action of purely physical causes; it is generally attributed
title: Elementary Forms

text: to the evil workings of some sorcerer. In a large number of Australian
title: Elementary Forms

text: societies, in order to determine who is the responsible author of this
title: Elementary Forms

text: murder, they work on the principle that the soul of the murderer must
title: Elementary Forms

text: inevitably come to visit its victim. Therefore, the body is placed upon
title: Elementary Forms

text: a scaffolding; then, the ground under the corpse and all around it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: carefully smoothed off so that the slightest mark becomes easily
title: Elementary Forms

text: perceptible. They return the next day; if an animal has passed by there
title: Elementary Forms

text: during the interval, its tracks are readily recognizable. Their form
title: Elementary Forms

text: reveals the species to which it belongs, and from that, they infer the
title: Elementary Forms

text: social group of which the guilty man is a member. They say that it is a
title: Elementary Forms

text: man of such a class or such a clan,[852] according to whether the
title: Elementary Forms

text: animal is the totem of this or that class or clan. So the soul is
title: Elementary Forms

text: believed to have come in the form of the totemic animal.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In other societies where totemism has weakened or disappeared, the soul
title: Elementary Forms

text: still continues to be thought of in an animal form. The natives of Cape
title: Elementary Forms

text: Bedford (North Queensland) believe that the child, at the moment of
title: Elementary Forms

text: entering the body of its mother, is a curlew if it is a girl, or a snake
title: Elementary Forms

text: if it is a boy.[853] It is only later that it takes a human form. Many
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the Indians of North America, says the Prince of Wied, say that they
title: Elementary Forms

text: have an animal in their bodies.[854] The Bororo of Brazil represent the
title: Elementary Forms

text: soul in the form of a bird, and therefore believe that they are birds of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the same variety.[855] In other places, it is thought of as a snake, a
title: Elementary Forms

text: lizard, a fly, a bee, etc.[856]
title: Elementary Forms

text: But it is especially after death that this animal nature of the soul is
title: Elementary Forms

text: manifested. During life, this characteristic is partially veiled, as it
title: Elementary Forms

text: were, by the very form of the human body. But when death has once set it
title: Elementary Forms

text: free, it becomes itself again. Among the Omaha, in at least two of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Buffalo clans, it is believed that the souls of the dead go to rejoin
title: Elementary Forms

text: the buffalo, their ancestors.[857] The Hopi are divided into a certain
title: Elementary Forms

text: number of clans, whose ancestors were animals or beings with animal
title: Elementary Forms

text: forms. Now Schoolcraft tells us that they say that at death, they take
title: Elementary Forms

text: their original form again; each becomes a bear or deer, according to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: clan to which he belongs.[858] Very frequently the soul is believed to
title: Elementary Forms

text: reincarnate itself in the body of an animal.[859] It is probably from
title: Elementary Forms

text: this that the widely-spread doctrine of metempsychosis was derived. We
title: Elementary Forms

text: have already seen how hard pressed Tylor is to account for it.[860] If
title: Elementary Forms

text: the soul is an essentially human principle, what could be more curious
title: Elementary Forms

text: than this marked predilection which it shows, in so large a number of
title: Elementary Forms

text: societies, for the animal form? On the other hand, everything is
title: Elementary Forms

text: explained if, by its very constitution, the soul is closely related to
title: Elementary Forms

text: the animal, for in that case, when it returns to the animal world at the
title: Elementary Forms

text: close of this life, it is only returning to its real nature. Thus the
title: Elementary Forms

text: generality of the belief in metempsychosis is a new proof that the
title: Elementary Forms

text: constituent elements of the idea of the soul have been taken largely
title: Elementary Forms

text: from the animal kingdom, as is presupposed by the theory which we have
title: Elementary Forms

text: just set forth.
title: Elementary Forms

text: IV
title: Elementary Forms

text: Thus the notion of the soul is a particular application of the beliefs
title: Elementary Forms

text: relative to sacred beings. This is the explanation of the religious
title: Elementary Forms

text: character which this idea has had from the moment when it first appeared
title: Elementary Forms

text: in history, and which it still retains to-day. In fact, the soul has
title: Elementary Forms

text: always been considered a sacred thing; on this ground, it is opposed to
title: Elementary Forms

text: the body which is, in itself, profane. It is not merely distinguished
title: Elementary Forms

text: from its material envelope as the inside from the outside; it is not
title: Elementary Forms

text: merely represented as made out of a more subtle and fluid matter; but
title: Elementary Forms

text: more than this, it inspires those sentiments which are everywhere
title: Elementary Forms

text: reserved for that which is divine. If it is not made into a god, it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: at least regarded as a spark of the divinity. This essential
title: Elementary Forms

text: characteristic would be inexplicable if the idea of the soul were only a
title: Elementary Forms

text: pre-scientific solution given to the problem of dreams; for there is
title: Elementary Forms

text: nothing in the dream to awaken religious emotions, so the cause by which
title: Elementary Forms

text: these are explained could not have such a character. But if the soul is
title: Elementary Forms

text: a part of the divine substance, it represents something not ourselves
title: Elementary Forms

text: that is within us; if it is made of the same mental matter as the sacred
title: Elementary Forms

text: beings, it is natural that it should become the object of the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: sentiments.
title: Elementary Forms

text: And the sacred character which men thus attribute to themselves is not
title: Elementary Forms

text: the product of a pure illusion either; like the notions of religious
title: Elementary Forms

text: force and of divinity, the notion of the soul is not without a
title: Elementary Forms

text: foundation in reality. It is perfectly true that we are made up of two
title: Elementary Forms

text: distinct parts, which are opposed to one another as the sacred to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: profane, and we may say that, in a certain sense, there is divinity in
title: Elementary Forms

text: us. For society, this unique source of all that is sacred, does not
title: Elementary Forms

text: limit itself to moving us from without and affecting us for the moment;
title: Elementary Forms

text: it establishes itself within us in a durable manner. It arouses within
title: Elementary Forms

text: us a whole world of ideas and sentiments which express it but which, at
title: Elementary Forms

text: the same time, form an integral and permanent part of ourselves. When
title: Elementary Forms

text: the Australian goes away from a religious ceremony, the representations
title: Elementary Forms

text: which this communal life has aroused or re-aroused within him are not
title: Elementary Forms

text: obliterated in a second. The figures of the great ancestors, the heroic
title: Elementary Forms

text: exploits whose memory these rites perpetuate, the great deeds of every
title: Elementary Forms

text: sort in which he, too, has participated through the cult, in a word, all
title: Elementary Forms

text: these numerous ideals which he has elaborated with the co-operation of
title: Elementary Forms

text: his fellows, continue to live in his consciousness and, through the
title: Elementary Forms

text: emotions which are attached to them and the ascendancy which they hold
title: Elementary Forms

text: over his entire being, they are sharply distinguished from the vulgar
title: Elementary Forms

text: impressions arising from his daily relations with external things. Moral
title: Elementary Forms

text: ideas have the same character. It is society which forces them upon us,
title: Elementary Forms

text: and as the respect inspired by it is naturally extended to all that
title: Elementary Forms

text: comes from it, its imperative rules of conduct are invested, by reason
title: Elementary Forms

text: of their origin, with an authority and a dignity which is shared by none
title: Elementary Forms

text: of our internal states: therefore, we assign them a place apart in our
title: Elementary Forms

text: psychical life. Although our moral conscience is a part of our
title: Elementary Forms

text: consciousness, we do not feel ourselves on an equality with it. In this
title: Elementary Forms

text: voice which makes itself heard only to give us orders and establish
title: Elementary Forms

text: prohibitions, we cannot recognize our own voices; the very tone in which
title: Elementary Forms

text: it speaks to us warns us that it expresses something within us that is
title: Elementary Forms

text: not of ourselves. This is the objective foundation of the idea of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: soul: those representations whose flow constitutes our interior life are
title: Elementary Forms

text: of two different species which are irreducible one into another. Some
title: Elementary Forms

text: concern themselves with the external and material world; others, with an
title: Elementary Forms

text: ideal world to which we attribute a moral superiority over the first. So
title: Elementary Forms

text: we are really made up of two beings facing in different and almost
title: Elementary Forms

text: contrary directions, one of whom exercises a real pre-eminence over the
title: Elementary Forms

text: other. Such is the profound meaning of the antithesis which all men have
title: Elementary Forms

text: more or less clearly conceived between the body and the soul, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: material and the spiritual beings who coexist within us. Moralists and
title: Elementary Forms

text: preachers have often maintained that no one can deny the reality of duty
title: Elementary Forms

text: and its sacred character without falling into materialism. And it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: true that if we have no idea of moral and religious imperatives, our
title: Elementary Forms

text: psychical life will all be reduced to one level,[861] all our states of
title: Elementary Forms

text: consciousness will be on the same plane, and all feeling of duality
title: Elementary Forms

text: will perish. To make this duality intelligible, it is, of course, in no
title: Elementary Forms

text: way necessary to imagine a mysterious and unrepresentable substance,
title: Elementary Forms

text: under the name of the soul, which is opposed to the body. But here, as
title: Elementary Forms

text: in regard to the idea of sacredness, the error concerns the letter of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the symbol employed, not the reality of the fact symbolized. It remains
title: Elementary Forms

text: true that our nature is double; there really is a particle of divinity
title: Elementary Forms

text: in us because there is within us us a particle of these great ideas
title: Elementary Forms

text: which are the soul of the group.
title: Elementary Forms

text: So the individual soul is only a portion of the collective soul of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: group; it is the anonymous force at the basis of the cult, but
title: Elementary Forms

text: incarnated in an individual whose personality it espouses; it is _mana_
title: Elementary Forms

text: individualized. Perhaps dreams aided in determining certain secondary
title: Elementary Forms

text: characteristics of the idea. The inconsistency and instability of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: images which fill our minds during sleep, and their remarkable aptitude
title: Elementary Forms

text: for transforming themselves into one another, may have furnished the
title: Elementary Forms

text: model for this subtile, transparent and Protean matter out of which the
title: Elementary Forms

text: soul is believed to be made. Also, the facts of swooning, catalepsy,
title: Elementary Forms

text: etc., may have suggested the idea that the soul was mobile, and quitted
title: Elementary Forms

text: the body temporarily during this life; this, in its turn, has served to
title: Elementary Forms

text: explain certain dreams. But all these experiences and observations could
title: Elementary Forms

text: have had only a secondary and complimentary influence, whose very
title: Elementary Forms

text: existence it is difficult to establish. All that is really essential in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the idea comes from elsewhere.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But does not this genesis of the idea of the soul misunderstand its
title: Elementary Forms

text: essential characteristic? If the soul is a particular form of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: impersonal principle which is diffused in the group, the totemic species
title: Elementary Forms

text: and all the things of every sort which are attached to these, at bottom
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is impersonal itself. So, with differences only of degree, it should
title: Elementary Forms

text: have the same properties as the force of which it is a special form, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: particularly, the same diffusion, the same aptitude for spreading itself
title: Elementary Forms

text: contagiously and the same ubiquity. But quite on the contrary, the soul
title: Elementary Forms

text: is voluntarily represented as a concrete, definite being, wholly
title: Elementary Forms

text: contained within itself and not communicable to others; it is made the
title: Elementary Forms

text: basis of our personality.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But this way of conceiving the soul is the product of a late and
title: Elementary Forms

text: philosophic elaboration. The popular representation, as it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: spontaneously formed from common experience, is very different,
title: Elementary Forms

text: especially at first. For the Australian, the soul is a very vague
title: Elementary Forms

text: thing, undecided and wavering in form, and spread over the whole
title: Elementary Forms

text: organism. Though it manifests itself especially at certain points, there
title: Elementary Forms

text: are probably none from which it is totally absent. So it has a
title: Elementary Forms

text: diffusion, a contagiousness and an omnipresence comparable to those of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the _mana_. Like the mana, it is able to divide and duplicate itself
title: Elementary Forms

text: infinitely, though remaining entire in each of its parts; it is from
title: Elementary Forms

text: these divisions and duplications that the plurality of souls is derived.
title: Elementary Forms

text: On the other hand, the doctrine of reincarnation, whose generality we
title: Elementary Forms

text: have established, shows how many impersonal elements enter into the idea
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the soul and how essential those are. For if the same soul is going
title: Elementary Forms

text: to clothe a new personality in each generation, the individual forms in
title: Elementary Forms

text: which it successively develops itself must all be equally external to
title: Elementary Forms

text: it, and have nothing to do with its true nature. It is a sort of generic
title: Elementary Forms

text: substance which individualizes itself only secondarily and
title: Elementary Forms

text: superficially. Moreover, this conception of the soul is by no means
title: Elementary Forms

text: completely gone. The cult of relics shows that for a host of believers
title: Elementary Forms

text: even to-day, the soul of a saint, with all its essential powers,
title: Elementary Forms

text: continues to adhere to his different bones; and this implies that he is
title: Elementary Forms

text: believed to be able to diffuse himself, subdivide himself and
title: Elementary Forms

text: incorporate himself in all sorts of different things simultaneously.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Just as the characteristic attributes of the mana are found in the soul,
title: Elementary Forms

text: so secondary and superficial changes are enough to enable the mana to
title: Elementary Forms

text: individualize itself in the form of a soul. We pass from the first idea
title: Elementary Forms

text: to the second with no break of continuity. Every religious force which
title: Elementary Forms

text: is attached in a special way to a determined being participates in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: characteristics of this being, takes on its appearance and becomes its
title: Elementary Forms

text: spiritual double. Tregear, in his Maori-Polynesian dictionary, has
title: Elementary Forms

text: thought it possible to connect the word _mana_ with another group of
title: Elementary Forms

text: words, such as _manawa_, _manamana_, etc., which seem to belong to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: same family, and which signify heart, life, consciousness.[862] Is this
title: Elementary Forms

text: not equivalent to saying that some sort of kinship ought to exist
title: Elementary Forms

text: between the corresponding ideas as well, that is to say, between the
title: Elementary Forms

text: idea of impersonal force and those of internal life, mental force and,
title: Elementary Forms

text: in a word, of the soul? This is why the question whether the churinga is
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacred because it serves as the residence of a soul, as Spencer and
title: Elementary Forms

text: Gillen believe, or because it has impersonal virtues, as Strehlow
title: Elementary Forms

text: thinks, seems to us to have little interest and to be without
title: Elementary Forms

text: sociological importance. Whether the efficacy of a sacred object is
title: Elementary Forms

text: represented in an abstract form in the mind or is attributed to some
title: Elementary Forms

text: personal agent does not really matter. The psychological roots of both
title: Elementary Forms

text: beliefs are identical: an object is sacred because it inspires, in one
title: Elementary Forms

text: way or another, a collective sentiment of respect which removes it from
title: Elementary Forms

text: profane touches. In order to explain this sentiment, men sometimes fall
title: Elementary Forms

text: back on to a vague and imprecise cause, and sometimes on to a determined
title: Elementary Forms

text: spiritual being endowed with a name and a history; but these different
title: Elementary Forms

text: interpretations are superadded to one fundamental phenomenon which is
title: Elementary Forms

text: the same in both cases.
title: Elementary Forms

text: This, moreover, is what explains the singular confusions, examples of
title: Elementary Forms

text: which we have met with as we have progressed. The individual, the soul
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the ancestor which he reincarnates or from which his own is an
title: Elementary Forms

text: emanation, his churinga and the animals of the totemic species are, as
title: Elementary Forms

text: we have said, partially equivalent and interchangeable things. This is
title: Elementary Forms

text: because in certain connections, they all affect the collective
title: Elementary Forms

text: consciousness in the same way. If the churinga is sacred, it is because
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the collective sentiments of respect inspired by the totemic emblem
title: Elementary Forms

text: carved upon its surface; now the same sentiment attaches itself to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: animals or plants whose outward form is reproduced by the totem, to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: soul of the individual, for it is thought of in the form of the totemic
title: Elementary Forms

text: being, and finally to the ancestral soul, of which the preceding one is
title: Elementary Forms

text: only a particular aspect. So all these various objects, whether real or
title: Elementary Forms

text: ideal, have one common element by which they arouse a single affective
title: Elementary Forms

text: state in the mind, and through this, they become confused. In so far as
title: Elementary Forms

text: they are expressed by one and the same representation, they are
title: Elementary Forms

text: indistinct. This is how the Arunta has come to regard the churinga as
title: Elementary Forms

text: the body common to the individual, the ancestor and even the totemic
title: Elementary Forms

text: being. It is his way of expressing the identity of the sentiments of
title: Elementary Forms

text: which these different things are the object.
title: Elementary Forms

text: However, it does not follow from the fact the idea of the soul is
title: Elementary Forms

text: derived from the idea of mana that the first has a relatively later
title: Elementary Forms

text: origin, or that there was a period in history when men were acquainted
title: Elementary Forms

text: with religious forces only in their impersonal forms. When some wish to
title: Elementary Forms

text: designate by the word preanimist an historical period during which
title: Elementary Forms

text: animism was completely unknown, they build up an arbitrary
title: Elementary Forms

text: hypothesis;[863] for there is no people among whom the ideas of the soul
title: Elementary Forms

text: and of mana do not coexist side by side. So there is no ground for
title: Elementary Forms

text: imagining that they were formed at two distinct times; everything, on
title: Elementary Forms

text: the contrary, goes to show that the two are coeval. Just as there is no
title: Elementary Forms

text: society without individuals, so those impersonal forces which are
title: Elementary Forms

text: disengaged from the group cannot establish themselves without
title: Elementary Forms

text: incarnating themselves in the individual consciousnesses where they
title: Elementary Forms

text: individualize themselves. In reality, we do not have two different
title: Elementary Forms

text: developments, but two different aspects of one and the same development.
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is true that they do not have an equal importance; one is more
title: Elementary Forms

text: essential than the other. The idea of mana does not presuppose the idea
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the soul; for if the mana is going to individualize itself and break
title: Elementary Forms

text: itself up into the particular souls, it must first of all exist, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: what it is in itself does not depend upon the forms it takes when
title: Elementary Forms

text: individualized. But on the contrary, the idea of the soul cannot be
title: Elementary Forms

text: understood except when taken in connection with the idea of mana. So on
title: Elementary Forms

text: this ground, it is possible to say that it is the result of a secondary
title: Elementary Forms

text: formation; but we are speaking of a secondary formation in the logical,
title: Elementary Forms

text: not the chronological, sense of the word.
title: Elementary Forms

text: V
title: Elementary Forms

text: But how does it come that men have believed that the soul survives the
title: Elementary Forms

text: body and is even able to do so for an indefinite length of time?
title: Elementary Forms

text: From the analysis which we have made, it is evident that the belief in
title: Elementary Forms

text: immortality has not been established under the influence of moral ideas.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Men have not imagined the prolongation of their existence beyond the
title: Elementary Forms

text: tomb in order that a just retribution for moral acts may be assured in
title: Elementary Forms

text: another life, if it fails in this one; for we have seen that all
title: Elementary Forms

text: considerations of this sort are foreign to the primitive conception of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the beyond.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Nor is the other hypothesis any better, according to which the other
title: Elementary Forms

text: life was imagined as a means of escaping the agonizing prospect of
title: Elementary Forms

text: annihilation. In the first place, it is not true that the need of
title: Elementary Forms

text: personal survival was actively felt at the beginning. The primitive
title: Elementary Forms

text: generally accepts the idea of death with a sort of indifference. Being
title: Elementary Forms

text: trained to count his own individuality for little, and being accustomed
title: Elementary Forms

text: to exposing his life constantly, he gives it up easily enough.[864] More
title: Elementary Forms

text: than that, the immortality promised by the religions he practices is not
title: Elementary Forms

text: personal. In a large number of cases, the soul does not continue the
title: Elementary Forms

text: personality of the dead man, or does not continue it long, for,
title: Elementary Forms

text: forgetful of its previous existence, it goes away, after a while, to
title: Elementary Forms

text: animate another body and thus becomes the vivifying principle of a new
title: Elementary Forms

text: personality. Even among the most advanced peoples, it was only a pale
title: Elementary Forms

text: and sad existence that shades led in Sheol or Erebus, and could hardly
title: Elementary Forms

text: attenuate the regrets occasioned by the memories of the life lost.
title: Elementary Forms

text: A more satisfactory explanation is the one attaching the conception of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: posthumous life to the experiences of dreams. Our dead friends and
title: Elementary Forms

text: relatives reappear to us in dreams: we see them act, we hear them speak;
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is natural to conclude that they continue to exist. But if these
title: Elementary Forms

text: observations were able to confirm the idea after it had once been born,
title: Elementary Forms

text: they hardly seem capable of creating it out of nothing. Dreams in which
title: Elementary Forms

text: we see departed persons living again are too rare and too short and
title: Elementary Forms

text: leave only too vague recollections of themselves, to have been able to
title: Elementary Forms

text: suggest so important a system of beliefs to men all by themselves. There
title: Elementary Forms

text: is a remarkable lack of proportion between the effect and the cause to
title: Elementary Forms

text: which it is attributed.
title: Elementary Forms

text: What makes this question embarrassing is the fact that in itself, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: idea of the soul does not imply that of its survival, but rather seems
title: Elementary Forms

text: to exclude it. In fact, we have seen that the soul, though being
title: Elementary Forms

text: distinguished from the body, is believed, nevertheless, to be closely
title: Elementary Forms

text: united to it: it ages along with the body, it feels a reaction from all
title: Elementary Forms

text: the maladies that fall upon the body; so it would seem natural that it
title: Elementary Forms

text: should die with the body. At least, men ought to have believed that it
title: Elementary Forms

text: ceased to exist from the moment when it definitely lost its original
title: Elementary Forms

text: form, and when it was no longer what it had been. Yet it is at just this
title: Elementary Forms

text: moment that a new life opens out before it.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The myths which we have already described give the only possible
title: Elementary Forms

text: explanation of this belief. We have seen that the souls of new-born
title: Elementary Forms

text: children are either emanations of the ancestral souls, or these souls
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves reincarnated. But in order that they may either reincarnate
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves, or periodically give off new emanations, they must have
title: Elementary Forms

text: survived their first holders. So it seems as though they admitted the
title: Elementary Forms

text: survival of the dead in order to explain the birth of the living. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: primitive does not have the idea of an all-powerful god who creates
title: Elementary Forms

text: souls out of nothing. It seems to him that souls cannot be made except
title: Elementary Forms

text: out of souls. So those who are born can only be new forms of those who
title: Elementary Forms

text: have been; consequently, it is necessary that these latter continue to
title: Elementary Forms

text: exist in order that others may be born. In fine, the belief in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: immortality of the soul is the only way in which men were able to
title: Elementary Forms

text: explain a fact which could not fail to attract their attention; this
title: Elementary Forms

text: fact is the perpetuity of the life of the group. Individuals die, but
title: Elementary Forms

text: the clan survives. So the forces which give it life must have the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: perpetuity. Now these forces are the souls which animate individual
title: Elementary Forms

text: bodies; for it is in them and through them that the group is realized.
title: Elementary Forms

text: For this reason, it is necessary that they endure. It is even necessary
title: Elementary Forms

text: that in enduring, they remain always the same; for, as the clan always
title: Elementary Forms

text: keeps its characteristic appearance, the spiritual substance out of
title: Elementary Forms

text: which it is made must be thought of as qualitatively invariable. Since
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is always the same clan with the same totemic principle, it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: necessary that the souls be the same, for souls are only the totemic
title: Elementary Forms

text: principle broken up and particularized. Thus there is something like a
title: Elementary Forms

text: germinative plasm, of a mystic order, which is transmitted from
title: Elementary Forms

text: generation to generation and which makes, or at least is believed to
title: Elementary Forms

text: make, the spiritual unity of the clan through all time. And this belief,
title: Elementary Forms

text: in spite of its symbolic character, is not without a certain objective
title: Elementary Forms

text: truth. For though the group may not be immortal in the absolute sense of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the word, still it is true that it endures longer than the individuals
title: Elementary Forms

text: and that it is born and incarnated afresh in each new generation.
title: Elementary Forms

text: A fact confirms this interpretation. We have seen that according to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: testimony of Strehlow, the Arunta distinguish two sorts of souls: on the
title: Elementary Forms

text: one hand are those of the ancestors of the Alcheringa, on the other,
title: Elementary Forms

text: those of the individuals who actually compose the active body of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: tribe at each moment in history. The second sort only survive the body
title: Elementary Forms

text: for a relatively short time; they are soon totally annihilated. Only the
title: Elementary Forms

text: former are immortal; as they are uncreated, so they do not perish. It is
title: Elementary Forms

text: also to be noticed that they are the only ones whose immortality is
title: Elementary Forms

text: necessary to explain the permanence of the group; for it is upon them,
title: Elementary Forms

text: and upon them alone, that it is incumbent to assure the perpetuity of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the clan, for every conception is their work. In this connection, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: others have no part to play. So souls are not said to be immortal except
title: Elementary Forms

text: in so far as this immortality is useful in rendering intelligible the
title: Elementary Forms

text: continuity of the collective life.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Thus the causes leading to the first beliefs in a future life had no
title: Elementary Forms

text: connections with the functions to be filled at a later period by the
title: Elementary Forms

text: institutions beyond the tomb. But when that had once appeared, they were
title: Elementary Forms

text: soon utilized for other purposes besides those which had been their
title: Elementary Forms

text: original reasons for existence. Even in the Australian societies, we see
title: Elementary Forms

text: them beginning to organize themselves for this other purpose. Moreover,
title: Elementary Forms

text: there was no need of any fundamental transformation for this. How true
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is that the same social institution can successively fulfil different
title: Elementary Forms

text: functions without changing its nature!
title: Elementary Forms

text: VI
title: Elementary Forms

text: The idea of the soul was for a long time, and still is in part, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: popular form of the idea of personality.[865] So the genesis of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: former of these ideas should aid us in understanding how the second one
title: Elementary Forms

text: was formed.
title: Elementary Forms

text: From what has already been said, it is clear that the notion of person
title: Elementary Forms

text: is the product of two sorts of factors. One of these is essentially
title: Elementary Forms

text: impersonal: it is the spiritual principle serving as the soul of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: group. In fact, it is this which constitutes the very substance of
title: Elementary Forms

text: individual souls. Now this is not the possession of any one in
title: Elementary Forms

text: particular: it is a part of the collective patrimony; in it and through
title: Elementary Forms

text: it, all consciousnesses communicate. But on the other hand, in order to
title: Elementary Forms

text: have separate personalities, it is necessary that another factor
title: Elementary Forms

text: intervene to break up and differentiate this principle: in other words,
title: Elementary Forms

text: an individualizing factor is necessary. It is the body that fulfils this
title: Elementary Forms

text: function. As bodies are distinct from each other, and as they occupy
title: Elementary Forms

text: different points of space and time, each of them forms a special centre
title: Elementary Forms

text: about which the collective representations reflect and colour themselves
title: Elementary Forms

text: differently. The result is that even if all the consciousnesses in these
title: Elementary Forms

text: bodies are directed towards the same world, to wit, the world of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: ideas and sentiments which brings about the moral unity of the group,
title: Elementary Forms

text: they do not all see it from the same angle; each one expresses it in its
title: Elementary Forms

text: own fashion.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Of these two equally indispensable factors, the former is certainly not
title: Elementary Forms

text: the less important, for this is the one which furnishes the original
title: Elementary Forms

text: matter for the idea of the soul. Perhaps some will be surprised to see
title: Elementary Forms

text: so considerable a role attributed to the impersonal element in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: genesis of the idea of personality. But the philosophical analysis of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the idea of person, which has gone far ahead of the sociological
title: Elementary Forms

text: analysis, has reached analogous results on this point. Among all the
title: Elementary Forms

text: philosophers, Leibniz is one of those who have felt most vividly what a
title: Elementary Forms

text: personality is; for before all, the nomad is a personal and autonomous
title: Elementary Forms

text: being. Yet, for Leibniz, the contents of all the monads is identical. In
title: Elementary Forms

text: fact, all are consciousnesses which express one and the same object, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: world; and as the world itself is only a system of representations, each
title: Elementary Forms

text: particular consciousness is really only the reflection of the universal
title: Elementary Forms

text: consciousness. However, each one expresses it from its own point of
title: Elementary Forms

text: view, and in its own manner. We know how this difference of perspectives
title: Elementary Forms

text: comes from the fact that the monads are situated differently in
title: Elementary Forms

text: relation to each other and to the whole system which they constitute.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Kant expresses the same sentiment, though in a different form. For him,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the corner-stone of the personality is the will. Now the will is the
title: Elementary Forms

text: faculty of acting in conformity with reason, and the reason is that
title: Elementary Forms

text: which is most impersonal within us. For reason is not my reason; it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: human reason in general. It is the power which the mind has of rising
title: Elementary Forms

text: above the particular, the contingent and the individual, to think in
title: Elementary Forms

text: universal forms. So from this point of view, we may say that what makes
title: Elementary Forms

text: a man a personality is that by which he is confounded with other men,
title: Elementary Forms

text: that which makes him a man, not a certain man. The senses, the body and,
title: Elementary Forms

text: in a word, all that individualizes, is, on the contrary, considered as
title: Elementary Forms

text: the antagonist of the personality by Kant.
title: Elementary Forms

text: This is because individuation is not the essential characteristic of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: personality. A person is not merely a single subject distinguished from
title: Elementary Forms

text: all the others. It is especially a being to which is attributed a
title: Elementary Forms

text: relative autonomy in relation to the environment with which it is most
title: Elementary Forms

text: immediately in contact. It is represented as capable of moving itself,
title: Elementary Forms

text: to a certain degree: this is what Leibniz expressed in an exaggerated
title: Elementary Forms

text: way when he said that the monad was completely closed to the outside.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Now our analysis permits us to see how this conception was formed and to
title: Elementary Forms

text: what it corresponds.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In fact, the soul, a symbolic representation of the personality, has the
title: Elementary Forms

text: same characteristic. Although closely bound to the body, it is believed
title: Elementary Forms

text: to be profoundly distinct from it and to enjoy, in relation to it, a
title: Elementary Forms

text: large degree of independence. During life, it may leave it temporarily,
title: Elementary Forms

text: and it definitely withdraws at death. Far from being dependent upon the
title: Elementary Forms

text: body, it dominates it from the higher dignity which is in it. It may
title: Elementary Forms

text: well take from the body the outward form in which it individualizes
title: Elementary Forms

text: itself, but it owes nothing essential to it. Nor is the autonomy which
title: Elementary Forms

text: all peoples have attributed to the soul a pure illusion; we know now
title: Elementary Forms

text: what its objective foundation is. It is quite true that the elements
title: Elementary Forms

text: which serve to form the idea of the soul and those which enter into the
title: Elementary Forms

text: representation of the body come from two different sources that are
title: Elementary Forms

text: independent of one another. One sort are made up of the images and
title: Elementary Forms

text: impressions coming from all parts of the organism; the others consist in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the ideas and sentiments which come from and express society. So the
title: Elementary Forms

text: former are not derived from the latter. There really is a part of
title: Elementary Forms

text: ourselves which is not placed in immediate dependence upon the organic
title: Elementary Forms

text: factor: this is all that which represents society in us. The general
title: Elementary Forms

text: ideas which religion or science fix in our minds, the mental operations
title: Elementary Forms

text: which these ideas suppose, the beliefs and sentiments which are at the
title: Elementary Forms

text: basis of our moral life, and all these superior forms of psychical
title: Elementary Forms

text: activity which society awakens in us, these do not follow in the trail
title: Elementary Forms

text: of our bodily states, as our sensations and our general bodily
title: Elementary Forms

text: consciousness do. As we have already shown, this is because the world of
title: Elementary Forms

text: representations in which social life passes is superimposed upon its
title: Elementary Forms

text: material substratum, far from arising from it; the determinism which
title: Elementary Forms

text: reigns there is much more supple than the one whose roots are in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: constitution of our tissues and it leaves with the actor a justified
title: Elementary Forms

text: impression of the greatest liberty. The medium in which we thus move is
title: Elementary Forms

text: less opaque and less resistant: we feel ourselves to be, and we are,
title: Elementary Forms

text: more at our ease there. In a word, the only way we have of freeing
title: Elementary Forms

text: ourselves from physical forces is to oppose them with collective forces.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But whatever we receive from society, we hold in common with our
title: Elementary Forms

text: companions. So it is not at all true that we are more personal as we are
title: Elementary Forms

text: more individualized. The two terms are in no way synonymous: in one
title: Elementary Forms

text: sense, they oppose more than they imply one another. Passion
title: Elementary Forms

text: individualizes, yet it also enslaves. Our sensations are essentially
title: Elementary Forms

text: individual; yet we are more personal the more we are freed from our
title: Elementary Forms

text: senses and able to think and act with concepts. So those who insist upon
title: Elementary Forms

text: all the social elements of the individual do not mean by that to deny or
title: Elementary Forms

text: debase the personality. They merely refuse to confuse it with the fact
title: Elementary Forms

text: of individuation.[866]
title: Elementary Forms

text: CHAPTER IX
title: Elementary Forms

text: THE IDEA OF SPIRITS AND GODS
title: Elementary Forms

text: When we come to the idea of the soul, we have left the circle of purely
title: Elementary Forms

text: impersonal forces. But above the soul the Australian religions already
title: Elementary Forms

text: recognize mythical personalities of a superior order: spirits,
title: Elementary Forms

text: civilizing heroes and even gods who are properly so-called. While it
title: Elementary Forms

text: will be unnecessary to enter into the detail of the mythologies, we must
title: Elementary Forms

text: at least seek the form in which these three categories of spiritual
title: Elementary Forms

text: beings are presented in Australia, and the way in which they are
title: Elementary Forms

text: connected with the whole religious system.
title: Elementary Forms

text: I
title: Elementary Forms

text: A soul is not a spirit. In fact, it is shut up in a determined organism;
title: Elementary Forms

text: though it may leave it at certain moments, it is ordinarily a prisoner
title: Elementary Forms

text: there. It definitely escapes only at death, and we have already seen the
title: Elementary Forms

text: difficulties under which the separation is accomplished. A spirit, on
title: Elementary Forms

text: the contrary, though often tied by the closest bonds to some particular
title: Elementary Forms

text: object, such as a spring, a rock, a tree, a star, etc., and though
title: Elementary Forms

text: residing there by preference, may go away at will and lead an
title: Elementary Forms

text: independent existence in free space. So it has a more extended circle of
title: Elementary Forms

text: action. It can act upon the individuals who approach it or whom it
title: Elementary Forms

text: approaches. The soul, on the contrary, has almost no influence except
title: Elementary Forms

text: over the body it animates; it is very exceptional that it succeeds in
title: Elementary Forms

text: influencing outside objects during the course of its terrestrial life.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But if the soul does not have the distinctive characteristics of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: spirit, it acquires them, at least in part, at death. In fact, when it
title: Elementary Forms

text: has been disincarnated, so long as it does not descend into a body
title: Elementary Forms

text: again, it has the same liberty of movement as a spirit. Of course, after
title: Elementary Forms

text: the rites of mourning have been accomplished, it is thought to go to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: land of souls, but before this it remains about the tomb for a rather
title: Elementary Forms

text: long time. Also, even after it has definitely departed, it is believed
title: Elementary Forms

text: to prowl about in the brush near the camp.[867] It is generally
title: Elementary Forms

text: represented as a rather beneficent being, especially for the surviving
title: Elementary Forms

text: members of its family; we have seen that the soul of the father comes to
title: Elementary Forms

text: aid the growth of his children or his grandchildren. But it also happens
title: Elementary Forms

text: sometimes that it shows signs of a veritable cruelty; everything depends
title: Elementary Forms

text: upon its humour and the manner in which it is treated by the
title: Elementary Forms

text: living.[868] So it is recommended, especially to women and children, not
title: Elementary Forms

text: to venture outside of the camp during the night so as not to expose
title: Elementary Forms

text: oneself to dangerous encounters.[869]
title: Elementary Forms

text: However, a ghost is not a real spirit. In the first place, it generally
title: Elementary Forms

text: has only a limited power of action; also, it does not have a definite
title: Elementary Forms

text: province. It is a vagabond, upon whom no determined task is incumbent,
title: Elementary Forms

text: for the effect of death has been to put it outside of all regular forms;
title: Elementary Forms

text: as regards the living, it is a sort of a exile. A spirit, on the other
title: Elementary Forms

text: hand, always has a power of a certain sort and it is by this that it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: defined; it is set over a certain order of cosmic or social phenomena;
title: Elementary Forms

text: it has a more or less precise function to fulfil in the system of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: universe.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But there are some souls which satisfy this double condition and which
title: Elementary Forms

text: are consequently spirits, in the proper sense of the word. These are the
title: Elementary Forms

text: souls of the mythical personages whom popular imagination has placed at
title: Elementary Forms

text: the beginning of time, the Altjirangamitjina or the men of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Alcheringa among the Arunta; the Mura-mura among the tribes of Lake
title: Elementary Forms

text: Eyre; the Muk-Kurnai among the Kurnai, etc. In one sense, they are still
title: Elementary Forms

text: souls, for they are believed to have formerly animated bodies from which
title: Elementary Forms

text: they separated themselves at a certain moment. But even when they led a
title: Elementary Forms

text: terrestrial life, they already had, as we have seen, exceptional powers;
title: Elementary Forms

text: they had a mana superior to that of ordinary men, and they have kept it.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Also, they are charged with definite functions.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In the first place, whether we accept the version of Spencer and Gillen
title: Elementary Forms

text: or that of Strehlow, it is to them that the care of assuring the
title: Elementary Forms

text: periodical recruiting of the clan falls. They have charge of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: phenomena of conception.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Even when the conception has been accomplished, the task of the ancestor
title: Elementary Forms

text: is not yet completed. It is his duty to guard over the new-born child.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Later, when the child has become a man, he accompanies him in the hunt,
title: Elementary Forms

text: brings game to him, warns him by dreams of the dangers he may run,
title: Elementary Forms

text: protects him against his enemies, etc. On this point, Strehlow is
title: Elementary Forms

text: entirely in accord with Spencer and Gillen.[870] It is true that someone
title: Elementary Forms

text: may ask how it is possible, according to the version of these latter,
