title: Elementary Forms

text: for the ancestor to fulfil this function; for, since he reincarnates
title: Elementary Forms

text: himself at the moment of conception, it seems as though he should be
title: Elementary Forms

text: confounded with the soul of the child and should therefore be unable to
title: Elementary Forms

text: protect it from without. But the fact is that he does not reincarnate
title: Elementary Forms

text: himself entirely; he merely duplicates himself. One part of him enters
title: Elementary Forms

text: the body of the woman and fertilizes her; another part continues to
title: Elementary Forms

text: exist outside and, under the special name of Arumburinga, fulfils the
title: Elementary Forms

text: office of guardian genius.[871]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Thus we see how great a kinship there is between this ancestral spirit
title: Elementary Forms

text: and the _genius_ of the Latins or the [Greek: daimon] of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Greeks.[872] The identification of function is complete. In fact, at
title: Elementary Forms

text: first the genius is the one who begets, _qui gignit_; he expresses and
title: Elementary Forms

text: personifies the powers of generation.[873] But at the same time, he is
title: Elementary Forms

text: the protector and director of the particular individual to whose person
title: Elementary Forms

text: he is attached.[874] He is finally confused with the personality itself
title: Elementary Forms

text: of this individual; he represents the totality of the proclivities and
title: Elementary Forms

text: tendencies which characterize him and give him a distinctive appearance
title: Elementary Forms

text: among other men.[875] Hence come the well-known expressions _indulgere
title: Elementary Forms

text: genio_, _defraudere genium_ with the sense of _to follow one's natural
title: Elementary Forms

text: temperament_. At bottom, the _genius_ is another form or double of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: soul of the individual. This is proved by the partial synonomy of
title: Elementary Forms

text: _genius_ and _manes_.[876] The manes is the genius after death; but it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is also all that survives of the dead man, that is to say, his soul. In
title: Elementary Forms

text: the same way, the soul of the Arunta and the ancestral spirit which
title: Elementary Forms

text: serves as his genius are only two different aspects of one and the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: being.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But it is not only in relation to persons that the ancestor has a
title: Elementary Forms

text: definite situation; he also has one in relation to things. Though he is
title: Elementary Forms

text: believed to have his real residence under the ground, they think that he
title: Elementary Forms

text: is always haunting the place where his nanja-tree or rock is, or the
title: Elementary Forms

text: water-hole which was spontaneously formed at the exact spot where he
title: Elementary Forms

text: disappeared into the ground, having terminated his first existence. As
title: Elementary Forms

text: this tree or rock is believed to represent the body of the hero, they
title: Elementary Forms

text: imagine that the soul itself is constantly coming back there, and lives
title: Elementary Forms

text: there more or less permanently; it is by the presence of this soul that
title: Elementary Forms

text: they explain the religious respect inspired by these localities. No one
title: Elementary Forms

text: can break the branch of a nanja-tree without a risk of falling
title: Elementary Forms

text: sick.[877] "Formerly the act of breaking it down or injuring it was
title: Elementary Forms

text: punished with death. An animal or bird taking refuge there could not be
title: Elementary Forms

text: killed. Even the surrounding bushes had to be respected: the grass could
title: Elementary Forms

text: not be burned, the rocks also had to be treated with respect. It was
title: Elementary Forms

text: forbidden to remove them or break them."[878] As this sacred character
title: Elementary Forms

text: is attributed to the ancestor, he appears as the spirit of this tree or
title: Elementary Forms

text: rock, of this water-hole or spring.[879] If the spring is thought of as
title: Elementary Forms

text: having some connection with rain,[880] he will become a spirit of rain.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Thus, the same souls which serve as protecting geniuses for men also
title: Elementary Forms

text: fulfil cosmic functions at the same time. It is undoubtedly in this
title: Elementary Forms

text: sense that we must understand the text of Roth where he says that in
title: Elementary Forms

text: northern Queensland, the spirits of nature are the souls of the dead who
title: Elementary Forms

text: have chosen to live in the forests or caves.[881]
title: Elementary Forms

text: So we have here some spiritual beings that are different from the
title: Elementary Forms

text: wandering souls with no definite powers. Strehlow calls them gods;[882]
title: Elementary Forms

text: but this expression is inexact, at least in the great majority of cases.
title: Elementary Forms

text: If it were true, then in a society like the Arunta where each one has
title: Elementary Forms

text: his protecting ancestor, there would be as many or more gods than there
title: Elementary Forms

text: are individuals. It would merely introduce confusion into our
title: Elementary Forms

text: terminology to give the name of god to a sacred being with only one
title: Elementary Forms

text: worshipper. It may be, of course, that the figure of the ancestor grows
title: Elementary Forms

text: to a point where it resembles a real divinity. Among the Warramunga, as
title: Elementary Forms

text: we have already pointed out,[883] the clan as a whole is thought to be
title: Elementary Forms

text: descended from one sole and unique ancestor. It is easily seen how this
title: Elementary Forms

text: collective ancestor might, under certain circumstances, become the
title: Elementary Forms

text: object of a collective devotion. To choose a notable example, this is
title: Elementary Forms

text: what has happened to the snake Wollunqua.[884] This mythical beast, from
title: Elementary Forms

text: whom the clan of the same name is held to be descended, continues to
title: Elementary Forms

text: live, they believe, in water-holes which are therefore surrounded with
title: Elementary Forms

text: a religious respect. Thus it becomes the object of a cult which the clan
title: Elementary Forms

text: celebrates collectively: through determined rites, they attempt to
title: Elementary Forms

text: please him and to win his favours, and they address to him all sorts of
title: Elementary Forms

text: prayers, etc. So we may say that he is like a god of the clan. But this
title: Elementary Forms

text: is a very exceptional case, or even, according to Spencer and Gillen, a
title: Elementary Forms

text: unique one. Normally, the word "spirits" is the only one suitable for
title: Elementary Forms

text: designating these ancestral personages.
title: Elementary Forms

text: As to the manner in which this conception has been formed, we may say
title: Elementary Forms

text: that it is evident from what has preceded.
title: Elementary Forms

text: As we have already shown, the existence of individual souls, when once
title: Elementary Forms

text: admitted, cannot be understood unless one imagines an original supply of
title: Elementary Forms

text: fundamental souls at the origin of things, from which all the others
title: Elementary Forms

text: were derived. Now these architype souls had to be conceived as
title: Elementary Forms

text: containing within them the source of all religious efficacy; for, since
title: Elementary Forms

text: the imagination does not go beyond them, it is from them and only from
title: Elementary Forms

text: them that all sacred things are believed to come, both the instruments
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the cult, the members of the clan and the animals of the totemic
title: Elementary Forms

text: species. They incarnate all the sacredness diffused in the whole tribe
title: Elementary Forms

text: and the whole world, and so they are attributed powers noticeably
title: Elementary Forms

text: superior to those enjoyed by the simple souls of men. Moreover, time by
title: Elementary Forms

text: itself increases and reinforces the sacred character of things. A very
title: Elementary Forms

text: ancient churinga inspires much more respect than a new one, and is
title: Elementary Forms

text: supposed to have more virtues.[885] The sentiments of veneration of
title: Elementary Forms

text: which it has been the object during the series of successive generations
title: Elementary Forms

text: who have handled it are, as it were, accumulated in it. For the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: reason, the personages who for centuries have been the subject of myths
title: Elementary Forms

text: respectfully passed on from mouth to mouth, and periodically put into
title: Elementary Forms

text: action by the rites, could not fail to take a very especial place in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: popular imagination.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But how does it happen that, instead of remaining outside of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: organized society, they have become regular members of it?
title: Elementary Forms

text: This is because each individual is the double of an ancestor. Now when
title: Elementary Forms

text: two beings are related as closely as this, they are naturally conceived
title: Elementary Forms

text: as incorporated together; since they participate in the same nature, it
title: Elementary Forms

text: seems as though that which affects one ought to affect the other as
title: Elementary Forms

text: well. Thus the group of mythical ancestors became attached to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: society of the living; the same interests and the same passions were
title: Elementary Forms

text: attributed to each; they were regarded as associates. However, as the
title: Elementary Forms

text: former had a higher dignity than the latter, this association takes, in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the public mind, the form of an agreement between superiors and
title: Elementary Forms

text: inferiors, between patrons and clients, benefactors and recipients. Thus
title: Elementary Forms

text: comes this curious idea of a protecting genius who is attached to each
title: Elementary Forms

text: individual.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The question of how this ancestor came to have relations not only with
title: Elementary Forms

text: men, but also with things, may appear more embarrassing; for, at the
title: Elementary Forms

text: first glance, we do not see what connection there can be between a
title: Elementary Forms

text: personage of this sort and a rock or tree. But a fact which we owe to
title: Elementary Forms

text: Strehlow furnishes us with a solution of this problem, which is at least
title: Elementary Forms

text: probable.
title: Elementary Forms

text: These trees and rocks are not situated at any point in the tribal
title: Elementary Forms

text: territory, but, for the most part, they are grouped around the
title: Elementary Forms

text: sanctuaries, called ertnatulunga by Spencer and Gillen and arknanaua by
title: Elementary Forms

text: Strehlow, where the churinga of the clan is kept.[886] We know the
title: Elementary Forms

text: respect with which these localities are enhaloed from the mere fact that
title: Elementary Forms

text: the most precious instruments of the cult are there. Each of these
title: Elementary Forms

text: spreads sanctity all about it. It is for this reason that the
title: Elementary Forms

text: neighbouring trees and rocks appear sacred, that it is forbidden to
title: Elementary Forms

text: destroy or harm them, and that all violence used against them is a
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacrilege. This sacred character is really due to a simple phenomenon of
title: Elementary Forms

text: psychic contagiousness; but in order to explain it, the native must
title: Elementary Forms

text: admit that these different objects have relations with the different
title: Elementary Forms

text: beings in whom he sees the source of all religious power, that is to
title: Elementary Forms

text: say, with the ancestors of the Alcheringa. Hence comes the system of
title: Elementary Forms

text: myths of which we have spoken. They imagined that each ertnatulunga
title: Elementary Forms

text: marked the spot where a group of ancestors entered into the ground. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: mounds or trees which covered the ground were believed to represent
title: Elementary Forms

text: their bodies. But as the soul retains, in a general way, a sort of
title: Elementary Forms

text: affinity for the body in which it dwelt, they were naturally led to
title: Elementary Forms

text: believe that these ancestral souls continued to frequent these places
title: Elementary Forms

text: where their material envelope remained. So they were located in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: rocks, the trees or the water-holes. Thus each of them, though remaining
title: Elementary Forms

text: attached to some determined individual, became transformed into a sort
title: Elementary Forms

text: of _genius loci_ and fulfilled its functions.[887]
title: Elementary Forms

text: The conceptions thus elucidated enable us to understand a form of
title: Elementary Forms

text: totemism which we have left unexplained up to the present: this is
title: Elementary Forms

text: individual totemism.
title: Elementary Forms

text: An individual totem is defined, in its essence, by the two following
title: Elementary Forms

text: characteristics: (1) it is a being in an animal or vegetable form whose
title: Elementary Forms

text: function is to protect an individual; (2) the fate of this individual
title: Elementary Forms

text: and that of his patron are closely united: all that touches the latter
title: Elementary Forms

text: is sympathetically communicated to the former. Now the ancestral spirits
title: Elementary Forms

text: of which we have just been speaking answer to this same definition. They
title: Elementary Forms

text: also belong, at least in part, to the animal or vegetable kingdoms.
title: Elementary Forms

text: They, too, are protecting geniuses. Finally, a sympathetic bond unites
title: Elementary Forms

text: each individual to his protecting ancestor. In fact, the nanja-tree,
title: Elementary Forms

text: representing the mystical body of this ancestor, cannot be destroyed
title: Elementary Forms

text: without the man's feeling himself menaced. It is true that this belief
title: Elementary Forms

text: is losing its force to-day, but Spencer and Gillen have observed it, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: in any case, they are of the opinion that formerly it was quite
title: Elementary Forms

text: general.[888]
title: Elementary Forms

text: The identity of these two conceptions is found even in their details.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The ancestral souls reside in trees or rocks which are considered
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacred. Likewise, among the Euahlayi, the spirit of the animal serving
title: Elementary Forms

text: as individual totem is believed to inhabit a tree or stone.[889] This
title: Elementary Forms

text: tree or stone is sacred; no one may touch it except the proprietor of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the totem; when it is a stone or rock, this interdiction is still
title: Elementary Forms

text: absolute.[890] The result is that they are veritable places of refuge.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Finally, we have seen that the individual soul is only another aspect of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the ancestral spirit, according to Strehlow, this serves after a
title: Elementary Forms

text: fashion, as a second self.[891] Likewise, following an expression of
title: Elementary Forms

text: Mrs. Parker, the individual totem of the Euahlayi, called Yunbeai, is
title: Elementary Forms

text: the _alter ego_ of the individual: "The soul of a man is in his Yunbeai
title: Elementary Forms

text: and the soul of his Yunbeai is in him."[892] So at bottom, it is one
title: Elementary Forms

text: soul in two bodies. The kinship of these two notions is so close that
title: Elementary Forms

text: they are sometimes expressed by one and the same word. This is the case
title: Elementary Forms

text: in Melanesia and in Polynesia: _atai_ in the island Mota, _tamaniu_ in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the island Aurora, and _talegia_ in Motlaw all designate both the soul
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the individual and his personal totem.[893] It is the same with
title: Elementary Forms

text: _aitu_ in Samoa.[894] This is because the individual totem is merely
title: Elementary Forms

text: the outward and visible form of the ego or the personality, of which the
title: Elementary Forms

text: soul is the inward and invisible form.[895]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Thus the individual totem has all the essential characteristics of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: protecting ancestor and fills the same role: this is because it has the
title: Elementary Forms

text: same origin and proceeds from the same idea.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Each of them, in fact, consists in a duplication of the soul. The totem,
title: Elementary Forms

text: as the ancestor, is the soul of the individual, but externalized and
title: Elementary Forms

text: invested with powers superior to those it is believed to possess while
title: Elementary Forms

text: within the organism. Now this duplication is the result of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: psychological necessity; for it only expresses the nature of the soul
title: Elementary Forms

text: which, as we have seen, is double. In one sense, it is ours: it
title: Elementary Forms

text: expresses our personality. But at the same time, it is outside of us,
title: Elementary Forms

text: for it is only the reaching into us of a religious force which is
title: Elementary Forms

text: outside of us. We cannot confound ourselves with it completely, for we
title: Elementary Forms

text: attribute to it an excellence and a dignity by which it rises far above
title: Elementary Forms

text: us and our empirical individuality. So there is a whole part of
title: Elementary Forms

text: ourselves which we tend to project into the outside. This way of
title: Elementary Forms

text: thinking of ourselves is so well established in our nature that we
title: Elementary Forms

text: cannot escape it, even when we attempt to regard ourselves without
title: Elementary Forms

text: having recourse to any religious symbols. Our moral consciousness is
title: Elementary Forms

text: like a nucleus about which the idea of the soul forms itself; yet when
title: Elementary Forms

text: it speaks to us, it gives the effect of an outside power, superior to
title: Elementary Forms

text: us, which gives us our law and judges us, but which also aids and
title: Elementary Forms

text: sustains us. When we have it on our side, we feel ourselves to be
title: Elementary Forms

text: stronger against the trials of life, and better assured of triumphing
title: Elementary Forms

text: over them, just as the Australian who, when trusting in his ancestor or
title: Elementary Forms

text: his personal totem, feels himself more valiant against his enemies.[896]
title: Elementary Forms

text: So there is something objective at the basis of these conceptions,
title: Elementary Forms

text: whether we have in mind the Roman _genius_, the individual totem, or the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Alcheringa ancestor; and this is why they have survived, in various
title: Elementary Forms

text: forms, up to the present day. Everything goes just as if we really had
title: Elementary Forms

text: two souls; one which is within us, or rather, which is us; the other
title: Elementary Forms

text: which is above us, and whose function it is to control and assist the
title: Elementary Forms

text: first one. Frazer thought that the individual totem was an external
title: Elementary Forms

text: soul; but he believed that this exteriority was the result of an
title: Elementary Forms

text: artifice and a magic ruse. In reality, it is implied in the very
title: Elementary Forms

text: constitution of the idea of the soul.[897]
title: Elementary Forms

text: II
title: Elementary Forms

text: The spirits of which we have just been speaking are essentially
title: Elementary Forms

text: benefactors. Of course they punish a man if he does not treat them in a
title: Elementary Forms

text: fitting manner;[898] but it is not their function to work evil.
title: Elementary Forms

text: However, a spirit is in itself just as capable of doing evil as good.
title: Elementary Forms

text: This is why we find a class of evil geniuses forming itself naturally,
title: Elementary Forms

text: in opposition to these auxiliary and protecting spirits, which enables
title: Elementary Forms

text: men to explain the permanent evils that they have to suffer, their
title: Elementary Forms

text: nightmares[899] and illnesses,[900] whirlwinds and tempests,[901] etc.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Of course this is not saying that all these human miseries have appeared
title: Elementary Forms

text: as things too abnormal to be explained in any way except by supernatural
title: Elementary Forms

text: forces; but it is saying that these forces are thought of under a
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious form. As it is a religious principle which is considered the
title: Elementary Forms

text: source of life, so, all the events which disturb or destroy life ought
title: Elementary Forms

text: logically to be traced to a principle of the same sort.
title: Elementary Forms

text: These harmful spirits seem to have been conceived on the same model as
title: Elementary Forms

text: the good spirits of which we have just been speaking. They are
title: Elementary Forms

text: represented in an animal form, or one that is half-animal,
title: Elementary Forms

text: half-man;[902] but men are naturally inclined to give them enormous
title: Elementary Forms

text: dimensions and a repulsive aspect.[903] Like the souls of the ancestors,
title: Elementary Forms

text: they are believed to inhabit trees, rocks, water-holes and subterranean
title: Elementary Forms

text: caverns.[904] Taking the Arunta as a particular example, Spencer and
title: Elementary Forms

text: Gillen say expressly that these evil geniuses, known under the name of
title: Elementary Forms

text: Oruncha, are beings of the Alcheringa.[905] Many are represented as the
title: Elementary Forms

text: souls of persons who had led a terrestrial life.[906] Among the
title: Elementary Forms

text: personages of the fabulous epoch, there were, in fact, many different
title: Elementary Forms

text: temperaments: some had cruel and evil instincts which they
title: Elementary Forms

text: retained;[907] others were naturally of a bad constitution; they were
title: Elementary Forms

text: thin and emaciated; so after they had entered into the ground, the nanja
title: Elementary Forms

text: rocks to which they gave birth were considered the homes of dangerous
title: Elementary Forms

text: influences.[908]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Yet they are distinguished by special characteristics from their
title: Elementary Forms

text: confreres, the heroes of the Alcheringa. They do not reincarnate
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves; among living men, there is no one who represents them; they
title: Elementary Forms

text: are without human posterity.[909] When, judging from certain signs, they
title: Elementary Forms

text: believe that a child is the result of their work, it is put to death as
title: Elementary Forms

text: soon as born.[910] Also, these belong to no determined totemic group;
title: Elementary Forms

text: they are outside the social organization.[911] By all these traits, they
title: Elementary Forms

text: are recognized as magic powers rather than religious ones. And in fact,
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is especially with the magician that they have relations; very
title: Elementary Forms

text: frequently it is from them that he gets his powers.[912] So we have now
title: Elementary Forms

text: arrived at the point where the world of religion stops and that of magic
title: Elementary Forms

text: commences; and as this latter is outside the field of our research, we
title: Elementary Forms

text: need not push our researches further.[913]
title: Elementary Forms

text: III
title: Elementary Forms

text: The appearance of the notion of spirits marks an important step in
title: Elementary Forms

text: advance in the individualization of religious forces.
title: Elementary Forms

text: However, the spiritual beings of whom we have been speaking up to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: present are as yet only secondary personages. They are either
title: Elementary Forms

text: evil-working geniuses who belong to magic rather than religion, or else,
title: Elementary Forms

text: being attached to determined individuals or places, they cannot make
title: Elementary Forms

text: their influence felt except within a circle of a very limited radius. So
title: Elementary Forms

text: they can only be the objects of private and local rites. But after the
title: Elementary Forms

text: idea has once been established, it naturally spreads to the higher
title: Elementary Forms

text: spheres of the religious life, and thus mythical personalities of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: superior order are born.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Though the ceremonies of the different clans differ from one another,
title: Elementary Forms

text: they all belong to the same religion, none the less; also, a certain
title: Elementary Forms

text: number of essential similarities exist between them. Since all the clans
title: Elementary Forms

text: are only parts of one and the same tribe, the unity of the tribe cannot
title: Elementary Forms

text: fail to make itself felt through this diversity of particular cults. In
title: Elementary Forms

text: fact, there is no totemic group that does not have churinga and
title: Elementary Forms

text: bull-roarers, and these are used everywhere in the same way. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: organization of the tribe into phratries, matrimonial classes and clans,
title: Elementary Forms

text: and the exogamic interdictions attached to them, are veritable tribal
title: Elementary Forms

text: institutions. The initiation celebrations all include certain
title: Elementary Forms

text: fundamental practices, the extraction of a tooth, circumcision,
title: Elementary Forms

text: subincision, etc., which do not vary with the totems within a single
title: Elementary Forms

text: tribe. The uniformity on this point is the more easily established as
title: Elementary Forms

text: the initiation always takes place in the presence of the tribe, or at
title: Elementary Forms

text: least, before an assembly to which the different clans have been
title: Elementary Forms

text: summoned. The reason for this is that the object of the initiation is to
title: Elementary Forms

text: introduce the neophyte into the religious life, not merely of the clan
title: Elementary Forms

text: into which he was born, but of the tribe as a whole; so it is necessary
title: Elementary Forms

text: that the various aspects of the tribal religion be represented before
title: Elementary Forms

text: him and take place, in a way, under his very eyes. It is on this
title: Elementary Forms

text: occasion that the moral and religious unity of the tribe is affirmed the
title: Elementary Forms

text: best.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Thus, in each society there are a certain number of rites which are
title: Elementary Forms

text: distinguished from all the others by their homogeneity and their
title: Elementary Forms

text: generality. So noticeably a harmony seemed to be explicable only by a
title: Elementary Forms

text: unity of origin. So they imagined that each group of similar rites had
title: Elementary Forms

text: been founded by one and the same ancestor, who came to reveal them to
title: Elementary Forms

text: the tribe as a whole. Thus, among the Arunta, it was an ancestor of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Wild Cat clan, named Putiaputia,[914] who is thought to have taught men
title: Elementary Forms

text: the way of making churinga and using it ritually; among the Warramunga,
title: Elementary Forms

text: it was Murtu-murtu;[915] among the Urabunna, Witurna;[916] it was Atnatu
title: Elementary Forms

text: among the Kaitish[917] and Tendun among the Kurnai.[918] Likewise, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: practice of circumcision is attributed by the eastern Dieri and many
title: Elementary Forms

text: other tribes[919] to two special Muramura, and by the Arunta to a hero
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the Alcheringa, of the Lizard totem, named Mangarkunjerkunja.[920] To
title: Elementary Forms

text: this same personage are ascribed the foundation of the matrimonial
title: Elementary Forms

text: institutions and the social organization they imply, the discovery of
title: Elementary Forms

text: fire, the invention of the spear, the buckler, the boomerang, etc. It
title: Elementary Forms

text: also happens very frequently that the inventor of the bull-roarer is
title: Elementary Forms

text: also considered the founder of the rites of initiation.[921]
title: Elementary Forms

text: These special ancestors cannot be put in the same rank as the others. On
title: Elementary Forms

text: the one hand, the sentiments of veneration which they inspire are not
title: Elementary Forms

text: limited to one clan, but are common to the whole tribe. On the other
title: Elementary Forms

text: hand, it is to them that men ascribe all that is most esteemed in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: tribal civilization. For this double reason, they became the object of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: special consideration. For example, they say of Atnatu that he was born
title: Elementary Forms

text: in heaven at an epoch even prior to the times of the Alcheringa, that he
title: Elementary Forms

text: made himself and that he gave himself the name he bears. The stars are
title: Elementary Forms

text: his wives and daughters. Beyond the heaven where he lives, there is
title: Elementary Forms

text: another one with another sun. His name is sacred, and should never be
title: Elementary Forms

text: pronounced before women or non-initiated persons.[922]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Yet, howsoever great the prestige enjoyed by these personages may be,
title: Elementary Forms

text: there was no occasion for founding special rites in their honour; for
title: Elementary Forms

text: they themselves are only rites personified. They have no other reason
title: Elementary Forms

text: for existence than to explain existing practices; they are only another
title: Elementary Forms

text: aspect of these. The churinga and the ancestor who invented it are only
title: Elementary Forms

text: one; sometimes, both have the same name.[923] When someone makes the
title: Elementary Forms

text: bull-roarer resound, they say that it is the voice of the ancestor
title: Elementary Forms

text: making himself heard.[924] But, for the very reason that each of these
title: Elementary Forms

text: heroes is confounded with the cult he is believed to have founded, they
title: Elementary Forms

text: believe that he is attentive to the way in which it is celebrated. He is
title: Elementary Forms

text: not satisfied unless the worshippers fulfil their duties exactly; he
title: Elementary Forms

text: punishes those who are negligent.[925] So he is thought of as the
title: Elementary Forms

text: guardian of the rite, as well as its founder, and for this reason, he
title: Elementary Forms

text: becomes invested with a veritable moral role.[926]
title: Elementary Forms

text: IV
title: Elementary Forms

text: However, this mythological formation is not the highest which is to be
title: Elementary Forms

text: found among the Australians. There are at least a certain number of
title: Elementary Forms

text: tribes who have arrived at a conception of a god who, if not unique, is
title: Elementary Forms

text: at least supreme, and to whom is attributed a pre-eminent position among
title: Elementary Forms

text: all the other religious entities.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The existence of this belief was pointed out long ago by different
title: Elementary Forms

text: observers;[927] but it is Howitt who has contributed the most to
title: Elementary Forms

text: establishing its relative generality. In fact, he has verified it over a
title: Elementary Forms

text: very extended geographical area embracing the State of Victoria and New
title: Elementary Forms

text: South Wales and even extending up to Queensland.[928] In all this entire
title: Elementary Forms

text: region, a considerable number of tribes believe in the existence of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: veritable tribal divinity, who has different names, according to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: district. The ones most frequently employed are Bunjil or Punjil,[929]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Daramulun[930] and Baiame.[931] But we also find Nuralie or
title: Elementary Forms

text: Nurelle,[932] Kohin[933] and Mangan-ngaua.[934] The same conception is
title: Elementary Forms

text: found again farther west, among the Narrinyeri, where the great god is
title: Elementary Forms

text: called Nurunderi or Ngurrunderi.[935] Among the Dieri, it is probable
title: Elementary Forms

text: that there is one of the Mura-mura, or ordinary ancestors, who enjoys a
title: Elementary Forms

text: sort of supremacy over the others.[936] Finally, in opposition to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: affirmations of Spencer and Gillen, who declare that they have observed
title: Elementary Forms

text: no belief in a real divinity among the Arunta,[937] Strehlow assures us
title: Elementary Forms

text: that this people, as well as the Loritja, recognize, under the name
title: Elementary Forms

text: Altjira, a veritable "good god."[938]
title: Elementary Forms

text: The essential characteristics of this personage are the same everywhere.
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is an immortal, and even an eternal being, for it was not derived
title: Elementary Forms

text: from any other. After having lived on earth for a certain length of
title: Elementary Forms

text: time, he ascended to heaven, or else was taken up there,[939] and
title: Elementary Forms

text: continues to live there, surrounded by his family, for generally he is
title: Elementary Forms

text: said to have one or several wives, children and brothers,[940] who
title: Elementary Forms

text: sometimes assist him in his functions. Under the pretext of a visit he
title: Elementary Forms

text: is said to have made to them, he and his family are frequently
title: Elementary Forms

text: identified with certain stars.[941] Moreover, they attribute to him a
title: Elementary Forms

text: power over stars. It is he who regulates the journey of the sun and
title: Elementary Forms

text: moon;[942] he gives them orders.[943] It is he who makes the lightning
title: Elementary Forms

text: leap from the clouds and who throws the thunder-bolts.[944] Since he is
title: Elementary Forms

text: the thunder, he is also connected with the rain:[945] it is to him that
title: Elementary Forms

text: men address themselves when there is a scarcity of water, or when too
title: Elementary Forms

text: much falls.[946]
title: Elementary Forms

text: They speak of him as a sort of creator: he is called the father of men
title: Elementary Forms

text: and they say that he made them. According to a legend current around
title: Elementary Forms

text: Melbourne, Bunjil made the first man in the following manner. He made a
title: Elementary Forms

text: little statue out of white clay; then, after he had danced all around it
title: Elementary Forms

text: several times and had breathed into its nostrils, the statue became
title: Elementary Forms

text: animated and commenced to walk about.[947] According to another myth, he
title: Elementary Forms

text: lighted the sun; thus the earth became heated and men came out of
title: Elementary Forms

text: it.[948] At the same time that he made men,[949] this divine personage
title: Elementary Forms

text: made the animals and trees;[950] it is to him that men owe all the arts
title: Elementary Forms

text: of life, arms, language and tribal rites.[951] He is the benefactor of
title: Elementary Forms

text: humanity. Even yet, he plays the role of a sort of providence for them.
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is he who supplies his worshippers with all that is necessary for
title: Elementary Forms

text: their existence.[952] He is in communication with them, either directly
title: Elementary Forms

text: or through intermediaries.[953] But being at the same time guardian of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the morals of the tribe, he treats them severely when these are
title: Elementary Forms

text: violated.[954] If we are to believe certain observers, he will even
title: Elementary Forms

text: fulfil the office of judge, after this life; he will separate the good
title: Elementary Forms

text: from the bad, and will not reward the ones like the others.[955] In any
title: Elementary Forms

text: case, they are often represented as ruling the land of the dead,[956]
title: Elementary Forms

text: and as gathering the souls together when they arrive in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: beyond.[957]
title: Elementary Forms

text: As the initiation is the principal form of the tribal cult, it is to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: rites of initiation that he is attached especially; he is their centre.
title: Elementary Forms

text: He is very frequently represented by an image cut on a piece of bark or
title: Elementary Forms

text: soaked into the ground. They dance around it; they sing in its honour;
title: Elementary Forms

text: they even address real prayers to it.[958] They explain to the young men
title: Elementary Forms

text: who the personage is whom this image represents; they tell them his
title: Elementary Forms

text: secret name, which the women and the uninitiated cannot know; they
title: Elementary Forms

text: relate to them his history and the part attributed to him in the life of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the tribe. At other times they raise their hands towards the heaven
title: Elementary Forms

text: where he is thought to dwell, or else they point their arms or the
title: Elementary Forms

text: ritual instruments they have in hand in this direction;[959] this is a
title: Elementary Forms

text: way of entering into communication with him. They feel his presence
title: Elementary Forms

text: everywhere. He watches over the neophyte when he has withdrawn into the
title: Elementary Forms

text: forest.[960] He is attentive to the manner in which the ceremonies are
title: Elementary Forms

text: celebrated. The initiation is his cult. So he gives special attention to
title: Elementary Forms

text: seeing that these are carried out exactly: if there are any faults or
title: Elementary Forms

text: negligences, he punishes them in a terrible manner.[961]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Moreover, the authority of each of these supreme gods is not limited to
title: Elementary Forms

text: a single tribe; it is recognized equally by a number of neighbouring
title: Elementary Forms

text: tribes. Bunjil is adored in nearly all of Victoria, Baiame in a
title: Elementary Forms

text: considerable portion of New South Wales, etc.; this is why there are so
title: Elementary Forms

text: few gods for a relatively extended geographical area. So the cults of
title: Elementary Forms

text: which they are the object have an international character. It even
title: Elementary Forms

text: happens sometimes that mythologies intermingle, combine and make mutual
title: Elementary Forms

text: borrowings. Thus the majority of the tribes who believe in Baiame also
title: Elementary Forms

text: admit the existence of Daramulun; however, they accord him a slighter
title: Elementary Forms

text: dignity. They make him a son or brother of Baiame, and subordinate to
title: Elementary Forms

text: this latter.[962] Thus the faith in Daramulun has spread in diverse
title: Elementary Forms

text: forms, into all of New South Wales. So it is far from true that
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious internationalism is a peculiarity of the most recent and
title: Elementary Forms

text: advanced religions. From the dawn of history, religious beliefs have
title: Elementary Forms

text: manifested a tendency to overflow out of one strictly limited political
title: Elementary Forms

text: society; it is as though they had a natural aptitude for crossing
title: Elementary Forms

text: frontiers, and for diffusing and internationalizing themselves. Of
title: Elementary Forms

text: course there have been peoples and times when this spontaneous aptitude
title: Elementary Forms

text: has been held in check by opposed social necessities; but that does not
title: Elementary Forms

text: keep it from being real and, as we see, very primitive.
title: Elementary Forms

text: To Tylor this conception has appeared to be a part of so elevated a
title: Elementary Forms

text: theology that he refuses to see in it anything but the product of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: European importation: he would have it be a more or less denatured
title: Elementary Forms

text: Christian idea.[963] Andrew Lang, on the contrary, considers them
title: Elementary Forms

text: autochthonous;[964] but as he also admits that it is contrasted with all
title: Elementary Forms

text: the other Australian beliefs and rests on completely different
title: Elementary Forms

text: principles, he concludes that the religions of Australia are made up of
title: Elementary Forms

text: two heterogeneous systems, superimposed one upon the other, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: consequently derived from a double origin. On the one hand, there were
title: Elementary Forms

text: ideas relative to totems and spirits, which had been suggested to men by
title: Elementary Forms

text: the sight of certain natural phenomena. But at the same time, by a sort
title: Elementary Forms

text: of intuition as to the nature of which he refuses to make himself
title: Elementary Forms

text: clear,[965] the human intelligence succeeded at the first onset in
title: Elementary Forms

text: conceiving a unique god, creator of the world and legislator of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: moral order. Lang even estimates that this idea was purer of foreign
title: Elementary Forms

text: elements at the beginning, and especially in Australia, than in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: civilizations which immediately followed. With time, it was covered over
title: Elementary Forms

text: and obscured little by little by the ever-growing mass of animistic and
title: Elementary Forms

text: totemic superstitions. Thus it underwent a sort of progressive
title: Elementary Forms

text: degeneration up to the day when, as the effect of a privileged culture,
title: Elementary Forms

text: it succeeded in coming into its own and restated itself again with more
title: Elementary Forms

text: force and clarity than it had in the first place.[966]
title: Elementary Forms

text: But the facts allow neither the sceptical hypothesis of Tylor nor the
title: Elementary Forms

text: theological interpretation of Lang.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In the first place, it is certain to-day that the ideas relative to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: great tribal god are of indigenous origin. They were observed before
title: Elementary Forms

text: the influence of the missionaries had as yet had time to make itself
title: Elementary Forms

text: felt.[967] But it does not follow that it is necessary to attribute them
title: Elementary Forms

text: to a mysterious revelation. Far from being derived from a different
title: Elementary Forms

text: source than the regular totemic beliefs, they are, on the contrary, only
title: Elementary Forms

text: the logical working-out of these beliefs and their highest form.
title: Elementary Forms

text: We have already seen how the notion of mythical ancestors is implied in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the very principles upon which totemism rests, for each of them is a
title: Elementary Forms

text: totemic being. Now, though the great gods are certainly superior to
title: Elementary Forms

text: these, still, there are only differences of degree between them; we pass
title: Elementary Forms

text: from the first to the second with no break of continuity. In fact, a
title: Elementary Forms

text: great god is himself an ancestor of especial importance. They frequently
title: Elementary Forms

text: speak to us about him as though he were a man, endowed, to be sure, with
title: Elementary Forms

text: more than human powers, but one who lived a human life upon the
title: Elementary Forms

text: earth.[968] He is pictured as a great hunter,[969] a powerful
title: Elementary Forms

text: magician,[970] or the founder of the tribe.[971] He was the first
title: Elementary Forms

text: man.[972] One legend even represents him in the form of a worn-out old
title: Elementary Forms

text: man who could hardly move about.[973] If a supreme god named Mura-mura
title: Elementary Forms

text: has existed among the Dieri, the very word is significant, for it serves
title: Elementary Forms

text: to designate the class of the ancestors. Likewise, Nuralie, the name of
title: Elementary Forms

text: a great god among the tribes on the Murray River, is sometimes used as a
title: Elementary Forms

text: collective expression which is applied to the group of mythical beings
title: Elementary Forms

text: whom tradition places at the origin of things.[974] They are personages
title: Elementary Forms

text: wholly comparable to those of the Alcheringa.[975] In Queensland, we
title: Elementary Forms

text: have already met with a god Anjea or Anjir, who made men but who seems,
title: Elementary Forms

text: nevertheless, to be only the first man.[976]
title: Elementary Forms

text: A fact that has aided Australian thought to pass from the numerous
title: Elementary Forms

text: ancestral geniuses to the idea of the tribal god is that between the two
title: Elementary Forms

text: extremes a middle term has been inserted, which has served as a
title: Elementary Forms

text: transition: these are the civilizing heroes. The fabulous beings whom we
title: Elementary Forms

text: call by this name are really simple ancestors to whom mythology has
title: Elementary Forms

text: attributed an eminent place in the history of the tribe, and whom it
title: Elementary Forms

text: has, for this reason, set above the others. We have even seen that they
title: Elementary Forms

text: ordinarily form a part of the totemic organization: Mangarkunjerkunja
title: Elementary Forms

text: belongs to the Lizard totem and Putiaputia to the Wild Cat totem. But on
title: Elementary Forms

text: the other hand, the functions which they are believed to fulfil, or to
title: Elementary Forms

text: have fulfilled, are closely similar to those incumbent upon a great god.
title: Elementary Forms

text: He, too, is believed to have introduced the arts of civilization among
title: Elementary Forms

text: men, to have been the founder of the principal social institutions and
title: Elementary Forms

text: the revealer of the great religious ceremonies which still remain under
title: Elementary Forms

text: his control. If he is the father of men, it is because he manufactured
title: Elementary Forms

text: them rather than begat them: but Mangarkunjerkunja also made them.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Before his time, there were no men, but only unformed masses of flesh,
title: Elementary Forms

text: in which the different members and even the different individuals were
title: Elementary Forms

text: not yet separated from one another. It was he who cut up this original
title: Elementary Forms

text: matter and made real human beings out of it.[977] Between this mode of
title: Elementary Forms

text: fabrication and the one the myth we have spoken of attributes to Bunjil,
title: Elementary Forms

text: there are only shades of difference. Moreover, the bonds uniting these
title: Elementary Forms

text: two sorts of figures to each other are well shown by the fact that a
title: Elementary Forms

text: relationship of descent is sometimes established between them. Among the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Kurnai, the hero of the bull-roarer, Tundun, is the son of the great god
title: Elementary Forms

text: Mungan-ngaua.[978] Likewise, among the Euahlayi, Daramulun, the son or
title: Elementary Forms

text: brother of Baiame, is identical with Gayandi who is the equivalent of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the Tundun of the Kurnai.[979] Of course it is not necessary to conclude
title: Elementary Forms

text: from these facts that the great god is nothing more than a civilizing
title: Elementary Forms

text: hero. There are cases where these two personages are carefully
title: Elementary Forms

text: differentiated. But if they are not confounded, they are at least
title: Elementary Forms

text: relatives. So it sometimes happens that we find it hard to distinguish
title: Elementary Forms

text: them; there are some who could be classified equally well in one
title: Elementary Forms

text: category or the other. Thus, we have spoken of Atnatu as a civilizing
title: Elementary Forms

text: hero; but he comes very near to being a great god.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The notion of a supreme god even depends so closely upon the entire
title: Elementary Forms

text: system of the totemic beliefs that it still bears their mark. Tundun is
title: Elementary Forms

text: a divine hero, as we have just seen, who is very close to the tribal
title: Elementary Forms

text: divinity; now among the Kurnai, the same word means totem.[980]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Similarly, among the Arunta, Altjira is the name of a great god; it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: also the name of the maternal totem.[981] But there is more to be said
title: Elementary Forms

text: than this; many great gods have an obviously totemic aspect. Daramulun
title: Elementary Forms

text: is an eagle-hawk;[982] his mother, an emu.[983] It is also under the
title: Elementary Forms

text: features of an emu that Baiame is represented.[984] The Altjira of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Arunta has the legs of an emu.[985] Before being the name of a great
title: Elementary Forms

text: god, Nuralie designated, as we just saw, the ancestor-founders of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: tribe; now some of these were crows, the others hawks.[986] According to
title: Elementary Forms

text: Howitt,[987] Bunjil is always represented in a human form; however, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: same word serves to designate the totem of a phratry, the eagle-hawk. At
title: Elementary Forms

text: least one of his sons is among the totems included in the phratry to
title: Elementary Forms

text: which he has given, or from which he has taken his name.[988] His
title: Elementary Forms

text: brother is Pallyan, the bat; now this latter serves as sexual totem for
title: Elementary Forms

text: the men in many tribes in Victoria.[989]
title: Elementary Forms

text: We can even go farther and state more definitely the connection which
title: Elementary Forms

text: these great gods have with the totemic system. We have just seen that
title: Elementary Forms

text: Bunjil is the totem of a phratry. Daramulun, like Bunjil, is an
title: Elementary Forms

text: eagle-hawk, and we know that this bird is the totem of phratries in a
title: Elementary Forms

text: large number of south-eastern tribes.[990] We have already pointed out
title: Elementary Forms

text: that Nuralie seems to have originally been a collective term designating
title: Elementary Forms

text: indistinctly either eagle-hawks or crows; now in the tribes where this
title: Elementary Forms

text: myth has been observed, the crow is the totem of one of the two
title: Elementary Forms

text: phratries, the eagle-hawk, that of the other.[991] Also, the legendary
title: Elementary Forms

text: history of the great gods resembles that of the totems of the phratries
title: Elementary Forms

text: very closely. The myths, and sometimes the rites, commemorate the
title: Elementary Forms

text: struggles which each of these divinities fought against a carnivorous
title: Elementary Forms

text: bird, over which it triumphed only with the greatest difficulty. Bunjil,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the first man, after making the second man, Karween, entered into a
title: Elementary Forms

text: conflict with him, and in the course of a sort of duel, he wounded him
title: Elementary Forms

text: severely and changed him into a crow.[992] The two species of Nurtalie
title: Elementary Forms

text: are represented as two hostile groups which were originally in a
title: Elementary Forms

text: constant state of war.[993] Baiame, on his side, had to fight against
title: Elementary Forms

text: Mullian, the cannibal eagle-hawk, who, by the way, is identical with
title: Elementary Forms

text: Daramulun.[994] Now, as we have seen, there is also a sort of
title: Elementary Forms

text: constitutional hostility between the totems of the phratries. This
title: Elementary Forms

text: parallelism completes the proof that the mythology of the great gods and
title: Elementary Forms

text: that of these totems are closely related. This relationship will appear
title: Elementary Forms

text: still more evident if we notice that the rival of the god is regularly
title: Elementary Forms

text: either a crow or an eagle-hawk, and that these are quite generally the
title: Elementary Forms

text: totems of the phratries.[995]
title: Elementary Forms

text: So Baiame, Daramulun, Nuralie and Bunjil seem to be phratry-totems who
title: Elementary Forms

text: have been deified; and we may imagine that this apotheosis took place as
title: Elementary Forms

text: follows. It is obviously in the assemblies which take place in regard to
title: Elementary Forms

text: the initiation that the conception was elaborated, for the great gods do
title: Elementary Forms

text: not play a role of any importance except in these rites, and are
title: Elementary Forms

text: strangers to the other religious ceremonies. Moreover, as the initiation
title: Elementary Forms

text: is the principal form of the tribal cult, it is only on this occasion
title: Elementary Forms

text: that a tribal mythology could arise. We have already seen how the
title: Elementary Forms

text: rituals of circumcision and subincision spontaneously tend to personify
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves under the form of civilizing heroes. However, these heroes
title: Elementary Forms

text: exercised no supremacy; they were on the same footing as the other
title: Elementary Forms

text: legendary benefactors of society. But wherever the tribe acquired a
title: Elementary Forms

text: livelier sentiment of itself, this sentiment naturally incarnated itself
title: Elementary Forms

text: in some personage, who became its symbol. In order to account for the
title: Elementary Forms

text: bonds uniting them to one another, no matter what clan they belonged to,
title: Elementary Forms

text: men imagined that they were all descended from the same stock and that
title: Elementary Forms

text: they were all descended from a single father, to whom they owe their
title: Elementary Forms

text: existence, though he owed his to no one. The god of the initiation was
title: Elementary Forms

text: predestined to this role, for, according to an expression frequently
title: Elementary Forms

text: coming to the lips of the natives, the object of the initiation is to
title: Elementary Forms

text: make or manufacture men. So they attributed a creative power to this
title: Elementary Forms

text: god, and for all these reasons, he found himself invested with a
title: Elementary Forms

text: prestige setting him well above the other heroes of the mythology. These
title: Elementary Forms

text: others became his auxiliaries, subordinate to him; they were made his
title: Elementary Forms

text: sons or younger brothers, as was the case with Tundun, Gayandi,
title: Elementary Forms

text: Karween, Pallyan, etc. But other sacred beings already existed, who
title: Elementary Forms

text: occupied an equally eminent place in the religious system of the clan:
title: Elementary Forms

text: these were the totems of the phratries. Wherever these are maintained,
title: Elementary Forms

text: they are believed to keep the totems of the clans dependent upon them.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Thus they had all that was necessary for becoming tribal divinities
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves. So it was only natural that a partial confusion should arise
title: Elementary Forms

text: between these two sorts of mythical beings; it is thus that one of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: two fundamental totems of the tribe gave his traits to the great god.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But as it was necessary to explain why only one of them was called to
title: Elementary Forms

text: this dignity and the other excluded, they supposed that this latter, in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the course of a fight against his rival, was vanquished and that his
title: Elementary Forms

text: exclusion was the consequence of his defeat. This theory was the more
title: Elementary Forms

text: readily admitted because it was in accord with the rest of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: mythology, where the totems of the phratries are generally considered
title: Elementary Forms

text: enemies of one another.
title: Elementary Forms

text: A myth observed by Mrs. Parker among the Euahlayi[996] may serve to
title: Elementary Forms

text: confirm this explanation, for it merely translates it into figurative
title: Elementary Forms

text: language. It is related that in this tribe, the totems were only the
title: Elementary Forms

text: names given to the different parts of Baiame's body at first. So the
title: Elementary Forms

text: clans were, in a sense, the fragments of the divine body. Now is this
title: Elementary Forms

text: not just another way of saying that the great god is the synthesis of
title: Elementary Forms

text: all the totems and consequently the personification of the tribal unity?
title: Elementary Forms

text: But at the same time, it takes an international character. In fact, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: members of the tribe to which the young initiates belong are not the
title: Elementary Forms

text: only ones who assist at the ceremonies of initiation; representatives
title: Elementary Forms

text: from the neighbouring tribes are specially summoned to these
title: Elementary Forms

text: celebrations, which thus become sorts of international fairs, at once
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious and laical.[997] Beliefs elaborated in social environments
title: Elementary Forms

text: thus constituted could not remain the exclusive patrimony of any special
title: Elementary Forms

text: nationality. The stranger to whom they are revealed carries them back to
title: Elementary Forms

text: his own tribe when he returns home; and as, sooner or later, he is
title: Elementary Forms

text: forced to invite his former hosts, there is a continual exchange of
title: Elementary Forms

text: ideas from tribe to tribe. It is thus that an international mythology
title: Elementary Forms

text: was established, of which the great god was quite naturally the
title: Elementary Forms

text: essential element, for it had its origin in the rites of initiation
title: Elementary Forms

text: which it is his function to personify. So his name passed from one
title: Elementary Forms

text: language to another, along with the representations which were attached
title: Elementary Forms

text: to it. The fact that the names of the phratries are generally the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: in very different tribes could not fail to facilitate this diffusion.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The internationalism of the totems opened the way for that of the great
title: Elementary Forms

text: god.
title: Elementary Forms

text: V
title: Elementary Forms

text: We thus reach the highest conception to which totemism has arrived. This
title: Elementary Forms

text: is the point where it touches and prepares the religions which are to
title: Elementary Forms

text: follow, and aids us in understanding them. But at the same time, we are
title: Elementary Forms

text: able to see that this culminating idea is united without any
title: Elementary Forms

text: interruption to the crudest beliefs which we analysed to start with.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In fact, the great tribal god is only an ancestral spirit who finally
title: Elementary Forms

text: won a pre-eminent place. The ancestral spirits are only entities forged
title: Elementary Forms

text: in the image of the individual souls whose origin they are destined to
title: Elementary Forms

text: explain. The souls, in their turn, are only the form taken by the
title: Elementary Forms

text: impersonal forces which we found at the basis of totemism, as they
title: Elementary Forms

text: individualize themselves in the human body. The unity of the system is
title: Elementary Forms

text: as great as its complexity.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In this work of elaboration, the idea of the soul has undoubtedly played
title: Elementary Forms

text: an important part: it is through it that the idea of personality has
title: Elementary Forms

text: been introduced into the domain of religion. But it is not true that, as
title: Elementary Forms

text: the theorists of animism maintain, it contains the germ of the whole
title: Elementary Forms

text: religion. First of all, it presupposes the notion of _mana_ or the
title: Elementary Forms

text: totemic principle of which it is only a special form. Then, if the
title: Elementary Forms

text: spirits and gods could not be conceived before the soul, they are,
title: Elementary Forms

text: nevertheless, more than mere human souls, liberated by death; else
title: Elementary Forms

text: whence would come their supernatural powers? The idea of the soul has
title: Elementary Forms

text: merely served to direct the mythological imagination in a new way and to
title: Elementary Forms

text: suggest to it constructions of a new sort. But the matter for these
title: Elementary Forms

text: conceptions has been taken, not from the representation of the soul, but
title: Elementary Forms

text: from this reservoir of the anonymous and diffused forces which
title: Elementary Forms

text: constitute the original foundation of religions. The creation of
title: Elementary Forms

text: mythical personalities has only been another way of thinking of these
title: Elementary Forms

text: essential forces.
title: Elementary Forms

text: As for the notion of the great god, it is due entirely to the sentiment
title: Elementary Forms

text: whose action we have already observed in the genesis of the most
title: Elementary Forms

text: specifically totemic beliefs: this is the tribal sentiment. In fact, we
title: Elementary Forms

text: have seen that totemism was not the work of isolated clans, but that it
title: Elementary Forms

text: was always elaborated in the body of a tribe which was to some degree
title: Elementary Forms

text: conscious of its unity. It is for this reason that the different cults
title: Elementary Forms

text: peculiar to each clan mutually touch and complete each other in such a
title: Elementary Forms

text: way as to form a unified whole.[998] Now it is this same sentiment of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: tribal unity which is expressed in the conception of a supreme god,
title: Elementary Forms

text: common to the tribe as a whole. So they are quite the same causes which
title: Elementary Forms

text: are active at the bottom and at the top of this religious system.
title: Elementary Forms

text: However, up to the present, we have considered the religious
title: Elementary Forms

text: representations as if they were self-sufficient and could be explained
title: Elementary Forms

text: by themselves. But in reality, they are inseparable from the rites, not
title: Elementary Forms

text: only because they manifest themselves there, but also because they, in
title: Elementary Forms

text: their turn, feel the influence of these. Of course the cult depends upon
title: Elementary Forms

text: the beliefs, but it also reacts upon them. So in order to understand
title: Elementary Forms

text: them better, it is important to understand it better. The moment has
title: Elementary Forms

text: come for undertaking its study.
title: Elementary Forms

text: BOOK III
title: Elementary Forms

text: THE PRINCIPAL RITUAL ATTITUDES
title: Elementary Forms

text: CHAPTER I
title: Elementary Forms

text: THE NEGATIVE CULT AND ITS FUNCTIONS THE ASCETIC RITES
title: Elementary Forms

text: We do not have the intention of attempting a complete description of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: primitive cult in what is to follow. Being preoccupied especially with
title: Elementary Forms

text: reaching that which is most elementary and most fundamental in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious life, we shall not attempt to reconstruct in detail the
title: Elementary Forms

text: frequently confused multiplicity of all the ritual forms. But out of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: midst of this extreme diversity of practices we should like to touch
title: Elementary Forms

text: upon the most characteristic attitudes which the primitive observes in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the celebration of his cult, to classify the most general forms of his
title: Elementary Forms

text: rites, and to determine their origins and significance, in order that we
title: Elementary Forms

text: may control and, if there is occasion, make more definite the results to
title: Elementary Forms

text: which the analysis of the beliefs has led us.[999]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Every cult presents a double aspect, one negative, the other positive.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In reality, of course, the two sorts of rites which we denominate thus
title: Elementary Forms

text: are closely associated; we shall see that they suppose one another. But
title: Elementary Forms

text: still, they are different and, if it is only to understand their
title: Elementary Forms

text: connection, it is necessary to distinguish them.
title: Elementary Forms

text: I
title: Elementary Forms

text: By definition, sacred beings are separated beings. That which
title: Elementary Forms

text: characterizes them is that there is a break of continuity between them
title: Elementary Forms

text: and the profane beings. Normally, the first are outside the others. A
title: Elementary Forms

text: whole group of rites has the object of realizing this state of
title: Elementary Forms

text: separation which is essential. Since their function is to prevent undue
title: Elementary Forms

text: mixings and to keep one of these two domains from encroaching upon the
title: Elementary Forms

text: other, they are only able to impose abstentions or negative acts.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Therefore, we propose to give the name negative cult to the system
title: Elementary Forms

text: formed by these special rites. They do not prescribe certain acts to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: faithful, but confine themselves to forbidding certain ways of acting;
title: Elementary Forms

text: so they all take the form of interdictions, or as is commonly said by
title: Elementary Forms

text: ethnographers, of _taboos_. This latter word is the one used in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Polynesian languages to designate the institution in virtue of which
title: Elementary Forms

text: certain things are withdrawn from common use[1000]; it is also an
title: Elementary Forms

text: adjective expressing the distinctive characteristic of these kinds of
title: Elementary Forms

text: things. We have already had occasion to show how hard it is to translate
title: Elementary Forms

text: a strictly local and dialectical expression like this into a generic
title: Elementary Forms

text: term. There is no religion where there are no interdictions and where
title: Elementary Forms

text: they do not play a considerable part; so it is regrettable that the
title: Elementary Forms

text: consecrated terminology should seem to make so universal an institution
title: Elementary Forms

text: into a peculiarity of Polynesia.[1001] The expression _interdicts_ or
title: Elementary Forms

text: _interdictions_ seems to us to be much more preferable. However, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: word taboo, like the word totem, is so customary that it would show an
title: Elementary Forms

text: excess of purism to prohibit it systematically; also, the inconveniences
title: Elementary Forms

text: it may have are attenuated when its real meaning and importance have
title: Elementary Forms

text: once been definitely stated.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But there are interdictions of different sorts which it is important to
title: Elementary Forms

text: distinguish; for we shall not have to treat all kinds of interdictions
title: Elementary Forms

text: in this chapter.
title: Elementary Forms

text: First of all, beside those coming from religion, there are others which
title: Elementary Forms

text: are due to magic. The two have this in common, that they declare certain
title: Elementary Forms

text: things incompatible, and prescribe the separation of the things whose
title: Elementary Forms

text: incompatibility is thus proclaimed. But there are also very grave
title: Elementary Forms

text: differences between them. In the first place, the sanctions are not the
title: Elementary Forms

text: same in the two cases. Of course the violation of the religious
title: Elementary Forms

text: interdicts is frequently believed, as we shall presently see, to bring
title: Elementary Forms

text: about material disorders mechanically, from which the guilty man will
title: Elementary Forms

text: suffer, and which are regarded as a judgment on his act. But even if
title: Elementary Forms

text: these really come about this spontaneous and automatic judgment is not
title: Elementary Forms

text: the only one; it is always completed by another one, supposing human
title: Elementary Forms

text: intervention. A real punishment is added to this, if it does not
title: Elementary Forms

text: anticipate it, and this one is deliberately inflicted by men; or at
title: Elementary Forms

text: least there is a blame and public reprobation. Even when the sacrilege
title: Elementary Forms

text: has been punished, as it were, by the sickness or natural death of its
title: Elementary Forms

text: author, it is also defamed; it offends opinion, which reacts against it;
title: Elementary Forms

text: it puts the man who did it in fault. On the contrary, the magic
title: Elementary Forms

text: interdiction is judged only by the material consequences which the
title: Elementary Forms

text: forbidden act is believed to produce, with a sort of physical
title: Elementary Forms

text: necessity. In disobeying, a man runs risks similar to those to which an
title: Elementary Forms

text: invalid exposes himself in not following the advice of his physician;
title: Elementary Forms

text: but in this case disobedience is not a fault; it creates no indignation.
title: Elementary Forms

text: There is no sin in magic. Moreover, this difference in sanction is due
title: Elementary Forms

text: to a profound difference in the nature of the interdictions. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious interdiction necessarily implies the notion of sacredness; it
title: Elementary Forms

text: comes from the respect inspired by the sacred object, and its purpose is
title: Elementary Forms

text: to keep this respect from failing. On the other hand, the interdictions
title: Elementary Forms

text: of magic suppose only a wholly lay notion of property. The things which
title: Elementary Forms

text: the magician recommends to be kept separate are those which, by reason
title: Elementary Forms

text: of their characteristic properties, cannot be brought together and
title: Elementary Forms

text: confused without danger. Even if he happens to ask his clients to keep
title: Elementary Forms

text: at a distance from certain sacred things, it is not through respect for
title: Elementary Forms

text: them and fear that they may be profaned, for, as we know, magic lives on
title: Elementary Forms

text: profanations;[1002] it is merely for reasons of temporal utility. In a
title: Elementary Forms

text: word, religious interdictions are categorical imperatives; others are
title: Elementary Forms

text: useful maxims, the first form of hygienic and medical interdictions. We
title: Elementary Forms

text: cannot study two orders of facts as different as these simultaneously,
title: Elementary Forms

text: or even under the same name, without confusion. We are only concerned
title: Elementary Forms

text: with the religious interdictions here.[1003]
title: Elementary Forms

text: But a new distinction is necessary between these latter.
title: Elementary Forms

text: There are religious interdictions whose object is to separate two sacred
title: Elementary Forms

text: things of different species from each other. For example, it will be
title: Elementary Forms

text: remembered that among the Wakelbura the scaffold upon which the corpse
title: Elementary Forms

text: is exposed must be made exclusively of materials belonging to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: phratry of the dead man; this is as much as to say that all contact
title: Elementary Forms

text: between the corpse, which is sacred, and the things of the other
title: Elementary Forms

text: phratry, which are also sacred, but differently, is forbidden.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Elsewhere, the arms which one uses to hunt an animal with cannot be made
title: Elementary Forms

text: out of a kind of wood that is classed in the same social group as the
title: Elementary Forms

text: animal itself.[1004] But the most important of these interdictions are
title: Elementary Forms

text: the ones which we shall study in the next chapter; they are intended to
title: Elementary Forms

text: prevent all communication between the purely sacred and the impurely
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacred, between the sacredly auspicious and the sacredly inauspicious.
title: Elementary Forms

text: All these interdictions have one common characteristic; they come, not
title: Elementary Forms

text: from the fact that some things are sacred while others are not, but from
title: Elementary Forms

text: the fact that there are inequalities and incompatibilities between
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacred things. So they do not touch what is essential in the idea of
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacredness. The observance of these prohibitions can give place only to
title: Elementary Forms

text: isolated rites which are particular and almost exceptional; but it could
title: Elementary Forms

text: not make a real cult, for before all, a cult is made by regular
title: Elementary Forms

text: relations between the profane and the sacred as such.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But there is another system of religious interdictions which is much
title: Elementary Forms

text: more extended and important; this is the one which separates, not
title: Elementary Forms

text: different species of sacred things, but all that is sacred from all that
title: Elementary Forms

text: is profane. So it is derived immediately from the notion of sacredness
title: Elementary Forms

text: itself, and it limits itself to expressing and realizing this. Thus it
title: Elementary Forms

text: furnishes the material for a veritable cult, and even of a cult which is
title: Elementary Forms

text: at the basis of all the others; for the attitude which it prescribes is
title: Elementary Forms

text: one from which the worshipper must never depart in all his relations
title: Elementary Forms

text: with the sacred. It is what we call the negative cult. We may say that
title: Elementary Forms

text: its interdicts are the religious interdicts _par excellence_.[1005] It
title: Elementary Forms

text: is only these that we shall discuss in the following pages.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But they take multiple forms. Here are the principal ones which we
title: Elementary Forms

text: observe in Australia.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Before all are the interdictions of contact; these are the original
title: Elementary Forms

text: taboos, of which the others are scarcely more than particular varieties.
title: Elementary Forms

text: They rest upon the principle that the profane should never touch the
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacred. We have seen already that the uninitiated may not touch the
title: Elementary Forms

text: churinga or the bull-roarers under any circumstances. If adults are
title: Elementary Forms

text: allowed the free use of them, it is because initiation has conferred a
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacred character upon them. Blood, and especially that which flows
title: Elementary Forms

text: during the initiation, has a religious virtue;[1006] it is under the
title: Elementary Forms

text: same interdict.[1007] It is the same with the hair.[1008] A dead man is
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacred because the soul which animated the body stays with the corpse;
title: Elementary Forms

text: for this reason it is sometimes forbidden to carry the bones of a dead
title: Elementary Forms

text: man about unless they are wrapped up in a piece of bark.[1009] Even the
title: Elementary Forms

text: place where the death took place should be avoided, for they believe
title: Elementary Forms

text: that the soul of the dead man continues to haunt the spot. That is why
title: Elementary Forms

text: they break camp and move some distance away;[1010] in certain cases they
title: Elementary Forms

text: destroy it along with everything it contains,[1011] and a certain time
title: Elementary Forms

text: must elapse before they can come back to the same place.[1012] Thus it
title: Elementary Forms

text: comes about that a dying man creates an empty space about him; they
