title: Elementary Forms

text: abandon him after they have installed him as comfortably as
title: Elementary Forms

text: possible.[1013]
title: Elementary Forms

text: An exceptionally intimate contact is the one resulting from the
title: Elementary Forms

text: absorption of food. Hence comes the interdiction against eating the
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacred animals or vegetables, and especially those serving as
title: Elementary Forms

text: totems.[1014] Such an act appears so very sacrilegious that the
title: Elementary Forms

text: prohibition covers even adults, or at least, the majority of them; only
title: Elementary Forms

text: the old men attain a sufficient religious dignity to escape this
title: Elementary Forms

text: interdict sometimes. This prohibition has sometimes been explained by
title: Elementary Forms

text: the mythical kinship uniting the man to the animals whose name he bears;
title: Elementary Forms

text: they are protected by the sentiment of sympathy which they inspire by
title: Elementary Forms

text: their position as kin.[1015] But the fact that the consumption of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: forbidden flesh is believed to cause sickness or death automatically
title: Elementary Forms

text: shows that this interdiction does not have its origin in the simple
title: Elementary Forms

text: revolt of the feeling of domestic relationship. Forces of another sort
title: Elementary Forms

text: are in action which are analogous to those in all religions and which
title: Elementary Forms

text: are believed to react against sacrileges.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Moreover, if certain foods are forbidden to the profane because they are
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacred, certain others, on the contrary, are forbidden to persons of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacred character, because they are profane. Thus it frequently happens
title: Elementary Forms

text: that certain animals are specially designated as the food of women; for
title: Elementary Forms

text: this reason, they believe that they partake of a feminine nature and
title: Elementary Forms

text: that they are consequently profane. On the other hand, the young
title: Elementary Forms

text: initiate is submitted to a series of rites of particular severity; to
title: Elementary Forms

text: give him the virtues which will enable him to enter into the world of
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacred things, from which he had up till then been excluded, they centre
title: Elementary Forms

text: an exceptionally powerful group of religious forces upon him. Thus he
title: Elementary Forms

text: enters into a state of sanctity which keeps all that is profane at a
title: Elementary Forms

text: distance. Then he is not allowed to eat the game which is regarded as
title: Elementary Forms

text: the special food of women.[1016]
title: Elementary Forms

text: But contact may be established by other means than the touch. One comes
title: Elementary Forms

text: into relations with a thing by merely regarding it: a look is a means of
title: Elementary Forms

text: contact. This is why the sight of sacred things is forbidden to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: profane in certain cases. A woman should never see the instruments of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the cult; the most that is permitted her is to catch a glimpse of them
title: Elementary Forms

text: from afar.[1017] It is the same with the totemic paintings executed on
title: Elementary Forms

text: the bodies of the officiants in the exceptionally important
title: Elementary Forms

text: ceremonies.[1018] The exceptional solemnity of the rites of initiation
title: Elementary Forms

text: prevents the women in certain tribes from seeing the place where they
title: Elementary Forms

text: were celebrated[1019] or even the neophyte himself.[1020] The sacred
title: Elementary Forms

text: character which is imminent in the ceremony as a whole is naturally
title: Elementary Forms

text: found in the persons of those who directed it or took some part in
title: Elementary Forms

text: it; the result of this is that the novice may not raise his eyes
title: Elementary Forms

text: to them, and this interdiction continues even after the rite is
title: Elementary Forms

text: accomplished.[1021] A dead man is also removed from view sometimes: his
title: Elementary Forms

text: face is covered over in such a way that it cannot be seen.[1022]
title: Elementary Forms

text: The word is another way of entering into relations with persons or
title: Elementary Forms

text: things. The breath expired establishes a communication; this is a part
title: Elementary Forms

text: of us which spreads outwards. Thus it is forbidden to the profane to
title: Elementary Forms

text: address the sacred beings or simply to speak in their presence. Just as
title: Elementary Forms

text: the neophyte must not regard either the operators or the assistants, so
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is forbidden to him to converse with them except by signs; and this
title: Elementary Forms

text: interdiction keeps the place to which it has been raised, by means of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: special rite.[1023]
title: Elementary Forms

text: In a general way, there are, among the Arunta, moments in the course of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the great ceremonies when silence is obligatory.[1024] As soon as the
title: Elementary Forms

text: churinga are exposed, every one keeps still, or if someone talks, he
title: Elementary Forms

text: does so in a low voice or with his lips only.[1025]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Besides the sacred things, there are words and sounds which have the
title: Elementary Forms

text: same character; they should not pass the lips of the profane or enter
title: Elementary Forms

text: their ears. There are ritual songs which women must not hear under pain
title: Elementary Forms

text: of death.[1026] They may hear the noise of the bull-roarers, but only
title: Elementary Forms

text: from a distance. Every proper name is considered an essential element of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the person who bears it; being closely associated in the mind to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: idea of this person, it participates in the sentiments which this latter
title: Elementary Forms

text: inspires. So if the one is sacred, the other is. Therefore, it may not
title: Elementary Forms

text: be pronounced in the course of the profane life. Among the Warramunga
title: Elementary Forms

text: there is one totem which is particularly venerated, this is the snake
title: Elementary Forms

text: called Wollunqua; its name is taboo.[1027] It is the same with Baiame,
title: Elementary Forms

text: Daramulun and Bunjil; the esoteric form of their name must not be
title: Elementary Forms

text: revealed to the uninitiate.[1028] During mourning, the name of the dead
title: Elementary Forms

text: man must not be mentioned, at least by his parents, except when there is
title: Elementary Forms

text: an absolute necessity, and even in this case it must be whispered.[1029]
title: Elementary Forms

text: This interdiction is frequently perpetual for the widow and certain
title: Elementary Forms

text: relatives.[1030] Among certain peoples, this even extends beyond the
title: Elementary Forms

text: family; all the individuals whose name is the same as that of the dead
title: Elementary Forms

text: man must change theirs temporarily.[1031] But there is more than this:
title: Elementary Forms

text: the relatives and intimate friends sometimes abstain from certain words
title: Elementary Forms

text: in the usual language, undoubtedly because they were employed by the
title: Elementary Forms

text: dead man; these gaps are filled in by means of periphrases or words
title: Elementary Forms

text: taken from some foreign dialects.[1032] In addition to their public and
title: Elementary Forms

text: everyday names all men have another which is kept a secret: the women
title: Elementary Forms

text: and children do not know it; it is never used in the ordinary life. This
title: Elementary Forms

text: is because it has a religious character.[1033] There are even ceremonies
title: Elementary Forms

text: during which it is necessary to speak a special language which must not
title: Elementary Forms

text: be used for profane purposes. It is the beginning of a sacred
title: Elementary Forms

text: language.[1034]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Not only are the sacred beings separated from the profane, but also
title: Elementary Forms

text: nothing which either directly or indirectly concerns the profane life
title: Elementary Forms

text: should be confused with the religious life. Complete nudity is
title: Elementary Forms

text: frequently demanded of the native as a prerequisite to being admitted to
title: Elementary Forms

text: participation in the rites;[1035] he is required to strip himself of all
title: Elementary Forms

text: his habitual ornaments, even those to which he is the most attached, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: from which he separates himself the least willingly because of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: protecting virtues he attributes to them.[1036] If he is obliged to
title: Elementary Forms

text: decorate himself to play his part in the ritual, this decoration has to
title: Elementary Forms

text: be made specially for the occasion; it is a ceremonial costume, a gala
title: Elementary Forms

text: dress.[1037] As these ornaments are sacred, owing to the use made of
title: Elementary Forms

text: them, he is forbidden to use them in profane affairs; when the ceremony
title: Elementary Forms

text: is finished, they are buried or burnt;[1038] the men must even wash
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves in such a way as to carry away with them no trace of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: decorations with which they were adorned.[1039]
title: Elementary Forms

text: In general, all acts characteristic of the ordinary life are forbidden
title: Elementary Forms

text: while those of the religious life are taking place. The act of eating
title: Elementary Forms

text: is, of itself, profane; for it takes place every day, it satisfies
title: Elementary Forms

text: essentially utilitarian and material needs and it is a part of our
title: Elementary Forms

text: ordinary existence.[1040] This is why it is prohibited in religious
title: Elementary Forms

text: times. When one totemic group has loaned its churinga to a foreign clan,
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is an exceptionally solemn moment when they are brought back and put
title: Elementary Forms

text: into the ertnatulunga; all those who take part in the ceremony must fast
title: Elementary Forms

text: as long as it lasts, and it lasts a long time.[1041] The same rule is
title: Elementary Forms

text: observed during the rites,[1042] of which we shall speak in the next
title: Elementary Forms

text: chapter, as well as at certain moments of the initiation.[1043]
title: Elementary Forms

text: For this same reason, all temporal occupations are suspended while the
title: Elementary Forms

text: great religious solemnities are taking place. According to a remark of
title: Elementary Forms

text: Spencer and Gillen,[1044] which we have already had occasion to cite,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the life of the Australian is divided into two very distinct parts: the
title: Elementary Forms

text: one is devoted to hunting, fishing and warfare; the other is consecrated
title: Elementary Forms

text: to the cult, and these two forms of activity mutually exclude and repel
title: Elementary Forms

text: one another. It is on this principle that the universal institution of
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious days of rest reposes. The distinctive character of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: feast-days in all known religions is the cessation of work and the
title: Elementary Forms

text: suspension of public and private life, in so far as it does not have a
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious objective. This repose is not merely a sort of temporary
title: Elementary Forms

text: relaxation which men have given themselves in order to give themselves
title: Elementary Forms

text: up more freely to the sentiments of joy ordinarily awakened by the
title: Elementary Forms

text: feast-days; for they are sad feasts, consecrated to mourning and
title: Elementary Forms

text: repentance, and during which this cessation is no less obligatory. This
title: Elementary Forms

text: is because work is an eminent form of profane activity: it has no other
title: Elementary Forms

text: apparent end than to provide for the temporal necessities of life; it
title: Elementary Forms

text: puts us in relations with ordinary things only. On feast days, on the
title: Elementary Forms

text: contrary, the religious life attains an exceptional degree of intensity.
title: Elementary Forms

text: So the contrast between the two forms of existence is especially marked
title: Elementary Forms

text: at this moment; consequently, they cannot remain near to each other. A
title: Elementary Forms

text: man cannot approach his god intimately while he still bears on him marks
title: Elementary Forms

text: of his profane life; inversely, he cannot return to his usual
title: Elementary Forms

text: occupations when a rite has just sanctified him. So the ritual day of
title: Elementary Forms

text: rest is only one particular case of the general incompatibility
title: Elementary Forms

text: separating the sacred from the profane; it is the result of an
title: Elementary Forms

text: interdiction.
title: Elementary Forms

text: It would be impossible to enumerate here all the different interdictions
title: Elementary Forms

text: which have been observed, even in the Australian religions alone. Like
title: Elementary Forms

text: the notion of sacredness upon which it rests, the system of interdicts
title: Elementary Forms

text: extends into the most diverse relations; it is even used deliberately
title: Elementary Forms

text: for utilitarian ends.[1045] But howsoever complex it may be, it finally
title: Elementary Forms

text: rests upon two fundamental interdictions, which summarize it and
title: Elementary Forms

text: dominate it.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In the first place, the religious life and the profane life cannot
title: Elementary Forms

text: coexist in the same place. If the former is to develop, a special spot
title: Elementary Forms

text: must be placed at its disposition, from which the second is excluded.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Hence comes the founding of temples and sanctuaries: these are the spots
title: Elementary Forms

text: awarded to sacred beings and things and serve them as residences, for
title: Elementary Forms

text: they cannot establish themselves in any place except on the condition of
title: Elementary Forms

text: entirely appropriating to themselves all within a certain distance. Such
title: Elementary Forms

text: arrangements are so indispensable to all religious life that even the
title: Elementary Forms

text: most inferior religions cannot do without them. The ertnatulunga, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: spot where the churinga are deposited, is a veritable sanctuary. So the
title: Elementary Forms

text: uninitiated are not allowed to approach it. It is even forbidden to
title: Elementary Forms

text: carry on any profane occupation whatsoever there. As we shall presently
title: Elementary Forms

text: see, there are other holy places where important ceremonies are
title: Elementary Forms

text: celebrated.[1046]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Likewise, the religious life and the profane life cannot coexist in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: same unit of time. It is necessary to assign determined days or periods
title: Elementary Forms

text: to the first, from which all profane occupations are excluded. Thus
title: Elementary Forms

text: feast days are born. There is no religion, and, consequently, no society
title: Elementary Forms

text: which has not known and practised this division of time into two
title: Elementary Forms

text: distinct parts, alternating with one another according to a law varying
title: Elementary Forms

text: with the peoples and the civilizations; as we have already pointed out,
title: Elementary Forms

text: it was probably the necessity of this alternation which led men to
title: Elementary Forms

text: introduce into the continuity and homogeneity of duration, certain
title: Elementary Forms

text: distinctions and differentiations which it does not naturally
title: Elementary Forms

text: have.[1047] Of course, it is almost impossible that the religious life
title: Elementary Forms

text: should ever succeed in concentrating itself hermetically in the places
title: Elementary Forms

text: and times which are thus attributed to it; it is inevitable that a
title: Elementary Forms

text: little of it should filter out. There are always some sacred things
title: Elementary Forms

text: outside the sanctuaries; there are some rites that can be celebrated on
title: Elementary Forms

text: work-days. But these are sacred things of the second rank and rites of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: lesser importance. Concentration remains the dominating characteristic
title: Elementary Forms

text: of this organization. Generally this concentration is complete for all
title: Elementary Forms

text: that concerns the public cult, which cannot be celebrated except in
title: Elementary Forms

text: common. The individual, private cult is the only one which comes very
title: Elementary Forms

text: near to the temporal life. Thus the contrast between these two
title: Elementary Forms

text: successive phases of human life attains its maximum of intensity in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: inferior societies; for it is there that the individual cult is the most
title: Elementary Forms

text: rudimentary.[1048]
title: Elementary Forms

text: II
title: Elementary Forms

text: Up to the present, the negative cult has been presented to us only as a
title: Elementary Forms

text: system of abstentions. So it seems to serve only to inhibit activity,
title: Elementary Forms

text: and not to stimulate it or to modify it. And yet, as an unexpected
title: Elementary Forms

text: reaction to this inhibitive effect, it is found to exercise a positive
title: Elementary Forms

text: action of the highest importance over the religious and moral nature of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the individual.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In fact, owing to the barrier which separates the sacred from the
title: Elementary Forms

text: profane, a man cannot enter into intimate relations with sacred things
title: Elementary Forms

text: except after ridding himself of all that is profane in him. He cannot
title: Elementary Forms

text: lead a religious life of even a slight intensity unless he commences by
title: Elementary Forms

text: withdrawing more or less completely from the temporal life. So the
title: Elementary Forms

text: negative cult is in one sense a means in view of an end: it is a
title: Elementary Forms

text: condition of access to the positive cult. It does not confine itself to
title: Elementary Forms

text: protecting sacred beings from vulgar contact; it acts upon the
title: Elementary Forms

text: worshipper himself and modifies his condition positively. The man who
title: Elementary Forms

text: has submitted himself to its prescribed interdictions is not the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: afterwards as he was before. Before, he was an ordinary being who, for
title: Elementary Forms

text: this reason, had to keep at a distance from the religious forces.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Afterwards, he is on a more equal footing with them; he has approached
title: Elementary Forms

text: the sacred by the very act of leaving the profane; he has purified and
title: Elementary Forms

text: sanctified himself by the very act of detaching himself from the base
title: Elementary Forms

text: and trivial matters that debased his nature. So the negative rites
title: Elementary Forms

text: confer efficient powers just as well as the positive ones; the first,
title: Elementary Forms

text: like the second, can serve to elevate the religious tone of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: individual. According to a very true remark which has been made, no one
title: Elementary Forms

text: can engage in a religious ceremony of any importance without first
title: Elementary Forms

text: submitting himself to a sort of preliminary initiation which introduces
title: Elementary Forms

text: him progressively into the sacred world.[1049] Unctions, lustrations,
title: Elementary Forms

text: benedictions or any essentially positive operation may be used for this
title: Elementary Forms

text: purpose; but the same result may be attained by means of fasts and
title: Elementary Forms

text: vigils or retreat and silence, that is to say, by ritual abstinences,
title: Elementary Forms

text: which are nothing more than certain interdictions put into practice.
title: Elementary Forms

text: When there are only particular and isolated negative rites, their
title: Elementary Forms

text: positive action is generally too slight to be easily perceptible. But
title: Elementary Forms

text: there are circumstances when a whole system of interdictions is
title: Elementary Forms

text: concentrated on one man; in these cases, their effects accumulate, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: thus become more manifest. This takes place in Australia at the time of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the initiation. The neophyte is submitted to a great variety of
title: Elementary Forms

text: negative rites. He must withdraw from the society in which his existence
title: Elementary Forms

text: has been passed up till then, and from almost all human society. Not
title: Elementary Forms

text: only is it forbidden for him to see women and uninitiated persons,[1050]
title: Elementary Forms

text: but he also goes to live in the brush, far from his fellows, under the
title: Elementary Forms

text: direction of some old men who serve him as godfathers.[1051] So very
title: Elementary Forms

text: true is it that the forest is considered his natural environment, that
title: Elementary Forms

text: in a certain number of tribes, the word with which the initiation is
title: Elementary Forms

text: designated signifies _that which is from the forest_.[1052] For this
title: Elementary Forms

text: same reason, he is frequently decorated with leaves during the
title: Elementary Forms

text: ceremonies at which he assists.[1053] In this way he passes long
title: Elementary Forms

text: months,[1054] interspersed from time to time with rites in which he must
title: Elementary Forms

text: take a part. This time is a period of all sorts of abstinences for him.
title: Elementary Forms

text: A multitude of foods are forbidden him; he is allowed only that quantity
title: Elementary Forms

text: of food which is absolutely indispensable for the maintenance of
title: Elementary Forms

text: life;[1055] he is even sometimes bound to a rigorous fast,[1056] or must
title: Elementary Forms

text: eat impure foods.[1057] When he eats, he must not touch the food with
title: Elementary Forms

text: his hands; his godfathers put it into his mouth for him.[1058] In some
title: Elementary Forms

text: cases, he must go to beg his food.[1059] Likewise, he sleeps only as
title: Elementary Forms

text: much as is indispensable.[1060] He must abstain from talking, to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: extent of not uttering a word; it is by signs that he makes known his
title: Elementary Forms

text: needs.[1061] He must not wash;[1062] sometimes he must not move. He
title: Elementary Forms

text: remains stretched out upon the earth, immobile[1063] and without
title: Elementary Forms

text: clothing of any sort.[1064] Now the result of the numerous interdictions
title: Elementary Forms

text: is to bring about a radical change of condition in the initiate. Before
title: Elementary Forms

text: the initiation, he lived with the women; he was excluded from the cult.
title: Elementary Forms

text: After it, he is admitted to the society of men; he takes part in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: rites, and has acquired a sacred character. The metamorphosis is so
title: Elementary Forms

text: complete that it is sometimes represented as a second birth. They
title: Elementary Forms

text: imagine that the profane person, who was the young man up till then, has
title: Elementary Forms

text: died, that he has been killed and carried away by the god of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: initiation, Bunjil, Baiame or Daramulun, and that quite another
title: Elementary Forms

text: individual has taken the place of the one that no longer is.[1065] So
title: Elementary Forms

text: here we find the very heart of the positive effects of which negative
title: Elementary Forms

text: rites are capable. Of course we do not mean to say that these latter
title: Elementary Forms

text: produced this great transformation all by themselves; but they certainly
title: Elementary Forms

text: contributed to it, and largely.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In the light of these facts, we are able to understand what asceticism
title: Elementary Forms

text: is, what place it occupies in the religious life and whence come the
title: Elementary Forms

text: virtues which have generally been attributed to it. In fact, there is no
title: Elementary Forms

text: interdict, the observance of which does not have an ascetic character to
title: Elementary Forms

text: a certain degree. Abstaining from something which may be useful or from
title: Elementary Forms

text: a form of activity which, since it is usual, should answer to some human
title: Elementary Forms

text: need, is, of necessity, imposing constraints and renunciations. So in
title: Elementary Forms

text: order to have real asceticism, it is sufficient for these practices to
title: Elementary Forms

text: develop in such a way as to become the basis of a veritable scheme of
title: Elementary Forms

text: life. Normally, the negative cult serves only as an introduction and
title: Elementary Forms

text: preparation for the positive cult. But it sometimes happens that it
title: Elementary Forms

text: frees itself from this subordination and passes to the first place, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: that the system of interdicts swells and exaggerates itself to the point
title: Elementary Forms

text: of usurping the entire existence. Thus a systematic asceticism is born
title: Elementary Forms

text: which is consequently nothing more than a hypertrophy of the negative
title: Elementary Forms

text: cult. The special virtues which it is believed to confer are only an
title: Elementary Forms

text: amplified form of those conferred, to a lesser degree, by the practice
title: Elementary Forms

text: of any interdiction. They have the same origin; for they both rest on
title: Elementary Forms

text: the principle that a man sanctifies himself only by efforts made to
title: Elementary Forms

text: separate himself from the profane. The pure ascetic is a man who raises
title: Elementary Forms

text: himself above men and acquires a special sanctity by fasts and vigils,
title: Elementary Forms

text: by retreat and silence, or in a word, by privations, rather than by acts
title: Elementary Forms

text: of positive piety (offerings, sacrifices, prayers, etc.). History shows
title: Elementary Forms

text: to what a high religious prestige one may attain by this method: the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Buddhist saint is essentially an ascetic, and he is equal or superior to
title: Elementary Forms

text: the gods.
title: Elementary Forms

text: It follows that asceticism is not a rare, exceptional and nearly
title: Elementary Forms

text: abnormal fruit of the religious life, as some have supposed it to be; on
title: Elementary Forms

text: the contrary, it is one of its essential elements. Every religion
title: Elementary Forms

text: contains it, at least in germ, for there are none in which a system of
title: Elementary Forms

text: interdicts is not found. Their only difference in this regard which
title: Elementary Forms

text: there may be between cults is that this germ is more or less developed
title: Elementary Forms

text: in different ones. It should also be added that there probably is not a
title: Elementary Forms

text: single one in which this development does not take, at least
title: Elementary Forms

text: temporarily, the characteristic traits of real asceticism. This is what
title: Elementary Forms

text: generally takes place at certain critical periods when, for a relatively
title: Elementary Forms

text: short time, it is necessary to bring about a grave change of condition
title: Elementary Forms

text: in a subject. Then, in order to introduce him more rapidly into the
title: Elementary Forms

text: circle of sacred things with which he must be put in contact, he is
title: Elementary Forms

text: separated violently from the profane world; but this does not come
title: Elementary Forms

text: without many abstinences and an exceptional recrudescence of the system
title: Elementary Forms

text: of interdicts. Now this is just what happens in Australia at the moment
title: Elementary Forms

text: of initiation. In order to transform youths into men, it is necessary to
title: Elementary Forms

text: make them live the life of a veritable ascetic. Mrs. Parker very justly
title: Elementary Forms

text: calls them the monks of Baiame.[1066]
title: Elementary Forms

text: But abstinences and privations do not come without suffering. We hold to
title: Elementary Forms

text: the profane world by all the fibres of our flesh; our senses attach us
title: Elementary Forms

text: to it; our life depends upon it. It is not merely the natural theatre of
title: Elementary Forms

text: our activity; it penetrates us from every side; it is a part of
title: Elementary Forms

text: ourselves. So we cannot detach ourselves from it without doing violence
title: Elementary Forms

text: to our nature and without painfully wounding our instincts. In other
title: Elementary Forms

text: words, the negative cult cannot develop without causing suffering. Pain
title: Elementary Forms

text: is one of its necessary conditions. Some have been led to think of it as
title: Elementary Forms

text: constituting a sort of rite in itself; they have seen in it a state of
title: Elementary Forms

text: grace which is to be sought and aroused, even artificially, because of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the powers and privileges which it confers in the same way as these
title: Elementary Forms

text: systems of interdicts, of which it is the natural accompaniment. So far
title: Elementary Forms

text: as we know, Preuss is the first who has realized the religious
title: Elementary Forms

text: role[1067] which is attributed to suffering in the inferior societies.
title: Elementary Forms

text: He cites the case of the Arapahs who inflict veritable torments upon
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves in order to become immune from the dangers of battle; of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Big Belly Indians who submit to actual tortures on the eve of military
title: Elementary Forms

text: expeditions; of the Hupa who swim in icy rivers and then remain
title: Elementary Forms

text: stretched out on the bank as long as possible, in order to assure
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves of success in their enterprises; of the Karaya who from time
title: Elementary Forms

text: to time draw blood from their arms and legs by means of scratches made
title: Elementary Forms

text: out of the teeth of fish, in order to strengthen their muscles; of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: men of Dallmannhafen (Emperor William's Land in New Guinea) who combat
title: Elementary Forms

text: the sterility of their women by making bloody incisions in the upper
title: Elementary Forms

text: part of their thighs.[1068]
title: Elementary Forms

text: But similar facts may be found without leaving Australia, especially in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the course of the initiation ceremonies. Many of the rites practised on
title: Elementary Forms

text: this occasion consist in systematically inflicting certain pains on the
title: Elementary Forms

text: neophyte in order to modify his condition and to make him acquire the
title: Elementary Forms

text: qualities characteristic of a man. Thus, among the Larakia, while the
title: Elementary Forms

text: young men are in retreat in the forest, their godfathers and guardians
title: Elementary Forms

text: give them violent blows at any instant, without warning and without
title: Elementary Forms

text: cause.[1069] Among the Urabunna, at a certain time, the novice is
title: Elementary Forms

text: stretched out on the ground, his face against the earth. All the men
title: Elementary Forms

text: present beat him rudely; then they make four or eight gashes on his
title: Elementary Forms

text: back, arranged on each side of the dorsal spine and one on the meridial
title: Elementary Forms

text: line of the nape of his neck.[1070] Among the Arunta, the first rite of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the initiation consists in tossing the subject in a blanket; the men
title: Elementary Forms

text: throw him into the air and catch him when he comes down, to throw him up
title: Elementary Forms

text: again.[1071] In the same tribe, at the close of this long series of
title: Elementary Forms

text: ceremonies, the young man lies down on a bed of leaves under which they
title: Elementary Forms

text: have placed live coals; he remains there, immobile in the midst of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: heat and suffocating smoke.[1072] A similar rite is observed among the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Urabunna; but in addition, while the patient is in this painful
title: Elementary Forms

text: situation, they beat him on the back.[1073] In a general way, all the
title: Elementary Forms

text: exercises to which he is submitted have this same character to such an
title: Elementary Forms

text: extent that when he is allowed to re-enter the ordinary life, he has a
title: Elementary Forms

text: pitiful aspect and appears half stupefied.[1074] It is true that all
title: Elementary Forms

text: these practices are frequently represented as ordeals destined to prove
title: Elementary Forms

text: the value of the neophyte and to show whether he is worthy of being
title: Elementary Forms

text: admitted into the religious society or not.[1075] But in reality, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: probational function of the rite is only another aspect of its efficacy.
title: Elementary Forms

text: For the fact that it has been undergone is proved by its producing its
title: Elementary Forms

text: effect, that is to say, by its conferring the qualities which are the
title: Elementary Forms

text: original reason for its existence.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In other cases, these ritual cruelties are executed, not on the organism
title: Elementary Forms

text: as a whole, but on a particular organ or tissue, whose vitality it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: their object to stimulate. Thus, among the Arunta, the Warramunga and
title: Elementary Forms

text: many other tribes,[1076] at a certain moment in the initiation, certain
title: Elementary Forms

text: persons are charged with biting the novice severely in the scalp. This
title: Elementary Forms

text: operation is so painful that the patient can hardly support it without
title: Elementary Forms

text: uttering cries. Its object is to make the hair grow.[1077] The same
title: Elementary Forms

text: treatment is applied to make the beard grow. The rite of pulling out
title: Elementary Forms

text: hairs, which Howitt mentions in other tribes, seems to have the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: reason for existence.[1078] According to Eylmann, the men and women of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the Arunta and the Kaitish make small wounds on their arms with sticks
title: Elementary Forms

text: red with fire, in order to become skilful in making fire or to acquire
title: Elementary Forms

text: the strength necessary for carrying heavy loads of wood.[1079] According
title: Elementary Forms

text: to this same observer, the Warramunga girls amputate the second and
title: Elementary Forms

text: third joints of the index finger on one hand, thinking that the finger
title: Elementary Forms

text: thus becomes better fitted for finding yams.[1080]
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is not impossible that the extraction of teeth was sometimes destined
title: Elementary Forms

text: to produce effects of this sort. In any case, it is certain that the
title: Elementary Forms

text: cruel rites of circumcision and subincision have the object of
title: Elementary Forms

text: conferring particular powers on the genital organs. In fact, the young
title: Elementary Forms

text: man is not allowed to marry until after he has undergone them; so he
title: Elementary Forms

text: owes them special virtues. What makes this initiation _sui generis_
title: Elementary Forms

text: indispensable is that in all inferior societies, the union of the sexes
title: Elementary Forms

text: is marked with a religious character. It is believed to put redoubtable
title: Elementary Forms

text: forces into play which a man cannot approach without danger, until after
title: Elementary Forms

text: he has acquired the necessary immunity, by ritual processes:[1081] for
title: Elementary Forms

text: this, a whole series of positive and negative practices is used, of
title: Elementary Forms

text: which circumcision and subincision are the forerunners. By painfully
title: Elementary Forms

text: mutilating an organ, a sacred character is given to it, since by that
title: Elementary Forms

text: act, it is put into shape for resisting the equally sacred forces which
title: Elementary Forms

text: it could not meet otherwise.
title: Elementary Forms

text: At the beginning of this work, we said that all the essential elements
title: Elementary Forms

text: of religious thought and life ought to be found, at least in germ, in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the most primitive religions: the preceding facts confirm this
title: Elementary Forms

text: assertion. If there is any one belief which is believed to be peculiar
title: Elementary Forms

text: to the most recent and idealistic religions, it is the one attributing a
title: Elementary Forms

text: sanctifying power to sorrow. Now this same belief is at the basis of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: rites which have just been observed. Of course, it is understood
title: Elementary Forms

text: differently at the different moments of history when it is studied. For
title: Elementary Forms

text: the Christian, it acts especially upon the soul: it purges it, ennobles
title: Elementary Forms

text: it, spiritualizes it. For the Australian, it is the body over which it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is efficient: it increases its vital energies; it makes its beard and
title: Elementary Forms

text: hair grow; it toughens its members. But in both cases the principle is
title: Elementary Forms

text: the same. In both it is admitted that suffering creates exceptional
title: Elementary Forms

text: strength. And this belief is not without foundation. In fact, it is by
title: Elementary Forms

text: the way in which he braves suffering that the greatness of a man is best
title: Elementary Forms

text: manifested. He never rises above himself with more brilliancy than when
title: Elementary Forms

text: he subdues his own nature to the point of making it follow a way
title: Elementary Forms

text: contrary to the one it would spontaneously take. By this, he
title: Elementary Forms

text: distinguishes himself from all the other creatures who follow blindly
title: Elementary Forms

text: wherever pleasure calls them; by this, he makes a place apart for
title: Elementary Forms

text: himself in the world. Suffering is the sign that certain of the bonds
title: Elementary Forms

text: attaching him to his profane environment are broken; so it testifies
title: Elementary Forms

text: that he is partially freed from this environment, and, consequently, it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is justly considered the instrument of deliverance. So he who is thus
title: Elementary Forms

text: delivered is not the victim of a pure illusion when he believes himself
title: Elementary Forms

text: invested with a sort of mastery over things: he really has raised
title: Elementary Forms

text: himself above them, by the very act of renouncing them; he is stronger
title: Elementary Forms

text: than nature, because he makes it subside.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Moreover, it is by no means true that this virtue has only an aesthetic
title: Elementary Forms

text: value: the whole religious life supposes it. Sacrifices and privations
title: Elementary Forms

text: do not come without privations which cost the worshipper dear. Even if
title: Elementary Forms

text: the rites do not demand material gifts from him, they require his time
title: Elementary Forms

text: and his strength. In order to serve his gods, he must forget himself; to
title: Elementary Forms

text: make for them a fitting place in his own life, he must sacrifice his
title: Elementary Forms

text: profane interests. The positive cult is possible only when a man is
title: Elementary Forms

text: trained to renouncement, to abnegation, to detachment from self, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: consequently to suffering. It is necessary that he have no dread of
title: Elementary Forms

text: them: he cannot even fulfil his duties joyfully unless he loves them to
title: Elementary Forms

text: some extent. But for that, it is necessary that he train himself, and it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is to this that the ascetic practices tend. So the suffering which they
title: Elementary Forms

text: impose is not arbitrary and sterile cruelty; it is a necessary school,
title: Elementary Forms

text: where men form and temper themselves, and acquire the qualities of
title: Elementary Forms

text: disinterestedness and endurance without which there would be no
title: Elementary Forms

text: religion. If this result is to be obtained, it is even a good thing that
title: Elementary Forms

text: the ascetic ideal be incarnated eminently in certain persons, whose
title: Elementary Forms

text: speciality, so to speak, it is to represent, almost with excess, this
title: Elementary Forms

text: aspect of the ritual life; for they are like so many living models,
title: Elementary Forms

text: inciting to effort. Such is the historic role of the great ascetics.
title: Elementary Forms

text: When their deeds and acts are analysed in detail, one asks himself what
title: Elementary Forms

text: useful end they can have. He is struck by the fact that there is
title: Elementary Forms

text: something excessive in the disdain they profess for all that ordinarily
title: Elementary Forms

text: impassions men. But these exaggerations are necessary to sustain among
title: Elementary Forms

text: the believers a sufficient disgust for an easy life and common
title: Elementary Forms

text: pleasures. It is necessary that an elite put the end too high, if the
title: Elementary Forms

text: crowd is not to put it too low. It is necessary that some exaggerate, if
title: Elementary Forms

text: the average is to remain at a fitting level.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But asceticism does not serve religious ends only. Here, as elsewhere,
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious interests are only the symbolic form of social and moral
title: Elementary Forms

text: interests. The ideal beings to whom the cults are addressed are not the
title: Elementary Forms

text: only ones who demand of their followers a certain disdain for suffering:
title: Elementary Forms

text: society itself is possible only at this price. Though exalting the
title: Elementary Forms

text: strength of man, it is frequently rude to individuals; it necessarily
title: Elementary Forms

text: demands perpetual sacrifices from them; it is constantly doing violence
title: Elementary Forms

text: to our natural appetites, just because it raises us above ourselves. If
title: Elementary Forms

text: we are going to fulfil our duties towards it, then we must be prepared
title: Elementary Forms

text: to do violence to our instincts sometimes and to ascend the decline of
title: Elementary Forms

text: nature when it is necessary. So there is an asceticism which, being
title: Elementary Forms

text: inherent in all social life, is destined to survive all the mythologies
title: Elementary Forms

text: and all the dogmas; it is an integral part of all human culture. At
title: Elementary Forms

text: bottom, this is the asceticism which is the reason for the existence of
title: Elementary Forms

text: and the justification of that which has been taught by the religions of
title: Elementary Forms

text: all times.
title: Elementary Forms

text: III
title: Elementary Forms

text: Having determined what the system of interdicts consists in and what its
title: Elementary Forms

text: positive and negative functions are, we must now seek the causes which
title: Elementary Forms

text: have given it birth.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In one sense, it is logically implied in the very notion of sacredness.
title: Elementary Forms

text: All that is sacred is the object of respect, and every sentiment of
title: Elementary Forms

text: respect is translated, in him who feels it, by movements of inhibition.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In fact, a respected being is always expressed in the consciousness by a
title: Elementary Forms

text: representation which, owing to the emotion it inspires, is charged with
title: Elementary Forms

text: a high mental energy; consequently, it is armed in such a way as to
title: Elementary Forms

text: reject to a distance every other representation which denies it in whole
title: Elementary Forms

text: or in part. Now the sacred world and the profane world are antagonistic
title: Elementary Forms

text: to each other. They correspond to two forms of life which mutually
title: Elementary Forms

text: exclude one another, or which at least cannot be lived at the same time
title: Elementary Forms

text: with the same intensity. We cannot give ourselves up entirely to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: ideal beings to whom the cult is addressed and also to ourselves and our
title: Elementary Forms

text: own interests at the same time; we cannot devote ourselves entirely to
title: Elementary Forms

text: the group and entirely to our own egoism at once. Here there are two
title: Elementary Forms

text: systems of conscious states which are directed and which direct our
title: Elementary Forms

text: conduct towards opposite poles. So the one having the greater power of
title: Elementary Forms

text: action should tend to exclude the other from the consciousness. When we
title: Elementary Forms

text: think of holy things, the idea of a profane object cannot enter the mind
title: Elementary Forms

text: without encountering grave resistance; something within us opposes
title: Elementary Forms

text: itself to its installation. This is because the representation of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacred thing does not tolerate neighbours. But this psychic antagonism
title: Elementary Forms

text: and this mutual exclusion of ideas should naturally result in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: exclusion of the corresponding things. If the ideas are not to coexist,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the things must not touch each other or have any sort of relations. This
title: Elementary Forms

text: is the very principle of the interdict.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Moreover, the world of sacred things is, by definition, a world apart.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Since it is opposed to the profane world by all the characteristics we
title: Elementary Forms

text: have mentioned, it must be treated in its own peculiar way: it would be
title: Elementary Forms

text: a misunderstanding of its nature and a confusion of it with something
title: Elementary Forms

text: that it is not, to make use of the gestures, language and attitudes
title: Elementary Forms

text: which we employ in our relations with ordinary things, when we have to
title: Elementary Forms

text: do with the things that compose it. We may handle the former freely; we
title: Elementary Forms

text: speak freely to vulgar beings; so we do not touch the sacred beings, or
title: Elementary Forms

text: we touch them only with reserve; we do not speak in their presence, or
title: Elementary Forms

text: we do not speak the common language there. All that is used in our
title: Elementary Forms

text: commerce with the one must be excluded from our commerce with the other.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But if this explanation is not inexact, it is, nevertheless,
title: Elementary Forms

text: insufficient. In fact, there are many beings which are the objects of
title: Elementary Forms

text: respect without being protected by systems of rigorous interdictions
title: Elementary Forms

text: such as those we have just described. Of course there is a general
title: Elementary Forms

text: tendency of the mind to localize different things in different places,
title: Elementary Forms

text: especially when they are incompatible with each other. But the profane
title: Elementary Forms

text: environment and the sacred one are not merely distinct, but they are
title: Elementary Forms

text: also closed to one another; between them there is an abyss. So there
title: Elementary Forms

text: ought to be some particular reason in the nature of sacred things, which
title: Elementary Forms

text: causes this exceptional isolation and mutual exclusion. And, in fact, by
title: Elementary Forms

text: a sort of contradiction, the sacred world is inclined, as it were, to
title: Elementary Forms

text: spread itself into this same profane world which it excludes elsewhere:
title: Elementary Forms

text: at the same time that it repels it, it tends to flow into it as soon as
title: Elementary Forms

text: it approaches. This is why it is necessary to keep them at a distance
title: Elementary Forms

text: from one another and to create a sort of vacuum between them.
title: Elementary Forms

text: What makes these precautions necessary is the extraordinary
title: Elementary Forms

text: contagiousness of a sacred character. Far from being attached to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: things which are marked with it, it is endowed with a sort of
title: Elementary Forms

text: elusiveness. Even the most superficial or roundabout contact is
title: Elementary Forms

text: sufficient to enable it to spread from one object to another. Religious
title: Elementary Forms

text: forces are represented in the mind in such a way that they always seem
title: Elementary Forms

text: ready to escape from the points where they reside and to enter
title: Elementary Forms

text: everything passing within their range. The nanja tree where the spirit
title: Elementary Forms

text: of an ancestor lives is sacred for the individual who considers himself
title: Elementary Forms

text: the reincarnation of this ancestor. But every bird which alights upon
title: Elementary Forms

text: this tree participates in this same nature: it is also forbidden to
title: Elementary Forms

text: touch it.[1082] We have already had occasion to show how simple contact
title: Elementary Forms

text: with a churinga is enough to sanctify men and things;[1083] it is also
title: Elementary Forms

text: upon this principle of the contagiousness of sacredness that all the
title: Elementary Forms

text: rites of consecration repose. The sanctity of the churinga is so great
title: Elementary Forms

text: that its action is even felt at a distance. It will be remembered how
title: Elementary Forms

text: this extends not only to the cave where they are kept, but also to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: whole surrounding district, to the animals who take refuge there, whom
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is forbidden to kill, and to the plants which grow there, which must
title: Elementary Forms

text: not be touched.[1084] A snake totem has its centre at a place where
title: Elementary Forms

text: there is a water-hole. The sacred character of the totem is
title: Elementary Forms

text: communicated to this place, to the water-hole and even to the water
title: Elementary Forms

text: itself, which is forbidden to all the members of the totemic
title: Elementary Forms

text: group.[1085] The initiate lives in an atmosphere charged with
title: Elementary Forms

text: religiousness, and it is as though he were impregnated with it
title: Elementary Forms

text: himself.[1086] Consequently all that he possesses and all that he
title: Elementary Forms

text: touches is forbidden to the women, and withdrawn from their contact,
title: Elementary Forms

text: even down to the bird he has struck with his stick, the kangaroo he has
title: Elementary Forms

text: pierced with his lance or the fish which has bit on his hook.[1087] But,
title: Elementary Forms

text: on the other hand, the rites to which he is submitted and the things
title: Elementary Forms

text: which have a part in them have a sanctity superior to his own: this
title: Elementary Forms

text: sanctity is contagiously transmitted to everything which evokes the idea
title: Elementary Forms

text: of one or the other. The tooth which has been knocked out of him is
title: Elementary Forms

text: considered very holy.[1088] For this reason, he may not eat animals with
title: Elementary Forms

text: prominent teeth, because they make him think of his own lost tooth. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: ceremonies of the Kuringal terminate with a ritual washing;[1089]
title: Elementary Forms

text: acquatic birds are forbidden to the neophyte because they make him think
title: Elementary Forms

text: of this rite. Animals that climb to the tops of trees are equally sacred
title: Elementary Forms

text: for him, because they are too near to Daramulun, the god of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: initiation, who lives in heaven.[1090] The soul of a dead man is a
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacred thing: we have already seen how this same property passes to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: corpse in which the soul resided, to the spot where this is buried, to
title: Elementary Forms

text: the camp in which he lived when alive, and which is either destroyed or
title: Elementary Forms

text: quitted, to the name he bore, to his wife and to his relations.[1091]
title: Elementary Forms

text: They, too, are invested, as it were, with a sacred character;
title: Elementary Forms

text: consequently, men keep at a distance from them; they do not treat them
title: Elementary Forms

text: as mere profane beings. In the societies observed by Dawson, their
title: Elementary Forms

text: names, like that of the dead man, cannot be pronounced during the period
title: Elementary Forms

text: of mourning.[1092] Certain animals which he ate may also be
title: Elementary Forms

text: prohibited.[1093]
title: Elementary Forms

text: This contagiousness of sacredness is too well known a phenomenon[1094]
title: Elementary Forms

text: to require any proof of its existence from numerous examples; we only
title: Elementary Forms

text: wish to show that it is as true in totemism as in the more advanced
title: Elementary Forms

text: religions. When once established, it quickly explains the extreme rigour
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the interdicts separating the sacred from the profane. Since, in
title: Elementary Forms

text: virtue of this extraordinary power of expansion, the slightest contact,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the least proximity, either material or simply moral, suffices to draw
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious forces out of their domain, and since, on the other hand, they
title: Elementary Forms

text: cannot leave it without contradicting their nature, a whole system of
title: Elementary Forms

text: measures is indispensable for maintaining the two worlds at a respectful
title: Elementary Forms

text: distance from one another. This is why it is forbidden to the profane,
title: Elementary Forms

text: not only to touch, but even to see or hear that which is sacred, and why
title: Elementary Forms

text: these two sorts of life cannot be mixed in their consciousnesses.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Precautions are necessary to keep them apart because, though opposing
title: Elementary Forms

text: one another, they tend to confuse themselves into one another.
title: Elementary Forms

text: When we understand the multiplicity of these interdicts we also
title: Elementary Forms

text: understand the way in which they operate and the sanctions which are
title: Elementary Forms

text: attached to them. Owing to the contagiousness inherent in all that is
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacred, a profane being cannot violate an interdict without having the
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious force, to which he has unduly approached, extend itself over
title: Elementary Forms

text: him and establish its empire over him. But as there is an antagonism
title: Elementary Forms

text: between them, he becomes dependent upon a hostile power, whose hostility
title: Elementary Forms

text: cannot fail to manifest itself in the form of violent reactions which
title: Elementary Forms

text: tend to destroy him. This is why sickness or death are considered the
title: Elementary Forms

text: natural consequences of every transgression of this sort; and they are
title: Elementary Forms

text: consequences which are believed to come by themselves, with a sort of
title: Elementary Forms

text: physical necessity. The guilty man feels himself attacked by a force
title: Elementary Forms

text: which dominates him and against which he is powerless. Has he eaten the
title: Elementary Forms

text: totemic animal? Then he feels it penetrating him and gnawing at his
title: Elementary Forms

text: vitals; he lies down on the ground and awaits death.[1095] Every
title: Elementary Forms

text: profanation implies a consecration, but one which is dreadful, both for
title: Elementary Forms

text: the subject consecrated and for those who approach him. It is the
title: Elementary Forms

text: consequences of this consecration which sanction, in part, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: interdict.[1096]
title: Elementary Forms

text: It should be noticed that this explanation of the interdicts does not
title: Elementary Forms

text: depend upon the variable symbols by the aid of which religious forces
title: Elementary Forms

text: are conceived. It matters little whether these are conceived as
title: Elementary Forms

text: anonymous and impersonal energies or figured as personalities endowed
title: Elementary Forms

text: with consciousness and feeling. In the former case, of course, they are
title: Elementary Forms

text: believed to react against profaning transgressions in an automatic and
title: Elementary Forms

text: unconscious manner, while in the latter case, they are thought to obey
title: Elementary Forms

text: passionate movements determined by the offence resented. But at bottom,
title: Elementary Forms

text: these two conceptions, which, moreover, have the same practical effect,
title: Elementary Forms

text: only express one and the same psychic mechanism in two different
title: Elementary Forms

text: languages. The basis of both is the antagonism of the sacred and the
title: Elementary Forms

text: profane, combined with the remarkable aptitude of the former for
title: Elementary Forms

text: spreading over to the latter; now this antagonism and this
title: Elementary Forms

text: contagiousness act in the same way, whether the sacred character is
title: Elementary Forms

text: attributed to blind forces or to conscious ones. Thus, so far is it from
title: Elementary Forms

text: being true that the real religious life commences only where there are
title: Elementary Forms

text: mythical personalities, that we see that in this case the rite remains
title: Elementary Forms

text: the same, whether the religious beings are personified or not. This is a
title: Elementary Forms

text: statement which we shall have occasion to repeat in each of the chapters
title: Elementary Forms

text: which follow.
title: Elementary Forms

text: IV
title: Elementary Forms

text: But if this contagiousness of sacredness helps to explain the system of
title: Elementary Forms

text: interdicts, how is it to be explained itself?
title: Elementary Forms

text: Some have tried to explain it with the well-known laws of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: association of ideas. The sentiments inspired in us by a person or a
title: Elementary Forms

text: thing spread contagiously from the idea of this thing or person to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: representations associated with it, and thence to the objects which
title: Elementary Forms

text: these representations express. So the respect which we have for a sacred
title: Elementary Forms

text: being is communicated to everything touching this being, or resembling
title: Elementary Forms

text: it, or recalling it. Of course a cultivated man is not deceived by these
title: Elementary Forms

text: associations; he knows that these derived emotions are due to mere plays
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the images and to entirely mental combinations, so he does not give
title: Elementary Forms

text: way to the superstitions which these illusions tend to bring about. But
title: Elementary Forms

text: they say that the primitive naively objectifies his impressions, without
title: Elementary Forms

text: criticising them. Does something inspire a reverential fear in him? He
title: Elementary Forms

text: concludes that an august and redoubtable force really resides in it; so
title: Elementary Forms

text: he keeps at a distance from this thing and treats it as though it were
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacred, even though it has no right to this title.[1097]
title: Elementary Forms

text: But whoever says this forgets that the most primitive religions are not
title: Elementary Forms

text: the only ones which have attributed this power of propagation to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacred character. Even in the most recent cults, there is a group of
title: Elementary Forms

text: rites which repose upon this principle. Does not every consecration by
title: Elementary Forms

text: means of anointing or washing consist in transferring into a profane
title: Elementary Forms

text: object the sanctifying virtues of a sacred one? Yet it is difficult to
title: Elementary Forms

text: regard an enlightened Catholic of to-day as a sort of retarded savage
title: Elementary Forms

text: who continues to be deceived by his associations of ideas, while nothing
title: Elementary Forms

text: in the nature of things explains or justifies these ways of thinking.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Moreover, it is quite arbitrarily that they attribute to the primitive
title: Elementary Forms

text: this tendency to objectify blindly all his emotions. In his ordinary
title: Elementary Forms

text: life, and in the details of his lay occupations, he does not impute the
title: Elementary Forms

text: properties of one thing to its neighbours, or _vice versa_. If he is
title: Elementary Forms

text: less careful than we are about clarity and distinction, still it is far
title: Elementary Forms

text: from true that he has some vague, deplorable aptitude for jumbling and
title: Elementary Forms

text: confusing everything. Religious thought alone has a marked leaning
title: Elementary Forms

text: towards these sorts of confusions. So it is in something special to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: nature of religious things, and not in the general laws of the human
title: Elementary Forms

text: intelligence, that the origin of these predispositions is to be sought.
title: Elementary Forms

text: When a force or property seems to be an integral part or constituent
title: Elementary Forms

text: element of the subject in which it resides, we cannot easily imagine its
title: Elementary Forms

text: detaching itself and going elsewhere. A body is defined by its mass and
title: Elementary Forms

text: its atomic composition; so we do not think that it could communicate any
title: Elementary Forms

text: of these distinctive characteristics by means of contact. But, on the
title: Elementary Forms

text: other hand, if we are dealing with a force which has penetrated the body
title: Elementary Forms

text: from without, since nothing attaches it there and since it is foreign to
title: Elementary Forms

text: the body, there is nothing inconceivable in its escaping again. Thus the
title: Elementary Forms

text: heat or electricity which a body has received from some external source
title: Elementary Forms

text: may be transmitted to the surrounding medium, and the mind readily
title: Elementary Forms

text: accepts the possibility of this transmission. So the extreme facility
title: Elementary Forms

text: with which religious forces spread out and diffuse themselves has
title: Elementary Forms

text: nothing surprising about it, if they are generally thought of as outside
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the beings in which they reside. Now this is just what the theory we
title: Elementary Forms

text: have proposed implies.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In fact, they are only collective forces hypostatized, that is to say,
title: Elementary Forms

text: moral forces; they are made up of the ideas and sentiments awakened in
title: Elementary Forms

text: us by the spectacle of society, and not of sensations coming from the
title: Elementary Forms

text: physical world. So they are not homogeneous with the visible things
title: Elementary Forms

text: among which we place them. They may well take from these things the
title: Elementary Forms

text: outward and material forms in which they are represented, but they owe
title: Elementary Forms

text: none of their efficacy to them. They are not united by external bonds
title: Elementary Forms

text: to the different supports upon which they alight; they have no roots
title: Elementary Forms

text: there; according to an expression we have already used[1098] and which
title: Elementary Forms

text: serves best for characterizing them, _they are added to them_. So there
title: Elementary Forms

text: are no objects which are predestined to receive them, to the exclusion
title: Elementary Forms

text: of all others; even the most insignificant and vulgar may do so;
title: Elementary Forms

text: accidental circumstances decide which are the chosen ones. The terms in
title: Elementary Forms

text: which Codrington speaks of the mana should be borne in mind: it is a
title: Elementary Forms

text: force, he says, which "_is not fixed in anything and can be conveyed in
title: Elementary Forms

text: almost anything_."[1099] Likewise, the Dakota of Miss Fletcher
title: Elementary Forms

text: represented the wakan as a sort of surrounding force which is always
title: Elementary Forms

text: coming and going through the world, alighting here and there, but
title: Elementary Forms

text: definitely fixing itself nowhere.[1100] Even the religious character
title: Elementary Forms

text: inherent in men does not have a different character. There is certainly
title: Elementary Forms

text: no other being in the world of experience which is closer to the very
title: Elementary Forms

text: source of all religious life; none participates in it more directly, for
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is in human consciousnesses that it is elaborated. Yet we know that
title: Elementary Forms

text: the religious principle animating men, to wit, the soul, is partially
title: Elementary Forms

text: external.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But if religious forces have a place of their own nowhere, their
title: Elementary Forms

text: mobility is easily explained. Since nothing attaches them to the things
title: Elementary Forms

text: in which we localize them, it is natural that they should escape on the
title: Elementary Forms

text: slightest contact, in spite of themselves, so to speak, and that they
title: Elementary Forms

text: should spread afar. Their intensity incites them to this spreading,
title: Elementary Forms

text: which everything favours. This is why the soul itself, though holding to
title: Elementary Forms

text: the body by very personal bonds, is constantly threatening to leave it:
title: Elementary Forms

text: all the apertures and pores of the body are just so many ways by which
title: Elementary Forms

text: it tends to spread and diffuse itself into the outside.[1101]
title: Elementary Forms

text: But we shall account for this phenomenon which we are trying to
title: Elementary Forms

text: understand, still better if, instead of considering the notion of
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious forces as it is when completely formulated, we go back to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: mental process from which it results.
title: Elementary Forms

text: We have seen, in fact, that the sacred character of a being does not
title: Elementary Forms

text: rest in any of its intrinsic attributes. It is not because the totemic
title: Elementary Forms

text: animal has a certain aspect or property that it inspires religious
title: Elementary Forms

text: sentiments; these result from causes wholly foreign to the nature of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: object upon which they fix themselves. What constitutes them are the
title: Elementary Forms

text: impressions of comfort and dependence which the action of the society
title: Elementary Forms

text: provokes in the mind. Of themselves, these emotions are not attached to
title: Elementary Forms

text: the idea of any particular object; but as these emotions exist and are
title: Elementary Forms

text: especially intense, they are also eminently contagious. So they make a
title: Elementary Forms

text: stain of oil; they extend to all the other mental states which occupy
title: Elementary Forms

text: the mind; they penetrate and contaminate those representations
title: Elementary Forms

text: especially in which are expressed the various objects which the man had
title: Elementary Forms

text: in his hands or before his eyes at the moment: the totemic designs
title: Elementary Forms

text: covering his body, the bull-roarers which he was making roar, the rocks
title: Elementary Forms

text: surrounding him, the ground under his feet, etc. It is thus that the
title: Elementary Forms

text: objects themselves get a religious value which is really not inherent in
title: Elementary Forms

text: them but is conferred from without. So the contagion is not a sort of
title: Elementary Forms

text: secondary process by which sacredness is propagated, after it has once
title: Elementary Forms

text: been acquired; it is the very process by which it is acquired. It is by
title: Elementary Forms

text: contagion that it establishes itself: we should not be surprised,
title: Elementary Forms

text: therefore, if it transmits itself contagiously. What makes its reality
title: Elementary Forms

text: is a special emotion; if it attaches itself to some object, it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: because this emotion has found this object in its way. So it is natural
title: Elementary Forms

text: that from this one it should spread to all those which it finds in its
title: Elementary Forms

text: neighbourhood, that is to say, to all those which any reason whatsoever,
title: Elementary Forms

text: either material contiguity or mere similarity, has mentally connected
title: Elementary Forms

text: with the first.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Thus, the contagiousness of sacredness finds its explanation in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: theory which we have proposed of religious forces, and by this very
title: Elementary Forms

text: fact, it serves to confirm our theory.[1102] And, at the same time, it
title: Elementary Forms

text: aids us in understanding a trait of primitive mentality to which we have
title: Elementary Forms

text: already called the attention.
title: Elementary Forms

text: We have seen[1103] the facility with which the primitive confuses
title: Elementary Forms

text: kingdoms and identifies the most heterogeneous things, men, animals,
title: Elementary Forms

text: plants, stars, etc. Now we see one of the causes which has contributed
title: Elementary Forms

text: the most to facilitating these confusions. Since religious forces are
title: Elementary Forms

text: eminently contagious, it is constantly happening that the same principle
title: Elementary Forms

text: animates very different objects equally; it passes from some into others
title: Elementary Forms

text: as the result of either a simple material proximity or of even a
title: Elementary Forms

text: superficial similarity. It is thus that men, animals, plants and rocks
title: Elementary Forms

text: come to have the same totem: the men because they bear the name of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: animal: the animals because they bring the totemic emblem to mind; the
title: Elementary Forms

text: plants because they nourish these animals; the rocks because they mark
title: Elementary Forms

text: the place where the ceremonies are celebrated. Now religious forces are
title: Elementary Forms

text: therefore considered the source of all efficacy; so beings having one
title: Elementary Forms

text: single religious principle ought to pass as having the same essence, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: as differing from one another only in secondary characteristics. This is
title: Elementary Forms

text: why it seemed quite natural to arrange them in a single category and to
title: Elementary Forms

text: regard them as mere varieties of the same class, transmutable into one
title: Elementary Forms

text: another.
title: Elementary Forms

text: When this relation has been established, it makes the phenomena of
title: Elementary Forms

text: contagion appear under a new aspect. Taken by themselves, they seem to
title: Elementary Forms

text: be quite foreign to the logical life. Is their effect not to mix and
title: Elementary Forms

text: confuse beings, in spite of their natural differences? But we have seen
title: Elementary Forms

text: that these confusions and participation have played a role of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: highest utility in logic; they have served to bind together things which
title: Elementary Forms

text: sensation leaves apart from one another. So it is far from true that
title: Elementary Forms

text: contagion, the source of these connections and confusions, is marked
title: Elementary Forms

text: with that fundamental irrationality that one is inclined to attribute it
title: Elementary Forms

text: at first. It has opened the way for the scientific explanations of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: future.
title: Elementary Forms

text: CHAPTER II
title: Elementary Forms

text: THE POSITIVE CULT
title: Elementary Forms

text: I.--_The Elements of the Sacrifice_
title: Elementary Forms

text: Whatever the importance of the negative cult may be, and though it may
title: Elementary Forms

text: indirectly have positive effects, it does not contain its reason for
title: Elementary Forms

text: existence in itself; it introduces one to the religious life, but it
title: Elementary Forms

text: supposes this more than it constitutes it. If it orders the worshipper
title: Elementary Forms

text: to flee from the profane world, it is to bring him nearer to the sacred
title: Elementary Forms

text: world. Men have never thought that their duties towards religious forces
title: Elementary Forms

text: might be reduced to a simple abstinence from all commerce; they have
title: Elementary Forms

text: always believed that they upheld positive and bilateral relations with
title: Elementary Forms

text: them, whose regulation and organization is the function of a group of
title: Elementary Forms

text: ritual practices. To this special system of rites we give the name of
title: Elementary Forms

text: _positive cult_.
title: Elementary Forms

text: For some time we almost completely ignored the positive cult of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: totemic religion and what it consists in. We knew almost nothing more
title: Elementary Forms

text: than the initiation rites, and we do not know those sufficiently well
title: Elementary Forms

text: even now. But the observations of Spencer and Gillen, prepared for by
title: Elementary Forms

text: those of Schulze and confirmed by those of Strehlow, on the tribes of
title: Elementary Forms

text: central Australia, have partially filled this gap in our information.
title: Elementary Forms

text: There is one ceremony especially which these explorers have taken
title: Elementary Forms

text: particular pains to describe to us and which, moreover, seems to
title: Elementary Forms

text: dominate the whole totemic cult: this is the one that the Arunta,
title: Elementary Forms

text: according to Spencer and Gillen, call the _Intichiuma_. It is true that
title: Elementary Forms

text: Strehlow contests the meaning of this word. According to him, intichiuma
title: Elementary Forms

text: (or, as he writes it, _intijiuma_) means "to instruct" and designates
title: Elementary Forms

text: the ceremonies performed before the young man to teach him the
title: Elementary Forms

text: traditions of the tribe. The feast which we are going to describe bears,
title: Elementary Forms

text: he says, the name _mbatjalkatiuma_, which means "to fecundate" or "to
title: Elementary Forms

text: put into a good condition."[1104] But we shall not try to settle this
title: Elementary Forms

text: question of vocabulary, which touches the real problem but slightly, as
title: Elementary Forms

text: the rites in question are all celebrated in the course of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: initiation. On the other hand, as the word Intichiuma now belongs to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: current language of ethnography, and has almost become a common noun, it
title: Elementary Forms

text: seems useless to replace it with another.[1105]
title: Elementary Forms

text: The date on which the Intichiuma takes place depends largely upon the
title: Elementary Forms

text: season. There are two sharply separated seasons in Australia: one is dry
title: Elementary Forms

text: and lasts for a long time; the other is rainy and is, on the contrary,
title: Elementary Forms

text: very short and frequently irregular. As soon as the rains arrive,
title: Elementary Forms

text: vegetation springs up from the ground as though by enchantment and
