title: Elementary Forms

text: animals multiply, so that the country which had recently been only a
title: Elementary Forms

text: sterile desert is rapidly filled with a luxurious flora and fauna. It is
title: Elementary Forms

text: just at the moment when the good season seems to be close at hand that
title: Elementary Forms

text: the Intichiuma is celebrated. But as the rainy season is extremely
title: Elementary Forms

text: variable, the date of the ceremonies cannot be fixed once for all. It
title: Elementary Forms

text: varies with the climatic circumstances, which only the chief of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: totemic group, the Alatunja, is qualified to judge: on a day which he
title: Elementary Forms

text: considers suitable, he informs his companions that the moment has
title: Elementary Forms

text: arrived.[1106]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Each totemic group has its own Intichiuma. Even if this rite is general
title: Elementary Forms

text: in the societies of the centre, it is not the same everywhere; among the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Warramunga, it is not what it is among the Arunta; it varies, not only
title: Elementary Forms

text: among the tribes, but also within the tribe, among the clans. But it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: obvious that the different mechanisms in use are too closely related to
title: Elementary Forms

text: each other to be dissociated completely. There is no ceremony, perhaps,
title: Elementary Forms

text: which is not made up of several, though these are very unequally
title: Elementary Forms

text: developed: what exists only as a germ in one, occupies the most
title: Elementary Forms

text: important place in another, and inversely. Yet they must be carefully
title: Elementary Forms

text: distinguished, for they constitute just so many different ritual types
title: Elementary Forms

text: to be described and explained separately, but afterwards we must seek
title: Elementary Forms

text: some common source from which they were derived.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Let us commence with those observed among the Arunta.
title: Elementary Forms

text: I
title: Elementary Forms

text: The celebration includes two successive phases. The object of the rites
title: Elementary Forms

text: which take place in the first is to assure the prosperity of the animal
title: Elementary Forms

text: or vegetable species serving the clan as totem. The means employed for
title: Elementary Forms

text: this end may be reduced to two principal types.
title: Elementary Forms

text: It will be remembered that the fabulous ancestors from whom each clan is
title: Elementary Forms

text: supposed to be descended, formerly lived on earth and left traces of
title: Elementary Forms

text: their passage there. These traces consist especially in stones and rocks
title: Elementary Forms

text: which they deposited at certain places, or which were formed at the
title: Elementary Forms

text: spots where they entered into the ground. These rocks and stones are
title: Elementary Forms

text: considered the bodies or parts of the bodies of the ancestors, whose
title: Elementary Forms

text: memory they keep alive; they represent them. Consequently, they also
title: Elementary Forms

text: represent the animals and plants which served these same ancestors as
title: Elementary Forms

text: totems, for an individual and his totem are only one. The same reality
title: Elementary Forms

text: and the same properties are attributed to them as to the actually living
title: Elementary Forms

text: plants or animals of the same species. But they have this advantage over
title: Elementary Forms

text: these latter, that they are imperishable, knowing neither sickness nor
title: Elementary Forms

text: death. So they are like a permanent immutable and ever-available reserve
title: Elementary Forms

text: of animal and vegetable life. Also, in a certain number of cases, it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: this reserve that they annually draw upon to assure the reproduction of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the species.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Here, for example, is how the Witchetty grub clan, at Alice Springs,
title: Elementary Forms

text: proceeds at its Intichiuma.[1107]
title: Elementary Forms

text: On the day fixed by the chief, all the members of the totemic group
title: Elementary Forms

text: assemble in the principal camp. The men of the other totems retire to a
title: Elementary Forms

text: distance;[1108] for among the Arunta, they are not allowed to be present
title: Elementary Forms

text: at the celebration of the rite, which has all the characteristics of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: secret ceremony. An individual of a different totem, but of the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: phratry, may be invited to be present, as a favour; but this is only as
title: Elementary Forms

text: a witness. In no case can he take an active part.
title: Elementary Forms

text: After the men of the totem have assembled, they leave the camp, leaving
title: Elementary Forms

text: only two or three of their number behind. They advance in a profound
title: Elementary Forms

text: silence, one behind another, all naked, without arms and without any of
title: Elementary Forms

text: their habitual ornaments. Their attitude and their pace are marked with
title: Elementary Forms

text: a religious gravity: this is because the act in which they are taking
title: Elementary Forms

text: part has an exceptional importance in their eyes. Also, until the end of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the ceremony they are required to observe a rigorous fast.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The country which they traverse is all filled with souvenirs left by the
title: Elementary Forms

text: glorious ancestors. Thus they arrive at a spot where a huge block of
title: Elementary Forms

text: quartz is found, with small round stones all around it. This block
title: Elementary Forms

text: represents the witchetty grub as an adult. The Alatunja strikes it with
title: Elementary Forms

text: a sort of wooden tray called _apmara_,[1109] and at the same time he
title: Elementary Forms

text: intones a chant, whose object is to invite the animal to lay eggs. He
title: Elementary Forms

text: proceeds in the same fashion with the stones which are regarded as the
title: Elementary Forms

text: eggs of the animal and with one of which he rubs the stomach of each
title: Elementary Forms

text: assistant. This done, they all descend a little lower, to the foot of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: cliff also celebrated in the myths of the Alcheringa, at the base of
title: Elementary Forms

text: which is another stone, also representing the witchetty grub. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: Alatunja strikes it with his apmara; the men accompanying him do so as
title: Elementary Forms

text: well, with branches of a gum-tree which they have gathered on the way,
title: Elementary Forms

text: all of which goes on in the midst of chants renewing the invitation
title: Elementary Forms

text: previously addressed to the animal. About ten different spots are
title: Elementary Forms

text: visited in turn, some of which are a mile or more from the others. At
title: Elementary Forms

text: each of them there is a stone at the bottom of a cave or hole, which is
title: Elementary Forms

text: believed to represent the witchetty grub in one of his aspects or at one
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the phases of his existence, and upon each of these stones, the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: ceremonies are repeated.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The meaning of the rite is evident. When the Alatunja strikes the sacred
title: Elementary Forms

text: stones, it is to detach some dust. The grains of this very holy dust are
title: Elementary Forms

text: regarded as so many germs of life; each of them contains a spiritual
title: Elementary Forms

text: principle which will give birth to a new being, when introduced into an
title: Elementary Forms

text: organism of the same species. The branches with which the assistants are
title: Elementary Forms

text: provided serve to scatter this precious dust in all directions; it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: scattered everywhere, to accomplish its fecundating work. By this means,
title: Elementary Forms

text: they assure, in their own minds, an abundant reproduction of the animal
title: Elementary Forms

text: species over which the clans guard, so to speak, and upon which it
title: Elementary Forms

text: depends.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The natives themselves give the rite this interpretation. Thus, in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: clan of the _ilpirla_ (a kind of "manna"), they proceed in the following
title: Elementary Forms

text: manner. When the day of the Intichiuma arrives, the group assembles near
title: Elementary Forms

text: a huge rock, about fifty feet high; on top of this rock is another, very
title: Elementary Forms

text: similar to the first in aspect and surrounded by other smaller ones.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Both represent masses of manna. The Alatunja digs up the ground at the
title: Elementary Forms

text: foot of this rock and uncovers a churinga which is believed to have been
title: Elementary Forms

text: buried there in Alcheringa times, and which is, as it were, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: quintessence of the manna. Then he climbs up to the summit of the higher
title: Elementary Forms

text: rock and rubs it, first with the churinga and then with the smaller
title: Elementary Forms

text: stones which surround it. Finally, he brushes away the dust which has
title: Elementary Forms

text: thus been collected on the surface of the rock, with the branches of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: tree; each of the assistants does the same in his turn. Now Spencer and
title: Elementary Forms

text: Gillen say that the idea of the natives is that the dust thus scattered
title: Elementary Forms

text: will "settle upon the mulga trees and so produce manna." In fact, these
title: Elementary Forms

text: operations are accompanied by a hymn sung by those present, in which
title: Elementary Forms

text: this idea is expressed.[1110]
title: Elementary Forms

text: With variations, this same rite is found in other societies. Among the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Urabunna, there is a rock representing an ancestor of the Lizard clan;
title: Elementary Forms

text: bits are detached from it which they throw in every direction, in order
title: Elementary Forms

text: to secure an abundant production of lizards.[1111] In this same tribe,
title: Elementary Forms

text: there is a sand-bank which mythological souvenirs closely associate with
title: Elementary Forms

text: the louse totem. At the same spot are two trees, one of which is called
title: Elementary Forms

text: the ordinary louse tree, the other, the crab-louse tree. They take some
title: Elementary Forms

text: of this sand, rub it on these trees, throw it about on every side and
title: Elementary Forms

text: become convinced that, as a result of this, lice will be born in large
title: Elementary Forms

text: numbers.[1112] The Mara perform the Intichiuma of the bees by scattering
title: Elementary Forms

text: dust detached from sacred rocks.[1113] For the kangaroo of the plains, a
title: Elementary Forms

text: slightly different method is used. They take some kangaroo-dung and wrap
title: Elementary Forms

text: it up in a certain herb of which the animal is very fond, and which
title: Elementary Forms

text: belongs to the kangaroo totem for this reason. Then they put the dung,
title: Elementary Forms

text: thus enveloped, on the ground between two bunches of this herb and set
title: Elementary Forms

text: the whole thing on fire. With the flame thus made, they light the
title: Elementary Forms

text: branches of trees and then whirl them about in such a way that sparks
title: Elementary Forms

text: fly in every direction. These sparks play the same role as the dust in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the preceding cases.[1114]
title: Elementary Forms

text: In a certain number of clans,[1115] men mix something of their own
title: Elementary Forms

text: substance with that of the stone, in order to make the rite more
title: Elementary Forms

text: efficacious. Young men open their veins and let streams of blood flow on
title: Elementary Forms

text: to the rock. This is the case, for example, in the Intichiuma of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Hakea flower among the Arunta. The ceremony takes place in a sacred
title: Elementary Forms

text: place around an equally sacred rock which, in the eyes of the natives,
title: Elementary Forms

text: represents Hakea flowers. After certain preliminary operations, "the old
title: Elementary Forms

text: leader asks one of the young men to open a vein in his arm, which he
title: Elementary Forms

text: does, and allows the blood to sprinkle freely, while the other men
title: Elementary Forms

text: continue the singing. The blood flows until the stone is completely
title: Elementary Forms

text: covered."[1116] The object of this practice is to revivify the virtues
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the stone, after a fashion, and to reinforce its efficacy. It should
title: Elementary Forms

text: not be forgotten that the men of the clan are relatives of the plant or
title: Elementary Forms

text: animal whose name they bear; the same principle of life is in them, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: especially in their blood. So it is only natural that one should use
title: Elementary Forms

text: this blood and the mystic germs which it carries to assure the regular
title: Elementary Forms

text: reproduction of the totemic species. It frequently happens among the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Arunta that when a man is sick or tired, one of his young companions
title: Elementary Forms

text: opens his veins and sprinkles him with his blood in order to reanimate
title: Elementary Forms

text: him.[1117] If blood is able to reawaken life in a man in this way, it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: not surprising that it should also be able to awaken it in the animal or
title: Elementary Forms

text: vegetable species with which the men of the clan are confounded.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The same process is employed in the Intichiuma of the Undiara kangaroo
title: Elementary Forms

text: among the Arunta. The theatre of the ceremony is a water-hole vaulted
title: Elementary Forms

text: over by a peaked rock. This rock represents an animal-kangaroo of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Alcheringa which was killed and deposited there by a man-kangaroo of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: same epoch; many kangaroo spirits are also believed to reside there.
title: Elementary Forms

text: After a certain number of sacred stones have been rubbed against each
title: Elementary Forms

text: other in the way we have described, several of the assistants climb up
title: Elementary Forms

text: on the rock upon which they let their blood flow.[1118] "The purpose of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the ceremony at the present day, so say the natives, is by means of
title: Elementary Forms

text: pouring out the blood of kangaroo men upon the rock, to drive out in all
title: Elementary Forms

text: directions the spirits of the kangaroo animals and so to increase the
title: Elementary Forms

text: number of the animals."[1119]
title: Elementary Forms

text: There is even one case among the Arunta where the blood seems to be the
title: Elementary Forms

text: active principle in the rite. In the Emu group, they do not use sacred
title: Elementary Forms

text: stones or anything resembling them. The Alatunja and some of his
title: Elementary Forms

text: assistants sprinkle the ground with their blood; on the ground thus
title: Elementary Forms

text: soaked, they trace lines in various colours, representing the different
title: Elementary Forms

text: parts of the body of an emu. They kneel down around this design and
title: Elementary Forms

text: chant a monotonous hymn. From the fictitious emu to which this chant is
title: Elementary Forms

text: addressed, and, consequently, from the blood which has served to make
title: Elementary Forms

text: it, they believe that vivifying principles go forth, which animate the
title: Elementary Forms

text: embryos of the new generation, and thus prevent the species from
title: Elementary Forms

text: disappearing.[1120]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Among the Wonkgongaru,[1121] there is one clan whose totem is a certain
title: Elementary Forms

text: kind of fish; in the Intichiuma of this totem also, it is the blood that
title: Elementary Forms

text: plays the principal part. The chief of the group, after being
title: Elementary Forms

text: ceremoniously painted, goes into a pool of water and sits down there.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Then he pierces his scrotum and the skin around his navel with small
title: Elementary Forms

text: pointed bones. "The blood from the wounds goes into the water and gives
title: Elementary Forms

text: rise to fish."[1122]
title: Elementary Forms

text: By a wholly similar process, the Dieri think that they assure the
title: Elementary Forms

text: reproduction of two of their totems, the carpet snake and the woma snake
title: Elementary Forms

text: (the ordinary snake). A Mura-mura named Minkani is thought to live under
title: Elementary Forms

text: a dune. His body is represented by some fossil bones of animals or
title: Elementary Forms

text: reptiles, such as the deltas of the rivers flowing into Lake Eyre
title: Elementary Forms

text: contain, according to Howitt. When the day of the ceremony arrives, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: men assemble and go to the home of the Minkani. There they dig until
title: Elementary Forms

text: they come to a layer of damp earth which they call "the excrement of
title: Elementary Forms

text: Minkani." From now on, they continue to turn up the soil with great care
title: Elementary Forms

text: until they uncover "the elbow of Minkani." Then two young men open their
title: Elementary Forms

text: veins and let their blood flow on to the sacred rock. They chant the
title: Elementary Forms

text: hymn of Minkani while the assistants, carried away in a veritable
title: Elementary Forms

text: frenzy, beat each other with their arms. The battle continues until they
title: Elementary Forms

text: get back to the camp, which is about a mile away. Here, the women
title: Elementary Forms

text: intervene and put an end to the combat. They collect the blood which has
title: Elementary Forms

text: flown from the wounds, mix it with the "excrement of Minkani," and
title: Elementary Forms

text: scatter the resulting mixture over the dune. When this rite has been
title: Elementary Forms

text: accomplished, they are convinced that carpet snakes will be born in
title: Elementary Forms

text: abundance.[1123]
title: Elementary Forms

text: In certain cases, they use the very substance which they wish to produce
title: Elementary Forms

text: as the vivifying principle. Thus among the Kaitish, in the course of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: ceremony whose object is to create rain, they sprinkle water over a
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacred rock which represents the mythical heroes of the Water clan. It
title: Elementary Forms

text: is evident that they believe that by this means they augment the
title: Elementary Forms

text: productive virtues of the rock just as well as with blood, and for the
title: Elementary Forms

text: same reasons.[1124] Among the Mara, the actor takes water from a sacred
title: Elementary Forms

text: hole, puts it in his mouth and spits it out in every direction.[1125]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Among the Worgaia, when the yams begin to sprout, the chief of the Yam
title: Elementary Forms

text: clan sends men of the phratry of which he is not a member himself to
title: Elementary Forms

text: gather some of these plants; these bring some to him, and ask him to
title: Elementary Forms

text: intervene, in order that the species may develop well. He takes one,
title: Elementary Forms

text: chews it, and throws the bits in every direction.[1126] Among the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Kaitish when, after various rites which we shall not describe, the grain
title: Elementary Forms

text: of a certain grass called Erlipinna has reached its full development,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the chief of the totem brings a little of it to camp and grinds it
title: Elementary Forms

text: between two stones; the dust thus obtained is piously gathered up, and a
title: Elementary Forms

text: few grains are placed on the lips of the chief, who scatters them by
title: Elementary Forms

text: blowing. This contact with the mouth of the chief, which has a very
title: Elementary Forms

text: special sacramental virtue, undoubtedly has the object of stimulating
title: Elementary Forms

text: the vitality of the germs which these grains contain and which, being
title: Elementary Forms

text: blown to all the quarters of the horizon, go to communicate these
title: Elementary Forms

text: fecundating virtues which they possess to the plants.[1127]
title: Elementary Forms

text: The efficacy of these rites is never doubted by the native: he is
title: Elementary Forms

text: convinced that they must produce the results he expects, with a sort of
title: Elementary Forms

text: necessity. If events deceive his hopes, he merely concludes that they
title: Elementary Forms

text: were counteracted by the sorcery of some hostile group. In any case, it
title: Elementary Forms

text: never enters his mind that a favourable result could be obtained by any
title: Elementary Forms

text: other means. If by chance the vegetation grows or the animals produce
title: Elementary Forms

text: before he has performed his Intichiuma, he supposes that another
title: Elementary Forms

text: Intichiuma has been celebrated under the ground by the ancestors and
title: Elementary Forms

text: that the living reap the benefits of this subterranean ceremony.[1128]
title: Elementary Forms

text: II
title: Elementary Forms

text: This is the first act of the celebration.
title: Elementary Forms

text: During the period immediately following, there are no regular
title: Elementary Forms

text: ceremonies. However, the religious life remains intense: this is
title: Elementary Forms

text: manifested especially by an aggravation of the system of interdicts. It
title: Elementary Forms

text: is as though the sacred character of the totem were reinforced: they do
title: Elementary Forms

text: not even dare to touch it. In ordinary times, the Arunta may eat the
title: Elementary Forms

text: animal or plant which serves as totem, provided they do so with
title: Elementary Forms

text: moderation, but on the morrow of the Intichiuma this right is suspended;
title: Elementary Forms

text: the alimentary interdiction is strict and without exceptions. They
title: Elementary Forms

text: believe that any violation of this interdict would result in
title: Elementary Forms

text: neutralizing the good effects of the rite and in preventing the increase
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the species. It is true that the men of other totems who happen to be
title: Elementary Forms

text: in the same locality are not submitted to the same prohibition. However,
title: Elementary Forms

text: their liberty is less than ordinary at this time. They may not consume
title: Elementary Forms

text: the totemic animal wherever they place, in the brush, for example; they
title: Elementary Forms

text: must bring it to camp, and it is there only that it may be cooked.[1129]
title: Elementary Forms

text: A final ceremony terminates this period of extraordinary interdictions
title: Elementary Forms

text: and definitely closes this long series of rites. It varies somewhat in
title: Elementary Forms

text: different clans, but the essential elements are the same everywhere.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Here are the two principal forms which it takes among the Arunta. One of
title: Elementary Forms

text: these is in connection with the witchetty grub, the other with the
title: Elementary Forms

text: kangaroo.
title: Elementary Forms

text: When the grubs have attained full maturity and appear in abundance, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: men of the totem, as well as others, collect as many of them as
title: Elementary Forms

text: possible; then they all bring those they have found back to camp and
title: Elementary Forms

text: cook them until they become hard and brittle. They are then preserved in
title: Elementary Forms

text: wooden vessels called _pitchi_. The harvest of grubs is possible only
title: Elementary Forms

text: during a very short time, for they appear only after the rain. When they
title: Elementary Forms

text: begin to be less numerous, the Alatunja summons everybody to the camp;
title: Elementary Forms

text: on his invitation, each one brings his supply. The others place theirs
title: Elementary Forms

text: before the men of that totem. The Alatunja takes one of these _pitchi_
title: Elementary Forms

text: and, with the aid of his companions, he grinds its contents between two
title: Elementary Forms

text: stones; after this, he eats a little of the powder thus obtained, his
title: Elementary Forms

text: assistants do the same, and what remains is given to the men of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: other clans, who may now dispose of it freely. They proceed in exactly
title: Elementary Forms

text: the same manner with the supply provided by the Alatunja. From now on,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the men and women of the totem may eat it, but only a little at a time;
title: Elementary Forms

text: if they went beyond the limits allowed, they would lose the powers
title: Elementary Forms

text: necessary to celebrate the Intichiuma and the species would not
title: Elementary Forms

text: reproduce. Yet, if they did not eat any at all, and especially if the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Alatunja ate none in the circumstances we have just described, they
title: Elementary Forms

text: would be overtaken by the same incapacity.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In the totemic group of the Kangaroo, which has its centre at Undiara,
title: Elementary Forms

text: certain characteristics of the ceremony are more clearly marked. After
title: Elementary Forms

text: the rites which we have described have been accomplished on the sacred
title: Elementary Forms

text: rock, the young men go and hunt the kangaroo, bringing their game back
title: Elementary Forms

text: to the camp. Here, the old men, with the Alatunja in their midst, eat a
title: Elementary Forms

text: little of the flesh of the animal, and anoint the bodies of those who
title: Elementary Forms

text: took part in the Intichiuma with its fat. The rest is divided up among
title: Elementary Forms

text: the men assembled. Next, the men of the totem decorate themselves with
title: Elementary Forms

text: totemic designs and the night is passed in songs commemorating the
title: Elementary Forms

text: exploits accomplished by men and animal kangaroos in the times of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Alcheringa. The next day, the young men go hunting again in the forest
title: Elementary Forms

text: and bring back a larger number of kangaroos than the first time, and the
title: Elementary Forms

text: ceremonies of the day before recommence.[1130]
title: Elementary Forms

text: With variations of detail, the same rite is found in other Arunta
title: Elementary Forms

text: clans,[1131] among the Urabunna,[1132] the Kaitish,[1133] the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Unmatjera,[1134] and in the Encounter Bay Tribe.[1135] Everywhere, it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: made up of the same essential elements. A few specimens of the totemic
title: Elementary Forms

text: animal or plant are presented to the chief of the clan, who solemnly
title: Elementary Forms

text: eats them and who must eat them. If he did not fulfil this duty, he
title: Elementary Forms

text: would lose the power of celebrating the Intichiuma efficaciously, that
title: Elementary Forms

text: is to say, so as to recreate the species annually. Sometimes the ritual
title: Elementary Forms

text: consumption is followed by an unction made with the fat of the animal or
title: Elementary Forms

text: certain parts of the plant.[1136] This rite is generally repeated by the
title: Elementary Forms

text: men of the totem, or at least by the old men, and after it has been
title: Elementary Forms

text: accomplished, the exceptional interdictions are raised.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In the tribes located farther north, among the Warramunga and
title: Elementary Forms

text: neighbouring societies,[1137] this ceremony is no longer found. However,
title: Elementary Forms

text: traces are found which seem to indicate that there was a time when it
title: Elementary Forms

text: was known. It is true that the chief of the clan never eats the totem
title: Elementary Forms

text: ritually and obligatorily. But in certain cases, men who are not of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: totem whose Intichiuma has just been celebrated, must bring the animal
title: Elementary Forms

text: or plant to camp and offer it to the chief, asking him if he wants to
title: Elementary Forms

text: eat it. He refuses and adds, "I have made this for you; you may eat it
title: Elementary Forms

text: freely."[1138] So the custom of the presentation remains and the
title: Elementary Forms

text: question asked of the chief seems to date back to an epoch when the
title: Elementary Forms

text: ritual consumption was practised.[1139]
title: Elementary Forms

text: III
title: Elementary Forms

text: The interest of the system of rites which has just been described lies
title: Elementary Forms

text: in the fact that in them we find, in the most elementary form that is
title: Elementary Forms

text: actually known, all the essential principles of a great religious
title: Elementary Forms

text: institution which was destined to become one of the foundation stones of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the positive cult in the superior religions: this is the institution of
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacrifice.
title: Elementary Forms

text: We know what a revolution the work of Robertson Smith brought about in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the traditional theory of sacrifice.[1140] Before him, sacrifice was
title: Elementary Forms

text: regarded as a sort of tribute or homage, either obligatory or optional,
title: Elementary Forms

text: analogous to that which subjects owe to their princes. Robertson Smith
title: Elementary Forms

text: was the first to remark that this classic explanation did not account
title: Elementary Forms

text: for two essential characteristics of the rite. In the first place, it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: a repast: its substance is food. Secondly, it is a repast in which the
title: Elementary Forms

text: worshippers who offer it take part, along with the god to whom it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: offered. Certain parts of the victim are reserved for the divinity;
title: Elementary Forms

text: others are attributed to the sacrificers, who consume them; this is why
title: Elementary Forms

text: the Bible often speaks of the sacrifice as a repast in the presence of
title: Elementary Forms

text: Jahveh. Now in a multitude of societies, meals taken in common are
title: Elementary Forms

text: believed to create a bond of artificial kinship between those who assist
title: Elementary Forms

text: at them: In fact, relatives are people who are naturally made of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: same flesh and blood. But food is constantly remaking the substance of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the organism. So a common food may produce the same effects as a common
title: Elementary Forms

text: origin. According to Smith, sacrificial banquets have the object of
title: Elementary Forms

text: making the worshipper and his god communicate in the same flesh, in
title: Elementary Forms

text: order to form a bond of kinship between them. From this point of view,
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacrifice takes on a wholly new aspect. Its essential element is no
title: Elementary Forms

text: longer the act of renouncement which the word sacrifice ordinarily
title: Elementary Forms

text: expresses; before all, it is an act of alimentary communion.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Of course there are some reservations to be made in the details of this
title: Elementary Forms

text: way of explaining the efficacy of sacrificial banquets. This does not
title: Elementary Forms

text: result exclusively from the act of eating together. A man does not
title: Elementary Forms

text: sanctify himself merely by sitting down, in some way, at the same table
title: Elementary Forms

text: with a god, but especially by eating food at this ritual repast which
title: Elementary Forms

text: has a sacred character. It has been shown how a whole series of
title: Elementary Forms

text: preliminary operations, lustrations, unctions, prayers, etc., transform
title: Elementary Forms

text: the animal to be immolated into a sacred thing, whose sacredness is
title: Elementary Forms

text: subsequently transferred to the worshipper who eats it.[1141] But it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: true, none the less, that the alimentary communion is one of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: essential elements of the sacrifice. Now when we turn to the rite which
title: Elementary Forms

text: terminates the ceremonies of the Intichiuma, we find that it, too,
title: Elementary Forms

text: consists in an act of this sort. After the totemic animal has been
title: Elementary Forms

text: killed, the Alatunja and the old men solemnly eat it. So they
title: Elementary Forms

text: communicate with the sacred principle residing in it and they assimilate
title: Elementary Forms

text: it. The only difference we find here is that the animal is naturally
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacred while it ordinarily acquires this character artificially in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: course of the sacrifice.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Moreover, the object of this communion is manifest. Every member of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: totemic clan contains a mystic substance within him which is the
title: Elementary Forms

text: pre-eminent part of his being, for his soul is made out of it. From it
title: Elementary Forms

text: come whatever powers he has and his social position, for it is this
title: Elementary Forms

text: which makes him a person. So he has a vital interest in maintaining it
title: Elementary Forms

text: intact and in keeping it, as far as is possible, in a state of perpetual
title: Elementary Forms

text: youth. Unfortunately all forces, even the most spiritual, are used up in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the course of time if nothing comes to return to them the energy they
title: Elementary Forms

text: lose through the normal working of things; there is a necessity of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: first importance here which, as we shall see, is the real reason for the
title: Elementary Forms

text: positive cult. Therefore the men of a totem cannot retain their position
title: Elementary Forms

text: unless they periodically revivify the totemic principle which is in
title: Elementary Forms

text: them; and as they represent this principle in the form of a vegetable or
title: Elementary Forms

text: animal, it is to the corresponding animal or vegetable species that they
title: Elementary Forms

text: go to demand the supplementary forces needed to renew this and to
title: Elementary Forms

text: rejuvenate it. A man of the Kangaroo clan believes himself and feels
title: Elementary Forms

text: himself a kangaroo; it is by this quality that he defines himself; it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: this which marks his place in the society. In order to keep it, he takes
title: Elementary Forms

text: a little of the flesh of this same animal into his own body from time to
title: Elementary Forms

text: time. A small bit is enough, owing to the rule: _the part is equal to
title: Elementary Forms

text: the whole_.[1142]
title: Elementary Forms

text: If this operation is to produce all the desired effects, it may not take
title: Elementary Forms

text: place at no matter what moment. The most opportune time is when the new
title: Elementary Forms

text: generation has just reached its complete development, for this is also
title: Elementary Forms

text: the moment when the forces animating the totemic species attain their
title: Elementary Forms

text: maximum intensity. They have just been drawn with great difficulty from
title: Elementary Forms

text: those rich reservoirs of life, the sacred trees and rocks. Moreover, all
title: Elementary Forms

text: sorts of means have been employed to increase their intensity still
title: Elementary Forms

text: more; this is the use of the rites performed during the first part of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the Intichiuma. Also, by their very aspect, the firstfruits of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: harvest manifest the energy which they contain: here the totemic god
title: Elementary Forms

text: acclaims himself in all the glory of his youth. This is why the
title: Elementary Forms

text: firstfruits have always been regarded as a very sacred fruit, reserved
title: Elementary Forms

text: for very holy beings. So it is natural that the Australian uses it to
title: Elementary Forms

text: regenerate himself spiritually. Thus both the date and the circumstances
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the ceremonies are explained.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Perhaps some will be surprised that so sacred a food may be eaten by
title: Elementary Forms

text: ordinary profane persons. But in the first place, there is no positive
title: Elementary Forms

text: cult which does not face this contradiction. Every sacred being is
title: Elementary Forms

text: removed from profane touch by this very character with which it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: endowed; but, on the other hand, they would serve for nothing and have
title: Elementary Forms

text: no reason whatsoever for their existence if they could not come in
title: Elementary Forms

text: contact with these same worshippers who, on another ground, must remain
title: Elementary Forms

text: respectfully distant from them. At bottom, there is no positive rite
title: Elementary Forms

text: which does not constitute a veritable sacrilege, for a man cannot hold
title: Elementary Forms

text: commerce with the sacred beings without crossing the barrier which
title: Elementary Forms

text: should ordinarily keep them separate. But the important thing is that
title: Elementary Forms

text: the sacrilege should be accompanied with precautions which attenuate
title: Elementary Forms

text: it. Among those employed, the most usual one consists in arranging the
title: Elementary Forms

text: transition so as to introduce the worshipper slowly and gradually into
title: Elementary Forms

text: the circle of sacred things. When it has been broken and diluted in this
title: Elementary Forms

text: fashion, the sacrilege does not offend the religious conscience so
title: Elementary Forms

text: violently; it is not regarded as a sacrilege and so vanishes. This is
title: Elementary Forms

text: what happens in the case now before us. The effect of the whole series
title: Elementary Forms

text: of rites which has preceded the moment when the totem is solemnly eaten
title: Elementary Forms

text: has been to sanctify those who took an active part in them. They
title: Elementary Forms

text: constitute an essentially religious period, through which no one could
title: Elementary Forms

text: go without a transformation of his religious state. The fasts, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: contact with sacred rocks, the churinga,[1143] the totemic decorations,
title: Elementary Forms

text: etc., have gradually conferred upon him a character which he did not
title: Elementary Forms

text: have before and which enables him to approach, without a shocking and
title: Elementary Forms

text: dangerous profanation, this desirable and redoubtable food which is
title: Elementary Forms

text: forbidden him in ordinary times.[1144]
title: Elementary Forms

text: If the act by which a sacred being is first immolated and then eaten by
title: Elementary Forms

text: those who adore it may be called a sacrifice, the rite of which we have
title: Elementary Forms

text: just been speaking has a right to this same name. Moreover, its
title: Elementary Forms

text: significance is well shown by the striking analogies it presents with so
title: Elementary Forms

text: many practices met with in a large number of agrarian cults. It is a
title: Elementary Forms

text: very general rule that even among peoples who have attained a high
title: Elementary Forms

text: degree of civilization, the firstfruits of the harvest are used in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: ritual repasts, of which the pascal feast is the best known
title: Elementary Forms

text: example.[1145] On the other hand, as the agrarian rites are at the very
title: Elementary Forms

text: basis of the most advanced forms of the cult, we see that the Intichiuma
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the Australian societies is closer to us than one might imagine from
title: Elementary Forms

text: its apparent crudeness.
title: Elementary Forms

text: By an intuition of genius, Smith had an intuition of all this, though he
title: Elementary Forms

text: was not acquainted with the facts. By a series of ingenious
title: Elementary Forms

text: deductions--which need not be reproduced here, for their interest is now
title: Elementary Forms

text: only historical[1146]--he thought that he could establish the fact that
title: Elementary Forms

text: at the beginning the animal immolated in the sacrifice must have been
title: Elementary Forms

text: regarded as quasi-divine and as a close relative of those who immolated
title: Elementary Forms

text: it: now these characteristics are just the ones with which the totemic
title: Elementary Forms

text: species is defined. Smith even went so far as to suppose that totemism
title: Elementary Forms

text: must have known and practised a rite wholly similar to the one we have
title: Elementary Forms

text: been studying; he was even inclined to see the original source of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: whole sacrificial institution in a sacrifice of this sort.[1147]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Sacrifice was not founded to create a bond of artificial kinship between
title: Elementary Forms

text: a man and his gods, but to maintain and renew the natural kinship which
title: Elementary Forms

text: primitively united them. Here, as elsewhere, the artifice was born only
title: Elementary Forms

text: to imitate nature. But in the book of Smith this hypothesis was
title: Elementary Forms

text: presented as scarcely more than a theory which the then known facts
title: Elementary Forms

text: supported very imperfectly. The rare cases of totemic sacrifice which he
title: Elementary Forms

text: cites in support of his theory do not have the significance he
title: Elementary Forms

text: attributed to them; the animals which figure in them are not real
title: Elementary Forms

text: totems.[1148] But to-day we are able to state that on at least one point
title: Elementary Forms

text: the demonstration is made: in fact, we have just seen that in an
title: Elementary Forms

text: important number of societies the totemic sacrifice, such as Smith
title: Elementary Forms

text: conceived it, is or has been practised. Of course, we have no proof that
title: Elementary Forms

text: this practice is necessarily inherent to totemism or that it is the germ
title: Elementary Forms

text: out of which all the other types of sacrifices have developed. But if
title: Elementary Forms

text: the universality of the rite is hypothetical, its existence is no longer
title: Elementary Forms

text: to be contested. Hereafter it is to be regarded as established that the
title: Elementary Forms

text: most mystical form of the alimentary communion is found even in the most
title: Elementary Forms

text: rudimentary cults known to-day.
title: Elementary Forms

text: IV
title: Elementary Forms

text: But on another point the new facts at our disposal invalidate the
title: Elementary Forms

text: theories of Smith.
title: Elementary Forms

text: According to him, the communion was not only an essential element of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacrifice, but at the beginning, at least, it was the unique element.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Not only is one mistaken when he reduces sacrifice to nothing more than
title: Elementary Forms

text: a tribute or offering, but the very idea of an offering was originally
title: Elementary Forms

text: absent from it; this intervened only at a late period and under the
title: Elementary Forms

text: influence of external circumstances; so instead of being able to aid us
title: Elementary Forms

text: in understanding it, it has rather masked the real nature of the ritual
title: Elementary Forms

text: mechanism. In fact, Smith claimed to find in the very notion of oblation
title: Elementary Forms

text: an absurdity so revolting that it could never have been the fundamental
title: Elementary Forms

text: reason for so great an institution. One of the most important functions
title: Elementary Forms

text: incumbent upon the divinity is to assure to men that food which is
title: Elementary Forms

text: necessary for life; so it seems impossible that the sacrifice, in its
title: Elementary Forms

text: turn, should consist in a presentation of food to the divinity. It even
title: Elementary Forms

text: seems self-contradictory that the gods should expect their food from a
title: Elementary Forms

text: man, when it is from them that he gets his. Why should they have need of
title: Elementary Forms

text: his aid in order to deduct beforehand their just share of the things
title: Elementary Forms

text: which he receives from their hands? From these considerations Smith
title: Elementary Forms

text: concluded that the idea of a sacrifice-offering could have been born
title: Elementary Forms

text: only in the great religions, where the gods, removed from the things
title: Elementary Forms

text: with which they were primitively confused, were thought of as sorts of
title: Elementary Forms

text: kings and the eminent proprietors of the earth and its products. From
title: Elementary Forms

text: this moment onwards, the sacrifice was associated with the tribute which
title: Elementary Forms

text: subjects paid to their prince, as a price of the rights which were
title: Elementary Forms

text: conceded to them. But this new interpretation was really an alteration
title: Elementary Forms

text: and even a corruption of the primitive conception. For "the idea of
title: Elementary Forms

text: property materializes all that it touches"; by introducing itself into
title: Elementary Forms

text: the sacrifice, it denatured it and made it into a sort of bargain
title: Elementary Forms

text: between the man and the divinity.[1149]
title: Elementary Forms

text: But the facts which we have described overthrow this argumentation.
title: Elementary Forms

text: These rites are certainly among the most primitive that have ever been
title: Elementary Forms

text: observed. No determined mythical personality appears in them; there is
title: Elementary Forms

text: no question of gods or spirits that are properly so called; it is only
title: Elementary Forms

text: vaguely anonymous and impersonal forces which they put into action. Yet
title: Elementary Forms

text: the reasoning which they suppose is exactly the one that Smith declared
title: Elementary Forms

text: impossible because of its absurdity.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Let us return to the first act of the Intichiuma, to the rites destined
title: Elementary Forms

text: to assure the fecundity of the animal or vegetable species which serves
title: Elementary Forms

text: the clan as totem. This species is the pre-eminently sacred thing; in it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is incarnated that which we have been able to call, by metaphor, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: totemic divinity. Yet we have seen that to perpetuate itself it has need
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the aid of men. It is they who dispense the life of the new
title: Elementary Forms

text: generation each year; without them, it would never be born. If they
title: Elementary Forms

text: stopped celebrating the Intichiuma, the sacred beings would disappear
title: Elementary Forms

text: from the face of the earth. So in one sense, it is from men that they
title: Elementary Forms

text: get their existence; yet in another way, it is from them that men get
title: Elementary Forms

text: theirs; for after they have once arrived at maturity, it is from them
title: Elementary Forms

text: that men acquire the force needed to support and repair their spiritual
title: Elementary Forms

text: beings. Thus we are able to say that men make their gods, or, at least,
title: Elementary Forms

text: make them live; but at the same time, it is from them that they live
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves. So they are regularly guilty of the circle which, according
title: Elementary Forms

text: to Smith, is implied in the very idea of a sacrificial tribute: they
title: Elementary Forms

text: give to the sacred beings a little of what they receive from them, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: they receive from them all that they give.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But there is still more to be said: the oblations which he is thus
title: Elementary Forms

text: forced to make every year do not differ in nature from those which are
title: Elementary Forms

text: made later in the rites properly called sacrifices. If the sacrificer
title: Elementary Forms

text: immolates an animal, it is in order that the living principles within it
title: Elementary Forms

text: may be disengaged from the organism and go to nourish the divinity.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Likewise, the grains of dust which the Australian detaches from the
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacred rock are so many sacred principles which he scatters into space,
title: Elementary Forms

text: so that they may go to animate the totemic species and assure its
title: Elementary Forms

text: renewal. The gesture with which this scattering is made is also that
title: Elementary Forms

text: which normally accompanies offerings. In certain cases, the resemblance
title: Elementary Forms

text: between the two rites may be followed even to the details of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: movements effected. We have seen that in order to have rain the Kaitish
title: Elementary Forms

text: pour water over the sacred stone; among certain peoples, the priest
title: Elementary Forms

text: pours water over the altar, with the same end in view.[1150] The
title: Elementary Forms

text: effusions of blood which are usual in a certain number of Intichiuma are
title: Elementary Forms

text: veritable oblations. Just as the Arunta or Dieri sprinkle the sacred
title: Elementary Forms

text: rock or the totemic design with blood, so it frequently happens that in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the more advanced cults, the blood of the sacrificed victim or of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: worshipper himself is spilt before or upon the altar.[1151] In these
title: Elementary Forms

text: cases, it is given to the gods, of whom it is the preferred food; in
title: Elementary Forms

text: Australia, it is given to the sacred species. So we have no ground for
title: Elementary Forms

text: saying that the idea of oblation is a late product of civilization.
title: Elementary Forms

text: A document which we owe to Strehlow puts this kinship of the Intichiuma
title: Elementary Forms

text: and the sacrifice clearly into evidence. This is a hymn which
title: Elementary Forms

text: accompanies the Intichiuma of the Kangaroo; the ceremony is described at
title: Elementary Forms

text: the same time that its expected effects are announced. A morsel of
title: Elementary Forms

text: kangaroo fat has been placed by the chief upon a support made of
title: Elementary Forms

text: branches. The text says that this fat makes the fat of the kangaroos
title: Elementary Forms

text: increase.[1152] This time, they do not confine themselves to sprinkling
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacred dust or human blood about; the animal itself is immolated, or
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacrificed as one might say, placed upon a sort of altar, and offered to
title: Elementary Forms

text: the species, whose life it should maintain.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Now we see the sense in which we may say that the Intichiuma contains
title: Elementary Forms

text: the germs of the sacrificial system. In the form which it takes when
title: Elementary Forms

text: fully constituted, a sacrifice is composed of two essential elements: an
title: Elementary Forms

text: act of communion and an act of oblation. The worshipper communes with
title: Elementary Forms

text: his god by taking in a sacred food, and at the same time he makes an
title: Elementary Forms

text: offering to this god. We find these two acts in the Intichiuma, as we
title: Elementary Forms

text: have described it. The only difference is that in the ordinary
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacrifice[1153] they are made simultaneously or else follow one another
title: Elementary Forms

text: immediately, while in the Australian ceremony they are separated. In the
title: Elementary Forms

text: former case, they are parts of one undivided rite; here, they take place
title: Elementary Forms

text: at different times, and may even be separated by a rather long interval.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But, at bottom, the mechanism is the same. Taken as a whole, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Intichiuma is a sacrifice, but one whose parts are not yet articulated
title: Elementary Forms

text: and organized.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The relating of these two ceremonies has the double advantage of
title: Elementary Forms

text: enabling us to understand better the nature of the Intichiuma and that
title: Elementary Forms

text: of sacrifice.
title: Elementary Forms

text: We understand the Intichiuma better. In fact, the conception of Frazer,
title: Elementary Forms

text: which made it a simple magic operation[1154] with no religious character
title: Elementary Forms

text: at all, is now seen to be unsupportable. One cannot dream of excluding
title: Elementary Forms

text: from religion a rite which is the forerunner of so great a religious
title: Elementary Forms

text: institution.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But we also understand what the sacrifice itself is better. In the first
title: Elementary Forms

text: place, the equal importance of the two elements entering into it is now
title: Elementary Forms

text: established. If the Australian makes offerings to his sacred beings,
title: Elementary Forms

text: there is no reason for supposing that the idea of oblation was foreign
title: Elementary Forms

text: to the primitive organization of the sacrificial institution and later
title: Elementary Forms

text: upset its natural arrangement. The theory of Smith must be revised on
title: Elementary Forms

text: this point.[1155] Of course the sacrifice is partially a communion; but
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is also, and no less essentially, a gift and an act of renouncement.
title: Elementary Forms

text: It always presupposes that the worshipper gives some of his substance or
title: Elementary Forms

text: his goods to his gods. Every attempt to deduce one of these elements
title: Elementary Forms

text: from the other is hopeless. Perhaps the oblation is even more permanent
title: Elementary Forms

text: than the communion.[1156]
title: Elementary Forms

text: In the second place, it ordinarily seems as though the sacrifice, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: especially the sacrificial oblation, could only be addressed to personal
title: Elementary Forms

text: beings. But the oblations which we have met with in Australia imply no
title: Elementary Forms

text: notion of this sort. In other words, the sacrifice is independent of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: varying forms in which the religious forces are conceived; it is founded
title: Elementary Forms

text: upon more profound reasons, which we shall seek presently.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In any case, it is clear that the act of offering naturally arouses in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the mind the idea of a moral subject, whom this offering is destined to
title: Elementary Forms

text: please. The ritual acts which we have described become more
title: Elementary Forms

text: intelligible when it is believed that they are addressed to persons. So
title: Elementary Forms

text: the practices of the Intichiuma, while actually putting only impersonal
title: Elementary Forms

text: forces into play, prepare the way for a different conception.[1157] Of
title: Elementary Forms

text: course they were not sufficient to form the idea of mythical
title: Elementary Forms

text: personalities by themselves, but when this idea had once been formed,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the very nature of these rites made it enter into the cult; thus, taking
title: Elementary Forms

text: a more direct interest in action and life, it also acquired a greater
title: Elementary Forms

text: reality. So we are even able to believe that the cult favoured, in a
title: Elementary Forms

text: secondary manner, no doubt, but nevertheless one which is worthy of
title: Elementary Forms

text: attention, the personification of the religious forces.
title: Elementary Forms

text: V
title: Elementary Forms

text: But we still have to explain the contradiction in which Robertson Smith
title: Elementary Forms

text: saw an inadmissible logical scandal.
title: Elementary Forms

text: If the sacred beings always manifested their powers in a perfectly equal
title: Elementary Forms

text: manner, it would appear inconceivable that men should dream of offering
title: Elementary Forms

text: them services, for we cannot see what need they could have of them. But
title: Elementary Forms

text: in the first place, in so far as they are confused with things, and in
title: Elementary Forms

text: so far as they are regarded as principles of the cosmic life, they are
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves submitted to the rhythm of this life. Now this goes in
title: Elementary Forms

text: oscillations in contrary directions, which succeed one another according
title: Elementary Forms

text: to a determined law. Sometimes it is affirmed in all its glory;
title: Elementary Forms

text: sometimes it weakens to such an extent that one may ask himself whether
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is not going to fade away. Vegetation dies every year; will it be
title: Elementary Forms

text: reborn? Animal species tend to become extinguished by the effect of
title: Elementary Forms

text: natural and violent death; will they be renewed at such a time and in
title: Elementary Forms

text: such a way as is proper? Above all, the rain is capricious; there are
title: Elementary Forms

text: long periods during which it seems to have disappeared for ever. These
title: Elementary Forms

text: periodical variations of nature bear witness to the fact that at the
title: Elementary Forms

text: corresponding periods, the sacred beings upon whom the plants, animals,
title: Elementary Forms

text: rain, etc., depend are themselves passing through grave crises; so they,
title: Elementary Forms

text: too, have their periods of giving way. But men could not regard these
title: Elementary Forms

text: spectacles as indifferent spectators. If he is to live, the universal
title: Elementary Forms

text: life must continue, and consequently the gods must not die. So he seeks
title: Elementary Forms

text: to sustain and aid them; for this, he puts at their service whatever
title: Elementary Forms

text: forces he has at his disposition, and mobilizes them for this purpose.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The blood flowing in his veins has fecundating virtues; he pours it
title: Elementary Forms

text: forth. From the sacred rocks possessed by his clan he takes those germs
title: Elementary Forms

text: of life which lie dormant there, and scatters them into space. In a
title: Elementary Forms

text: word, he makes oblations.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The external and physical crises, moreover, duplicate internal and
title: Elementary Forms

text: mental crises which tend toward the same result. Sacred beings exist
title: Elementary Forms

text: only when they are represented as such in the mind. When we cease to
title: Elementary Forms

text: believe in them, it is as though they did not exist. Even those which
title: Elementary Forms

text: have a material form and are given by sensible experience, depend upon
title: Elementary Forms

text: the thought of the worshippers who adore them; for the sacred character
title: Elementary Forms

text: which makes them objects of the cult is not given by their natural
title: Elementary Forms

text: constitution; it is added to them by belief. The kangaroo is only an
title: Elementary Forms

text: animal like all others; yet, for the men of the Kangaroo, it contains
title: Elementary Forms

text: within it a principle which puts it outside the company of others, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: this principle exists only in the minds of those who believe in
title: Elementary Forms

text: it.[1158] If these sacred beings, when once conceived, are to have no
title: Elementary Forms

text: need of men to continue, it would be necessary that the representations
title: Elementary Forms

text: expressing them always remain the same. But this stability is
title: Elementary Forms

text: impossible. In fact, it is in the communal life that they are formed,
title: Elementary Forms

text: and this communal life is essentially intermittent. So they necessarily
title: Elementary Forms

text: partake of this same intermittency. They attain their greatest intensity
title: Elementary Forms

text: at the moment when the men are assembled together and are in immediate
title: Elementary Forms

text: relations with one another, when they all partake of the same idea and
title: Elementary Forms

text: the same sentiment. But when the assembly has broken up and each man has
title: Elementary Forms

text: returned to his own peculiar life, they progressively lose their
title: Elementary Forms

text: original energy. Being covered over little by little by the rising flood
title: Elementary Forms

text: of daily experiences, they would soon fall into the unconscious, if we
title: Elementary Forms

text: did not find some means of calling them back into consciousness and
title: Elementary Forms

text: revivifying them. If we think of them less forcefully, they amount to
title: Elementary Forms

text: less for us and we count less upon them; they exist to a lesser degree.
title: Elementary Forms

text: So here we have another point of view, from which the services of men
title: Elementary Forms

text: are necessary to them. This second reason for their existence is even
title: Elementary Forms

text: more important than the first, for it exists all the time. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: intermittency of the physical life can affect religious beliefs only
title: Elementary Forms

text: when religions are not yet detached from their cosmic basis. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: intermittency of the social life, on the other hand, is inevitable; even
title: Elementary Forms

text: the most idealistic religions cannot escape it.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Moreover, it is owing to this state of dependency upon the thought of
title: Elementary Forms

text: men, in which the gods find themselves, that the former are able to
title: Elementary Forms

text: believe in the efficacy of their assistance. The only way of renewing
title: Elementary Forms

text: the collective representations which relate to sacred beings is to
title: Elementary Forms

text: retemper them in the very source of the religious life, that is to say,
title: Elementary Forms

text: in the assembled groups. Now the emotions aroused by these periodical
title: Elementary Forms

text: crises through which external things pass induce the men who witness
title: Elementary Forms

text: them to assemble, to see what should be done about it. But by the very
title: Elementary Forms

text: fact of uniting, they are mutually comforted; they find a remedy because
title: Elementary Forms

text: they seek it together. The common faith becomes reanimated quite
title: Elementary Forms

text: naturally in the heart of this reconstituted group; if is born again
title: Elementary Forms

text: because it again finds those very conditions in which it was born in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: first place. After it has been restored, it easily triumphs over all the
title: Elementary Forms

text: private doubts which may have arisen in individual minds. The image of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the sacred things regains power enough to resist the internal or
title: Elementary Forms

text: external causes which tended to weaken it. In spite of their apparent
title: Elementary Forms

text: failure, men can no longer believe that the gods will die, because they
title: Elementary Forms

text: feel them living in their own hearts. The means employed to succour
title: Elementary Forms

text: them, howsoever crude these may be, cannot appear vain, for everything
title: Elementary Forms

text: goes on as if they were really effective. Men are more confident because
title: Elementary Forms

text: they feel themselves stronger; and they really are stronger, because
title: Elementary Forms

text: forces which were languishing are now reawakened in the consciousness.
title: Elementary Forms

text: So we must be careful not to believe, along with Smith, that the cult
title: Elementary Forms

text: was founded solely for the benefit of men and that the gods have nothing
title: Elementary Forms

text: to do with it: they have no less need of it than their worshippers. Of
title: Elementary Forms

text: course men would be unable to live without gods, but, on the other hand,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the gods would die if their cult were not rendered. This does not have
title: Elementary Forms

text: the sole object of making profane subjects communicate with sacred
title: Elementary Forms

text: beings, but it also keeps these latter alive and is perpetually remaking
title: Elementary Forms

text: and regenerating them. Of course it is not the material oblations which
title: Elementary Forms

text: bring about this regeneration by their own virtues; it is the mental
title: Elementary Forms

text: states which these actions, though vain in themselves, accompany or
title: Elementary Forms

text: reawaken. The real reason for the existence of the cults, even of those
title: Elementary Forms

text: which are the most materialistic in appearance, is not to be sought in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the acts which they prescribe, but in the internal and moral
title: Elementary Forms

text: regeneration which these acts aid in bringing about. The things which
title: Elementary Forms

text: the worshipper really gives his gods are not the foods which he places
title: Elementary Forms

text: upon the altars, nor the blood which he lets flow from his veins: it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: his thought. Nevertheless, it is true that there is an exchange of
title: Elementary Forms

text: services, which are mutually demanded, between the divinity and its
title: Elementary Forms

text: worshippers. The rule _do ut des_, by which the principle of sacrifice
title: Elementary Forms

text: has sometimes been defined, is not a late invention of utilitarian
title: Elementary Forms

text: theorists: it only expresses in an explicit way the very mechanism of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the sacrificial system and, more generally, of the whole positive cult.
title: Elementary Forms

text: So the circle pointed out by Smith is very real; but it contains nothing
title: Elementary Forms

text: humiliating for the reason. It comes from the fact that the sacred
title: Elementary Forms

text: beings, though superior to men, can live only in the human
title: Elementary Forms

text: consciousness.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But this circle will appear still more natural to us, and we shall
title: Elementary Forms

text: understand its meaning and the reason for its existence still better if,
title: Elementary Forms

text: carrying our analysis still farther and substituting for the religious
title: Elementary Forms

text: symbols the realities which they represent, we investigate how these
title: Elementary Forms

text: behave in the rite. If, as we have attempted to establish, the sacred
title: Elementary Forms

text: principle is nothing more nor less than society transfigured and
title: Elementary Forms

text: personified, it should be possible to interpret the ritual in lay and
title: Elementary Forms

text: social terms. And, as a matter of fact, social life, just like the
title: Elementary Forms

text: ritual, moves in a circle. On the one hand, the individual gets from
title: Elementary Forms

text: society the best part of himself, all that gives him a distinct
title: Elementary Forms

text: character and a special place among other beings, his intellectual and
title: Elementary Forms

text: moral culture. If we should withdraw from men their language, sciences,
title: Elementary Forms

text: arts and moral beliefs, they would drop to the rank of animals. So the
title: Elementary Forms

text: characteristic attributes of human nature come from society. But, on the
title: Elementary Forms

text: other hand, society exists and lives only in and through individuals. If
title: Elementary Forms

text: the idea of society were extinguished in individual minds and the
title: Elementary Forms

text: beliefs, traditions and aspirations of the group were no longer felt and
title: Elementary Forms

text: shared by the individuals, society would die. We can say of it what we
title: Elementary Forms

text: just said of the divinity: it is real only in so far as it has a place
title: Elementary Forms

text: in human consciousnesses, and this place is whatever one we may give it.
title: Elementary Forms

text: We now see the real reason why the gods cannot do without their
title: Elementary Forms

text: worshippers any more than these can do without their gods; it is because
title: Elementary Forms

text: society, of which the gods are only a symbolic expression, cannot do
title: Elementary Forms

text: without individuals any more than these can do without society.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Here we touch the solid rock upon which all the cults are built and
title: Elementary Forms

text: which has caused their persistence ever since human societies have
title: Elementary Forms

text: existed. When we see what religious rites consist of and towards what
title: Elementary Forms

text: they seem to tend, we demand with astonishment how men have been able to
title: Elementary Forms

text: imagine them, and especially how they can remain so faithfully attached
title: Elementary Forms

text: to them. Whence could the illusion have come that with a few grains of
title: Elementary Forms

text: sand thrown to the wind, or a few drops of blood shed upon a rock or the
title: Elementary Forms

text: stone of an altar, it is possible to maintain the life of an animal
title: Elementary Forms

text: species or of a god? We have undoubtedly made a step in advance towards
title: Elementary Forms

text: the solution of this problem when we have discovered, behind these
title: Elementary Forms

text: outward and apparently unreasonable movements, a mental mechanism which
title: Elementary Forms

text: gives them a meaning and a moral significance. But we are in no way
title: Elementary Forms

text: assured that this mechanism itself does not consist in a simple play of
title: Elementary Forms

text: hallucinatory images. We have pointed out the psychological process
title: Elementary Forms

text: which leads the believers to imagine that the rite causes the spiritual
title: Elementary Forms

text: forces of which they have need to be reborn about them; but it does not
title: Elementary Forms

text: follow from the fact that this belief is psychologically explicable that
title: Elementary Forms

text: it has any objective value. If we are to see in the efficacy attributed
title: Elementary Forms

text: to the rites anything more than the product of a chronic delirium with
title: Elementary Forms

text: which humanity has abused itself, we must show that the effect of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: cult really is to recreate periodically a moral being upon which we
title: Elementary Forms

text: depend as it depends upon us. Now this being does exist: it is society.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Howsoever little importance the religious ceremonies may have, they put
title: Elementary Forms

text: the group into action; the groups assemble to celebrate them. So their
title: Elementary Forms

text: first effect is to bring individuals together, to multiply the relations
title: Elementary Forms

text: between them and to make them more intimate with one another. By this
title: Elementary Forms

text: very fact, the contents of their consciousnesses is changed. On ordinary
title: Elementary Forms

text: days, it is utilitarian and individual avocations which take the greater
title: Elementary Forms

text: part of the attention. Every one attends to his own personal business;
title: Elementary Forms

text: for most men, this primarily consists in satisfying the exigencies of
title: Elementary Forms

text: material life, and the principal incentive to economic activity has
title: Elementary Forms

text: always been private interest. Of course social sentiments could never be
title: Elementary Forms

text: totally absent. We remain in relations with others; the habits, ideas
title: Elementary Forms

text: and tendencies which education has impressed upon us and which
title: Elementary Forms

text: ordinarily preside over our relations with others, continue to make
title: Elementary Forms

text: their action felt. But they are constantly combated and held in check by
title: Elementary Forms

text: the antagonistic tendencies aroused and supported by the necessities of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the daily struggle. They resist more or less successfully, according to
title: Elementary Forms

text: their intrinsic energy: but this energy is not renewed. They live upon
title: Elementary Forms

text: their past, and consequently they would be used up in the course of
title: Elementary Forms

text: time, if nothing returned to them a little of the force that they lose
title: Elementary Forms

text: through these incessant conflicts and frictions. When the Australians,
title: Elementary Forms

text: scattered in little groups, spend their time in hunting and fishing,
title: Elementary Forms

text: they lose sight of what concerns their clan or tribe: their only thought
title: Elementary Forms

text: is to catch as much game as possible. On feast days, on the contrary,
title: Elementary Forms

text: these preoccupations are necessarily eclipsed; being essentially
title: Elementary Forms

text: profane, they are excluded from these sacred periods. At this time,
title: Elementary Forms

text: their thoughts are centred upon their common beliefs, their common
title: Elementary Forms

text: traditions, the memory of their great ancestors, the collective ideal
title: Elementary Forms

text: of which they are the incarnation; in a word, upon social things. Even
title: Elementary Forms

text: the material interests which these great religious ceremonies are
title: Elementary Forms

text: designed to satisfy concern the public order and are therefore social.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Society as a whole is interested that the harvest be abundant, that the
title: Elementary Forms

text: rain fall at the right time and not excessively, that the animals
title: Elementary Forms

text: reproduce regularly. So it is society that is in the foreground of every
title: Elementary Forms

text: consciousness; It dominates and directs all conduct; this is equivalent
title: Elementary Forms

text: to saying that it is more living and active, and consequently more real,
title: Elementary Forms

text: than in profane times. So men do not deceive themselves when they feel
title: Elementary Forms

text: at this time that there is something outside of them which is born
title: Elementary Forms

text: again, that there are forces which are reanimated and a life which
title: Elementary Forms

text: reawakens. This renewal is in no way imaginary and the individuals
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves profit from it. For the spark of a social being which each
title: Elementary Forms

text: bears within him necessarily participates in this collective renovation.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The individual soul is regenerated too, by being dipped again in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: source from which its life comes; consequently it feels itself stronger,
title: Elementary Forms

text: more fully master of itself, less dependent upon physical necessities.
title: Elementary Forms

text: We know that the positive cult naturally tends to take periodic forms;
title: Elementary Forms

text: this is one of its distinctive features. Of course there are rites which
title: Elementary Forms

text: men celebrate occasionally, in connection with passing situations. But
title: Elementary Forms

text: these episodic practices are always merely accessory, and in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: religions studied in this book, they are almost exceptional. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: essential constituent of the cult is the cycle of feasts which return
title: Elementary Forms

text: regularly at determined epochs. We are now able to understand whence
title: Elementary Forms

text: this tendency towards periodicity comes; the rhythm which the religious
title: Elementary Forms

text: life follows only expresses the rhythm of the social life, and results
title: Elementary Forms

text: from it. Society is able to revivify the sentiment it has of itself only
title: Elementary Forms

text: by assembling. But it cannot be assembled all the time. The exigencies
title: Elementary Forms

text: of life do not allow it to remain in congregation indefinitely; so it
title: Elementary Forms
