text: scatters, to assemble anew when it again feels the need of this. It is
title: Elementary Forms

text: to these necessary alternations that the regular alternations of sacred
title: Elementary Forms

text: and profane times correspond. Since the apparent object, at least, of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the cult was at first to regularize the course of natural phenomena, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: rhythm of the cosmic life has put its mark on the rhythm of the ritual
title: Elementary Forms

text: life. This is why the feasts have long been associated with the seasons;
title: Elementary Forms

text: we have seen this characteristic already in the Intichiuma of Australia.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But the seasons have only furnished the outer frame-work for this
title: Elementary Forms

text: organization, and not the principle upon which it rests; for even the
title: Elementary Forms

text: cults which aim at exclusively spiritual ends have remained periodical.
title: Elementary Forms

text: So this periodicity must be due to other causes. Since the seasonal
title: Elementary Forms

text: changes are critical periods for nature, they are a natural occasion for
title: Elementary Forms

text: assembling, and consequently for religious ceremonies. But other events
title: Elementary Forms

text: can and have successfully fulfilled this function of occasional cause.
title: Elementary Forms

text: However, it must be recognized that this frame-work, though purely
title: Elementary Forms

text: external, has given proof of a singular resistive force, for traces of
title: Elementary Forms

text: it are found even in the religions which are the most fully detached
title: Elementary Forms

text: from all physical bases. Many Christian celebrations are founded, with
title: Elementary Forms

text: no break of continuity, on the pastoral and agrarian feasts of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: ancient Hebrews, although in themselves they are neither pastoral nor
title: Elementary Forms

text: agrarian.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Moreover, this rhythm is capable of varying in different societies.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Where the period of dispersion is long, and the dispersion itself is
title: Elementary Forms

text: extreme, the period of congregation, in its turn, is very prolonged, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: produces veritable debauches of collective and religions life. Feasts
title: Elementary Forms

text: succeed one another for weeks or even for months, while the ritual life
title: Elementary Forms

text: sometimes attains to a sort of frenzy. This is what happens among the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Australian tribes and many of the tribes of North-western America.[1159]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Elsewhere, on the contrary, these two phases of the social life succeed
title: Elementary Forms

text: one another after shorter intervals, and then the contrast between them
title: Elementary Forms

text: is less marked. The more societies develop, the less they seem to allow
title: Elementary Forms

text: of too great intermittences.

text: CHAPTER III
title: Elementary Forms

text: THE POSITIVE CULT--_continued_
title: Elementary Forms

text: II.--_Imitative Rites and the Principle of Causality_
title: Elementary Forms

text: But the processes which we have just been describing are not the only
title: Elementary Forms

text: ones employed to assure the fecundity of the totemic species. There are
title: Elementary Forms

text: others which serve for the same end, whether they accompany the
title: Elementary Forms

text: preceding ones or replace them.
title: Elementary Forms

text: I
title: Elementary Forms

text: In the very ceremonies which we have been describing, in addition to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: oblations, whether bloody or otherwise, there are other rites which are
title: Elementary Forms

text: frequently celebrated, whose object is to complete the former ones and
title: Elementary Forms

text: to consolidate their effects. They consist in movements and cries whose
title: Elementary Forms

text: object is to imitate the different attitudes and aspects of the animal
title: Elementary Forms

text: whose reproduction is desired; therefore, we shall call them
title: Elementary Forms

text: _imitative_.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Thus the Intichiuma of the Witchetty grub among the Arunta includes more
title: Elementary Forms

text: than the rites performed upon the sacred rocks, of which we have already
title: Elementary Forms

text: spoken. When these are finished, the men set out to return to camp; but
title: Elementary Forms

text: when they still are about a mile away, they halt and all decorate
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves ritually; after this, the march is resumed. The decorations
title: Elementary Forms

text: with which they thus adorn themselves announce that an important
title: Elementary Forms

text: ceremony is going to take place. And, in fact, while the company was
title: Elementary Forms

text: absent, one of the old men who had been left to guard the camp had built
title: Elementary Forms

text: a shelter out of branches, called _Umbana_, which represented the
title: Elementary Forms

text: chrysalis out of which the insect comes. All of those who had taken part
title: Elementary Forms

text: in the previous ceremonies assemble near the spot where this
title: Elementary Forms

text: construction has been raised; then they advance slowly, stopping from
title: Elementary Forms

text: time to time, until they reach the _Umbana_, which they enter. At once
title: Elementary Forms

text: all the men who do not belong to the phratry of the Witchetty grub
title: Elementary Forms

text: totem, and who assist at the scene, though from a distance, lie down on
title: Elementary Forms

text: the ground, with their faces against the earth; they must remain in this
title: Elementary Forms

text: position without moving until they are allowed to get up again.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Meanwhile, a chant arises from the interior of the Umbana, which
title: Elementary Forms

text: describes the different phases through which the animal passes in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: course of its development, and the myths of which the sacred rocks are
title: Elementary Forms

text: the subject. When this hymn ceases, the Alatunja glides out of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: _Umbana_, though remaining in a squatting position, and advances slowly
title: Elementary Forms

text: over the ground before him; he is followed by all his companions who
title: Elementary Forms

text: reproduce gestures whose evident object is to represent the insect as it
title: Elementary Forms

text: leaves the chrysalis. Also, a hymn which is heard at just this moment
title: Elementary Forms

text: and which is like an oral commentary on the rite, consists in a
title: Elementary Forms

text: description of the movements made by the insect at this stage of its
title: Elementary Forms

text: development.[1160]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Another Intichiuma,[1161] celebrated in connection with another kind of
title: Elementary Forms

text: grub, the _unchalka_[1162] grub, has this character still more clearly.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The actors of this rite decorate themselves with designs representing
title: Elementary Forms

text: the _unchalka_ bush upon which this grub lives at the beginning of its
title: Elementary Forms

text: existence. Then they cover a buckler with concentric circles of down,
title: Elementary Forms

text: representing another kind of bush upon which the insect lays its eggs
title: Elementary Forms

text: when it has become adult. When all these preparations are finished, they
title: Elementary Forms

text: all sit down on the ground in a semicircle facing the principal
title: Elementary Forms

text: officiant. He alternately bends his body double by leaning towards the
title: Elementary Forms

text: ground and then rises on his knees; at the same time, he shakes his
title: Elementary Forms

text: stretched-out arms, which is a way of representing the wings of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: insect. From time to time, he leans over the buckler, imitating the way
title: Elementary Forms

text: in which the butterfly flies over the trees where it lays its eggs. When
title: Elementary Forms

text: this ceremony is finished, another commences at a different spot, to
title: Elementary Forms

text: which they go in silence. This time they use two bucklers. Upon one the
title: Elementary Forms

text: tracks of the grub are represented by zigzag lines; upon the other,
title: Elementary Forms

text: concentric circles of uneven dimensions represent the eggs of the insect
title: Elementary Forms

text: and the seed of the Eremophile bush, upon which it is nourished. As in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the former ceremony, they all sit down in silence while the officiant
title: Elementary Forms

text: acts, representing the movements of the animal when leaving its
title: Elementary Forms

text: chrysalis and taking its first flight.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Spencer and Gillen also point out certain analogous facts among the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Arunta, though these are of a minor importance: in the Intichiuma of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Emu, for example, at a certain moment the actors try to reproduce by
title: Elementary Forms

text: their attitude the air and aspect of this bird;[1163] in the Intichiuma
title: Elementary Forms

text: of water, the men of the totem utter the characteristic cry of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: plover, a cry which is naturally associated in the mind with the rainy
title: Elementary Forms

text: season.[1164] But in all, the examples of imitative rites which these
title: Elementary Forms

text: two explorers have noted are rather few in number. However, it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: certain that their relative silence on this point is due either to their
title: Elementary Forms

text: not having observed the Intichiuma sufficiently or else to their having
title: Elementary Forms

text: neglected this side of the ceremonies; Schulze, on the other hand, has
title: Elementary Forms

text: been struck by the essentially imitative nature of the Arunta rites.
title: Elementary Forms

text: "The sacred corrobbori," he says, "are generally ceremonies representing
title: Elementary Forms

text: animals": he calls them _animal tjurunga_[1165] and his testimony is now
title: Elementary Forms

text: confirmed by the documents collected by Strehlow. The examples given by
title: Elementary Forms

text: this latter author are so numerous that it is impossible to cite them
title: Elementary Forms

text: all: there are scarcely any ceremonies in which some imitating gesture
title: Elementary Forms

text: is not pointed out. According to the nature of the animals whose feast
title: Elementary Forms

text: is celebrated, they jump after the manner of kangaroos, or imitate the
title: Elementary Forms

text: movements they make in eating, the flight of winged ants, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: characteristic noise of the bat, the cry of the wild turkey, the hissing
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the snake, the croaking of the frog, etc.[1166] When the totem is a
title: Elementary Forms

text: plant, they make the gesture of plucking it,[1167] or eating it,[1168]
title: Elementary Forms

text: etc.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Among the Warramunga, the Intichiuma generally takes a special form,
title: Elementary Forms

text: which we shall describe in the next chapter and which differs from those
title: Elementary Forms

text: which we have studied up to the present. However, there is one typical
title: Elementary Forms

text: case of a purely imitative Intichiuma among this people; it is that of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the black cockatoo. The ceremony described by Spencer and Gillen
title: Elementary Forms

text: commenced at ten o'clock in the evening. All night long the chief of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: clan imitated the cry of the bird with a disheartening monotony. He
title: Elementary Forms

text: stopped only when he had come to the end of his force, and then his son
title: Elementary Forms

text: replaced him; then he commenced again as soon as he felt a little
title: Elementary Forms

text: refreshed. These exhausting exercises continued until morning without
title: Elementary Forms

text: interruption.[1169]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Living beings are not the only ones which they try to imitate. In a
title: Elementary Forms

text: large number of tribes, the Intichiuma of rain consists essentially in
title: Elementary Forms

text: imitative rites. One of the most simple of these is that celebrated
title: Elementary Forms

text: among the Arabunna. The chief of the clan is seated on the ground, all
title: Elementary Forms

text: covered with white down and holding a lance in his hands. He shakes
title: Elementary Forms

text: himself, undoubtedly in order to detach from his body the down which is
title: Elementary Forms

text: fixed there and which represents clouds when scattered about in the air.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Thus he imitates the men-clouds of the Alcheringa who, according to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: legend, had the habit of ascending to heaven and forming clouds there,
title: Elementary Forms

text: from which the rain then fell. In a word, the object of the whole rite
title: Elementary Forms

text: is to represent the formation and ascension of clouds, the bringers of
title: Elementary Forms

text: The ceremony is much more complicated among the Kaitish. We have already
title: Elementary Forms

text: spoken of one of the means employed: the officiant pours water over the
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacred stones and himself. But the action of this sort of oblation is
title: Elementary Forms

text: reinforced by other rites. The rainbow is considered to have a close
title: Elementary Forms

text: connection with rain: they say that it is its son and that it is always
title: Elementary Forms

text: urged to appear to make the rain stop. To make the rain fall, it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: therefore necessary that it should not appear; they believe that this
title: Elementary Forms

text: result can be obtained in the following manner. A design representing a
title: Elementary Forms

text: rainbow is made upon a buckler. They carry this buckler to camp, taking
title: Elementary Forms

text: care to keep it hidden from all eyes. They are convinced that by making
title: Elementary Forms

text: this image of the rainbow invisible, they keep the rainbow itself from
title: Elementary Forms

text: appearing. Meanwhile, the chief of the clan, having beside him a
title: Elementary Forms

text: _pitchi_ full of water, throws in all directions flakes of down which
title: Elementary Forms

text: represent clouds. Repeated imitations of the cry of the plover complete
title: Elementary Forms

text: this ceremony, which seems to have an especial gravity; for as long as
title: Elementary Forms

text: it lasts, all those who participate in it, either as actors or
title: Elementary Forms

text: assistants, may have no relations whatsoever with their wives; they may
title: Elementary Forms

text: not even speak to them.[1171]
title: Elementary Forms

text: The processes of figuration are different among the Dieri. Rain is not
title: Elementary Forms

text: represented by water, but by blood, which the men cause to flow from
title: Elementary Forms

text: their veins on to the assistants.[1172] At the same time they throw
title: Elementary Forms

text: handfuls of white down about, which represent clouds. A hut has been
title: Elementary Forms

text: constructed previously, in which they now place two large stones
title: Elementary Forms

text: representing piles of clouds, a sign of rain. After they have been left
title: Elementary Forms

text: there for a little while, they are carried a little distance away and
title: Elementary Forms

text: placed as high as possible in the loftiest tree to be found; this is a
title: Elementary Forms

text: way of making the clouds mount into the sky. Powdered gypsum is then
title: Elementary Forms

text: thrown into a water-hole, for when he sees this, the rain spirit soon
title: Elementary Forms

text: makes the clouds appear. Finally all the men, young and old, assemble
title: Elementary Forms

text: around the hut and with heads lowered, they charge upon it; they rush
title: Elementary Forms

text: violently through it, repeating the operation several times, until
title: Elementary Forms

text: nothing remains of the whole construction except the supporting posts.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Then they fall upon these and shake and pull at them until the whole
title: Elementary Forms

text: thing has tumbled down. The operation consisting in running through the
title: Elementary Forms

text: hut is supposed to represent clouds bursting; the tumbling down of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: construction, the fall of rain.[1173]
title: Elementary Forms

text: In the north-western tribes studied by Clement,[1174] which occupy the
title: Elementary Forms

text: district included between the Fontescue and Fitzroy rivers, certain
title: Elementary Forms

text: ceremonies are celebrated whose object is exactly the same as that of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the Intichiuma of the Arunta, and which seem to be, for the most part,
title: Elementary Forms

text: essentially imitative.
title: Elementary Forms

text: These peoples give the name _tarlow_ to certain piles of stones which
title: Elementary Forms

text: are evidently sacred, for, as we shall see, they are the object of
title: Elementary Forms

text: important rites. Every animal, every plant, and in fact, every totem or
title: Elementary Forms

text: sub-totem,[1175] is represented by a _tarlow_ which a special clan[1176]
title: Elementary Forms

text: guards. The analogy between these _tarlow_ and the sacred rocks of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Arunta is easily seen.
title: Elementary Forms

text: When kangaroos, for example, become rare, the chief of the clan to which
title: Elementary Forms

text: the _tarlow_ of the kangaroo belongs goes to it with a certain number of
title: Elementary Forms

text: companions. Here various rites are performed, the chief of which consist
title: Elementary Forms

text: in jumping around the _tarlow_ as kangaroos jump, in drinking as they
title: Elementary Forms

text: drink and, in a word, in imitating all their most characteristic
title: Elementary Forms

text: movements. The weapons used in hunting the animal have an important part
title: Elementary Forms

text: in these rites. They brandish them, throw them against the stones, etc.
title: Elementary Forms

text: When they are concerned for emus, they go to the _tarlow_ of the emu,
title: Elementary Forms

text: and walk and run as these birds do. The skill which the natives show in
title: Elementary Forms

text: these imitations is, as it appears, really remarkable.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Other _tarlow_ are consecrated to plants, such as the cereals. In this
title: Elementary Forms

text: case, they imitate the actions of threshing and grinding the grain.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Since in ordinary life it is the women who are normally charged with
title: Elementary Forms

text: these tasks, it is also they who perform the rite, in the midst of songs
title: Elementary Forms

text: and dances.
title: Elementary Forms

text: II
title: Elementary Forms

text: All these rites belong to the same type. The principle upon which they
title: Elementary Forms

text: rest is one of those at the basis of what is commonly and incorrectly
title: Elementary Forms

text: called sympathetic[1177] magic.
title: Elementary Forms

text: These principles are ordinarily reduced to two.[1178]
title: Elementary Forms

text: The first may be stated thus: _anything touching an object also touches
title: Elementary Forms

text: everything which has any relation of proximity or unity whatsoever with
title: Elementary Forms

text: this object_. Thus, whatever affects the part also affects the whole;
title: Elementary Forms

text: any action exercised over an individual is transmitted to his
title: Elementary Forms

text: neighbours, relatives and all those to whom he is united in any way. All
title: Elementary Forms

text: these cases are simple applications of the law of contagion, which we
title: Elementary Forms

text: have already studied. A condition or a good or bad quality are
title: Elementary Forms

text: communicated contagiously from one subject to another who has some
title: Elementary Forms

text: connection with the former.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The second principle is ordinarily summed up in the formula: _like
title: Elementary Forms

text: produces like_. The representation of a being or condition produces this
title: Elementary Forms

text: being or condition. This is the maxim which brings about the rites which
title: Elementary Forms

text: we have just been describing, and it is in them that we can best observe
title: Elementary Forms

text: its characteristics. The classical example of the magic charm, which is
title: Elementary Forms

text: ordinarily given as the typical application of this same precept, is
title: Elementary Forms

text: much less significant. The charm is, to a large extent, a simple
title: Elementary Forms

text: phenomenon of transfer. The idea of the image is associated in the mind
title: Elementary Forms

text: with that of the model; consequently the effects of an action performed
title: Elementary Forms

text: upon a statue are transmitted contagiously to the person whose traits it
title: Elementary Forms

text: reproduces. The function of the image is for its original what that of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: part is for the whole: it is an agent of transmission. Therefore men
title: Elementary Forms

text: think that they can obtain the same result by burning the hair of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: person whom they wish to injure: the only difference between these two
title: Elementary Forms

text: sorts of operations is that in one, the communication is made through
title: Elementary Forms

text: similarity, while in the other it is by means of contiguity. It is
title: Elementary Forms

text: different with the rites which concern us. They suppose not only the
title: Elementary Forms

text: displacement of a given condition or quality, which passes from one
title: Elementary Forms

text: object into the other, but also the creation of something entirely new.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The mere act of representing the animal gives birth to this animal and
title: Elementary Forms

text: creates it; by imitating the sound of wind or falling water, they cause
title: Elementary Forms

text: clouds to form, rain to fall, etc. Of course resemblance plays an
title: Elementary Forms

text: important part in each case, but not at all the same one. In a charm, it
title: Elementary Forms

text: only gives a special direction to the action exercised; it directs in a
title: Elementary Forms

text: certain way an action not originating in it. In the rites of which we
title: Elementary Forms

text: have just been speaking, it acts by itself and is directly efficacious.
title: Elementary Forms

text: So, in contradiction to the usual definitions, the real difference
title: Elementary Forms

text: between the two principles of the so-called sympathetic magic and the
title: Elementary Forms

text: corresponding practices is not that it is contiguity acts in one case
title: Elementary Forms

text: and resemblance in the other, but that in the former there is a simple
title: Elementary Forms

text: contagious communication, while there is production and creation in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: latter.[1179]
title: Elementary Forms

text: The explanation of imitative rites therefore implies the explanation of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the second of these principles, and reciprocally.
title: Elementary Forms

text: We shall not tarry long to discuss the explanation proposed by the
title: Elementary Forms

text: anthropological school, and especially by Tylor and Frazer. Just as in
title: Elementary Forms

text: their attempts to account for the contagiousness of a sacred character,
title: Elementary Forms

text: they invoke the association of ideas. "Hom[oe]opathic magic," says
title: Elementary Forms

text: Frazer, who prefers this expression to imitative magic, "is founded on
title: Elementary Forms

text: the association of ideas by similarity; contagious magic is founded on
title: Elementary Forms

text: the association of ideas by contiguity. Hom[oe]opathic magic commits the
title: Elementary Forms

text: mistake of assuming that things which resemble each other are the
title: Elementary Forms

text: same."[1180] But this is a misunderstanding of the special nature of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: practices under discussion. On the one hand, the formula of Frazer may
title: Elementary Forms

text: be applied with some fitness to the case of charms;[1181] here, in fact,
title: Elementary Forms

text: two distinct things are associated with each other, owing to their
title: Elementary Forms

text: partial resemblance: these are the image and the model which it
title: Elementary Forms

text: represents more or less systematically. But in the imitative rites,
title: Elementary Forms

text: which we have just been observing, the image alone is given; as for the
title: Elementary Forms

text: model, it does not exist, for the new generation of the totemic species
title: Elementary Forms

text: is as yet only a hope and even an uncertain hope at that. So there could
title: Elementary Forms

text: be no question of association, whether correct or not; there is a real
title: Elementary Forms

text: creation, and we cannot see how the association of ideas could possibly
title: Elementary Forms

text: lead to a belief in this creation. How could the mere act of
title: Elementary Forms

text: representing the movements of an animal bring about the certitude that
title: Elementary Forms

text: this animal will be born, and born in abundance?
title: Elementary Forms

text: The general properties of human nature cannot explain such special
title: Elementary Forms

text: practices. So instead of considering the principle upon which they rest
title: Elementary Forms

text: in its general and abstract form, let us replace it in the environment
title: Elementary Forms

text: of which it is a part and where we have been observing it, and let us
title: Elementary Forms

text: connect it with the system of ideas and sentiments which the above rites
title: Elementary Forms

text: put into practice, and then we shall be better able to perceive the
title: Elementary Forms

text: causes from which it results.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The men who assemble on the occasion of these rites believe that they
title: Elementary Forms

text: are really animals or plants of the species whose name they bear. They
title: Elementary Forms

text: feel within them an animal or vegetable nature, and in their eyes, this
title: Elementary Forms

text: is what constitutes whatever is the most essential and the most
title: Elementary Forms

text: excellent in them. So when they assemble, their first movement ought to
title: Elementary Forms

text: be to show each other this quality which they attribute to themselves
title: Elementary Forms

text: and by which they are defined. The totem is their rallying sign; for
title: Elementary Forms

text: this reason, as we have seen, they design it upon their bodies; but it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is no less natural that they should seek to resemble it in their
title: Elementary Forms

text: gestures, their cries, their attitude. Since they are emus or kangaroos,
title: Elementary Forms

text: they comport themselves like the animals of the same name. By this
title: Elementary Forms

text: means, they mutually show one another that they are all members of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: same moral community and they become conscious of the kinship uniting
title: Elementary Forms

text: them. The rite does not limit itself to expressing this kinship; it
title: Elementary Forms

text: makes it or remakes it. For it exists only in so far as it is believed
title: Elementary Forms

text: in, and the effect of all these collective demonstrations is to support
title: Elementary Forms

text: the beliefs upon which they are founded. Therefore, these leaps, these
title: Elementary Forms

text: cries and these movements of every sort, though bizarre and grotesque in
title: Elementary Forms

text: appearance, really have a profound and human meaning. The Australian
title: Elementary Forms

text: seeks to resemble his totem just as the faithful in more advanced
title: Elementary Forms

text: religions seek to resemble their God. For the one as for the other, this
title: Elementary Forms

text: is a means of communicating with the sacred being, that is to say, with
title: Elementary Forms

text: the collective ideal which this latter symbolizes. This is an early form
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the [Greek: homoiosis to theo].
title: Elementary Forms

text: However, as this first reason is connected with the most specialized
title: Elementary Forms

text: portions of the totemic beliefs, the principle by which like produces
title: Elementary Forms

text: like should not have survived totemism, if this had been the only one in
title: Elementary Forms

text: operation. Now there is probably no religion in which rites derived from
title: Elementary Forms

text: it are not found. So another reason must co-operate with this first one.
title: Elementary Forms

text: And, in fact, the ceremonies where we have seen it applied do not merely
title: Elementary Forms

text: have the very general object which we have just mentioned, howsoever
title: Elementary Forms

text: essential this may be; they also aim at a more immediate and more
title: Elementary Forms

text: conscious end, which is the assurance of the reproduction of the totemic
title: Elementary Forms

text: species. The idea of this necessary reproduction haunts the minds of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: worshippers: upon it the forces of their attention and will are
title: Elementary Forms

text: concentrated. Now a single preoccupation cannot possess a group of men
title: Elementary Forms

text: to this point without being externalized in a material form. Since all
title: Elementary Forms

text: think of the animal or plant to whose destinies the clan is united, it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is inevitable that this common thought should not be manifested
title: Elementary Forms

text: outwardly by gestures,[1182] and those naturally designated for this
title: Elementary Forms

text: office are those which represent this animal or plant in one of its most
title: Elementary Forms

text: characteristic attitudes; there are no other movements so close to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: idea filling every mind, for these are an immediate and almost automatic
title: Elementary Forms

text: translation of it. So they make themselves imitate the animal; they cry
title: Elementary Forms

text: like it, they jump like it; they reproduce the scenes in which they make
title: Elementary Forms

text: daily use of the plant. All these ways of representation are just so
title: Elementary Forms

text: many means of ostensibly showing the end towards which all minds are
title: Elementary Forms

text: directed, of telling the thing which they wish to realize, of calling it
title: Elementary Forms

text: up and of evoking it. And this need belongs to no one time, nor does it
title: Elementary Forms

text: depend upon the beliefs of any special religion; it is essentially
title: Elementary Forms

text: human. This is why, even in religions very far removed from those we
title: Elementary Forms

text: have been studying, the worshippers, when assembled to ask their gods
title: Elementary Forms

text: for some event which they ardently desire, are forced to figure it. Of
title: Elementary Forms

text: course, the word is also a way of expressing it; but the gesture is no
title: Elementary Forms

text: less natural; it bursts out from the organism just as spontaneously; it
title: Elementary Forms

text: even precedes the word, or, in any case, accompanies it.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But if we can thus understand how the gestures acquired a place in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: ceremony, we still must explain the efficacy attributed to them. If the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Australian repeats them regularly each new season, it is because he
title: Elementary Forms

text: believes them essential to the success of the rite. Where could he have
title: Elementary Forms

text: gotten the idea that by imitating an animal, one causes it to reproduce?
title: Elementary Forms

text: So manifest an error seems hardly intelligible so long as we see in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: rite only the material end towards which it seems to aim. But we know
title: Elementary Forms

text: that in addition to the effect which it is thought to have on the
title: Elementary Forms

text: totemic species, it also exercises a profound influence over the souls
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the worshippers who take part in it. They take away with them a
title: Elementary Forms

text: feeling of well-being, whose causes they cannot clearly see, but which
title: Elementary Forms

text: is well founded. They feel that the ceremony is good for them; and, as a
title: Elementary Forms

text: matter of fact, they reforge their moral nature in it. How could this
title: Elementary Forms

text: sort of well-being fail to give them a feeling that the rite has
title: Elementary Forms

text: succeeded, that it has been what it set out to be, and that it has
title: Elementary Forms

text: attained the ends at which it was aimed? As the only end which was
title: Elementary Forms

text: consciously sought was the reproduction of the totemic species, this
title: Elementary Forms

text: seems to be assured by the means employed, the efficacy of which is thus
title: Elementary Forms

text: proven. Thus it comes about that men attribute creative virtues to their
title: Elementary Forms

text: gestures, which in themselves are vain. The moral efficacy of the rite,
title: Elementary Forms

text: which is real, leads to the belief in its physical efficacy, which is
title: Elementary Forms

text: imaginary; that of the whole, to the belief in that of each part by
title: Elementary Forms

text: itself. The truly useful effects produced by the whole ceremony are like
title: Elementary Forms

text: an experimental justification of the elementary practices out of which
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is made, though in reality, all these practices are in no way
title: Elementary Forms

text: indispensable to its success. A certain proof, moreover, that they do
title: Elementary Forms

text: not act by themselves is that they may be replaced by others, of a very
title: Elementary Forms

text: different nature, without any modification of the final result. It
title: Elementary Forms

text: appears that there are Intichiuma which include only oblations, with no
title: Elementary Forms

text: imitative rites; others are purely imitative, and include no oblations.
title: Elementary Forms

text: However, both are believed to have the same efficacy. So if a price is
title: Elementary Forms

text: attached to these various man[oe]uvres, it is not because of their
title: Elementary Forms

text: intrinsic value, but because they are a part of a complex rite, whose
title: Elementary Forms

text: utility as a whole is realized.
title: Elementary Forms

text: We are able to understand this state of mind all the easier because we
title: Elementary Forms

text: can still observe it about us. Especially among the most cultivated
title: Elementary Forms

text: peoples and environments, we frequently meet with believers who, though
title: Elementary Forms

text: having doubts as to the special efficacy attributed by dogma to each
title: Elementary Forms

text: rite considered separately, still continue to participate in the cult.
title: Elementary Forms

text: They are not sure that the details of the prescribed observances are
title: Elementary Forms

text: rationally justifiable; but they feel that it would be impossible to
title: Elementary Forms

text: free oneself of them without falling into a moral confusion before which
title: Elementary Forms

text: they recoil. The very fact that in them the faith has lost its
title: Elementary Forms

text: intellectual foundations throws into eminence the profound reasons upon
title: Elementary Forms

text: which they rest. This is why the easy criticisms to which an unduly
title: Elementary Forms

text: simple rationalism has sometimes submitted ritual prescriptions
title: Elementary Forms

text: generally leave the believer indifferent: it is because the true
title: Elementary Forms

text: justification of religious practices does not lie in the apparent ends
title: Elementary Forms

text: which they pursue, but rather in the invisible action which they
title: Elementary Forms

text: exercise over the mind and in the way in which they affect our mental
title: Elementary Forms

text: status. Likewise, when preachers undertake to convince, they devote much
title: Elementary Forms

text: less attention to establishing directly and by methodical proofs the
title: Elementary Forms

text: truth of any particular proposition or the utility of such and such an
title: Elementary Forms

text: observance, than to awakening or reawakening the sentiment of the moral
title: Elementary Forms

text: comfort attained by the regular celebration of the cult. Thus they
title: Elementary Forms

text: create a predisposition to belief, which precedes proofs, which leads
title: Elementary Forms

text: the mind to overlook the insufficiency of the logical reasons, and which
title: Elementary Forms

text: thus prepares it for the proposition whose acceptance is desired. This
title: Elementary Forms

text: favourable prejudice, this impulse towards believing, is just what
title: Elementary Forms

text: constitutes faith; and it is faith which makes the authority of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: rites, according to the believer, whoever he may be, Christian or
title: Elementary Forms

text: Australian. The only superiority of the former is that he better
title: Elementary Forms

text: accounts for the psychological process from which his faith results; he
title: Elementary Forms

text: knows that "it is faith that saves."
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is because faith has this origin that it is, in a sense, "impermeable
title: Elementary Forms

text: to experience."[1183] If the intermittent failures of the Intichiuma do
title: Elementary Forms

text: not shake the confidence of the Australian in his rite, it is because
title: Elementary Forms

text: he holds with all the strength of his soul to these practices in which
title: Elementary Forms

text: he periodically recreates himself; he could not deny their principle
title: Elementary Forms

text: without causing an upheaval of his own being, which resists. But
title: Elementary Forms

text: howsoever great this force of resistance may be, it cannot radically
title: Elementary Forms

text: distinguish religious mentality from the other forms of human mentality,
title: Elementary Forms

text: even those which are the most habitually opposed to it. In this
title: Elementary Forms

text: connection, that of a scholar differs from the preceding only in degree.
title: Elementary Forms

text: When a scientific law has the authority of numerous and varied
title: Elementary Forms

text: experiments, it is against all method to renounce it too quickly upon
title: Elementary Forms

text: the discovery of a fact which seems to contradict it. It is still
title: Elementary Forms

text: necessary to make sure that the fact does not allow of a single
title: Elementary Forms

text: interpretation, and that it is impossible to account for it, without
title: Elementary Forms

text: abandoning the proposition which it seems to invalidate. Now the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Australian does not proceed otherwise when he attributes the failure of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the Intichiuma to some sorcery, or the abundance of a premature crop to
title: Elementary Forms

text: a mystic Intichiuma celebrated in the beyond. He has all the more reason
title: Elementary Forms

text: for not doubting his rite on the belief in a contrary fact, since its
title: Elementary Forms

text: value is, or seems to be, established by a larger number of harmonizing
title: Elementary Forms

text: facts. In the first place, the moral efficacy of the ceremony is real
title: Elementary Forms

text: and is felt directly by all who participate in it; there is a constantly
title: Elementary Forms

text: renewed experience in it, whose importance no contradictory experience
title: Elementary Forms

text: can diminish. Also, the physical efficacy itself is not unable to find
title: Elementary Forms

text: an at least apparent confirmation in the data of objective observation.
title: Elementary Forms

text: As a matter of fact, the totemic species normally does reproduce
title: Elementary Forms

text: regularly; so in the great majority of cases, everything happens just as
title: Elementary Forms

text: if the ritual gestures really did produce the effects expected of them.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Failures are the exception. As the rites, and especially those which are
title: Elementary Forms

text: periodical, demand nothing more of nature than that it follow its
title: Elementary Forms

text: ordinary course, it is not surprising that it should generally have the
title: Elementary Forms

text: air of obeying them. So if the believer shows himself indocile to
title: Elementary Forms

text: certain lessons of experience, he does so because of other experiences
title: Elementary Forms

text: which seem more demonstrative. The scholar does not do otherwise; only
title: Elementary Forms

text: he introduces more method.
title: Elementary Forms

text: So magic is not, as Frazer has held,[1184] an original fact, of which
title: Elementary Forms

text: religion is only a derived form. Quite on the contrary, it was under the
title: Elementary Forms

text: influence of religious ideas that the precepts upon which the art of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: magician is based were established, and it was only through a secondary
title: Elementary Forms

text: extension that they were applied to purely lay relations. Since all the
title: Elementary Forms

text: forces of the universe have been conceived on the model of the sacred
title: Elementary Forms

text: forces, the contagiousness inherent in the second was extended to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: first, and men have believed that all the properties of a body could be
title: Elementary Forms

text: transmitted contagiously. Likewise, when the principle according to
title: Elementary Forms

text: which like produces like had been established, in order to satisfy
title: Elementary Forms

text: certain religious needs, it detached itself from its ritual origins to
title: Elementary Forms

text: become, through a sort of spontaneous generalization, a law of
title: Elementary Forms

text: nature.[1185] But in order to understand these fundamental axioms of
title: Elementary Forms

text: magic, they must be replaced in the religious atmosphere in which they
title: Elementary Forms

text: arose and which alone enables us to account for them. When we regard
title: Elementary Forms

text: them as the work of isolated individuals or solitary magicians, we ask
title: Elementary Forms

text: how they could ever have occurred to the mind of man, for nothing in
title: Elementary Forms

text: experience could either suggest or verify them; and especially we do not
title: Elementary Forms

text: explain how so deceiving an art has been able to impose itself for so
title: Elementary Forms

text: long a time in the confidence of men. But this problem disappears when
title: Elementary Forms

text: we realize that the faith inspired by magic is only a particular case of
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious faith in general, and that it is itself the product, at least
title: Elementary Forms

text: indirectly, of a collective effervescence. This is as much as to say
title: Elementary Forms

text: that the use of the expression sympathetic magic to designate the system
title: Elementary Forms

text: of rites which we have just been speaking is not very exact. There are
title: Elementary Forms

text: sympathetic rites, but they are not peculiar to magic; not only are they
title: Elementary Forms

text: to be found in religion, but it was from religion that magic received
title: Elementary Forms

text: them. So we only risk confusion when, by the name we give them, we have
title: Elementary Forms

text: the air of making them something which is specifically magic.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The results of our analysis thus attach themselves to and confirm those
title: Elementary Forms

text: attained by MM. Hubert and Mauss when they studied magic directly.[1186]
title: Elementary Forms

text: They have shown that this is nothing more nor less than crude industry
title: Elementary Forms

text: based on incomplete science. Behind the mechanisms, purely laical in
title: Elementary Forms

text: appearance, which are used by the magician, they point out a background
title: Elementary Forms

text: of religious conceptions and a whole world of forces, the idea of which
title: Elementary Forms

text: has been taken by magic from religion. We are now able to understand how
title: Elementary Forms

text: it comes that magic is so full of religious elements: it is because it
title: Elementary Forms

text: was born of religion.

text: III
title: Elementary Forms

text: But the principle which has just been set forth does not merely have a
title: Elementary Forms

text: function in the ritual; it is of direct interest for the theory of
title: Elementary Forms

text: knowledge. In fact, it is a concrete statement of the law of causality
title: Elementary Forms

text: and, in all probability, one of the most primitive statements of it
title: Elementary Forms

text: which has ever existed. A full conception of the causal relation is
title: Elementary Forms

text: implied in the power thus attributed to the like to produce the like;
title: Elementary Forms

text: and this conception dominates primitive thought, for it is the basis
title: Elementary Forms

text: both of the practices of the cult and the technique of the magician. So
title: Elementary Forms

text: the origins of the precept upon which the imitative rites depend are
title: Elementary Forms

text: able to clarify those of the principle of causality. The genesis of one
title: Elementary Forms

text: should aid us in understanding the genesis of the other. Now we have
title: Elementary Forms

text: shown how the former is a product of social causes: it was elaborated by
title: Elementary Forms

text: groups having collective ends in view, and it translates collective
title: Elementary Forms

text: sentiments. So we may assume that the same is true for the second.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In fact, an analysis of the principle of causality is sufficient to
title: Elementary Forms

text: assure us that the diverse elements of which it is composed really did
title: Elementary Forms

text: have this origin.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The first thing which is implied in the notion of the causal relation is
title: Elementary Forms

text: the idea of efficacy, of productive power, of active force. By cause we
title: Elementary Forms

text: ordinarily mean something capable of producing a certain change. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: cause is the force before it has shown the power which is in it; the
title: Elementary Forms

text: effect is this same power, only actualized. Men have always thought of
title: Elementary Forms

text: causality in dynamic terms. Of course certain philosophers had refused
title: Elementary Forms

text: all objective value to this conception; they see in it only an arbitrary
title: Elementary Forms

text: construction of the imagination, which corresponds to nothing in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: things themselves. But, at present, we have no need of asking whether it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is founded in reality or not; it is enough for us to state that it
title: Elementary Forms

text: exists and that it constitutes and always has constituted an element of
title: Elementary Forms

text: ordinary mentality; and this is recognized even by those who criticize
title: Elementary Forms

text: it. Our immediate purpose is to seek, not what it may be worth
title: Elementary Forms

text: logically, but how it is to be explained.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Now it depends upon social causes. Our analysis of facts has already
title: Elementary Forms

text: enabled us to see that the prototype of the idea of force was the mana,
title: Elementary Forms

text: wakan, orenda, the totemic principle or any of the various names given
title: Elementary Forms

text: to collective force objectified and projected into things.[1187] The
title: Elementary Forms

text: first power which men have thought of as such seems to have been that
title: Elementary Forms

text: exercised by humanity over its members. Thus reason confirms the results
title: Elementary Forms

text: of observation; in fact, it is even possible to show why this notion of
title: Elementary Forms

text: power, efficacy or active force could not have come from any other
title: Elementary Forms

text: source.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In the first place, it is evident and recognized by all that it could
title: Elementary Forms

text: not be furnished to us by external experience. Our senses only enable
title: Elementary Forms

text: us to perceive phenomena which coexist or which follow one another, but
title: Elementary Forms

text: nothing perceived by them could give us the idea of this determining and
title: Elementary Forms

text: compelling action which is characteristic of what we call a power or
title: Elementary Forms

text: force. They can touch only realized and known conditions, each separate
title: Elementary Forms

text: from the others; the internal process uniting these conditions escapes
title: Elementary Forms

text: them. Nothing that we learn could possibly suggest to us the idea of
title: Elementary Forms

text: what an influence or efficaciousness is. It is for this very reason that
title: Elementary Forms

text: the philosophers of empiricism have regarded these different conceptions
title: Elementary Forms

text: as so many mythological aberrations. But even supposing that they all
title: Elementary Forms

text: are hallucinations, it is still necessary to show how they originated.
title: Elementary Forms

text: If external experience counts for nothing in the origin of these ideas,
title: Elementary Forms

text: and it is equally inadmissible that they were given us ready-made, one
title: Elementary Forms

text: might suppose that they come from internal experience. In fact, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: notion of force obviously includes many spiritual elements which could
title: Elementary Forms

text: only have been taken from our psychic life.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Some have believed that the act by which our will brings a deliberation
title: Elementary Forms

text: to a close, restrains our impulses and commands our organism, might have
title: Elementary Forms

text: served as the model of this construction. In willing, it is said, we
title: Elementary Forms

text: perceive ourselves directly as a power in action. So when this idea had
title: Elementary Forms

text: once occurred to men, it seems that they only had to extend it to things
title: Elementary Forms

text: to establish the conception of force.
title: Elementary Forms

text: As long as the animist theory passed as a demonstrated truth, this
title: Elementary Forms

text: explanation was able to appear to be confirmed by history. If the forces
title: Elementary Forms

text: with which human thought primitively populated the world really had been
title: Elementary Forms

text: spirits, that is to say, personal and conscious beings more or less
title: Elementary Forms

text: similar to men, it was actually possible to believe that our individual
title: Elementary Forms

text: experience was enough to furnish us with the constituent elements of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: notion of force. But we know that the first forces which men imagined
title: Elementary Forms

text: were, on the contrary, anonymous, vague and diffused powers which
title: Elementary Forms

text: resemble cosmic forces in their impersonality, and which are therefore
title: Elementary Forms

text: most sharply contrasted with the eminently personal power, the human
title: Elementary Forms

text: will. So it is impossible that they should have been conceived in its
title: Elementary Forms

text: image.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Moreover, there is one essential characteristic of the impersonal forces
title: Elementary Forms

text: which would be inexplicable under this hypothesis: this is their
title: Elementary Forms

text: communicability. The forces of nature have always been thought of as
title: Elementary Forms

text: capable of passing from one object to another, of mixing, combining and
title: Elementary Forms

text: transforming themselves into one another. It is even this property which
title: Elementary Forms

text: gives them their value as an explanation, for it is through this that
title: Elementary Forms

text: effects can be connected with their causes without a break of
title: Elementary Forms

text: continuity. Now the self has just the opposite characteristic: it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: incommunicable. It cannot change its material substratum or spread from
title: Elementary Forms

text: one to another; it spreads out in metaphor only. So the way in which it
title: Elementary Forms

text: decides and executes its decisions could never have suggested the idea
title: Elementary Forms

text: of an energy which communicates itself and which can even confound
title: Elementary Forms

text: itself with others and, through these combinations and mixings, give
title: Elementary Forms

text: rise to new effects.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Therefore, the idea of force, as implied in the conception of the causal
title: Elementary Forms

text: relation, must present a double character. In the first place, it can
title: Elementary Forms

text: come only from our internal experience; the only forces which we can
title: Elementary Forms

text: directly learn about are necessarily moral forces. But, at the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: time, they must be impersonal, for the notion of an impersonal power was
title: Elementary Forms

text: the first to be constituted. Now the only ones which satisfy these two
title: Elementary Forms

text: conditions are those coming from life together: they are collective
title: Elementary Forms

text: forces. In fact, these are, on the one hand, entirely psychical; they
title: Elementary Forms

text: are made up exclusively of objectified ideas and sentiments. But, on the
title: Elementary Forms

text: other hand, they are impersonal by definition, for they are the product
title: Elementary Forms

text: of a co-operation. Being the work of all, they are not the possession of
title: Elementary Forms

text: anybody in particular. They are so slightly attached to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: personalities of the subjects in whom they reside that they are never
title: Elementary Forms

text: fixed there. Just as they enter them from without, they are also always
title: Elementary Forms

text: ready to leave them. Of themselves, they tend to spread further and
title: Elementary Forms

text: further and to invade ever new domains: we know that there are none more
title: Elementary Forms

text: contagious, and consequently more communicable. Of course physical
title: Elementary Forms

text: forces have the same property, but we cannot know this directly; we
title: Elementary Forms

text: cannot even become acquainted with them as such, for they are outside
title: Elementary Forms

text: us. When I throw myself against an obstacle, I have a sensation of
title: Elementary Forms

text: hindrance and trouble; but the force causing this sensation is not in
title: Elementary Forms

text: me, but in the obstacle, and is consequently outside the circle of my
title: Elementary Forms

text: perception. We perceive its effects, but we cannot reach the cause
title: Elementary Forms

text: itself. It is otherwise with social forces: they are a part of our
title: Elementary Forms

text: internal life, as we know, more than the products of their action; we
title: Elementary Forms

text: see them acting. The force isolating the sacred being and holding
title: Elementary Forms

text: profane beings at a distance is not really in this being; it lives in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the minds of the believers. So they perceive it at the very moment when
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is acting upon their wills, to inhibit certain movements or command
title: Elementary Forms

text: others. In a word, this constraining and necessitating action, which
title: Elementary Forms

text: escapes us when coming from an external object, is readily perceptible
title: Elementary Forms

text: here because everything is inside us. Of course we do not always
title: Elementary Forms

text: interpret it in an adequate manner, but at least we cannot fail to be
title: Elementary Forms

text: conscious of it.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Moreover, the idea of force bears the mark of its origin in an apparent
title: Elementary Forms

text: way. In fact, it implies the idea of power which, in its turn, does not
title: Elementary Forms

text: come without those of ascendancy, mastership and domination, and their
title: Elementary Forms

text: corollaries, dependence and subordination; now the relations expressed
title: Elementary Forms

text: by all these ideas are eminently social. It is society which classifies
title: Elementary Forms

text: beings into superiors and inferiors, into commanding masters and obeying
title: Elementary Forms

text: servants; it is society which confers upon the former the singular
title: Elementary Forms

text: property which makes the command efficacious and which makes _power_. So
title: Elementary Forms

text: everything tends to prove that the first powers of which the human mind
title: Elementary Forms

text: had any idea were those which societies have established in organizing
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves: it is in their image that the powers of the physical world
title: Elementary Forms

text: have been conceived. Also, men have never succeeded in imagining
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves as forces mistress over the bodies in which they reside,
title: Elementary Forms

text: except by introducing concepts taken from social life. In fact, these
title: Elementary Forms

text: must be distinguished from their physical doubles and must be attributed
title: Elementary Forms

text: a dignity superior to that of these latter; in a word, they must think
title: Elementary Forms

text: of themselves as souls. As a matter of fact, men have always given the
title: Elementary Forms

text: form of souls to the forces which they believe that they are. But we
title: Elementary Forms

text: know that the soul is quite another thing from a name given to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: abstract faculty of moving, thinking and feeling; before all, it is a
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious principle, a particular aspect of the collective force. In
title: Elementary Forms

text: fine, a man feels that he has a soul, and consequently a force, because
title: Elementary Forms

text: he is a social being. Though an animal moves its members just as we do,
title: Elementary Forms

text: and though it has the same power as we over its muscles, nothing
title: Elementary Forms

text: authorizes us to suppose that it is conscious of itself as an active and
title: Elementary Forms

text: efficacious cause. This is because it does not have, or, to speak more
title: Elementary Forms

text: exactly, does not attribute to itself a soul. But if it does not
title: Elementary Forms

text: attribute a soul to itself, it is because it does not participate in a
title: Elementary Forms

text: social life comparable to that of men. Among animals, there is nothing
title: Elementary Forms

text: resembling a civilization.[1188]
title: Elementary Forms

text: But the notion of force is not all of the principle of causality. This
title: Elementary Forms

text: consists in a judgment stating that every force develops in a definite
title: Elementary Forms

text: manner, and that the state in which it is at each particular moment of
title: Elementary Forms

text: its existence predetermines the next state. The former is called cause,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the latter, effect, and the causal judgment affirms the existence of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: necessary connection between these two moments for every force. The mind
title: Elementary Forms

text: posits this connection before having any proofs of it, under the empire
title: Elementary Forms

text: of a sort of constraint from which it cannot free itself; it postulates
title: Elementary Forms

text: it, as they say, _a priori_.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Empiricism has never succeeded in accounting for this apriorism and
title: Elementary Forms

text: necessity. Philosophers of this school have never been able to explain
title: Elementary Forms

text: how an association of ideas, reinforced by habit, could produce more
title: Elementary Forms

text: than an expectation or a stronger or weaker predisposition on the part
title: Elementary Forms

text: of ideas to appear in a determined order. But the principle of causality
title: Elementary Forms

text: has quite another character. It is not merely an imminent tendency of
title: Elementary Forms

text: our thought to take certain forms; it is an external norm, superior to
title: Elementary Forms

text: the flow of our representations, which it dominates and rules
title: Elementary Forms

text: imperatively. It is invested with an authority which binds the mind and
title: Elementary Forms

text: surpasses it, which is as much as to say that the mind is not its
title: Elementary Forms

text: artisan. In this connection, it is useless to substitute hereditary
title: Elementary Forms

text: habit for individual habit, for habit does not change its nature by
title: Elementary Forms

text: lasting longer than one man's life; it is merely stronger. An instinct
title: Elementary Forms

text: is not a rule.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The rites which we have been studying allow us to catch a glimpse of
title: Elementary Forms

text: another source of this authority, which, up to the present, has scarcely
title: Elementary Forms

text: been suspected. Let us bear in mind how the law of causality, which the
title: Elementary Forms

text: imitative rites put into practice, was born. Being filled with one
title: Elementary Forms

text: single preoccupation, the group assembles: if the species whose name it
title: Elementary Forms

text: bears does not reproduce, it is a matter of concern to the whole clan.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The common sentiment thus animating all the members is outwardly
title: Elementary Forms

text: expressed by certain gestures, which are always the same in the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: circumstances, and after the ceremony has been performed, it happens,
title: Elementary Forms

text: for the reasons set forth, that the desired result seems obtained. So an
title: Elementary Forms

text: association arises between the idea of this result and that of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: gestures preceding it; and this association does not vary from one
title: Elementary Forms

text: subject to another; it is the same for all the participators in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: rite, since it is the product of a collective experience. However, if no
title: Elementary Forms

text: other factor intervened, it would produce only a collective expectation;
title: Elementary Forms

text: after the imitative gestures had been accomplished, everybody would
title: Elementary Forms

text: await the subsequent appearance of the desired event, with more or less
title: Elementary Forms

text: confidence; an imperative rule of thought could never be established by
title: Elementary Forms

text: this. But since a social interest of the greatest importance is at
title: Elementary Forms

text: stake, society cannot allow things to follow their own course at the
title: Elementary Forms

text: whim of circumstances; it intervenes actively in such a way as to
title: Elementary Forms

text: regulate their march in conformity with its needs. So it demands that
title: Elementary Forms

text: this ceremony, which it cannot do without, be repeated every time that
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is necessary, and consequently, that the movements, a condition of
title: Elementary Forms

text: its success, be executed regularly: it imposes them as an obligation.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Now they imply a certain definite state of mind which, in return,
title: Elementary Forms

text: participates in this same obligatory character. To prescribe that one
title: Elementary Forms

text: must imitate an animal or plant to make them reproduce, is equivalent to
title: Elementary Forms

text: stating it as an axiom which is above all doubt, that like produces
title: Elementary Forms

text: like. Opinion cannot allow men to deny this principle in theory without
title: Elementary Forms

text: also allowing them to violate it in their conduct. So society imposes
title: Elementary Forms

text: it, along with the practices which are derived from it, and thus the
title: Elementary Forms

text: ritual precept is doubled by a logical precept which is only the
title: Elementary Forms

text: intellectual aspect of the former. The authority of each is derived from
title: Elementary Forms

text: the same source: society. The respect which this inspires is
title: Elementary Forms

text: communicated to the ways of thought to which it attaches a value, just
title: Elementary Forms

text: as much as to ways of action. So a man cannot set aside either the ones
title: Elementary Forms

text: or the others without hurling himself against public opinion. This is
title: Elementary Forms

text: why the former require the adherence of the intelligence before
title: Elementary Forms

text: examination, just as the latter require the submission of the will.
title: Elementary Forms

text: From this example, we can show once more how the sociological theory of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the idea of causality, and of the categories in general, sets aside the
title: Elementary Forms

text: classical doctrines on the question, while conciliating them. Together
title: Elementary Forms

text: with apriorism, it maintains the prejudicial and necessary character of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the causal relation; but it does not limit itself to affirming this; it
title: Elementary Forms

text: accounts for it, yet without making it vanish under the pretext of
title: Elementary Forms

text: explaining it, as empiricism does. On the other hand, there is no
title: Elementary Forms

text: question of denying the part due to individual experience. There can be
title: Elementary Forms

text: no doubt that by himself, the individual observes the regular succession
title: Elementary Forms

text: of phenomena and thus acquires a certain _feeling_ of regularity. But
title: Elementary Forms

text: this feeling is not the _category_ of causality. The former is
title: Elementary Forms

text: individual, subjective, incommunicable; we make it ourselves, out of our
title: Elementary Forms

text: own personal observations. The second is the work of the group, and is
title: Elementary Forms

text: given to us ready-made. It is a frame-work in which our empirical
title: Elementary Forms

text: ascertainments arrange themselves and which enables us to think of them,
title: Elementary Forms

text: that is to say, to see them from a point of view which makes it possible
title: Elementary Forms

text: for us to understand one another in regard to them. Of course, if this
title: Elementary Forms

text: frame can be applied to the contents, that shows that it is not out of
title: Elementary Forms

text: relation with the matter which it contains; but it is not to be confused
title: Elementary Forms

text: with this. It surpasses it and dominates it. This is because it is of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: different origin. It is not a mere summary of individual experiences;
title: Elementary Forms

text: before all else, it is made to fulfil the exigencies of life in common.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In fine, the error of empiricism has been to regard the causal bond as
title: Elementary Forms

text: merely an intellectual construction of speculative thought and the
title: Elementary Forms

text: product of a more or less methodical generalization. Now, by itself,
title: Elementary Forms

text: pure speculation can give birth only to provisional, hypothetical and
title: Elementary Forms

text: more or less plausible views, but ones which must always be regarded
title: Elementary Forms

text: with suspicion, for we can never be sure that some new observation in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the future will not invalidate them. An axiom which the mind accepts and
title: Elementary Forms

text: must accept, without control and without reservation, could never come
title: Elementary Forms

text: from this source. Only the necessities of action, and especially of
title: Elementary Forms

text: collective action, can and must express themselves in categorical
title: Elementary Forms

text: formulae, which are peremptory and short, and admit of no contradiction,
title: Elementary Forms

text: for collective movements are possible only on condition of being in
title: Elementary Forms

text: concert and, therefore, regulated and definite. They do not allow of any
title: Elementary Forms

text: fumbling, the source of anarchy; by themselves, they tend towards an
title: Elementary Forms

text: organization which, when once established, imposes itself upon
title: Elementary Forms

text: individuals. And as action cannot go beyond intelligence, it frequently
title: Elementary Forms

text: happens that the latter is drawn into the same way and accepts without
title: Elementary Forms

text: discussion the theoretical postulates demanded by action. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: imperatives of thought are probably only another side of the imperatives
title: Elementary Forms

text: of action.
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is to be borne in mind, moreover, that we have never dreamed of
title: Elementary Forms

text: offering the preceding observations as a complete theory of the concept
title: Elementary Forms

text: of causality. The question is too complex to be resolved thus. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: principle of causality has been understood differently in different
title: Elementary Forms

text: times and places; in a single society, it varies with the social
title: Elementary Forms

text: environment and the kingdoms of nature to which it is applied.[1189] So
title: Elementary Forms

text: it would be impossible to determine with sufficient precision the causes
title: Elementary Forms

text: and conditions upon which it depends, after a consideration of only one
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the forms which it has presented during the course of history. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: views which we have set forth should be regarded as mere indications,
title: Elementary Forms

text: which must be controlled and completed. However, as the causal law which
title: Elementary Forms

text: we have been considering is certainly one of the most primitive which
title: Elementary Forms

text: exists, and as it has played a considerable part in the development of
title: Elementary Forms

text: human thought and industry, it is a privileged experiment, so we may
title: Elementary Forms

text: presume that the remarks of which it has been the occasion may be
title: Elementary Forms

text: generalized to a certain degree.

text: THE POSITIVE CULT--_continued_
title: Elementary Forms

text: III.--_Representative or Commemorative Rites_
title: Elementary Forms

text: The explanation which we have given of the positive rites of which we
title: Elementary Forms

text: have been speaking in the two preceding chapters attributes to them a
title: Elementary Forms

text: significance which is, above all, moral and social. The physical
title: Elementary Forms

text: efficaciousness assigned to them by the believer is the product of an
title: Elementary Forms

text: interpretation which conceals the essential reason for their existence:
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is because they serve to remake individuals and groups morally that
title: Elementary Forms

text: they are believed to have a power over things. But even if this
title: Elementary Forms

text: hypothesis has enabled us to account for the facts, we cannot say that
title: Elementary Forms

text: it has been demonstrated directly; at first view, it even seems to
title: Elementary Forms

text: conciliate itself rather badly with the nature of the ritual mechanisms
title: Elementary Forms

text: which we have analysed. Whether they consist in oblations or imitative
title: Elementary Forms

text: acts, the gestures composing them have purely material ends in view;
title: Elementary Forms

text: they have, or seem to have, the sole object of making the totemic
title: Elementary Forms

text: species reproduce. Under these circumstances, is it not surprising that
title: Elementary Forms

text: their real function should be to serve moral ends?
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is true that their physical function may have been exaggerated by
title: Elementary Forms

text: Spencer and Gillen, even in the cases where it is the most
title: Elementary Forms

text: incontestable. According to these authors, each clan celebrates its
title: Elementary Forms

text: Intichiuma for the purpose of assuring a useful food to the other clans,
title: Elementary Forms

text: and the whole cult consists in a sort of economic co-operation of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: different totemic groups; each works for the others. But according to
title: Elementary Forms

text: Strehlow, this conception of Australian totemism is wholly foreign to
title: Elementary Forms

text: the native mind. "If," he says, "the members of one totemic group set
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves to multiplying the animals or plants of the consecrated
title: Elementary Forms

text: species, and seem to work for their companions of other totems, we must
title: Elementary Forms

text: be careful not to regard this collaboration as the fundamental principle
title: Elementary Forms

text: of Arunta or Loritja totemism. The blacks themselves have never told me
title: Elementary Forms

text: that this was the object of their ceremonies. Of course, when I
title: Elementary Forms

text: suggested and explained the idea to them, they understood it and
title: Elementary Forms

text: acquiesced. But I should not be blamed for having some distrust of
title: Elementary Forms

text: replies gained in this fashion." Strehlow also remarks that this way of
title: Elementary Forms

text: interpreting the rite is contradicted by the fact that the totemic
title: Elementary Forms

text: animals and plants are not all edible or useful; some are good for
title: Elementary Forms

text: nothing; some are even dangerous. So the ceremonies which concern them
title: Elementary Forms

text: could not have any such end in view.[1190] "When some one asks the
title: Elementary Forms

text: natives what the determining reason for these ceremonies is," concludes
title: Elementary Forms

text: our author, "they are unanimous in replying: 'It is because our
title: Elementary Forms

text: ancestors arranged things thus. This is why we do thus and not
title: Elementary Forms

text: differently.'"[1191] But in saying that the rite is observed because it
title: Elementary Forms

text: comes from the ancestors, it is admitted that its authority is
title: Elementary Forms

text: confounded with the authority of tradition, which is a social affair of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the first order. Men celebrate it to remain faithful to the past, to
title: Elementary Forms

text: keep for the group its normal physiognomy, and not because of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: physical effects which it may produce. Thus, the way in which the
title: Elementary Forms

text: believers themselves explain them show the profound reasons upon which
title: Elementary Forms

text: the rites proceed.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But there are cases when this aspect of the ceremonies is immediately
title: Elementary Forms

text: apparent.
title: Elementary Forms

text: I
title: Elementary Forms

text: These may be observed the best among the Warramunga.[1192]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Among this people, each clan is thought to be descended from a single
title: Elementary Forms

text: ancestor who, after having been born in some determined spot, passed his
title: Elementary Forms

text: terrestrial existence in travelling over the country in every direction.
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is he who, in the course of his voyages, gave to the land the form
title: Elementary Forms

text: which it now has; it is he who made the mountains and plains, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: water-holes and streams, etc. At the same time, he sowed upon his route
title: Elementary Forms

text: living germs which were disengaged from his body and, after many
title: Elementary Forms

text: successive reincarnations, became the actual members of the clan. Now
title: Elementary Forms

text: the ceremony of the Warramunga which corresponds exactly to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Intichiuma of the Arunta, has the object of commemorating and
title: Elementary Forms

text: representing the mythical history of this ancestor. There is no
title: Elementary Forms

text: question of oblations or, except in one single case,[1193] of imitative
title: Elementary Forms

text: practices. The rite consists solely in recollecting the past and, in a
title: Elementary Forms
