text: way, making it present by means of a veritable dramatic representation.
title: Elementary Forms

text: This word is the more exact because in this ceremony, the officiant is
title: Elementary Forms

text: in no way considered an incarnation of the ancestor, whom he represents;
title: Elementary Forms

text: he is an actor playing a role.
title: Elementary Forms

text: As an example, let us describe the Intichiuma of the Black Snake, as
title: Elementary Forms

text: Spencer and Gillen observed it.[1194]
title: Elementary Forms

text: An initial ceremony does not seem to refer to the past; at least the
title: Elementary Forms

text: description of it which is given us gives no authorization for
title: Elementary Forms

text: interpreting it in this sense. It consists in running and leaping on the
title: Elementary Forms

text: part of two officiants,[1195] who are decorated with designs
title: Elementary Forms

text: representing the black snake. When they finally fall exhausted on the
title: Elementary Forms

text: ground, the assistants gently pass their hands over the emblematic
title: Elementary Forms

text: designs with which the backs of the two actors are covered. They say
title: Elementary Forms

text: that this act pleases the black snake. It is only afterwards that the
title: Elementary Forms

text: series of commemorative ceremonies commences.
title: Elementary Forms

text: They put into action the mythical history of the ancestor Thalaualla,
title: Elementary Forms

text: from the moment he emerged from the ground up to his definite return
title: Elementary Forms

text: thither. They follow him through all his voyages. The myth says that in
title: Elementary Forms

text: each of the localities where he sojourned, he celebrated totemic
title: Elementary Forms

text: ceremonies; they now repeat them in the same order in which they are
title: Elementary Forms

text: supposed to have taken place originally. The movement which is acted the
title: Elementary Forms

text: most frequently consists in twisting the entire body about rhythmically
title: Elementary Forms

text: and violently; this is because the ancestor did the same thing to make
title: Elementary Forms

text: the germs of life which were in him come out. The actors have their
title: Elementary Forms

text: bodies covered with down, which is detached and flies away during these
title: Elementary Forms

text: movements; this is a way of representing the flight of these mystic
title: Elementary Forms

text: germs and their dispersion into space.
title: Elementary Forms

text: It will be remembered that among the Arunta, the scene of the ceremony
title: Elementary Forms

text: is determined by the ritual: it is the spot where the sacred rocks,
title: Elementary Forms

text: trees and water-holes are found, and the worshippers must go there to
title: Elementary Forms

text: celebrate the cult. Among the Warramunga, on the contrary, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: ceremonial ground is arbitrarily chosen according to convenience. It is
title: Elementary Forms

text: a conventional scene. However, the original scene of the events whose
title: Elementary Forms

text: reproduction constitutes the theme of the rite is itself represented by
title: Elementary Forms

text: means of designs. Sometimes these designs are made upon the very bodies
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the actors. For example, a small circle coloured red, painted on the
title: Elementary Forms

text: back and stomach, represents a water-hole.[1196] In other cases, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: image is traced on the soil. Upon a ground previously soaked and covered
title: Elementary Forms

text: with red ochre, they draw curved lines, made up of a series of white
title: Elementary Forms

text: points, which symbolize a stream or a mountain. This is a beginning of
title: Elementary Forms

text: decoration.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In addition to the properly religious ceremonies which the ancestor is
title: Elementary Forms

text: believed to have celebrated long ago, they also represent simple
title: Elementary Forms

text: episodes of his career, either epic or comic. Thus, at a given moment,
title: Elementary Forms

text: while three actors are on the scene, occupied in an important rite,
title: Elementary Forms

text: another one hides behind a bunch of trees situated at some distance. A
title: Elementary Forms

text: packet of down is attached about his neck which represents a _wallaby_.
title: Elementary Forms

text: As soon as the principal ceremony is finished, an old man traces a line
title: Elementary Forms

text: upon the ground which is directed towards the spot where the fourth
title: Elementary Forms

text: actor is hidden. The others march behind him, with eyes lowered and
title: Elementary Forms

text: fixed upon this line, as though following a trail. When they discover
title: Elementary Forms

text: the man, they assume a stupefied air and one of them beats him with a
title: Elementary Forms

text: club. This represents an incident in the life of the great black snake.
title: Elementary Forms

text: One day, his son went hunting, caught a _wallaby_ and ate it without
title: Elementary Forms

text: giving his father any. The latter followed his tracks, surprised him and
title: Elementary Forms

text: forced him to disgorge; it is to this that the beating at the end of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: representation alludes.[1197]
title: Elementary Forms

text: We shall not relate here all the mythical events which are represented
title: Elementary Forms

text: successively. The preceding examples are sufficient to show the
title: Elementary Forms

text: character of these ceremonies: they are dramas, but of a particular
title: Elementary Forms

text: variety; they act, or at least they are believed to act, upon the course
title: Elementary Forms

text: of nature. When the commemoration of Thalaualla is terminated, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Warramunga are convinced that black snakes cannot fail to increase and
title: Elementary Forms

text: multiply. So these dramas are rites, and even rites which, by the nature
title: Elementary Forms

text: of their efficacy, are comparable on every point to those which
title: Elementary Forms

text: constitute the Intichiuma of the Arunta.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Therefore each is able to clarify the other. It is even more legitimate
title: Elementary Forms

text: to compare them than if there were no break of continuity between them.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Not only is the end pursued identical in each case, but the most
title: Elementary Forms

text: characteristic part of the Warramunga ritual is found in germ in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: other. In fact, the Intichiuma, as the Arunta generally perform it,
title: Elementary Forms

text: contains within it a sort of implicit commemoration. The places where it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is celebrated are necessarily those which the ancestor made illustrious.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The roads over which the worshippers pass in the course of their pious
title: Elementary Forms

text: pilgrimages are those which the heroes of the Alcheringa traversed; the
title: Elementary Forms

text: places where they stop to proceed with the rites are those where their
title: Elementary Forms

text: fathers sojourned themselves, where they vanished into the ground, etc.
title: Elementary Forms

text: So everything brings their memory to the minds of the assistants.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Moreover, to the manual rites they frequently add hymns relating the
title: Elementary Forms

text: exploits of their ancestors.[1198] If, instead of being told, these
title: Elementary Forms

text: stories are acted, and if, in this new form, they develop in such a way
title: Elementary Forms

text: as to become an essential part of the ceremony, then we have the
title: Elementary Forms

text: ceremony of the Warramunga. But even more can be said, for on one side,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the Arunta Intichiuma is already a sort of representation. The officiant
title: Elementary Forms

text: is one with the ancestor from whom he is descended and whom he
title: Elementary Forms

text: reincarnates.[1199] The gestures he makes are those which this ancestor
title: Elementary Forms

text: made in the same circumstances. Speaking exactly, of course he does not
title: Elementary Forms

text: play the part of the ancestral personage as an actor might do it; he is
title: Elementary Forms

text: this personage himself. But it is true, notwithstanding, that, in one
title: Elementary Forms

text: sense, it is the hero who occupies the scene. In order to accentuate the
title: Elementary Forms

text: representative character of the rite, it would be sufficient for the
title: Elementary Forms

text: duality of the ancestor and the officiant to become more marked; this is
title: Elementary Forms

text: just what happens among the Warramunga.[1200] Even among the Arunta, at
title: Elementary Forms

text: least one Intichiuma is mentioned in which certain persons are charged
title: Elementary Forms

text: with representing ancestors with whom they have no relationship of
title: Elementary Forms

text: mythical descent, and in which there is consequently a proper dramatic
title: Elementary Forms

text: representation: this is the Intichiuma of the Emu.[1201] It seems that
title: Elementary Forms

text: in this case, also, contrarily to the general rule among this people,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the theatre of the ceremony is artificially arranged.[1202]
title: Elementary Forms

text: It does not follow from the fact that, in spite of the differences
title: Elementary Forms

text: separating them, these two varieties of ceremony thus have an air of
title: Elementary Forms

text: kinship, as it were, that there is a definite relation of succession
title: Elementary Forms

text: between them, and that one is a transformation of the other. It may very
title: Elementary Forms

text: well be that the resemblances pointed out come from the fact that the
title: Elementary Forms

text: two sprang from the same source, that is, from the same original
title: Elementary Forms

text: ceremony, of which they are only divergent forms: we shall even see that
title: Elementary Forms

text: this hypothesis is the most probable one. But even without taking sides
title: Elementary Forms

text: on this question, what has already been said is enough to show that they
title: Elementary Forms

text: are rites of the same nature. So we may be allowed to compare them, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: to use the one to enable us to understand the other better.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Now the peculiar thing in the ceremonies of the Warramunga of which we
title: Elementary Forms

text: have been speaking, is that not a gesture is made whose object is to aid
title: Elementary Forms

text: or to provoke directly the increase of the totemic species.[1203] If we
title: Elementary Forms

text: analyse the movements made, as well as the words spoken, we generally
title: Elementary Forms

text: find nothing which betrays any intention of this sort. Everything is in
title: Elementary Forms

text: representations whose only object can be to render the mythical past of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the clan present to the mind. But the mythology of a group is the system
title: Elementary Forms

text: of beliefs common to this group. The traditions whose memory it
title: Elementary Forms

text: perpetuates express the way in which society represents man and the
title: Elementary Forms

text: world; it is a moral system and a cosmology as well as a history. So the
title: Elementary Forms

text: rite serves and can serve only to sustain the vitality of these beliefs,
title: Elementary Forms

text: to keep them from being effaced from memory and, in sum, to revivify the
title: Elementary Forms

text: most essential elements of the collective consciousness. Through it, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: group periodically renews the sentiment which it has of itself and of
title: Elementary Forms

text: its unity; at the same time, individuals are strengthened in their
title: Elementary Forms

text: social natures. The glorious souvenirs which are made to live again
title: Elementary Forms

text: before their eyes, and with which they feel that they have a kinship,
title: Elementary Forms

text: give them a feeling of strength and confidence: a man is surer of his
title: Elementary Forms

text: faith when he sees to how distant a past it goes back and what great
title: Elementary Forms

text: things it has inspired. This is the characteristic of the ceremony which
title: Elementary Forms

text: makes it instructive. Its tendency is to act entirely upon the mind and
title: Elementary Forms

text: upon it alone. So if men believe nevertheless that it acts upon things
title: Elementary Forms

text: and that it assures the prosperity of the species, this can be only as a
title: Elementary Forms

text: reaction to the moral action which it exercises and which is obviously
title: Elementary Forms

text: the only one which is real. Thus the hypothesis which we have proposed
title: Elementary Forms

text: is verified by a significant experiment, and this verification is the
title: Elementary Forms

text: more convincing because, as we have shown, there is no difference in
title: Elementary Forms

text: nature between the ritual system of the Warramunga and that of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Arunta. The one only makes more evident what we had already conjectured
title: Elementary Forms

text: from the other.
title: Elementary Forms

text: II
title: Elementary Forms

text: But there are ceremonies in which this representative and idealistic
title: Elementary Forms

text: character is still more accentuated.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In those of which we have been speaking, the dramatic representation did
title: Elementary Forms

text: not exist for itself; it was only a means having a very material end in
title: Elementary Forms

text: view, namely, the reproduction of the totemic species. But there are
title: Elementary Forms

text: others which do not differ materially from the preceding ones, but from
title: Elementary Forms

text: which, nevertheless, all preoccupations of this sort are absent. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: past is here represented for the mere sake of representing it and fixing
title: Elementary Forms

text: it more firmly in the mind, while no determined action over nature is
title: Elementary Forms

text: expected of the rite. At least, the physical effects sometimes imputed
title: Elementary Forms

text: to it are wholly secondary and have no relation with the liturgical
title: Elementary Forms

text: importance attributed to it.
title: Elementary Forms

text: This is the case notably with the ceremonies which the Warramunga
title: Elementary Forms

text: celebrate in honour of the snake Wollunqua.[1204]
title: Elementary Forms

text: As we have already said, the Wollunqua is a totem of a very especial
title: Elementary Forms

text: sort. It is not an animal or vegetable species, but a unique being:
title: Elementary Forms

text: there is only one Wollunqua. Moreover, this being is purely mythical.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The natives represent it as a colossal snake whose length is such that
title: Elementary Forms

text: when it rises on its tail its head is lost in the clouds. It resides,
title: Elementary Forms

text: they believe, in a water-hole called Thapauerlu, which is hidden in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: bottom of a solitary valley. But if it differs in certain ways from the
title: Elementary Forms

text: ordinary totems, it has all their distinctive characteristics
title: Elementary Forms

text: nevertheless. It serves as the collective name and emblem of a whole
title: Elementary Forms

text: group of individuals who regard it as their common ancestor, while the
title: Elementary Forms

text: relations which they sustain with this mythical beast are identical with
title: Elementary Forms

text: those which the members of other totems believe that they sustain with
title: Elementary Forms

text: the founders of their respective clans. In the Alcheringa[1205] times,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the Wollunqua traversed the country in every direction. In the different
title: Elementary Forms

text: localities where it stopped, it scattered "spirit-children," the
title: Elementary Forms

text: spiritual principles which still serve as the souls of the living of
title: Elementary Forms

text: to-day. The Wollunqua is even considered as a sort of pre-eminent totem.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The Warramunga are divided into two phratries, called Uluuru and
title: Elementary Forms

text: Kingilli. Nearly all the totems of the former are snakes of different
title: Elementary Forms

text: kinds. Now they are all believed to be descended from the Wollunqua;
title: Elementary Forms

text: they say that it was their grandfather.[1206] From this, we can catch a
title: Elementary Forms

text: glimpse of how the myth of the Wollunqua probably arose. In order to
title: Elementary Forms

text: explain the presence of so many similar totems in the same phratry, they
title: Elementary Forms

text: imagined that all were derived from one and the same totem; it was
title: Elementary Forms

text: necessary to give it a gigantic form so that in its very appearance it
title: Elementary Forms

text: might conform to the considerable role assigned to it in the history of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the tribe.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Now the Wollunqua is the object of ceremonies not differing in nature
title: Elementary Forms

text: from those which we have already studied: they are representations in
title: Elementary Forms

text: which are portrayed the principal events of its fabulous life. They show
title: Elementary Forms

text: it coming out of the ground and passing from one locality to another;
title: Elementary Forms

text: they represent different episodes in its voyages, etc. Spencer and
title: Elementary Forms

text: Gillen assisted at fifteen ceremonies of this sort which took place
title: Elementary Forms

text: between the 27th of July and the 23rd of August, all being linked
title: Elementary Forms

text: together in a determined order, in such a way as to form a veritable
title: Elementary Forms

text: cycle.[1207] In the details of the rites constituting it, this long
title: Elementary Forms

text: celebration is therefore indistinct from the ordinary Intichiuma of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Warramunga, as is recognized by the authors who have described it to
title: Elementary Forms

text: us.[1208] But, on the other hand, it is an Intichiuma which could not
title: Elementary Forms

text: have the object of assuring the fecundity of an animal or vegetable
title: Elementary Forms

text: species, for the Wollunqua is a species all by itself and does not
title: Elementary Forms

text: reproduce. It exists, and the natives do not seem to feel that it has
title: Elementary Forms

text: need of a cult to preserve it in its existence. These ceremonies not
title: Elementary Forms

text: only seem to lack the efficacy of the classic Intichiuma, but it even
title: Elementary Forms

text: seems as though they have no material efficacy of any sort. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: Wollunqua is not a divinity set over a special order of natural
title: Elementary Forms

text: phenomena, so they expect no definite service from him in exchange for
title: Elementary Forms

text: the cult. Of course they say that if the ritual prescriptions are badly
title: Elementary Forms

text: observed, the Wollunqua becomes angry, leaves his retreat and comes to
title: Elementary Forms

text: punish his worshippers for their negligence; and inversely, when
title: Elementary Forms

text: everything passes regularly, they are led to believe that they will be
title: Elementary Forms

text: fortunate and that some happy event will take place; but it is quite
title: Elementary Forms

text: evident that these possible sanctions are an after-thought to explain
title: Elementary Forms

text: the rite. After the ceremony had been established, it seemed natural
title: Elementary Forms

text: that it should serve for something, and that the omission of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: prescribed observances should therefore expose one to grave dangers. But
title: Elementary Forms

text: it was not established to forestall these mythical dangers or to assure
title: Elementary Forms

text: particular advantages. The natives, moreover, have only the very haziest
title: Elementary Forms

text: ideas of them. When the whole ceremony is completed, the old men
title: Elementary Forms

text: announce that if the Wollunqua is pleased, he will send rain. But it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: not to have rain that they go through with the celebration.[1209] They
title: Elementary Forms

text: celebrate it because their ancestors did, because they are attached to
title: Elementary Forms

text: it as to a highly respected tradition and because they leave it with a
title: Elementary Forms

text: feeling of moral well-being. Other considerations have only a
title: Elementary Forms

text: complimentary part; they may serve to strengthen the worshippers in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: attitude prescribed by the rite, but they are not the reason for the
title: Elementary Forms

text: existence of this attitude.
title: Elementary Forms

text: So we have here a whole group of ceremonies whose sole purpose is to
title: Elementary Forms

text: awaken certain ideas and sentiments, to attach the present to the past
title: Elementary Forms

text: or the individual to the group. Not only are they unable to serve useful
title: Elementary Forms

text: ends, but the worshippers themselves demand none. This is still another
title: Elementary Forms

text: proof that the psychical state in which the assembled group happens to
title: Elementary Forms

text: be constitutes the only solid and stable basis of what we may call the
title: Elementary Forms

text: ritual mentality. The beliefs which attribute such or such a physical
title: Elementary Forms

text: efficaciousness to the rites are wholly accessory and contingent, for
title: Elementary Forms

text: they may be lacking without causing any alteration in the essentials of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the rite. Thus the ceremonies of the Wollunqua show even better than the
title: Elementary Forms

text: preceding ones the fundamental function of the positive cult.
title: Elementary Forms

text: If we have insisted especially upon these solemnities, it is because of
title: Elementary Forms

text: their exceptional importance. But there are others with exactly the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: character. Thus, the Warramunga have a totem "of the laughing boy."
title: Elementary Forms

text: Spencer and Gillen say that the clan bearing this name has the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: organization as the other totemic groups. Like them, it has its sacred
title: Elementary Forms

text: places (_mungai_) where the founder-ancestor celebrated ceremonies in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the fabulous times, and where he left behind him spirit-children who
title: Elementary Forms

text: became the men of the clan; the rites connected with this totem are
title: Elementary Forms

text: indistinguishable from those relating to the animal or vegetable
title: Elementary Forms

text: totems.[1210] Yet it is evident that they could not have any physical
title: Elementary Forms

text: efficaciousness. They consist in a series of four ceremonies which
title: Elementary Forms

text: repeat one another more or less, but which are intended only to amuse
title: Elementary Forms

text: and to provoke laughter by laughter, in fine, to maintain the gaiety and
title: Elementary Forms

text: good-humour which the group has as its speciality.[1211]
title: Elementary Forms

text: We find more than one totem among the Arunta themselves which has no
title: Elementary Forms

text: other Intichiuma. We have seen that among this people, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: irregularities and depressions of the land, which mark the places where
title: Elementary Forms

text: some ancestor sojourned, sometimes serve as totems.[1212] Ceremonies are
title: Elementary Forms

text: attached to these totems which are manifestly incapable of physical
title: Elementary Forms

text: effects of any sort. They can consist only in representations whose
title: Elementary Forms

text: object is to commemorate the past, and they can aim at no end beyond
title: Elementary Forms

text: this commemoration.[1213]
title: Elementary Forms

text: While they enable us to understand the nature of the cult better, these
title: Elementary Forms

text: ritual representations also put into evidence an important element of
title: Elementary Forms

text: religion: this is the recreative and esthetic element.
title: Elementary Forms

text: We have already had occasion to show that they are closely akin to
title: Elementary Forms

text: dramatic representations.[1214] This kinship appears with still greater
title: Elementary Forms

text: clarity in the latter ceremonies of which we have spoken. Not only do
title: Elementary Forms

text: they employ the same processes as the real drama, but they also pursue
title: Elementary Forms

text: an end of the same sort: being foreign to all utilitarian ends, they
title: Elementary Forms

text: make men forget the real world and transport them into another where
title: Elementary Forms

text: their imagination is more at ease; they distract. They sometimes even go
title: Elementary Forms

text: so far as to have the outward appearance of a recreation: the assistants
title: Elementary Forms

text: may be seen laughing and amusing themselves openly.[1215]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Representative rites and collective recreations are even so close to one
title: Elementary Forms

text: another that men pass from one sort to the other without any break of
title: Elementary Forms

text: continuity. The characteristic feature of the properly religious
title: Elementary Forms

text: ceremonies is that they must be celebrated on a consecrated ground, from
title: Elementary Forms

text: which women and non-initiated persons are excluded.[1216] But there are
title: Elementary Forms

text: others in which this religious character is somewhat effaced, though it
title: Elementary Forms

text: has not disappeared completely. They take place outside the ceremonial
title: Elementary Forms

text: ground, which proves that they are already laicized to a certain degree;
title: Elementary Forms

text: but profane persons, women and children, are not yet admitted to them.
title: Elementary Forms

text: So they are on the boundary between the two domains. They generally deal
title: Elementary Forms

text: with legendary personages, but ones having no regular place in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: frame-work of the totemic religion. They are spirits, more generally
title: Elementary Forms

text: malevolent ones, having relations with the magicians rather than the
title: Elementary Forms

text: ordinary believers, and sorts of bugbears, in whom men do not believe
title: Elementary Forms

text: with the same degree of seriousness and firmness of conviction as in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: proper totemic beings and things.[1217] As the bonds by which the events
title: Elementary Forms

text: and personages represented are attached to the history of the tribe
title: Elementary Forms

text: relax, these take on a proportionately more unreal appearance, while the
title: Elementary Forms

text: corresponding ceremonies change in nature. Thus men enter into the
title: Elementary Forms

text: domain of pure fancy, and pass from the commemorative rite to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: ordinary corrobbori, a simple public merry-making, which has nothing
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious about it and in which all may take part indifferently. Perhaps
title: Elementary Forms

text: some of these representations, whose sole object now is to distract, are
title: Elementary Forms

text: ancient rites, whose character has been changed. In fact, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: distinction between these two sorts of ceremonies is so variable that it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is impossible to state with precision to which of the two kinds they
title: Elementary Forms

text: belong.[1218]
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is a well-known fact that games and the principal forms of art seem
title: Elementary Forms

text: to have been born of religion and that for a long time they retained a
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious character.[1219] We now see what the reasons for this are: it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is because the cult, though aimed primarily at other ends, has also been
title: Elementary Forms

text: a sort of recreation for men. Religion has not played this role by
title: Elementary Forms

text: hazard or owing to a happy chance, but through a necessity of its
title: Elementary Forms

text: nature. Though, as we have established, religious thought is something
title: Elementary Forms

text: very different from a system of fictions, still the realities to which
title: Elementary Forms

text: it corresponds express themselves religiously only when religion
title: Elementary Forms

text: transfigures them. Between society as it is objectively and the sacred
title: Elementary Forms

text: things which express it symbolically, the distance is considerable. It
title: Elementary Forms

text: has been necessary that the impressions really felt by men, which served
title: Elementary Forms

text: as the original matter of this construction, should be interpreted,
title: Elementary Forms

text: elaborated and transformed until they became unrecognizable. So the
title: Elementary Forms

text: world of religious things is a partially imaginary world, though only in
title: Elementary Forms

text: its outward form, and one which therefore lends itself more readily to
title: Elementary Forms

text: the free creations of the mind. Also, since the intellectual forces
title: Elementary Forms

text: which serve to make it are intense and tumultuous, the unique task of
title: Elementary Forms

text: expressing the real with the aid of appropriate symbols is not enough to
title: Elementary Forms

text: occupy them. A surplus generally remains available which seeks to employ
title: Elementary Forms

text: itself in supplementary and superfluous works of luxury, that is to say,
title: Elementary Forms

text: in works of art. There are practices as well as beliefs of this sort.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The state of effervescence in which the assembled worshippers find
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves must be translated outwardly by exuberant movements which are
title: Elementary Forms

text: not easily subjected to too carefully defined ends. In part, they escape
title: Elementary Forms

text: aimlessly, they spread themselves for the mere pleasure of so doing, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: they take delight in all sorts of games. Besides, in so far as the
title: Elementary Forms

text: beings to whom the cult is addressed are imaginary, they are not able to
title: Elementary Forms

text: contain and regulate this exuberance; the pressure of tangible and
title: Elementary Forms

text: resisting realities is required to confine activities to exact and
title: Elementary Forms

text: economical forms. Therefore one exposes oneself to grave
title: Elementary Forms

text: misunderstandings if, in explaining rites, he believes that each gesture
title: Elementary Forms

text: has a precise object and a definite reason for its existence. There are
title: Elementary Forms

text: some which serve nothing; they merely answer the need felt by
title: Elementary Forms

text: worshippers for action, motion, gesticulation. They are to be seen
title: Elementary Forms

text: jumping, whirling, dancing, crying and singing, though it may not always
title: Elementary Forms

text: be possible to give a meaning to all this agitation.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Therefore religion would not be itself if it did not give some place to
title: Elementary Forms

text: the free combinations of thought and activity, to play, to art, to all
title: Elementary Forms

text: that recreates the spirit that has been fatigued by the too great
title: Elementary Forms

text: slavishness of daily work: the very same causes which called it into
title: Elementary Forms

text: existence make it a necessity. Art is not merely an external ornament
title: Elementary Forms

text: with which the cult has adorned itself in order to dissimulate certain
title: Elementary Forms

text: of its features which may be too austere and too rude; but rather, in
title: Elementary Forms

text: itself, the cult is something aesthetic. Owing to the well-known
title: Elementary Forms

text: connection which mythology has with poetry, some have wished to exclude
title: Elementary Forms

text: the former from religion;[1220] the truth is that there is a poetry
title: Elementary Forms

text: inherent in all religion. The representative rites which have just been
title: Elementary Forms

text: studied make this aspect of the religious life manifest; but there are
title: Elementary Forms

text: scarcely any rites which do not present it to some degree.
title: Elementary Forms

text: One would certainly commit the gravest error if he saw only this one
title: Elementary Forms

text: aspect of religion, or if he even exaggerated its importance. When a
title: Elementary Forms

text: rite serves only to distract, it is no longer a rite. The moral forces
title: Elementary Forms

text: expressed by religious symbols are real forces with which we must reckon
title: Elementary Forms

text: and with which we cannot do what we will. Even when the cult aims at
title: Elementary Forms

text: producing no physical effects, but limits itself to acting on the mind,
title: Elementary Forms

text: its action is in quite a different way from that of a pure work of art.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The representations which it seeks to awaken and maintain in our minds
title: Elementary Forms

text: are not vain images which correspond to nothing in reality, and which we
title: Elementary Forms

text: call up aimlessly for the mere satisfaction of seeing them appear and
title: Elementary Forms

text: combine before our eyes. They are as necessary for the well working of
title: Elementary Forms

text: our moral life as our food is for the maintenance of our physical life,
title: Elementary Forms

text: for it is through them that the group affirms and maintains itself, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: we know the point to which this is indispensable for the individual. So
title: Elementary Forms

text: a rite is something different from a game; it is a part of the serious
title: Elementary Forms

text: life. But if its unreal and imaginary element is not essential,
title: Elementary Forms

text: nevertheless it plays a part which is by no means negligible. It has its
title: Elementary Forms

text: share in the feeling of comfort which the worshipper draws from the rite
title: Elementary Forms

text: performed; for recreation is one of the forms of the moral remaking
title: Elementary Forms

text: which is the principal object of the positive rite. After we have
title: Elementary Forms

text: acquitted ourselves of our ritual duties, we enter into the profane life
title: Elementary Forms

text: with increased courage and ardour, not only because we come into
title: Elementary Forms

text: relations with a superior source of energy, but also because our forces
title: Elementary Forms

text: have been reinvigorated by living, for a few moments, in a life that is
title: Elementary Forms

text: less strained, and freer and easier. Hence religion acquires a charm
title: Elementary Forms

text: which is not among the slightest of its attractions.
title: Elementary Forms

text: This is why the very idea of a religious ceremony of some importance
title: Elementary Forms

text: awakens the idea of a feast. Inversely, every feast, even when it has
title: Elementary Forms

text: purely lay origins, has certain characteristics of the religious
title: Elementary Forms

text: ceremony, for in every case its effect is to bring men together, to put
title: Elementary Forms

text: the masses into movement and thus to excite a state of effervescence,
title: Elementary Forms

text: and sometimes even of delirium, which is not without a certain kinship
title: Elementary Forms

text: with the religious state. A man is carried outside himself and diverted
title: Elementary Forms

text: from his ordinary occupation and preoccupations. Thus the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: manifestations are to be observed in each case: cries, songs, music,
title: Elementary Forms

text: violent movements, dances, the search for exciteants which raise the
title: Elementary Forms

text: vital level, etc. It has frequently been remarked that popular feasts
title: Elementary Forms

text: lead to excesses, and cause men to lose sight of the distinction
title: Elementary Forms

text: separating the licit from the illicit;[1221] there are also religious
title: Elementary Forms

text: ceremonies which make it almost necessary to violate the rules which are
title: Elementary Forms

text: ordinarily the most respected.[1222] Of course this does not mean that
title: Elementary Forms

text: there is no way to distinguish these two forms of public activity. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: simple merry-making, the profane corrobbori, has no serious object,
title: Elementary Forms

text: while, as a whole, a ritual ceremony always has an important end. Still
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is to be remembered that there is perhaps no merry-making in which
title: Elementary Forms

text: the serious life does not have some echo. The difference consists rather
title: Elementary Forms

text: in the unequal proportions in which the two elements are combined.
title: Elementary Forms

text: III
title: Elementary Forms

text: A more general fact confirms the views which precede.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In their first book, Spencer and Gillen presented the Intichiuma as a
title: Elementary Forms

text: perfectly definite ritual entity: they spoke of it as though it were an
title: Elementary Forms

text: operation destined exclusively for the assurance of the reproduction of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the totemic species, and it seemed as though it ought to lose all
title: Elementary Forms

text: meaning, if this unique function were set aside. But in their _Northern
title: Elementary Forms

text: Tribes of Central Australia_, the same authors use a different language,
title: Elementary Forms

text: though perhaps without noticing it. They recognize that these same
title: Elementary Forms

text: ceremonies may take place either in the regular Intichiuma or in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: initiation rites.[1223] So they serve equally in the making of animals
title: Elementary Forms

text: or plants of the totemic species, or in conferring upon novices the
title: Elementary Forms

text: qualities necessary to make them regular members of the men's
title: Elementary Forms

text: society.[1224] From this point of view, the Intichiuma takes on a new
title: Elementary Forms

text: aspect. It is no longer a distinct ritual mechanism, resting upon
title: Elementary Forms

text: principles of its own, but a particular application of more general
title: Elementary Forms

text: ceremonies which may be utilized for very different ends. For this
title: Elementary Forms

text: reason, in their later work, before speaking of the Intichiuma and the
title: Elementary Forms

text: initiation they consecrate a special chapter to the totemic ceremonies
title: Elementary Forms

text: in general, making abstraction of the diverse forms which they may take,
title: Elementary Forms

text: according to the ends for which they are employed.[1225]
title: Elementary Forms

text: This fundamental indetermination of the totemic ceremonies was only
title: Elementary Forms

text: indicated by Spencer and Gillen, and rather indirectly at that; but it
title: Elementary Forms

text: has now been confirmed by Strehlow in more explicit terms. "When they
title: Elementary Forms

text: lead the young novices through the different feasts of the initiation,"
title: Elementary Forms

text: he says, "they perform before them a series of ceremonies which, though
title: Elementary Forms

text: reproducing, even in their most characteristic details, the rites of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: regular cult (viz. _the rites which Spencer and Gillen call the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Intichiuma_), do not have, nevertheless, the end of multiplying the
title: Elementary Forms

text: corresponding totem and causing it to prosper."[1226] It is the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: ceremony which serves in the two cases; the name alone is not the same.
title: Elementary Forms

text: When its special object is the reproduction of the species, they call it
title: Elementary Forms

text: _mbatjalkatiuma_ and it is only when it is a part of the process of
title: Elementary Forms

text: initiation that they give it the name Intichiuma.[1227]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Moreover, these two sorts of ceremonies are distinguished from one
title: Elementary Forms

text: another among the Arunta by certain secondary characteristics. Though
title: Elementary Forms

text: the structure of the rite is the same in both cases, still we know that
title: Elementary Forms

text: the effusions of blood and, more generally, the oblations characteristic
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the Arunta Intichiuma are not found in the initiation ceremonies.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Moreover, among this same people, the Intichiuma takes place at
title: Elementary Forms

text: a spot regularly fixed by tradition, to which men must make a
title: Elementary Forms

text: pilgrimage, while the scene of the initiation ceremonies is purely
title: Elementary Forms

text: conventional.[1228] But when the Intichiuma consists in a simple
title: Elementary Forms

text: dramatic representation, as is the case among the Warramunga, the lack
title: Elementary Forms

text: of distinction between the two rites is complete. In the one as in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: other, they commemorate the past, they put the myth into action, they
title: Elementary Forms

text: play--and one cannot play in two materially different ways. So,
title: Elementary Forms

text: according to the circumstances, one and the same ceremony serves two
title: Elementary Forms

text: distinct functions.[1229]
title: Elementary Forms

text: It may even lend itself to other uses. We know that as blood is a sacred
title: Elementary Forms

text: thing, women must not see it flow. Yet it happens sometimes that a
title: Elementary Forms

text: quarrel breaks out in their presence and ends in the shedding of blood.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Thus an infraction of the ritual is committed. Among the Arunta, the man
title: Elementary Forms

text: whose blood flowed first must, to atone for this fault, "celebrate a
title: Elementary Forms

text: ceremony connected with the totem either of his father or of his
title: Elementary Forms

text: mother";[1230] this ceremony has a special name, _Alua uparilima_, which
title: Elementary Forms

text: means the washing away of blood. But in itself, it does not differ from
title: Elementary Forms

text: those celebrated at the time of the initiation or in the Intichiuma: it
title: Elementary Forms

text: represents an event of ancestral history. So it may serve equally to
title: Elementary Forms

text: initiate, to act upon the totemic species or to expiate a sacrilege. We
title: Elementary Forms

text: shall see that a totemic ceremony may also take the place of a funeral
title: Elementary Forms

text: MM. Hubert and Mauss have already pointed out a functional ambiguity of
title: Elementary Forms

text: this same sort in the case of sacrifice, and more especially, in that of
title: Elementary Forms

text: Hindu sacrifice.[1232] They have shown how the sacrifice of communion,
title: Elementary Forms

text: that of expiation, that of a vow and that of a contract are only
title: Elementary Forms

text: variations of one and the same mechanism. We now see that the fact is
title: Elementary Forms

text: much more primitive, and in no way limited to the institution of
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacrifice. Perhaps no rite exists which does not present a similar
title: Elementary Forms

text: indetermination. The mass serves for marriages as for burials; it
title: Elementary Forms

text: redeems the faults of the dead and wins the favours of the deity for the
title: Elementary Forms

text: living, etc. Fasting is an expiation and a penance; but it is also a
title: Elementary Forms

text: preparation for communion; it even confers positive virtues. This
title: Elementary Forms

text: ambiguity shows that the real function of a rite does not consist in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: particular and definite effects which it seems to aim at and by which it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is ordinarily characterized, but rather in a general action which,
title: Elementary Forms

text: though always and everywhere the same, is nevertheless capable of taking
title: Elementary Forms

text: on different forms according to the circumstances. Now this is just what
title: Elementary Forms

text: is demanded by the theory which we have proposed. If the real function
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the cult is to awaken within the worshippers a certain state of soul,
title: Elementary Forms

text: composed of moral force and confidence, and if the various effects
title: Elementary Forms

text: imputed to the rites are due only to a secondary and variable
title: Elementary Forms

text: determination of this fundamental state, it is not surprising if a
title: Elementary Forms

text: single rite, while keeping the same composition and structure, seems to
title: Elementary Forms

text: produce various effects. For the mental dispositions, the excitation of
title: Elementary Forms

text: which is its permanent function, remain the same in every case; they
title: Elementary Forms

text: depend upon the fact that the group is assembled, and not upon the
title: Elementary Forms

text: special reasons for which it is assembled. But, on the other hand, they
title: Elementary Forms

text: are interpreted differently according to the circumstances to which they
title: Elementary Forms

text: are applied. Is it a physical result which they wish to obtain? The
title: Elementary Forms

text: confidence they feel convinces them that the desired result is or will
title: Elementary Forms

text: be obtained by the means employed. Has some one committed a fault for
title: Elementary Forms

text: which he wishes to atone? The same state of moral assurance will lead
title: Elementary Forms

text: him to attribute expiatory virtues to these same ritual gestures. Thus,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the apparent efficacy will seem to change while the real efficacy
title: Elementary Forms

text: remains invariable, and the rite will seem to fulfil various functions
title: Elementary Forms

text: though in fact it has only one, which is always the same.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Inversely, just as a single rite may serve many ends, so many rites may
title: Elementary Forms

text: produce the same effect and mutually replace one another. To assure the
title: Elementary Forms

text: reproduction of the totemic species, one may have recourse equally to
title: Elementary Forms

text: oblations, to imitative practices or to commemorative representations.
title: Elementary Forms

text: This aptitude of rites for substituting themselves for one another
title: Elementary Forms

text: proves once more both their plasticity and the extreme generality of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: useful action which they exercise. The essential thing is that men are
title: Elementary Forms

text: assembled, that sentiments are felt in common and expressed in common
title: Elementary Forms

text: acts; but the particular nature of these sentiments and acts is
title: Elementary Forms

text: something relatively secondary and contingent. To become conscious of
title: Elementary Forms

text: itself, the group does not need to perform certain acts in preference to
title: Elementary Forms

text: all others. The necessary thing is that it partakes of the same thought
title: Elementary Forms

text: and the same action; the visible forms in which this communion takes
title: Elementary Forms

text: place matter but little. Of course, these external forms do not come by
title: Elementary Forms

text: chance; they have their reasons; but these reasons do not touch the
title: Elementary Forms

text: essential part of the cult.
title: Elementary Forms

text: So everything leads us back to this same idea: before all, rites are
title: Elementary Forms

text: means by which the social group reaffirms itself periodically. From
title: Elementary Forms

text: this, we may be able to reconstruct hypothetically the way in which the
title: Elementary Forms

text: totemic cult should have arisen originally. Men who feel themselves
title: Elementary Forms

text: united, partially by bonds of blood, but still more by a community of
title: Elementary Forms

text: interest and tradition, assemble and become conscious of their moral
title: Elementary Forms

text: unity. For the reasons which we have set forth, they are led to
title: Elementary Forms

text: represent this unity in the form of a very special kind of
title: Elementary Forms

text: consubstantiality: they think of themselves as all participating in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: nature of some determined animal. Under these circumstances, there is
title: Elementary Forms

text: only one way for them to affirm their collective existence: this is to
title: Elementary Forms

text: affirm that they are like the animals of this species, and to do so not
title: Elementary Forms

text: only in the silence of their own thoughts, but also by material acts.
title: Elementary Forms

text: These are the acts which make up the cult, and they obviously can
title: Elementary Forms

text: consist only in movements by which the man imitates the animal with
title: Elementary Forms

text: which he identifies himself. When understood thus, the imitative rites
title: Elementary Forms

text: appear as the first form of the cult. It will be thought that this is
title: Elementary Forms

text: attributing a very considerable historical importance to practices
title: Elementary Forms

text: which, at first view, give the effect of childish games. But, as we have
title: Elementary Forms

text: shown, these naive and awkward gestures and these crude processes of
title: Elementary Forms

text: representation translate and maintain a sentiment of pride, confidence
title: Elementary Forms

text: and veneration wholly comparable to that expressed by the worshippers in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the most idealistic religions when, being assembled, they proclaim
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves the children of the almighty God. For in the one case as in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the other, this sentiment is made up of the same impressions of security
title: Elementary Forms

text: and respect which are awakened in individual consciousnesses by this
title: Elementary Forms

text: great moral force which dominates them and sustains them, and which is
title: Elementary Forms

text: the collective force.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The other rites which we have been studying are probably only variations
title: Elementary Forms

text: of this essential rite. When the close union of the animal and men has
title: Elementary Forms

text: once been admitted, men feel acutely the necessity of assuring the
title: Elementary Forms

text: regular reproduction of the principal object of the cult. These
title: Elementary Forms

text: imitative practices, which probably had only a moral end at first, thus
title: Elementary Forms

text: became subordinated to utilitarian and material ends, and they were
title: Elementary Forms

text: thought of as means of producing the desired result. But
title: Elementary Forms

text: proportionately as, through the development of mythology, the ancestral
title: Elementary Forms

text: hero, who was at first confused with the totemic animal, distinguished
title: Elementary Forms

text: himself more and more, and became a more personal figure, the imitation
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the ancestor was substituted for the imitation of the animal, or took
title: Elementary Forms

text: a place beside it, and then representative ceremonies replaced or
title: Elementary Forms

text: completed the imitative rites. Finally, to be surer of attaining the end
title: Elementary Forms

text: they sought, men felt the need of putting into action all the means at
title: Elementary Forms

text: their disposal. Close at hand they had reserves of living forces
title: Elementary Forms

text: accumulated in the sacred rocks, so they utilized them; since the blood
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the men was of the same nature as that of the animal, they used it
title: Elementary Forms

text: for the same purpose and shed it. Inversely, owing to this same kinship,
title: Elementary Forms

text: men used the flesh of the animal to remake their own substance. Hence
title: Elementary Forms

text: came the rites of oblation and communion. But, at bottom, all these
title: Elementary Forms

text: different practices are only variations of one and the same theme:
title: Elementary Forms

text: everywhere their basis is the same state of mind, interpreted
title: Elementary Forms

text: differently according to the situations, the moments of history and the
title: Elementary Forms

text: dispositions of the worshippers.
title: Elementary Forms

text: CHAPTER V
title: Elementary Forms

text: PIACULAR RITES AND THE AMBIGUITY OF THE NOTION OF SACREDNESS
title: Elementary Forms

text: Howsoever much they may differ from one another in the nature of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: gestures they imply, the positive rites which we have been passing under
title: Elementary Forms

text: review have one common characteristic: they are all performed in a state
title: Elementary Forms

text: of confidence, joy and even enthusiasm. Though the expectation of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: future and contingent event is not without a certain uncertainty, still
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is normal that the rain fall when the season for it comes, and that
title: Elementary Forms

text: the animal and vegetable species reproduce regularly. Oft-repeated
title: Elementary Forms

text: experiences have shown that the rites generally do produce the effects
title: Elementary Forms

text: which are expected of them and which are the reason for their existence.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Men celebrate them with confidence, joyfully anticipating the happy
title: Elementary Forms

text: event which they prepare and announce. Whatever movements men perform
title: Elementary Forms

text: participate in this same state of mind: of course, they are marked with
title: Elementary Forms

text: the gravity which a religious solemnity always supposes, but this
title: Elementary Forms

text: gravity excludes neither animation nor joy.
title: Elementary Forms

text: These are all joyful feasts. But there are sad celebrations as well,
title: Elementary Forms

text: whose object is either to meet a calamity, or else merely to commemorate
title: Elementary Forms

text: and deplore it. These rites have a special aspect, which we are going to
title: Elementary Forms

text: attempt to characterize and explain. It is the more necessary to study
title: Elementary Forms

text: them by themselves since they are going to reveal a new aspect of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious life to us.
title: Elementary Forms

text: We propose to call the ceremonies of this sort piacular. The term
title: Elementary Forms

text: _piaculum_ has the advantage that while it suggests the idea of
title: Elementary Forms

text: expiation, it also has a much more extended signification. Every
title: Elementary Forms

text: misfortune, everything of evil omen, everything that inspires sentiments
title: Elementary Forms

text: of sorrow or fear necessitates a _piaculum_ and is therefore called
title: Elementary Forms

text: piacular.[1233] So this word seems to be very well adapted for
title: Elementary Forms

text: designating the rites which are celebrated by those in a state of
title: Elementary Forms

text: uneasiness or sadness.
title: Elementary Forms

text: I
title: Elementary Forms

text: Mourning offers us a first and important example of piacular rites.
title: Elementary Forms

text: However, a distinction is necessary between the different rites which go
title: Elementary Forms

text: to make up mourning. Some consist in mere abstentions: it is forbidden
title: Elementary Forms

text: to pronounce the name of the dead,[1234] or to remain near the place
title: Elementary Forms

text: where the death occurred;[1235] relatives, especially the female ones,
title: Elementary Forms

text: must abstain from all communication with strangers;[1236] the ordinary
title: Elementary Forms

text: occupations of life are suspended, just as in feast-time,[1237] etc. All
title: Elementary Forms

text: these practices belong to the negative cult and are explained like the
title: Elementary Forms

text: other rites of the same sort, so they do not concern us at present. They
title: Elementary Forms

text: are due to the fact that the dead man is a sacred being. Consequently,
title: Elementary Forms

text: everything which is or has been connected with him is, by contagion, in
title: Elementary Forms

text: a religious state excluding all contact with things from profane life.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But mourning is not made up entirely of interdicts which have to be
title: Elementary Forms

text: observed. Positive acts are also demanded, in which the relatives are
title: Elementary Forms

text: both the actors and those acted upon.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Very frequently these rites commence as soon as the death appears
title: Elementary Forms

text: imminent. Here is a scene which Spencer and Gillen witnessed among the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Warramunga. A totemic ceremony had just been celebrated and the company
title: Elementary Forms

text: of actors and spectators was leaving the consecrated ground when a
title: Elementary Forms

text: piercing cry suddenly came from the camp: a man was dying there. At
title: Elementary Forms

text: once, the whole company commenced to run as fast as they could, while
title: Elementary Forms

text: most of them commenced to howl. "Between us and the camp," say these
title: Elementary Forms

text: observers, "lay a deep creek, and on the bank of this, some of the men,
title: Elementary Forms

text: scattered about here and there, sat down, bending their heads forwards
title: Elementary Forms

text: between their knees, while they wept and moaned. Crossing the creek we
title: Elementary Forms

text: found that, as usual, the men's camp had been pulled to pieces. Some of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the women, who had come from every direction, were lying prostrate on
title: Elementary Forms

text: the body, while others were standing or kneeling around, digging the
title: Elementary Forms

text: sharp ends of yam-sticks into the crown of their heads, from which the
title: Elementary Forms

text: blood streamed down over their faces, while all the time they kept up a
title: Elementary Forms

text: loud, continuous wail. Many of the men, rushing up to the spot, threw
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves upon the body, from which the women arose when the men
title: Elementary Forms

text: approached, until in a few minutes we could see nothing but a struggling
title: Elementary Forms

text: mass of bodies all mixed up together. To one side, three men of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Thapungarti class, who still wore their ceremonial decorations, sat down
title: Elementary Forms

text: wailing loudly, with their backs towards the dying man, and in a minute
title: Elementary Forms

text: or two another man of the same class rushed on to the ground yelling and
title: Elementary Forms

text: brandishing a stone knife. Reaching the camp, he suddenly gashed both
title: Elementary Forms

text: thighs deeply, cutting right across the muscles, and, unable to stand,
title: Elementary Forms

text: fell down into the middle of the group, from which he was dragged out
title: Elementary Forms

text: after a time by three or four female relatives, who immediately applied
title: Elementary Forms

text: their mouths to the gaping wounds while he lay exhausted on the ground."
title: Elementary Forms

text: The man did not actually die until late in the evening. As soon as he
title: Elementary Forms

text: had given up his last breath, the same scene was re-enacted, only this
title: Elementary Forms

text: time the wailing was still louder, and men and women, seized by a
title: Elementary Forms

text: veritable frenzy, were rushing about cutting themselves with knives and
title: Elementary Forms

text: sharp-pointed sticks, the women battering one another's heads with
title: Elementary Forms

text: fighting clubs, no one attempting to ward off either cuts or blows.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Finally, after about an hour, a torchlight procession started off across
title: Elementary Forms

text: the plain, to a tree in whose branches the body was left.[1238]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Howsoever great the violence of these manifestations may be, they are
title: Elementary Forms

text: strictly regulated by etiquette. The individuals who make bloody
title: Elementary Forms

text: incisions in themselves are designated by usage: they must have certain
title: Elementary Forms

text: relations of kinship with the dead man. Thus, in the case observed by
title: Elementary Forms

text: Spencer and Gillen among the Warramunga, those who slashed their thighs
title: Elementary Forms

text: were the maternal grandfather of the deceased, his maternal uncle, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: the maternal uncle and brother of his wife.[1239] Others must cut their
title: Elementary Forms

text: whiskers and hair, and then smear their scalps with pipe-clay. Women
title: Elementary Forms

text: have particularly severe obligations. They must cut their hair and cover
title: Elementary Forms

text: the whole body with pipe-clay; in addition to this, a strict silence is
title: Elementary Forms

text: imposed upon them during the whole period of mourning, which may last as
title: Elementary Forms

text: long as two years. It is not rare among the Warramunga that, as a result
title: Elementary Forms

text: of this interdiction, all the women of a camp are condemned to the most
title: Elementary Forms

text: absolute silence. This becomes so habitual to them that even after the
title: Elementary Forms

text: expiration of the period of mourning, they voluntarily renounce all
title: Elementary Forms

text: spoken language and prefer to communicate with gestures--in which, by
title: Elementary Forms

text: the way, they acquire a remarkable ability. Spencer and Gillen knew one
title: Elementary Forms

text: old woman who had not spoken for over twenty-four years.[1240]
title: Elementary Forms

text: The ceremony which we have described opens a long series of rites which
title: Elementary Forms

text: succeed one another for weeks and even for months. During the days which
title: Elementary Forms

text: follow, they are renewed in various forms. Groups of men and women sit
title: Elementary Forms

text: on the ground, weeping and lamenting, and kissing each other at certain
title: Elementary Forms

text: moments. These ritual kissings are repeated frequently during the period
title: Elementary Forms

text: of mourning. It seems as though men felt a need of coming close together
title: Elementary Forms

text: and communicating most closely; they are to be seen holding to each
title: Elementary Forms

text: other and wound together so much as to make one single mass, from which
title: Elementary Forms

text: loud groans escape.[1241] Meanwhile, the women commence to lacerate
title: Elementary Forms

text: their heads again, and, in order to intensify the wounds they make, they
title: Elementary Forms

text: even go so far as to burn them with the points of fiery sticks.[1242]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Practices of this sort are general in all Australia. The funeral rites,
title: Elementary Forms

text: that is, the ritual cares given to the corpse, the way in which it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: buried, etc., change with different tribes,[1243] and in a single tribe
title: Elementary Forms

text: they vary with the age, sex and social importance of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: individual.[1244] But the real ceremonies of mourning repeat the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: theme everywhere; the variations are only in the details. Everywhere we
title: Elementary Forms

text: find this same silence interrupted by groans,[1245] the same obligation
title: Elementary Forms

text: of cutting the hair and beard,[1246] or of covering one's head with
title: Elementary Forms

text: pipe-clay or cinders, or perhaps even with excrements;[1247] everywhere,
title: Elementary Forms

text: finally, we find this same frenzy for beating one's self, lacerating
title: Elementary Forms

text: one's self and burning one's self. In central Victoria, "when death
title: Elementary Forms

text: visits a tribe there is great weeping and lamentation amongst the women,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the elder portion of whom lacerate their temples with their nails. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: parents of the deceased lacerate themselves fearfully, especially if it
title: Elementary Forms

text: be an only son whose loss they deplore. The father beats and cuts his
title: Elementary Forms

text: head with a tomahawk until he utters bitter groans, the mother sits by
title: Elementary Forms

text: the fire and burns her breasts and abdomen with a small fire-stick.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Sometimes the burns thus inflicted are so severe as to cause
title: Elementary Forms

text: According to an account of Brough Smyth, here is what happens in one of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the southern tribes of the same state. As the body is lowered into the
title: Elementary Forms

text: grave, "the widow begins her sad ceremonies. She cuts off her hair above
title: Elementary Forms

text: her forehead, and becoming frantic, seizes fire-sticks, and burns her
title: Elementary Forms

text: breasts, arms, legs and thighs. She seems to delight in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: self-inflicted torture. It would be rash and vain to interrupt her. When
title: Elementary Forms

text: exhausted, and when she can hardly walk, she yet endeavours to kick the
title: Elementary Forms

text: embers of the fire, and to throw them about. Sitting down, she takes the
title: Elementary Forms

text: ashes into her hands, rubs them into her wounds, and then scratches her
title: Elementary Forms

text: face (the only part not touched by the fire-sticks) until the blood
title: Elementary Forms

text: mingles with the ashes, which partly hide her cruel wounds. In this
title: Elementary Forms

text: plight, scratching her face continually, she utters howls and
title: Elementary Forms

text: lamentations."[1249]
title: Elementary Forms

text: The description which Howitt gives of the rites of mourning among the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Kurnai is remarkably similar to these others. After the body has been
title: Elementary Forms

text: wrapped up in opossum skins and put in a shroud of bark, a hut is built
title: Elementary Forms

text: in which the relatives assemble. "There they lay lamenting their loss,
title: Elementary Forms

text: saying, for instance, 'Why did you leave us?' Now and then their grief
title: Elementary Forms

text: would be intensified by some one, for instance, the wife, uttering an
title: Elementary Forms

text: ear-piercing wail, 'My spouse is dead,' or another would say, 'My child
title: Elementary Forms

text: is dead.' All the others would then join in with the proper term of
title: Elementary Forms

text: relationship, and they would gash themselves with sharp stones and
title: Elementary Forms

text: tomahawks until their heads and bodies streamed with blood. This bitter
title: Elementary Forms

text: wailing and weeping continued all night."[1250]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Sadness is not the only sentiment expressed during these ceremonies; a
title: Elementary Forms

text: sort of anger is generally mixed with it. The relatives feel a need of
title: Elementary Forms

text: avenging the death in some way or other. They are to be seen throwing
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves upon one another and trying to wound each other. Sometimes
title: Elementary Forms

text: the attack is real; sometimes it is only pretended.[1251] There are even
title: Elementary Forms

text: cases when these peculiar combats are organized. Among the Kaitish, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: hair of the deceased passes by right to his son-in-law. But he, in
title: Elementary Forms

text: return, must go, in company with some of his relatives and friends, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: provoke a quarrel with one of his tribal brothers, that is, with a man
title: Elementary Forms

text: belonging to the same matrimonial class as himself and one who might
title: Elementary Forms

text: therefore have married the daughter of the dead man. This provocation
title: Elementary Forms

text: cannot be refused and the two combatants inflict serious wounds upon
title: Elementary Forms

text: each other's shoulders and thighs. When the duel is terminated, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: challenger passes on to his adversary the hair which he had temporarily
title: Elementary Forms

text: inherited. This latter then provokes and fights with another of his
title: Elementary Forms

text: tribal brothers, to whom the precious relic is next transmitted, but
title: Elementary Forms

text: only provisionally; thus it passes from hand to hand and circulates from
title: Elementary Forms

text: group to group.[1252] Also, something of these same sentiments enters
title: Elementary Forms

text: into that sort of rage with which each relative beats himself, burns
title: Elementary Forms

text: himself or slashes himself: a sorrow which reaches such a paroxysm is
title: Elementary Forms

text: not without a certain amount of anger. One cannot fail to be struck by
title: Elementary Forms

text: the resemblances which these practices present to those of the vendetta.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Both proceed from the same principle that death demands the shedding of
title: Elementary Forms

text: blood. The only difference is that in one case the victims are the
title: Elementary Forms

text: relatives, while in the other they are strangers. We do not have to
title: Elementary Forms

text: treat especially of the vendetta, which belongs rather to the study of
title: Elementary Forms

text: juridic institutions; but it should be pointed out, nevertheless, how it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is connected with the rites of mourning, whose end it announces.[1253]
title: Elementary Forms

text: In certain societies, the mourning is terminated by a ceremony whose
title: Elementary Forms

text: effervescence reaches or surpasses that produced by the inaugural
title: Elementary Forms

text: ceremonies. Among the Arunta, this closing rite is called _Urpmilchima_.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Spencer and Gillen assisted at two of these rites. One was celebrated in
title: Elementary Forms

text: honour of a man, the other of a woman. Here is the description they give
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the latter.[1254]
title: Elementary Forms

text: They commence by making some ornaments of a special sort, called
title: Elementary Forms

text: _Chimurilia_ by the men and _Aramurilia_ by the women. With a kind of
title: Elementary Forms

text: resin, they fixed small animal bones, which had previously been gathered
title: Elementary Forms

text: and set aside, to locks of hair furnished by the relatives of the dead
title: Elementary Forms

text: woman. These are then attached to one of the head-bands which women
title: Elementary Forms

text: ordinarily wear and the feathers of black cockatoos and parrots are
title: Elementary Forms

text: added to it. When these preparations are completed, the women assemble
title: Elementary Forms

text: in their camp. They paint their bodies different colours, according to
title: Elementary Forms

text: their degree of kinship with the deceased. After being embraced by one
title: Elementary Forms

text: another for some ten minutes, while uttering uninterrupted groans, they
title: Elementary Forms

text: set out for the tomb. At a certain distance, they meet a brother by
title: Elementary Forms

text: blood of the dead woman, who is accompanied by some of his tribal
title: Elementary Forms

text: brothers. Everybody sits down on the ground, and the lamentations
title: Elementary Forms

text: recommence. A _pitchi_[1255] containing the Chimurilia is then presented
title: Elementary Forms

text: to the elder brother, who presses it against his stomach; they say that
title: Elementary Forms

text: this is a way of lessening his sorrow. They take out one of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Chimurilia and the dead woman's mother puts it on her head for a little
title: Elementary Forms

text: while; then it is put back into the _pitchi_, which each of the other
title: Elementary Forms

text: men presses against his breast, in his turn. Finally, the brother puts
title: Elementary Forms

text: the Chimurilia on the heads of two elder sisters and they set out again
title: Elementary Forms

text: for the tomb. On the way, the mother throws herself on the ground
title: Elementary Forms

text: several times, and tries to slash her head with a pointed stick. Every
title: Elementary Forms

text: time, the other women pick her up, and seem to take care that she does
title: Elementary Forms

text: not hurt herself too much. When they arrive at the tomb, she throws
title: Elementary Forms

text: herself on the knoll and endeavours to destroy it with her hands, while
title: Elementary Forms

text: the other women literally dance upon her. The tribal mothers and aunts
title: Elementary Forms

text: (sisters of the dead woman's father) follow her example; they also throw
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves on the ground, and mutually beat and tear each other; finally
title: Elementary Forms

text: their bodies are all streaming with blood. After a while, they are
title: Elementary Forms

text: dragged aside. The elder sisters then make a hole in the earth of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: tomb, in which they place the Chimurilia, which had previously been torn
title: Elementary Forms

text: to pieces. Once again the tribal mothers throw themselves on the ground
title: Elementary Forms

text: and slash each other's heads. At this moment, "the weeping and wailing
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the women who were standing round seemed to drive them almost
title: Elementary Forms

text: frenzied, and the blood, streaming down their bodies over the white
title: Elementary Forms

text: pipe-clay, gave them a ghastly appearance. At last only the old mother
title: Elementary Forms

text: was left crouching alone, utterly exhausted and moaning weakly on the
title: Elementary Forms

text: grave."[1256] Then the others raised her up and rubbed off the pipe-clay
title: Elementary Forms

text: with which she was covered; this was the end of the ceremony and of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: mourning.[1256]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Among the Warramunga, the final rite presents some rather particular
title: Elementary Forms

text: characteristics. There seems to be no shedding of blood here, but the
title: Elementary Forms

text: collective effervescence is translated in another manner.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Among his people, before the body is definitely interred, it is exposed
title: Elementary Forms

text: upon a platform placed in the branches of a tree; it is left there to
title: Elementary Forms

text: decompose slowly, until nothing remains but the bones. Then these are
title: Elementary Forms

text: gathered together and, with the exception of the humerus, they are
title: Elementary Forms

text: placed inside an ant-hill. The humerus is wrapped up in a bark box,
title: Elementary Forms

text: which is decorated in different manners. The box is then brought to
title: Elementary Forms

text: camp, amid the cries and groans of the women. During the following days,
title: Elementary Forms

text: they celebrate a series of totemic rites, concerning the totem of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: deceased and the mythical history of the ancestors from whom the clan is
title: Elementary Forms

text: descended. When all these ceremonies have been terminated, they proceed
title: Elementary Forms

text: to the closing rite.
title: Elementary Forms

text: A trench one foot deep and fifteen feet long is dug in the field of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: ceremony. A design representing the totem of the deceased and certain
title: Elementary Forms

text: spots where the ancestor stopped is made on the ground a little distance
title: Elementary Forms

text: from it. Near this design, a little ditch is dug in the ground. Ten
title: Elementary Forms

text: decorated men then advance, one behind another, and with their hands
title: Elementary Forms

text: crossed behind their heads and their legs wide apart they stand
title: Elementary Forms

text: astraddle the trench. At a given signal, the women run from the camp in
title: Elementary Forms

text: a profound silence; when they are near, they form in Indian file, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: last one holding in her hands the box containing the humerus. Then,
title: Elementary Forms

text: after throwing themselves on the ground, they advance on their hands and
title: Elementary Forms

text: knees, and pass all along the trench, between the legs of the men. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: scene shows a state of great sexual excitement. As soon as the last
title: Elementary Forms

text: woman has passed, they take the box from her, and take it to the ditch,
title: Elementary Forms
