text: near which is an old man; he breaks the bone with a sharp blow, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: hurriedly buries it in the debris. During this time, the women have
title: Elementary Forms

text: remained at a distance, with their backs turned upon the scene, for they
title: Elementary Forms

text: must not see it. But when they hear the blow of the axe, they flee,
title: Elementary Forms

text: uttering cries and groans. The rite is accomplished; the mourning is
title: Elementary Forms

text: terminated.[1257]
title: Elementary Forms

text: II
title: Elementary Forms

text: These rites belong to a very different type from those which we have
title: Elementary Forms

text: studied hitherto. We do not mean to say that important resemblances
title: Elementary Forms

text: cannot be found between the two, which we shall have to note; but the
title: Elementary Forms

text: differences are more apparent. Instead of happy dances, songs and
title: Elementary Forms

text: dramatic representations which distract and relax the mind, they are
title: Elementary Forms

text: tears and groans and, in a word, the most varied manifestations of
title: Elementary Forms

text: agonized sorrow and a sort of mutual pity, which occupy the whole scene.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Of course the shedding of blood also takes place in the Intichiuma, but
title: Elementary Forms

text: this is an oblation made with a movement of pious enthusiasm. Even
title: Elementary Forms

text: though the motions may be the same, the sentiments expressed are
title: Elementary Forms

text: different and even opposed. Likewise, the ascetic rites certainly imply
title: Elementary Forms

text: privations, abstinences and mutilations, but ones which must be borne
title: Elementary Forms

text: with an impassive firmness and serenity. Here, on the contrary,
title: Elementary Forms

text: dejection, cries and tears are the rule. The ascetic tortures himself in
title: Elementary Forms

text: order to prove, in his own eyes and those of his fellows, that he is
title: Elementary Forms

text: above suffering. During mourning, men injure themselves to prove that
title: Elementary Forms

text: they suffer. By all these signs, the characteristic traits of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: piacular rites are to be recognized.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But how are they to be explained?
title: Elementary Forms

text: One initial fact is constant: mourning is not the spontaneous expression
title: Elementary Forms

text: of individual emotions.[1258] If the relations weep, lament, mutilate
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves, it is not because they feel themselves personally affected
title: Elementary Forms

text: by the death of their kinsman. Of course, it may be that in certain
title: Elementary Forms

text: particular cases, the chagrin expressed is really felt.[1259] But it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: more generally the case that there is no connection between the
title: Elementary Forms

text: sentiments felt and the gestures made by the actors in the rite.[1260]
title: Elementary Forms

text: If, at the very moment when the weepers seem the most overcome by their
title: Elementary Forms

text: grief, some one speaks to them of some temporal interest, it frequently
title: Elementary Forms

text: happens that they change their features and tone at once, take on a
title: Elementary Forms

text: laughing air and converse in the gayest fashion imaginable.[1261]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Mourning is not a natural movement of private feelings wounded by a
title: Elementary Forms

text: cruel loss; it is a duty imposed by the group. One weeps, not simply
title: Elementary Forms

text: because he is sad, but because he is forced to weep. It is a ritual
title: Elementary Forms

text: attitude which he is forced to adopt out of respect for custom, but
title: Elementary Forms

text: which is, in a large measure, independent of his affective state.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Moreover, this obligation is sanctioned by mythical or social penalties.
title: Elementary Forms

text: They believe, for example, that if a relative does not mourn as is
title: Elementary Forms

text: fitting, then the soul of the departed follows upon his steps and kills
title: Elementary Forms

text: him.[1262] In other cases, society does not leave it to the religious
title: Elementary Forms

text: forces to punish the negligent; it intervenes itself, and reprimands the
title: Elementary Forms

text: ritual faults. If a son-in-law does not render to his father-in-law the
title: Elementary Forms

text: funeral attentions which are due him, and if he does not make the
title: Elementary Forms

text: prescribed incisions, then his tribal fathers-in-law take his wife away
title: Elementary Forms

text: from him and give him another.[1263] Therefore, in order to square
title: Elementary Forms

text: himself with usage, a man sometimes forces tears to flow by artificial
title: Elementary Forms

text: means.[1264]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Whence comes this obligation?
title: Elementary Forms

text: Ethnographers and sociologists are generally satisfied with the reply
title: Elementary Forms

text: which the natives themselves give to this question. They say that the
title: Elementary Forms

text: dead wish to be lamented, that by refusing them the tribute of sorrow
title: Elementary Forms

text: which is their right, men offend them, and that the only way of
title: Elementary Forms

text: preventing their anger is to conform to their will.[1265]
title: Elementary Forms

text: But this mythological interpretation merely modifies the terms of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: problem, without resolving it; it is still necessary to explain why the
title: Elementary Forms

text: dead imperatively reclaim the mourning. It may be said that it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: natural for men to wish to be mourned and regretted. But in making this
title: Elementary Forms

text: sentiment explain the complex system of rites which make up mourning, we
title: Elementary Forms

text: attribute to the Australian affective exigencies of which the civilized
title: Elementary Forms

text: man himself does not always give evidence. Let us admit--as is not
title: Elementary Forms

text: evident _a priori_--that the idea of not being forgotten too readily is
title: Elementary Forms

text: pleasing to a man who thinks of the future. It is still to be
title: Elementary Forms

text: established that it has ever had enough importance in the minds of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: living for one to attribute to the dead a state of mind proceeding
title: Elementary Forms

text: almost entirely from this preoccupation. It seems especially improbable
title: Elementary Forms

text: that such a sentiment could obsess and impassion men who are seldom
title: Elementary Forms

text: accustomed to thinking beyond the present moment. So far is it from
title: Elementary Forms

text: being a fact that the desire to survive in the memory of those who are
title: Elementary Forms

text: still alive is to be regarded as the origin of mourning, that we may
title: Elementary Forms

text: even ask ourselves whether it was not rather mourning itself which, when
title: Elementary Forms

text: once established, aroused the idea of and the taste for posthumous
title: Elementary Forms

text: regrets.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The classic interpretation appears still more unsustainable when we know
title: Elementary Forms

text: what the primitive mourning consists in. It is not made up merely of
title: Elementary Forms

text: pious regrets accorded to him who no longer is, but also of severe
title: Elementary Forms

text: abstinences and cruel sacrifices. The rite does not merely demand that
title: Elementary Forms

text: one think of the deceased in a melancholy way, but also that he beat
title: Elementary Forms

text: himself, bruise himself, lacerate himself and burn himself. We have even
title: Elementary Forms

text: seen that persons in mourning sometimes torture themselves to such a
title: Elementary Forms

text: degree that they do not survive their wounds. What reason has the dead
title: Elementary Forms

text: man for imposing such torments upon them? Such a cruelty on his part
title: Elementary Forms

text: denotes something more than a desire not to be forgotten. If he is to
title: Elementary Forms

text: find pleasure in seeing his own suffer, it is necessary that he hate
title: Elementary Forms

text: them, that he be thirsty for their blood. This ferocity would
title: Elementary Forms

text: undoubtedly appear natural to those for whom every spirit is necessarily
title: Elementary Forms

text: an evil and redoubted power. But we know that there are spirits of every
title: Elementary Forms

text: sort; how does it happen that the soul of the dead man is necessarily an
title: Elementary Forms

text: evil spirit? As long as the man is alive, he loves his relatives and
title: Elementary Forms

text: exchanges services with them. Is it not strange that as soon as it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: freed from his body, his soul should instantly lay aside its former
title: Elementary Forms

text: sentiments and become an evil and tormenting genius? It is a general
title: Elementary Forms

text: rule that the dead man retains the personality of the living, and that
title: Elementary Forms

text: he has the same character, the same hates and the same affections. So
title: Elementary Forms

text: this metamorphosis is not easily understandable by itself. It is true
title: Elementary Forms

text: that the natives admit it implicitly when they explain the rite by the
title: Elementary Forms

text: exigencies of the dead man, but the question now before us is to know
title: Elementary Forms

text: whence this conception came. Far from being capable of being regarded
title: Elementary Forms

text: as a truism, it is as obscure as the rite itself, and consequently
title: Elementary Forms

text: cannot account for it.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Finally, even if we had found the reasons for this surprising
title: Elementary Forms

text: transformation, we would still have to explain why it is only temporary.
title: Elementary Forms

text: For it does not last beyond the period of mourning; after the rites have
title: Elementary Forms

text: once been accomplished, the dead man becomes what he was when alive, an
title: Elementary Forms

text: affectionate and devoted relation. He puts the new powers which he
title: Elementary Forms

text: receives from his new condition at the service of his friends.[1266]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Thenceforth, he is regarded as a good genius, always ready to aid those
title: Elementary Forms

text: whom he was recently tormenting. Whence come these successive transfers?
title: Elementary Forms

text: If the evil sentiments attributed to the soul come solely from the fact
title: Elementary Forms

text: that it is no longer in life, they should remain invariable, and if the
title: Elementary Forms

text: mourning is due to this, it should be interminable.
title: Elementary Forms

text: These mythical explanations express the idea which the native has of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: rite, and not the rite itself. So we may set them aside and face the
title: Elementary Forms

text: reality which they translate, though disfiguring it in doing so. If
title: Elementary Forms

text: mourning differs from the other forms of the positive cult, there is one
title: Elementary Forms

text: feature in which it resembles them: it, too, is made up out of
title: Elementary Forms

text: collective ceremonies which produce a state of effervescence among those
title: Elementary Forms

text: who take part in them. The sentiments aroused are different; but the
title: Elementary Forms

text: arousal is the same. So it is presumable that the explanation of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: joyous rites is capable of being applied to the sad rites, on condition
title: Elementary Forms

text: that the terms be transposed.
title: Elementary Forms

text: When some one dies, the family group to which he belongs feels itself
title: Elementary Forms

text: lessened and, to react against this loss, it assembles. A common
title: Elementary Forms

text: misfortune has the same effects as the approach of a happy event:
title: Elementary Forms

text: collective sentiments are renewed which then lead men to seek one
title: Elementary Forms

text: another and to assemble together. We have even seen this need for
title: Elementary Forms

text: concentration affirm itself with a particular energy: they embrace one
title: Elementary Forms

text: another, put their arms round one another, and press as close as
title: Elementary Forms

text: possible to one another. But the affective state in which the group then
title: Elementary Forms

text: happens to be only reflects the circumstances through which it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: passing. Not only do the relatives, who are effected the most directly,
title: Elementary Forms

text: bring their own personal sorrow to the assembly, but the society
title: Elementary Forms

text: exercises a moral pressure over its members, to put their sentiments in
title: Elementary Forms

text: harmony with the situation. To allow them to remain indifferent to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: blow which has fallen upon it and diminished it, would be equivalent to
title: Elementary Forms

text: proclaiming that it does not hold the place in their hearts which is due
title: Elementary Forms

text: it; it would be denying itself. A family which allows one of its
title: Elementary Forms

text: members to die without being wept for shows by that very fact that it
title: Elementary Forms

text: lacks moral unity and cohesion: it abdicates; it renounces its
title: Elementary Forms

text: existence. An individual in his turn, if he is strongly attached to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: society of which he is a member, feels that he is morally held to
title: Elementary Forms

text: participating in its sorrows and joys; not to be interested in them
title: Elementary Forms

text: would be equivalent to breaking the bonds uniting him to the group; it
title: Elementary Forms

text: would be renouncing all desire for it and contradicting himself. When
title: Elementary Forms

text: the Christian, during the ceremonies commemorating the Passion, and the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Jew, on the anniversary of the fall of Jerusalem, fast and mortify
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves, it is not in giving way to a sadness which they feel
title: Elementary Forms

text: spontaneously. Under these circumstances, the internal state of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: believer is out of all proportion to the severe abstinences to which
title: Elementary Forms

text: they submit themselves. If he is sad, it is primarily because he
title: Elementary Forms

text: consents to being sad, and he consents to it in order to affirm his
title: Elementary Forms

text: faith. The attitude of the Australian during mourning is to be explained
title: Elementary Forms

text: in the same way. If he weeps and groans, it is not merely to express an
title: Elementary Forms

text: individual chagrin; it is to fulfil a duty of which the surrounding
title: Elementary Forms

text: society does not fail to remind him.
title: Elementary Forms

text: We have seen elsewhere how human sentiments are intensified when
title: Elementary Forms

text: affirmed collectively. Sorrow, like joy, becomes exalted and amplified
title: Elementary Forms

text: when leaping from mind to mind, and therefore expresses itself outwardly
title: Elementary Forms

text: in the form of exuberant and violent movements. But these are no longer
title: Elementary Forms

text: expressive of the joyful agitation which we observed before; they are
title: Elementary Forms

text: shrieks and cries of pain. Each is carried along by the others; a
title: Elementary Forms

text: veritable panic of sorrow results. When pain reaches this degree of
title: Elementary Forms

text: intensity, it is mixed with a sort of anger and exasperation. One feels
title: Elementary Forms

text: the need of breaking something, of destroying something. He takes this
title: Elementary Forms

text: out either upon himself or others. He beats himself, burns himself,
title: Elementary Forms

text: wounds himself or else he falls upon others to beat, burn and wound
title: Elementary Forms

text: them. Thus it became the custom to give one's self up to the veritable
title: Elementary Forms

text: orgies of tortures during mourning. It seems very probable that
title: Elementary Forms

text: blood-revenge and head-hunting have their origin in this. If every death
title: Elementary Forms

text: is attributed to some magic charm, and for this reason it is believed
title: Elementary Forms

text: that the dead man ought to be avenged, it is because men must find a
title: Elementary Forms

text: victim at any price, upon whom the collective pain and anger may be
title: Elementary Forms

text: discharged. Naturally this victim is sought outside the group; a
title: Elementary Forms

text: stranger is a subject _minoris resistentiae_; as he is not protected by
title: Elementary Forms

text: the sentiments of sympathy inspired by a relative or neighbour, there is
title: Elementary Forms

text: nothing in him which subdues and neutralizes the evil and destructive
title: Elementary Forms

text: sentiments aroused by the death. It is undoubtedly for this same reason
title: Elementary Forms

text: that women serve more frequently than men as the passive objects of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: cruellest rites of mourning; since they have a smaller social value,
title: Elementary Forms

text: they are more obviously designated as scapegoats.
title: Elementary Forms

text: We see that this explanation of mourning completely leaves aside all
title: Elementary Forms

text: ideas of souls or spirits. The only forces which are really active are
title: Elementary Forms

text: of a wholly impersonal nature: they are the emotions aroused in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: group by the death of one of its members. But the primitive does not
title: Elementary Forms

text: know the psychical mechanism from which these practices result. So when
title: Elementary Forms

text: he tries to account for them, he is obliged to forge a wholly different
title: Elementary Forms

text: explanation. All he knows is that he must painfully mortify himself. As
title: Elementary Forms

text: every obligation suggests the notion of a will which obliges, he looks
title: Elementary Forms

text: about him to see whence this constraint which he feels may come. Now,
title: Elementary Forms

text: there is one moral power, of whose reality he is assured and which seems
title: Elementary Forms

text: designated for this role: this is the soul which the death has
title: Elementary Forms

text: liberated. For what could have a greater interest than it in the effects
title: Elementary Forms

text: which its own death has on the living? So they imagine that if these
title: Elementary Forms

text: latter inflict an unnatural treatment upon themselves, it is to conform
title: Elementary Forms

text: to its exigencies. It was thus that the idea of the soul must have
title: Elementary Forms

text: intervened at a later date into the mythology of mourning. But also,
title: Elementary Forms

text: since it is thus endowed with inhuman exigencies, it must be supposed
title: Elementary Forms

text: that in leaving the body which it animated, the soul lays aside every
title: Elementary Forms

text: human sentiment. Hence the metamorphosis which makes a dreaded enemy out
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the relative of yesterday. This transformation is not the origin of
title: Elementary Forms

text: mourning; it is rather its consequence. It translates a change which has
title: Elementary Forms

text: come over the affective state of the group: men do not weep for the dead
title: Elementary Forms

text: because they fear them; they fear them because they weep for them.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But this change of the affective state can only be a temporary one, for
title: Elementary Forms

text: while the ceremonies of mourning result from it, they also put an end to
title: Elementary Forms

text: it. Little by little, they neutralize the very causes which have given
title: Elementary Forms

text: rise to them. The foundation of mourning is the impression of a loss
title: Elementary Forms

text: which the group feels when it loses one of its members. But this very
title: Elementary Forms

text: impression results in bringing individuals together, in putting them
title: Elementary Forms

text: into closer relations with one another, in associating them all in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: same mental state, and therefore in disengaging a sensation of comfort
title: Elementary Forms

text: which compensates the original loss.--Since they weep together, they
title: Elementary Forms

text: hold to one another and the group is not weakened, in spite of the blow
title: Elementary Forms

text: which has fallen upon it. Of course they have only sad emotions in
title: Elementary Forms

text: common, but communicating in sorrow is still communicating, and every
title: Elementary Forms

text: communion of mind, in whatever form it may be made, raises the social
title: Elementary Forms

text: vitality. The exceptional violence of the manifestations by which the
title: Elementary Forms

text: common pain is necessarily and obligatorily expressed even testifies to
title: Elementary Forms

text: the fact that at this moment, the society is more alive and active than
title: Elementary Forms

text: ever. In fact, whenever the social sentiment is painfully wounded, it
title: Elementary Forms

text: reacts with greater force than ordinarily: one never holds so closely to
title: Elementary Forms

text: his family as when it has just suffered. This surplus energy effaces the
title: Elementary Forms

text: more completely the effects of the interruption which was felt at first,
title: Elementary Forms

text: and thus dissipates the feeling of coldness which death always brings
title: Elementary Forms

text: with it. The group feels its strength gradually returning to it; it
title: Elementary Forms

text: begins to hope and to live again. Presently one stops mourning, and he
title: Elementary Forms

text: does so owing to the mourning itself. But as the idea formed of the soul
title: Elementary Forms

text: reflects the moral state of the society, this idea should change as this
title: Elementary Forms

text: state changes. When one is in the period of dejection and agony, he
title: Elementary Forms

text: represents the soul with the traits of an evil being, whose sole
title: Elementary Forms

text: occupation is to persecute men. But when he feels himself confident and
title: Elementary Forms

text: secure once more, he must admit that it has retaken its former nature
title: Elementary Forms

text: and its former sentiments of tenderness and solidarity. Thus we explain
title: Elementary Forms

text: the very different ways in which it is conceived at different moments of
title: Elementary Forms

text: its existence.[1267]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Not only do the rites of mourning determine certain of the secondary
title: Elementary Forms

text: characteristics attributed to the soul, but perhaps they are not foreign
title: Elementary Forms

text: to the idea that it survives the body. If he is to understand the
title: Elementary Forms

text: practices to which he submits on the death of a parent, a man is obliged
title: Elementary Forms

text: to believe that these are not an indifferent matter for the deceased.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The shedding of blood which is practised so freely during mourning is a
title: Elementary Forms

text: veritable sacrifice offered to the dead man.[1268] So something of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: dead man must survive, and as this is not the body, which is manifestly
title: Elementary Forms

text: immobile and decomposed, it can only be the soul. Of course it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: impossible to say with any exactness what part these considerations have
title: Elementary Forms

text: had in the origin of the idea of immortality. But it is probable that
title: Elementary Forms

text: here the influence of the cult is the same as it is elsewhere. Rites are
title: Elementary Forms

text: more easily explicable when one imagines that they are addressed to
title: Elementary Forms

text: personal beings; so men have been induced to extend the influence of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the mythical personalities in the religious life. In order to account
title: Elementary Forms

text: for mourning, they have prolonged the existence of the soul beyond the
title: Elementary Forms

text: tomb. This is one more example of the way in which rites react upon
title: Elementary Forms

text: beliefs.
title: Elementary Forms

text: III
title: Elementary Forms

text: But death is not the only event which may disturb a community. Men have
title: Elementary Forms

text: many other occasions for being sorry and lamenting, so we might foresee
title: Elementary Forms

text: that even the Australians would know and practise other piacular rites
title: Elementary Forms

text: besides mourning. However, it is a remarkable fact that only a small
title: Elementary Forms

text: number of examples are to be found in the accounts of the observers.
title: Elementary Forms

text: One rite of this sort greatly resembles those which have just been
title: Elementary Forms

text: studied. It will be remembered that among the Arunta, each local group
title: Elementary Forms

text: attributes exceptionally important virtues to its collection of
title: Elementary Forms

text: churinga: this is this collective palladium, upon whose fate the fate of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the community itself is believed to depend. So when enemies or white men
title: Elementary Forms

text: succeed in stealing one of these religious treasures, this loss is
title: Elementary Forms

text: considered a public calamity. This misfortune is the occasion of a rite
title: Elementary Forms

text: having all the characteristics of mourning: men smear their bodies with
title: Elementary Forms

text: white pipe-clay and remain in camp, weeping and lamenting, during a
title: Elementary Forms

text: period of two weeks.[1269] This is a new proof that mourning is
title: Elementary Forms

text: determined, not by the way in which the soul of the dead is conceived,
title: Elementary Forms

text: but by impersonal causes, by the moral state of the group. In fact, we
title: Elementary Forms

text: have here a rite which, in its structure, is indistinguishable from the
title: Elementary Forms

text: real mourning, but which is, nevertheless, independent of every notion
title: Elementary Forms

text: of spirits or evil-working demons.[1270]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Another circumstance which gives occasion for ceremonies of the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: nature is the distress in which the society finds itself after an
title: Elementary Forms

text: insufficient harvest. "The natives who live in the vicinity of Lake
title: Elementary Forms

text: Eyre," says Eylmann, "also seek to prevent an insufficiency of food by
title: Elementary Forms

text: means of secret ceremonies. But many of the ritual practices observed in
title: Elementary Forms

text: this region are to be distinguished from those which have been mentioned
title: Elementary Forms

text: already: it is not by symbolic dances, by imitative movements nor
title: Elementary Forms

text: dazzling decorations that they try to act upon the religious powers or
title: Elementary Forms

text: the forces of nature, but by means of the suffering which individuals
title: Elementary Forms

text: inflict upon themselves. In the northern territories, it is by means of
title: Elementary Forms

text: tortures, such as prolonged fasts, vigils, dances persisted up to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: exhaustion of the dancers, and physical pains of every sort, that they
title: Elementary Forms

text: attempt to appease the powers which are ill-disposed towards men."[1271]
title: Elementary Forms

text: The torments to which the natives submit themselves for this purpose
title: Elementary Forms

text: sometimes leave them in such a state of exhaustion that they are unable
title: Elementary Forms

text: to follow the hunt for some days to come.[1272]
title: Elementary Forms

text: These practices are employed especially for fighting against drought.
title: Elementary Forms

text: This is because a scarcity of water results in a general want. To remedy
title: Elementary Forms

text: this evil, they have recourse to violent methods. One which is
title: Elementary Forms

text: frequently used is the extraction of a tooth. Among the Kaitish, for
title: Elementary Forms

text: example, they pull out an incisor from one man, and hang it on a
title: Elementary Forms

text: tree.[1273] Among the Dieri, the idea of rain is closely associated with
title: Elementary Forms

text: that of bloody incisions made in the skin of the chest and arms.[1274]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Among this same people, whenever the drought is very great, the great
title: Elementary Forms

text: council assembles and summons the whole tribe. It is really a tribal
title: Elementary Forms

text: event. Women are sent in every direction to notify men to assemble at a
title: Elementary Forms

text: given place and time. After they have assembled, they groan and cry in a
title: Elementary Forms

text: piercing voice about the miserable state of the land, and they beg the
title: Elementary Forms

text: _Mura-mura_ (the mythical ancestors) to give them the power of making an
title: Elementary Forms

text: abundant rain fall.[1275] In the cases, which, by the way, are very
title: Elementary Forms

text: rare, when there has been an excessive rainfall, an analogous ceremony
title: Elementary Forms

text: takes place to stop it. Old men then enter into a veritable
title: Elementary Forms

text: frenzy,[1276] while the cries uttered by the crowd are really painful to
title: Elementary Forms

text: Spencer and Gillen describe, under the name of Intichiuma, a ceremony
title: Elementary Forms

text: which may well have the same object and the same origin as the preceding
title: Elementary Forms

text: ones: a physical torture is applied to make an animal species multiply.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Among the Urabunna, there is one clan whose totem is a variety of snake
title: Elementary Forms

text: called _wadnungadni_. This is how the chief of the clan proceeds, to
title: Elementary Forms

text: make sure that these snakes may never be lacking. After having been
title: Elementary Forms

text: decorated, he kneels down on the ground, holding his arms straight out.
title: Elementary Forms

text: An assistant pinches the skin of his right arm between his fingers, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: the officiant forces a pointed bone five inches long through the fold
title: Elementary Forms

text: thus formed. This self-mutilation is believed to produce the desired
title: Elementary Forms

text: result.[1278] An analogous rite is used among the Dieri to make the
title: Elementary Forms

text: wild-hens lay: the operators pierce their scrotums.[1279] In certain of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the Lake Eyre tribes, men pierce their ears to make yams
title: Elementary Forms

text: reproduce.[1280]
title: Elementary Forms

text: But these partial or total famines are not the only plagues which may
title: Elementary Forms

text: fall upon a tribe. Other events happen more or less periodically which
title: Elementary Forms

text: menace, or seem to menace, the existence of the group. This is the case,
title: Elementary Forms

text: for example, with the southern lights. The Kurnai believe that this is a
title: Elementary Forms

text: fire lighted in the heavens by the great god Mungan-ngaua; therefore,
title: Elementary Forms

text: whenever they see it, they are afraid that it may spread to the earth
title: Elementary Forms

text: and devour them, so a great effervescence results in the camp. They
title: Elementary Forms

text: shake a withered hand, to which the Kurnai attribute various virtues,
title: Elementary Forms

text: and utter such cries as "Send it away; do not let us be burned." At the
title: Elementary Forms

text: same time, the old men order an exchange of wives, which always
title: Elementary Forms

text: indicates a great excitement.[1281] The same sexual licence is mentioned
title: Elementary Forms

text: among the Wiimbaio whenever a plague appears imminent, and especially in
title: Elementary Forms

text: times of an epidemic.[1282]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Under the influence of these ideas, mutilations and the shedding of
title: Elementary Forms

text: blood are sometimes considered an efficient means of curing maladies. If
title: Elementary Forms

text: an accident happens to a child among the Dieri, his relations beat
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves on the head with clubs or boomerangs until the blood flows
title: Elementary Forms

text: down over their faces. They believe that by this process, they relieve
title: Elementary Forms

text: the child of the suffering.[1283] Elsewhere, they imagine that they can
title: Elementary Forms

text: obtain the same end by means of a supplementary totemic ceremony.[1284]
title: Elementary Forms

text: We may connect with these the example already given of a ceremony
title: Elementary Forms

text: celebrated specially to efface the effects of a ritual fault.[1285] Of
title: Elementary Forms

text: course there are neither wounds nor blows nor physical suffering of any
title: Elementary Forms

text: sort in these two latter cases, yet the rite does not differ in nature
title: Elementary Forms

text: from the others: the end sought is always the turning aside of an evil
title: Elementary Forms

text: or the expiation of a fault by means of an extraordinary ritual
title: Elementary Forms

text: prestation.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Outside of mourning, such are the only cases of piacular rites which we
title: Elementary Forms

text: have succeeded in finding in Australia. To be sure, it is probable that
title: Elementary Forms

text: some have escaped us, while we may presume equally well that others have
title: Elementary Forms

text: remained unperceived by the observers. But if those discovered up to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: present are few in number, it is probably because they do not hold a
title: Elementary Forms

text: large place in the cult. We see how far primitive religions are from
title: Elementary Forms

text: being the daughters of agony and fear from the fact that the rites
title: Elementary Forms

text: translating these painful emotions are relatively rare. Of course this
title: Elementary Forms

text: is because the Australian, while leading a miserable existence as
title: Elementary Forms

text: compared with other more civilized peoples, demands so little of life
title: Elementary Forms

text: that he is easily contented. All that he asks is that nature follow its
title: Elementary Forms

text: normal course, that the seasons succeed one another regularly, that the
title: Elementary Forms

text: rain fall, at the ordinary time, in abundance and without excess. Now
title: Elementary Forms

text: great disturbances in the cosmic order are always exceptional; thus it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is noticeable that the majority of the regular piacular rites, examples
title: Elementary Forms

text: of which we have given above, have been observed in the tribes of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: centre, where droughts are frequent and constitute veritable disasters.
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is still surprising, it is true, that piacular rites specially
title: Elementary Forms

text: destined to expiate sins, seem to be completely lacking. However, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Australian, like every other man, must commit ritual faults, which he
title: Elementary Forms

text: has an interest in redeeming; so we may ask if the silence of the texts
title: Elementary Forms

text: on this point may not be due to insufficient observation.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But howsoever few the facts which we have been able to gather may be,
title: Elementary Forms

text: they are, nevertheless, instructive.
title: Elementary Forms

text: When we study piacular rites in the more advanced religions, where the
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious forces are individualized, they appear to be closely bound up
title: Elementary Forms

text: with anthropomorphic conceptions. When the believer imposes privations
title: Elementary Forms

text: upon himself and submits himself to austerities, it is in order to
title: Elementary Forms

text: disarm the malevolence attributed by him to certain of the sacred beings
title: Elementary Forms

text: upon whom he thinks that he is dependent. To appease their hatred or
title: Elementary Forms

text: anger, he complies with their exigencies; he beats himself in order that
title: Elementary Forms

text: he may not be beaten by them. So it seems as though these practices
title: Elementary Forms

text: could not arise until after gods and spirits were conceived as moral
title: Elementary Forms

text: persons, capable of passions analogous to those of men. For this reason,
title: Elementary Forms

text: Robertson Smith thought it possible to assign a relatively late date to
title: Elementary Forms

text: expiatory sacrifices, just as to sacrificial oblations. According to
title: Elementary Forms

text: him, the shedding of blood which characterizes these rites was at first
title: Elementary Forms

text: a simple process of communion: men poured forth their blood upon the
title: Elementary Forms

text: altar in order to strengthen the bonds uniting them to their god. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: rite acquired a piacular and penal character only when its original
title: Elementary Forms

text: significance was forgotten and when the new idea which was formed of
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacred beings allowed men to attribute another function to it.[1286]
title: Elementary Forms

text: But as piacular rites are met with even in the Australian societies, it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is impossible to assign them so late an origin. Moreover, all that we
title: Elementary Forms

text: have observed, with one single exception,[1287] are independent of all
title: Elementary Forms

text: anthropomorphic conceptions: there is no question of either spirits or
title: Elementary Forms

text: gods. Abstinences and effusions of blood stop famines and cure
title: Elementary Forms

text: sicknesses directly and by themselves. No spiritual being introduces his
title: Elementary Forms

text: action between the rite and the effect it is believed to produce. So
title: Elementary Forms

text: mythical personalities intervened only at a late date. After the
title: Elementary Forms

text: mechanism of the ritual had once been established, they served to make
title: Elementary Forms

text: it more easily representable in the mind, but they are not conditions of
title: Elementary Forms

text: its existence. It is for other reasons that it was founded; it is to
title: Elementary Forms

text: another cause that it owes its efficacy.
title: Elementary Forms

text: It acts through the collective forces which it puts into play. Does a
title: Elementary Forms

text: misfortune which menaces the group appear imminent? Then the group
title: Elementary Forms

text: unites, as in the case of mourning, and it is naturally an impression of
title: Elementary Forms

text: uneasiness and perplexity which dominates the assembled body. Now, as
title: Elementary Forms

text: always, the pooling of these sentiments results in intensifying them. By
title: Elementary Forms

text: affirming themselves, they exalt and impassion themselves and attain a
title: Elementary Forms

text: degree of violence which is translated by the corresponding violence of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the gestures which express them. Just as at the death of a relative,
title: Elementary Forms

text: they utter terrible cries, fly into a passion and feel that they must
title: Elementary Forms

text: tear and destroy; it is to satisfy this need that they beat themselves,
title: Elementary Forms

text: wound themselves, and make their blood flow. When emotions have this
title: Elementary Forms

text: vivacity, they may well be painful, but they are not depressing; on the
title: Elementary Forms

text: contrary, they denote a state of effervescence which implies a
title: Elementary Forms

text: mobilization of all our active forces, and even a supply of external
title: Elementary Forms

text: energies. It matters little that this exaltation was provoked by a sad
title: Elementary Forms

text: event, for it is real, notwithstanding, and does not differ specifically
title: Elementary Forms

text: from what is observed in the happy feasts. Sometimes it is even made
title: Elementary Forms

text: manifest by movements of the same nature: there is the same frenzy which
title: Elementary Forms

text: seizes the worshippers and the same tendency towards sexual debauches, a
title: Elementary Forms

text: sure sign of great nervous over-excitement. Robertson Smith had already
title: Elementary Forms

text: noticed this curious influence of sad rites in the Semitic cults: "in
title: Elementary Forms

text: evil times," he says, "when men's thoughts were habitually sombre, they
title: Elementary Forms

text: betook themselves to the physical excitement of religion as men now take
title: Elementary Forms

text: refuge in wine.... And so in general when an act of Semitic worship
title: Elementary Forms

text: began with sorrow and lamentation--as in the mourning for Adonis, or the
title: Elementary Forms

text: great atoning ceremonies which became common in later times--a swift
title: Elementary Forms

text: revulsion of feeling followed, and the gloomy part of the service was
title: Elementary Forms

text: presently succeeded by a burst of hilarious revelry."[1288] In a word,
title: Elementary Forms

text: even when religious ceremonies have a disquieting or saddening event as
title: Elementary Forms

text: their point of departure, they retain their stimulating power over the
title: Elementary Forms

text: affective state of the group and individuals. By the mere fact that they
title: Elementary Forms

text: are collective, they raise the vital tone. When one feels life within
title: Elementary Forms

text: him--whether it be in the form of painful irritation or happy
title: Elementary Forms

text: enthusiasm--he does not believe in death; so he becomes reassured and
title: Elementary Forms

text: takes courage again, and subjectively, everything goes on as if the rite
title: Elementary Forms

text: had really driven off the danger which was dreaded. This is how curing
title: Elementary Forms

text: or preventive virtues come to be attributed to the movements which one
title: Elementary Forms

text: makes, to the cries uttered, to the blood shed and to the wounds
title: Elementary Forms

text: inflicted upon one's self or others; and as these different tortures
title: Elementary Forms

text: necessarily make one suffer, suffering by itself is finally regarded as
title: Elementary Forms

text: a means of conjuring evil or curing sickness.[1289] Later, when the
title: Elementary Forms

text: majority of the religious forces had taken the form of moral
title: Elementary Forms

text: personalities, the efficacy of these practices was explained by
title: Elementary Forms

text: imagining that their object was to appease an evil-working or irritated
title: Elementary Forms

text: god. But these conceptions only reflect the rite and the sentiments it
title: Elementary Forms

text: arouses; they are an interpretation of it, not its determining cause.
title: Elementary Forms

text: A negligence of the ritual acts in the same way. It, too, is a menace
title: Elementary Forms

text: for the group; it touches it in its moral existence for it touches it in
title: Elementary Forms

text: its beliefs. But if the anger which it causes is affirmed ostensibly and
title: Elementary Forms

text: energetically, it compensates the evil which it has caused. For if it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: acutely felt by all, it is because the infraction committed is an
title: Elementary Forms

text: exception and the common faith remains entire. So the moral unity of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: group is not endangered. Now the penalty inflicted as an expiation is
title: Elementary Forms

text: only a manifestation of the public anger, the material proof of its
title: Elementary Forms

text: unanimity. So it really does have the healing effect attributed to it.
title: Elementary Forms

text: At bottom, the sentiment which is at the root of the real expiatory
title: Elementary Forms

text: rites does not differ in nature from that which we have found at the
title: Elementary Forms

text: basis of the other piacular rites: it is a sort of irritated sorrow
title: Elementary Forms

text: which tends to manifest itself by acts of destruction. Sometimes it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: assuaged to the detriment of him who feels it; sometimes it is at the
title: Elementary Forms

text: expense of some foreign third party. But in either case, the psychic
title: Elementary Forms

text: mechanism is essentially the same.[1290]
title: Elementary Forms

text: IV
title: Elementary Forms

text: One of the greatest services which Robertson Smith has rendered to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: science of religions is to have pointed out the ambiguity of the notion
title: Elementary Forms

text: of sacredness.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Religious forces are of two sorts. Some are beneficent, guardians of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: physical and moral order, dispensers of life and health and all the
title: Elementary Forms

text: qualities which men esteem: this is the case with the totemic principle,
title: Elementary Forms

text: spread out in the whole species, the mythical ancestor, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: animal-protector, the civilizing heroes and the tutelar gods of every
title: Elementary Forms

text: kind and degree. It matters little whether they are conceived as
title: Elementary Forms

text: distinct personalities or as diffused energies; under either form they
title: Elementary Forms

text: fulfil the same function and affect the minds of the believers in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: same way: the respect which they inspire is mixed with love and
title: Elementary Forms

text: gratitude. The things and the persons which are normally connected with
title: Elementary Forms

text: them participate in the same sentiments and the same character: these
title: Elementary Forms

text: are holy things and persons. Such are the spots consecrated to the cult,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the objects which serve in the regular rites, the priests, the ascetics,
title: Elementary Forms

text: etc.--On the other hand, there are evil and impure powers, productive of
title: Elementary Forms

text: disorders, causes of death and sickness, instigators of sacrilege. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: only sentiments which men have for them are a fear into which horror
title: Elementary Forms

text: generally enters. Such are the forces upon which and by which the
title: Elementary Forms

text: sorcerer acts, those which arise from corpses or the menstrual blood,
title: Elementary Forms

text: those freed by every profanation of sacred things, etc. The spirits of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the dead and malign genii of every sort are their personified forms.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Between these two categories of forces and beings, the contrast is as
title: Elementary Forms

text: complete as possible and even goes into the most radical antagonism. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: good and salutary powers repel to a distance these others which deny and
title: Elementary Forms

text: contradict them. Therefore the former are forbidden to the latter: any
title: Elementary Forms

text: contact between them is considered the worst of profanations. This is
title: Elementary Forms

text: the typical form of those interdicts between sacred things of different
title: Elementary Forms

text: species, the existence of which we have already pointed out.[1291] Women
title: Elementary Forms

text: during menstruation, and especially at its beginning, are impure; so at
title: Elementary Forms

text: this moment they are rigorously sequestered; men may have no relations
title: Elementary Forms

text: with them.[1292] Bull-roarers and churinga never come near a dead
title: Elementary Forms

text: man.[1293] A sacrilegious person is excluded from the society of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: faithful; access to the cult is forbidden him. Thus the whole religious
title: Elementary Forms

text: life gravitates about two contrary poles between which there is the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: opposition as between the pure and the impure, the saint and the
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacrilegious, the divine and the diabolic.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But while these two aspects of the religious life oppose one another,
title: Elementary Forms

text: there is a close kinship between them. In the first place, both have the
title: Elementary Forms

text: same relation towards profane beings: these must abstain from all
title: Elementary Forms

text: contact with impure things just as from the most holy things. The former
title: Elementary Forms

text: are no less forbidden than the latter: they are withdrawn from
title: Elementary Forms

text: circulation alike. This shows that they too are sacred. Of course the
title: Elementary Forms

text: sentiments inspired by the two are not identical: respect is one thing,
title: Elementary Forms

text: disgust and horror another. Yet, if the gestures are to be the same in
title: Elementary Forms

text: both cases, the sentiments expressed must not differ in nature. And, in
title: Elementary Forms

text: fact, there is a horror in religious respect, especially when it is very
title: Elementary Forms

text: intense, while the fear inspired by malign powers is generally not
title: Elementary Forms

text: without a certain reverential character. The shades by which these two
title: Elementary Forms

text: attitudes are differentiated are even so slight sometimes that it is not
title: Elementary Forms

text: always easy to say which state of mind the believers actually happen to
title: Elementary Forms

text: be in. Among certain Semitic peoples, pork was forbidden, but it was not
title: Elementary Forms

text: always known exactly whether this was because it was a pure or an impure
title: Elementary Forms

text: thing[1294] and the same may be said of a very large number of
title: Elementary Forms

text: alimentary interdictions.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But there is more to be said; it very frequently happens that an impure
title: Elementary Forms

text: thing or an evil power becomes a holy thing or a guardian power, without
title: Elementary Forms

text: changing its nature, through a simple modification of external
title: Elementary Forms

text: circumstances. We have seen how the soul of a dead man, which is a
title: Elementary Forms

text: dreaded principle at first, is transformed into a protecting genius as
title: Elementary Forms

text: soon as the mourning is finished. Likewise, the corpse, which begins by
title: Elementary Forms

text: inspiring terror and aversion, is later regarded as a venerated relic:
title: Elementary Forms

text: funeral anthropophagy, which is frequently practised in the Australian
title: Elementary Forms

text: societies, is a proof of this transformation.[1295] The totemic animal
title: Elementary Forms

text: is the pre-eminently sacred being; but for him who eats its flesh
title: Elementary Forms

text: unduly, it is a cause of death. In a general way, the sacrilegious
title: Elementary Forms

text: person is merely a profane one who has been infected with a benevolent
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious force. This changes its nature in changing its habitat; it
title: Elementary Forms

text: defiles rather than sanctifies.[1296] The blood issuing from the
title: Elementary Forms

text: genital organs of a woman, though it is evidently as impure as that of
title: Elementary Forms

text: menstruation, is frequently used as a remedy against sickness.[1297] The
title: Elementary Forms

text: victim immolated in expiatory sacrifices is charged with impurities, for
title: Elementary Forms

text: they have concentrated upon it the sins which were to be expiated. Yet,
title: Elementary Forms

text: after it has been slaughtered, its flesh and blood are employed for the
title: Elementary Forms

text: most pious uses.[1298] On the contrary, though the communion is
title: Elementary Forms

text: generally a religious operation whose normal function is to consecrate,
title: Elementary Forms

text: it sometimes produces the effects of a sacrilege. In certain cases, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: persons who have communicated are forced to flee from one another as
title: Elementary Forms

text: from men infected with a plague. One would say that they have become a
title: Elementary Forms

text: source of dangerous contamination for one another: the sacred bond which
title: Elementary Forms

text: unites them also separates them. Examples of this sort of communion are
title: Elementary Forms

text: numerous in Australia. One of the most typical has been observed among
title: Elementary Forms

text: the Narrinyeri and the neighbouring tribes. When an infant arrives in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the world, its parents carefully preserve its umbilical cord, which is
title: Elementary Forms

text: believed to conceal a part of its soul. Two persons who exchange the
title: Elementary Forms

text: cords thus preserved communicate together by the very act of this
title: Elementary Forms

text: exchange, for it is as though they exchanged their souls. But, at the
title: Elementary Forms

text: same time, they are forbidden to touch or speak to or even to see one
title: Elementary Forms

text: another. It is just as though they were each an object of horror for the
title: Elementary Forms

text: other.[1299]
title: Elementary Forms

text: So the pure and the impure are not two separate classes, but two
title: Elementary Forms

text: varieties of the same class, which includes all sacred things. There are
title: Elementary Forms

text: two sorts of sacredness, the propitious and the unpropitious, and not
title: Elementary Forms

text: only is there no break of continuity between these two opposed forms,
title: Elementary Forms

text: but also one object may pass from the one to the other without changing
title: Elementary Forms

text: its nature. The pure is made out of the impure, and reciprocally. It is
title: Elementary Forms

text: in the possibility of these transmutations that the ambiguity of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacred consists.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But even if Robertson Smith did have an active sentiment of this
title: Elementary Forms

text: ambiguity, he never gave it an express explanation. He confined himself
title: Elementary Forms

text: to remarking that, as all religious forces are indistinctly intense and
title: Elementary Forms

text: contagious, it is wise not to approach them except with respectful
title: Elementary Forms

text: precautions, no matter what direction their action may be exercised in.
title: Elementary Forms

text: It seemed to him that he could thus account for the air of kinship which
title: Elementary Forms

text: they all present, in spite of the contrasts which oppose them
title: Elementary Forms

text: otherwise. But the question was only put off; it still remains to be
title: Elementary Forms

text: shown how it comes that the powers of evil have the same intensity and
title: Elementary Forms

text: contagiousness as the others. In other words, how does it happen that
title: Elementary Forms

text: they, too, are of a religious nature? Also, the energy and force of
title: Elementary Forms

text: expansion which they have in common do not enable us to understand how,
title: Elementary Forms

text: in spite of the conflict which divides them, they may be transformed
title: Elementary Forms

text: into one another or substituted for each other in their respective
title: Elementary Forms

text: functions, and how the pure may contaminate while the impure sometimes
title: Elementary Forms

text: serves to sanctify.[1300]
title: Elementary Forms

text: The explanation of piacular rites which we have proposed enables us to
title: Elementary Forms

text: reply to this double question.
title: Elementary Forms

text: We have seen, in fact, that the evil powers are the product of these
title: Elementary Forms

text: rites and symbolize them. When a society is going through circumstances
title: Elementary Forms

text: which sadden, perplex or irritate it, it exercises a pressure over its
title: Elementary Forms

text: members, to make them bear witness, by significant acts, to their
title: Elementary Forms

text: sorrow, perplexity or anger. It imposes upon them the duty of weeping,
title: Elementary Forms

text: groaning or inflicting wounds upon themselves or others, for these
title: Elementary Forms

text: collective manifestations, and the moral communion which they show and
title: Elementary Forms

text: strengthen, restore to the group the energy which circumstances threaten
title: Elementary Forms

text: to take away from it, and thus they enable it to become settled. This is
title: Elementary Forms

text: the experience which men interpret when they imagine that outside them
title: Elementary Forms

text: there are evil beings whose hostility, whether constitutional or
title: Elementary Forms

text: temporary, can be appeased only by human suffering. These beings are
title: Elementary Forms

text: nothing other than collective states objectified; they are society
title: Elementary Forms

text: itself seen under one of its aspects. But we also know that the
title: Elementary Forms

text: benevolent powers are constituted in the same way; they, too, result
title: Elementary Forms

text: from the collective life and express it; they, too, represent the
title: Elementary Forms

text: society, but seen from a very different attitude, to wit, at the moment
title: Elementary Forms

text: when it confidently affirms itself and ardently presses on towards the
title: Elementary Forms

text: realization of the ends which it pursues. Since these two sorts of
title: Elementary Forms

text: forces have a common origin, it is not at all surprising that, though
title: Elementary Forms

text: facing in opposite directions, they should have the same nature, that
title: Elementary Forms

text: they are equally intense and contagious and consequently forbidden and
title: Elementary Forms

text: sacred.
title: Elementary Forms

text: From this we are able to understand how they change into one another.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Since they reflect the abjective state in which the group happens to be,
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is enough that this state change for their character to change. After
title: Elementary Forms

text: the mourning is over, the domestic group is re-calmed by the mourning
title: Elementary Forms

text: itself; it regains confidence; the painful pressure which they felt
title: Elementary Forms

text: exercised over them is relieved; they feel more at their ease. So it
title: Elementary Forms

text: seems to them as though the spirit of the deceased had laid aside its
title: Elementary Forms

text: hostile sentiments and become a benevolent protector. The other
title: Elementary Forms

text: transmutations, examples of which we have cited, are to be explained in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the same way. As we have already shown, the sanctity of a thing is due
title: Elementary Forms

text: to the collective sentiment of which it is the object. If, in violation
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the interdicts which isolate it, it comes in contact with a profane
title: Elementary Forms

text: person, then this same sentiment will spread contagiously to this latter
title: Elementary Forms

text: and imprint a special character upon him. But in spreading, it comes
title: Elementary Forms

text: into a very different state from the one it was in at first. Offended
title: Elementary Forms

text: and irritated by the profanation implied in this abusive and unnatural
title: Elementary Forms

text: extension, it becomes aggressive and inclined to destructive violences:
title: Elementary Forms

text: it tends to avenge itself for the offence suffered. Therefore the
title: Elementary Forms

text: infected subject seems to be filled with a mighty and harmful force
title: Elementary Forms

text: which menaces all that approaches him; it is as though he were marked
title: Elementary Forms

text: with a stain or blemish. Yet the cause of this blemish is the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: psychic state which, in other circumstances, consecrates and sanctifies.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But if the anger thus aroused is satisfied by an expiatory rite, it
title: Elementary Forms

text: subsides, alleviated; the offended sentiment is appeased and returns to
title: Elementary Forms

text: its original state. So it acts once more as it acted in the beginning;
title: Elementary Forms

text: instead of contaminating, it sanctifies. As it continues to infect the
title: Elementary Forms

text: object to which it is attached, this could never become profane and
title: Elementary Forms

text: religiously indifferent again. But the direction of the religious force
title: Elementary Forms

text: with which it seems to be filled is inverted: from being impure, it has
title: Elementary Forms

text: become pure and an instrument of purification.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In resume, the two poles of the religious life correspond to the two
title: Elementary Forms

text: opposed states through which all social life passes. Between the
title: Elementary Forms

text: propitiously sacred and the unpropitiously sacred there is the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: contrast as between the states of collective well-being and ill-being.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But since both are equally collective, there is, between the
title: Elementary Forms

text: mythological constructions symbolizing them, an intimate kinship of
title: Elementary Forms

text: nature. The sentiments held in common vary from extreme dejection to
title: Elementary Forms

text: extreme joy, from painful irritation to ecstatic enthusiasm; but, in
title: Elementary Forms

text: any case, there is a communion of minds and a mutual comfort resulting
title: Elementary Forms

text: from this communion. The fundamental process is always the same; only
title: Elementary Forms

text: circumstances colour it differently. So, at bottom, it is the unity and
title: Elementary Forms

text: the diversity of social life which make the simultaneous unity and
title: Elementary Forms

text: diversity of sacred beings and things.
title: Elementary Forms

text: This ambiguity, moreover, is not peculiar to the idea of sacredness
title: Elementary Forms

text: alone; something of this characteristic has been found in all the rites
title: Elementary Forms

text: which we have been studying. Of course it was essential to distinguish
title: Elementary Forms

text: them; to confuse them would have been to misunderstand the multiple
title: Elementary Forms

text: aspects of the religious life. But, on the other hand, howsoever
title: Elementary Forms

text: different they may be, there is no break of continuity between them.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Quite on the contrary, they overlap one another and may even replace
title: Elementary Forms

text: each other mutually. We have already shown how the rites of oblation and
title: Elementary Forms

text: communion, the imitative rites and the commemorative rites frequently
title: Elementary Forms

text: fulfil the same function. One might imagine that the negative cult, at
title: Elementary Forms

text: least, would be more sharply separated from the positive cult; yet we
title: Elementary Forms

text: have seen that the former may produce positive effects, identical with
title: Elementary Forms

text: those produced by the latter. The same results are obtained by fasts,
title: Elementary Forms

text: abstinences and self-mutilations as by communions, oblations and
title: Elementary Forms

text: commemorations. Inversely, offerings and sacrifices imply privations and
title: Elementary Forms

text: renunciations of every sort. The continuity between ascetic and piacular
title: Elementary Forms

text: rites is even more apparent: both are made up of sufferings, accepted or
title: Elementary Forms

text: undergone, to which an analogous efficacy is attributed. Thus the
title: Elementary Forms

text: practices, like the beliefs, are not arranged in two separate classes.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Howsoever complex the outward manifestations of the religious life may
title: Elementary Forms

text: be, at bottom it is one and simple. It responds everywhere to one and
title: Elementary Forms

text: the same need, and is everywhere derived from one and the same mental
title: Elementary Forms

text: state. In all its forms, its object is to raise man above himself and to
title: Elementary Forms

text: make him lead a life superior to that which he would lead, if he
title: Elementary Forms

text: followed only his own individual whims: beliefs express this life in
title: Elementary Forms

text: representations; rites organize it and regulate its working.
title: Elementary Forms

text: CONCLUSION
title: Elementary Forms

text: At the beginning of this work we announced that the religion whose study
title: Elementary Forms

text: we were taking up contained within it the most characteristic elements
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the religious life. The exactness of this proposition may now be
title: Elementary Forms

text: verified. Howsoever simple the system which we have studied may be, we
title: Elementary Forms

text: have found within it all the great ideas and the principal ritual
title: Elementary Forms

text: attitudes which are at the basis of even the most advanced religions:
title: Elementary Forms

text: the division of things into sacred and profane, the notions of the soul,
title: Elementary Forms

text: of spirits, of mythical personalities, and of a national and even
title: Elementary Forms

text: international divinity, a negative cult with ascetic practices which are
title: Elementary Forms

text: its exaggerated form, rites of oblation and communion, imitative rites,
title: Elementary Forms

text: commemorative rites and expiatory rites; nothing essential is lacking.
title: Elementary Forms

text: We are thus in a position to hope that the results at which we have
title: Elementary Forms

text: arrived are not peculiar to totemism alone, but can aid us in an
title: Elementary Forms

text: understanding of what religion in general is.
title: Elementary Forms

text: It may be objected that one single religion, whatever its field of
title: Elementary Forms

text: extension may be, is too narrow a base for such an induction. We have
title: Elementary Forms

text: not dreamed for a moment of ignoring the fact that an extended
title: Elementary Forms

text: verification may add to the authority of a theory, but it is equally
title: Elementary Forms

text: true that when a law has been proven by one well-made experiment, this
title: Elementary Forms

text: proof is valid universally. If in one single case a scientist succeeded
title: Elementary Forms

text: in finding out the secret of the life of even the most protoplasmic
title: Elementary Forms

text: creature that can be imagined, the truths thus obtained would be
title: Elementary Forms

text: applicable to all living beings, even the most advanced. Then if, in our
title: Elementary Forms

text: studies of these very humble societies, we have really succeeded in
title: Elementary Forms

text: discovering some of the elements out of which the most fundamental
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious notions are made up, there is no reason for not extending the
title: Elementary Forms

text: most general results of our researches to other religions. In fact, it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is inconceivable that the same effect may be due now to one cause, now
title: Elementary Forms

text: to another, according to the circumstances, unless the two causes are at
title: Elementary Forms

text: bottom only one. A single idea cannot express one reality here and
title: Elementary Forms

text: another one there, unless the duality is only apparent. If among certain
title: Elementary Forms

text: peoples the ideas of sacredness, the soul and God are to be explained
title: Elementary Forms

text: sociologically, it should be presumed scientifically that, in principle,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the same explanation is valid for all the peoples among whom these same
title: Elementary Forms

text: ideas are found with the same essential characteristics. Therefore,
title: Elementary Forms

text: supposing that we have not been deceived, certain at least of our
title: Elementary Forms

text: conclusions can be legitimately generalized. The moment has come to
title: Elementary Forms

text: disengage these. And an induction of this sort, having at its foundation
title: Elementary Forms

text: a clearly defined experiment, is less adventurous than many summary
title: Elementary Forms

text: generalizations which, while attempting to reach the essence of religion
title: Elementary Forms

text: at once, without resting upon the careful analysis of any religion in
title: Elementary Forms

text: particular, greatly risk losing themselves in space.
title: Elementary Forms

text: I
title: Elementary Forms

text: The theorists who have undertaken to explain religion in rational terms
title: Elementary Forms

text: have generally seen in it before all else a system of ideas,
title: Elementary Forms

text: corresponding to some determined object. This object has been conceived
title: Elementary Forms

text: in a multitude of ways: nature, the infinite, the unknowable, the ideal,
title: Elementary Forms

text: etc.; but these differences matter but little. In any case, it was the
title: Elementary Forms

text: conceptions and beliefs which were considered as the essential elements
title: Elementary Forms

text: of religion. As for the rites, from this point of view they appear to be
title: Elementary Forms

text: only an external translation, contingent and material, of these internal
title: Elementary Forms

text: states which alone pass as having any intrinsic value. This conception
title: Elementary Forms

text: is so commonly held that generally the disputes of which religion is the
title: Elementary Forms

text: theme turn about the question whether it can conciliate itself with
title: Elementary Forms

text: science or not, that is to say, whether or not there is a place beside
title: Elementary Forms

text: our scientific knowledge for another form of thought which would be
title: Elementary Forms

text: specifically religious.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But the believers, the men who lead the religious life and have a direct
title: Elementary Forms

text: sensation of what it really is, object to this way of regarding it,
title: Elementary Forms

text: saying that it does not correspond to their daily experience. In fact,
title: Elementary Forms

text: they feel that the real function of religion is not to make us think, to
title: Elementary Forms

text: enrich our knowledge, nor to add to the conceptions which we owe to
title: Elementary Forms

text: science others of another origin and another character, but rather, it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is to make us act, to aid us to live. The believer who has communicated
title: Elementary Forms

text: with his god is not merely a man who sees new truths of which the
title: Elementary Forms

text: unbeliever is ignorant; he is a man who is _stronger_. He feels within
title: Elementary Forms

text: him more force, either to endure the trials of existence, or to conquer
title: Elementary Forms

text: them. It is as though he were raised above the miseries of the world,
title: Elementary Forms

text: because he is raised above his condition as a mere man; he believes that
title: Elementary Forms

text: he is saved from evil, under whatever form he may conceive this evil.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The first article in every creed is the belief in salvation by faith.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But it is hard to see how a mere idea could have this efficacy. An idea
title: Elementary Forms

text: is in reality only a part of ourselves; then how could it confer upon us
title: Elementary Forms

text: powers superior to those which we have of our own nature? Howsoever rich
title: Elementary Forms

text: it might be in affective virtues, it could add nothing to our natural
title: Elementary Forms

text: vitality; for it could only release the motive powers which are within
title: Elementary Forms

text: us, neither creating them nor increasing them. From the mere fact that
title: Elementary Forms

text: we consider an object worthy of being loved and sought after, it does
title: Elementary Forms

text: not follow that we feel ourselves stronger afterwards; it is also
title: Elementary Forms

text: necessary that this object set free energies superior to these which we
title: Elementary Forms

text: ordinarily have at our command and also that we have some means of
title: Elementary Forms

text: making these enter into us and unite themselves to our interior lives.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Now for that, it is not enough that we think of them; it is also
title: Elementary Forms

text: indispensable that we place ourselves within their sphere of action, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: that we set ourselves where we may best feel their influence; in a word,
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is necessary that we act, and that we repeat the acts thus necessary
title: Elementary Forms

text: every time we feel the need of renewing their effects. From this point
title: Elementary Forms

text: of view, it is readily seen how that group of regularly repeated acts
title: Elementary Forms

text: which form the cult get their importance. In fact, whoever has really
title: Elementary Forms

text: practised a religion knows very well that it is the cult which gives
title: Elementary Forms

text: rise to these impressions of joy, of interior peace, of serenity, of
title: Elementary Forms

text: enthusiasm which are, for the believer, an experimental proof of his
title: Elementary Forms

text: beliefs. The cult is not simply a system of signs by which the faith is
title: Elementary Forms

text: outwardly translated; it is a collection of the means by which this is
title: Elementary Forms

text: created and recreated periodically. Whether it consists in material acts
title: Elementary Forms

text: or mental operations, it is always this which is efficacious.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Our entire study rests upon this postulate that the unanimous sentiment
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the believers of all times cannot be purely illusory. Together with a
title: Elementary Forms

text: recent apologist of the faith[1301] we admit that these religious
title: Elementary Forms

text: beliefs rest upon a specific experience whose demonstrative value is, in
title: Elementary Forms

text: one sense, not one bit inferior to that of scientific experiments,
title: Elementary Forms

text: though different from them. We, too, think that "a tree is known by its
title: Elementary Forms

text: fruits,"[1302] and that fertility is the best proof of what the roots
title: Elementary Forms

text: are worth. But from the fact that a "religious experience," if we choose
title: Elementary Forms

text: to call it this, does exist and that it has a certain foundation--and,
title: Elementary Forms

text: by the way, is there any experience which has none?--it does not follow
title: Elementary Forms

text: that the reality which is its foundation conforms objectively to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: idea which believers have of it. The very fact that the fashion in which
title: Elementary Forms

text: it has been conceived has varied infinitely in different times is enough
title: Elementary Forms

text: to prove that none of these conceptions express it adequately. If a
title: Elementary Forms

text: scientist states it as an axiom that the sensations of heat and light
title: Elementary Forms

text: which we feel correspond to some objective cause, he does not conclude
title: Elementary Forms

text: that this is what it appears to the senses to be. Likewise, even if the
title: Elementary Forms

text: impressions which the faithful feel are not imaginary, still they are in
title: Elementary Forms

text: no way privileged intuitions; there is no reason for believing that they
title: Elementary Forms

text: inform us better upon the nature of their object than do ordinary
title: Elementary Forms

text: sensations upon the nature of bodies and their properties. In order to
title: Elementary Forms

text: discover what this object consists of, we must submit them to an
title: Elementary Forms

text: examination and elaboration analogous to that which has substituted for
title: Elementary Forms

text: the sensuous idea of the world another which is scientific and
title: Elementary Forms

text: conceptual.
title: Elementary Forms

text: This is precisely what we have tried to do, and we have seen that this
title: Elementary Forms

text: reality, which mythologies have represented under so many different
title: Elementary Forms

text: forms, but which is the universal and eternal objective cause of these
title: Elementary Forms

text: sensations _sui generis_ out of which religious experience is made, is
title: Elementary Forms

text: society. We have shown what moral forces it develops and how it awakens
title: Elementary Forms

text: this sentiment of a refuge, of a shield and of a guardian support which
title: Elementary Forms

text: attaches the believer to his cult. It is that which raises him outside
title: Elementary Forms

text: himself; it is even that which made him. For that which makes a man is
title: Elementary Forms

text: the totality of the intellectual property which constitutes
title: Elementary Forms
