text: civilization, and civilization is the work of society. Thus is explained
title: Elementary Forms

text: the preponderating role of the cult in all religions, whichever they may
title: Elementary Forms

text: be. This is because society cannot make its influence felt unless it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: in action, and it is not in action unless the individuals who compose it
title: Elementary Forms

text: are assembled together and act in common. It is by common action that it
title: Elementary Forms

text: takes consciousness of itself and realizes its position; it is before
title: Elementary Forms

text: all else an active co-operation. The collective ideas and sentiments are
title: Elementary Forms

text: even possible only owing to these exterior movements which symbolize
title: Elementary Forms

text: them, as we have established.[1303] Then it is action which dominates
title: Elementary Forms

text: the religious life, because of the mere fact that it is society which is
title: Elementary Forms

text: its source.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In addition to all the reasons which have been given to justify this
title: Elementary Forms

text: conception, a final one may be added here, which is the result of our
title: Elementary Forms

text: whole work. As we have progressed, we have established the fact that the
title: Elementary Forms

text: fundamental categories of thought, and consequently of science, are of
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious origin. We have seen that the same is true for magic and
title: Elementary Forms

text: consequently for the different processes which have issued from it. On
title: Elementary Forms

text: the other hand, it has long been known that up until a relatively
title: Elementary Forms

text: advanced moment of evolution, moral and legal rules have been
title: Elementary Forms

text: indistinguishable from ritual prescriptions. In summing up, then, it may
title: Elementary Forms

text: be said that nearly all the great social institutions have been born in
title: Elementary Forms

text: religion.[1304] Now in order that these principal aspects of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: collective life may have commenced by being only varied aspects of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious life, it is obviously necessary that the religious life be the
title: Elementary Forms

text: eminent form and, as it were, the concentrated expression of the whole
title: Elementary Forms

text: collective life. If religion has given birth to all that is essential in
title: Elementary Forms

text: society, it is because the idea of society is the soul of religion.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Religious forces are therefore human forces, moral forces. It is true
title: Elementary Forms

text: that since collective sentiments can become conscious of themselves only
title: Elementary Forms

text: by fixing themselves upon external objects, they have not been able to
title: Elementary Forms

text: take form without adopting some of their characteristics from other
title: Elementary Forms

text: things: they have thus acquired a sort of physical nature; in this way
title: Elementary Forms

text: they have come to mix themselves with the life of the material world,
title: Elementary Forms

text: and then have considered themselves capable of explaining what passes
title: Elementary Forms

text: there. But when they are considered only from this point of view and in
title: Elementary Forms

text: this role, only their most superficial aspect is seen. In reality, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: essential elements of which these collective sentiments are made have
title: Elementary Forms

text: been borrowed by the understanding. It ordinarily seems that they should
title: Elementary Forms

text: have a human character only when they are conceived under human
title: Elementary Forms

text: forms;[1305] but even the most impersonal and the most anonymous are
title: Elementary Forms

text: nothing else than objectified sentiments.
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is only by regarding religion from this angle that it is possible to
title: Elementary Forms

text: see its real significance. If we stick closely to appearances, rites
title: Elementary Forms

text: often give the effect of purely manual operations: they are anointings,
title: Elementary Forms

text: washings, meals. To consecrate something, it is put in contact with a
title: Elementary Forms

text: source of religious energy, just as to-day a body is put in contact with
title: Elementary Forms

text: a source of heat or electricity to warm or electrize it; the two
title: Elementary Forms

text: processes employed are not essentially different. Thus understood,
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious technique seems to be a sort of mystic mechanics. But these
title: Elementary Forms

text: material man[oe]uvres are only the external envelope under which the
title: Elementary Forms

text: mental operations are hidden. Finally, there is no question of
title: Elementary Forms

text: exercising a physical constraint upon blind and, incidentally, imaginary
title: Elementary Forms

text: forces, but rather of reaching individual consciousnesses, of giving
title: Elementary Forms

text: them a direction and of disciplining them. It is sometimes said that
title: Elementary Forms

text: inferior religions are materialistic. Such an expression is inexact. All
title: Elementary Forms

text: religions, even the crudest, are in a sense spiritualistic: for the
title: Elementary Forms

text: powers they put in play are before all spiritual, and also their
title: Elementary Forms

text: principal object is to act upon the moral life. Thus it is seen that
title: Elementary Forms

text: whatever has been done in the name of religion cannot have been done in
title: Elementary Forms

text: vain: for it is necessarily the society that did it, and it is humanity
title: Elementary Forms

text: that has reaped the fruits.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But, it is said, what society is it that has thus made the basis of
title: Elementary Forms

text: religion? Is it the real society, such as it is and acts before our very
title: Elementary Forms

text: eyes, with the legal and moral organization which it has laboriously
title: Elementary Forms

text: fashioned during the course of history? This is full of defects and
title: Elementary Forms

text: imperfections. In it, evil goes beside the good, injustice often reigns
title: Elementary Forms

text: supreme, and the truth is often obscured by error. How could anything so
title: Elementary Forms

text: crudely organized inspire the sentiments of love, the ardent enthusiasm
title: Elementary Forms

text: and the spirit of abnegation which all religions claim of their
title: Elementary Forms

text: followers? These perfect beings which are gods could not have taken
title: Elementary Forms

text: their traits from so mediocre, and sometimes even so base a reality.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But, on the other hand, does someone think of a perfect society, where
title: Elementary Forms

text: justice and truth would be sovereign, and from which evil in all its
title: Elementary Forms

text: forms would be banished for ever? No one would deny that this is in
title: Elementary Forms

text: close relations with the religious sentiment; for, they would say, it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: towards the realization of this that all religions strive. But that
title: Elementary Forms

text: society is not an empirical fact, definite and observable; it is a
title: Elementary Forms

text: fancy, a dream with which men have lightened their sufferings, but in

title: Elementary Forms

text: But, in the first place, things are arbitrarily simplified when religion
title: Elementary Forms

text: is seen only on its idealistic side: in its way, it is realistic. There
title: Elementary Forms

text: is no physical or moral ugliness, there are no vices or evils which do
title: Elementary Forms

text: not have a special divinity. There are gods of theft and trickery, of
title: Elementary Forms

text: lust and war, of sickness and of death. Christianity itself, howsoever
title: Elementary Forms

text: high the idea which it has made of the divinity may be, has been obliged
title: Elementary Forms

text: to give the spirit of evil a place in its mythology. Satan is an
title: Elementary Forms

text: essential piece of the Christian system; even if he is an impure being,
title: Elementary Forms

text: he is not a profane one. The anti-god, is a god, inferior and
title: Elementary Forms

text: subordinated, it is true, but nevertheless endowed with extended
title: Elementary Forms

text: powers; he is even the object of rites, at least of negative ones. Thus
title: Elementary Forms

text: religion, far from ignoring the real society and making abstraction of
title: Elementary Forms

text: it, is in its image; it reflects all its aspects, even the most vulgar
title: Elementary Forms

text: and the most repulsive. All is to be found there, and if in the majority
title: Elementary Forms

text: of cases we see the good victorious over evil, life over death, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: powers of light over the powers of darkness, it is because reality is
title: Elementary Forms

text: not otherwise. If the relation between these two contrary forces were
title: Elementary Forms

text: reversed, life would be impossible; but, as a matter of fact, it
title: Elementary Forms

text: maintains itself and even tends to develop.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But if, in the midst of these mythologies and theologies we see reality
title: Elementary Forms

text: clearly appearing, it is none the less true that it is found there only
title: Elementary Forms

text: in an enlarged, transformed and idealized form. In this respect, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: most primitive religions do not differ from the most recent and the most
title: Elementary Forms

text: refined. For example, we have seen how the Arunta place at the beginning
title: Elementary Forms

text: of time a mythical society whose organization exactly reproduces that
title: Elementary Forms

text: which still exists to-day; it includes the same clans and phratries, it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is under the same matrimonial rules and it practises the same rites. But
title: Elementary Forms

text: the personages who compose it are ideal beings, gifted with powers and
title: Elementary Forms

text: virtues to which common mortals cannot pretend. Their nature is not only
title: Elementary Forms

text: higher, but it is different, since it is at once animal and human. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: evil powers there undergo a similar metamorphosis: evil itself is, as it
title: Elementary Forms

text: were, made sublime and idealized. The question now raises itself of
title: Elementary Forms

text: whence this idealization comes.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Some reply that men have a natural faculty for idealizing, that is to
title: Elementary Forms

text: say, of substituting for the real world another different one, to which
title: Elementary Forms

text: they transport themselves by thought. But that is merely changing the
title: Elementary Forms

text: terms of the problem; it is not resolving it or even advancing it. This
title: Elementary Forms

text: systematic idealization is an essential characteristic of religions.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Explaining them by an innate power of idealization is simply replacing
title: Elementary Forms

text: one word by another which is the equivalent of the first; it is as if
title: Elementary Forms

text: they said that men have made religions because they have a religious
title: Elementary Forms

text: nature. Animals know only one world, the one which they perceive by
title: Elementary Forms

text: experience, internal as well as external. Men alone have the faculty of
title: Elementary Forms

text: conceiving the ideal, of adding something to the real. Now where does
title: Elementary Forms

text: this singular privilege come from? Before making it an initial fact or a
title: Elementary Forms

text: mysterious virtue which escapes science, we must be sure that it does
title: Elementary Forms

text: not depend upon empirically determinable conditions.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The explanation of religion which we have proposed has precisely this
title: Elementary Forms

text: advantage, that it gives an answer to this question. For our definition
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the sacred is that it is something added to and above the real: now
title: Elementary Forms

text: the ideal answers to this same definition; we cannot explain one without
title: Elementary Forms

text: explaining the other. In fact, we have seen that if collective life
title: Elementary Forms

text: awakens religious thought on reaching a certain degree of intensity, it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is because it brings about a state of effervescence which changes the
title: Elementary Forms

text: conditions of psychic activity. Vital energies are over-excited,
title: Elementary Forms

text: passions more active, sensations stronger; there are even some which are
title: Elementary Forms

text: produced only at this moment. A man does not recognize himself; he feels
title: Elementary Forms

text: himself transformed and consequently he transforms the environment which
title: Elementary Forms

text: surrounds him. In order to account for the very particular impressions
title: Elementary Forms

text: which he receives, he attributes to the things with which he is in most
title: Elementary Forms

text: direct contact properties which they have not, exceptional powers and
title: Elementary Forms

text: virtues which the objects of every-day experience do not possess. In a
title: Elementary Forms

text: word, above the real world where his profane life passes he has placed
title: Elementary Forms

text: another which, in one sense, does not exist except in thought, but to
title: Elementary Forms

text: which he attributes a higher sort of dignity than to the first. Thus,
title: Elementary Forms

text: from a double point of view it is an ideal world.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The formation of the ideal world is therefore not an irreducible fact
title: Elementary Forms

text: which escapes science; it depends upon conditions which observation can
title: Elementary Forms

text: touch; it is a natural product of social life. For a society to become
title: Elementary Forms

text: conscious of itself and maintain at the necessary degree of intensity
title: Elementary Forms

text: the sentiments which it thus attains, it must assemble and concentrate
title: Elementary Forms

text: itself. Now this concentration brings about an exaltation of the mental
title: Elementary Forms

text: life which takes form in a group of ideal conceptions where is portrayed
title: Elementary Forms

text: the new life thus awakened; they correspond to this new set of psychical
title: Elementary Forms

text: forces which is added to those which we have at our disposition for the
title: Elementary Forms

text: daily tasks of existence. A society can neither create itself nor
title: Elementary Forms

text: recreate itself without at the same time creating an ideal. This
title: Elementary Forms

text: creation is not a sort of work of supererogation for it, by which it
title: Elementary Forms

text: would complete itself, being already formed; it is the act by which it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is periodically made and remade. Therefore when some oppose the ideal
title: Elementary Forms

text: society to the real society, like two antagonists which would lead us in
title: Elementary Forms

text: opposite directions, they materialize and oppose abstractions. The ideal
title: Elementary Forms

text: society is not outside of the real society; it is a part of it. Far from
title: Elementary Forms

text: being divided between them as between two poles which mutually repel
title: Elementary Forms

text: each other, we cannot hold to one without holding to the other. For a
title: Elementary Forms

text: society is not made up merely of the mass of individuals who compose it,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the ground which they occupy, the things which they use and the
title: Elementary Forms

text: movements which they perform, but above all is the idea which it forms
title: Elementary Forms

text: of itself. It is undoubtedly true that it hesitates over the manner in
title: Elementary Forms

text: which it ought to conceive itself; it feels itself drawn in divergent
title: Elementary Forms

text: directions. But these conflicts which break forth are not between the
title: Elementary Forms

text: ideal and reality, but between two different ideals, that of yesterday
title: Elementary Forms

text: and that of to-day, that which has the authority of tradition and that
title: Elementary Forms

text: which has the hope of the future. There is surely a place for
title: Elementary Forms

text: investigating whence these ideals evolve; but whatever solution may be
title: Elementary Forms

text: given to this problem, it still remains that all passes in the world of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the ideal.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Thus the collective ideal which religion expresses is far from being due
title: Elementary Forms

text: to a vague innate power of the individual, but it is rather at the
title: Elementary Forms

text: school of collective life that the individual has learned to idealize.
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is in assimilating the ideals elaborated by society that he has
title: Elementary Forms

text: become capable of conceiving the ideal. It is society which, by leading
title: Elementary Forms

text: him within its sphere of action, has made him acquire the need of
title: Elementary Forms

text: raising himself above the world of experience and has at the same time
title: Elementary Forms

text: furnished him with the means of conceiving another. For society has
title: Elementary Forms

text: constructed this new world in constructing itself, since it is society
title: Elementary Forms

text: which this expresses. Thus both with the individual and in the group,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the faculty of idealizing has nothing mysterious about it. It is not a
title: Elementary Forms

text: sort of luxury which a man could get along without, but a condition of
title: Elementary Forms

text: his very existence. He could not be a social being, that is to say, he
title: Elementary Forms

text: could not be a man, if he had not acquired it. It is true that in
title: Elementary Forms

text: incarnating themselves in individuals, collective ideals tend to
title: Elementary Forms

text: individualize themselves. Each understands them after his own fashion
title: Elementary Forms

text: and marks them with his own stamp; he suppresses certain elements and
title: Elementary Forms

text: adds others. Thus the personal ideal disengages itself from the social
title: Elementary Forms

text: ideal in proportion as the individual personality develops itself and
title: Elementary Forms

text: becomes an autonomous source of action. But if we wish to understand
title: Elementary Forms

text: this aptitude, so singular in appearance, of living outside of reality,
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is enough to connect it with the social conditions upon which it
title: Elementary Forms

text: depends.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Therefore it is necessary to avoid seeing in this theory of religion a
title: Elementary Forms

text: simple restatement of historical materialism: that would be
title: Elementary Forms

text: misunderstanding our thought to an extreme degree. In showing that
title: Elementary Forms

text: religion is something essentially social, we do not mean to say that it
title: Elementary Forms

text: confines itself to translating into another language the material forms
title: Elementary Forms

text: of society and its immediate vital necessities. It is true that we take
title: Elementary Forms

text: it as evident that social life depends upon its material foundation and
title: Elementary Forms

text: bears its mark, just as the mental life of an individual depends upon
title: Elementary Forms

text: his nervous system and in fact his whole organism. But collective
title: Elementary Forms

text: consciousness is something more than a mere epiphenomenon of its
title: Elementary Forms

text: morphological basis, just as individual consciousness is something more
title: Elementary Forms

text: than a simple efflorescence of the nervous system. In order that the
title: Elementary Forms

text: former may appear, a synthesis _sui generis_ of particular
title: Elementary Forms

text: consciousnesses is required. Now this synthesis has the effect of
title: Elementary Forms

text: disengaging a whole world of sentiments, ideas and images which, once
title: Elementary Forms

text: born, obey laws all their own. They attract each other, repel each
title: Elementary Forms

text: other, unite, divide themselves, and multiply, though these combinations
title: Elementary Forms

text: are not commanded and necessitated by the condition of the underlying
title: Elementary Forms

text: reality. The life thus brought into being even enjoys so great an
title: Elementary Forms

text: independence that it sometimes indulges in manifestations with no
title: Elementary Forms

text: purpose or utility of any sort, for the mere pleasure of affirming
title: Elementary Forms

text: itself. We have shown that this is often precisely the case with ritual
title: Elementary Forms

text: activity and mythological thought.[1307]
title: Elementary Forms

text: But if religion is the product of social causes, how can we explain the
title: Elementary Forms

text: individual cult and the universalistic character of certain religions?
title: Elementary Forms

text: If it is born _in foro externo_, how has it been able to pass into the
title: Elementary Forms

text: inner conscience of the individual and penetrate there ever more and
title: Elementary Forms

text: more profoundly? If it is the work of definite and individualized
title: Elementary Forms

text: societies, how has it been able to detach itself from them, even to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: point of being conceived as something common to all humanity?
title: Elementary Forms

text: In the course of our studies, we have met with the germs of individual
title: Elementary Forms

text: religion and of religious cosmopolitanism, and we have seen how they
title: Elementary Forms

text: were formed; thus we possess the more general elements of the reply
title: Elementary Forms

text: which is to be given to this double question.
title: Elementary Forms

text: We have shown how the religious force which animates the clan
title: Elementary Forms

text: particularizes itself, by incarnating itself in particular
title: Elementary Forms

text: consciousnesses. Thus secondary sacred beings are formed; each
title: Elementary Forms

text: individual has his own, made in his own image, associated to his own
title: Elementary Forms

text: intimate life, bound up with his own destiny; it is the soul, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: individual totem, the protecting ancestor, etc. These beings are the
title: Elementary Forms

text: object of rites which the individual can celebrate by himself, outside
title: Elementary Forms

text: of any group; this is the first form of the individual cult. To be sure,
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is only a very rudimentary cult; but since the personality of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: individual is still only slightly marked, and but little value is
title: Elementary Forms

text: attributed to it, the cult which expresses it could hardly be expected
title: Elementary Forms

text: to be very highly developed as yet. But as individuals have
title: Elementary Forms

text: differentiated themselves more and more and the value of an individual
title: Elementary Forms

text: has increased, the corresponding cult has taken a relatively greater
title: Elementary Forms

text: place in the totality of the religious life and at the same time it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: more fully closed to outside influences.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Thus the existence of individual cults implies nothing which contradicts
title: Elementary Forms

text: or embarrasses the sociological interpretation of religion; for the
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious forces to which it addresses itself are only the
title: Elementary Forms

text: individualized forms of collective forces. Therefore, even when religion
title: Elementary Forms

text: seems to be entirely within the individual conscience, it is still in
title: Elementary Forms

text: society that it finds the living source from which it is nourished. We
title: Elementary Forms

text: are now able to appreciate the value of the radical individualism which
title: Elementary Forms

text: would make religion something purely individual: it misunderstands the
title: Elementary Forms

text: fundamental conditions of the religious life. If up to the present it
title: Elementary Forms

text: has remained in the stage of theoretical aspirations which have never
title: Elementary Forms

text: been realized, it is because it is unrealizable. A philosophy may well
title: Elementary Forms

text: be elaborated in the silence of the interior imagination, but not so a
title: Elementary Forms

text: faith. For before all else, a faith is warmth, life, enthusiasm, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: exaltation of the whole mental life, the raising of the individual above
title: Elementary Forms

text: himself. Now how could he add to the energies which he possesses without
title: Elementary Forms

text: going outside himself? How could he surpass himself merely by his own
title: Elementary Forms

text: forces? The only source of life at which we can morally reanimate
title: Elementary Forms

text: ourselves is that formed by the society of our fellow beings; the only
title: Elementary Forms

text: moral forces with which we can sustain and increase our own are those
title: Elementary Forms

text: which we get from others. Let us even admit that there really are beings
title: Elementary Forms

text: more or less analogous to those which the mythologies represent. In
title: Elementary Forms

text: order that they may exercise over souls the useful direction which is
title: Elementary Forms

text: their reason for existence, it is necessary that men believe in them.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Now these beliefs are active only when they are partaken by many. A man
title: Elementary Forms

text: cannot retain them any length of time by a purely personal effort; it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: not thus that they are born or that they are acquired; it is even
title: Elementary Forms

text: doubtful if they can be kept under these conditions. In fact, a man who
title: Elementary Forms

text: has a veritable faith feels an invincible need of spreading it:
title: Elementary Forms

text: therefore he leaves his isolation, approaches others and seeks to
title: Elementary Forms

text: convince them, and it is the ardour of the convictions which he arouses
title: Elementary Forms

text: that strengthens his own. It would quickly weaken if it remained alone.
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is the same with religious universalism as with this individualism.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Far from being an exclusive attribute of certain very great religions,
title: Elementary Forms

text: we have found it, not at the base, it is true, but at the summit of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Australian system. Bunjil, Daramulun or Baiame are not simple tribal
title: Elementary Forms

text: gods; each of them is recognized by a number of different tribes. In a
title: Elementary Forms

text: sense, their cult is international. This conception is therefore very
title: Elementary Forms

text: near to that found in the most recent theologies. So certain writers
title: Elementary Forms

text: have felt it their duty to deny its authenticity, howsoever
title: Elementary Forms

text: incontestable this may be.
title: Elementary Forms

text: And we have been able to show how this has been formed.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Neighbouring tribes of a similar civilization cannot fail to be in
title: Elementary Forms

text: constant relations with each other. All sorts of circumstances give an
title: Elementary Forms

text: occasion for it: besides commerce, which is still rudimentary, there are
title: Elementary Forms

text: marriages; these international marriages are very common in Australia.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In the course of these meetings, men naturally become conscious of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: moral relationship which united them. They have the same social
title: Elementary Forms

text: organization, the same division into phratries, clans and matrimonial
title: Elementary Forms

text: classes; they practise the same rites of initiation, or wholly similar
title: Elementary Forms

text: ones. Mutual loans and treaties result in reinforcing these spontaneous
title: Elementary Forms

text: resemblances. The gods to which these manifestly identical institutions
title: Elementary Forms

text: were attached could hardly have remained distinct in their minds.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Everything tended to bring them together and consequently, even
title: Elementary Forms

text: supposing that each tribe elaborated the notion independently, they must
title: Elementary Forms

text: necessarily have tended to confound themselves with each other. Also, it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is probable that it was in inter-tribal assemblies that they were first
title: Elementary Forms

text: conceived. For they are chiefly the gods of initiation, and in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: initiation ceremonies, the different tribes are usually represented. So
title: Elementary Forms

text: if sacred beings are formed which are connected with no geographically
title: Elementary Forms

text: determined society, that is not because they have an extra-social
title: Elementary Forms

text: origin. It is because there are other groups above these geographically
title: Elementary Forms

text: determined ones, whose contours are less clearly marked: they have no
title: Elementary Forms

text: fixed frontiers, but include all sorts of more or less neighbouring and
title: Elementary Forms

text: related tribes. The particular social life thus created tends to spread
title: Elementary Forms

text: itself over an area with no definite limits. Naturally the mythological
title: Elementary Forms

text: personages who correspond to it have the same character; their sphere of
title: Elementary Forms

text: influence is not limited; they go beyond the particular tribes and their
title: Elementary Forms

text: territory. They are the great international gods.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Now there is nothing in this situation which is peculiar to Australian
title: Elementary Forms

text: societies. There is no people and no state which is not a part of
title: Elementary Forms

text: another society, more or less unlimited, which embraces all the peoples
title: Elementary Forms

text: and all the States with which the first comes in contact, either
title: Elementary Forms

text: directly or indirectly; there is no national life which is not dominated
title: Elementary Forms

text: by a collective life of an international nature. In proportion as we
title: Elementary Forms

text: advance in history, these international groups acquire a greater
title: Elementary Forms

text: importance and extent. Thus we see how, in certain cases, this
title: Elementary Forms

text: universalistic tendency has been able to develop itself to the point of
title: Elementary Forms

text: affecting not only the higher ideas of the religious system, but even
title: Elementary Forms

text: the principles upon which it rests.

text: Thus there is something eternal in religion which is destined to survive
title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

text: enveloped itself. There can be no society which does not feel the need
title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms
