text: which does not differ in nature from that employed by science; the
title: Elementary Forms

text: attempt is made by both to connect things with each other, to establish
title: Elementary Forms

text: internal relations between them, to classify them and to systematize
title: Elementary Forms

text: them. We have even seen that the essential ideas of scientific logic are
title: Elementary Forms

text: of religious origin. It is true that in order to utilize them, science
title: Elementary Forms

text: gives them a new elaboration; it purges them of all accidental elements;
title: Elementary Forms

text: in a general way, it brings a spirit of criticism into all its doings,
title: Elementary Forms

text: which religion ignores; it surrounds itself with precautions to "escape
title: Elementary Forms

text: precipitation and bias," and to hold aside the passions, prejudices and
title: Elementary Forms

text: all subjective influences. But these perfectionings of method are not
title: Elementary Forms

text: enough to differentiate it from religion. In this regard, both pursue
title: Elementary Forms

text: the same end; scientific thought is only a more perfect form of
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious thought. Thus it seems natural that the second should
title: Elementary Forms

text: progressively retire before the first, as this becomes better fitted to
title: Elementary Forms

text: perform the task.
title: Elementary Forms

text: And there is no doubt that this regression has taken place in the course
title: Elementary Forms

text: of history. Having left religion, science tends to substitute itself for
title: Elementary Forms

text: this latter in all that which concerns the cognitive and intellectual
title: Elementary Forms

text: functions. Christianity has already definitely consecrated this
title: Elementary Forms

text: substitution in the order of material things. Seeing in matter that
title: Elementary Forms

text: which is profane before all else, it readily left the knowledge of this
title: Elementary Forms

text: to another discipline, _tradidit mundum hominum disputationi_, "He gave
title: Elementary Forms

text: the world over to the disputes of men"; it is thus that the natural
title: Elementary Forms

text: sciences have been able to establish themselves and make their authority
title: Elementary Forms

text: recognized without very great difficulty. But it could not give up the
title: Elementary Forms

text: world of souls so easily; for it is before all over souls that the god
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the Christians aspires to reign. That is why the idea of submitting
title: Elementary Forms

text: the psychic life to science produced the effect of a sort of profanation
title: Elementary Forms

text: for a long time; even to-day it is repugnant to many minds. However,
title: Elementary Forms

text: experimental and comparative psychology is founded and to-day we must
title: Elementary Forms

text: reckon with it. But the world of the religious and moral life is still
title: Elementary Forms

text: forbidden. The great majority of men continue to believe that here there
title: Elementary Forms

text: is an order of things which the mind cannot penetrate except by very
title: Elementary Forms

text: special ways. Hence comes the active resistance which is met with every
title: Elementary Forms

text: time that someone tries to treat religious and moral phenomena
title: Elementary Forms

text: scientifically. But in spite of these oppositions, these attempts are
title: Elementary Forms

text: constantly repeated and this persistence even allows us to foresee that
title: Elementary Forms

text: this final barrier will finally give way and that science will establish
title: Elementary Forms

text: herself as mistress even in this reserved region.
title: Elementary Forms

text: That is what the conflict between science and religion really amounts
title: Elementary Forms

text: to. It is said that science denies religion in principle. But religion
title: Elementary Forms

text: exists; it is a system of given facts; in a word, it is a reality. How
title: Elementary Forms

text: could science deny this reality? Also, in so far as religion is action,
title: Elementary Forms

text: and in so far as it is a means of making men live, science could not
title: Elementary Forms

text: take its place, for even if this expresses life, it does not create it;
title: Elementary Forms

text: it may well seek to explain the faith, but by that very act it
title: Elementary Forms

text: presupposes it. Thus there is no conflict except upon one limited point.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Of the two functions which religion originally fulfilled, there is one,
title: Elementary Forms

text: and only one, which tends to escape it more and more: that is its
title: Elementary Forms

text: speculative function. That which science refuses to grant to religion is
title: Elementary Forms

text: not its right to exist, but its right to dogmatize upon the nature of
title: Elementary Forms

text: things and the special competence which it claims for itself for knowing
title: Elementary Forms

text: man and the world. As a matter of fact, it does not know itself. It does
title: Elementary Forms

text: not even know what it is made of, nor to what need it answers. It is
title: Elementary Forms

text: itself a subject for science, so far is it from being able to make the
title: Elementary Forms

text: law for science! And from another point of view, since there is no
title: Elementary Forms

text: proper subject for religious speculation outside that reality to which
title: Elementary Forms

text: scientific reflection is applied, it is evident that this former cannot
title: Elementary Forms

text: play the same role in the future that it has played in the past.
title: Elementary Forms

text: However, it seems destined to transform itself rather than to disappear.
title: Elementary Forms

text: We have said that there is something eternal in religion: it is the cult
title: Elementary Forms

text: and the faith. Men cannot celebrate ceremonies for which they see no
title: Elementary Forms

text: reason, nor can they accept a faith which they in no way understand. To
title: Elementary Forms

text: spread itself or merely to maintain itself, it must be justified, that
title: Elementary Forms

text: is to say, a theory must be made of it. A theory of this sort must
title: Elementary Forms

text: undoubtedly be founded upon the different sciences, from the moment
title: Elementary Forms

text: when these exist; first of all, upon the social sciences, for religious
title: Elementary Forms

text: faith has its origin in society; then upon psychology, for society is a
title: Elementary Forms

text: synthesis of human consciousnesses; and finally upon the sciences of
title: Elementary Forms

text: nature, for man and society are a part of the universe and can be
title: Elementary Forms

text: abstracted from it only artificially. But howsoever important these
title: Elementary Forms

text: facts taken from the constituted sciences may be, they are not enough;
title: Elementary Forms

text: for faith is before all else an impetus to action, while science, no
title: Elementary Forms

text: matter how far it may be pushed, always remains at a distance from this.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Science is fragmentary and incomplete; it advances but slowly and is
title: Elementary Forms

text: never finished; but life cannot wait. The theories which are destined to
title: Elementary Forms

text: make men live and act are therefore obliged to pass science and complete
title: Elementary Forms

text: it prematurely. They are possible only when the practical exigencies and
title: Elementary Forms

text: the vital necessities which we feel without distinctly conceiving them
title: Elementary Forms

text: push thought in advance, beyond that which science permits us to affirm.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Thus religions, even the most rational and laicized, cannot and never
title: Elementary Forms

text: will be able to dispense with a particular form of speculation which,
title: Elementary Forms

text: though having the same subjects as science itself, cannot be really
title: Elementary Forms

text: scientific: the obscure intuitions of sensation and sentiment too often
title: Elementary Forms

text: take the place of logical reasons. On one side, this speculation
title: Elementary Forms

text: resembles that which we meet with in the religions of the past; but on
title: Elementary Forms

text: another, it is different. While claiming and exercising the right of
title: Elementary Forms

text: going beyond science, it must commence by knowing this and by inspiring
title: Elementary Forms

text: itself with it. Ever since the authority of science was established, it
title: Elementary Forms

text: must be reckoned with; one can go farther than it under the pressure of
title: Elementary Forms

text: necessity, but he must take his direction from it. He can affirm nothing
title: Elementary Forms

text: that it denies, deny nothing that it affirms, and establish nothing that
title: Elementary Forms

text: is not directly or indirectly founded upon principles taken from it.
title: Elementary Forms

text: From now on, the faith no longer exercises the same hegemony as formerly
title: Elementary Forms

text: over the system of ideas that we may continue to call religion. A rival
title: Elementary Forms

text: power rises up before it which, being born of it, ever after submits it
title: Elementary Forms

text: to its criticism and control. And everything makes us foresee that this
title: Elementary Forms

text: control will constantly become more extended and efficient, while no
title: Elementary Forms

text: limit can be assigned to its future influence.
title: Elementary Forms

text: III
title: Elementary Forms

text: But if the fundamental notions of science are of a religious origin, how
title: Elementary Forms

text: has religion been able to bring them forth? At first sight, one does not
title: Elementary Forms

text: see what relations there can be between religion and logic. Or, since
title: Elementary Forms

text: the reality which religious thought expresses is society, the question
title: Elementary Forms

text: can be stated in the following terms, which make the entire difficulty
title: Elementary Forms

text: appear even better: what has been able to make social life so important
title: Elementary Forms

text: a source for the logical life? It seems as though nothing could have
title: Elementary Forms

text: predestined it to this role, for it certainly was not to satisfy their
title: Elementary Forms

text: speculative needs that men associated themselves together.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Perhaps we shall be found over bold in attempting so complex a question
title: Elementary Forms

text: here. To treat it as it should be treated, the sociological conditions
title: Elementary Forms

text: of knowledge should be known much better than they actually are; we are
title: Elementary Forms

text: only beginning to catch glimpses of some of them. However, the question
title: Elementary Forms

text: is so grave, and so directly implied in all that has preceded, that we
title: Elementary Forms

text: must make an effort not to leave it without an answer. Perhaps it is not
title: Elementary Forms

text: impossible, even at present, to state some general principles which may
title: Elementary Forms

text: at least aid in the solution.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Logical thought is made up of concepts. Seeking how society can have
title: Elementary Forms

text: played a role in the genesis of logical thought thus reduces itself to
title: Elementary Forms

text: seeking how it can have taken a part in the formation of concepts.
title: Elementary Forms

text: If, as is ordinarily the case, we see in the concept only a general
title: Elementary Forms

text: idea, the problem appears insoluble. By his own power, the individual
title: Elementary Forms

text: can compare his conceptions and images, disengage that which they have
title: Elementary Forms

text: in common, and thus, in a word, generalize. Then it is hard to see why
title: Elementary Forms

text: this generalization should be possible only in and through society. But,
title: Elementary Forms

text: in the first place, it is inadmissible that logical thought is
title: Elementary Forms

text: characterized only by the greater extension of the conceptions of which
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is made up. If particular ideas have nothing logical about them, why
title: Elementary Forms

text: should it be different with general ones? The general exists only in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: particular; it is the particular simplified and impoverished. Then the
title: Elementary Forms

text: first could have no virtues or privileges which the second has not.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Inversely, if conceptual thought can be applied to the class, species or
title: Elementary Forms

text: variety, howsoever restricted these may be, why can it not be extended
title: Elementary Forms

text: to the individual, that is to say, to the limit towards which the
title: Elementary Forms

text: conception tends, proportionately as its extension diminishes? As a
title: Elementary Forms

text: matter of fact, there are many concepts which have only individuals as
title: Elementary Forms

text: their object. In every sort of religion, gods are individualities
title: Elementary Forms

text: distinct from each other; however, they are conceived, not perceived.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Each people represents its historic or legendary heroes in fashions
title: Elementary Forms

text: which vary with the time. Finally, every one of us forms an idea of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: individuals with whom he comes in contact, of their character, of their
title: Elementary Forms

text: appearance, their distinctive traits and their moral and physical
title: Elementary Forms

text: temperaments: these notions, too, are real concepts. It is true that in
title: Elementary Forms

text: general they are formed crudely enough; but even among scientific
title: Elementary Forms

text: concepts, are there a great many that are perfectly adequate for their
title: Elementary Forms

text: object? In this direction, there are only differences of degree between
title: Elementary Forms

text: them.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Therefore the concept must be defined by other characteristics. It is
title: Elementary Forms

text: opposed to sensual representations of every order--sensations,
title: Elementary Forms

text: perceptions or images--by the following properties.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Sensual representations are in a perpetual flux; they come after each
title: Elementary Forms

text: other like the waves of a river, and even during the time that they
title: Elementary Forms

text: last, they do not remain the same thing. Each of them is an integral
title: Elementary Forms

text: part of the precise instant when it takes place. We are never sure of
title: Elementary Forms

text: again finding a perception such as we experienced it the first time; for
title: Elementary Forms

text: if the thing perceived has not changed, it is we who are no longer the
title: Elementary Forms

text: same. On the contrary, the concept is, as it were, outside of time and
title: Elementary Forms

text: change; it is in the depths below all this agitation; it might be said
title: Elementary Forms

text: that it is in a different portion of the mind, which is serener and
title: Elementary Forms

text: calmer. It does not move of itself, by an internal and spontaneous
title: Elementary Forms

text: evolution, but, on the contrary, it resists change. It is a manner of
title: Elementary Forms

text: thinking that, at every moment of time, is fixed and crystallized.[1308]
title: Elementary Forms

text: In so far as it is what it ought to be, it is immutable. If it changes,
title: Elementary Forms

text: it is not because it is its nature to do so, but because we have
title: Elementary Forms

text: discovered some imperfection in it; it is because it had to be
title: Elementary Forms

text: rectified. The system of concepts with which we think in everyday life
title: Elementary Forms

text: is that expressed by the vocabulary of our mother tongue; for every word
title: Elementary Forms

text: translates a concept. Now language is something fixed; it changes but
title: Elementary Forms

text: very slowly, and consequently it is the same with the conceptual system
title: Elementary Forms

text: which it expresses. The scholar finds himself in the same situation in
title: Elementary Forms

text: regard to the special terminology employed by the science to which he
title: Elementary Forms

text: has consecrated himself, and hence in regard to the special scheme of
title: Elementary Forms

text: concepts to which this terminology corresponds. It is true that he can
title: Elementary Forms

text: make innovations, but these are always a sort of violence done to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: established ways of thinking.
title: Elementary Forms

text: And at the same time that it is relatively immutable, the concept is
title: Elementary Forms

text: universal, or at least capable of becoming so. A concept is not my
title: Elementary Forms

text: concept; I hold it in common with other men, or, in any case, can
title: Elementary Forms

text: communicate it to them. It is impossible for me to make a sensation pass
title: Elementary Forms

text: from my consciousness into that of another; it holds closely to my
title: Elementary Forms

text: organism and personality and cannot be detached from them. All that I
title: Elementary Forms

text: can do is to invite others to place themselves before the same object as
title: Elementary Forms

text: myself and to leave themselves to its action. On the other hand,
title: Elementary Forms

text: conversation and all intellectual communication between men is an
title: Elementary Forms

text: exchange of concepts. The concept is an essentially impersonal
title: Elementary Forms

text: representation; it is through it that human intelligences
title: Elementary Forms

text: communicate.[1309]
title: Elementary Forms

text: The nature of the concept, thus defined, bespeaks its origin. If it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: common to all, it is the work of the community. Since it bears the mark
title: Elementary Forms

text: of no particular mind, it is clear that it was elaborated by a unique
title: Elementary Forms

text: intelligence, where all others meet each other, and after a fashion,
title: Elementary Forms

text: come to nourish themselves. If it has more stability than sensations or
title: Elementary Forms

text: images, it is because the collective representations are more stable
title: Elementary Forms

text: than the individual ones; for while an individual is conscious even of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the slight changes which take place in his environment, only events of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: greater gravity can succeed in affecting the mental status of a society.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Every time that we are in the presence of a _type_[1310] of thought or
title: Elementary Forms

text: action which is imposed uniformly upon particular wills or
title: Elementary Forms

text: intelligences, this pressure exercised over the individual betrays the
title: Elementary Forms

text: intervention of the group. Also, as we have already said, the concepts
title: Elementary Forms

text: with which we ordinarily think are those of our vocabulary. Now it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: unquestionable that language, and consequently the system of concepts
title: Elementary Forms

text: which it translates, is the product of a collective elaboration. What it
title: Elementary Forms

text: expresses is the manner in which society as a whole represents the facts
title: Elementary Forms

text: of experience. The ideas which correspond to the diverse elements of
title: Elementary Forms

text: language are thus collective representations.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Even their contents bear witness to the same fact. In fact, there are
title: Elementary Forms

text: scarcely any words among those which we usually employ whose meaning
title: Elementary Forms

text: does not pass, to a greater or less extent, the limits of our personal
title: Elementary Forms

text: experience. Very frequently a term expresses things which we have never
title: Elementary Forms

text: perceived or experiences which we have never had or of which we have
title: Elementary Forms

text: never been the witnesses. Even when we know some of the objects which it
title: Elementary Forms

text: concerns, it is only as particular examples that they serve to
title: Elementary Forms

text: illustrate the idea which they would never have been able to form by
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves. Thus there is a great deal of knowledge condensed in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: word which I never collected, and which is not individual; it even
title: Elementary Forms

text: surpasses me to such an extent that I cannot even completely appropriate
title: Elementary Forms

text: all its results. Which of us knows all the words of the language he
title: Elementary Forms

text: speaks and the entire signification of each?
title: Elementary Forms

text: This remark enables us to determine the sense in which we mean to say
title: Elementary Forms

text: that concepts are collective representations. If they belong to a whole
title: Elementary Forms

text: social group, it is not because they represent the average of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: corresponding individual representations; for in that case they would be
title: Elementary Forms

text: poorer than the latter in intellectual content, while, as a matter of
title: Elementary Forms

text: fact, they contain much that surpasses the knowledge of the average
title: Elementary Forms

text: individual. They are not abstractions which have a reality only in
title: Elementary Forms

text: particular consciousnesses, but they are as concrete representations as
title: Elementary Forms

text: an individual could form of his own personal environment: they
title: Elementary Forms

text: correspond to the way in which this very special being, society,
title: Elementary Forms

text: considers the things of its own proper experience. If, as a matter of
title: Elementary Forms

text: fact, the concepts are nearly always general ideas, and if they express
title: Elementary Forms

text: categories and classes rather than particular objects, it is because the
title: Elementary Forms

text: unique and variable characteristics of things interest society but
title: Elementary Forms

text: rarely; because of its very extent, it can scarcely be affected by more
title: Elementary Forms

text: than their general and permanent qualities. Therefore it is to this
title: Elementary Forms

text: aspect of affairs that it gives its attention: it is a part of its
title: Elementary Forms

text: nature to see things in large and under the aspect which they ordinarily
title: Elementary Forms

text: have. But this generality is not necessary for them, and, in any case,
title: Elementary Forms

text: even when these representations have the generic character which they
title: Elementary Forms

text: ordinarily have, they are the work of society and are enriched by its
title: Elementary Forms

text: experience.
title: Elementary Forms

text: That is what makes conceptual thought so valuable for us. If concepts
title: Elementary Forms

text: were only general ideas, they would not enrich knowledge a great deal,
title: Elementary Forms

text: for, as we have already pointed out, the general contains nothing more
title: Elementary Forms

text: than the particular. But if before all else they are collective
title: Elementary Forms

text: representations, they add to that which we can learn by our own personal
title: Elementary Forms

text: experience all that wisdom and science which the group has accumulated
title: Elementary Forms

text: in the course of centuries. Thinking by concepts, is not merely seeing
title: Elementary Forms

text: reality on its most general side, but it is projecting a light upon the
title: Elementary Forms

text: sensation which illuminates it, penetrates it and transforms it.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Conceiving something is both learning its essential elements better and
title: Elementary Forms

text: also locating it in its place; for each civilization has its organized
title: Elementary Forms

text: system of concepts which characterizes it. Before this scheme of ideas,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the individual is in the same situation as the [Greek: nous] of Plato
title: Elementary Forms

text: before the world of Ideas. He must assimilate them to himself, for he
title: Elementary Forms

text: must have them to hold intercourse with others; but the assimilation is
title: Elementary Forms

text: always imperfect. Each of us sees them after his own fashion. There are
title: Elementary Forms

text: some which escape us completely and remain outside of our circle of
title: Elementary Forms

text: vision; there are others of which we perceive certain aspects only.
title: Elementary Forms

text: There are even a great many which we pervert in holding, for as they are
title: Elementary Forms

text: collective by nature, they cannot become individualized without being
title: Elementary Forms

text: retouched, modified, and consequently falsified. Hence comes the great
title: Elementary Forms

text: trouble we have in understanding each other, and the fact that we even
title: Elementary Forms

text: lie to each other without wishing to: it is because we all use the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: words without giving them the same meaning.
title: Elementary Forms

text: We are now able to see what the part of society in the genesis of
title: Elementary Forms

text: logical thought is. This is possible only from the moment when, above
title: Elementary Forms

text: the fugitive conceptions which they owe to sensuous experience, men have
title: Elementary Forms

text: succeeded in conceiving a whole world of stable ideas, the common ground
title: Elementary Forms

text: of all intelligences. In fact, logical thinking is always impersonal
title: Elementary Forms

text: thinking, and is also thought _sub species aetrnitatis_--as though for
title: Elementary Forms

text: all time. Impersonality and stability are the two characteristics of
title: Elementary Forms

text: truth. Now logical life evidently presupposes that men know, at least
title: Elementary Forms

text: confusedly, that there is such a thing as truth, distinct from sensuous
title: Elementary Forms

text: appearances. But how have they been able to arrive at this conception?
title: Elementary Forms

text: We generally talk as though it should have spontaneously presented
title: Elementary Forms

text: itself to them from the moment they opened their eyes upon the world.
title: Elementary Forms

text: However, there is nothing in immediate experience which could suggest
title: Elementary Forms

text: it; everything even contradicts it. Thus the child and the animal have
title: Elementary Forms

text: no suspicion of it. History shows that it has taken centuries for it to
title: Elementary Forms

text: disengage and establish itself. In our Western world, it was with the
title: Elementary Forms

text: great thinkers of Greece that it first became clearly conscious of
title: Elementary Forms

text: itself and of the consequences which it implies; when the discovery was
title: Elementary Forms

text: made, it caused an amazement which Plato has translated into magnificent
title: Elementary Forms

text: language. But if it is only at this epoch that the idea is expressed in
title: Elementary Forms

text: philosophic formulae, it was necessarily pre-existent in the stage of an
title: Elementary Forms

text: obscure sentiment. Philosophers have sought to elucidate this sentiment,
title: Elementary Forms

text: but they have not succeeded. In order that they might reflect upon it
title: Elementary Forms

text: and analyse it, it was necessary that it be given them, and that they
title: Elementary Forms

text: seek to know whence it came, that is to say, in what experience it was
title: Elementary Forms

text: founded. This is in collective experience. It is under the form of
title: Elementary Forms

text: collective thought that impersonal thought is for the first time
title: Elementary Forms

text: revealed to humanity; we cannot see by what other way this revelation
title: Elementary Forms

text: could have been made. From the mere fact that society exists, there is
title: Elementary Forms

text: also, outside of the individual sensations and images, a whole system of
title: Elementary Forms

text: representations which enjoy marvellous properties. By means of them, men
title: Elementary Forms

text: understand each other and intelligences grasp each other. They have
title: Elementary Forms

text: within them a sort of force or moral ascendancy, in virtue of which they
title: Elementary Forms

text: impose themselves upon individual minds. Hence the individual at least
title: Elementary Forms

text: obscurely takes account of the fact that above his private ideas, there
title: Elementary Forms

text: is a world of absolute ideas according to which he must shape his own;
title: Elementary Forms

text: he catches a glimpse of a whole intellectual kingdom in which he
title: Elementary Forms

text: participates, but which is greater than he. This is the first intuition
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the realm of truth. From the moment when he first becomes conscious
title: Elementary Forms

text: of these higher ideas, he sets himself to scrutinizing their nature; he
title: Elementary Forms

text: asks whence these pre-eminent representations hold their prerogatives
title: Elementary Forms

text: and, in so far as he believes that he has discovered their causes, he
title: Elementary Forms

text: undertakes to put these causes into action for himself, in order that he
title: Elementary Forms

text: may draw from them by his own force the effects which they produce; that
title: Elementary Forms

text: is to say, he attributes to himself the right of making concepts. Thus
title: Elementary Forms

text: the faculty of conception has individualized itself. But to understand
title: Elementary Forms

text: its origins and function, it must be attached to the social conditions
title: Elementary Forms

text: upon which it depends.
title: Elementary Forms

text: It may be objected that we show the concept in one of its aspects only,
title: Elementary Forms

text: and that its unique role is not the assuring of a harmony among minds,
title: Elementary Forms

text: but also, and to a greater extent, their harmony with the nature of
title: Elementary Forms

text: things. It seems as though it had a reason for existence only on
title: Elementary Forms

text: condition of being true, that is to say, objective, and as though its
title: Elementary Forms

text: impersonality were only a consequence of its objectivity. It is in
title: Elementary Forms

text: regard to things, thought of as adequately as possible, that minds ought
title: Elementary Forms

text: to communicate. Nor do we deny that the evolution of concepts has been
title: Elementary Forms

text: partially in this direction. The concept which was first held as true
title: Elementary Forms

text: because it was collective tends to be no longer collective except on
title: Elementary Forms

text: condition of being held as true: we demand its credentials of it before
title: Elementary Forms

text: according it our confidence. But we must not lose sight of the fact that
title: Elementary Forms

text: even to-day the great majority of the concepts which we use are not
title: Elementary Forms

text: methodically constituted; we get them from language, that is to say,
title: Elementary Forms

text: from common experience, without submitting them to any criticism. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: scientifically elaborated and criticized concepts are always in the very
title: Elementary Forms

text: slight minority. Also, between them and those which draw all their
title: Elementary Forms

text: authority from the fact that they are collective, there are only
title: Elementary Forms

text: differences of degree. A collective representation presents guarantees
title: Elementary Forms

text: of objectivity by the fact that it is collective: for it is not without
title: Elementary Forms

text: sufficient reason that it has been able to generalize and maintain
title: Elementary Forms

text: itself with persistence. If it were out of accord with the nature of
title: Elementary Forms

text: things, it would never have been able to acquire an extended and
title: Elementary Forms

text: prolonged empire over intellects. At bottom, the confidence inspired by
title: Elementary Forms

text: scientific concepts is due to the fact that they can be methodically
title: Elementary Forms

text: controlled. But a collective representation is necessarily submitted to
title: Elementary Forms

text: a control that is repeated indefinitely; the men who accept it verify it
title: Elementary Forms

text: by their own experience. Therefore, it could not be wholly inadequate
title: Elementary Forms

text: for its subject. It is true that it may express this by means of
title: Elementary Forms

text: imperfect symbols; but scientific symbols themselves are never more than
title: Elementary Forms

text: approximative. It is precisely this principle which is at the basis of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the method which we follow in the study of religious phenomena: we take
title: Elementary Forms

text: it as an axiom that religious beliefs, howsoever strange their
title: Elementary Forms

text: appearance may be at times, contain a truth which must be
title: Elementary Forms

text: discovered.[1311]
title: Elementary Forms

text: On the other hand, it is not at all true that concepts, even when
title: Elementary Forms

text: constructed according to the rules of science, get their authority
title: Elementary Forms

text: uniquely from their objective value. It is not enough that they be true
title: Elementary Forms

text: to be believed. If they are not in harmony with the other beliefs and
title: Elementary Forms

text: opinions, or, in a word, with the mass of the other collective
title: Elementary Forms

text: representations, they will be denied; minds will be closed to them;
title: Elementary Forms

text: consequently it will be as though they did not exist. To-day it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: generally sufficient that they bear the stamp of science to receive a
title: Elementary Forms

text: sort of privileged credit, because we have faith in science. But this
title: Elementary Forms

text: faith does not differ essentially from religious faith. In the last
title: Elementary Forms

text: resort, the value which we attribute to science depends upon the idea
title: Elementary Forms

text: which we collectively form of its nature and role in life; that is as
title: Elementary Forms

text: much as to say that it expresses a state of public opinion. In all
title: Elementary Forms

text: social life, in fact, science rests upon opinion. It is undoubtedly true
title: Elementary Forms

text: that this opinion can be taken as the object of a study and a science
title: Elementary Forms

text: made of it; this is what sociology principally consists in. But the
title: Elementary Forms

text: science of opinion does not make opinions; it can only observe them and
title: Elementary Forms

text: make them more conscious of themselves. It is true that by this means it
title: Elementary Forms

text: can lead them to change, but science continues to be dependent upon
title: Elementary Forms

text: opinion at the very moment when it seems to be making its laws; for, as
title: Elementary Forms

text: we have already shown, it is from opinion that it holds the force
title: Elementary Forms

text: necessary to act upon opinion.[1312]
title: Elementary Forms

text: Saying that concepts express the manner in which society represents
title: Elementary Forms

text: things is also saying that conceptual thought is coeval with humanity
title: Elementary Forms

text: itself. We refuse to see in it the product of a more or less retarded
title: Elementary Forms

text: culture. A man who did not think with concepts would not be a man, for
title: Elementary Forms

text: he would not be a social being. If reduced to having only individual
title: Elementary Forms

text: perceptions, he would be indistinguishable from the beasts. If it has
title: Elementary Forms

text: been possible to sustain the contrary thesis, it is because concepts
title: Elementary Forms

text: have been defined by characteristics which are not essential to them.
title: Elementary Forms

text: They have been identified with general ideas[1313] and with clearly
title: Elementary Forms

text: limited and circumscribed general ideas.[1314] In these conditions it
title: Elementary Forms

text: has possibly seemed as though the inferior societies had no concepts
title: Elementary Forms

text: properly so called; for they have only rudimentary processes of
title: Elementary Forms

text: generalization and the ideas which they use are not generally very well
title: Elementary Forms

text: defined. But the greater part of our concepts are equally indetermined;
title: Elementary Forms

text: we force ourselves to define them only in discussions or when doing
title: Elementary Forms

text: careful work. We have also seen that conceiving is not generalizing.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Thinking conceptually is not simply isolating and grouping together the
title: Elementary Forms

text: common characteristics of a certain number of objects; it is relating
title: Elementary Forms

text: the variable to the permanent, the individual to the social. And since
title: Elementary Forms

text: logical thought commences with the concept, it follows that it has
title: Elementary Forms

text: always existed; there is no period in history when men have lived in a
title: Elementary Forms

text: chronic confusion and contradiction. To be sure, we cannot insist too
title: Elementary Forms

text: much upon the different characteristics which logic presents at
title: Elementary Forms

text: different periods in history; it develops like the societies themselves.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But howsoever real these differences may be, they should not cause us to
title: Elementary Forms

text: neglect the similarities, which are no less essential.
title: Elementary Forms

text: IV
title: Elementary Forms

text: We are now in a position to take up a final question which has already
title: Elementary Forms

text: been raised in our introduction[1315] and which has been taken as
title: Elementary Forms

text: understood in the remainder of this work. We have seen that at least
title: Elementary Forms

text: some of the categories are social things. The question is where they got
title: Elementary Forms

text: this character.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Undoubtedly it will be easily understood that since they are themselves
title: Elementary Forms

text: concepts, they are the work of the group. It can even be said that there
title: Elementary Forms

text: are no other concepts which present to an equal degree the signs by
title: Elementary Forms

text: which a collective representation is recognized. In fact, their
title: Elementary Forms

text: stability and impersonality are such that they have often passed as
title: Elementary Forms

text: being absolutely universal and immutable. Also, as they express the
title: Elementary Forms

text: fundamental conditions for an agreement between minds, it seems evident
title: Elementary Forms

text: that they have been elaborated by society.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But the problem concerning them is more complex, for they are social in
title: Elementary Forms

text: another sense and, as it were in the second degree. They not only come
title: Elementary Forms

text: from society, but the things which they express are of a social nature.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Not only is it society which has founded them, but their contents are
title: Elementary Forms

text: the different aspects of the social being: the category of class was at
title: Elementary Forms

text: first indistinct from the concept of the human group; it is the rhythm
title: Elementary Forms

text: of social life which is at the basis of the category of time; the
title: Elementary Forms

text: territory occupied by the society furnished the material for the
title: Elementary Forms

text: category of space; it is the collective force which was the prototype of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the concept of efficient force, an essential element in the category of
title: Elementary Forms

text: causality. However, the categories are not made to be applied only to
title: Elementary Forms

text: the social realm; they reach out to all reality. Then how is it that
title: Elementary Forms

text: they have taken from society the models upon which they have been
title: Elementary Forms

text: constructed?
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is because they are the pre-eminent concepts, which have a
title: Elementary Forms

text: preponderating part in our knowledge. In fact, the function of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: categories is to dominate and envelop all the other concepts: they are
title: Elementary Forms

text: permanent moulds for the mental life. Now for them to embrace such an
title: Elementary Forms

text: object, they must be founded upon a reality of equal amplitude.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Undoubtedly the relations which they express exist in an implicit way in
title: Elementary Forms

text: individual consciousnesses. The individual lives in time, and, as we
title: Elementary Forms

text: have said, he has a certain sense of temporal orientation. He is
title: Elementary Forms

text: situated at a determined point in space, and it has even been held, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: sustained with good reasons, that all sensations have something special
title: Elementary Forms

text: about them.[1316] He has a feeling of resemblances; similar
title: Elementary Forms

text: representations are brought together and the new representation formed
title: Elementary Forms

text: by their union has a sort of generic character. We also have the
title: Elementary Forms

text: sensation of a certain regularity in the order of the succession of
title: Elementary Forms

text: phenomena; even an animal is not incapable of this. However, all these
title: Elementary Forms

text: relations are strictly personal for the individual who recognizes them,
title: Elementary Forms

text: and consequently the notion of them which he may have can in no case go
title: Elementary Forms

text: beyond his own narrow horizon. The generic images which are formed in my
title: Elementary Forms

text: consciousness by the fusion of similar images represent only the objects
title: Elementary Forms

text: which I have perceived directly; there is nothing there which could give
title: Elementary Forms

text: me the idea of a class, that is to say, of a mould including the _whole_
title: Elementary Forms

text: group of all possible objects which satisfy the same condition. Also, it
title: Elementary Forms

text: would be necessary to have the idea of group in the first place, and the
title: Elementary Forms

text: mere observations of our interior life could never awaken that in us.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But, above all, there is no individual experience, howsoever extended
title: Elementary Forms

text: and prolonged it may be, which could give a suspicion of the existence
title: Elementary Forms

text: of a whole class which would embrace every single being, and to which
title: Elementary Forms

text: other classes are only co-ordinated or subordinated species. This idea
title: Elementary Forms

text: of _all_, which is at the basis of the classifications which we have
title: Elementary Forms

text: just cited, could not have come from the individual himself, who is only
title: Elementary Forms

text: a part in relation to the whole and who never attains more than an
title: Elementary Forms

text: infinitesimal fraction of reality. And yet there is perhaps no other
title: Elementary Forms

text: category of greater importance; for as the role of the categories is to
title: Elementary Forms

text: envelop all the other concepts, the category _par excellence_ would seem
title: Elementary Forms

text: to be this very concept of _totality_. The theorists of knowledge
title: Elementary Forms

text: ordinarily postulate it as if it came of itself, while it really
title: Elementary Forms

text: surpasses the contents of each individual consciousness taken alone to
title: Elementary Forms

text: an infinite degree.
title: Elementary Forms

text: For the same reasons, the space which I know by my senses, of which I am
title: Elementary Forms

text: the centre and where everything is disposed in relation to me, could not
title: Elementary Forms

text: be space in general, which contains all extensions and where these are
title: Elementary Forms

text: co-ordinated by personal guide-lines which are common to everybody. In
title: Elementary Forms

text: the same way, the concrete duration which I feel passing within me and
title: Elementary Forms

text: with me could not give me the idea of time in general: the first
title: Elementary Forms

text: expresses only the rhythm of my individual life; the second should
title: Elementary Forms

text: correspond to the rhythm of a life which is not that of any individual
title: Elementary Forms

text: in particular, but in which all participate.[1317] In the same way,
title: Elementary Forms

text: finally, the regularities which I am able to conceive in the manner in
title: Elementary Forms

text: which my sensations succeed one another may well have a value for me;
title: Elementary Forms

text: they explain how it comes about that when I am given the first of two
title: Elementary Forms

text: phenomena whose concurrence I have observed, I tend to expect the other.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But this personal state of expectation could not be confounded with the
title: Elementary Forms

text: conception of a universal order of succession which imposes itself upon
title: Elementary Forms

text: all minds and all events.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Since the world expressed by the entire system of concepts is the one
title: Elementary Forms

text: that society regards, society alone can furnish the most general notions
title: Elementary Forms

text: with which it should be represented. Such an object can be embraced only
title: Elementary Forms

text: by a subject which contains all the individual subjects within it. Since
title: Elementary Forms

text: the universe does not exist except in so far as it is thought of, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: since it is not completely thought of except by society, it takes a
title: Elementary Forms

text: place in this latter; it becomes a part of society's interior life,
title: Elementary Forms

text: while this is the totality, outside of which nothing exists. The concept
title: Elementary Forms

text: of totality is only the abstract form of the concept of society: it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: the whole which includes all things, the supreme class which embraces
title: Elementary Forms

text: all other classes. Such is the final principle upon which repose all
title: Elementary Forms

text: these primitive classifications where beings from every realm are placed
title: Elementary Forms

text: and classified in social forms, exactly like men.[1318] But if the world
title: Elementary Forms

text: is inside of society, the space which this latter occupies becomes
title: Elementary Forms

text: confounded with space in general. In fact, we have seen how each thing
title: Elementary Forms

text: has its assigned place in social space, and the degree to which this
title: Elementary Forms

text: space in general differs from the concrete expanses which we perceive is
title: Elementary Forms

text: well shown by the fact that this localization is wholly ideal and in no
title: Elementary Forms

text: way resembles what it would have been if it had been dictated to us by
title: Elementary Forms

text: sensuous experience alone.[1319] For the same reason, the rhythm of
title: Elementary Forms

text: collective life dominates and embraces the varied rhythms of all the
title: Elementary Forms

text: elementary lives from which it results; consequently the time which it
title: Elementary Forms

text: expresses dominates and embraces all particular durations. It is time in
title: Elementary Forms

text: general. For a long time the history of the world has been only another
title: Elementary Forms

text: aspect of the history of society. The one commences with the other; the
title: Elementary Forms

text: periods of the first are determined by the periods of the second. This
title: Elementary Forms

text: impersonal and total duration is measured, and the guide-lines in
title: Elementary Forms

text: relation to which it is divided and organized are fixed by the movements
title: Elementary Forms

text: of concentration or dispersion of society; or, more generally, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: periodical necessities for a collective renewal. If these critical
title: Elementary Forms

text: instants are generally attached to some material phenomenon, such as the
title: Elementary Forms

text: regular recurrence of such or such a star or the alternation of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: seasons, it is because objective signs are necessary to make this
title: Elementary Forms

text: essentially social organization intelligible to all. In the same way,
title: Elementary Forms

text: finally, the causal relation, from the moment when it is collectively
title: Elementary Forms

text: stated by the group, becomes independent of every individual
title: Elementary Forms

text: consciousness; it rises above all particular minds and events. It is a
title: Elementary Forms

text: law whose value depends upon no person. We have already shown how it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: clearly thus that it seems to have originated.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Another reason explains why the constituent elements of the categories
title: Elementary Forms

text: should have been taken from social life: it is because the relations
title: Elementary Forms

text: which they express could not have been learned except in and through
title: Elementary Forms

text: society. If they are in a sense immanent in the life of an individual,
title: Elementary Forms

text: he has neither a reason nor the means for learning them, reflecting upon
title: Elementary Forms

text: them and forming them into distinct ideas. In order to orient himself
title: Elementary Forms

text: personally in space and to know at what moments he should satisfy his
title: Elementary Forms

text: various organic needs, he has no need of making, once and for all, a
title: Elementary Forms

text: conceptual representation of time and space. Many animals are able to
title: Elementary Forms

text: find the road which leads to places with which they are familiar; they
title: Elementary Forms

text: come back at a proper moment without knowing any of the categories;
title: Elementary Forms

text: sensations are enough to direct them automatically. They would also be
title: Elementary Forms

text: enough for men, if their sensations had to satisfy only individual
title: Elementary Forms

text: needs. To recognize the fact that one thing resembles another which we
title: Elementary Forms

text: have already experienced, it is in no way necessary that we arrange them
title: Elementary Forms

text: all in groups and species: the way in which similar images call up each
title: Elementary Forms

text: other and unite is enough to give the feeling of resemblance. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: impression that a certain thing has already been seen or experienced
title: Elementary Forms

text: implies no classification. To recognize the things which we should seek
title: Elementary Forms

text: or from which we should flee, it would not be necessary to attach the
title: Elementary Forms

text: effects of the two to their causes by a logical bond, if individual
title: Elementary Forms

text: conveniences were the only ones in question. Purely empirical sequences
title: Elementary Forms

text: and strong connections between the concrete representations would be as
title: Elementary Forms

text: sure guides for the will. Not only is it true that the animal has no
title: Elementary Forms

text: others, but also our own personal conduct frequently supposes nothing
title: Elementary Forms

text: more. The prudent man is the one who has a very clear sensation of what
title: Elementary Forms

text: must be done, but which he would ordinarily be quite incapable of
title: Elementary Forms

text: stating as a general law.
title: Elementary Forms

text: It is a different matter with society. This is possible only when the
title: Elementary Forms

text: individuals and things which compose it are divided into certain groups,
title: Elementary Forms

text: that is to say, classified, and when these groups are classified in
title: Elementary Forms

text: relation to each other. Society supposes a self-conscious organization
title: Elementary Forms

text: which is nothing other than a classification. This organization of
title: Elementary Forms

text: society naturally extends itself to the place which this occupies. To
title: Elementary Forms

text: avoid all collisions, it is necessary that each particular group have a
title: Elementary Forms

text: determined portion of space assigned to it: in other terms, it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: necessary that space in general be divided, differentiated, arranged,
title: Elementary Forms

text: and that these divisions and arrangements be known to everybody. On the
title: Elementary Forms

text: other hand, every summons to a celebration, a hunt or a military
title: Elementary Forms

text: expedition implies fixed and established dates, and consequently that a
title: Elementary Forms

text: common time is agreed upon, which everybody conceives in the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: fashion. Finally, the co-operation of many persons with the same end in
title: Elementary Forms

text: view is possible only when they are in agreement as to the relation
title: Elementary Forms

text: which exists between this end and the means of attaining it, that is to
title: Elementary Forms

text: say, when the same causal relation is admitted by all the co-operators
title: Elementary Forms

text: in the enterprise. It is not surprising, therefore, that social time,
title: Elementary Forms

text: social space, social classes and causality should be the basis of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: corresponding categories, since it is under their social forms that
title: Elementary Forms

text: these different relations were first grasped with a certain clarity by
title: Elementary Forms

text: the human intellect.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In summing up, then, we must say that society is not at all the
title: Elementary Forms

text: illogical or a-logical, incoherent and fantastic being which it has too
title: Elementary Forms

text: often been considered. Quite on the contrary, the collective
title: Elementary Forms

text: consciousness is the highest form of the psychic life, since it is the
title: Elementary Forms

text: consciousness of the consciousnesses. Being placed outside of and above
title: Elementary Forms

text: individual and local contingencies, it sees things only in their
title: Elementary Forms

text: permanent and essential aspects, which it crystallizes into communicable
title: Elementary Forms

text: ideas. At the same time that it sees from above, it sees farther; at
title: Elementary Forms

text: every moment of time, it embraces all known reality; that is why it
title: Elementary Forms

text: alone can furnish the mind with the moulds which are applicable to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: totality of things and which make it possible to think of them. It does
title: Elementary Forms

text: not create these moulds artificially; it finds them within itself; it
title: Elementary Forms

text: does nothing but become conscious of them. They translate the ways of
title: Elementary Forms

text: being which are found in all the stages of reality but which appear in
title: Elementary Forms

text: their full clarity only at the summit, because the extreme complexity of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the psychic life which passes there necessitates a greater development
title: Elementary Forms

text: of consciousness. Attributing social origins to logical thought is not
title: Elementary Forms

text: debasing it or diminishing its value or reducing it to nothing more than
title: Elementary Forms

text: a system of artificial combinations; on the contrary, it is relating it
title: Elementary Forms

text: to a cause which implies it naturally. But this is not saying that the
title: Elementary Forms

text: ideas elaborated in this way are at once adequate for their object. If
title: Elementary Forms

text: society is something universal in relation to the individual, it is none
title: Elementary Forms

text: the less an individuality itself, which has its own personal physiognomy
title: Elementary Forms

text: and its idiosyncrasies; it is a particular subject and consequently
title: Elementary Forms

text: particularizes whatever it thinks of. Therefore collective
title: Elementary Forms

text: representations also contain subjective elements, and these must be
title: Elementary Forms

text: progressively rooted out, if we are to approach reality more closely.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But howsoever crude these may have been at the beginning, the fact
title: Elementary Forms

text: remains that with them the germ of a new mentality was given, to which
title: Elementary Forms

text: the individual could never have raised himself by his own efforts: by
title: Elementary Forms

text: them the way was opened to a stable, impersonal and organized thought
title: Elementary Forms

text: which then had nothing to do except to develop its nature.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Also, the causes which have determined this development do not seem to
title: Elementary Forms

text: be specifically different from those which gave it its initial impulse.
title: Elementary Forms

text: If logical thought tends to rid itself more and more of the subjective
title: Elementary Forms

text: and personal elements which it still retains from its origin, it is not
title: Elementary Forms

text: because extra-social factors have intervened; it is much rather because
title: Elementary Forms

text: a social life of a new sort is developing. It is this international life
title: Elementary Forms

text: which has already resulted in universalizing religious beliefs. As it
title: Elementary Forms

text: extends, the collective horizon enlarges; the society ceases to appear
title: Elementary Forms

text: as the only whole, to become a part of a much vaster one, with
title: Elementary Forms

text: indetermined frontiers, which is susceptible of advancing indefinitely.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Consequently things can no longer be contained in the social moulds
title: Elementary Forms

text: according to which they were primitively classified; they must be
title: Elementary Forms

text: organized according to principles which are their own, so logical
title: Elementary Forms

text: organization differentiates itself from the social organization and
title: Elementary Forms

text: becomes autonomous. Really and truly human thought is not a primitive
title: Elementary Forms

text: fact; it is the product of history; it is the ideal limit towards which
title: Elementary Forms

text: we are constantly approaching, but which in all probability we shall
title: Elementary Forms

text: never succeed in reaching.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Thus it is not at all true that between science on the one hand, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: morals and religion on the other, there exists that sort of antinomy
title: Elementary Forms

text: which has so frequently been admitted, for the two forms of human
title: Elementary Forms

text: activity really come from one and the same source. Kant understood this
title: Elementary Forms

text: very well, and therefore he made the speculative reason and the
title: Elementary Forms

text: practical reason two different aspects of the same faculty. According to
title: Elementary Forms

text: him, what makes their unity is the fact that the two are directed
title: Elementary Forms

text: towards the universal. Rational thinking is thinking according to the
title: Elementary Forms

text: laws which are imposed upon all reasonable beings; acting morally is
title: Elementary Forms

text: conducting one's self according to those maxims which can be extended
title: Elementary Forms

text: without contradiction to all wills. In other words, science and morals
title: Elementary Forms

text: imply that the individual is capable of raising himself above his own
title: Elementary Forms

text: peculiar point of view and of living an impersonal life. In fact, it
title: Elementary Forms

text: cannot be doubted that this is a trait common to all the higher forms of
title: Elementary Forms

text: thought and action. What Kant's system does not explain, however, is the
title: Elementary Forms

text: origin of this sort of contradiction which is realized in man. Why is he
title: Elementary Forms

text: forced to do violence to himself by leaving his individuality, and,
title: Elementary Forms

text: inversely, why is the impersonal law obliged to be dissipated by
title: Elementary Forms

text: incarnating itself in individuals? Is it answered that there are two
title: Elementary Forms

text: antagonistic worlds in which we participate equally, the world of matter
title: Elementary Forms

text: and sense on the one hand, and the world of pure and impersonal reason
title: Elementary Forms

text: on the other? That is merely repeating the question in slightly
title: Elementary Forms

text: different terms, for what we are trying to find out is why we must lead
title: Elementary Forms

text: these two existences at the same time. Why do these two worlds, which
title: Elementary Forms

text: seem to contradict each other, not remain outside of each other, and why
title: Elementary Forms

text: must they mutually penetrate one another in spite of their antagonism?
title: Elementary Forms

text: The only explanation which has ever been given of this singular
title: Elementary Forms

text: necessity is the hypothesis of the Fall, with all the difficulties which
title: Elementary Forms

text: it implies, and which need not be repeated here. On the other hand, all
title: Elementary Forms

text: mystery disappears the moment that it is recognized that impersonal
title: Elementary Forms

text: reason is only another name given to collective thought. For this is
title: Elementary Forms

text: possible only through a group of individuals; it supposes them, and in
title: Elementary Forms

text: their turn, they suppose it, for they can continue to exist only by
title: Elementary Forms

text: grouping themselves together. The kingdom of ends and impersonal truths
title: Elementary Forms

text: can realize itself only by the co-operation of particular wills, and the
title: Elementary Forms

text: reasons for which these participate in it are the same as those for
title: Elementary Forms

text: which they co-operate. In a word, there is something impersonal in us
title: Elementary Forms

text: because there is something social in all of us, and since social life
title: Elementary Forms

text: embraces at once both representations and practices, this impersonality
title: Elementary Forms

text: naturally extends to ideas as well as to acts.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Perhaps some will be surprised to see us connect the most elevated forms
title: Elementary Forms

text: of thought with society: the cause appears quite humble, in
title: Elementary Forms

text: consideration of the value which we attribute to the effect. Between the
title: Elementary Forms

text: world of the senses and appetites on the one hand, and that of reason
title: Elementary Forms

text: and morals on the other, the distance is so considerable that the second
title: Elementary Forms

text: would seem to have been able to add itself to the first only by a
title: Elementary Forms

text: creative act. But attributing to society this preponderating role in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: genesis of our nature is not denying this creation; for society has a
title: Elementary Forms

text: creative power which no other observable being can equal. In fact, all
title: Elementary Forms

text: creation, if not a mystical operation which escapes science and
title: Elementary Forms

text: knowledge, is the product of a synthesis. Now if the synthesis of
title: Elementary Forms

text: particular conceptions which take place in each individual consciousness
title: Elementary Forms

text: are already and of themselves productive of novelties, how much more
title: Elementary Forms

text: efficacious these vast syntheses of complete consciousnesses which make
title: Elementary Forms

text: society must be! A society is the most powerful combination of physical
title: Elementary Forms

text: and moral forces of which nature offers us an example. Nowhere else is
title: Elementary Forms

text: an equal richness of different materials, carried to such a degree of
title: Elementary Forms

text: concentration, to be found. Then it is not surprising that a higher life
title: Elementary Forms

text: disengages itself which, by reacting upon the elements of which it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: the product, raises them to a higher plane of existence and transforms
title: Elementary Forms

text: them.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Thus sociology appears destined to open a new way to the science of man.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Up to the present, thinkers were placed before this double alternative:
title: Elementary Forms

text: either explain the superior and specific faculties of men by connecting
title: Elementary Forms

text: them to the inferior forms of his being, the reason to the senses, or
title: Elementary Forms

text: the mind to matter, which is equivalent to denying their uniqueness; or
title: Elementary Forms

text: else attach them to some super-experimental reality which was
title: Elementary Forms

text: postulated, but whose existence could be established by no observation.
title: Elementary Forms

text: What put them in this difficulty was the fact that the individual passed
title: Elementary Forms

text: as being the _finis naturae_--the ultimate creation of nature; it seemed
title: Elementary Forms

text: that there was nothing beyond him, or at least nothing that science
title: Elementary Forms

text: could touch. But from the moment when it is recognized that above the
title: Elementary Forms

text: individual there is society, and that this is not a nominal being
title: Elementary Forms

text: created by reason, but a system of active forces, a new manner of
title: Elementary Forms

text: explaining men becomes possible. To conserve his distinctive traits it
title: Elementary Forms

text: is no longer necessary to put them outside experience. At least, before
title: Elementary Forms

text: going to this last extremity, it would be well to see if that which
title: Elementary Forms

text: surpasses the individual, though it is within him, does not come from
title: Elementary Forms

text: [1] In the same way, we shall say of these societies that they are
title: Elementary Forms

text: primitive, and we shall call the men of these societies primitives.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Undoubtedly the expression lacks precision, but that is hardly evitable,
title: Elementary Forms

text: and besides, when we have taken pains to fix the meaning, it is not
title: Elementary Forms

text: inconvenient.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [2] But that is not equivalent to saying that all luxury is lacking to
title: Elementary Forms

text: the primitive cults. On the contrary, we shall see that in every
title: Elementary Forms

text: religion there are beliefs and practices which do not aim at strictly
title: Elementary Forms

text: utilitarian ends (Bk. III, ch. iv, Sec. 2). This luxury is indispensable to
title: Elementary Forms

text: the religious life; it is at its very heart. But it is much more
title: Elementary Forms

text: rudimentary in the inferior religions than in the others, so we are
title: Elementary Forms

text: better able to determine its reason for existence here.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [3] It is seen that we give a wholly relative sense to this word
title: Elementary Forms

text: "origins," just as to the word "primitive." By it we do not mean an
title: Elementary Forms

text: absolute beginning, but the most simple social condition that is
title: Elementary Forms

text: actually known or that beyond which we cannot go at present. When we
title: Elementary Forms

text: speak of the origins or of the commencement of religious history or
title: Elementary Forms

text: thought, it is in this sense that our statements should be understood.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [4] We say that time and space are categories because there is no
title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

text: see, Hamelin, _Essai sur les elements principaux de la representation_,
title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

text: [6] Thus we see all the difference which exists between the group of
title: Elementary Forms

text: sensations and images which serve to locate us in time, and the category
title: Elementary Forms

text: of time. The first are the summary of individual experiences, which are
title: Elementary Forms

text: of value only for the person who experienced them. But what the category
title: Elementary Forms

text: of time expresses is a time common to the group, a social time, so to
title: Elementary Forms

text: speak. In itself it is a veritable social institution. Also, it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: peculiar to man; animals have no representations of this sort.
title: Elementary Forms

text: This distinction between the category of time and the corresponding
title: Elementary Forms

text: sensations could be made equally well in regard to space or cause.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Perhaps this would aid in clearing up certain confusions which are
title: Elementary Forms

text: maintained by the controversies of which these questions are the
title: Elementary Forms

text: subject. We shall return to this point in the conclusion of the present
title: Elementary Forms

text: work (Sec. 4).

title: Elementary Forms

text: [15] Even in the theory of Spencer, it is by individual experience that
title: Elementary Forms

text: the categories are made. The only difference which there is in this
title: Elementary Forms

text: regard between ordinary empiricism and evolutionary empiricism is that
title: Elementary Forms

text: according to this latter, the results of individual experience are
title: Elementary Forms

text: accumulated by heredity. But this accumulation adds nothing essential to
title: Elementary Forms

text: them; no element enters into their composition which does not have its
title: Elementary Forms

text: origin in the experience of the individual. According to this theory,
title: Elementary Forms

text: also, the necessity with which the categories actually impose themselves
title: Elementary Forms

text: upon us is the product of an illusion and a superstitious prejudice,
title: Elementary Forms

text: strongly rooted in the organism, to be sure, but without foundation in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the nature of things.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [16] Perhaps some will be surprised that we do not define the apriorist
title: Elementary Forms

text: theory by the hypothesis of innateness. But this conception really plays
title: Elementary Forms

text: a secondary part in the doctrine. It is a simple way of stating the
title: Elementary Forms

text: impossibility of reducing rational knowledge to empirical data. Saying
title: Elementary Forms

text: that the former is innate is only a positive way of saying that it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: not the product of experience, such as it is ordinarily conceived.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [17] At least, in so far as there are any representations which are
title: Elementary Forms

text: individual and hence wholly empirical. But there are in fact probably
title: Elementary Forms

text: none where the two elements are not found closely united.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [18] This irreducibility must not be taken in any absolute sense. We do
title: Elementary Forms

text: not wish to say that there is nothing in the empirical representations
title: Elementary Forms

text: which shows rational ones, nor that there is nothing in the individual
title: Elementary Forms

text: which could be taken as a sign of social life. If experience were
title: Elementary Forms

text: completely separated from all that is rational, reason could not operate
title: Elementary Forms

text: upon it; in the same way, if the psychic nature of the individual were
title: Elementary Forms

text: absolutely opposed to the social life, society would be impossible. A
title: Elementary Forms

text: complete analysis of the categories should seek these germs of
title: Elementary Forms

text: rationality even in the individual consciousness. We shall have occasion
title: Elementary Forms

text: to come back to this point in our conclusion. All that we wish to
title: Elementary Forms

text: establish here is that between these indistinct germs of reason and the
title: Elementary Forms

text: reason properly so called, there is a difference comparable to that
title: Elementary Forms

text: which separates the properties of the mineral elements out of which a
title: Elementary Forms

text: living being is composed from the characteristic attributes of life
title: Elementary Forms

text: after this has once been constituted.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [19] It has frequently been remarked that social disturbances result in
title: Elementary Forms

text: multiplying mental disturbances. This is one more proof that logical
title: Elementary Forms

text: discipline is a special aspect of social discipline. The first gives way
title: Elementary Forms

text: as the second is weakened.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [20] There is an analogy between this logical necessity and moral
title: Elementary Forms

text: obligation but there is not an actual identity. To-day society treats
title: Elementary Forms

text: criminals in a different fashion than subjects whose intelligence only
title: Elementary Forms

text: is abnormal; that is a proof that the authority attached to logical
title: Elementary Forms

text: rules and that inherent in moral rules are not of the same nature, in
title: Elementary Forms

text: spite of certain similarities. They are two species of the same class.
title: Elementary Forms

text: It would be interesting to make a study on the nature and origin of this
title: Elementary Forms

text: difference, which is probably not primitive, for during a long time, the
title: Elementary Forms

text: public conscience has poorly distinguished between the deranged and the
title: Elementary Forms

text: delinquent. We confine ourselves to signalizing this question. By this
title: Elementary Forms

text: example, one may see the number of problems which are raised by the
title: Elementary Forms

text: analysis of these notions which generally pass as being elementary and
title: Elementary Forms

text: simple, but which are really of an extreme complexity.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [21] This question will be treated again in the conclusion of this work.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [22] The rationalism which is imminent in the sociological theory of
title: Elementary Forms

text: knowledge is thus midway between the classical empiricism and apriorism.
title: Elementary Forms

text: For the first, the categories are purely artificial constructions; for
title: Elementary Forms

text: the second, on the contrary, they are given by nature; for us, they are
title: Elementary Forms

text: in a sense a work of art, but of an art which imitates nature with a
title: Elementary Forms

text: perfection capable of increasing unlimitedly.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [23] For example, that which is at the foundation of the category of
title: Elementary Forms

text: time is the rhythm of social life; but if there is a rhythm in
title: Elementary Forms

text: collective life, one may rest assured that there is another in the life
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the individual, and more generally, in that of the universe. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: first is merely more marked and apparent than the others. In the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: way, we shall see that the notion of class is founded on that of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: human group. But if men form natural groups, it can be assumed that
title: Elementary Forms

text: among things there exists groups which are at once analogous and
title: Elementary Forms

text: different. Classes and species are natural groups of things.
title: Elementary Forms

text: If it seems to many minds that a social origin cannot be attributed to
title: Elementary Forms

text: the categories without depriving them of all speculative value, it is
title: Elementary Forms

text: because society is still too frequently regarded as something that is
title: Elementary Forms

text: not natural; hence it is concluded that the representations which
title: Elementary Forms

text: express it express nothing in nature. But the conclusion is not worth
title: Elementary Forms

text: more than the premise.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [24] This is how it is legitimate to compare the categories to tools;

title: Elementary Forms

text: [202] It is true that at the end and at the beginning there are some
title: Elementary Forms

text: general theories on totemism, which will be described and discussed
title: Elementary Forms

text: below. But these theories are relatively independent of the collection
title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms
