title: Elementary Forms

text: [206] It should be noted that in this connection, the more recent work,
title: Elementary Forms

text: _Totemism and Exogamy_, shows an important progress in the thought as
title: Elementary Forms

text: well as the method of Frazer. Every time that he describes the religious
title: Elementary Forms

text: or domestic institutions of a tribe, he sets himself to determine the
title: Elementary Forms

text: geographic and social conditions in which this tribe is placed.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Howsoever summary these analyses may be, they bear witness nevertheless
title: Elementary Forms

text: to a rupture with the old methods of the anthropological school.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [207] Undoubtedly we also consider that the principal object of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: science of religions is to find out what the religious nature of man
title: Elementary Forms

text: really consists in. However, as we do not regard it as a part of his
title: Elementary Forms

text: constitutional make-up, but rather as the product of social causes, we
title: Elementary Forms

text: consider it impossible to find it, if we leave aside his social
title: Elementary Forms

text: environment.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [208] We cannot repeat too frequently that the importance which we
title: Elementary Forms

text: attach to totemism is absolutely independent of whether it was ever
title: Elementary Forms

text: universal or not.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [209] This is the case with the phratries and matrimonial classes; on
title: Elementary Forms

text: this point, see Spencer and Gillen, _Northern Tribes_, ch. iii; Howitt,
title: Elementary Forms

text: _Native Tribes_, pp. 109 and 137-142; Thomas, _Kinship and Marriage in
title: Elementary Forms

text: Australia_, ch. vi and vii.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [210] _Division du Travail social_, 3rd ed., p. 150.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [211] It is to be understood that this is not always the case. It
title: Elementary Forms

text: frequently happens, as we have already said, that the simpler forms aid
title: Elementary Forms

text: to a better understanding of the more complex. On this point, there is
title: Elementary Forms

text: no rule of method which is applicable to every possible case.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [212] Thus the individual totemism of America will aid us in
title: Elementary Forms

text: understanding the function and importance of that in Australia. As the
title: Elementary Forms

text: latter is very rudimentary, it would probably have passed unobserved.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [213] Besides, there is not one unique type of totemism in America, but
title: Elementary Forms

text: several different species which must be distinguished.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [214] We shall leave this field only very exceptionally, and when a
title: Elementary Forms

text: particularly instructive comparison seems to us to impose itself.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [215] This is the definition given by Cicero: _Gentiles sunt qui inter
title: Elementary Forms

text: se eodem nomine sunt_ (_Top._ 6). (Those are of the same gens who have
title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

text: [216] It may be said in a general way that the clan is a family group,
title: Elementary Forms

text: where kinship results solely from a common name; it is in this sense
title: Elementary Forms

text: that the _gens_ is a clan. But the totemic clan is a particular sort of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the class thus constituted.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [217] In a certain sense, these bonds of solidarity extend even beyond
title: Elementary Forms

text: the frontiers of the tribe. When individuals of different tribes have
title: Elementary Forms

text: the same totem, they have peculiar duties towards each other. This fact
title: Elementary Forms

text: is expressly stated for certain tribes of North America (see Frazer,
title: Elementary Forms

text: _Totemism and Exogamy_, III, pp. 57, 81, 299, 356-357). The texts
title: Elementary Forms

text: relative to Australia are less explicit. However, it is probable that
title: Elementary Forms

text: the prohibition of marriage between members of a single totem is
title: Elementary Forms

text: international.

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

text: [238] As we indicated in the preceding chapter, totemism is at the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: time of interest for the question of religion and that of the family,
title: Elementary Forms

text: for the clan is a family. In the lower societies, these two problems are
title: Elementary Forms

text: very closely connected. But both are so complex that it is indispensable
title: Elementary Forms

text: to treat them separately. Also, the primitive family organization cannot
title: Elementary Forms

text: be understood before the primitive religious beliefs are known; for the
title: Elementary Forms

text: latter serve as the basis of the former. This is why it is necessary to
title: Elementary Forms

text: study totemism as a religion before studying the totemic clan as a
title: Elementary Forms

text: family group.

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

text: these tribes, except the Mara and the Anula, the transmission of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: totem in the paternal line is only a general rule, which has exceptions.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [241] According to Spencer and Gillen (Nat. Tr., pp. 123 ff.), the soul
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the ancestor becomes reincarnate in the body of the mother and
title: Elementary Forms

text: becomes the soul of the child; according to Strehlow (II, pp. 51 ff.),
title: Elementary Forms

text: the conception, though being the work of the ancestor, does not imply
title: Elementary Forms

text: any reincarnation; but in neither interpretation does the totem of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: child necessarily depend upon that of the parents.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [242] _Nat. Tr._, p. 133; Strehlow, II, p. 53.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [243] It is in large part the locality where the mother believes that
title: Elementary Forms

text: she conceived which determines the totem of the child. Each totem, as we
title: Elementary Forms

text: shall see, has its centre and the ancestors preferably frequent the
title: Elementary Forms

text: places serving as centres for their respective totems. The totem of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: child is therefore that which belongs to the place where the mother
title: Elementary Forms

text: believes that she conceived. As this should generally be in the vicinity
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the place which serves as totemic centre for her husband, the child
title: Elementary Forms

text: should generally follow the totem of his father. It is undoubtedly this
title: Elementary Forms

text: which explains why the greater part of the inhabitants of a given
title: Elementary Forms

text: locality belong to the same totem (_Nat. Tr._, p. 9).

title: Elementary Forms

text: [259] Nevertheless, some tribes are cited where the matrimonial classes
title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

text: [260] Perhaps the same explanation is applicable to certain other tribes
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the South-East and the East where, if we are to believe the informers
title: Elementary Forms

text: of Howitt, totems specially attached to each matrimonial class are to be
title: Elementary Forms

text: found. This is the case among the Wiradjuri, the Wakelbura and the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Bunta-Murra on the Bulloo River (Howitt, _Nat. Tr._, pp. 210, 221, 226).
title: Elementary Forms

text: However, the evidence collected is suspect, according to his own
title: Elementary Forms

text: admission. In fact, it appears from the lists which he has drawn up,
title: Elementary Forms

text: that many totems are found equally in the two classes of the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: phratry.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The explanation which we propose, after Frazer (_Totemism and Exogamy_,
title: Elementary Forms

text: pp. 531 ff.), raises one difficulty. In principle, each clan and
title: Elementary Forms

text: consequently each totem, is represented equally in the two classes of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: single phratry, since one of the classes is that of the children and the
title: Elementary Forms

text: other that of the parents from whom the former get their totems. So when
title: Elementary Forms

text: the clans disappeared, the totemic interdictions which survived should
title: Elementary Forms

text: have remained in both matrimonial classes, while in the actual cases
title: Elementary Forms

text: cited, each class has its own. Whence comes this differentiation? The
title: Elementary Forms

text: example of the Kaiabara (a tribe of southern Queensland) allows us to
title: Elementary Forms

text: see how it may have come about. In this tribe, the children have the
title: Elementary Forms

text: totem of their mother, but it is particularized by some distinctive
title: Elementary Forms

text: mark. If the mother has the black eagle-hawk as totem, the child has the
title: Elementary Forms

text: white eagle-hawk (Howitt, _Nat. Tr._, p. 229). This appears to be the
title: Elementary Forms

text: beginning of a tendency for the totems to differentiate themselves
title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

text: [378] This is the case among the Loritja (Strehlow, II, pp. 60, 61), the

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

text: phratry. Spencer and Gillen remark (p. 167, n.), that in this regard the

title: Elementary Forms

text: is true that in both cases the offer must come from the other phratry.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But when it is a question of the paternal totem, or the totem properly
title: Elementary Forms

text: so-called, this phratry is the one to which the totem does not belong;
title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

text: [386] Even among the Omaha, it is not certain that the interdictions of
title: Elementary Forms

text: contact, certain examples of which we have just cited, are really of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: totemic nature, for many of them have no direct connection with the
title: Elementary Forms

text: animal that serves as totem of the clan. Thus in the sub-clan of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Eagle, the characteristic interdiction is against touching the head of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: buffalo (Dorsey, _op. cit._, p. 239); in another sub-clan with the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: totem, they must not touch verdigris, charcoal, etc. (_ibid._, p. 245).
title: Elementary Forms

text: We do not mention other interdictions mentioned by Frazer, such as those
title: Elementary Forms

text: of naming or looking at the animal or plant, for it is still less
title: Elementary Forms

text: certain that they are of totemic origin, except perhaps for certain
title: Elementary Forms

text: facts observed among the Bechuana (_Totemism_, pp. 12-13). Frazer admits
title: Elementary Forms

text: too readily--and in this regard, he has imitators--that the prohibitions
title: Elementary Forms

text: against eating or touching an animal depend upon totemic beliefs.
title: Elementary Forms

text: However, there is one case in Australia, where the sight of the animal
title: Elementary Forms

text: seems to be forbidden. According to Strehlow (II, p. 59), among the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Arunta and the Loritja, a man who has the moon as totem must not look at
title: Elementary Forms

text: it very long, or he would be likely to die at the hand of an enemy. But
title: Elementary Forms

text: we believe that this is a unique case. We must not forget, also, that
title: Elementary Forms

text: astronomical totems were probably not primitive in Australia, so this
title: Elementary Forms

text: prohibition may be the product of a complex elaboration. This hypothesis
title: Elementary Forms

text: is confirmed by the fact that among the Euahlayi, looking at the moon is
title: Elementary Forms

text: forbidden to all mothers and children, no matter what their totems may
title: Elementary Forms

text: be (L. Parker, _The Euahlayi_, p. 53).

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

text: [397] It is thus that the Turtle clan of the Iroquois took form. A group
title: Elementary Forms

text: of turtles had been forced to leave the lake where they dwelt and seek
title: Elementary Forms

text: another home. One of them, which was larger than the others, stood this
title: Elementary Forms

text: exercise very badly owing to the heat. It made such violent efforts that
title: Elementary Forms

text: it got out of its shell. The process of transformation, being once
title: Elementary Forms

text: commenced, went on by itself and the turtle finally became a man who was
title: Elementary Forms

text: the ancestor of the clan (Erminnie A. Smith, _The Myths of the Iroquois,
title: Elementary Forms

text: IInd Report_, p. 77). The Crab clan of the Choctaw was formed in a
title: Elementary Forms

text: similar manner. Some men surprised a certain number of crabs that lived
title: Elementary Forms

text: in the neighbourhood, took them home with them, taught them to talk and
title: Elementary Forms

text: to walk, and finally adopted them into their society (Catlin, _North
title: Elementary Forms

text: American Indians_, II, p. 128).
title: Elementary Forms

text: [398] For example, here is a legend of the Tsimshian. In the course of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: hunt, an Indian met a black bear which took him to its home, and taught
title: Elementary Forms

text: him to catch salmon and build canoes. The man stayed with the bear for
title: Elementary Forms

text: two years, and then returned to his native village. But the people were
title: Elementary Forms

text: afraid of him, because he was just like a bear. He could not talk or eat
title: Elementary Forms

text: anything except raw food. Then he was rubbed with magic herbs and
title: Elementary Forms

text: gradually regained his original form. After that, whenever he was in
title: Elementary Forms

text: trouble, he called upon his bear friends, who came to aid him. He built
title: Elementary Forms

text: a house and painted a bear on the foundation. His sister made a blanket
title: Elementary Forms

text: for the dance, upon which a bear was designed. That is why the
title: Elementary Forms

text: descendants of this sister had the bear as their emblem (Boas,
title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

text: Columbia_, in _J.A.I._, 1905, XXXV, p. 150).
title: Elementary Forms

text: Thus we see the inconveniences in making this mystical relationship
title: Elementary Forms

text: between the man and the animal the distinctive characteristic of
title: Elementary Forms

text: totemism, as M. Van Gennep proposes (_Totemisme et methode comparative_,
title: Elementary Forms

text: in _Revue de l'histoire des religions_, Vol. LVIII, July, 1908, p. 55).
title: Elementary Forms

text: This relationship is a mythical representation of otherwise profound
title: Elementary Forms

text: facts; but it may be omitted without causing the disappearance of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: essential traits of totemism. Undoubtedly there are always close bonds
title: Elementary Forms

text: between the people of the clan and the totemic animal, but these are not
title: Elementary Forms

text: necessarily bonds of blood-relationship, though they are frequently
title: Elementary Forms

text: conceived in this form.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [468] However, there are certain tribes in Queensland where the things

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

text: [681] We hope that this analysis and those which follow will put an end
title: Elementary Forms

text: to an inexact interpretation of our thought, from which more than one
title: Elementary Forms

text: misunderstanding has resulted. Since we have made constraint the
title: Elementary Forms

text: _outward sign_ by which social facts can be the most easily recognized
title: Elementary Forms

text: and distinguished from the facts of individual psychology, it has been
title: Elementary Forms

text: assumed that according to our opinion, physical constraint is the
title: Elementary Forms

text: essential thing for social life. As a matter of fact, we have never
title: Elementary Forms

text: considered it more than the material and apparent expression of an
title: Elementary Forms

text: interior and profound fact which is wholly ideal: this is _moral
title: Elementary Forms

text: authority_. The problem of sociology--if we can speak of _a_
title: Elementary Forms

text: sociological problem--consists in seeking, among the different forms of
title: Elementary Forms

text: external constraint, the different sorts of moral authority
title: Elementary Forms

text: corresponding to them and in discovering the causes which have
title: Elementary Forms

text: determined these latter. The particular question which we are treating
title: Elementary Forms

text: in this present work has as its principal object, the discovery of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: form under which that particular variety of moral authority which is
title: Elementary Forms

text: inherent in all that is religious has been born, and out of what
title: Elementary Forms

text: elements it is made. It will be seen presently that even if we do make
title: Elementary Forms

text: social pressure one of the distinctive characteristics of sociological
title: Elementary Forms

text: phenomena, we do not mean to say that it is the only one. We shall show
title: Elementary Forms

text: another aspect of the collective life, nearly opposite to the preceding
title: Elementary Forms

text: one, but none the less real (see p. 212).

text: [716] Thus we see how erroneous those theories are which, like the

text: [741] There certainly was a time when the Gnanji women had souls, for a
title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

text: a soul. Moreover, it is possible to explain whence this absence of
title: Elementary Forms

text: reincarnation comes. Filiation among the Gnanji, after having been
title: Elementary Forms

text: uterine, is now in the paternal line: a mother no longer transmits her
title: Elementary Forms

text: totem to her child. So the woman no longer has any descendants to
title: Elementary Forms

text: perpetuate her; she is the _finis familiae suae_. To explain this
title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

text: [861] Even if we believe that religious and moral representations
title: Elementary Forms

text: constitute the essential elements of the idea of the soul, still we do
title: Elementary Forms

text: not mean to say that they are the only ones. Around this central nucleus
title: Elementary Forms

text: are grouped other states of consciousness having this same character,
title: Elementary Forms

text: though to a slighter degree. This is the case with all the superior
title: Elementary Forms

text: forms of the intellectual life, owing to the special price and dignity
title: Elementary Forms

text: attributed to them by society. When we devote our lives to science or
title: Elementary Forms

text: art, we feel that we are moving in a circle of things that are above
title: Elementary Forms

text: bodily sensations, as we shall have occasion to show more precisely in
title: Elementary Forms

text: our conclusion. This is why the highest functions of the intelligence
title: Elementary Forms

text: have always been considered specific manifestations of the soul. But
title: Elementary Forms

text: they would probably not have been enough to establish the idea of it.

text: [865] It may be objected perhaps that unity is the characteristic of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: personality, while the soul has always been conceived as multiple, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: as capable of dividing and subdividing itself almost to infinity. But we
title: Elementary Forms

text: know to-day that the unity of the person is also made up of parts and
title: Elementary Forms

text: that it, too, is capable of dividing and decomposing. Yet the notion of
title: Elementary Forms

text: personality does not vanish because of the fact that we no longer think
title: Elementary Forms

text: of it as a metaphysical and indivisible atom. It is the same with the
title: Elementary Forms

text: popular conceptions of personality which find their expression in the
title: Elementary Forms

text: idea of the soul. These show that men have always felt that the human
title: Elementary Forms

text: personality does not have that absolute unity attributed to it by
title: Elementary Forms

text: certain metaphysicians.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [866] For all this, we do not deny the importance of the individual
title: Elementary Forms

text: factor: this is explained from our point of view just as easily as its
title: Elementary Forms

text: contrary. If the essential element of the personality is the social part
title: Elementary Forms

text: of us, on the other hand there can be no social life unless distinct
title: Elementary Forms

text: individuals are associated, and this is richer the more numerous and
title: Elementary Forms

text: different from each other they are. So the individual factor is a
title: Elementary Forms

text: condition of the impersonal factor. And the contrary is no less true,
title: Elementary Forms

text: for society itself is an important source of individual differences (see
title: Elementary Forms

text: our _Division du travail social_, 3rd. ed., pp. 267 ff.).

text: [896] This close connection between the soul, the guardian genius and
title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

text: may leave it to warn the individual or to manifest its approbation when
title: Elementary Forms

text: he does well. So in one sense, it plays the role of a moral conscience.
title: Elementary Forms

text: However, its communications are not confined to the domain of moral
title: Elementary Forms

text: facts. It is called the younger brother of the soul, as the placenta is
title: Elementary Forms

text: called the younger brother of the child.... In war, it inspires the man
title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

text: [897] It still remains to be investigated how it comes that after a
title: Elementary Forms

text: certain moment in evolution, this duplication of the soul was made in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the form of an individual totem rather than of a protecting ancestor.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Perhaps this question has an ethnological rather than a sociological
title: Elementary Forms

text: interest. However, the manner in which this substitution was probably
title: Elementary Forms

text: effected may be represented as follows.
title: Elementary Forms

text: The individual totem commenced by playing a merely complimentary role.
title: Elementary Forms

text: Those individuals who wished to acquire powers superior to those
title: Elementary Forms

text: possessed by everybody, did not and could not content themselves with
title: Elementary Forms

text: the mere protection of the ancestor; so they began to look for another
title: Elementary Forms

text: assistant of the same sort. Thus it comes about that among the Euahlayi,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the magicians are the only ones who have or who can procure individual
title: Elementary Forms

text: totems. As each one has a collective totem in addition, he finds himself
title: Elementary Forms

text: having many souls. But there is nothing surprising in this plurality of
title: Elementary Forms

text: souls: it is the condition of a superior power.
title: Elementary Forms

text: But when collective totemism once begins to lose ground, and when the
title: Elementary Forms

text: conception of the protecting ancestor consequently begins to grow dim in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the mind, another method must be found for representing the double
title: Elementary Forms

text: nature of the soul, which is still felt. The resulting idea was that,
title: Elementary Forms

text: outside of the individual soul, there was another, charged with watching
title: Elementary Forms

text: over the first one. Since this protecting power was no longer
title: Elementary Forms

text: demonstrated by the very fact of birth, men found it natural to employ,
title: Elementary Forms

text: for its discovery, means analogous to those used by magicians to enter
title: Elementary Forms

text: into communion with the forces of whose aid they thus assured
title: Elementary Forms

text: themselves.

text: [1005] Many of the interdictions between sacred things can be traced
title: Elementary Forms

text: back, we think, to those between the sacred and the profane. This is the

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

text: that is how it becomes possible to prevent access to an object by a mere
title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

text: Men have this privilege almost to the exclusion of women (Roth cites one
title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

text: [1071] Spencer and Gillen, _Nat. Tr._, pp. 214 ff.--From this example we
title: Elementary Forms

text: see that the rites of initiation sometimes have all the characteristics
title: Elementary Forms

text: of hazing. In fact, hazing is a real social institution which arises
title: Elementary Forms

text: spontaneously every time that two groups, inequal in their moral and
title: Elementary Forms

text: social situation, come into intimate contact. In this case, the one
title: Elementary Forms

text: considering itself superior to the other resists the intrusion of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: new-comers; it reacts against them is such a way as to make them aware
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the superiority it feels. This reaction, which is produced
title: Elementary Forms

text: automatically and which takes the form of more or less grave cruelties
title: Elementary Forms

text: quite naturally, is also destined to shape the individuals for their new
title: Elementary Forms

text: existence and assimilate them into their new environment. So it is a
title: Elementary Forms

text: sort of initiation. Thus it is explained how the initiation, on its
title: Elementary Forms

text: side, takes the form of hazing. It is because the group of old men is
title: Elementary Forms

text: superior in religious and moral dignity to that of the young men, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: yet the first must assimilate the second. So all the conditions for
title: Elementary Forms

text: hazing are given.

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

text: [1185] We do not wish to say that there was ever a time when religion
title: Elementary Forms

text: existed without magic. Probably as religion took form, certain of its
title: Elementary Forms

text: principles were extended to non-religious relations, and it was thus
title: Elementary Forms

text: supplemented by a more or less developed magic. But if these two systems
title: Elementary Forms

text: of ideas and practices do not correspond to distinct historical phases,
title: Elementary Forms

text: they have a relation of definite derivation between them. This is all we
title: Elementary Forms

text: have sought to establish.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [1187] See above, pp. 203 f.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [1188] Of course animal societies do exist. However, the word does not
title: Elementary Forms

text: have exactly the same sense when applied to men and to animals. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: institution is a characteristic fact of human societies; but animals
title: Elementary Forms

text: have no institutions.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [1189] The conception of cause is not the same for a scholar and for a
title: Elementary Forms

text: man with no scientific culture. Also, many of our contemporaries
title: Elementary Forms

text: understand the principle of causality differently, as they apply it to
title: Elementary Forms

text: social facts and to physico-chemical facts. In the social order, men
title: Elementary Forms

text: frequently exhibit a conception of causality singularly like that which
title: Elementary Forms

text: was at the basis of magic for a long time. One might even ask if a
title: Elementary Forms

text: physicist and a biologist represent the causal relation in the same
title: Elementary Forms

text: fashion.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [1190] Of course these ceremonies are not followed by an alimentary
title: Elementary Forms

text: communion. According to Strehlow, they have another name, at least when
title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

text: [1191] Strehlow, III, p. 8.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [1192] The Warramunga are not the only ones among whom the Intichiuma
title: Elementary Forms

text: takes the form of a dramatic representation. It is also found among the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Tjingilli, the Umbaia, the Wulmala, the Walpari and even the Kaitish,
title: Elementary Forms

text: though in certain of its features the ritual of these latter resembles
title: Elementary Forms

text: that of the Arunta (_Nor. Tr._, p. 291, 309, 311, 317). If we take the
title: Elementary Forms

text: Warramunga as a type, it is because they have been studied the best by
title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

text: above, p. 353).

title: Elementary Forms

text: but to that of the Crow. This is because the Crow is supposed to be an
title: Elementary Forms

text: [1199] Strehlow himself recognizes this: "The totemic ancestor and his
title: Elementary Forms

text: descendant, who represents him (_der Darsteller_) are presented as one
title: Elementary Forms

text: in these sacred hymns." (III, p. 6). As this incontestable fact
title: Elementary Forms

text: contradicts the theory according to which ancestral souls do not
title: Elementary Forms

text: reincarnate themselves, Strehlow adds, it is true, in a note, that "in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the course of the ceremony there is no real incarnation of the ancestor
title: Elementary Forms

text: in the person who represents him." If Strehlow wishes to say that the
title: Elementary Forms

text: incarnation does not take place on the occasion of the ceremony, then
title: Elementary Forms

text: nothing is more certain. But if he means that there is no incarnation at
title: Elementary Forms

text: all, we do not understand how the officiant and the ancestor can be
title: Elementary Forms

text: confounded.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [1200] Perhaps this difference is partially due to the fact that among
title: Elementary Forms

text: the Warramunga each clan is thought to be descended from one single
title: Elementary Forms

text: ancestor about whom the legendary history of the clan centres. This is
title: Elementary Forms

text: the ancestor whom the rite commemorates; now the officiant need not be
title: Elementary Forms

text: descended from him. One might even ask if these mythical chiefs, who are
title: Elementary Forms

text: sorts of demigods, are submitted to reincarnation.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [1201] In this Intichiuma, three assistants represent ancestors "of a
title: Elementary Forms

text: considerable antiquity"; they play a real part (_Nat. Tr._, pp.
title: Elementary Forms

text: 181-182). It is true that Spencer and Gillen add that these are
title: Elementary Forms

text: ancestors posterior to the Alcheringa. Nevertheless, mythical personages
title: Elementary Forms

text: are represented in the course of the rite.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [1202] Sacred rocks and water-holes are not mentioned. The centre of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: ceremony is the image of an emu drawn on the ground, which can be made
title: Elementary Forms

text: anywhere.
title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

text: are of this type. The example of the white cockatoo, of which we spoke
title: Elementary Forms

text: above, proves that there are exceptions.

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

text: the Wollunqua represented to the native mind the idea of a dominant
title: Elementary Forms

text: totem" (_Nor. Tr._, p. 248).
title: Elementary Forms

text: [1207] One of the most solemn of these ceremonies is the one which we
title: Elementary Forms

text: have had occasion to describe above (p. 217), in the course of which an
title: Elementary Forms

text: image of the Wollunqua is designed on a sort of hillock which is then
title: Elementary Forms

text: torn to pieces in the midst of a general effervescence.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [1209] Here are the terms of Spencer and Gillen in the only passage in
title: Elementary Forms

text: which they speak of a possible connection between the Wollunqua and
title: Elementary Forms

text: rain. A few days after the rite about the hillock, "the old men say that
title: Elementary Forms

text: they have heard Wollunqua speak, that he was satisfied with what had
title: Elementary Forms

text: passed and that he was going to send rain. The reason for this prophecy
title: Elementary Forms

text: was that they, as well as ourselves, had heard thunder rolling at a
title: Elementary Forms

text: distance." To such a slight extent is the production of rain the
title: Elementary Forms

text: immediate object of the ceremony that they did not attribute it to
title: Elementary Forms

text: Wollunqua until several days later, and then after accidental
title: Elementary Forms

text: circumstances. Another fact shows how vague the ideas of the natives are
title: Elementary Forms

text: on this point. A few lines below, thunder is spoken of as a sign, not of
title: Elementary Forms

text: the Wollunqua's satisfaction, but of its discontent. In spite of these
title: Elementary Forms

text: prognostics, continue our authors, "the rain did not fall. But some days
title: Elementary Forms

text: later, they heard the thunder rolling in the distance again. The old men
title: Elementary Forms

text: said that the Wollunqua was grumbling because he was not contented" with
title: Elementary Forms

text: the way in which the rite had been celebrated. Thus a single phenomenon,
title: Elementary Forms

text: the noise of thunder, is sometimes interpreted as a sign of a favouring
title: Elementary Forms

text: disposition, and sometimes as a mark of evil intentions.
title: Elementary Forms

text: However, there is one detail of the ritual which, if we accept the
title: Elementary Forms

text: explanation of it proposed by Spencer and Gillen, is directly efficient.
title: Elementary Forms

text: According to them, the destruction of the hillock was intended to
title: Elementary Forms

text: frighten the Wollunqua and to prevent it, by magic constraint, from
title: Elementary Forms

text: leaving its retreat. But this interpretation seems very doubtful to us.
title: Elementary Forms

text: In fact, in the very case of which we were speaking, where it was
title: Elementary Forms

text: announced that the Wollunqua was dissatisfied, this dissatisfaction was
title: Elementary Forms

text: attributed to the fact that they had neglected to take away the debris
title: Elementary Forms

text: of the hillock. So this removal is demanded by the Wollunqua itself, and
title: Elementary Forms

text: in no way intended to intimidate it and exercise a coercive influence
title: Elementary Forms

text: over it. This is probably merely one case of a more general rule which
title: Elementary Forms

text: is in force among the Warramunga: the instruments of the cult must be
title: Elementary Forms

text: destroyed after each ceremony. Thus the ritual ornamentations with which
title: Elementary Forms

text: the officiants are decorated are violently torn off from them when the
title: Elementary Forms

text: rite is terminated (_Nor. Tr._, p. 205).
title: Elementary Forms

text: [1222] Thus the exogamic rules must be violated in the course of certain
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious ceremonies (see above, p. 216, n. 1). A precise ritual meaning
title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

text: [1228] It cannot be otherwise. In fact, as the initiation is a tribal
title: Elementary Forms

text: feast, novices of different totems are initiated at the same time. So
title: Elementary Forms

text: the ceremonies which thus succeed one another in the same place have to
title: Elementary Forms

text: do with several totems, and, therefore, they must take place away from
title: Elementary Forms

text: the places with which they are connected by the myth.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [1229] It will now be understood why we have never studied the
title: Elementary Forms

text: initiation rites by themselves: it is because they are not a ritual
title: Elementary Forms

text: entity, but are formed by the conglomeration of rites of different
title: Elementary Forms

text: sorts. There are interdictions, ascetic rites and representative
title: Elementary Forms

text: ceremonies which cannot be distinguished from those celebrated at the
title: Elementary Forms

text: time of the Intichiuma. So we had to dismember this composite system and
title: Elementary Forms

text: treat each of the different rites composing it separately, classifying
title: Elementary Forms

text: them with the similar rites to which they are to be related. We have
title: Elementary Forms

text: also seen (pp. 285 ff.) that the initiation has served as the point of
title: Elementary Forms

text: departure for a new religion which tends to surpass totemism. But it has
title: Elementary Forms

text: been sufficient for us to show that totemism contained the germs of this
title: Elementary Forms

text: religion; we have had no need of following out its development. The
title: Elementary Forms

text: object of this book is to study the elementary beliefs and practices; so
title: Elementary Forms

text: we must stop at the moment when they give birth to more complex forms.

text: [1267] It may be asked why repeated ceremonies are necessary to produce
title: Elementary Forms

text: the relief which follows upon mourning. The funeral ceremonies are
title: Elementary Forms

text: frequently very long; they include many operations which take place at
title: Elementary Forms

text: intervals during many months. Thus they prolong and support the moral
title: Elementary Forms

text: disturbance brought about by the death (cf. Hertz, _La Representation
title: Elementary Forms

text: collective de la mort_, in _Annee Sociol._, X, pp. 48 ff.). In a general
title: Elementary Forms

text: way, a death marks a grave change of condition which has extended and
title: Elementary Forms

text: enduring effects upon the group. It takes a long time to neutralize
title: Elementary Forms

text: these effects.

title: Elementary Forms

text: that the fact is unique and abnormal (_ibid._, p. 157), while Strehlow
title: Elementary Forms

text: energetically denies it (II, p. 79).
title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

text: [1298] Among the Hebrews, for example, they sprinkled the altar with the
title: Elementary Forms

text: blood of the expiatory victim (Lev. iv, 5 ff.); they burned the flesh
title: Elementary Forms

text: and used products of this combustion to make water of purification
title: Elementary Forms

text: (Numb. xix).
title: Elementary Forms

text: [1299] Taplin, _The Narrinyeri_, pp. 32-34. When two persons who have
title: Elementary Forms

text: thus exchanged their umbilical cords belong to different tribes, they
title: Elementary Forms

text: are used as inter-tribal messengers. In this case, the exchange of cords
title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

title: Elementary Forms

text: [1300] It is true that Smith did not admit the reality of these
title: Elementary Forms

text: substitutions and transformations. According to him, if the expiatory
title: Elementary Forms

text: victim served to purify, it was because it had nothing impure in itself.
title: Elementary Forms

text: At first, it was a holy thing; it was destined to re-establish, by means
title: Elementary Forms

text: of a communion, the bonds of kinship uniting the worshipper to his god,
title: Elementary Forms

text: when a ritual fault had strained or broken them. An exceptionally holy
title: Elementary Forms

text: animal was chosen for this operation in order that the communion might
title: Elementary Forms

text: be as efficacious as possible, and efface the effects of the fault as
title: Elementary Forms

text: completely as possible. It was only when they no longer understood the
title: Elementary Forms

text: meaning of the rite that the sacrosanct animal was considered impure
title: Elementary Forms

text: (_op. cit._, pp. 347 ff.). But it is inadmissible that beliefs and
title: Elementary Forms

text: practices as universal as these, which we find at the foundation of the
title: Elementary Forms

text: expiatory sacrifice, should be the product of a mere error of
title: Elementary Forms

text: interpretation. In fact, we cannot doubt that the expiatory victim was
title: Elementary Forms

text: charged with the impurity of the sin. We have shown, moreover, that
title: Elementary Forms

text: these transformations of the pure into the impure, or the contrary, are
title: Elementary Forms

text: to be found in the most inferior societies which we know.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [1301] William James, _The Varieties of Religious Experience_.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [1302] Quoted by James, _op. cit._, p. 20.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [1303] See above, pp. 230 ff.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [1304] Only one form of social activity has not yet been expressly
title: Elementary Forms

text: attached to religion: that is economic activity. Sometimes processes
title: Elementary Forms

text: that are derived from magic have, by that fact alone, an origin that is
title: Elementary Forms

text: indirectly religious. Also, economic value is a sort of power or
title: Elementary Forms

text: efficacy, and we know the religious origins of the idea of power. Also,
title: Elementary Forms

text: richness can confer _mana_; therefore it has it. Hence it is seen that
title: Elementary Forms

text: the ideas of economic value and of religious value are not without
title: Elementary Forms

text: connection. But the question of the nature of these connections has not
title: Elementary Forms

text: yet been studied.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [1305] It is for this reason that Frazer and even Preuss set impersonal
title: Elementary Forms

text: religious forces outside of, or at least on the threshold of religion,
title: Elementary Forms

text: to attach them to magic.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [1306] Boutroux, _Science et Religion_, pp. 206-207.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [1307] See above, pp. 379 ff. On this same question, see also our
title: Elementary Forms

text: article, "Representations individuelles et representations collectives,"
title: Elementary Forms

text: in the _Revue de Metaphysique_, May, 1898.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [1308] William James, _Principles of Psychology_, I, p. 464.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [1309] This universality of the concept should not be confused with its
title: Elementary Forms

text: generality: they are very different things. What we mean by universality
title: Elementary Forms

text: is the property which the concept has of being communicable to a number
title: Elementary Forms

text: of minds, and in principle, to all minds; but this communicability is
title: Elementary Forms

text: wholly independent of the degree of its extension. A concept which is
title: Elementary Forms

text: applied to only one object, and whose extension is consequently at the
title: Elementary Forms

text: minimum, can be the same for everybody: such is the case with the
title: Elementary Forms

text: concept of a deity.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [1310] It may be objected that frequently, as the mere effect of
title: Elementary Forms

text: repetition, ways of thinking and acting become fixed and crystallized in
title: Elementary Forms

text: the individual, in the form of habits which resist change. But a habit
title: Elementary Forms

text: is only a tendency to repeat an act or idea automatically every time
title: Elementary Forms

text: that the same circumstances appear; it does not at all imply that the
title: Elementary Forms

text: idea or act is in the form of an exemplary type, proposed to or imposed
title: Elementary Forms

text: upon the mind or will. It is only when a type of this sort is set up,
title: Elementary Forms

text: that is to say, when a rule or standard is established, that social
title: Elementary Forms

text: action can and should be presumed.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [1311] Thus we see how far it is from being true that a conception lacks
title: Elementary Forms

text: objective value merely because it has a social origin.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [1312] See also above, p. 208.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [1313] Levy-Bruhl, _Les fonctions mentales dans les societes
title: Elementary Forms

text: inferieures_, pp. 131-138.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [1315] See above, p. 18.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [1316] William James, _Principles of Psychology_, I, p. 134.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [1317] Men frequently speak of space and time as if they were only
title: Elementary Forms

text: concrete extent and duration, such as the individual consciousness can
title: Elementary Forms

text: feel, but enfeebled by abstraction. In reality, they are representations
title: Elementary Forms

text: of a wholly different sort, made out of other elements, according to a
title: Elementary Forms

text: different plan, and with equally different ends in view.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [1318] At bottom, the concept of totality, that of society and that of
title: Elementary Forms

text: divinity are very probably only different aspects of the same notion.
title: Elementary Forms

text: [1319] See our _Classifications primitives_, _loc. cit._, pp. 40 ff.
